 
 =[MASK]Homarus gammarus = 
 
 Homarus gammaru[MASK] , known as the[MASK]Europ[MASK]an lobster or co[MASK]mon lobster , is a species of clawed lobster from the eastern Atlantic [MASK]cean , Mediterranean Sea and parts of the Black Sea . It i[MASK] closely related to the Amer[MASK]can lobster , H. americanus . It may grow to a length of 60 cm ( 24 in ) and a mass of 6 ki[MASK]ograms ( 13 lb ) [MASK] and be[MASK]rs a conspicuous pair of claws . In life , the lobsters are blue , only becoming " [MASK]obster red " on cooking . Mating oc[MASK]urs in the summer , producing egg[MASK] which are carried by the females for up to a year before hatching i[MASK]to planktonic larvae . Homarus gammarus is a highly esteemed food , and is widely caught using lobster pots , mostly around the British Isles . 
 
 = = Description = = 
 
 Homarus gammarus is a large crustacean , with a body length up to 60 centimetres ( 24 in ) and weighing up to 5 – 6 kilograms ( 11 – 13 lb ) , although the lobsters caught in lobster pots are usually 23 – 38 cm ( 9 – 15 [MASK]n ) [MASK]ong and weigh 0 @.@ 7 – 2 @.@ 2 kg ( 1 @.@ 5 – 4 @.@ 9 lb )[MASK]. Like other crustaceans , lobsters hav[MASK] a hard exoskeleton which they must shed in order to grow , in a process called ecdysis ( moulting ) .[MASK]This may occur several times a year for young lobsters , but decreas[MASK]s to once every 1 – 2 years for larger animals . 
 The firs[MASK] pai[MASK] of pereiopods is armed with a lar[MASK]e , asymmetrical pair of claws . The larger one is the " crusher " , and has rounded nodules used for crushing prey ; the other [MASK]s the " cu[MASK]ter " , which has sharp inner edges , and is used for holding or tearing the prey . Usually , the left claw is the crusher , and [MASK]he right is the cutter . 
 The exoskeleton is generally blue above , with spots that[MASK]coalesce , and yell[MASK]w below . T[MASK]e red colour associated with [MASK]obsters only appears after cooking . This occurs because , in life , the red pigment[MASK]astaxanthin is bound to a p[MASK]otein complex , but the complex is broken up by [MASK]he heat of cooking , releas[MASK]ng the red pigment . 
 The closest relative of H. gammarus is the A[MASK]erican lobster [MASK] Homarus americanus . The two species are very similar , an[MASK] can be crossed artifici[MASK]lly , a[MASK]though hybrids a[MASK]e unlikely to occur in the wild [MASK]inc[MASK] their ranges do not overlap . The two species can be disting[MASK]ished by a number of characteristics : 
 [MASK]he rostrum of H. americanus bears one or more s[MASK]ines on the underside , [MASK]hich are lacking in[MASK]H. gamm[MASK]rus . 
 The spines on the claws of H. [MASK]mericanus are red or red[MASK]@-@ tipped , while those of H. gammarus are white or white @-@ tipped . 
 The underside of the claw of H. americanus is orange or red , while that of[MASK]H. gammar[MASK]s is creamy white or very [MASK]ale red . 
[MASK]
[MASK]= = Life cycle = = 
 
 Female H. gammarus reach sexual maturity when they have grown to a carapace[MASK]length of 80 –[MASK]85 millimetres ( 3 @.@ 1 – 3 @.@ [MASK] in ) , whereas males m[MASK]ture at a slightly s[MASK]aller size . Mating typically occurs in summer between a recently moulted female , whose sh[MASK]ll is therefore soft , and a hard @-@ shelled male . T[MASK]e female carries the eggs for up to 12 months , depending[MASK]on the temperature , attached t[MASK] her pleo[MASK]ods . Females ca[MASK]rying eggs are said to be " berried " and can be found throughout t[MASK]e year . 
 The eggs hatch at night , and the larvae swim to the water surface wh[MASK]re they drift with the [MASK]cean currents , prey[MASK]ng on zooplankton . This stage involves three moults and lasts for 15 – 35 days . After the third moult , [MASK]he juvenile takes on a form closer to the adult , and adopts a benthic lifestyle . The juveniles are rarely seen in [MASK]he wild , and are poo[MASK]ly[MASK]known , although they are known to be capable of digging extensive burrows . It is estim[MASK]ted [MASK]hat only 1 larva in every 20 @,@ 000 survives to the benthic phase . When they reach a carapace length of 15 mm ( 0 @.@ 59 in ) , the juveniles leave the[MASK]r burrows and start their adult lives . 
 
 = = Distributio[MASK] = = 
 
 Homarus gammarus is foun[MASK] across the no[MASK]th @-@ eastern Atlantic Ocean from northern Norway to the[MASK]Azores and Mor[MASK][MASK]co , not including the Baltic Sea . It is also present in most of the Mediterranean Sea , only mis[MASK]i[MASK]g from the section east of[MASK]Crete , and along only the north @-@ west coast of the Black Sea . The northernmost populatio[MASK]s are found in the Norwegian[MASK]fjords Tysfjorden and Nord[MASK]olda , inside the Arctic Circle . 
 The species can be divided into four genetically distinct populations , one widespread population , and three which have diverged [MASK]ue to small effective population sizes , possibly due to adaptation to the loc[MASK]l environme[MASK]t . The first of these is th[MASK] population of lobsters from northern Norway , which have been referred to as the " midnight @-@ sun lobster " . The popula[MASK]ions in the [MASK]editerranean Sea are distinct from those in the Atlantic Ocean . The last distinct population is found in the Netherlands : samples from the Oosterschelde were distinct from those collected in the Nor[MASK]h Sea or English Channel . 
 Attemp[MASK]s have been made to introduce H. gammarus to New Zealand[MASK], al[MASK]ngside other[MASK]European species such as the edible crab , Cancer pagurus . Between 190[MASK] and 1914 , one million lobster larvae were released from hatcheries in Dunedin , but the species did not become established there . 
 
 = = Ecology = = 
 
 Adult H. gamm[MASK]rus live[MASK]on the contin[MASK]n[MASK]al shelf at depths of 0 – 150 metres ( 0 [MASK] 492 ft ) , although[MASK]not normally deeper than 50 m ( 160 ft ) . They prefer hard substrates , such as rocks or hard mud , and live in holes or crevices , emerging at night to feed . 
 T[MASK]e diet of H. gammarus mostly consists of other benthic inverteb[MASK]ates . These include crabs , mollus[MASK]s , sea urchins , starfish an[MASK] polychaete worms . 
 The [MASK]hree clawed lobster spe[MASK]ies Homarus gammarus , H. americanus and Nephrops norvegicus are hosts to the three known [MASK]pecies of the [MASK]nimal phylum Cycliophora ; the species on H. gammarus has not been described . 
 Homarus gammarus is susceptible to the disease ga[MASK]fkaemia , caused by the bacterium Aerococcus viridan[MASK] . Alt[MASK]ough it is frequently found in American lobsters , the disease has only been seen in captive H. gammarus , where prior occupation of the tanks by H. americanus could not be ruled out . 
 
 = = Human consumption = = 
 
 Homarus gammarus is traditionally " highly esteemed " [MASK]s a foodstuff and was mentioned i[MASK] " The Crabfish " a seventeenth century En[MASK]lish folk song . It[MASK]may f[MASK]tch very high prices a[MASK]d may be sold fresh , frozen[MASK], canne[MASK] or powdered . Both the claws and the abd[MASK]men of H. gammarus contain " excellent " white meat , and most of[MASK]the contents of the cephalothorax are edible . The exceptions are the gastric mill and the " sand vein " ( gut ) . The price of H. gammarus is up to three[MASK]times higher than that of H. americanus , and the European species is [MASK]onsidered to have a better flavour . 
 Lobsters are mostly fished using lobster pots , although lines baited[MASK]with octopus or [MASK]uttlefish sometimes succeed in tempting them out[MASK], to allow them to be caught in a net or by hand [MASK] In 2008 , 4 @,@ 386 t of H. gammarus were caught across Europe [MASK]nd North Africa , of whi[MASK]h 3 @,@ 462 t ( 79 % ) was caught in the British Isles ( including the Channel Island[MASK] ) . The minimum landing size for H. gammarus is a carapace length of 87 mm ( 3 @.@ 4 in ) . 
 Aquacu[MASK]ture s[MASK][MASK]tems for H. gammarus are under development , and production[MASK]rates are still very[MASK]low . 
 
 = = Taxonomic history = = 
 
 Homarus gammarus was first given [MASK][MASK]binomial name by Carl Linnaeus in th[MASK] tenth edition of his Systema Naturae , published in 175[MASK] . That name was Cancer gammarus , since Linnaeu[MASK] ' concept of the genus Cancer at that time[MASK]in[MASK]lude[MASK] all large crustaceans . 
 H. gammarus is the type species of the genu[MASK] Homarus Weber , 1795 , as determi[MASK]ed by Direction 51 of the Internat[MASK]onal Commission on Zoological Nomenclature . Prior[MASK]to that direction , confusion a[MASK]ose because the species had been referred to by several different n[MASK]mes , inc[MASK]uding Astacus [MASK]arinus Fabricius ,[MASK]1775 and Homaru[MASK] vulgaris H. Milne @-@ Edwa[MASK]ds , 1837 , and also because Friedrich Weber 's description of the genus h[MASK]d been overlooked until rediscovered by Mary Rathbun , rendering any prior assignments of type species ( for Homarus H. Milne @-@ Edw[MASK]rds , 1837 ) invalid for Homarus Weber , 17[MASK]5 .[MASK]
 The type specimen of Homarus ga[MASK]marus was a lectotype selec[MASK]ed by Lipke Holthuis in 1974 . It came from 57 ° 53 ′ N 11 ° 32 ′ E , near Marstrand , Sweden ( 48 kilometres or 30 miles northwest of Gothenburg ) , but both it[MASK]and the paralectotypes have since been lost . 
 The common name fo[MASK] H. gammarus preferred by the Food an[MASK] Agricult[MASK]re Organiz[MASK]tion is " European lobster " [MASK] but the species is also widely known as the " common lobster " . 
 
 
 = Frank Headlam = 
 
 Air Vice Marshal Frank Headlam ,[MASK]CB , CBE ( 15 J[MASK]ly 1914 – 23 December 1976 ) was a senior commander i[MASK] the Royal Australian Air For[MASK][MASK] ( RAAF ) . Born and educated in Tasmania , he joined the RA[MASK]F as an air cadet in January 1934 . He specialised[MASK]in flying instruction a[MASK]d navigation before the outbreak of World War II . In April 1941 , he became commanding of[MASK]icer of No. 2 Squadron , which operated Lockheed[MASK]Hudsons . The squadron was deployed to Dutch Timor in December[MASK], and saw action against Japanese forces in the South West Pacific . A[MASK]ter returning to Australia in February 1942 , Headlam held staf[MASK] appointments and training commands , finishing the war a group captain . 
 Headlam served as Officer Commanding North @-@ Western Area in 1946 , and as Director of Training from 1947 to 1950 . In 1950 – 51 , during the Mala[MASK]an Emergenc[MASK] , he was stationed at Singapore as com[MASK]ander of No. 90 ( Composite ) Wing and , later , RAF Tengah . He twice served as acting Air[MASK]Member for Personnel , in 1957 and 1959 – 60 , receiving appointment as a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 1958 . [MASK]romot[MASK][MASK] air vice marshal , he successively held the positions of Air Offi[MASK]er Commanding ( AOC ) Operational Command in 1961 – 62 , AOC No. 224 Group RAF from 1962 to 1965 during the Indonesia – Malaysia Konfrontasi , Deputy Chief of the Air Staff in 1965 – 66 , and[MASK]AOC [MASK]upport Command in 1966 – 67 .[MASK]He was appointed a Companion of [MASK]he Order of the [MASK]ath in 1965 . Follow[MASK]ng a posting to London as Head of[MASK]the Australian Joint Services Staff from 1968 to[MASK]1971 , he retired from the Air Force and died in Mel[MASK]ourne five years later . 
 
 = = Early career = = 
 
 The son of [MASK]armers Malcolm and Hilda Headlam , Frank Headlam was born on 1[MASK] July 1914 in L[MASK]unceston , Tasmania . He was schooled at Clemes College , Hobart , and matriculated in 1932 . Against the wishes of his parents he joined the Royal Australian Air Force ( RAAF ) as an air cadet on 16 January 1934 . He underwent flying instruction with No. 1 Flying Training School ( FTS ) at RAAF Point Cook , Victoria , and was commissioned as a p[MASK]lot [MASK]fficer on 1 January 193[MASK] . 
 After completing a conversion course , Headlam was assigned to the Seaplane Squadron at Point Cook . No larger than a flight according [MASK]o [MASK]he official history of the pre @-@ war RAAF , Seaplane Squadron [MASK]as part of No. 1 FTS and operated Supermarine Southampton flying boats and de Havilland Gipsy Moth floatplanes , among other types . During this posting Headlam was promoted to flying officer , on 1 July 1935 , and wrote a paper on nati[MASK]nal defence in which he suggeste[MASK] that with " stro[MASK]g [MASK]ir forces[MASK], naval [MASK]orces ( including submarines ) , and[MASK]fixed defences , Australia may be made practically[MASK]invulnerable " . According to Air Force historian Alan Stephens , [MASK]his paper " in effect , defined th[MASK] ' anti @-@ lodgment ' concept which has been a pe[MASK]sistent feature of RAAF strategic thinking " . 
 Headlam completed a flying instructors course in July 1936 and joined the staff of N[MASK]. 1 FTS . He was promoted to flight lieutenant on 1 March 1937 . Commenci[MASK]g in[MASK]July 1938 , he was one of six students to take part in the RAAF 's first Long Specialist Navigation Course , run by Flight Lieutenants Bill Garing and Alister Murdoch at Point Cook . The course involved several epic training flights that attracted considerable media attention[MASK], including a twelve @-@ day , [MASK]0 @,@ 80[MASK] @-@ kilometre ( 6 @,@ [MASK]00 mi ) round @-@ A[MASK]stralia trip by three Avro Ansons , one of which was piloted by Headlam , in November . The [MASK]ollowing [MASK]onth , Headlam led the three Ansons on a six @-@ day journey back and forth over Central Australia . He subsequently passed the navigation cours[MASK] with a special distinction . On 27 January 1939 he was posted to[MASK]RAAF Station Laverton , Victoria , as a fl[MASK]ght commander . He served initially with No. 2 Squadron , before t[MASK]ansferring to No. 1 Squadron on 29 August . Both units operated Ansons . 
 
 = = World War II = = 
 
 Following the outbreak of World War II , No. 1 Squadron was engaged[MASK]in convoy escort and maritime reconnaissance duties off south @-@ eastern Aus[MASK]ralia . Headlam continued to serve with the squadron as a flight command[MASK]r until 15 January 1940 , when he was assigned to Headquarters Lavert[MASK]n as the station navigation officer . On 27 March he was posted to the staff o[MASK] RAAF Headquarters , Melbourne . He was promoted to squadron leader on 1 June 1940 . Two week[MASK] later he married Katherine Brid[MASK]e at S[MASK] Paul 's A[MASK]glican Church in Frankston ; the couple would have a son and a daughter . 
 Headlam was given command of No. 2 Squadron [MASK]t Laverton on 15 Apr[MASK]l 1941 , and raised to wi[MASK]g commander on 1 July . Equipped with Lockheed Hudsons , the squadron mainly conducted maritime patrols in southern waters until 5 December , when four of its aircraft were ordered to Darwin , Northern Territory , in response to fears of Japanese aggression in the Pacific . On 7 December , this detachment established itself[MASK]at Penfui , near Koepang in Dutch Timor[MASK], while No. [MASK] Squadron 's eight [MASK]emaining Hudsons were stationed at Darwin on standby . The following day , awa[MASK]e that Australia was now at war in the Pa[MASK]ific , one of the Penfui @-@ based Hudsons attacked the Japanese pearler Nanyo Maru , which was suspecte[MASK] of being a ra[MASK]io ship , and forced it aground . By 12 Dece[MASK]ber , Headlam had transferred to Penfui as commanding officer[MASK]of the base , as well as No. 2 Squad[MASK]on . 
 During January 1942 , No. 2 Squadron 's aircraft were dispersed at Penfui ,[MASK]Boeroe Island , and Darwin . The Penfui detachment attacked Japanese shipping ta[MASK]ing part in the i[MASK]vasion of Celebes . Two Hudsons s[MASK]ot down or damaged three Japanese floatplanes that att[MASK]cked them as they were bombing a transport ship on 11 January ; the next day b[MASK]th Hudsons were themselves shot do[MASK]n by Mitsubishi Zeros . Penfui was bombed by the Japanese for [MASK]he first time on 26 Janua[MASK]y 1942 , and attacked regularly thereafter , damaging some aircraft . The intact Hudsons were withdrawn to Darwin but Headlam and his staff remained at [MASK]enfui to enabl[MASK] the base to be used by aircraft during reconnaissance missions from Australia .[MASK]On 18 February , Headlam was ordered to evacuate all his personnel except a small party to demolish the airfield with assistance from Sparrow Force .[MASK]H[MASK] returned to Darwin the following day , just as the city experienced its first raid by the Japanese . Four of[MASK]No. [MASK] Squadron 's Hudsons were destr[MASK]yed in the attack ; the remainder were relocated to Daly Waters , where they continued to carry out reconnaissance and bomb[MASK]ng missions against Japanese targets in Timor . 
 Headlam r[MASK]ma[MASK]ned in Darwin as C[MASK]ntroller of Operations at Headquarters No[MASK]th @-@ Western Area Command until 12 Ma[MASK] 1942 ,[MASK]when he was posted to Nhill , Victoria , as commanding of[MASK]icer of No. 2 Air Navigation School , o[MASK]erating Ansons . N[MASK]. 97 ( Reserve ) Squadron was fo[MASK]med from the school 's personnel in June . On 20 July 1943 , Headlam took command of No. 2 Air O[MASK]server School ( AOS ) , also operating Ansons , at Mount Gambier , South Australia . He was promoted to group captain on 1 December 1943 [MASK] and was appointed the inaugural commanding officer of No. 3 AO[MASK] , operating Ansons and Fairey Battles out of Port Pirie , on 9 [MASK]ecember . After handing over command of No. 3 AOS , he co[MASK]menced studies at RAAF Staff School[MASK]in Mount Martha , Victo[MASK]ia , on 2 October 1944 . He was appoin[MASK]e[MASK] se[MASK]ior administrative staff officer at North @-@ Western Area Command on 12 [MASK]anuary 1945 . 
 
 = = Post @-@ w[MASK]r career = = 
 
 Headlam became Officer C[MASK]mmanding North @-@ Western Area in January 1946 . Posted to Britain at the end of the year , he at[MASK]ended the Royal Air Force Staff College , An[MASK]over , and served with RAAF Overseas Headquarters , London . On his[MASK]return to Australia , in November 1947 , he became Director of Training at RAAF Headquarters . In November 1950 , Headlam was appointe[MASK] [MASK]o take over command of No. 90 ( Composite ) Wing from Group Captain Paddy Heffernan . Headquartere[MASK] at RAF Changi , Singapore , No. [MASK]0 Wing controlled RAAF units operating during the Malayan Emergency : No. 1 ( Bomber ) Squadron , flying Avro Lincolns , and No. 38 ( Transport ) Squadron , flying Douglas C @-@ 47 Dakotas . Th[MASK] Lincolns conducted area bombing missio[MASK]s over communist @-@ held territory , as well as strikes against pinpoi[MASK]t targets . The Dakotas were tasked with courier flights , VI[MASK] transport and medical evacuations across South East As[MASK]a , and in Malaya wi[MASK]h airlifting troops and cargo , dropping supp[MASK]ies to friendly forces and despatching propaganda leaf[MASK]ets . Headlam was slightly[MASK]injured on 20 December , when a No. 38 Squadron Dakota he was [MASK]o @-@ piloting on a [MASK]upply drop crash @-@ landed at Kampong Aur in Pahang , following engine failure . In August 1951 he wa[MASK] named commander of RAF Tengah , Singapore , in addition to his post as commanding officer of No. 90 Wing . Headlam handed over command of No. 9[MASK] Wing in December 1951 . 
 On 19 February 1952 , Headlam became senior air s[MASK]aff officer ( SASO ) at Eastern Area Command in Penrith , New South Wales . During his term as SASO , the RA[MASK]F began re @-@ equipping with English El[MASK]ctric Canberra jet bombers and CAC [MASK]abre jet fighters . The Air Force also u[MASK]derwent a major organisational change , as it transitioned from a geographically based command @-@ and @-@ control system to one based on function , resulting in the establishm[MASK]nt of Home ( opera[MASK]ional ) , Training , and Maintenance Commands . E[MASK]stern Area Command , considered [MASK] de facto operational headquarters owing to the preponderance of combat units unde[MASK] it[MASK] co[MASK]trol ,[MASK]was reorganised as Home Command in October 1953 . Headlam was appointe[MASK] an Officer of the Order of the British Empire ( OBE ) in the 1954 New Year Honours for his " exceptional ability and d[MASK]votion to duty " . He was promoted to acting air commodore in May . [MASK]is appo[MASK]ntment as aide @-@ de @-@ camp to Queen Elizabeth II was announced on 7 October 1954 . 
 Headlam was promot[MASK]d to substantive air commod[MASK]re on 1 January 1955 . In November he was posted to RA[MASK]F Overseas Headquarters , London , and the foll[MASK]wing year undertook studies at the Imperial Defence College . Returning to Australia , he served [MASK]s acting Air Member for Personnel at the Department of Air[MASK], Canberra , from 19 March to 21 October [MASK]957 , between the terms of Air Vice Marshals Fred Scherger and Allan Wal[MASK]ers , and again from 24 [MASK]ugust 1959 to 28 March 1960 , betwee[MASK] the terms of Wal[MASK]ers and Air Vice M[MASK]rshal [MASK]ill Hely . In[MASK]this role Headlam occupied a seat on th[MASK] Air Board [MASK] the service '[MASK] controlling body that comprised its senior [MASK]fficers and was [MASK]haired by the Chief of the Air Staff . He was also on[MASK] of two RAAF repre[MASK]entatives to serve on a committee , chaired by businessman William John Allison , examining conditions of defence service ; the committee 's recommendat[MASK]ons led to a doubling of flight pay , among other improvements . Headlam 's oth[MASK]r positions at the Department of Air included Air Commodo[MASK]e Plans from October 1957 to January 1959 , a[MASK]d Director General Plans and Policy from January to August 1959 . The latter assig[MASK]ment put him in charge of the RAAF 's[MASK]Directorate of Intelligence . Headlam was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British E[MASK]pire ( CBE ) in the 1958 Queen 's Birthday Honours , gazetted on 3 June . In May 1960 he became ac[MASK]ing Deputy Chief of the Air Staff . 
 On 30 January 1961 , Headlam joined the staff of Operatio[MASK]al Command ( OPCOM ) , the successor organisation to Home Command , responsible for the direction of RAAF operational units . He took[MASK]over as Air Officer Commanding ( AOC ) OPCOM from Air Vice Marshal Val Hancock[MASK]in April . Headlam was promoted to air vi[MASK]e marshal on 29 May . On [MASK]7 July 1962 , he was posted to RAAF Base Butterworth[MASK], Malaya , and took up the appointment of AOC No. 224 Group RAF in Singapore one week later . He was succeeded as AOC OPCOM[MASK]by Air Vice Marshal Alister Murdoch . As AOC No. 224 Group , Headlam had overall respons[MASK]bilit[MASK] for [MASK]egional air defence and offensive air operatio[MASK]s du[MASK]ing the Brunei Rebellion in Dec[MASK]mber 1962 , and the subsequent Konfrontasi between Indonesia an[MASK] Malaysia that officially began the following month . Divorced from his first wife in 1956 , he married widowed social worker Vernon Spence at the Sydney [MASK]egistry office on 20 January 1964 . He handed over No. 224 Group to Air Vice Ma[MASK]shal Christopher Foxley @-@ Norris on 30 November . 
 Returning to Australia , Headlam became Deputy Chief of the Air Staff ( DCAS ) on 26 January 1965 . He was appointed a Companion of the Order of th[MASK] Bath ( CB ) " in recognition of disting[MASK]ished service in the Borneo Territories " on 22 June . His tenure as DCAS coincided with[MASK]the most significant rearmament program the Air Force had undertaken since World War II , and with [MASK]anpower shortages stemming from this expans[MASK]on and from Australia 's increasing involvement in the security of South East Asia . The first RAAF h[MASK]licopters we[MASK]e committed to the Vietnam War towards the end of his term , and he t[MASK]avelled [MASK]o Saigon with the Chief of the General Staff , Lieutenant General Sir[MASK]Jo[MASK]n Wilton , in March 1966 to plan the deployment[MASK]. The year before , Wilton had recommended [MASK]o Air [MASK]arshal Murdoch , the Chief of the Air Staff , that two Iroquois be sent to Vietnam for familiarisation purposes ; Murdoch had rebuffed Wi[MASK]ton , and the RAAF helicopter squadron was considered underprepared for its army co @-@ op[MASK]ration role wh[MASK]n it finally did deploy . Headlam succe[MASK]ded Air Vice Marshal Douglas Candy as AOC Support Command , Melbou[MASK]n[MASK] , on 8[MASK]August 1966 . Support Command had been formed in 1959 , by m[MASK]rging the RAAF 's former Training and Maint[MASK]nance Commands . On 1 January 1968 , Headlam was posted t[MASK] London as Head of the Australian Joint Services St[MASK]ff . He se[MASK]ved as a[MASK] Extra Gentleman U[MASK]her to the Queen from 17 Novem[MASK]er 1970 to 5 June 1971 . 
 
 = = Reti[MASK]ement = = 
 
 Returning to Australia in J[MASK]ne 1971 , Headl[MASK]m took resettlement leave before retiring from the Air Force on 3 Augu[MASK]t . He made his home in Melbourne , where he died [MASK]ged 62 on 23 December 1976 , after a lengthy battl[MASK] with cancer . Survived by his[MASK]ch[MASK]ld[MASK]en and his [MASK]econd wife , he was given a private funeral and cremated at Spr[MASK]ngvale Crematorium . 
 
 
 = M @-@ 82 ( Michigan highway ) = 
 
 M @-@ 82 is a state trunkline in the Lower Peninsula in the US state of Michigan that travels between Fremont and Howard City . The sec[MASK]ion between Newaygo and Howard City travels through Fremont and along [MASK]he sou[MASK]hern edge of Manistee[MASK]National Forest [MASK] The current version of M @-@ 82 is actu[MASK]lly the second in the state ; the first usage appeared in the Upper Peninsula by 1919 . [MASK]he Lower Peninsula ro[MASK]ting has been in u[MASK]e since the 1920s . Variou[MASK] exte[MASK]s[MASK]ons and truncations have s[MASK]ifted the term[MASK]nus as far west as New Er[MASK] or Hesperia in the past . The [MASK]urrent route was finalized in the late 1970s 
 
 = = Rou[MASK]e description = = 
 
 M @-@ 82 begins at a junction with M @-@ 120 and B @-@[MASK]96 west of Fremont . [MASK]his junction is at a tripoint of county lines . M @-@ 120 forms the north – sou[MASK]h Newaygo – Oceana and Newaygo – Muskegon county lines . B @-@ 96 , which forms the east – west Oceana – Muskegon county line runs due west of the intersec[MASK]ion . M @-@ 82 exits the intersection to the east . Th[MASK] h[MASK]ghway r[MASK]ns along 48th Stre[MASK][MASK] through rural farms into the community of Fremont . The road , now called Main Street , passes t[MASK]rough the downtown are[MASK] and M @-@ 82 tur[MASK]s sout[MASK] along Stewart Avenue out of town . The highway rounds a cu[MASK]ve and transitions t[MASK] 72nd Street running eastward throu[MASK]h more farm land . As the trunkline approaches Newaygo , the terrain becomes more wooded near the Muskegon River . M @-@ 82 follows Fremont Street east to a[MASK]junction with M @-@ 37 . The tw[MASK] [MASK]ighways merge and run concurrently over the river and into downtown on Sta[MASK]e Street . So[MASK]th of down[MASK]own , M @-@[MASK]82 turns east again , independent of M @-@ 37 , and runs along 82nd Street on t[MASK]e southern edge of the Manistee National[MASK]Forest . The east end of M @-@ 82 i[MASK] at exit 118 o[MASK] US 131 / M @-@ 46 west of Howard City . [MASK] The Michigan [MASK]e[MASK]artment of Transportation ( MDOT [MASK] , as a part of its maintenance resp[MASK]nsibilities ,[MASK]tracks the volu[MASK]e of traffic using its roadways . These levels are expressed in terms of a met[MASK]ic called average annual daily traffic ( [MASK]ADT[MASK]) , which is a calculation of the traffic along a segment of road for any a[MASK]erage day of the year . In 2009 ,[MASK]t[MASK]e department 's m[MASK]asurements indicated that a seg[MASK]ent of M @-@ 82 west of Fremont had the peak volume for the highway at 16 @,@ 532 vehicles daily . The traffic nadir was 4 @,@ 018 vehicles east of Newaygo . In addition , MDOT has not had[MASK]any section of the highw[MASK]y listed on the National Highway System , a network of roads im[MASK]ortant to the country 's econ[MASK]my , defense , and mobility . 
 
 = = [MASK]istory[MASK]= = 
 
 
 = = = Previou[MASK][MASK]designation = = = 
 
 The first usage of M[MASK][MASK]-@ 82 wa[MASK] in the Upper Peninsula by Jul[MASK] 1 , 1919 .[MASK]The trunkline start[MASK]d at M @-@ 25 and ran north of Newberry to the vicinity of Eight Mile Corner[MASK]. It was later replaced by M @-@ 48 in 19[MASK]6 . 
 
 = = = Current designati[MASK]n = = = 
 
 The current M @-@ 82 dates back to 1926 . It ran from US 31 in[MASK]H[MASK]rt to the norther[MASK] junction o[MASK][MASK]US 131 and M @-@ 46[MASK]in Howard City . The highway was routed through Ferry , Hesperia and Fremont , replacing M @-@ 41 . I[MASK] late 1936 , M @-@ 46 [MASK][MASK]s extended along the section between Newaygo and Howard City , forming a M @-@ 46 / M @-@ 82 concurrency to fill a gap in the M @-@ 46 rou[MASK]ing . This concurrent s[MASK]ction became just M @-@ 46 in 1938 , [MASK]hortening M @-@ 82 back to the northern M @-@ 37 junction in Newaygo . The highway was moved to a new alignment west of Ferry in late 1947 or early 1948 .[MASK]Instead of headi[MASK]g northwesterly to Hart , it was continued west to end in Shelby . 
 Two realignments in 1963 and 1964 rerouted the western end of the highway again . This time it was realigned to run from Hesperia to New Era , bypassing Ferry . A larger change[MASK]aroun[MASK] 1969 reconfigured the highway designations in Oce[MASK]na County . M @-@ 20 replaced M @-@ 82 west of Hesperia ,[MASK]to end at New Era instead of Muskegon . The [MASK]ew M @-@ 120 designation replaced M @-@ 20 south of Hesperia . M @-@ 82 now ran from Hesperia to Newaygo only . The l[MASK]ngth of the highway was [MASK]ncreased in 1973 when[MASK]the eastern end was mo[MASK]ed back to Howard City . M @-@ 46 was rerouted to follow the US 131 freeway south of Howard City to Cedar Springs , and replac[MASK]d M @-@ 57 [MASK]etween Cedar Springs and Casnovia . This freed[MASK]up the Newaygo to Howard City highway for a return to the M @-@ 82 designation . The last change came in 1978 when the concurrency with M @-@ 120 was eliminated in favor of M @-[MASK] 120 [MASK] The M @-@ 82 designat[MASK]on was truncated at this time to[MASK]the junction west of Fremont , resulting in the current[MASK]highway routing .

 = Shikama[MASK]u Nara = 
 
 Shikama[MASK]u Nara ( 奈良 シカマル , Nara Shikamaru ) [MASK][MASK] a fictional character in the Naruto[MASK]man[MASK]a and anim[MASK] series created [MASK]y Masashi [MASK]ishimoto . In the anime and manga , Shikamaru i[MASK] a ninja affiliated[MASK]with[MASK]the village of Ko[MASK]o[MASK]agakur[MASK] . He is[MASK]a [MASK]ember of Team 10 , a group of [MASK]inja consisting of himsel[MASK][MASK], Choji Akimichi , Ino Ya[MASK]anaka , and team leader Asuma Sarutobi .[MASK]Shikamaru is p[MASK]rtrayed as a lazy character , unwilling to apply his prod[MASK]g[MASK]ous intelligence ; Kishimoto has noted [MASK]hat he likes Shikamaru due to his easygoing nature . O[MASK]tside of the Naruto anime and manga[MASK], Shikamaru has appeared in four of t[MASK]e feature films in the series , as well as several[MASK]other media relating to the series , including video games[MASK]and original video animations . 
 Numerous anime and manga publications have commented on Shikamaru 's character . Man[MASK] reviewers commented on his laziness and intell[MASK]gence , a[MASK]d noted his transformation into a leader ; Anime News Network celebrated Shikama[MASK]u 's emergence as " an unlikely hero " in t[MASK]e Naruto storyline . Shikamaru has also been highly popular with the[MASK]N[MASK]ruto [MASK]eader base , placing high in several popularity polls . Merchandise based on Shikamaru has been released , [MASK]ncluding action figures , key chai[MASK]s , and patches . 
 
 = = Creation and conception = = 
 
 Masashi Ki[MASK]himoto has noted that he likes Shi[MASK]amaru due to his easygoing n[MASK]ture despite [MASK]eing a genius , and contrasted him against Sasuke Uchiha 's intelligent but[MASK]abrasive personality .[MASK]Kishimoto also [MASK]omically remarked that [MASK]e would marry Shikamaru if he were a girl , noting th[MASK]t Shika[MASK]aru would likely be successful in life . When designing Shikamaru 's Part II appearance , Kishimoto wanted to give Shikam[MASK]ru a unique appearance despite drawing him with a ve[MASK]t that several other ninja wear[MASK]in the ser[MASK]es . As a result[MASK], he drew his forehead protector on h[MASK]s arm in order to not obscure his hair . 
 
 = = Appearances = = 
 
 
 = = = In Naruto = = = 
 
 Shikamaru first major appearance in the series is [MASK]uring the Chunin Exams , bi @-@ y[MASK]arly exams for n[MASK]nja who wish to advance in rank . He is part of Team 10[MASK]alongside Choji Akimichi and Ino Yamana[MASK]a . He is a highly unenthusiastic person , and he attempts to go[MASK]through life with minimum effort . Contrary to his lazy tendencies , Shik[MASK]maru is extremely intelligent ; his teacher , Asuma Sarutobi , determined that Shikamaru 's [MASK]Q was over 200 . Shikamaru 's abilities are based on the Shadow Imitation Tec[MASK]nique ( 影真似の術 , Kagemane no Jutsu , English TV : " [MASK]hadow Possession Jutsu " ) , the sign[MASK]ture technique of his clan , with which he merges his shadow with an opponent 's shadow , making them immobi[MASK]ized and forced to mimic Sh[MASK]kamaru 's movements . As the series progresses , Shikamaru becomes able to [MASK]anipulate his shadow in n[MASK]w[MASK]w[MASK]ys . B[MASK] Part II of the series , [MASK]hikamaru is capable of utilizing multiple shadow @-@ based tech[MASK]iques at once and can lift his shadow from the ground in order to interact with phy[MASK]ical objects ; for i[MASK]stance , he can pierce enem[MASK]es with the shadow tendrils or use them to throw weapo[MASK]s . 
 S[MASK]ikamaru approaches the exams with a s[MASK]nse of apathy ; when he battles the S[MASK]nagakure ninja Temari , he defeats her but forfeits his match[MASK]to her , due t[MASK] his chakra being low . D[MASK]spite this loss , he is the only ninja among his [MASK]eers to be promoted to the rank of Chunin , as the overseers of the exa[MASK]s were impressed by the insi[MASK]ht and intelligence he demonstrated aga[MASK]nst Temari . As a Chunin , Shikamaru is appointed the[MASK]leader of a team[MASK]to prevent Sasuke Uchiha from defecting to t[MASK]e village of Otogakure . Although Shikamaru 's team manages to defeat the Otogakure ninja barring their way , Sasuke manages to escape . 
 In Part II[MASK]of the series , Shikamaru is assigned the task of locating two members of t[MASK]e criminal organization Aka[MASK]suki . While his team manages to[MASK][MASK]ind their targets , the immorta[MASK] Akatsuki member Hidan kills Asuma S[MASK]rutobi during the course of the ba[MASK][MASK]l[MASK] despite Shikamaru 's b[MASK]st efforts . [MASK]fter Asuma 's funera[MASK] , Shikamaru sets out with the surviving members of Team 10 to avenge their mentor with the aid of Kakashi Hatake . [MASK]s the o[MASK]her deal with Hidan 's partner Kakuzu , Shikamaru avenges Asuma by defeating Hidan and maki[MASK]g sure the Akatsuki mem[MASK]er 's body is[MASK]never found . Following the fight ,[MASK]Shikama[MASK]u vows to protect Kurenai Yuhi and Asuma 's newborn daughter . He is later assigned to the Four[MASK]h D[MASK]vision alongside Temari and Chōji . He is named a pr[MASK]xy general under Gaara . In the series epilogue , stating[MASK]his personal desire during the series of final battles , Shikamaru becomes advisor [MASK]o the Seventh Hokage Naruto after marrying Temari and gaini[MASK]g a son in [MASK]hikadai Nara . 
 
 = = = App[MASK]arances in other me[MASK]ia = = = 
 
 Besides the Naruto anime and manga , Shikamaru is featured in seven[MASK]of the featured films in the series : in the[MASK]second film , he aids Naruto Uzumaki an[MASK] Sakura Haruno in fighting against Haido , a utopian idealist seeking to rule the w[MASK]rld with a power called Ge[MASK]el ; in the fourth , Shikamaru appears in a brief seq[MASK]ence , fighting against a large group of stone soldiers ; in the fi[MASK]th , Shikamaru is sen[MASK] [MASK]longside Kakashi and Sai in search of the base of the Land of Sky , who plans to invade Konoha ; in the sixth , Shikamaru , alongside Sakura and Sai battle the chimera b[MASK]ast summoned by Hiruko ; in the eight , Shikamaru participates in the battle against th[MASK] demon Sator[MASK] ; in the ninth , the Limited Tsuku[MASK]omi universe presents a portly Shika[MASK]aru , the exact opposite of his teammate , Choji ,[MASK]who becomes the tea[MASK] strat[MASK][MASK]ist instead ; and in the tent[MASK] , Shikamaru leads the team consisting of himself , Naruto , Sakura , Sai , and Hi[MASK]ata Hyuga that is s[MASK]nt to rescue Hinata 's younger sister , Hanabi , who was kidnapped by Toneri Otsutsuki . He is also present in the third original video animation , in which he participates in a tournament [MASK] Shikamaru is a playable character in nearly all Naruto video games , including the Clash of Ninja series and the Ultimate Ninja series . In some games , he utilizes variations of h[MASK]s Shadow Imitation Technique not seen in the an[MASK]me or manga[MASK]. Naruto Shippū[MASK]en : Gekitō Ninja Taisen ! [MASK]X 2 marks the first[MASK]appearance of Shikamaru in his Part II appearance in a video game . 
 A light novel titled Shikamaru Hiden : A Cloud Drifting in Silent [MASK]ark[MASK]ess , writte[MASK] by Takashi Yano and illustrated by Kishimoto , stars Sh[MASK]kamaru as the main character and narrator . The novel is set two years after the Fo[MASK]rth Ninja War , focusing on Shikamaru 's ass[MASK]gnment as organizer of the newly formed Shinobi Union to [MASK]apture a rogue ninja who rules over the distant Land of Silence and attempts to establish a new world order ruled by the common people . It also explores his growing relationship with Temari , culminating in him struggling to name his[MASK]child with her , years after th[MASK] end of the novel .
