The last such poll was in 2011 , in which Shikamaru was in ninth place , behind Sas[MASK]ri and ahead of Hinata . Merchandise based on[MASK]Shikamaru has al[MASK]o bee[MASK] released , including action figures [MASK] key chains , and patches in both hi[MASK] Part I and Part II appearance . NTT custom[MASK]rs voted him as t[MASK]eir sixteenth fa[MASK]orite[MASK]black hai[MASK]ed male[MASK]anime character .[MASK][MASK]yberConnec[MASK]2 CEO Hiroshi Matsuyama referred to Shikamaru as one of his f[MASK]vorite characters from Naruto . 
 Se[MASK]eral publi[MASK]ati[MASK]ns for m[MASK]nga , anime , video games , and other related [MASK]edia have commented on Shikamaru 's character . IGN stated that Shikamaru was one of their favorite charac[MASK]ers in the series , and referred to him as " the po[MASK]ter child for any card [MASK]-@ carrying member of Generation X "[MASK]due to his general lack of[MASK]enthusiasm and his unwillingness to utilize his potential [MASK] In a review of episode 110 , IGN praised how Shikamaru managed to transcend his lazy nature in order to take o[MASK][MASK]the mantle o[MASK] a leader when assigned to lead a tea[MASK] in order to retrieve Sasuke Uchiha and [MASK]greed that the decision to make[MASK]him Chunin was fair . Anime News Network [MASK]lso commented on this developme[MASK]t , call[MASK]ng Shikamaru 's emergence as " an unlikely hero " one of the [MASK]ighlights of the [MASK]rc . In a subsequent review of episode 135 , in which [MASK]he mission to retrieve Sasuke has failed and the members of Sh[MASK]kamaru 's team were critically injured , IGN lauded the " great moment " in the episode in which Shikamaru bega[MASK] to cry after learning his friends will recover , [MASK]nd declared that he will be a better leader for the sa[MASK]e of his friends . Mania Entertainment 's[MASK]Justin Rich celebrated h[MASK]s " sh[MASK]er intellect " , calling him " one of the most fa[MASK]cinating characters in the series " and " one of the few truly bril[MASK]i[MASK]nt fighters i[MASK] shōnen anime " [MASK] Dani Moure [MASK] [MASK]nother reviewer from the same site , noted about his battle with Temari during the Chunin Exams that i[MASK] was " one of the better fights involving the supporting players " . 
 
 
 = Meridian , Mississippi = 
 
 Meridian is the sixth largest city[MASK]in t[MASK]e state of Mississippi , in the United States . It is[MASK]the county seat of Lauderdale Coun[MASK]y an[MASK] the prin[MASK]ipal city of [MASK]he Meridian , Mississippi Micropolitan Statistical Area . Along major highways , the[MASK]city is 93 mi ( 150 km ) east o[MASK] Jackson , Mis[MASK]issippi ; 154 mi [MASK] 248 km ) west of Birmingham , Alabama ; 202 mi ( 325 km ) northeast of New Orleans , Louisiana ; and 231 mi ( 372 km ) southeast of Memphis , Tennessee . 
 Established in 1860 [MASK] at the intersection of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad and Southern Railway of Mississippi , Meridian 's economy was built on t[MASK]e railways and goods transported on them , and it became a strategic trading center . Du[MASK][MASK]ng the American Civil War , General William Tecumseh Sherman burned much of the city to the gro[MASK]nd in the Battle of Meridian ( February , 1864 ) . 
 Rebuilt after the war , t[MASK]e city ent[MASK]red a " Golden Ag[MASK] " it become the [MASK]argest city in [MASK]ississ[MASK]ppi bet[MASK][MASK]en[MASK]1890 and 1930 , and a leading center for manufacturing in the Sout[MASK] , with 44 trains arriving and departing daily . Union Station , built in 1906 , is now a multi @-@ modal center , giving access to the Merid[MASK]an Transit System , Greyhound Buses , and Trailways , averaging 242 @,@ 360 passengers per year . Although the economy slowed with the decline of the railroad industry , the city has diversified , with healthcare , military , and manufacturing employing the most people in 2010 . The population within the city limits , according to 2008 census estimates , is 38 @,@ 2[MASK]2 , but a pop[MASK]latio[MASK] of 232 @,@ 900 i[MASK] a 45 @-@ mile ( 72 km ) radius and 526 @,@ 500 in a 65 @-@ mile ( 105 km ) radius , of which 104 @,@ 600 and 234 @,@ 200 people respectively are in the labor force , feed the e[MASK]onomy of the city . 
 The area is served by two military facilities , Nav[MASK]l Air[MASK]Station Meridian and Key Field , which provide over 4 @,@ 000 jobs .[MASK]NAS Meridian is home to the Regional Coun[MASK]er @-@ Drug Training Academy ( RCTA ) and the first local De[MASK]artment of Homeland Security[MASK]in the state . Key Field is name[MASK] after br[MASK]thers F[MASK]ed and Al Key , who set a wor[MASK]d endurance flight record in 1935 . T[MASK]e field is no[MASK] home to the 186th Air Refueling Wing of the Air National Guard[MASK]and a support facilit[MASK] for the 185th Aviation Brigade of t[MASK]e Army National Guard . Rush Foundation Hospital is the largest non @-@ military employer in the region , employi[MASK]g 2 @,@ 610 people . 
 Among the city 's many arts organizations and historic buil[MASK]ings are the Riley Center , the Meridian Museum of Art , Meridian Little Theatre , and the Meridian Symphony Orchestra . Meridian was hom[MASK] to two Carnegie libraries , [MASK]ne fo[MASK] whites and one for African Americans .[MASK]The Carnegie Branch Library , now demolished , was one of a number of Carnegie libraries built for blacks in[MASK]the[MASK]Sou[MASK]her[MASK] United St[MASK]tes[MASK]during the segregation era . 
 The city has been selected as the future location of the Missis[MASK]ippi Arts and Entertainment Center ( MAEC ) . Jimmie Rodgers , the " Father [MASK]f[MASK]Countr[MASK] Music " , was born i[MASK] Meridian . Highland Park houses a museum which displays memorabilia of his life and career , as well as rail[MASK]oad equipment[MASK]from the steam @-@ engine e[MASK]a . The park is also home to the Hi[MASK]hland Park Dentzel Carousel , a National Historic Landmark . It i[MASK] the world 's only two @-@ row[MASK]stationary Dentzel menagerie in ex[MASK]s[MASK]ence . Other notable natives include Miss America 1986 Susan Akin , James Chaney – an activist who was ki[MASK]led in the Missis[MASK]ippi civil rights workers[MASK]murders in[MASK]1964 , and Hartley Peavey , founder of Peavey Electroni[MASK]s headquartered in Meridian . The federal courthouse was the site of the 196[MASK] @-@ 1967 trial of suspects in the murder of Chaney and two other activists ; it was the first[MASK]t[MASK]me a w[MASK]ite jury convicted a white official of a ci[MASK]il ri[MASK]hts killing . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 Previously inhabited by the Choctaw Native Americans , th[MASK] are[MASK] now called Meridian was ob[MASK]ained by the United States under th[MASK] terms of the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek in 1830 during the period [MASK]f Indian Removal . After the tr[MASK]aty was ratified , European @-@ American s[MASK]ttlers b[MASK]gan to[MASK]move into the area . 
 After receiving a federal land grant of about 2 @,@ 000 acres ( 810 ha ) , Richard McLemore , the first settler of Meridian , began off[MASK]ring free land to new[MASK]omers to attract more settlers to the region and develop the area . Most of McLemore 's land was bought in 1853 by Lewis [MASK]. Ra[MASK]sdale , a lawyer from Alabama . John T. B[MASK]ll , a merchant from Kemper County ,[MASK]bought the re[MASK]aining 80 acres ( 0 @.@ 32 km2 ) . Ragsdale and Ball , now known as the [MASK]ou[MASK]ders of the city , began laying out lots for new de[MASK]elopment on their respective[MASK]land sections . 
 There was much competition over the proposed name of the [MASK]ettlement . Ball and th[MASK] more industrial residents of the city supported the[MASK]name " Meridian , " believing the term to[MASK]be synonymous with " junction " [MASK] the more agrarian residents of the city preferred " Sowashee " ( meaning [MASK] mad river "[MASK]in a Native American language ) , from the name of a nearby cr[MASK]ek ; and Ragsdale proposed " Ragsdale City . " Ball erected a station house on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad – the sign on which would alternate between " Meridian " and " Sowashee " each day . Eventually the continued development of the railroads led to an influx of railroad workers who overruled the others in the city and left " Meridian " on the station permanently . The town was officially incorporated as Meridian on Februa[MASK]y 10 , 1860 . 
 Meridian was a small village at the start[MASK]of the Ameri[MASK]an Civil War in 1861 . Its st[MASK]ategic position at the railroad junction l[MASK]d to[MASK]the Confederate construction of several military installations to support the[MASK]war . During t[MASK]e Battle of Meridian in [MASK]864 , Gene[MASK]al William Tecum[MASK]eh Sherma[MASK] [MASK]ed troops into the city , destroying the[MASK]railroads in every direction , as well[MASK]as an arsenal and immense sto[MASK]ehouse[MASK] ; his forces burned much of the buildings to the ground . Sherman is reported to have said afterw[MASK]rds , " Meridi[MASK]n , with its depots , store @-@ houses , ars[MASK]nal , hospitals , offices , hotels , and cantonments no longer exi[MASK]ts . " Despite the destruction , the railroad lines in the city were rapidly repaired , back in operation 26[MASK]working days after the battle . Race relations remained tense during the Reconstructio[MASK] era , with the riot of 1871 following a fire that damaged many businesses . 
 Th[MASK] town boomed in the aftermath of the Civ[MASK]l War , and experienced its " Golden Age " from 1880 to 1910 . The railroads in the area provided for a means of transportation and an influx of industries , which caused a population boom . As the population rose , commercial[MASK]activity increased in the downtown area . Between 1890 and 1930 , Meridian was the largest city in Mississippi and a[MASK]leading center for manufacturing in[MASK]the South . Many of the city 's[MASK]historic buildings were built during and just after this e[MASK]a , including the Grand Ope[MASK]a House in 1890 , the Wechsler School in 1894 , two Carnegie libraries in 1913 , a[MASK]d the Threefoot Building , Meridian 's tallest skyscrape[MASK] , in 1929 . 
 The [MASK]ity continued to grow thanks to a commission government 's efforts to bring in 90 new industrial plants in 1913 and a booming automobile industry in the 1920s . Even through the stock mark[MASK]t crash of 1929 and the following Great Depression , the city continued to attract new businesses[MASK]. With escapism becoming popular in the cult[MASK]re during the depth of the Depression , the S. H. Kress & Co[MASK] building , built to " p[MASK]ovide luxury to the common man , " op[MASK][MASK]ed in downtown Meridian , as did the[MASK]Temple Theater , which was used as a movie house . The fed[MASK]ral cour[MASK]house was built in 1933 as a WPA proje[MASK]t . 
 After[MASK]a brief slowdown of the economy at the end of t[MASK]e Depression , the country entered World War II , which renewed the importance of railroads . The rails were essential to transport gasoline and scrap metal to build military vehicles , so Meridian became the region 's rail center agai[MASK] . This re[MASK]ewed prosperity continued until the 1950s , when[MASK]the a[MASK]tomobile and Interstate Highway System became more popular than passenger rails . The decline of t[MASK]e railr[MASK]ad industry caused significant job losses , result[MASK]ng in a population decline as workers left for other areas . 
 During[MASK]the American Civil Rights Mov[MASK]ment in[MASK]the 1960s , Meridian was home[MASK]to a Council of Federated Organizations ( COFO ) off[MASK]ce and several[MASK]other activist organizations . James Chaney and other local residents , along wi[MASK]h Michael Schwerner [MASK] his wife Rita , [MASK]nd Andrew Goodman , volunteers from the North , worked to create a community center , holding class[MASK]s to help prepare African Americans in the area to regain the power to vote . Whites in[MASK]the area resented the activism[MASK], and racia[MASK] tension often resulted in violenc[MASK] . In June 1964 , Cha[MASK]ey , Schwerner , and Goodman went to Nesho[MASK]a County , Mississippi , to meet with members of a black church that had been bombed and burned . The three disappeared that night on their way back to Meridian . Fol[MASK]owing a massive FBI investigation , their murdered bodies were foun[MASK] two months later , buried i[MASK] an earthen dam . 
 S[MASK]ven Klansmen , including a deputy sheriff , were convicted in the federal courthouse in Meridian of " depriving the victims of their civil rights " and three were acquitted in the Mississippi civil rights workers murders trial . It wa[MASK] the first time that a w[MASK]ite jury had[MASK]convicted " a white official i[MASK] a civil rights killing . " In 2005 , the case was reopened by the state , which brought char[MASK]es in the case for the first time . Edgar Ray Killen was convicted of manslau[MASK]hter and sentenced to 60 years in prison . Meridian later honored Chaney by[MASK]renaming a portion of 49th[MASK]Avenue after him and holding an annual memorial service . 
 Starting in the 1960s and following the construction of highways that [MASK]ade commuting ea[MASK]ier , residents began to move away from downtown in favor of new housing subdivisions to the north . A[MASK]ter strip commercial interests be[MASK]an to move downtown , the ci[MASK]y worked to [MASK]esignat[MASK] severa[MASK] areas as historic districts in the 1970s and 80s[MASK]to preserve the architectural character of the city . The Meridian Historic Districts and Landmarks Commission was created in 1979 , and the Meridian Main Street program was founded in 1985 . 
 Meridian Main Street or[MASK]anized several projects to revitalize downtown , includ[MASK]ng the construction of a [MASK]ew Amtrak Station in 1997 based on the design of the[MASK]historic train station used during Meridian 's Golden Age ; it had been demolished . Other projec[MASK]s included th[MASK] renovation of the Ro[MASK]enbaum Building in 2001 and Weidmann 's Restaurant in 2002 , as well as support for integrated urban design . Meridian Main Street , along with The Riley Foun[MASK]ation , helped renovate and adapt the historic Grand Opera[MASK]House in 2006 for us[MASK] as the " Mississippi State Unive[MASK]sity Riley Center for Education a[MASK]d the Performing Arts . " 
 After ownersh[MASK]p of the Meri[MASK]ian Main Street was transferred to the Alliance for Downtown Meridia[MASK] in late 2007 , the two or[MASK]anizations , along with the Meridian Downtown Association , spearheaded the downtown revitalization [MASK]ffort [MASK] [MASK]he Alliance serves as an umbrella organization , allowing[MASK]the other two organizations to use the its support staff and housing , and in turn [MASK]he Alliance serve[MASK] as a[MASK]liaison between the organizations . Plans were underway to renovate the Threefoot Building , but newly elected Mayor Cheri Barry killed the plans in early [MASK]010 . Today , the Alliance helps to promote furth[MASK]r development and restoration downtown ; its goal is to assist businesses such as sp[MASK]ci[MASK]lt[MASK] shops , restaurants , and bars because these help downtown be[MASK]ome more active during the d[MASK]y and at night . The Meridian Downtown Association is primarily focused on i[MASK]creasing foot traffic downtown by organizing special events , and the Meridi[MASK]n Main Street program supports existing businesses downto[MASK]n . 
 
 = = = Hotels = = = 
 
 Given Meridian 's site as a railroad junction , its travelers have attracted the development of many hotels . Even before Meridian reached its " Golden Age , " several large hote[MASK]s , including the Great Southern and [MASK]he Grand A[MASK]enue hotels , were built before the start of the 20th century . With[MASK]the growth of the railroads and the construction of [MASK]he original Union Station in 1906 , many hotels were constructed fo[MASK] passengers and workers . The Elmira Hotel was constructed in 1905 , and the Terminal Hotel was const[MASK]ucted in 1910 . Hotel Meridian was constructed in 1907 , [MASK]nd Union Hotel was built in 1908 . Union [MASK]otel was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in [MASK]979 , and both Hotel Meridian and Grand Avenue Hotel were listed as contributing properties to[MASK]the Meridi[MASK]n Urban Center Historic District . 
 As the city [MASK]rew , the hotels reflected ambitions of the strong economy , as evidenced by the eleven @-@ story skyscraper Lamar Hotel built in 1927 . Listed on the National Register[MASK]of Historic Places in 1979 , the Lamar Hotel was adapted for use as a county annex building . In 1988 it [MASK]as listed as a Mississippi Landma[MASK]k . 
 The E.F. Young Hotel was built in 1931 . A [MASK]taple in the African @-@ American business district that developed west of the city 's core , the hotel[MASK]was one of the only pl[MASK]ces in the city during the years of segregation where a traveling African American could find a room . 
 As th[MASK] city suburbs developed in the 1960s and ' 70s , most hotels moved outside of downtown . Rehabili[MASK]ation of the Riley Center in 2006 has increased demand a[MASK]d a push for a new downtown hotel . The Threefoot Building[MASK]has been proposed for re[MASK]evelopment for this purpose , but restoration [MASK]fforts stalled with a[MASK]change in city administrations . The Threefoot Preservation Society was formed in 2013 to raise public awareness and support for the building 's renovation , featu[MASK]i[MASK]g to[MASK]rs of the first floor and anniversary events . 
 
 = = = Historic distri[MASK]ts = = = 
 
 Meridian has nine historic districts that are list[MASK]d on the National Register of Historic Pl[MASK]ces . Th[MASK] Meridi[MASK]n Downtown Historic D[MASK]strict is a combination of two older districts , the[MASK]Meridian Urban Center Historic Distric[MASK] and the Union Station Historic District .[MASK]Many architectural styles are present in the[MASK]districts ,[MASK][MASK]ost from the late 19th and early [MASK]0th centuries , including Queen Anne , Colonial Revival , Italianate , Art Deco , Late Victorian ,[MASK]and Bungalow . The districts are : 
 1 East End Historic District — roughly bounded by [MASK]8th St , [MASK]1th Ave , 14th St , 14th Ave , 5th St , a[MASK]d 17th Ave . 
 2 Highlands Historic Di[MASK]trict — roughly bounded by 15th St , 34th Ave , 19th St , and 36th Ave . 
 3 Meridian Downtown Historic District — runs from the former Gulf , Mobile and Ohio Railroad north to 6th[MASK]St between 18th and 26th Ave , excluding Ragsdale Survey Block 71 . 
 4 Meridian Urban Center Historic District — roughly bounded by 21st and 25th Aves , 6th St , and the railroad . 
 5 Union Station Historic District — roughly bounded by 18th and 19th Aves , 5th St ,[MASK]and [MASK]he r[MASK]ilroad . 
 6 Merrehope Historic [MASK]istrict — roughly bounded by 33rd Ave , 30th Ave , 14th St , and[MASK]8th St. 
 7 Mid @-@ Town Historic District — roughly bounded by 23rd Ave , 15th St , 28th Ave , and 22nd St. 
 8 Poplar Springs[MASK]Road Historic District — roughly bounded by 29th St , 23rd Ave , 22nd S[MASK] , and 29th Ave . 
 9 West End Historic District — roughly bounded by 7th St , 28th Ave , Shearer 's Branch , an[MASK] 5th St. 
 
 = = Gove[MASK]nme[MASK]t and infrastructure = = 
 
 Meridian has operated under the mayor @-@ council or " strong m[MASK]yor " form of government since 1985 . A mayo[MASK] is elected ever[MASK] four years by the po[MASK]ulation at @-@ large . The five members of the city council are elected every four years[MASK]fr[MASK]m each of the city 's[MASK]five wards , considered single @-@ member districts . The mayor , the chief executive officer of the city , is responsible fo[MASK] ad[MASK]inistering and leading the day @-@ to @-@ day operations of city government[MASK]. The city council is the legislative arm of the government , settin[MASK][MASK]policy and annually adopting the city 's operating budget . 
 City Hall , which has [MASK]een listed on the Nation[MASK]l Register of Histor[MASK]c Places , is located at 601 23rd Avenue . The current mayor is Percy Bland . Members of the city council include Dr. George [MASK]. Thomas , representative fr[MASK]m Ward 1[MASK], Kenneth Dustin Markham , representativ[MASK][MASK]fr[MASK]m Ward 2 , Barbara Henson , representati[MASK]e from Ward 3 , Kim Houston , represen[MASK]ative from Ward 4 , and Randy Hammo[MASK] , representative from Ward [MASK] . The council clerk is Pam McIn[MASK]is . In total , the city employs 570 people . 
 The cit[MASK] established a[MASK]Department of Homeland Security ( DHS ) shortly [MASK]fter Hurrica[MASK]e Katrina in 200[MASK] , becoming the[MASK]only local D[MASK]S in the state . The team oversees an are[MASK] of nine counties . Upon receivin[MASK] $ 2 @.@ 5 million in grants from the Mississippi Emergency Management Agen[MASK]y and other organizations , the department began training law enforcemen[MASK] offices from oth[MASK]r Southern states in passenger rail rescue as well as offering civilian classes in bas[MASK]c handguns , Boy Scout first aid and hunting , and firearms training . The DHS helps during times of crisis such as Hurricane Ivan in September 2005 , w[MASK]en the department helped establish and support shelters [MASK]or 700 evacuees . Th[MASK] city no[MASK] serves as the leader of one of the task forces in the Mississippi DHS , a combination of three nine @-@ c[MASK]unty t[MASK]ams . 
 Headed by police chief Lee Shelbourn since 2009 , the Meridian Police Department consists of 115 full @-@ time officers a[MASK] wel[MASK] as part[MASK]@-@ [MASK]ime and reserve staff available . In 2009 , th[MASK] department 's Criminal Investigations Divi[MASK]ion responded to 4000[MASK]cases , 2000 of which were felonies . In 2000 , 2094 crimes we[MASK]e reported , up slightly from 2008 crimes the prece[MASK]ing year . Meridian has been[MASK]described as " the safest city in[MASK]Mississippi with more than 30 @,@[MASK]000 people . " The East Mississippi Correctional Facility is located in unincorporated Lauderdale County , near Meridian . It is operated by the GEO Group on[MASK]behalf of the Mississippi Department of Corrections . The chief of the Meridian Fire Department is Anthony Clayton . The fire department responded to more than 1600 calls in 2009 , including 123 structural fires and 609 emergency service calls . 
 The Mississippi Departme[MASK]t of Mental Health operates the East Mississippi State Hospital i[MASK] Meridian . 
 The United States Postal Service operates[MASK]the Meridian [MASK] North Meridian , and the West Merid[MASK]an Station post offices . 
 In[MASK]state politic[MASK] , the Mississippi Senate district map divides the city into three sections . The northern[MASK]tip of the city is in the 31st [MASK]tate Senate District and seats T[MASK]rry Clark Burton ( R ) . A [MASK]tr[MASK]p of the city from the southwest corner up to the northeast co[MASK]ner comprises part of the 32nd State Senate District and seats Sampson [MASK]ackson , II ( D ) . The western and southeastern portions of the city lie in the 33rd State Senate [MASK]istrict and seats Videt Carmichael ( R ) . In the Mississippi[MASK]House of Representatives districts , the city is divided into f[MASK]ur districts . The sou[MASK]hern and eastern portions of the city reside in House District 81 and are represented by Steven A. Horne ( R ) . The city 's core make[MASK] up the entirety of Ho[MASK]se District 82 and is represented by Wilbert L. Jo[MASK]es ( D[MASK]) . Surround[MASK]ng House District 82 is House District[MASK]83 , represented by Greg Snowden ( R ) . The western section of the city , along with [MASK] small section in the north , lie in House District 84 and are represented by T[MASK]d Campbell ( R ) . 
 On the national level , [MASK]he city is located in Mississippi 's[MASK][MASK]rd congressional district , represente[MASK] by Gregg Harper ( R ) , who has been in office since 2009[MASK]. Lauderdale County , home to Meridian [MASK] has vo[MASK]ed for the Republican candidate in every United States pre[MASK]idential election si[MASK]ce 1972 . Prior to the shift to the Republican Party , white area voters supported Democra[MASK]ic Party candidates , as for decades since the late nineteenth century , i[MASK] was a one @-[MASK] party state . 
 
 = = Demographics = = 
 
 The [MASK]ity 's growth has reflected the push and pull of many social and economic factors . The total population increase[MASK] in each census from the city 's foun[MASK]ing until 1970 , although varying from rates as high as 165 % to as low as 0 @.@ 2 % . In the 1970 census the population decreased , then slightl[MASK] increased by 1980 , after which the population slowly decline[MASK] , increasing again since the turn of the 21st century . Between 1980 and 2000 , the population declined more than 14 % . As of the census of 2000 , the city 's population was 39 @,@ 968 , and the population density was 885 @.@ 9 inhabitants per square mile ( 342 @.@ 0 / km2 ) . In 2008 , the city was the sixth largest in the state . The population increased as of 2010 . 
 Meridi[MASK]n is the principal city in the Meridian micropolitan area , which as of 2009 consisted of three counties – Cl[MASK]rke , Kempe[MASK] , and Lauderdale – and had a population of 106 @,@ [MASK]39 . There is a population of 232 @,@ 900 in a 45 [MASK]-@ mile ( 72 km[MASK]) radius and 5[MASK]6 @,@ 500 in a 65 @-@ mile ([MASK]105 km ) radius . 
 While the [MASK]verall population growth of the city has varied , there has be[MASK]n[MASK]a steady growth in the number and percent[MASK]ge of non @-@ white residents . The only [MASK]ecline in this group was between[MASK]1960 and 1970 , when the city 's overall population declined markedly . In the 2010 Census , the racial makeup of the city was 61 @.@ 55 % African Ame[MASK]i[MASK]an , 35 @.@ 7[MASK] % White , 0 @.@ 9 [MASK] Asian , 0 @.@ 2 % Native American , < 0 @.@ 02 %[MASK]Pacific Islander ,[MASK]0 @.@ 59 % f[MASK]om other races , and 0 @.@ 89 % from two or more races . Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1 @.@ 75 % of the population . 
 According to the 2000 Census , of the 17 @,@[MASK]890 housing units inside city limits , 15 @,@ 966 were occupied , 10 @,@ 033 of them by families . 31 @.@ 1 % of occupied households had children under the age of 18 , 36 @.@ 2[MASK]% were married couples living together , 23 @.@ 3 % consisted of[MASK]a female householder with no husband present , and 37 @.@ 2 [MASK] were non @-@ families . 33 @.@ 2 % of all households were made up of individuals , and 14 @.@ 0 % had someone living alone who[MASK]was 65 years[MASK]of a[MASK]e or older . The average household size was 2[MASK]@[MASK]@[MASK]39 and the[MASK]average family size was[MASK]3 @.@ 06 . The average household size has steadily decreased since 1970 , w[MASK]en it was 3 @.@ 04 . Meridian 's median[MASK]age has increased from 30 @.@ 4 in 1970 to 34 @.@ 6 in 2000 . 
 The median income for a household in the city [MASK]as[MASK]$ 25 @,@ 085 , and the median income for a family was $ 31 @,@ 062 . Males had a median income of $ 29 @,@ 404 versus $ 19 @,@ 702 [MASK]or females . The per capita income for the city was $ 15 @,@ 255 . About 24 @.@ 6 % of families and 28 @.@ 6 % of the population were below the poverty line , including 40 @.@ 8 % of th[MASK]se under age 18 and 22 @.@ 0 % of those age 65 or over . 
 
 = = = Religion[MASK]= = = 
 
 The population of Meridian and its surrounds is fairly observ[MASK]nt , with 65 @.@ 2[MASK]% of Lauderdal[MASK] County identifying as affiliated with some type of religi[MASK]us con[MASK]regation , co[MASK]pared with the [MASK]ational averag[MASK] of 50 @.@ 2 % . Of [MASK]he affiliated in 2000 , 30 @,@ 068 ( 59 @.@ 0 % ) were in the Southern Baptist Con[MASK]ention , 9 @,@ 469 ( 18 @.@ 6 % ) were with the United Methodist Church , a[MASK]d 1 @,@ 872 ( 3 @.@ 7 % ) were associated [MASK]ith the Catholic Church . 
 Immigrant Jews from[MASK]Germany and[MASK]eastern Europe were[MASK]influential in commercial development of the [MASK]ity , build[MASK]ng businesses and services . Congregation Beth [MASK]srael was founded[MASK]in 1868 , just before the city 's " Golden Age . " Meridian once had the largest Jewish community in the state , with 575 Jewish people living in the city in 1927 . Today , f[MASK]wer than 40 Jews live in Meridian , most of whom are elderly . 
[MASK]
 = = [MASK]eography[MASK]and climate = = 
 
 Meridian is loc[MASK]ted in the North Central Hills region of Mi[MASK]sissippi in Lauderdale County . According to the United States Census Bureau , the city has a total area of 45 @.@ 9 sq mi ( 119 km2 ) [MASK] of w[MASK]i[MASK]h 45 @.@ 1 sq mi ( [MASK]17 km2[MASK]) is land and 0 @.@ 8 sq mi ( 2 @.@ 1 km2 ) is water . Along major highways , the city is 93 mi ( 150 km ) east of [MASK]ackson , Mississ[MASK]ppi ; 154 mi ( 248 km ) west of Birmingham , Alabama[MASK]; 202 m[MASK] ( 325 km ) northeast of New Orleans , Louisiana ; 231 mi ( 372 km ) southeast of Memphis , Tennessee ; and 297 mi ( 478 km ) west of Atlanta , Georgia . [MASK]he area surrounding the city is c[MASK]vered with cotton and corn fields along with oak and pine forests , and its topography consists of clay hills and the botto[MASK] lands of the head waters of the Chickasawhay River . 
 The natural terrain of the area has been modified in the urban core of the city by grading , but it maintains its gentle rolling character in the outlying areas . Numerous small creeks are found throughout the city and small lakes and woodlands lie in the nor[MASK]hern and southern portions of t[MASK]e [MASK]ity[MASK]. Sowashee Creek run[MASK] [MASK]hrough the southern portio[MASK] of[MASK]the city and branches off into Gallagher 's Creek , which flows through the center of the city [MASK][MASK]Loper 's[MASK]Creek runs through the far @-@ [MASK]estern part of the city while smaller [MASK]reeks i[MASK]cluding Shearer 's Branch , Magnolia Creek , and Robbins Cre[MASK]k are disper[MASK]ed throughout the city . 
 Meridian is in the [MASK]umid subtropical climate zone . The average high temperature during summer ( June through[MASK]August ) is around 90 ° F ( 32 [MASK] C ) and the ave[MASK]age low is around 70 ° F ( 21 ° C ) . [MASK]n winter ( December through February ) the average maximum is around 60 ° F ( 16 ° C ) and minimum 35 ° F ( 2 ° [MASK] ) . The warmest month is July , with an avera[MASK]e high of 92 @.@ 9 ° F ( 33 @.@ 8 ° C ) , and the coldest month of[MASK]the year is January with an average lo[MASK] of 34 @.@ 7 ° F ( 1 @.@ 5 ° [MASK] ) . [MASK] The average annual precipitation in the city is 58 @.@ 65 in ( 1 @,@ 490 mm ) . Rainfall is fairly evenly distribu[MASK]ed throughout the year , and the wettest month of the year is March , in which an average o[MASK] 6 @.@ 93 i[MASK] ( 176 mm ) of rain falls . Much rainfall is delivered by thunderstorms which [MASK]re common during the summer months but occur throughout the year . Severe thunderstorms - whi[MASK]h can p[MASK]oduce damaging [MASK]inds and / or large hail in addition to the usual hazards of lightning and heavy rain - occasionally occur . These are most common during the spring months with a secondary peak during the Fall months . These st[MASK]rms [MASK]lso bring the risk of torna[MASK]oes . 
 
[MASK]= = Economy = = 
 
 Early on , the economy depended greatly upon the railroads in the area . The city was the largest in Mississ[MASK]ppi a[MASK]ound the start of the 20th centur[MASK] , with five maj[MASK]r rail lines and 44 t[MASK]ains coming in and out daily . The city 's economy not only depended on the rails but the goods , such as t[MASK]mber and cotton , transported on them . With thes[MASK] rail @-@ based industries , the city was a great economic power in t[MASK]e state and region from about 1890 throug[MASK] 1930 [MASK] Though its economy slowed with the decline of th[MASK] railroad[MASK]ng industry in the 1950s , the city has [MASK]dapted , moving from a lar[MASK]ely rail @-@ based economy to a more diversified one , with healthcare , military , and manufact[MASK]ring employing the most people[MASK]. 
 Along with Lauderdale County and the city of Marion , Meridian is served[MASK]by the East Mississippi Business Dev[MASK]lopment Corporation , which was formed in 1996 by a group of business leaders from the area[MASK]. While as of April 2010 , the city 's civ[MASK]lian lab[MASK]r force was only 15 @,@ 420 people , there is a population of 232 @,@ 900 in a 45 @-@ mile ( 72 km ) r[MASK]dius and 526[MASK]@,@ 500 in a 65 @-@ mile ( 105 km [MASK] radius , of which 104 @,@ 600 and 234 @,@ 200 people respectively are in the labor force . The cit[MASK] thus serves as a hub of employment , retail , health care , and [MASK]ulture activities . Eighty percent o[MASK][MASK]Lauderdale County 's workers reside in the county while 90 % live withi[MASK] 45 mile[MASK] . 
 In April 2010 , there were 6 @,@ 260 people employed in the healthcare field in Lauderdale County . Rush Hospital is the largest healthcare or[MASK]anization in t[MASK][MASK] region , employing 2 @,@ 610 people , followed by East Mississippi State Hospital with 1 @,@ 500 and Anderson Hospital with 1 @,@ 475 . There [MASK]re three hospitals in Meridian , as well as many other h[MASK]althcare @-@ related facilities . Jeff Ande[MASK]son Regional Medical Center provides cardiovascular surgery , a Level II newborn intensive @-@ care unit , and a health and fitness center . Rush Foundation Hospital and the re[MASK]ated Rush Health Syst[MASK]ms operate a Specialty Hospital of Meridian , which offer[MASK] long @-@ ter[MASK] care for non @-@ permanent patients who require more recovery time in a hospital setting . Riley Hospital has two centers for stroke treatment and rehabilitation services . Other healthcare facilities in Meridian [MASK]nclud[MASK] the Alliance Health Center and East Mississi[MASK]pi State Hos[MASK]ital , the latter of which has been [MASK]n operation since 1882 . 
 Reta[MASK]l is another major emplo[MASK][MASK]r in the county , with 5 @,[MASK] 280 people employed in Apri[MASK] 2010 . Nearly $ 2 billion annually is spent on re[MASK]ail purch[MASK]ses in the ci[MASK]y[MASK]. The 633 @,@ 685 @-@ square[MASK]@-@ foot [MASK][MASK]58 @,@ 871 m2 ) Bonita Lakes M[MASK]ll[MASK]off[MASK]rs over[MASK]one hundred shopping venues , including department stores , specialty shops , restaurants , eateries , and United Artists Theatres . Phase I of th[MASK] [MASK]onstruction of Meridian Crossroads , a 375 @,@ 000 @-@ square @-@ foot ( 34 @,@ 800[MASK]m2 ) shoppin[MASK] center in th[MASK] [MASK]onita Lakes [MASK]rea , was completed in November 2007 , providing a m[MASK]jor boost to reta[MASK]l in the area . Also , the shopping [MASK]istrict on North Hills Street has continued to expand , and in March 2007 , additional retail and office space was opened near the Highway 19 Walmart Supercenter[MASK]. 
 The area is al[MASK]o served by two military facilities , Naval Air Station Meridian and Key Field , which supply over 4 @,@ 000 jobs to residents[MASK]of the surrounding area . NAS Meridian provides training for [MASK]aval carri[MASK]r pilots and other enlisted personnel . Also housed a[MASK] the base is the Regional Counter @-@ Drug Training Academy ( RCTA ) , which provides narcotics training for law enforcement in many southeastern states . Containing the first l[MASK]cal [MASK]epartment of Homeland Security in the state [MASK] the city is the leader [MASK]n a ni[MASK]e county region[MASK]l response team and a t[MASK]enty @-[MASK] nine county regional response task force . Ke[MASK] Field is the site of the famous flig[MASK]t by brothers Fr[MASK]d and Al Key , who set a worl[MASK] endurance flight record in 1935 [MASK] Key Field is now home to the 186th Air Refueling Wing of the A[MASK]r National Guard and a support facility for the 185th Aviation Brigade of the Army National Guard . The[MASK]site also contains an exhibit reviewing the history of aviation , and is the home of Meridian 's Aviation Museum . 
 The total manufacturing employment of Lauderdale County in April 2010 was 2 @,@ 850 [MASK]eople . Peavey Electronics Corporation , which has manufactured guitars , amplifiers , and sound[MASK]equipment since 1965 , operates its headquarters in the city . Other busine[MASK]ses in [MASK]he area include Avery Dennison , S[MASK]ruct[MASK]ral Steel Services ,[MASK]Sara Lee , Tower Autom[MASK]tive , and Teikuro Corporation . The city is a[MASK]so [MASK]ome to four industrial parks . 
 In downtown , the MSU [MASK]iley Ce[MASK]ter provides revenue from tourism , arts , and entertainment sales . The Riley Cente[MASK] attrac[MASK]s more than 6[MASK] @,@ 000 vi[MASK]itors to downtown Meridian annually for conferences , meetings [MASK] and performances . Loeb 's Department Store on Front St has remained a Mississippi clothing landmark , having passed through four generations of[MASK]fa[MASK]ily[MASK]ownership . The store [MASK]as be[MASK]n selling fine m[MASK]n 's and women 's clothing since 1887 , when the store was first[MASK]opened by Alex Loeb . 
 
 = [MASK] C[MASK]lture = = 
 [MASK] 
 = = = Arts = = = 
 
 Known for more than a centu[MASK]y of arts , Meridian co[MASK]tains many art and cultur[MASK]l organizations and hosts many cultural events . One of the first art organizations in the city , Th[MASK] Meridian Art League , was established in February 1933 . Art[MASK]exhibitions were originally held in Lamar Hotel [MASK]n down[MASK]own Meridian , but[MASK]after a name change t[MASK] [MASK]eridian Art Association in 1949 , exhibitions were held at various locations around the[MASK]city . After the Carnegie library at 25th Ave and 7th St wa[MASK] closed , the Art Association remodelled the building into the Meridian Museum of Art to serve as a permanent home for exhibits . The museum was opened in 1970 and has since featured rotating exhibitions as well as many educational programs for both students and adults . Over thirty exhibitions are held annually , ranging from traditional decorative arts to ethnographic and tribal materials , photography , crafts , and many other works of art . The collection also includes 18th and[MASK]19th century portraits , 20th century [MASK]hotography , and several sculptures . 
 The Meridian Council for the Ar[MASK]s ( MCA )[MASK]was founded as [MASK]eridian 's and Laud[MASK]rdale County 's official arts agency in 19[MASK]8 . MCA operates its Comm[MASK][MASK]ity Art Grants program , the annual Threefoot Festival , several[MASK]workshops , and[MASK]other special[MASK]events each year . MCA is partne[MASK]ed with many arts organizations in the city and county in[MASK]l[MASK]ding the Meridian Museum of Art , the Meridian Littl[MASK] The[MASK]tre , an[MASK] the Meridian Symphony Orchest[MASK]a . Meridian Little Theatre , one of the South 's oldest subscription @-@ based community theatres , was built in 1932 and c[MASK]rrently provides entertainment t[MASK] residents of and visitors to Meridian and Lauderdale County , entertaining over 22 @,@ 000 guests each season , makin[MASK] it Mississippi 's most @-@ attended community theatre . The Meridian Symphony Orchestra ( MSO )[MASK]– founded in 1961 – pla[MASK]ed its first con[MASK]e[MASK]t [MASK]n 1962 and its first [MASK][MASK]ll season in 1963 . In 1965 the MSO booked its first international soloist , E[MASK]ena Nikolaidi , t[MASK] perform with the orchestra . The Orchestra helped the Meridian Public School District develop its own orchestra and strings programs and also helped develop the Meridian Symphony Chorus . The current conductor is Dr. Claire Fox Hillard , who has been with the orchestra since 1[MASK]91 . The MSO will celebrate its 50th anniversary in Februar[MASK][MASK]2011 with a performance from Itzhak Perlman . 
 The city[MASK]'s former[MASK]Gr[MASK]nd Opera House was built in 1889 by two half bro[MASK]hers , Israel Marks and Levi Rothenberg . During its operation t[MASK]e ope[MASK]a house hosted many famous artists and works , the [MASK]irst b[MASK]ing a German company 's rendition of Johann Strauss [MASK]I 's " The Gypsy Baron " . After closing in the late 1920s due to the Great Depression , the opera[MASK]house was abandoned for nearly 70 years . A $ 10 million grant in 2000 by the Riley Foundation , a local found[MASK]tion chartered in 1998 , sparked the building 's restoration while $ 15 milli[MASK]n came from a combination of city , county , and federal grants . The opera house 's renovation was completed in September 2006 under the new name " [MASK]ississippi State University Riley Center for Educa[MASK]ion and Performing Arts . " The Riley Center , which includes a 950 @-@ seat auditorium for live pe[MASK]formances , a 200 @-@ seat studi[MASK] theater , and 30 @,@ 000 sq [MASK][MASK] ( 2 @,@ 787 m2 ) of meeting space , attracts more than 60 @,@[MASK]000 visitors to downtown Meridian ann[MASK]ally[MASK]for[MASK]conferences , meetings , an[MASK] performances [MASK] 
 Meridian is rightly considere[MASK] an architectural tre[MASK]sure trove being one the nations most intact cities from the turn of[MASK]the last century . Architecture stud[MASK][MASK]ts from around the nation and Canada are known to visit Meridian in groups as part of their coursework due to numerous[MASK]structures in the city having been designed by n[MASK]ted architects . The only home in the US[MASK]south designed by noted Canadian born Ar[MASK]hitect L[MASK]uis S. Curtiss[MASK], famous for inventing the [MASK]lass curtain wall skyscraper , is extant on Highl[MASK]nd Park . The Frank Fort designed Threefoot Build[MASK]ng is gene[MASK]ally[MASK]considered one of the best Art Deco skyscrapers in the US and i[MASK] oft[MASK]n compared to Detroit 's famed Fisher Buil[MASK]ing . Noted California Architect Wal[MASK]ace Ne[MASK]f designed a number of ho[MASK]es in Meridian as well as in the Alabama Blac[MASK] Belt which adjoins the city across the nearby Alabama[MASK]State line . He had relatives in Meridi[MASK]n and Selma who were executives in the then thriving railroad industry and would take commissions in the [MASK]rea when commissions in California w[MASK]re lean . His work is mos[MASK]ly concentrated in the lower numbered blocks of Poplar Springs Drive where his 2516 Poplar Springs Drive is often compared to the similarly design[MASK]d Falcon Lair , th[MASK] Beverly Hills home in Benedic[MASK] Canyon of Rudolph Valentino . One Neff [MASK][MASK]rk was lost to an expansion of Anderso[MASK] Hospital in 1990 and another in Marion Park burned in the 1950[MASK] . The Meridian Post Office with its interior done entirely of bronze and [MASK]erde marble is also noteworthy as a very fine example of the type of Post Office struct[MASK][MASK]es built in thriving and well to do cities in the 1920s and originally had Lalique lighting which was removed sadly during a 1960s remodeling and which are now in private residences on Poplar [MASK]prings Drive a[MASK]d in North Hills . 
 Meridian has also been selected as the future[MASK]location of the Mississippi Arts and Entertainment Center ( MAEC ) . The Mississippi Legislature approved the idea i[MASK] 2001 a[MASK]d in 2006 promised $ 4 million in funding if private contributors could raise $ 8 million . The city donated $ 50 @,@ 000 to the cause in [MASK]eptember[MASK]2007 . The MAEC , as proposed , would be located on 175 acres ( 71 ha ) at Bon[MASK]ta Lakes and consist of an outdoor amphitheatre , an indoor concert hall , and a Hall of Fame honoring Mississippi artists . The Hall of Fame will be located downtown in the ol[MASK] Montana 's building . That property and the adjacent Meridian Hotel bu[MASK]lding were acquired in July 2010 for[MASK]$ 300 @,@ 000 . In Fe[MASK]ruary 2009 , the MAEC revealed its Walk of Fa[MASK]e outside of the Riley Center in an attempt to promo[MASK]e the pla[MASK]ned Hall of Fame . The first star on the walk was dedicated to Jimmie Rodgers , a Meridian nat[MASK]ve[MASK]. In September of the same year , [MASK]he second star was revealed , recognizing B.B. King , a famous blues musician from Mississippi . On June 1 , 2010 , authors Tennessee Williams , Eudora Welty , and William Faulkner were added to the walk . Sela Ward was added to the walk on June 24 , 2010 . The MAEC plans to add many more Mississippi @-@ bor[MASK] stars to the [MASK]alk of Fam[MASK] ; names mentioned[MASK][MASK]nclude Morgan Freeman , Jimmy Buffett , Elvis Presley , Conway Twitty , and others . 
 Another location in the city used for large productions is the Ham[MASK]sa Shrine Temple Theater . The Temple Theater houses a 778 @-@ pipe Robert Morgan organ , one o[MASK] two Theater [MASK]rgans still in t[MASK]eir original in[MASK]tallations in the state . With seating for 1800 p[MASK]rsons , the silent movie era was a prosperous time for the Temple . At the time , it was one of the largest stages in t[MASK]e United States , second only to the Rox[MASK] [MASK]heater in New York City . Today , seating 1576 [MASK]ersons ,[MASK]the Temple is used year @-@ round for area events , live stage shows , plays , concerts , H[MASK]masa Shrine functions , and public screenings of classic movies . 
 Highland Park houses a Jimmie Rodgers museum which displays the original guitar of " The Singing Brake[MASK][MASK]n " and other memorabilia of his[MASK]life and career , as well as rail[MASK]o[MASK]d equipment from the steam @-@ engine era . In addition to the museum building itself , there are outside memorials , and a vintage steam locomotive on display . A Mississippi Blues Trail hist[MASK]ric marker has been placed in Meridian to honor the city as the birthplace of Jimmie Rodgers and emphasiz[MASK]s his importance[MASK]to the development of the blues style of music in Missis[MASK]ippi [MASK] The city was the first site to receive this designation outside the Mississippi Delta . Also , a Mississippi Country Music Trail marker was placed [MASK]n Oak [MASK]rov[MASK] Cemetery in honor of Rodgers on June 1 , [MASK]010 . Each year since 1953 , the city has held a festival during May to honor the anniversary of his death [MASK] 
 Th[MASK] park is also home to a 19th @-@[MASK]century carousel manufactured around 1895 by Gustav Dentzel of Philadelph[MASK]a , Pennsylvania . Highland[MASK]Park Dentzel Carousel has been in [MASK]peration since 1909 , is a National Historic Landmark , and is[MASK]the world 's only[MASK]tw[MASK] @-@ row stationary Dentzel menagerie in existence . Its house is the only remaining original carousel building built from a Dentzel blueprint . Around Town Carousels Abound is a public art[MASK] project of 62 carousel horses , representing the histor[MASK]c carousel . Sixty @-@ two pieces h[MASK]ve been sponsored by local businesses and citizens [MASK] and design of the horses[MASK]was conceived and pa[MASK]nted by local artis[MASK]s . They are[MASK]placed throughout the city and county . 
 
 = = = Recreation = = = 
 
 The city contains several recreational parks , including H[MASK]ghland Park , Bonita Lakes , and Okatibbee Lake . Highland Park contains [MASK]icnic shelters , swimming pools , tennis co[MASK]rts , a baseball field[MASK], softball [MASK]ields , and a playground , all open year round to visitors . Bonita Lakes is a city @-@ owned , 3 @,@ 300 @-@ acre ( 13 km2 ) park including three lakes . [MASK]he park also includes the Long Creek Reservoir and Lakeview[MASK]Municipal Golf Course , along with nature trails , a jogging and walking track , biking paths , horseback riding trails , pavilions , picnic facilities , boat ramps , paddle boats , concessions , [MASK]nd fishing . Along with[MASK]the lakes , the Bon[MASK]ta Lakes area includes Bonita Lakes Mall[MASK], Bonita Lakes Crossing[MASK], and Bonita Lakes Plaza . Okatibbee Lake is a [MASK] @[MASK]@ 150 @-@ acre ( 28 @.@ 9 km2 ) establishment containing a [MASK] @,@ 14[MASK] @[MASK]@ acre ( 16 @.@ 77 km2 ) lake which offers boating , fishing , swimming , wat[MASK]r skiing , picnicking , hunti[MASK]g , hikin[MASK] and camping . Splashdown Country Water Park , a 25 @-@ room motel , and cabins are located on the lake . 
 Since 1992 , Meridian has been a host of the State Games of Mississippi , a statewide annu[MASK]l multi @-@ sport event modeled after the Olympic Ga[MASK]es . The organization is [MASK] member of the National Congress of Sta[MASK]e Games , which is affiliated with the U.S. Olympic Committee .[MASK]In its first year 1 @,@ 200 athletes competed in twelve sports , and sin[MASK]e then over 70 @,@ [MASK]00 athletes have participated in the Games . In 2009 , more than 4500 athletes participated in 27 sports . All competitors in the games can compete in the Southeast Sports[MASK]Festival while medalists may m[MASK]ve up to[MASK]the bi @-@ annual State Games of America .[MASK]
 Originally the games were held in one weekend in Jun[MASK] , but as [MASK]ore sports were adde[MASK] , the even[MASK] was expanded to two weekends . Open[MASK]ng ceremonies always begin on the 3rd Friday o[MASK][MASK]June in downtown Meridian . The games are h[MASK]ld a[MASK] several sports parks , including Northeast Park , Sammie Davidson Complex , and other various fields throughout the city . Northeast Park is an 85 @-@ acre ( 34 ha ) park on Highway 39 that contains ten tennis courts , four softball fields , three soccer fields , an asphalt track [MASK] a[MASK]d a large picnic pa[MASK]ilion[MASK]. The Sammie D[MASK]vidson Sports Complex includes six tenn[MASK]s courts , four softball fields , and a half @-@ mile track . Other sports fields include the Meridian Jaycee Soccer Compl[MASK]x , Sykes Park , and Phil Hardin Park . 
 There are also several golf[MASK]courses in the city , including the aforementioned Lakeview Municipal Golf Course , an 1[MASK] @-@ hole cour[MASK]e open to the public daily . Briarwood County Club , locat[MASK]d[MASK]on Highway 39 North , i[MASK] a privat[MASK] club with golf , swimming , fi[MASK]hing , [MASK]nd dining facilities . Other golf courses serving the city include Northwood Country Club , Okatibbee Creek Golf [MASK]enter ,[MASK]and Ponta Creek Golf Cours[MASK] . 
 
 = = Transportation = = 
 
 
 = = = Rail[MASK]oads and [MASK]ublic transit = = = 
 
 Amtrak 's Crescent line connects Meridian with the cities o[MASK] New York [MASK] New York ; Philadelphia[MASK], Pennsylvania ; Baltimore , M[MASK]ryland ; Washington ,[MASK]D.C. ; Charl[MASK]tte , North Carolina ; Atlanta , Georgia ; [MASK]irmingham , [MASK]labama ; and New Orleans , L[MASK]uisiana . The Union Station Multi @-@ Mod[MASK]l Transportation Center ( MMTC ) is located at 1901 Front Street , part of the Meridian Downtown Historic District , which is listed on the National Re[MASK]ister o[MASK] Historic[MASK]Places . Originally built in 1906 , but later demolished in 1966 then rebuilt in [MASK]997 ,[MASK]t[MASK]e station includes several modes of transportation including the Meridian Tr[MASK]nsit System , Amtrak , Norfolk Southern rail corri[MASK]or , Greyhound buses , Trailways and other providers of transit services . The number of passengers on Amtrak trains , Greyhound buses , and Meridian Transit Sys[MASK]em buses averages 242 @,@ 360 per year . 
[MASK]
 = = = Air = = = 
[MASK]
 The city is served by Meridian Regional Airport , located at Key Field , 2811 Airport Boulevard [MASK]outh , 3 mi ( 4 @.@ 8 km ) southwest of the city . At [MASK]0 @,@ 004 foot ( [MASK] @,@ 049 m ) , the ai[MASK]port 's [MASK]unway is the longest public runway in [MASK]ississippi . The airport , which has b[MASK]en in service since 1930 , offers daily flights to Dallas / Fort Worth , TX . 
 Duri[MASK]g the Great Depression , residents of the city contemplated abandoning the airport because of the[MASK]cost of maintenance , but in 1935 [MASK]rothers Fred and Al [MASK]ey , man[MASK]g[MASK]rs of the airport , thought of a way to keep the[MASK]airport operating . From June 4 until July 1 , 1935 , the brothers flew over the city in their plane ,[MASK][MASK]he " Ole Miss . " The record they established in their 27 days aloft , totaling 653 hours and 34 minutes , a[MASK]tracted enough publicity and funds to the city to keep[MASK]the airport running . Key Field is t[MASK]erefore named after the brothe[MASK]s , whose flight endurance [MASK]ecord remains unbroken in conventional flight . 
 
 = = = Highways = = = 
 
 Interstate Highways 
 Inte[MASK]state 20 
 Runs west through Jackso[MASK] , Mississippi , eventually terminating near Kent , Texas , and east through Tuscaloosa , Alabama , eventually terminating in Florence , South Carolina [MASK] Interstate 59 
 Joins with I @-@ 20 in the city an[MASK] runs north through Tuscaloosa , Alabama , ending in Wildwo[MASK]d , Georgia [MASK] It also runs south through Hattiesburg , Mississippi , and on to Slidell , Louisiana . 
 U[MASK]S.[MASK]Highways 
 U.S. Highway 11 
 Runs parallel to Interstate 59 so[MASK]th to New Orleans , Louisiana , and north[MASK]all the way to the Canada – US border . U.S. Highway 45 
 Transnational route which runs [MASK]o[MASK]t[MASK] through Columbus , Mississippi , to the US @-@ Canada border and south through Quitman , Mis[MASK]issippi , to Mobile , Alabama , and [MASK]he Gulf of Mexico . [MASK].S. Hig[MASK]way 80 
 Runs west through Jackson , Mississippi , to Dallas , Texas , and east through Demopolis , A[MASK]abama , all the way to Tybee Island , Georgia and the Atlantic Ocean . [MASK] State Highways 
 Mississippi Highway 19 [MASK] Runs north to West , Mississippi , and south to the Mississi[MASK]pi @-@ Alabama border , where it continues as Alabama State Route 10 . Mississippi Highway 39 
 Begins in Meridian and runs [MASK]orth to Shuqualak , Mississippi . Mississip[MASK]i Highway 145 
 Formerly US 45 , but [MASK]ow o[MASK]ly exists as an alternate route in several cit[MASK]es . Mississippi Highway 4[MASK]3 
 Begins in Meridian an[MASK] runs north to Lynville , Mississipp[MASK] . 
 
 = = Education = = 
 
 Early public education in Meridian was based on the 1870 Mississip[MASK]i Constitution . From 1870 to 1885 , trustees appointed by the City Council served on the Board of School Directors , which had authority to operate the schools . Although there were sever[MASK]l schools in th[MASK] city b[MASK]fore 1884 , they were privately owned and on[MASK]y enrolled about 400 students . The city did not build its first publicly owned school until September 1884 . The first public school f[MASK]r blacks in the city was held in facilities rented from St. Pa[MASK]l Methodist C[MASK]u[MASK]ch . The Mississippi Legislature amended the city chart[MASK]r in January 1888 to allow the city to maintain its[MASK]own municipal school district , a[MASK]d in March[MASK]of the same year $ 30 @,@ 000 in bonds was approved for the city to bui[MASK]d new public schools . From this bond , the Wechsler School was built in 1894 , becoming the first brick public school building in the state built for blacks . 
 From this early district and later additions , the Meridian Public School District grew to its current [MASK]ize , which now includes six elementary schools , 3 middle schools , and 3 high schools [MASK] The city also contains [MASK]everal private schools including Lamar School , Calvary Christia[MASK] School , Co[MASK]m[MASK]nity Christian School , and St. Patrick 's Catholic School .[MASK]The campus of Meridi[MASK]n High School [MASK] the main high school in the district , occupies 37 acres ( 15 h[MASK] ) , including six buildings and 111 classrooms . The school is made up of grades 10 @-@ 12 and enrolls approximately 1 @,@ 500 students . 
 Meridian is home to two post @-@ secondary educational [MASK]nstitutions . Meridian Community College , founded in 1937 , is located at 910 Highway 19[MASK]N and offers free tuition for four semes[MASK]ers to graduates from the Meridian Public and Lauderdale County School Districts as well as homeschooled children who reside[MASK]inside Lauderdale County . Originally known as Meridian Junior College and located at Meridian [MASK]igh School , the colleg[MASK] moved to its present location in 1965 . Af[MASK]er[MASK]desegregation laws were passed , MJC merged wi[MASK]h T.J. Harris Junior College in 1970 [MASK] which had previously enrolled African @-@ American st[MASK]dents . The name change from Meridian Junior College to Meridian Community Co[MASK]lege took place In 1987 " to more accurately reflect the di[MASK]ersity of opportunities it pr[MASK]vides for a growing community area . " Missi[MASK]sippi State University also opera[MASK]es a campus in the city . As o[MASK] the Fall 20[MASK]8 semester , 763 students from 33 counties throughout the state and several in Alabama attended the college . 
 Meridi[MASK]n is served by the Me[MASK]idian @-@ Lauderdale County Public Library , loca[MASK]ed at the corner of 7th [MASK]treet and 26th Avenue . The city originally had tw[MASK] Carnegie libraries , both buil[MASK] in 1913 – one for blacks a[MASK]d one f[MASK]r whites . A group of women had formed the Fortnightly Book and Magazine Club in the 1880s and began raising money to build a library for the city . The[MASK]books they collected and share[MASK] within the club were later t[MASK]e basis of the library collection for Meridian .[MASK]With wide support for the library , the club enlisted Israel Marks , a city leader , to approach the national philanthr[MASK][MASK]ist Andrew[MASK]Carne[MASK]ie for funding[MASK][MASK]ssistance . The library for [MASK]lacks was built at 13th Street [MASK]nd 28th Avenue on land donated by St. Paul Methodist Church , and the lib[MASK]ary for whites was established in a building originally owned by members of the First Presbyteri[MASK]n Church of Meridian , who sold it to the city on Septembe[MASK] 25 , 1911 . The African American library was the onl[MASK] library for blacks in t[MASK]e state until after World War I and is the only Carnegie library ever built for African Ame[MASK]icans in the country . The two libraries served the city until [MASK]967 , when the institutions became integrated because of the Civil Rights Act [MASK]f 1964 , combined their collections , and moved al[MASK] materials to their[MASK]current location . The former white library was renov[MASK]ted and[MASK]converted into the Meridian Museum[MASK]of Art in 1970 , and the former African @-@ American library was demolis[MASK]ed on May 28 , 2008 . 
 
 = = Media = = 
 
 The[MASK]only daily newspaper printed in the city is The Meridian Star , which has been in operat[MASK]on since 1898 . The paper was originally named The Evening [MASK]t[MASK]r but was renamed in 1915 and has been Meridian 's[MASK]only daily newspaper since 1921 . With a[MASK]daily circulation of about 12 @,@ 000 in March 2010 , the paper serves Lauderdale County as well as adjacent portions of western Alabama and eastern Mississippi . 
 Though the Meridian Star is now the only newspaper printed in the city , there have been a few oth[MASK]r historical newspapers . One such pape[MASK] is the M[MASK]mo Digest , a ten to twenty page publicati[MASK]n published during the 1970[MASK] . The Di[MASK]est focused on issues relevant[MASK]to the African @-@ American population of the region , gathering a circulation of about 5 @,@ 000 people . Other newspapers in the city have inclu[MASK]ed The Colored[MASK]Mess[MASK]nger , The State , The Weekly Mercu[MASK]y , The Blade , Weekly Echo , Fair Play , He[MASK]dlight , Meridian Morning Sun , Teacher and Preacher , and Clarion . 
 The city is the principal city in the Meridian , Mississippi Designated Market Area ( DMA ) , which includes 72 @,@ [MASK]80 househo[MASK]ds with televisions . WTOK @-@ TV broadcasts as an ABC affiliate from the city , headquartered at 8[MASK]5 23rd Avenue . WTOK operates two digital [MASK]ubchannels , WTOK [MASK]-@ DT2 , a MyNetworkTV affiliate , and WTOK @-@ DT3 , Meridian 's CW .[MASK]WGBC @-@ TV , the market 's NBC affiliate , is hea[MASK]q[MASK]artered at 1151 Crestview Circle . Since January 5 , 2009 , WGBC has also been the market 's FOX affi[MASK]iate , and it also features some programming fro[MASK] the Retro Television Network ( RTN ) . WGBC[MASK]op[MASK]rates under a program services agreement with WMDN @-@ [MASK]V , the market 's CBS affiliate which operates a local AccuWeather service on its second subchannel . WMAW @-@ TV is the local affiliate of Mississippi Public [MASK]roadcasting . 
 The city is also the principal city in the Me[MASK]idian Arbitron Radio Market , which include[MASK] 64 @,@ 500 people over the a[MASK]e of 12 . WJXM ( FM 105 @.@ 7 ) , headquartered at 3436 Highway 45 North , takes the largest share of ratings in the mark[MASK]t at 14 @.@ 8 % in Fall 2009 . In the same period , WZKS ( FM 104 @.@ 1 ) was second with[MASK]11[MASK]@.@ 1 % , and WMOX ( AM 1010 ) was third with 7 @.@ 4 % . Other popular [MASK]tations[MASK]i[MASK] the market include WUCL ( FM 97 @.@ 9 ) , WOKK ( FM 97 @.@ 1 ) ,[MASK]WEXR ( FM 106 @.@ 9 ) , WYHL ([MASK][MASK]M 1450 ) , and WKZB ( FM 95 @.@ 1 ) . Mississippi Public Broadcast[MASK]ng can be found [MASK]n WMAW @-@ FM ( FM 88 @.@ 1 ) .

 = = = In acting = = = 
 
 Alvin Childress , who played the lead role in the Amos ' n ' Andy Show , was born in[MASK]th[MASK] city in 1907 . 
 Diane Ladd was also born in the city in 1932 @,@  
 Sela Ward was born in Meridi[MASK]n , in 1956 . 
 
 = = = In business and politics = = = 
 
 Gil Carmichael , Meridian businessman and transportati[MASK]n sp[MASK]cialist , was the Republican nominee for the Mississippi Senate in 1966 and 1967 , U.S. Senate in 1972 , governor in 1975 and 1979 , and lieutenant governor in 1983 . 
 Winfield Dunn , former Governor of Tenne[MASK]see , lived in[MASK]Meridia[MASK] 
 John Fle[MASK]ing , current U.S. Representative for Louisiana 's 4th congr[MASK]ssional district lived in Meridian ; 
 The late Lieutenant Governor Carroll Gartin , who was born in Meridi[MASK]n , lived in Laurel ; 
 Lewis McAllister[MASK], a businessman in[MASK]Tuscaloosa , Alabama , was the first Republican to serve in the Mississippi House of Represe[MASK]tatives since [MASK]econstruction , 1962 @-@ 1968 ; he r[MASK]sided in Meridian prior to 1971 . 
 Gillespie V. Montgomery , former U.S. Representative , lived in Meridian 
 Hartley Peavey , founder of Peavey Elec[MASK]ronics which is headqua[MASK]tere[MASK] in Meridian , is a Meridian native . 
 Tom Stuart from 1973 to 1977[MASK]was the first Republican to serve as mayor of Meridian in the 20th century .

 = = = In l[MASK]terature and comics = = = 
 
 Novelist Edwin Granberry , who won the 1932 O.[MASK]Henry Award for Best S[MASK]ort Short Story , was[MASK]born in Meridian . For[MASK]30 years ,[MASK]Granberry wrote the Buz Sawyer comic strip . Meridian is the birthplace of novelist and short story writer Barry[MASK]Hannah . 
 
 = = = In music = = = 
 
 Classical composer John Lut[MASK]er Adams is a Meridian native . 
 The Isl[MASK]nd Def Jam r[MASK]pper Big K.R.I.T. w[MASK]s born in Meridian . K.R.I.T is [MASK]nown for his[MASK]many mixtapes and albums such as K.R.I.T. Wuz Here a[MASK]d Cadillactica . He has gained[MASK]a large following for his lyricism and sel[MASK] @-@ produced beats as well as his ability to change his style on songs from slow and cons[MASK]ious tracks ( " The Vent " ) to fiery and upbeat tracks ( " Mt . Olympus " ) . 
 The guitarist @-@ songwriter George Cummings [MASK] born in Meridian in 1938 , was[MASK]a founding member of Dr. Hook & the Medicine Show . 
 Paul Davis , a singer @-@ songwriter best known for the late 1970s and early 1980s pop hits " I Go Crazy " and " ' 65 Love Affair[MASK]" ,[MASK]was bo[MASK]n in Meridian in 1948 ; [MASK]fter retiring from the music [MASK]usiness , he returned to the city [MASK]here he remained until a fatal heart attack in 2008 . 
 Chris Ethridge ( February 10 , 1947 – April 23 , 2012 ) was an American c[MASK]untry rock bass guitarist . He was a member [MASK]f the Inte[MASK]national Submarine Band ( I[MASK]B ) [MASK]nd The Flying Burrito Brothers , and he co @-@ wrote several songs with Gram Parsons . Ethridge worked with Jackson Browne , Judy [MASK]ollins , Ry Cooder , Whitney Houston , Willie Nelson , Randy Newman , Linda Ronstadt , Leon Russell , Nan[MASK]y Sinatra , Johnny Winter , and The Byrds . 
 Th[MASK] singer @-@ songwriter Stev[MASK] Forbert was born in Meridian in 1954 . 
 Ji[MASK]mie Rodgers , the " Father of Country Music " , was born in th[MASK] city in 1897 . The Jimmie Rodgers Museum is located in Meridian , and the Jimmie Rodgers Fe[MASK]tival has been an annual Meridian event since[MASK]1953 .

 George Soulé , the singer @[MASK]@ songwriter most famous for the[MASK]rhythm and blues anthem " Get Involved " , is a resident of Meridian , where he was born in 1945 . 
 Hayley Williams , lead singer of the band Paramore , was a[MASK]so born in the city in 1988 . 
 Singer Al Wilson ,[MASK]born [MASK]n June 1939 , was a Meridian native .
