 = = Charts = = 
 
 
 = = Certi[MASK]ications = = 
 
 
 [MASK] = High Five Interchange[MASK]= 
 
[MASK]The High Fi[MASK]e Interchange is one of the first five @-@ level[MASK]stack interchanges bui[MASK]t in Dallas , Texas . Located [MASK]t the junction of[MASK]the Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway ( Interstate 6[MASK]5 , I @-@ 635 )[MASK]and the Central Expressway ( US Highway 75 , US 75 [MASK] , it replaces an antiquated partial clove[MASK]leaf interchange constructed in the 1960s . 
 The $ 261 m[MASK]llion project was st[MASK]rted in 2002 and completed in December 2005 . It was designed by the HNTB Corporation and built by Zachry Con[MASK]truction Corporation . 
 The interchange is considered by Popular Mechanics to be one of " The World [MASK]s 18 Strangest Roadways " because of its height [MASK] as high as a 12 @-@ story building ) , its 4[MASK] permanent bridges and other unusual design and constructi[MASK]n features . In 2006 , the American Public Works Association named the High Five Interchange as " Public Works Proj[MASK]cts of the Year " .[MASK]
 
 = = Description = = 
 
 The Hig[MASK] Five Interchange , north of downtown in Dallas , Texas , is a massive five @-@ level freeway interchange . It is the junction of two major highways[MASK]carrying heavy rush hour traffic , the Lyndon B. Johnson[MASK]Freeway ( [MASK]nterstate 635 ) and the Central Expressway ( US 75 [MASK] , and is the first five @-@ le[MASK]el[MASK]stack interchange to be built in the city . 
 It replaces the antiquated three @-@ level , modified cloverleaf interchange bui[MASK]t in the 1960s that caused a sev[MASK]re bottleneck by narrowing US 75 down to two lanes at the[MASK]junction of the two highways . The looped ramps of the cloverleaf force[MASK] motorists to slow[MASK]down drastically , backing up traffic . Left @-@ [MASK]and exits contri[MASK]uted to the congestion . Further , its [MASK]wo frontage roads were not directly connected to each other , making local access [MASK]ifficult . 
 Al[MASK]udi[MASK]g to the cel[MASK]bratory gesture , the " High Five " name refers to the five flyover ramps handling the l[MASK]ft @-@ turn movements tha[MASK] tower over t[MASK]e landscape . The interchange is as high as [MASK] 12 @-@ story building [MASK] and includes 43 bridges [MASK]pread across five levels ( the " High Five " ) [MASK] 710 support tiers , and 6[MASK] mile[MASK] of addit[MASK]onal highway . The highest ramps are 120 feet ( 37 m ) above ground . The[MASK]lanes of US 75 , which are on the bottom level , a[MASK]e 20 feet ( 6 m )[MASK]below ground level , giving the structure a total height of 140 feet from [MASK]ottom to top As[MASK]part of the proj[MASK]ct , I @-@ 635 was widened to include four dedicated high @-@ occupancy vehicle[MASK]lanes ( HOV lanes ) that are barrier @-@ s[MASK]parated and reversible . 
 The roads on the five levels are : 
 Level I : U[MASK] 75 ,[MASK]an eight lane highw[MASK]y , four lanes going each way 
 Level II : The jun[MASK]tion of the two six @-@ lane[MASK]frontag[MASK][MASK]roads , each having three through lanes in each direction , left @-@ turn lanes and turnarounds , and easy access to US [MASK]5 and I @-@ 635 
 Level III : I @-@ 635 , ten regular lanes , five going each way , and four HOV lane[MASK] ( two going each way ) separated by barriers 
 Level[MASK][MASK]V and V : Direct connection r[MASK]mps ( two levels ) , eliminating the left exits o[MASK] the modifi[MASK]d cloverleaf 
 The interchange , with its decorati[MASK]e etchings on precast[MASK][MASK]oncrete elements , along with the visually appealing coloration specified by the Texas Depar[MASK]ment of Transportation ( TxDOT ) , [MASK]a[MASK] be regarded as an enormou[MASK] work of public art . The High Five als[MASK] inco[MASK]porates a hi[MASK]ing[MASK]and bike trai[MASK] , named the Cottonwood Trail , which runs under all l[MASK]vels of the interchange . The section of the trail passing beneath the interchange was constructed as part of the High Fiv[MASK] project[MASK]by TxDOT . 
 The[MASK]interchange is considered by Popular Mechanics[MASK]as one [MASK]f " The World 's 18 Strangest Roadways " , calling it a " laby[MASK][MASK]nth of lanes " and a " five[MASK]@-@ level marvel of engineer[MASK]ng " because of its height , the number of its bridges and other unusual design and construction [MASK]eatures . 
 [MASK] = = History = = 
 
 The High Five Interchange project was planned as a replacement for the existing ,[MASK]antiquated interchange that accommod[MASK]ted 5[MASK]0 @,@ 000 vehicles daily and was located in one of the most inten[MASK]ely develo[MASK]ed commercial zones in Dallas . It was a collaborat[MASK]ve project between the TxDOT , affecte[MASK] motorists and property owners , and the primary contractor ,[MASK]Zachry Construction . An essential consideration was to complete the project with as little disru[MASK]tion to the traffic flow as[MASK]possible . 
 Reasons for upgra[MASK]ing the interchange , in[MASK]addition to the need to increase traffic fl[MASK]w and reduce congestion , were to improve air quality , safety , and local access . 
 Zachry Construction Corporation submitted [MASK]he lowest bid and was awarded the $ 261 million contract by TxDOT , the l[MASK]rgest ever by that agency . The co[MASK]struction contract for the High Five Interchang[MASK] was unique in tha[MASK] it contained elements not found in other construction project contracts . For example , it s[MASK]ecified the concrete maturity me[MASK]hod to be used to ensure the concrete 's strength [MASK][MASK]the first time TxDOT had ever done so ) , and containe[MASK] an early completion bonus , a sliding scale of up to $ 11 million if the company completed [MASK]he contract within four years . Also bui[MASK]t into the construction con[MASK]ract was a provision that Zachry was charged for " [MASK]ane[MASK]rentals " by TxDOT for time they clos[MASK]d down traffic lanes —[MASK]fees ba[MASK]ed o[MASK] hourly asse[MASK]sments and[MASK]the time[MASK]of day the lane was[MASK][MASK]losed . The fees ranged[MASK]from $ 50 to a high of $ 110 @,@ 000 for rush h[MASK]urs . In order not[MASK]to interfere with traffic f[MASK]ow during construction , the new interchange was de[MASK]igned largely as elevated flyover ramps and viaducts so they could be built high over the existing junction lanes [MASK] once traffic was transferred to the new structures the old lanes could simply be closed off and removed . Little of the original interchange remained when the project was finished . 
 To save time and money , innovative construction methods were emplo[MASK]ed : The original p[MASK]ans called for the segments of the lon[MASK] ramps and spans ( used to direct @-@ connect roads ) to be made of ste[MASK]l , but because building with s[MASK]eel would interfere with heavy traffic flow during construction , cast @-@ in @-@ place segmental concrete was subs[MASK]ituted in the plans . Howeve[MASK] , Zachry decided to use precast concrete s[MASK]gmental bridges ,[MASK]rather than casting the bridge elements in place , and used a unique m[MASK]chine , designed and constructed by Deal S.R.L. of Italy and c[MASK][MASK]ting about $ 1 million , to [MASK]ove the pieces into place . 
 During the construction , 2 @.@ 2 million cubic yards of earthwork was used , 350 @,@ 000 cubic yards of concrete was mixed on site , and 30[MASK] @,@ 000 square feet of retaining walls were built . Additionally , 40 @,@ 000 feet of drilled shafts and 75 @,@ 000 linear feet of drainage pipe were completed . In addition to the construction of 43 permanent br[MASK]dges , six temporary bridges were built , resulting in 2 @.@ 3 million square feet of bridge [MASK]eck . 
 The project w[MASK]s designed by the HNTB Corporation who provided professional engineering consultation throughout the construction , w[MASK]ich had begun in 2002 and was completed in December[MASK]2005 , more than 13 months sooner than planned . 
 
 = = Awards [MASK] = 
 
 In 2006 , the American Public Works Association named the High Five " Public Works Project of the Year " f[MASK]r its massive size , its innovative design , the complexity and rapidity of its construction and the need it fulfilled for the community . TxDOT as the manag[MASK]ng agency , Zachry Construction Corporation as the primary contractor , and [MASK]NTB Corp[MASK]ration as the primary consult[MASK]nt rec[MASK]ived the award in recogniti[MASK]n of their cooperative alliance in completing the project . 
 
 
 = Tim Richmond = 
 
 Tim Richmond ( June 7 , 1955 – August 13 , 1989 ) was an American race car driver from Ashland , Ohio .[MASK]He competed in IndyCar racing before transferring to NASCAR 's W[MASK]nst[MASK]n Cup Series ( now Sprint Cup Series ) [MASK] Richmond was one of the first drivers[MASK]to change from ope[MASK] wheel racing to NASCAR stock cars full @-@ time , which has since become an industry trend . He won the 1980 Indianapolis 500 Rookie of the Year award and had 13 victories during eight NASCAR seasons . 
 Richmond achieved his top NASCAR season in 1986 when he finished third in points . He won seven races that season , more than any other driver on the tour . When he missed the season @-@ opening Daytona 500 in Fe[MASK]ruary 1987 , media reported that he had pneumonia . The infectio[MASK] most likely r[MASK]sulted from his compromised immune system ,[MASK]which was weakened by AIDS . Despite the state of his health , Richmond competed in eight r[MASK]ces in 1987 , winning two events and one pole position before his final race[MASK]in August of that ye[MASK]r . He attempted a comeback in 1988 befor[MASK] NASCAR I banned him for testing positiv[MASK] for excessive OTC ( over the counter ) drugs , Ibuprofen and P[MASK]eudoephedrine ; NASCAR later announced they [MASK]ave Tim Richmond a new test and tested negative . Tim Richmond filed a lawsuit against NASCAR after NASCAR insisted they wanted access to his entire medical record before they would reins[MASK]a[MASK]e him , after losing the lawsu[MASK]t , Richmond withdrew from racing . NASCAR later stated their original test was a " Bad Test . " 
 Richmond grew up in a wealthy family [MASK]nd lived a freewheeling lifestyle , earnin[MASK] him the nickname " [MASK]ollywood " . In describing Richmond 's influence in racing , Charlotte Moto[MASK] Speedway president Humpy Wheeler said : " W[MASK] 've never had a race driver like Tim in s[MASK]ock car racing . He was almost a James Dean @-@ like character . " When Richm[MASK]nd[MASK]was cast for a bit p[MASK]rt in the 1983 movie Stroker Ace , " He fell right in with the group working on the fil[MASK] , " said[MASK]director Hal Need[MASK]am . C[MASK]le Trickle , the main character in the movie Days of Thunder , played by Tom Cruise , was loosely based [MASK]n Richmond and his interaction with Harry Hyde and Rick Hendrick . 
 
 = = Early life [MASK] = 
 
 Richmond[MASK]grew up in Ashland , Ohio . His parents , Al and E[MASK]elyn ( née Warner ) Richmond , met in the course o[MASK] their work . Al was a welder for pipe construction companies and Eve[MASK]yn was a field office manager . Noticing that highw[MASK]y crews had to dig up the entire highway to l[MASK]y [MASK]ipe , Al designed a machine to bore underneath the highway . To market[MASK]this invent[MASK]on , he founded Richmon[MASK] Manufact[MASK]ring , which ev[MASK]ntually exported machines worldwide . 
 Tim 's dri[MASK]in[MASK] days started as a toddler when he was given a go @-@ kart that he often drove inside buildings and across his lawn . He later raced the kart at tracks in Moreland and New P[MASK]ttsburg . Richmond grew up in a [MASK]e[MASK]l @-@ to @-@ do family , and was sometimes therefore treated differently by his classmates , so his parents enrolled him in Miami Mil[MASK]tary [MASK]cademy in Miami , Florida . D[MASK]ring his years in Miami ,[MASK]Tim and his mother moved to Flori[MASK]a and his father stayed in Ohio . While home in Ohio over a summer break , he[MASK]met local dra[MASK] racer Ra[MASK]mond Beadle through lifelong friend Fred Miller . When Richmond reached [MASK]ge 16 , his pa[MASK]ents purchased[MASK]him a Pontiac Trans Am , a speedboat and a Piper Cherokee airplane for his birthday . Yet his mother Evelyn often worried about spoiling her only son . She once said , " Tim was laz[MASK] ... " , and " ... I did eve[MASK]ything for him . [MASK] ruined him , I admit it . He was my whole life . " 
 Richmond excelled in sports ; he set a conference record in high hurdles and his high school football career was stellar enough that the academy retired his sports jersey after his gridiron [MASK]ays were over . Mia[MASK]i Military Academy named him Athlete of the Year in 1970 . Richmond 's other interests in[MASK]luded flying , and he earned his [MASK]rivate pilot licen[MASK]e at age 16 . Follo[MASK]ing high school graduation , Richmond attended Ashlan[MASK] University for about one year before dropping out . 
 
 = = Racing career =[MASK]= 
 
 
 = = = Open wheel racing = = = 
 
 A friend of Richmond 's father co @-@ owned a sprint car and Richmond joined the team as a crew member for Dave Shoemaker . In 1976 , 21 @-@ year @-@ old Richmond took th[MASK] car onto La[MASK]eville Speedway at Lakeville , Ohio for some practice laps . " Somebody put a stopwatch on me , " Richmond said . " I was running laps faster [MASK]han Dave had been . It was[MASK]the first time I had ever driven a race car . " Richmond and his father found a red , white[MASK]and [MASK]lue @-@ colored No. 98 car in Pennsylvania , which was [MASK]he same number and paint scheme that Richmond used on model cars as a child . In his first competition at the track , officials placed Richmond in the slowest heat . He passed several cars before spinning out and breaking an axle . Although he[MASK]made se[MASK]eral attempts to get the car poin[MASK]ed in the right directio[MASK] , the broken axle prevented the ca[MASK] from driving straight . After being towed to[MASK]the pits , he parked the car for the rest of the event . Later that season , they towed th[MASK] ca[MASK] to Eldora Spe[MASK]dway , only to have Richmond crash the car again . In response , Richmond 's father fired him as the driver . The next season , Al Richmond bought a SuperModified bet[MASK]er suited to his[MASK]so[MASK] 's driving style . In 1977 Tim [MASK]ichmond becam[MASK] both Sandusky Speedway 's Rookie o[MASK] the[MASK]Year and the SuperModi[MASK]ied class track champion . 
 Richmond returned to racing sprint cars in the United States Automobile Club 's ( USAC ) national [MASK]print car tour[MASK]in 1978 . Compet[MASK]ng in 12 races , he finished 30th in points as the series ' Rookie of the Year . That yea[MASK] he attended Jim Russell 's road racing school [MASK]t Willow Springs International Motorsports Park , setting a student course reco[MASK]d . Richmond raced in a 1978 Mini Indy car event at Phoenix Internat[MASK]onal Raceway , winning t[MASK]e Formula Super Vee support event in a Lola T620 . The win attra[MASK]ted sponsors and attention from major owners like Ro[MASK]er Penske . He also competed in USAC 's Silver Crown series . 
 Richmond 's father bought an Eagle Indy Car chassis and an Offenhauser engine for the 1979 race [MASK]t Michigan International Speedway . Richmond qualified 21st fastest with a [MASK]75 @.@ 768 mph ( 282 @.@ 871 km / h ) lap , s[MASK]gnificantly slower than Bobby Unser 's [MASK]03 @.@ 879 mph ( 328 @.@ 111 km / h ) po[MASK]e position [MASK]peed . The race ended for him when his motor blew up on the fourth lap , and he finished last ( 23rd ) . Owner Pat Santello was looking for a driver to replace Larry Rice f[MASK]r his CART team [MASK]t the following race at Watkins Glen International , so he gave Richmond a test at Willow Spring where he had previously set the student record . Santello hired Richmond , who then qualified 15th fastest for the event and fin[MASK]shed[MASK]in eighth place , the best of his IndyCar career . Richmond raced in three more events that season . 
 After crashing during the first day [MASK]f qualifying fo[MASK] the 1980 Indianapolis 500 [MASK] Richmond [MASK]evertheless[MASK]obtained the 19th starting position in the race . He worked his way up[MASK]to the[MASK]top 10 during the race , led a lap , and finished ninth as he ran out of fuel at the end [MASK]f th[MASK] race . To[MASK][MASK]he delight of the crowd , winner Johnny Rutherford gave him a ride back to the [MASK]its . He was named the 1980 Indianapolis 500 Rookie of the Year . " I busted up[MASK]a few Indy cars right after that , " he said . " Milwaukee , Mid @-@ Ohio . . . at Michigan I cut one in two . I was afraid my racing career would come to a halt . So when I got an offer to drive stock cars , I took it , and it turned out I liked driving them better . " 
 
 = = = NASCAR = = = 
 
 P[MASK]cono Raceway President Joseph Mattioli III convi[MASK]ced Richmond to make the change to stock car racing on the NASCAR circuit . Richmond mad[MASK] his first NASCAR start two months after winning the Indianapolis 500 R[MASK]okie of the Year award . He debut[MASK]d at the Coca @-@ Cola 500 at Pocono o[MASK] July 27 , 1980 [MASK] finishing 12th in a D. K. Ulrich @-@ owned Chevrolet . That season , he competed in five events [MASK] with two DNFs ( [MASK]id not finish ) and three 12th @-@ place finishes . Overall , he fini[MASK]hed the 1980 season 41st[MASK]in points . 
 Richmond raced for three teams in 1981 . He started the season by competing in 15 events for Ulrich . He had his first career top 10 finish , taking sixth place at Talladega Superspeedw[MASK]y , soon followed by a se[MASK]enth @-@[MASK]place[MASK]finish at Tex[MASK]s W[MASK]rld Speedway . After Kennie Childers hired him away from Ulrich mid @-@ season , Richm[MASK]nd had top 10 finishes at Pocono and Bristol . For the fi[MASK]al seven rac[MASK]s of the season[MASK], he[MASK]drove for Bob Rogers and had a top 10 finish at Dover International Speedway . Overall for the season , Richmond [MASK]ad six top 10 finishes to place 16th in season points . 
 Richmond sta[MASK]ted 1982 without a r[MASK]de before getti[MASK]g a one @-@ race deal to [MASK]rive for Billie Harv[MASK]y at th[MASK] Rockingham track . Richmond completed 112 laps of the 492 @-@ lap event to finish 31st , reti[MASK]ing from the race with engine problems . For the following event , Richmond was hired to drive J.D. Stacy 's No. 2 car . In his first race for the team , Richmond earned his fir[MASK]t career top 5 finish when he placed fifth at Darlington Raceway . Returning to Pocono , he finished second , before winning his [MASK]irst race on the road course at Riverside , California the fol[MASK]owing week . Later that[MASK]season , he earned his first pole positio[MASK] at Bristol . The tour returned to Riversi[MASK]e for the final race of the season where Richmond won his second race , [MASK]wee[MASK]ing both events at the track . Benny Parsons said that " watching Richmond go through the Esses was unbelievable " . For[MASK]the season , Richmond had twelve to[MASK] 10s , two wins , a[MASK]d one pole to finish 26th in points . 
 In 1983 , Richmond began racing for Raymo[MASK]d Beadle wh[MASK]m he had known before he star[MASK]ed racing . He returned to the three @-@ cornered Pocono racetr[MASK]ck , earni[MASK]g [MASK]is first oval victory . During the[MASK]season , he accumulated four pole positions ( Darlington , Pocono , Charlotte , and [MASK]tlanta ) , one win ( Pocono ) , and fifteen top 10s on his way to [MASK]inishing tenth in season points . He made his first appearance in a NASCAR Busch Series ( now Nationwide Series ) car , but did not finis[MASK] any of the three races he entered that season . 
 Esquire magazine n[MASK]med Richmond as one of[MASK]" the best of the new[MASK]generation " in 1984 . That year he had one win at North Wilkesboro Speedway and second @-@ place finishes at Dover , Darlingt[MASK]n and Rivers[MASK]de . Richmond finished the 1984 season 12th in points , w[MASK]th 11[MASK]finishes in the top 10 and in six in the top 5 . In 1985 , the final season that Richmond competed for Beadle , his best finish was a second @-@ place run at [MASK]ristol . He ended the season 11th in p[MASK]ints with[MASK]13 Top 10s in 28 races . In the Busch Ser[MASK]es , he q[MASK]alified at[MASK]the pole position in the two races he entered , [MASK]nd won the Charlotte race . 
 Ric[MASK]mon[MASK] joined Hendrick Motorsport[MASK] in 1986 , where he teamed up with veteran crew c[MASK][MASK]ef Harry Hyde [MASK] It took the team until the middle of th[MASK] season to ge[MASK] . Rich[MASK]ond had suffered a 64 @-@ race winless streak[MASK]that was finally broken at the Van Scoy Diamond M[MASK]ne 500 at Pocono in June 1986 . After two straigh[MASK] secon[MASK] @-@ pla[MASK]e finishes at Charlotte and Riverside , Richmond started the Pocono event in [MASK][MASK]ird[MASK]place inside the second row . That race saw a caution for rain with five laps left before t[MASK]e halfway point . NASCAR wanted the cars to get to the halfwa[MASK] point to make the race official , so the sanctioning body had the drivers slowly circle the track . It took the dr[MASK]vers 26 minutes to complete the laps , and the rain was so heavy that some[MASK]driver[MASK] had to look out their side w[MASK]ndows because they could not see[MASK]out their windshields . Tw[MASK] hours later , the track [MASK][MASK]d dried[MASK]and the race resumed with Richmon[MASK] in third . After Richmond 's car was adjusted to remove the " push " , the car was more to his liking . Because his radio did not work , he was unable to communicate with his crew c[MASK]ief , Hyde , and he made his final pit stop with 37 laps left[MASK]. Hyde worried that Richmond had stopped a lap too early to ensu[MASK]e that he would have enough fuel to [MASK]ake it to the end . After Richmond took the lead with 30 laps left in the rac[MASK] , Dale[MASK]Earnhardt made up three seconds on Richmond 's five @-@ second lead . With four laps to go , Buddy Arr[MASK]ngton spun in a three @-@ car accident[MASK]. The remaining laps of[MASK]the race where completed slow[MASK]y under caution and Richmond took the checkered flag for the victory . He had led 97 laps , including the fi[MASK]al 30 , taking his first victory in a Rick Hendrick car . 
 The tour returned to Pocono a month later , and Richmond battled for another v[MASK]ctory in a fog @-@ shortened event . In the final 8 @-@ lap sprint , Richmond c[MASK]mpeted in a three @-@ car battle with Geoff Bodine and Ricky Rudd . Richmond crossed the finish line beside Rudd , winning the race by 0 @.@ 05 seconds . He no[MASK]ched four more victories that s[MASK]ason , and over a span of twelve [MASK]aces , Richmond[MASK]earned [MASK]hree second @-@ place finishes , and six wins . The Natio[MASK]al Motorsports Press Ass[MASK]ciation named h[MASK]m Co @-@ Driver of the Year with Earnhardt[MASK]after Richmond accumulated 13 top 5 f[MASK]nish[MASK]s and 16 in the top 10 . He had a career @-@ best third @-@ place finish in points after winning seven events in 1986 , in what was hi[MASK] last full NASCAR season .[MASK]
 
 = = Illness and death =[MASK]= 
 
 Richmond fell ill the day after the 1986 NASCAR annual banquet during a promotional trip to New York . He was not well enough to begin the [MASK]987 NASCAR season despite lengthy hospitalizati[MASK]n in Cleveland and further rest at home ; when Richmond missed the Daytona 500 , his conditi[MASK]n was reported as do[MASK]ble pneumonia . Media later reported that he had tested positive for [MASK]cquire[MASK] immune deficiency sy[MASK]drome ( AIDS ) . He returned to Pocono for the Miller High Life 500 during the middle of the year . Starting third , he led by the fifth [MASK]ap and ultimately led 82 laps , including the final 46 , to win the race by eight car @-@ lengths over Bill Elliott . In the middle of the race , Richmond 's car [MASK]uffered gearbox problems . Because he could use only fourth [MASK] high ) gear , he had to use that gear to slowly exit the pits . Richmond was emotional after the victory , saying , " I had tears in my eyes when I took the checkered [MASK]lag . Then ever[MASK] time anyone congratulated me , I started bawling agai[MASK] . " Richmond earned a victory in the next race at Riverside , and mad[MASK] his final 1987 start at Michigan [MASK]nternational Speedway 's Champion[MASK]Spark Plug 400 that August , finishing 29t[MASK] wi[MASK]h a blown eng[MASK]ne . He resigned from Hendrick Motorsports in September 1987 . 
 Although Richmond attempted a comeback in 1988 , NASCAR suspended him for testing positive for banned substances . The substances [MASK]ere identified as Sudafed , a non[MASK]@-@ prescription over @-@ the @-@ counter allerg[MASK] medication , and Advil , an over @-@ the @-@ counter pain reliever . I[MASK] [MASK]pril 1988 , Richmond sued NASCAR over the suspension . Although he retested later that year and was reinstated , he could not find a car to drive . In his final public appearance in F[MASK]bruary 1988 , Richmond denied that he abused drugs and said that a mistake had been made in his drug test . His suit with NASCAR was settled out @-@ of @-@ court , the terms sealed . 
 Richmond [MASK]ithdrew into[MASK]his co[MASK]do in Florida . There were by then rumors of HIV and AIDS , which he denied . He was later hospitalized in West Palm Beach [MASK] 
 ESPN sent a get @-@ well @-@ soon card to Richmond when it air[MASK]d the July 1989 NASCAR race at Pocono . The television network showed hi[MASK]hlights of Richmond 's victory at the track from 1986 . " Tim had Hollywood[MASK]good looks and the chari[MASK]m[MASK] of Tom Cr[MASK]ise , " said his friend Dr. Jerry Punch . " There he was in victory lane with the team all around him and beauty queens hanging[MASK]all over him . It was important for the people at the hospital to see[MASK]Tim the way he really was , when he was[MASK]healthy and handsome and vital , not the way he was as [MASK]hey saw him [MASK]very da[MASK] in the hospital . " 
 On August 13 , 1989 , Richmond died at the age of 34 , about two years after his final NASCAR race . He was buried in As[MASK]land , Ohio[MASK]. 
 The secrecy s[MASK]rrounding the circumstanc[MASK] of his death caused speculation for seve[MASK]al days . At the t[MASK]me , Punch stated that Richmond had been hospitalized due [MASK]o a motorcycle accident , though it is unlikely that Richmond had the [MASK]tren[MASK]th to ride a motorcycle during his last months . Ten days after his death , on August 23 , the Richmond fam[MASK]ly held a press conference to reveal that Richmond died from complications from AIDS , which he acquired from an unknown woman . Richmond 's physician , Dr. David Dodson , said : " Ther[MASK] 's no way of knowing who that woman was . Tim was a celebrity w[MASK]th a lot of charisma , a handsome guy . He naturally attracted a[MASK]lot of women . " Punch later claimed that more than 90 drivers and pe[MASK]sonnel underwe[MASK]t HIV testing in the wake of Richmond 's death . 
 
 = = Legacy = = 
[MASK]
 In 1990 , a few months after Richmond 's death , Washington television station WJLA @-@ TV and reporter Roberta Baskin reported that Dr. Forest Tennant , who w[MASK]s then the National Football League 's drug ad[MASK]iser , " falsified drug tests " that ultimately helped shorten Richmon[MASK] 's NASC[MASK]R career . Bas[MASK]in reported that sealed court documents and interviews showed Tennant and NASCAR used " allegedly false drug @-@ test results in 1988 to bar Richmond from racing " . Baskin also stated that NASCAR had targeted Richmond , reques[MASK]ing that Tennant establish a substance @-@ abuse policy with Richmond in mind . A series of drug tests and falsely reported positive results shortly before the 1988 Daytona 500 kept Richmond from dri[MASK]ing in what was to have been his last big race ... " , the report said . The New York Times published the findings . While neither Tennant nor NASCAR supplied [MASK]n official r[MASK]sponse at the time , NASCAR did confirm that they [MASK]ere seeking to replace Tennant . [MASK] The Ashland County [MASK]ports [MASK]all of Fame inducted [MASK]ichmond in their seco[MASK]d class in 1996 . In 1998 , NASCAR named Richmond one of its 50 greatest drivers of all time . He was inducted int[MASK] the International[MASK]Motorsports Hall of [MASK]ame in 2002 . The Mansfield Motorsports Park ARCA Re[MASK]/ Max Series race in 2009 was named the Tim Richmond[MASK]Memorial ARCA Re / Max 250[MASK]in honor of the area native . The race at Mansfield was co @-@ promoted by Mattioli 's son Joseph Mattioli III . 
 The documentary film Tim Richmo[MASK]d : To The Limit was produced as part of ESPN 's 30 for 30 series with a premiere date of October 19 , 2010 .

 = = = = Busch Series = = = = 
 
 
 [MASK] = Trout Creek Mountains = 
 
 The [MASK]rout Creek Mountains are a remote , semi @-@ arid Great Basin mountain range mostly in southeastern Oregon a[MASK]d pa[MASK]tially in northern Nevada in the United States . The range 's [MASK]ighest point [MASK]s Orevada View Benchmark[MASK], 8 @,@ [MASK]06 feet ( 2 @,@ 593 m ) above sea level , i[MASK] Nevada[MASK]. Disaster Pea[MASK] , elevat[MASK]on 7 @,@ 781[MASK]feet ([MASK][MASK] @,@ 372 m ) , i[MASK] another prominent su[MASK]mit in the Nevada portio[MASK] of the mountains . 
 The mountains are c[MASK]aracteristic of the Great Basin 's topography of mostly parall[MASK]l mountain ranges alternating with flat valleys . Oriented [MASK]enerally north to south ,[MASK]the Trout Creek Mountains consist primarily of fault blocks of basal[MASK] , which came from an ancient volcano and ot[MASK]er[MASK]vents , [MASK]n top of older metamorphic rocks . The southern end of[MASK]the range , however , features many granitic outcrops . As a whole , the faulted terrain is dominated by rolling hills and ridges c[MASK]t by escarpments and canyons . 
 Most of the range is public lan[MASK] administered by the federal Bureau of Land Man[MASK]gement . There is very little human development in the remote region — cattle grazing and ranching are the primary human uses — but former mines at the McDermitt Caldera pro[MASK]uced some of the lar[MASK]est amounts of mercury in North America in the 20th century . Public lands in the m[MASK]untains[MASK]are open to recreation but are rarely v[MASK]sited . Ve[MASK]etation includes large swaths of big sagebrush in addition to desert grasses and cottonwood and alder stands . Sage grouse and mountain c[MASK]ickadee are two bird species native t[MASK] the range , and common mammals include prongho[MASK]n and jackrabbits . 
 Despite the area 's dry climate , a few year @-@ round streams provid[MASK] habitat for the rare Lahontan cutthroat trout . Fish populations in the T[MASK]out Creek Mountains declined throughout much of the 20th century . In the 1980s , the effects of grazing allotments on riparian zones and the fish led to land @-@ use conflict . The Trout Creek Mountain Working[MASK]Group was formed in 1988 to help resolve disagreements among livestock owners , env[MASK]ronmentalists , government agenc[MASK]es , and other intere[MASK]ted parties [MASK] The stakeholders met and agreed on changes to land @-@ use practices , and since the early 1990s , riparian zones have begun to recover . 
 
 = = Geography = = 
 
 The T[MASK]out Creek Mountains are in a very remote area of southeastern Oregon [MASK]nd nort[MASK]ern Nevada , in Harney and Humboldt counties . The nearest human settlements are the Whitehorse Ranch , abo[MASK]t 20 miles ( 32 km ) directly north from the middle of the mo[MASK]ntains ; Fi[MASK]lds , Oregon , about 23 miles ( 37 km ) to the northwest ; Denio [MASK] Nevada , about 15[MASK]miles[MASK]( 24 km ) to the west ; and McDermitt , Nevada – Oregon , about 30 miles ( 48 km ) to the east . The mountains are about 150 miles ( 240 km ) directly southwest of Boise ,[MASK]Id[MASK]ho , an[MASK] [MASK]bout 190 miles ( 310 km )[MASK]northeast of Reno , Nevada [MASK] 
 The range and surrounding non @-@ mountainous areas cov[MASK]r an area of 8[MASK]1 square miles ( 2 @,@ 100 km2 ) . The mountains run 51 miles ( 82 km ) north t[MASK] south and 36 miles ( 58 km [MASK] east to west . More of the range is in Oregon ( 78 % ) than in Ne[MASK]ada[MASK]( 22 % ) . The highest point in the range is Orevada View Benchmark , which is 8 @,@ 506 feet ( 2 @[MASK]@ 593 m ) above sea level and[MASK]is located in Nevada about one mile south of the O[MASK]egon border . About two miles southeast [MASK]f Orevada View is Disaster Peak , " a large , symmetrical butte tha[MASK] [MASK]s visible throughout the region . " At 7 @[MASK]@ 781 feet ([MASK]2 @,@ 372 m ) , Di[MASK]a[MASK]ter Peak anchors the sou[MASK]hern en[MASK] of the mountains in a sub @-@ range called The Granites . 
 The Oregon Canyon Mountains border the Trout Creek Mountains on the east along the Harney – Malheur county line ( according to the United States Geological Survey 's d[MASK]finitions ) , while the Pueblo Mountains are the next range west of the Trout Creek Mountains . The Bilk Creek Mountains in both Oregon and Nevada border the Trout[MASK]Creek Mountains on the southwest ; the two ranges are separated by Log Cabin Cree[MASK] and South Fork Cottonwood Cree[MASK] . South [MASK]f the T[MASK]out Creek Mountains is the [MASK]ings Riv[MASK]r Valley , which separ[MASK]tes the Bil[MASK] Creek Mountains on the west from the Montana Mountains on the east . 
 The terrain in t[MASK]e Trout C[MASK]eek Mountains varies from [MASK]road ,[MASK]flat basins and rolling ridges to high rock escarpments cut by deep canyons . The canyons have steep walls with loose talus s[MASK]opes at the bottoms . There are meadows around springs in the [MASK]ountains , although most streams in the range do not flow year @-@ round . Major streams[MASK]that flow off the north slopes of the mountains include ( from west to east ) Cott[MASK]nwood C[MASK]eek , Trout Cre[MASK]k , Willow Creek , and Whitehorse Creek . These streams all flow into endorheic basins in Harney County , Oregon . Trout Creek and Whitehorse Creek are the largest of the four . The Kings River and [MASK]c[MASK]ermitt Creek e[MASK]ch drain an area on the south slopes of the Trout Creek Mountains . The Kings River begins in [MASK]he Granites[MASK]and flows south into Nevada , where it meets th[MASK] Quinn River , which evaporates in the Black Rock Desert . McDermitt Creek begins in Oregon a few miles north of Th[MASK] Granites and fl[MASK]ws generally east , crossing the Oregon –[MASK]Nev[MASK]da border five times before d[MASK]sappear[MASK]ng into the floor of the Quinn River Valley south of McDermitt . 
 
 = = Geology = = 
 
 The mountains lie within the Basin and Range Province or Gr[MASK]at Basin of the Western United State[MASK] , which is characterized by a series of parallel fault blocks that form long north – south mountain rang[MASK]s separated by wide , high @-@ desert valleys . The Trout Creek Mountains are uplifted and tilted blocks with steep escarpments along the southern and eastern sides of the range . The southern area of the range , known as The Granites , has numerous outcroppings o[MASK] Cretaceous age granite .[MASK]These granite outcrops are commonly found in the eroded [MASK]alleys below the volcanic ridgelines . 
 The Trout Creek Mountains are composed mostly of basalt from a shield volcano that once stood where Steens Mountain is today . Crustal th[MASK][MASK]ning and the Yellowstone hotspot , which was then be[MASK]eath south[MASK]astern Orego[MASK] , induce[MASK] eruptions from Steen[MASK] and nearby vents about [MASK]7 million years ago , in the Miocene . The vents produced a series of la[MASK]a flows that spread across the land now known as the Trout Creek Mountains . Eruptions from the Steens volc[MASK]no lasted for about one million years , and at least 70 separate lava flows occurred . Under the resulting basalt[MASK]rock lie much older metamorphic rocks that may be related to so[MASK]e of the Triassic age formations o[MASK] the Blue Mountains in northeastern Oregon . Wi[MASK]hin these metamorphic rocks are diorite and granodiorite intrusive bodies which were presumably intruded during the Cretaceous Period . 
 The broad McDermitt Caldera is a prominent geologic feature in the Trout Creek Mountains . The ov[MASK]l @-@ shaped [MASK]aldera is a collapsed lava dome th[MASK]t straddles the Oregon – Nevad[MASK] border on the eastern side of the range and south of the Oregon Can[MASK][MASK]n Mountains . It is about 28 miles ( 45 km ) long and 22 miles ( 35 km [MASK] wide . The l[MASK]va dome was created by volcanic eruptions in the early Miocene . A total of f[MASK]ve large ash flows were produced along with a l[MASK]rge rhyolite dome structure . T[MASK]e caldera formed when the dome collapsed about 16 million years ago . The caldera contains significant ore depo[MASK]its , and m[MASK]rcury and uranium have bee[MASK] mined at eight or more sites in and around the caldera . Ot[MASK]er areas in the caldera were mined for ores of antimony , cesium , and lithium . 
 
 = = Climate = = 
 
 The Trout Creek Mountains are semi @-@ arid because they are in the eastern rain shadow of mounta[MASK]n ranges to the west . When m[MASK]ist air from the Pacif[MASK]c Ocean moves eastward over[MASK]the Oregon and C[MASK]lifornia c[MASK]astal [MASK]anges and the Cascade Range , most precipitation falls in those mountai[MASK]s before reaching the Trout Creek Mountains .[MASK]As a result , the average [MASK]nnual precipitation in the Trout Creek Mountains [MASK]s only 8 to 26 inches ( 200 to 660 mm ) per year , wit[MASK] most areas receiving betwe[MASK]n 8 and 12 inches ( 200 and[MASK]300 mm ) annually . Much of the annual precipitation occurs between the beginning of March and the end of June . Most of the rest falls as snow during the fall and[MASK]winter months . Sn[MASK]wpack at elevations below 6 @,@ 000 feet ( 1 @,@ 800 m ) usually melts by April ; [MASK]oweve[MASK] , at the higher elevations , snow can remain until mid @-@ June . Local flooding often occurs in the sprin[MASK] as the snowpack melts . 
 The pre[MASK]ailing winds are from the west [MASK]-@ southwest , and they are normally strongest in March and April . Brief , intense thunderstorms are common between April and October . Thunderstorms[MASK]in the summer months tend to be more isolated and often produce dry lightning strikes . 
 
 = = Ecology = = 
 
 
 = = = Flora = = = 
 
 Vegetation in the Trou[MASK] Cre[MASK]k Mountains i[MASK] dominated by big sagebrush and desert grasses . Other common shrubs include bitter[MASK]rush , snowberry , and Ceanothus . T[MASK]ere are also patches of moun[MASK]ain mahogany in some are[MASK]s . Common grass species include Idaho [MASK]escu[MASK] , bluebunch wheatgrass , cheatgrass , western needlegrass , Sandberg 's b[MASK]uegrass , Thurbe[MASK] 's needlegrass , and bo[MASK]tlebrush squirreltail , a[MASK] well as basin wildrye in some wel[MASK] @-@ drai[MASK]ed areas .[MASK]
 Less than one per[MASK][MASK]nt of the rang[MASK] co[MASK]sists of meadow wetlands and riparian greenways ( vegetation along stream banks ) . [MASK]owever , these areas are vital to th[MASK] local ecos[MASK]stem . The [MASK]eadows surround springs , which are mostly on gently sloping uplands or in stream bottoms , and range in size from about 1 to [MASK] acres [MASK] 0 @.@ 40 to 2 @.@ 02 ha ) . Narrow riparian greenways follow the year @-@ round streams . Many greenway areas have quaking [MASK]spen and willow groves . Cottonwood and a[MASK][MASK]er grove[MASK] can b[MASK] found at lower elevat[MASK]ons where[MASK]terrain is flatter and stream channe[MASK]s are wider . Sedges and rushes are also native to t[MASK]ese stream bottoms . Years of heavy livestock grazing in parts of the range resulted in the loss of some grass species , riparian vegetation , and young aspen and willow trees . Restorati[MASK]n of riparian areas began in the early 1970s ,[MASK]and plans to reduce grazing were implemented in the 1980s and early 1990s . However , large wildfires in southeastern Oregon during the summer of 2012 burned much of the range 's v[MASK]getation , damaging riparian ecosystems an[MASK] k[MASK]lling hundreds of grazing cattle . [MASK] 
 = = = Fauna = = = 
[MASK]
 Animals in the[MASK]Trout Creek Mounta[MASK]ns are adapted to the environment[MASK]of the High Desert . Pronghorn are c[MASK]mmon in the open , sagebrush @-@ covered basins , [MASK]hile mule deer live in the cottonwood[MASK]and willow groves . There are also bighorn sheep , cougars , and bobcats in the high countr[MASK] . Jackrabbits and coyotes are prevalent throughout the range . Mustangs sometimes pass through the mountains as they roam the Great Basin . Some other mammals i[MASK]clude the northern pocket gopher , [MASK]ountain cottontail , and Belding 's ground squirrel . North American beavers live in and along streams , as do Pacific tree frogs , western spadefoot [MASK]oads , and[MASK]garter snakes . Native bird species include the sage grouse , mountain chickadee , gray @-@ headed junco , black @-@ throated gray warbler , Virginia 's warbler , MacGillivray 's warbler , pine siskin , red crossbill , bushtit , hermit thrush , northern goshawk , and [MASK]pecies of raven [MASK]nd eagle . 
 Several streams in the Trout Creek Mountains are home to trout , including the rare Lahontan cutthroat trout subspecies . These include Wil[MASK]ow Creek , Whitehorse Creek , Little Whitehorse Creek , Doolittle Creek , Fifteen Mile Creek , Indian Creek , Sage Canyon Creek , Line Canyon Creek , and some tributaries of McDermitt Creek . Lahontan cutthroat trout[MASK]live in small , isolated populations that are often confined to[MASK]individua[MASK] streams , many of them in the T[MASK]out Creek Mountains . These populations have significant genetic differences due to their history of isolation . Fo[MASK] most of the 20th century , the trout 's numbers declined consider[MASK]bl[MASK] . It was listed u[MASK][MASK]er federal [MASK]aw as an endangered species in 1970 and was reclassified as thre[MASK]tened in 1975 . Reasons for the fish 's decline included habitat degradation from cattle grazing , drought , overfis[MASK]ing , competition with other fish , and hybridizati[MASK]n with introduced rainbow trout , which decreased t[MASK]e number of genetically pure Lahontan cutthroat trout . However , reductions in cattle grazing in riparian zone[MASK] sinc[MASK] the 1980[MASK] allowe[MASK] fish habitat and populations to start to recover . 
 
 = = Human uses = = 
 
 The Bureau[MASK]of Land Management ( BLM ) administers most land in the Trout Creek [MASK]ountains , but there are also some private lands and some roads in the area . The private lands are mainly used for ranching along mountain streams , while the BLM lands include large grazing all[MASK]tments for local ranchers ' c[MASK]ttle . At least 100 mining claims in the mountains have been recorded since 1892 , some of which were staked for gold exploration . C[MASK]mmercial mining has occurred in some areas , mostly[MASK]near the McDermitt Caldera , where uranium and la[MASK]ge am[MASK]unts of mercury have[MASK]been[MASK]extracted[MASK]. Mines in what was called the Opalite[MASK]Mining Dist[MASK]ic[MASK] produced 270 @,@ 000 flasks of mercury — " the richest suppl[MASK] of mercury in the western hemisphere " — from cinnabar extracted from the cald[MASK]ra in the 20th century . The t[MASK][MASK] leading mercu[MASK]y @-@ producing mines in North America we[MASK]e the Cordero and McDermitt mines on the edge of the calder[MASK] in Nevada . Together , they operated from 193[MASK] to 1989 . The McDermitt Mine , the last me[MASK]cur[MASK][MASK]mine in the United States , clos[MASK]d three years[MASK]later , in 1992 . However , mineral exploration has continued at the Cordero Mine in [MASK]he 21st century , and waste conta[MASK]ni[MASK]g merc[MASK]ry and arsenic was returned [MASK]here from the community of McDermitt as part of a U.S. Environmenta[MASK] [MASK]rotection Agency cleanup project . 
 T[MASK]e entire mountain range is ver[MASK] remote ; as a result , there are few visi[MASK]ors , and the range offers a wilderness @-@ like experience . Camping , hunting , fishing , and hiking are the[MASK]most popular activities . The only developed recreation site nearby is at W[MASK]llow Creek Hot Springs , just south of the Whiteh[MASK]rse Ranch , where nearby there are miles of trails designated for f[MASK]ur @-@ wheel off @-@ [MASK]oad vehicles . Hunters [MASK]ome to th[MASK] mountains seeking trophy mule[MASK]deer , pronghorn , chukars , and rabbits . Fishing on some strea[MASK]s is someti[MASK]es [MASK]ermitted on a cat[MASK]h @-@ and @-@ release basis . The mountains are also [MASK]uitable for hiking cross @-@ country or on game trails in natural corridors along cany[MASK]ns and [MASK]reek bottoms . There are more than 100 archaeological sites in the range that document use by Northern Paiute people as lo[MASK]g as 7 @,@ 000 years ago . 
 Cattl[MASK] grazi[MASK]g in the Trout Creek Mountains began in the late 19th ce[MASK]tury , and the BLM [MASK]urrently oversees grazing allotments in the area . Cattle can be fo[MASK]nd grazing in some areas during th[MASK] spring and summer months . The effects of grazing on the local environment were the subject of controversy in the 1980s . 
 [MASK] = = [MASK]and @-@ mana[MASK]ement compromise = = 
 
 By the 1970s and 1980s , a century of intense cattle grazing had reduced much of the riparian vegetation along stream banks in the Trout Creek [MASK]ountains and elsewh[MASK]re in the Great Basin . As a result , stream banks were eroding and upland vegetation was encroaching into riparian zones . Aspen populations declined as grazing cattle eliminated young trees , decreasing sha[MASK]e over streams and raising water temperatures . These conditions put the rare Lahontan cutthroat trout population at risk . Since the Lahontan was officially de[MASK]ignated as a threatened species , environmental groups began advocat[MASK]ng the cancellation [MASK]f grazing permits in the Trout Creek Mountains . 
 Beginning in the early 1970s , the Bureau o[MASK] Land Management identified damaged riparian zones and began projects to restore n[MASK]tural habitat in those areas . Approximately 20 [MASK],@ 000 willow trees were planted along streams , [MASK]mall dams were put together to create more pools in the streams , an[MASK] fencing was added to protect riparian zones from grazing . Next , the agency sought to reform lan[MASK] @-@ use plans to change grazing practices , which became a comp[MASK]ex and controversial project . 
 As environmentalists pressed the BLM to close much of the Trout Creek[MASK]Mountains to grazing , frustrat[MASK]d ranchers joined[MASK]the Sagebrush Rebellion seeking to protect their grazing allotments[MASK]. Initial[MASK]y , it appeared that the issue of grazing in the range would produce prolonged liti[MASK]ati[MASK]n with appeals potentially[MASK]lasting dec[MASK]des . However , in 1988 , interest groups representing all sides of the issue joined to form the[MASK]Trout Creek Mountain Working Group . The group 's goal was to find a solution acceptable to everyone — a plan that would protect both [MASK]he land 's ecological health and ranchers ' economic needs . 
 Initial members of the Trout Cree[MASK] Mountain Working[MASK]Group included : 
 Over the next several ye[MASK]rs , the[MASK]group continued to meet and discuss options for restoring the land while meeting t[MASK]e economic needs of local ranchers . Meetings we[MASK]e all open to the public . 
 The group[MASK]eventually en[MASK]orsed a grazing management plan that provided for both the ecological health of sensitive[MASK]riparian areas and the ec[MASK]nomic well @-@ being of ranchers . In 1989 , the Whitehorse Ranch agreed to res[MASK] two grazing allotments totaling 50 @,@ 000 acres ( 20 @,@ 000 ha ) to restore critical stream greenways and mountain pastures . The ranch 's allotment[MASK]on Fifteen Mile Creek was rested for three[MASK]years , a[MASK]d its Willow Creek pasture received a five @-@ year rest b[MASK]fore [MASK]razing was resumed . In ad[MASK]ition , the grazing season in mountain pastures was reduced from four months to two , an[MASK] the tot[MASK]l number of cattle released in the allotment areas was reduced from 3 @,@ 800 to 2 @,@ 200 . Finally , sensitive areas were fen[MASK]ed to protect them from cattle , and additional water sources were constructed away from streams . Other ranches also agreed to rest specific pastures including the Trout Creek , Cot[MASK]onwood Creek , and Whitehorse Butte allotments . 
[MASK]In 1991 , the Bureau of Land Management appro[MASK]ed a new grazing allotment mana[MASK]ement plan . It was based on the agreements made by the Trout Cre[MASK]k Mountain Working Group , and it took effect[MASK]in 1992 . Since then , vegetation in riparian areas of the Trout Creek Mountains has recovered , and studies by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service [MASK]ave found that the Laho[MASK]tan[MASK]cutthroat trout populat[MASK]on , still listed as threatened , is also recovering . 
 
 
 = Mycena inclinata = 
 
 Mycena inclinata , commonl[MASK] known as the clust[MASK]red bonnet or the oak @-@ stump bonnet cap , is a species of mushroom in[MASK]th[MASK] family Mycenaceae[MASK]. The doubtfully edible mushroom has a reddish[MASK]@-@ brown bell @-@ shaped cap up to 4 @.@ [MASK] cm ( 1 @.@ 8 in ) in diameter . The thin stem is up to 9 cm ( 3 @.@ 5 in ) tall , whitish to yellow @-@ b[MASK]own at the top but prog[MASK]essively becoming reddish @-@ brown towards the base in maturity , where the[MASK] are covered by a yellowish myce[MASK]ium that can be up to a third of the length of the stem . The gills are pale brown to pinkish , and the spore print is white . It is a widespread saprobic fungus , and has[MASK]been found in Europe , North Africa , Asia , Australasia , and N[MASK]rt[MASK] America , where it grows in small groups or tufts on fallen logs and stu[MASK]ps , especially [MASK]f oak . Bri[MASK]ish mycologist E.J.H. Corner has described two[MASK]varieties of the mushroom from Borneo . Lookalike species with which M. inclinata [MASK]ay be confused include M. galericulata and M. [MASK]aculata .[MASK]
 
 = = T[MASK]xonomy , phylogeny , and na[MASK]ing = = 
 
 First described as Agaricus inclinatus by Swedish mycologist Elias Mag[MASK]us Fries in 1838 , it was assigned its current name in 1872[MASK]by Lucien Quélet . Mycena galericulata var.[MASK]calopus ( [MASK]amed by Karsten in 1879 ) , and it[MASK] basionym Agaricus galericulatus var. calopus ( n[MASK]med by Fries in [MASK]873 ) , are synonyms . 
 In a molecular study of the large su[MASK]unit ribosomal DNA sequenc[MASK]s of mycorrhizal f[MASK]ngi of the orchid Gastrodi[MASK] confusa , M. inclinata was found to be closely related to M. aurantiomarginata , M. crocata , and M. leaiana . 
 The specific [MASK]pithet inclinata means " bent in " . The mushroom is[MASK]commonly known as the " clustered bonnet " or the " oak @-@ stump bonnet cap " . 
 
 = = Description[MASK]= = 
 
 The cap is light reddish @-@ brown[MASK], with a diameter typically [MASK]an[MASK]ing[MASK]from 1 to 4 @.@ 5 cm ( 0 @.@ 4 to 1 @.@ 8 in ) . Initially conic to bell @-@ shaped to convex , it flattens during maturity[MASK], developing visible surface grooves corresponding t[MASK] the gills underneat[MASK] the cap . The margin of the cap has minute but distinct scallops . The surface is moist and smooth , and hygroph[MASK]nous . The cap frequently develops splits in the margin , or cracks in the disc ( the central part of the cap[MASK]) . The flesh of the cap is thick in the center but thin elsewhere , grayish to whit[MASK]sh , frag[MASK]le , and with a slightly mealy odor and taste . The gills have a decurrent attachment to the s[MASK]em ( that is [MASK] run[MASK]ing down the length[MASK]of the stem ) and are a pale brownish color wit[MASK] tinges of red . [MASK]hey are broad [MASK] between 3 and 6 mm ) , and have a close to subdistant spacing , wit[MASK] about 26 – 35 gills r[MASK]ach[MASK]ng the stem . The fragile stem is 3 to 9 cm ( 1 @.@ 2 to [MASK] @.@ 5 in ) long by 0 @.@ 15 to 0 [MASK].@ 4 cm ( 0 @.@ 06 to 0 @.@ 16 in ) [MASK]hick and[MASK]yellow to yellow @-@ brown , becoming reddish @-@ brown to orange @-@ brown in the bottom half in maturity . The lower portion of young stems is covered with white flecks . Roughly equal in thickness at the to[MASK] and bott[MASK]m , the base of the stem is covered by a ye[MASK]lowish mycelium that can be up to a third of the length of the stem . The edibi[MASK]ity of the mushroom is " doubtful " and consumption " best avoided " . 
 
 =[MASK]= = Microscopic characteristics = = = 
 
 The spores are 7 – 9 by 5 – 6 @.@ 5 μm , broadly ellipsoid , smooth , and strongly amyloid ( it tu[MASK]ns bla[MASK]k when treated with Melzer 's reagent ) . Th[MASK] basidia ( spore @-@ bearing cells ) are four @-@ spored . The pleurocystidia ( cystidia on the gill face ) are not dif[MASK]erentiated . The cheilocystidia ( cystidia on the gill edge ) are embedded in the gill edge and very inconspi[MASK]uous , club @-@ s[MASK]ap[MASK]d[MASK], 26 – 36 by 5 – 10 μm , and have tips that are covered [MASK]ith contorted projections that can be slender or thick . The flesh of the[MASK]gills is homogeneous , and pale yellowish[MASK]to di[MASK]t[MASK] brown when stained in iodine . The flesh of th[MASK] c[MASK]p has a dist[MASK]nct pellicle , a well @-@ differentiated hypoderm ( a region of tissue immediately u[MASK]der the pellicle ) , and a f[MASK]l[MASK]mentous tramal body[MASK]( gill [MASK]issue ) ; it is pale yellowish to sordid brownish in iod[MASK]ne[MASK]stain . 
 
 = = = Varieties = = = 
 
 E.J.H. Corner defin[MASK]d the varieties M. inclinata var. kinabaluensis [MASK]nd var. subglobospora in his 19[MASK]4 publication on A[MASK]aric mushrooms of Malesia [MASK] a biogeographical region straddling the boundary of the Indomalaya and Australasia ecoz[MASK]nes . The variety kinabaluensis ( named after its type locality , Kinabalu ) has a cap margin that is [MASK]ot scalloped , little or no odor[MASK], and cheilocystidia with shorter processes . It was found growing on the dead wood of Lithocarpus havilandii , a stone oak tree in the beec[MASK] family . Va[MASK]iety subglobospora , found in Sabah , has[MASK]spores that are alm[MASK]st spherical . 
 
 = = = Similar species = = = 
 
 Mycena maculata bears some resemblance to M. inclinata , but is onl[MASK] associated with decaying h[MASK]rdwood logs and stumps , and is found [MASK]n eastern North America , and sometimes on oak on the West Coast . In [MASK][MASK]e , [MASK]t develops reddi[MASK]h spots on the gills that are [MASK]ot seen in M. inclinata . M. inclinata is often con[MASK]used with the edible M. [MASK]alericulata , a [MASK]ommon species that is variable in cap color , size and shape . M. galeri[MASK]ulata typically has a bluntly con[MASK]cal cap that is dull gray @-@ brown , and white[MASK]to grayish veins that have numerous cross @-@ veins . M. polygr[MASK]mma has a ridged stem that is bluish @-@ gray . 
 
 = = Habitat and distribution = = 
 
 Mycena inclinata is a saprobic fungus , deriving[MASK]its nutrients from decomposing organic matter fou[MASK]d in plant litter such as leaves , twigs , bark and branches . It accomplishes th[MASK]s by producing enzymes [MASK]apable of breaking down the three major biochemical components of plant cell walls found in litter : cellulose , hemicellulos[MASK] and lignin . 
 The fruit bodies of Mycena inclinata grow in dense groups or clusters on decaying hardwood logs and stumps ( especia[MASK]ly oak [MASK]nd chestnut ) during the spring and autumn . The fungus forms a white , woolly mycelium on the[MASK]surface of decomposing oak leaves . Occasionally , it can be found growing on a living tree . In ea[MASK]tern North America , it is[MASK]abundant in the area [MASK]ounded by Nova Sco[MASK]ia , Ontario , Manitoba , Missouri , North Caro[MASK]ina , and New York . It has been [MASK]ound in Oregon , but the species appears to be generally rare along the Pacific Coast . The range of the fu[MASK]gus also includes Europe , the C[MASK]nary Islands , North Africa , East Siberia , Japan , Malesia , Turkey , and New Zealand . 
 
 = = Chemistry = =[MASK]
 
 In a study of the trace metal concentrations of various mushrooms specie[MASK] found in Ordu ( Turkey ) , M[MASK] i[MASK]clinata was found to have comparatively high levels of iron ( 628 mg per kg ) and nic[MASK]el [MASK] 21 @.@ 6 mg / kg ) , measured on a dry weight basis . Laboratory studies have shown that the fungus is resistant to aluminum . The fun[MASK]us has been investigated for its ability to decolorize synthetic dyes that are used in the textile , plasti[MASK]s , biomedical and foodstuff indu[MASK]tries . The dyes are [MASK]ot readily biodegradable , and when discharged into the environment are persistent and ma[MASK]y are toxic . 
 
 
 = Capel Lligwy = 
 
 Capel Lligwy ( sometimes referred to as Hen Gapel Lligwy ) is a ruined chapel near Rhos Lligwy in[MASK]Anglesey , north Wales , dating bac[MASK] to the first hal[MASK] of the 12th century . The chapel 's original purpose is unknown , but it might [MASK]a[MASK]e [MASK]een used as a memorial chapel or in connection with a local roya[MASK] court , or as a c[MASK]apel of ease in a large parish with a growing population . It was[MASK]u[MASK]ed for a time[MASK]until the e[MASK]rly 18th century as a private place of worship for a nearby house [MASK] th[MASK]n later fell into disrepair . The walls s[MASK]ill re[MASK]ain , with some traces of render [MASK]n them internally , but there is no roof [MASK] 
 It contains a[MASK]16th @-@ century side chapel with a vault beneath , used as[MASK]a burial chamber . It is a Grade II listed building , a national designation given to " buildings of special interest , which [MASK]arrant every effort being made to preserve them " , in particular because it is " a substantiall[MASK] 12th @-@ century structure [MASK] [MASK]ith the " unusual[MASK]16th @-@ c[MASK]ntury vaulted south chapel " . 
 
 = = Histor[MASK] and location = = 
 
 The oldest parts of[MASK]Capel Lligwy[MASK]date fr[MASK]m the first half of the 12th century . This was a time when many churches on Anglesey in n[MASK]rth @-@ west W[MASK]les were first built in stone following the end of Viking raids and attempts by the Normans[MASK]to gain contr[MASK]l of the island . The reason for its construction , and the saint to wh[MASK]m it was dedicated , are unknown [MASK] Geraint Jones , author of a 2006 guide to the ch[MASK]rches[MASK]of Anglesey , suggests that it m[MASK]y originally [MASK]ave been a memorial chapel , o[MASK] connected to[MASK]a royal court n[MASK]arby . Yates and Longley , authors of a 2001 guide to [MASK]ncient A[MASK]glesey monuments , note that it was built in the large parish of Penrhos Lligwy and was perhaps intended to serving the expanding population in medieval times . Despite this , it seems to have remained as a chapel of ease rather than become a parish church in its own right[MASK]. The chapel is sometimes referred to as " Hen Gapel Lligw[MASK] " ( " hen " being the Welsh word for " old " and "[MASK]capel " meaning " chapel " ) . 
 The walls were partially rebuilt in the 14th century , and the upper parts of the walls date from thi[MASK][MASK]time . A chapel was added to t[MASK]e south side of the building in the 16th century . A vault under the[MASK]south chap[MASK]l was used to bury members of a local family , the Pierce Lloyds . In 1999 , the vault was used to record some " atmos[MASK]heres " for [MASK]he album " You Have Just Been Poisoned By The Serpents " by The [MASK]erpents , a collective of Wels[MASK] musicians including members of Echo and[MASK]the Bun[MASK]ymen , Super Furry Animals and Ectogram that was described by one journal[MASK]st as " possibly th[MASK] strangest pop group of all time " . 
 For a time , Capel Lligwy wa[MASK] used [MASK]s a private place of worship for Lligwy House , a " venerable mans[MASK]on " once owned by the Lloyd family which came into [MASK]he possession of William Irby , 1s[MASK] Baron Boston , in the 18th century . After the early part of the 18th century , however , the chapel became unused and began to fa[MASK]l into disrepair [MASK] The walls remain to gable level , wi[MASK]h some traces of render on the inside , but the roo[MASK] has gone . 
 Cap[MASK]l Lligwy is in th[MASK] Anglesey countryside near Llanallgo ; the parish church of St Gallgo , Llanallgo is about 0[MASK]@.@ 78 miles ( 1 @.@ 26 km ) away [MASK] Part[MASK]of the churc[MASK]ya[MASK]d wall remains , showing [MASK]hat it was originally within a mainly circular enclosure , as often found with early churches . [MASK]t is cared for by Cadw , the Welsh Assembly Government body responsible for the built heritage of Wales , and is [MASK]pen to the public . 
 
 = = Architecture and fittings = = 
 
 Capel Lligwy is built from rubble masonry ; at about 5 feet ( 1 @.@ 5 [MASK] ) up the walls , the style changes and smaller stones are insert[MASK]d into spaces [MASK]et[MASK]een the larger blocks , showing where the 14th @-@ century rebuilding started [MASK] The doorway is on the south side , headed by a plain arch , and dates[MASK]from the 12th century . There is a stone bellcote at the w[MASK]st end . There is no struct[MASK]ral division between the nave ( where the congregation wou[MASK]d ha[MASK]e sat ) and the chancel ( where the alta[MASK] would have been located ) . There[MASK]are no window openings on the nor[MASK]h side , b[MASK]t there is a blocked opening to the east ( about 5 feet ( 1 @.@ 5 m ) w[MASK]de ) and there [MASK]re the remains of a window on the sout[MASK] wall . There is a blocked windo[MASK] in the south wall of the[MASK]south chapel . The vault , which is about 27 square [MASK]eet ( 2 @.@ 5 m2[MASK]) , is [MASK]eached by stone steps from inside[MASK]the south chapel . Limestone slabs form the roof of the[MASK]vault and the floor of the chapel above . A stone in the[MASK]nave , about 2 square feet ( 0 @.@ 19 m2 ) with a hole in t[MASK]e top , might once have been used as a churchyard cross . 
 
 = = Assessment = = 
 
 Capel Lligwy has national recognition and statut[MASK]ry protection [MASK]ro[MASK] alteration as it has [MASK]een designated as a Grade II listed building – the lowest of the three grades of listing , design[MASK]ting " buildings of special interest , which warrant ever[MASK] effort being mad[MASK] to preserve [MASK]hem " . It was given this status on 2 September 1952 and has been listed because it is " important as a substantially 12t[MASK] @-@ century structure , with some architectural details surviving from this early period " ,[MASK]even though it is now in [MASK] " ruinous condition " . Cadw ( which [MASK]s responsible for the inclusion of Welsh buildings on the statutory lists )[MASK]also n[MASK]tes the " unusual 16th @-@ ce[MASK]t[MASK]ry vaulted south chapel " . 
 The 19th @-@ century antiquarian Angharad Llwyd mentioned the church in her history of Anglesey . She said that the architecture was of " the rudest kind , [ which ] bears testimony to its great ant[MASK]quity . " She recounted that a fox had on[MASK]e taken shelter in the ruins , and when it was dug out , the vault was discovered , " containing several human skeleto[MASK]s , which crumbled into dust , when exposed to the air " . She [MASK]dded that further expl[MASK]ration of the vault then revealed " a large mass of human bones , sever[MASK]l feet in depth "[MASK]. 
 A 1990 book about abandoned churches in Wales [MASK]efers to t[MASK]e ancien[MASK] monuments in this part of Anglesey , and calls Capel Lligwy a " medieval gesture of Christian power in a land so obviously imbued with the spirit of a pagan past " . It notes[MASK]that " the wheel [MASK]as turned full circle and Capel Lligwy today is just another ruined r[MASK]lic of a former age . " The authors describe the chapel as a [MASK] simple , square building " with a " small and ruggedly austere south chapel " ,[MASK]adding that the stone slabs [MASK]ver the vault are " almost in imitation of the ancient burial chambers which dot the surrounding landscape . " 
 
 
 = 2011 – 12 Michigan Wolverines men 's basketball team = 
 
 The 2011 – 12 Michigan Wolverines men 's bask[MASK]tbal[MASK] team represented the University of Michigan during the 2011 – 12 NCAA Division I men 's basketball season . The team played its [MASK]ome games in Ann Arbor , Michigan at Crisler Center for the 45th consecutive yea[MASK] . It had a seating capacity of 12 @,@ 721 . It was also th[MASK][MASK]team 's 95th straight season as a memb[MASK]r of th[MASK] [MASK]ig Ten Conference . Fifth @-@ year head coach John Beilein led the [MASK]eam , alongside All @-@ Big Ten players Trey Burke , Tim Hardaway , Jr. and Zack [MASK]ovak . [MASK]urke was named Big Ten Freshman of the Year and was Michigan 's first Asso[MASK]iated Press A[MASK]l @-@ American honoree since 1998 . 
 The team 's season began with a preseason media day and practices in October 2011 . In February 2012 , Michigan hosted ESPN 's College GameDay for the first time in a game against Ohio State . It was the eighth time a Big Ten team hosted the show , which began in 2005 . 
 The team was in the national rankings all season and ended as t[MASK]e 2011 – 12 Big Ten co @-@ [MASK]hampion with Michigan State and Ohio State . It [MASK]ad three victories over teams ranked in the top [MASK]0[MASK]at the time of the meeting ( eig[MASK]th @-[MASK] ranked Memphis , ninth @-@ ranked Michigan St[MASK]te and sixth @-@ rank[MASK]d Ohio S[MASK]ate ) . The team was undefeated at home until its last[MASK]home game of the season . Michigan lost in the semifinal[MASK] of the[MASK]2012 Big Ten Conference Tournament and bowed out in the second round of the 2012 NCAA Tournament to end the season with a 24 @-[MASK] 10 record . The team won the school 's f[MASK]rst Big Ten Conference Champi[MASK]nship sin[MASK]e the 1985 – 86[MASK]season and had th[MASK] school 's best Big Ten record[MASK]( 13 – 5 ) since the 1993 – 94 season .

It 's going to be one of th[MASK] weaker point guard drafts in years .[MASK]" Some observers thought Burke was at his peak [MASK]n terms of NBA potential .
