 In the battle , U.S. Marines , u[MASK]der the overall command of U.S[MASK] Major General Alexander Vandegrift , repulsed an atta[MASK]k[MASK]by the Japanese 35th Infantry[MASK]B[MASK]igade , under the command of[MASK]Japanese[MASK]Major General Kiyotake[MASK]Kawaguchi . The Marines were defendin[MASK] the Lunga perimeter that guarded Henderson Field on Guadalcanal , which was captured from the Japanese by the Alli[MASK]s in landings on Guadalcanal on 7 August 1942 . Kawaguchi 's uni[MASK] was sent to Guadalcanal in response to the Allied landings with the mission of recapturin[MASK] the airfield and driving the Allied forces from[MASK]the island . 
 Under[MASK]stimating the strength of Allied forces on Guadalcanal – abo[MASK][MASK] 12 @,@ 000 – Kawaguchi 's 6 @,@ 000 soldiers conduc[MASK]ed several nighttime frontal assaults on the U.S. defenses . The main Japanese assault occ[MASK]rred around Lunga ridge south of Henderson Field , man[MASK]ed by troops from several[MASK]U.S. Marine Corps units , [MASK]rimarily troops from the 1st[MASK]Raider an[MASK] 1st Parac[MASK]ute Battali[MASK]ns under U.S. Marine Corps Lieutenant Colonel Merritt A. Edson . Although the Marine defenses were almost overrun , Kawaguchi 's attac[MASK] was ultimately defeated , with heavy losses for the Japanese . 
 Because of the key participa[MASK]ion by Edson 's un[MASK]t in defending the ridge , the ridge was commonly referr[MASK]d to as " E[MASK]son 's " ridge in historical accounts of the battle in Western sources . After Edson 's Ridge , the Japanese continued to send troops to Guadalcanal for further attempts to retake Henderson Field , affecting Japanese offensive operations in other areas of the South Pacific[MASK][MASK] 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 
 = = = Guadalc[MASK]nal campaign = = = 
[MASK]
 On 7 August 1942 , Allied forces ( primarily U.S. ) landed[MASK]on Guadalcanal , Tulagi , and Florida Islands in the Solomon Islands .[MASK]The landings on the islan[MASK]s were meant to deny their [MASK]se by the Japanese as bases for threatening the supply routes[MASK]between the U.S. and [MASK]ustralia . They were also in[MASK]ended to secure the islands as starting points for [MASK] campaign to neutralize the major Japanese[MASK]base at Rabaul and support the Allied New Guinea campaign [MASK] The landings initiated the six @-@ month[MASK]@-@ [MASK]ong Guadalcanal campaign . 
 Taking the Japanese by surprise , by nightfall on 8 August the Allied land[MASK]ng forces had secured Tulagi and nearby small islands , as well as an airfield under construction at Lunga Point ( 9 ° 25 ′ 45 ″ S 160 ° 3 ′ 4 ″ E ) on the[MASK]north shore of the island of Guadalcanal east of the present day capital of Honiara . Vandegrift placed his 11 @,@ 000 troops of the 1st Marine Division on Guadalcanal in a loose perimeter around the Lunga Point area . 
 On 1[MASK] August , the airfield was named Henderson Field after Major Lofton Henderson , a Marine aviat[MASK]r who had been killed at the Battle of Midway . The Allied air[MASK]raft and pilots that subsequently operated out of Henderson Field were called the " Cactus Air [MASK]orce " aft[MASK]r the Allied code name for Guadalcanal . 
 In response to the Allied landi[MASK]gs on Gua[MASK]alcanal , the Japanese Imperial General Headquarters assigned the Imperial Japanese Army 's 17th Army — a corps @-@ s[MASK]zed command based at Rabaul ( 4 ° 11 ′ 56 ″ S 152 ° 9 ′ 57 ″ E ) and under the command of Lieutenant @-@ General Harukichi Hyakutake — with the task of ret[MASK]king Guadalcanal from Allied forces . The 17th Army — heavily involved with the Japanese ca[MASK]paign in N[MASK]w Guinea — had only a few units available to send to the souther[MASK] Solomons area . Of these units , the 35th Infantry Brigade — under Major General Kiyotake Kawaguchi — was at Palau , the 4th ( [MASK]oba ) Infantry Regiment was in the Philippin[MASK]s and the 28th ( Ichiki ) Infantry Regiment — und[MASK]r the command of Colonel Kiyonao Ichiki — was embarked on transport ships near Gua[MASK] . The different units began to move toward Guadalcanal immediately ;[MASK]Ichiki 's regiment —[MASK]the closest — arrived first . The " First Element " of Ichiki [MASK]s unit — consisting of about 917 soldiers — landed from destroyers at Taivu Point ( 9 ° 24 ′ 38 ″ S 160[MASK]° 20 ′ 56 ″ E ) , about[MASK]18 mi ( 29 km ) east of the Lunga perimeter , on August 1[MASK] . 
 Underestimating the strength of Allied forces on Guadalcanal , Ichiki 's First Element conducted a night[MASK]ime frontal assault on Marine positions at Alligator Creek on the [MASK]ast side of the Lunga perimeter in the early morning hours of August 21 . Ichiki 's assault was repulsed with devastating losses for the attackers in what became [MASK]nown as the Battle of the [MASK]enaru : all but 128 of the 9[MASK]7 men of the First Element [MASK] including Ichiki himself ) were killed in [MASK]he battle . The survi[MASK]ors returned to Taivu Point , notified 17th Army headquarters of their defeat in the battle and awaited further reinforcements and orders from Rabaul . 
 By 23 August , Kawaguchi 's unit had reache[MASK] Truk an[MASK] was loaded onto slo[MASK] transport ships for the rest of the trip to Guadalcanal [MASK] Because of the damage caused by Allie[MASK] air attack to a separate troop convoy during the [MASK]attle of the Eastern Solo[MASK]ons , the Japanese decided not to deliver Kawaguchi 's troops to Guadalcanal [MASK]y slow transport ship ; instead , the ships carrying Kawaguchi 's soldiers were sent [MASK][MASK] Rabaul . From there , the Japanese planned to[MASK]deliver Kaw[MASK]guchi 's men to Guadalcanal by destroyers , staging through a Japanese naval base in the Shortland Islands . The Japanese destr[MASK]yers were usually able [MASK]o make the round trip down " The Slot " to Guadalcanal and back in a single night , minimizing their exposure to Allied air attack . However , most of the soldiers ' heavy equipment and supplies , such as heavy artillery , vehicles , and much food and ammunition , could not be taken to Guadalcanal with them . Thes[MASK] high @-@ speed destroyer runs to Guadal[MASK]anal , which occurred throughout t[MASK]e campaign , were later called the " Tokyo Express " by Allied forces and " Rat Transportation " by [MASK]he Japanese . The Japanese controlled the seas around the Solomon Islands during t[MASK]e nighttime and were not challe[MASK]ged by the Allies . [MASK]owever , any J[MASK][MASK]anese ship remaining within t[MASK]e 200 mi [MASK] [MASK]20 km ) range of the aircraft at Henderson Field in daylight was in [MASK]reat danger from air attacks . This " curious tactical situation " held for several months . 
 
 = = = Troop movement = = = 
 
 On 28 August , 600 of Kawaguchi 's troops were loaded on[MASK]o the destroyers Asagiri , Amagiri , Yugiri , and S[MASK][MASK][MASK]akumo , designated Destroyer Division 20 ( DD20 ) . Because of a shortage of fuel , DD20 could not make the entire round trip to Guadalcanal at high s[MASK]eed in one night , but had to start the trip earlier in the day so that they could complete the trip by[MASK]the next morning at a slower speed wh[MASK]ch conserved fuel . At 18 : 05 that day , 11 U.S. dive bombers from VMSB @-@ 232 un[MASK]er the command of Lt. Col. Richard Mangru[MASK] , flew from Hende[MASK]son Field and located and attacked DD20 about 70 mi ( 110 km [MASK] no[MASK]th of Guadalcanal , sinking Asagiri and heavily damaging Y[MASK]giri and Shirak[MASK]mo . Amagiri took Shirakumo in tow and the three destroyers returned to the Shortlands without completin[MASK] the[MASK]r miss[MASK]on . The attack on DD20 killed 62 of Kawaguchi 's soldiers and 94 crew members . 
 Subs[MASK]quen[MASK] " Express " [MASK]uns were more successful [MASK] Between 29 August and 4 Septembe[MASK] , var[MASK]ous Japanese light cruisers , destroyers , and patrol boats were able to land almost 5 @,@ 000 t[MASK]oops at Taivu Point , including all of the 35th Infantry Brigade , one [MASK]attalion of the Aoba Regim[MASK]nt , and the rest of Ichiki 's regiment . General Kawaguchi , who landed at Tai[MASK]u Point on the 31 August Express run , was placed in command of all the Japanese troops on Guadalcanal . On the nig[MASK][MASK] of 4 / 5 September [MASK] as three of the Express destr[MASK]yer[MASK] — Yūdachi , Hatsu[MASK]uki , and Murakumo — prepared to shell Henderson Field[MASK]after landing their troops ,[MASK]they detected and sank two U.S. sh[MASK]ps in the vicinity , the small , old destroyer transports ( called " APDs [MASK] by the[MASK]U.S. Marines ) USS Litt[MASK]e and Gregory that were use[MASK] to shuttle Allied troops arou[MASK]d the Guadalcanal / Tulagi area . [MASK] In spite of the successes of the destroyer runs , Kawaguchi insisted that as many soldiers of his brigade as possible be delivered to Guadalcanal by slow barges . Therefore , a convoy carrying 1 @,@ 100 of Kawaguchi 's troops and heavy equipment in[MASK]61 barges , ma[MASK]nly from the 2nd Battalion , 124th Infantry Regiment under the command of Colonel Akinosuka Oka , departed the northern coast[MASK]of Santa Isabel Island on 2 September . On 4 – 5 September[MASK], [MASK]ircraft from Henderson Field attac[MASK]ed the barge convoy , killing about 90 of the soldiers in the barges and destroying much of the unit 's heavy equipment . Most[MASK]of the remaining 1 @,@ [MASK]00 [MASK]roops were able to land nea[MASK] Kamimbo ( 9 ° 15 ′ 32 ″[MASK]S 159 ° 40 ′ 18 ″ E ) , west of the Lunga perimeter over the next few days . By 7 September , Kawaguchi had 5 @,@[MASK]200 troops at Taivu Point and 1 @,@ 000 west of the Lunga perimeter . Kawaguchi was confident enough that he could defeat the[MASK]Allied forces[MASK]facing him that[MASK]he declined an offer from the 17th Army for delivery [MASK]f one more infantry battalion to augmen[MASK] his forces . Kawaguchi b[MASK]lieved that there were only about 2 @,@ 000 U.S. Marines on Guadalcanal . 
 During this time , Vandegrift [MASK]ontinued to direct efforts to strengthen and [MASK]mprove the defenses of the Lunga perimeter . Between 21 August and 3 September , he relocated three Marine ba[MASK]talions — includ[MASK]ng the 1st Raider Battalion , under U.S. Lieutenant Colonel Merritt A. Edson ( Edson 's Raiders ) , and th[MASK] 1st Parachute Battalion — from Tulagi and Gavu[MASK]u to Guadalcanal . These units added a[MASK][MASK]ut 1 @,@ 500 troops to Vandegrift 's original 11 @,@ 000 men defending Henderson Field[MASK]. The[MASK]1st Parachute battalion , which had suffered h[MASK]avy casualties in the Battle of Tulagi and Gavutu @-@ Tanambogo in August , was placed under [MASK]dson 's command . 
 
 = = Battle = = 
 
 
 = = = Prelude =[MASK]= = 
 
 Kawaguchi set the date for his attack on the Lunga perimete[MASK] for 12 September and began mar[MASK]hing his forces west from Taivu towards Lunga Point on 5 September . He radioed 17th Army and requested that it carry out air strikes on Henderson [MASK]ield beginning on 9 September , and that naval warships be stationed off Lun[MASK]a Point on September 12 to " destroy any Americans[MASK]who attempted to flee from the island[MASK]. " On 7 September , Kawaguchi issued his attack plan to " rout and annihilate th[MASK] enemy in the vicinity of the Guadalcanal Island airfield . " Kawaguchi 's plan called for his forces to split into three , approach the Lunga perimeter inland , and launch a surprise night attack . Oka 's force would attack the perimeter from the west while Ichiki 's Seco[MASK]d Echelon — renamed the Kuma Battalion — would[MASK]attack from the east . The mai[MASK] attack would be by Kawaguchi 's " Ce[MASK]ter Body " , numb[MASK]ring 3 @,@ 000 men in three battalions , from the south of the Lunga perimeter . By 7 September , most of Kawaguch[MASK] 's tro[MASK]ps had started marching from Ta[MASK]vu towards Lunga Point along the coastline . A[MASK]out 250 Japanese troops remained behind to guard the brigade 's supply base at Taivu . 
 Meanwhile , [MASK]ative island scouts — directed by British government official and officer in the British Solomon Islands Prote[MASK]torate Defence Force , Martin Clemens — told the Marines of Japanese troops at [MASK]aivu , [MASK]ear the village of Tasimboko [MASK] about 17 mi ( 27 km ) east of Lunga . Edson launched a raid against the[MASK]Japanese troops at Taivu . Destroyer transports USS McKean and Manley and [MASK]wo patrol boats took 813 of Edson 's men to Taivu in two trips . Edson and his first wave of 501 troops landed at T[MASK]ivu at[MASK]05 : 20 ( local time ) on 8 September . Supported by aircraft from[MASK]Henderson Field and gunfire from the destroyer transports , Edson '[MASK] men a[MASK]vanced towards Tasimboko village but were slowed by Japanese resistance . At 11 : 00 , the r[MASK]st of Edson 's men landed . W[MASK]th this reinforcement and more support from the Henderson Field aircraft , Edson 's force pushed into the village . The Japanese defenders , believing a major landing was underway [MASK]ft[MASK]r[MASK]observing the concurrent approach of an Allied supply ship convoy heading towards Lunga Point , retreated into the jungle , leaving behind 27 dead . Two Marine[MASK] were kil[MASK]ed . 
 In Tasimboko , Edson 's troops discovered the supply base for Kawaguchi 's forces ,[MASK]including large stockpiles of food , ammunition and medical supplies , and a shortwave ra[MASK]io . The Marines seized documents , equipment and food supplies , destroyed the rest , and returned to the Lunga perimeter at 17 : 30 . The quantities of supplies an[MASK] [MASK]ntelligence from the captured document[MASK] revealed that at least 3 @,@ 000 J[MASK]panese troops were on the island and apparently pl[MASK]nning an attack . 
 Edson and Colonel Geral[MASK] Thomas , Vandegrift 's operati[MASK]ns officer ,[MASK]bel[MASK]eved that t[MASK]e J[MASK]panese attack would come at the Lu[MASK]ga Ri[MASK]ge , a narrow , gra[MASK]sy , 1 @,@ 000 [MASK] ( 1 @,@ 100 yd ) long , coral ridge ( 9 ° 26 ′ 39 ″ S 160 ° 2 ′ 50 ″ E ) parallel to the Lunga River just south of Henderson Field . The ridge offered a natural avenue of approach to the airfield , commanded the surrounding area and was almost undefended . Edson and [MASK]hom[MASK]s tried to persuade Vandegrift to move f[MASK]rces to defend the ridge , but Vandegrift refused , believing tha[MASK] the Japanese were more likely[MASK]to attack alon[MASK] the coast . Finally , Thomas convinced Vandegrift that the ridge was a good location for Edson 's Raiders to " rest " from their actions of the [MASK]receding month . On [MASK]1 September , the 840 men of Edson 's unit — including the 1st Raiders and the Paramarines — deployed onto [MASK]nd arou[MASK]d the ridge and prepared to defend it . 
 Kawaguchi 's Center Body of troops was planning to attack the[MASK]Lunga perimeter at the ridge , which they called " the cent[MASK]pede " ( mukade gata ) because of i[MASK]s shape . On 9 September , Kawagu[MASK]h[MASK] 's troops left the coast at Koli Point . Split into four columns , they marched into the jungle towards their predesignated a[MASK]tack points[MASK]south and southeast of the airfield . Lack of good maps , at le[MASK]st one faulty compass , and thick , almost impenetrable jungle caused the Japanes[MASK] columns to proceed slowly and zigzag , costing a lot of time . A[MASK] the same time , [MASK]ka 's troops [MASK]pproach[MASK]d the Lunga perimeter from the west . Oka had some intelligence[MASK]on the Marine defenses , extrac[MASK]ed from a U.S. Army pilot captured on 30 August . 
 During the day of 12 September , Kawaguchi 's troops strugg[MASK]ed through th[MASK] [MASK]ungle toward th[MASK]ir assembly points for [MASK]h[MASK]t night 's attacks . Kawaguchi wanted his three Center Body bat[MASK]alions in plac[MASK] by 14 : 00 , but they did not reach t[MASK]eir assembly areas until after 22 : 00 . Oka was also delay[MASK]d in his advance[MASK]towards t[MASK]e Marine lines in the west . Only the Kuma battalion reported that t[MASK]ey were in place on time . Desp[MASK]te the problems in[MASK]reaching the planned attack po[MASK]itions , Kawaguchi was still confident in his a[MASK]tack [MASK]lan because a[MASK]captured U.S. p[MASK]lot disclosed that th[MASK] ridge was the weakest part of the Marine defenses . Japanese bombers attacked the ridge during daytime on 11 – 12 September , causing a few casualties , in[MASK]luding two killed . 
 
 = = = First night 's action = = = 
 
 The American[MASK] knew of the approach of the J[MASK]panese forces from reports from native scouts and their own patrols , but did not know exactly where or when they would attack . The ridge around which Edson deployed his[MASK]men consisted of three dis[MASK]inct hillocks . At the southern tip and surrounded on three sides by thick jungle was Hill 80 ( so named because it rose 80 ft ( 24 m ) above sea level ) . Six hundr[MASK]d yards north was Hill 123 ( 123 ft ( 37 m ) high ) , the dominant feature o[MASK] the ridge . The northernmost hillock was unnamed and about 60 ft ( 18 m ) high . Edson placed the five companies from the Raider battalion on the west side of the ridge and the three Parachute battalion compan[MASK]es on the east side , holding positions in depth from Hill 80 back to Hil[MASK] 1[MASK]3 . Two of the five Raider companies , " B " and " C " , held a line between the ridge , a small , swampy lago[MASK]n , and the Lunga [MASK]iver . Machine @-@ gun teams from " E " Company , the heavy weapons[MASK]company , were sca[MASK]tered throughout the defenses . Edson placed his command post on Hill 123 . 
 At 21 : 30 on 12 September , the Japanese cruiser Send[MASK]i and three destroyers shelled[MASK]the Lunga perimeter for 20 minutes and illuminated the ridge with a searchlight . Japanese artillery began shelling the Marine lines , but did little damage . At the same time , scattered groups of Kawaguchi 's troops began skirmishing with Marines around the ridge . Kawaguchi 's 1st B[MASK]ttalion — led [MASK]y Major Yukichi Kokusho — attacked the Raider 's " C " company between the lagoon and the Lunga River , overrunnin[MASK] at least one platoon and forcing the Marine company to fall back to the ridge . Kokusho 's unit b[MASK]c[MASK]me entangled with troops from Kawaguchi 's 3rd Battalion under Lieutenant Colonel Kusukichi Watanabe , who[MASK]w[MASK]re still struggling to reach their attack positions , and the resulting [MASK]onfusion effectively stopped the Japanese attack on the ridge that night . Kawaguchi , who was having trouble locating where [MASK]e was in relation to the U.S. Marine lines as well as coordinating his troops '[MASK]att[MASK]cks , lat[MASK]r complained , " Due t[MASK] the devilish jungle , the brigade was scattered all over and was completely beyond my con[MASK]rol . In my whole life I have never f[MASK]lt s[MASK] disappointed and helpless . " Twelve U.S. Marines were killed ; Japanese casualties are unknown but perhaps somewhat [MASK]r[MASK]ater . Although both [MASK]ka in th[MASK] west and the Kuma unit in the eas[MASK] t[MASK]ied to attack the Marine lines that night , they failed to make contact and halted ne[MASK]r the Marine lines at dawn . 
 At fir[MASK]t light on 13 September , Cactus Air Force airc[MASK]aft and Marine ar[MASK]illery fired into the area just[MASK]south of the ridge , forcing any Japanese out in the open to s[MASK]ek cover in the nearby jungle . The Japanese[MASK]suffered several casualties , including two officers from Watanabe 's battalion . At 05 : 50 , Kawaguchi decided to regroup his forces for another attack that n[MASK]ght . 
 
 = = = Second night 's action on the ridge = = = 
 
 Expecting the Japanese to attack again that n[MASK]ght , [MASK]dson directed his troops to improve their defenses on an[MASK] around the ridge . After a failed attempt by two companies [MASK]o retake the ground on the Marine right [MASK]lank lost to Kokusho the night before , Edson repositioned his forces . He pulled his front back ab[MASK]ut 400 yd ( 370 m ) to a line that stretched 1 @,@ 800 yd ( 1 @,@ 600 m ) , star[MASK]ing at the Lunga River and crossing the ridge a[MASK]out 150 yd ( 140 m ) south of Hill 123 . Around and behind Hill 123[MASK]he placed[MASK]five companies . Any Ja[MASK]anese attackers surmounting Hi[MASK]l 80 [MASK]ould have to advan[MASK]e over 400 yd ( 37[MASK] m ) of open terrain to close with the Marine positions at Hill [MASK]23 . With only a few hours to prepare , the Marines were only able to c[MASK]nstruct rudimentary and shallow fortifications . They were low on ammunition , with one or two grenades for each Marine . Vandegrift ordered a reserve force consisting of the 2nd Battalion , 5th Marine Regiment ( 2 /[MASK]5 ) to move into a position just [MASK]o the rear of Edson 's troops . In addition , a battery of four 105mm howitzers from the 1[MASK]th Marine Regimen[MASK] moved to a location from where it could provide direct fire onto[MASK]the ridge , and a forward artillery observer was placed w[MASK]th Edson 's front line units . 
 Late in[MASK]the afternoon , Edson stepped onto a gr[MASK]nade box and addressed his exhauste[MASK] troops , saying , 
 You men have done a great[MASK]job , and I have just one more thing to ask of yo[MASK][MASK]. Hold out just one more night . I know we 've been w[MASK]thout sleep a long time . But we expect another attack from them tonight and they may come through here . I have every reason t[MASK] believe that we will have reliefs here for all of us in the morning . 
 Edson 's speech " raised the spirits " of [MASK]h[MASK] Raiders and helped them prepare mentally for the night ahead . 
 As the sun[MASK]set on 13 September , Kawaguchi faced Edson 's 830 Marines with 3 @,@ 000 troops of his brigade [MASK] plus an[MASK]assortment of light artillery . The night [MASK]as pitch black , with[MASK]no moon . At 21 : 00 , seven[MASK]Japanese destroyers briefly bombarded the ridge . Kawaguchi 's attack began just after nightfall , with K[MASK]kusho '[MASK] battalion assaulting Raider Comp[MASK]ny B on the Marine right flank , just to the west of the ridge . The force of the assault caused Company B to fall back to Hill 123 . Under Marine a[MASK]tillery fire , Kokusho reassembled his men and continued his a[MASK]tack . Without pausing to try to " roll @-@ up " the other nearby Mari[MASK]e units , whose flanks were now unprotected ,[MASK]Kokusho 's unit surged forward thro[MASK]gh the swampy lowlands bet[MASK]een the ridge and the Lunga River , heading for the airfie[MASK]d . Kokusho 's men came u[MASK][MASK]n a pile of Marine supplies an[MASK] rations . Not having eaten adequately for a couple of days , they paused to " gorge themselves " on the " C " and " K " rations . Kokusho ordered his[MASK]men to continue the attack . At about 03 : 00 , he led them against the M[MASK]rine units around the[MASK]northern portion of the ridge , just short of the air[MASK]ield , as well as Hill 123 . In the heavy fighting [MASK]hat followed , Kokusho and around 100 of his men were kill[MASK]d , ending that attack . 
 [MASK]eanwhile , Kawaguchi 's 2nd Battalion , under Major Masao Tamur[MASK] , assembled for their planned assault against Hill 80 from the jungle south of the ridge . Mari[MASK]e observers spotted T[MASK]mura 's preparations and called in artillery fire . At about 22 : 00 , a ba[MASK]rage from twelve 105 mm ( 4 @.@ 1 in ) guns hit[MASK]Tamura 's position . In response , two companies of Tamura 's tr[MASK]ops — numbering about [MASK]20 men — charge[MASK] up Hill 80 with fixed bayonets behind their own barrage of mortar fire and grenade[MASK] . Tamura 's attack hit [MASK]omp[MASK]ny B of the Marine Parachute battalion and also Raider Company B , pushing the Parachutis[MASK]s off the east side of the ridge into a draw below th[MASK] ridgeline . To protect the exposed Raide[MASK] Company B , Edson immediately ordered them to pull back onto Hill 123 . [MASK] At the same time , a Japane[MASK]e company from Watanabe 's battalion infiltr[MASK]ted through a gap between the east side of the ridge and Parachute Company C. Deciding that their positions were now untenable , Parach[MASK]te Companies B and C climbed onto the ridge and retreated to a position behind Hill 123 . In the dar[MASK]ness and confusion of the battle ,[MASK]the retreat q[MASK]ickly became confused and dis[MASK]rganized . A few Marines began yelling that the Japanese were attacking with poison gas , scaring other Mari[MASK]es [MASK]ho no longer possessed their gas masks . After arriving behind Hill 123 , some of the Marines continued on towards the airfield , repeating the word " withdraw " to anyone within earshot . Other Marines began to[MASK]follow them . Just at the moment that[MASK]it appeared that the Marines on the hil[MASK] were about to break and head for the rear in a rout , Edson ,[MASK]Major Kenneth D. Bailey from Edson 's staff , and other Marin[MASK] officers appeared and , with " v[MASK]vid[MASK]" languag[MASK] , herded the Mar[MASK]nes back into defensive [MASK]ositions around Hill 123 . 
 As the Marines formed into a horseshoe @-@ sh[MASK]ped [MASK]ine [MASK]round Hill 123 , Tamura 's battalion began a ser[MASK]es of frontal assaults [MASK]n the hill , charging up the saddle from Hill 80 and up from below the east side of the ridge . Under the light of parachute flares dro[MASK]ped by at least one Japanese flo[MASK]tplane , the Marines repulsed the first two attacks by Tamura 's men . Tamura 's troops hoisted a 75 mm ( 2 @.@ 95 in ) " regimental " gun to the top of Hill 80 in an effort to fire it directly at the Marines . Thi[MASK] gun , which "[MASK]could have turned [MASK]he tide in favor of the Japanese , " however , was di[MASK]abled by a faulty firi[MASK]g pin[MASK]. At midnight , during a short lull in the fighting , Edson ordered Parachute Companies B and C to advance from behind Hill 123 to strengthen his left flank . With fixed bayonets , t[MASK]e Para[MASK]arines swept forward , killi[MASK]g Japanese soldiers who had overrun the Marine lines and were [MASK]pparently preparing to roll up the Marine lines from the flank , and took position o[MASK] the east side o[MASK] th[MASK] hill . Marines from other units , as well [MASK]s members of Edson[MASK][MASK]s command staff , including Major Bailey , took ammunition and gr[MASK]nades under fire to the Marines around Hill 123 , who were running criti[MASK]ally low . Said Marine participant Captain William J. McKennan , " The Japane[MASK][MASK] attack was almost cons[MASK]ant , like a rain that subsi[MASK]es for a moment and then pours the harder ... When one wave was mowed down - and I mean mowed down - another followed it into death . " 
 The [MASK]apa[MASK]ese hit Edson 's left flank just after the Parachutists took position but were again stopped by Marine rifle , machine @-@ gun , mortar , and grenade fire . Marine 105 mm and 75 mm artillery was also taking a heavy toll on the attacking Japanese . A captured Japanese soldier[MASK]later [MASK]aid that his unit was " annih[MASK]lated " by the Marine artillery fire , [MASK]hich only 10[MASK]% of his company survived . 
 By 04 : 00[MASK], after withstanding several more[MASK]assaults , some of which resulted in hand @-@ to @-@ hand fighting , and severe sniper fire from all sides , Edson 's men were joined by troops from the 2nd Battalion , 5th Marine Regiment , [MASK]ho helped repulse two more Japanese attacks before dawn . Throug[MASK]out the night , as Kawaguchi 's men came close to overrunning the Marine defenses , Edson remained standing about 20 yd ( 18 m ) behind the Marine firing line on Hill 123 , exhorting his troops and d[MASK]recting their defensive efforts . Said Marine Captain Tex Smith , who was in position to observe Edson for most of the night , " I can say that if there is such a thing a[MASK] one man holding a battalion together , Edson did it that night . He stood just behind the front lines – stood , when most of us hugged the ground . " 
 During the hea[MASK]y fighting , portions of three Japanese companies , inclu[MASK]ing two from Tamura 's [MASK]nd one from Watanabe 's bat[MASK]alions , skirted the Marine defenses on the ridge , w[MASK]ile suffering heavy [MASK]osses from Marine gunfire , and reached the edge of [MASK] Fighter One " , a secondary runway of[MASK]Henderso[MASK] Field . A counterattack by th[MASK] Marine engineers stopped one Japanese company 's advances and forced it to retreat . Th[MASK] other tw[MASK] companies waited at the edge of the jungle for reinfor[MASK]emen[MASK]s to arrive befo[MASK]e attacking into the open area around the airfield . When no reinforcements joined them , both companies went back to their o[MASK]iginal positions s[MASK]uth of t[MASK]e ridge after daybreak . Most of the rest of Watanabe 's bat[MASK]alion did not participate in t[MASK]e battle because they lost contact with their commander durin[MASK] the night . 
 As the sun rose on 14 September , pockets o[MASK] Japanese soldiers remained scattered along both sides of the ridge . But[MASK]with Tamura 's battalion shattered after losing ¾ o[MASK][MASK]its officers and men , and with heavy casualties to his other attacking units as well [MASK] Kawaguch[MASK] 's assault on the ridge had effectively ended . A[MASK]out 100 Japane[MASK]e soldiers still remained in the open on[MASK]the south[MASK]slope of [MASK]ill 80 , perhaps preparing [MASK]or one [MASK]ore charge on Hill 123 . [MASK]t first light , three U.S. Army aircraft from the 67th Fighter Squadron at Henderson Field , acting on a request personally delivered by Bailey , strafed the Japanese near Hill[MASK]80 and killed most of them , with the few survivors retreating back int[MASK] the jungle . 
 
 = = = Kuma and Oka attacks = = = 
 
 As the battle on the ri[MASK]ge took place , Kawaguchi 's Kuma and Oka units also a[MASK]tacked the Marine defenses on the east and west s[MASK]des of the Lunga perimeter . The Kuma battalion — [MASK]e[MASK] by Major Takeshi Mizuno — attacked the southeastern sector of the Lunga perimeter , defended by Marin[MASK]s of the 3rd Battalion , 1[MASK]t Mari[MASK]e Regiment ( 3 / 1 ) . Mizuno 's attack started around midnight , with one company attacking through Marine artillery fire and engaging in h[MASK]n[MASK] [MASK]-@ to @-@ hand combat with the Marine defenders before being thrown back . Mizuno was killed in the attack . After daybreak , t[MASK]e Marines , believing that the rest of Mizuno 's battalion was still in the area [MASK] sent forward six light tanks without infantry support to sweep the [MASK]rea [MASK]n front of the Marine lines ; four Ja[MASK]anese 37 mm ( 1 @.@ 46 in[MASK]) anti @-@ tank guns destroyed or disable[MASK] three of them . After abandoning their burning tanks , several of the[MASK]disabled tanks ' crewmembers were bayoneted and killed by the Japanese . One tank tumbled down an embankment into t[MASK]e Tenaru River , drow[MASK]in[MASK] [MASK]ts crew . 
 At 23 : 00 on 14 September , the remnants of the Kuma battalion conducted another attack on the same portion of the Marine lines , but were repulsed . A final " weak " attack by [MASK]he Kuma unit on the evening of 15 September was also defeated . 
 Oka 's un[MASK]t of about 650 men atta[MASK]ked the Marines at several[MASK]locations on [MASK]he west side of the Lunga perimeter . At about 04 : 00 on 14 September , [MASK]wo Japanese companies attacked posit[MASK]ons held by the 3rd Battalion[MASK], 5th Marine Regiment ( 3 / 5 ) near the coast and were thrown back with heavy losses . Another Japanese company captured a small ridge s[MASK]m[MASK]what inland but was then p[MASK]nned down by Marine artillery fire throughout the day and took heavy losses before w[MASK]thd[MASK]awing on the evening of 14 September . T[MASK]e rest of Oka 's unit failed t[MASK] fin[MASK] the Mari[MASK]e lines and did not participate in the attack . 
 
 = = Aftermath = = 
 
 At 13 : 05 on 14 September , Kawaguchi led the survivors of his shattered brigade away from the ridge and deeper into the jungle , where they rest[MASK]d and tended to their wounded[MASK]all the next day . Kawagu[MASK]hi 's units we[MASK]e then ordered to withdraw west to the Matanikau [MASK]iver valley to join with Oka 's unit , a 6 mi ( 9 @.@ 7 km ) marc[MASK] over difficult terrain . Kawaguchi 's troops began the march on the morning of 1[MASK] September . Almost every soldier able to walk had to help carry the wounde[MASK] . As the march progressed , the [MASK]xhausted and hungry soldiers [MASK] who had eaten their last rations on the morning before [MASK][MASK]eir withdrawal , began to discar[MASK] their heavy equipment an[MASK] then their rifles . By the time mos[MASK] of them reached Oka 's positions at Kokumbona five days later , only half still carried their weapons . The Kuma battalion 's survivors ,[MASK]attempt[MASK]ng to follow Kawaguc[MASK]i 's Center Body forces , became lost , wandered for three weeks in the jungle , and[MASK]almost sta[MASK]ved to death before finally reaching [MASK]awaguchi '[MASK] camp . 
 [MASK]n total , Kawaguchi 's forces lost about 830 killed in the attack , including 350 in Tamura 's battalion , 200 in Kokusho 's battalion , 120 in Oka 's fo[MASK]ce , 100 in the Kuma battalion , and 60 in Watanabe 's battalion[MASK]. An unknown number of wounded also died during the withdrawal march to the Matanika[MASK] . O[MASK] and around the ri[MASK]ge , th[MASK] Marines[MASK]counted 500 Japanese dead , includ[MASK]ng 200 on the slopes of Hill 123 . The Marines suffe[MASK]ed 80 [MASK]illed between 12 and 14 S[MASK]ptember . 
 On 17 September[MASK], Vandegrift sent two companies from the 1st Battalion , 1st Marine Regiment ( 1 / 1 ) to pursue the retreating Japanese . The Marines were ambushed by two Japanese companies acting as rear @-@ gu[MASK]rds for the withdrawal[MASK], and one Marine platoon was pinned dow[MASK] as the rest of the Marines retreated . The Marine company commander requested permission to attempt to rescu[MASK] his platoon but was denied by Vandegrift .[MASK]By nightfall , the Japanese overran and nearly an[MASK]ihilated the platoon , killing 24 Marines with only a few wounded members of the platoon surviving [MASK] On 20 September , a patrol f[MASK]om Edson 's Raiders enc[MASK]untered stragglers fro[MASK] Kawaguchi 's retreating colum[MASK] and called in artillery fire that killed 19 of them . 
[MASK]As t[MASK]e Japanese regrouped west of the Matanikau , th[MASK] U.S. forces concentrated on shoring up and strengthening their Lunga de[MASK]enses . On 14 September , Vandegrift moved an[MASK]ther battalion , the 3rd Battalion , 2nd Marine Regiment ( 3 /[MASK]2 ) , fr[MASK]m Tulagi to Guadalcanal . On 18 September , an Allied naval convoy delivered 4 @,@ 1[MASK]7 men from the 3rd Provisional Marine Brigade ( the U.S. 7th Marine Regiment augmented by addit[MASK]onal support units ) to Guadalcanal . These reinforcements all[MASK]wed Vandegrift — beginning on 19 Septemb[MASK]r — to establish an unbroken lin[MASK] of de[MASK]en[MASK]e around the Lunga perimeter . Vandegrift 's forces ' next significant clash[MASK]s with the J[MASK]panese occurred along the Matanikau Riv[MASK]r from 23 – 27 September and 6 – 9 October . 
 
 = = Significance = = 
 
 On 15 Se[MASK]tember , General Hyak[MASK]take at Rabaul learned of Kawaguchi 's d[MASK]feat , th[MASK] Imperial Japanese Army 's first defeat in[MASK]olving a unit of this size in the war . The general forwarded the news to th[MASK] Imperial General Headqu[MASK]rters in Japan . In an emergency session , the [MASK]op Japanese army and navy command staffs concluded that , " Guadalcanal might develop into the decisive battle of the war . " The results of the[MASK]battle beg[MASK]n to[MASK]have a telling strat[MASK]gic [MASK]mpact on Japanese operations in other areas of[MASK]the Pacific . Hy[MASK]kutake realized that , i[MASK] [MASK]rder to send suffi[MASK]ient troop[MASK] and materiel to defeat the Allied forces [MASK][MASK] Guadalcan[MASK]l , he could no longer support the major Japanese offensive [MASK]n the Kokoda Track in New Guinea . Hyakutake — with the concurrence of the General[MASK]Headquarter[MASK] — ordered his troops on New Guinea , who were within 30 mi ( 48 km ) of their objective of Port Moresby — to withdraw until the Guadalcanal matter[MASK]was resolve[MASK] . The Japane[MASK]e were never able to restart their dri[MASK]e towards Port Moresby ; the defeat at Edson 's Ridge contributed not only to Japan 's defeat in the Guadalcanal campaign , but also to Japan 's ultimate d[MASK]feat throu[MASK]hout the South Pacific . 
 After delivering more forces during the next month the Japanese mounted a maj[MASK]r ground offensive on Guadalcanal , led by Hyakutake[MASK], i[MASK] late Octobe[MASK] 1942 at the Battle fo[MASK] Henderson [MASK]ie[MASK]d , but it resulted in an even more decisive defeat fo[MASK] the Japanese . Vandegrift later stated th[MASK]t Kawaguchi 's assa[MASK]lt on the ridge in September was the only time during the entire campaign he had doubts[MASK]about the outcome and that[MASK]had it succeeded , " we would have been in a pretty ba[MASK] co[MASK]dition . " H[MASK]storian Richard B. Fra[MASK]k adds , " The Japanese never came closer to victory on the island itself than in September 1942 , on a ridg[MASK] thrusting up from[MASK]the jungle just south of the critical airfield , best [MASK]nown ever after as Bloody Ridge . " 
 
 
 = New Jersey Route 50 = 
 
 Route 50 is a state highway in the southern part of the U.S. [MASK]tate of New Jersey . It runs 26 @.@ 02 mi ( 41 @.@ 88 km ) from an intersection with U.S. Rou[MASK]e 9 ( US [MASK] ) and the Garden State Parkwa[MASK] in Upper Township , Cape [MASK]ay County to an intersection with US 30 and County Route 563 ( CR 563 ) in [MASK]gg Harbor City , Atlantic County . The route , which is mostly a two @-@ lane undivided ro[MASK]d , passes through mostly rural areas of Atlantic and Cape May counties as well as the communities of Tuckahoe , Corbin City , Estell Manor , and Mays Landing . NJ 50 intersects several roads , includ[MASK]ng Route 49 in Tu[MASK]kahoe , US 40 in Mays Landing , and [MASK]S 322 and the Atlantic City Expressway in [MASK]amilton Township[MASK]. 
 The port[MASK]on of c[MASK]rrent Route 50 between Seaville and Petersburg received[MASK]funding in 1910[MASK]to become a spur of the Ocean Hi[MASK]hway . In 1917 , what is now Route 50 was [MASK]esignated a part of pre @-@ 1927 Route 14 , a route that was to run from Cape May to[MASK]Egg Harbor City . Route 50 was designated onto its current alignment in 1927 , replacing t[MASK]is portion [MASK]f pre @-@ 1927 Route[MASK]1[MASK] . In 1960 , a freeway was proposed for Route 50 , running from the Garden State Parkway in Dennis Town[MASK]hip to US 30 in Mullica To[MASK]nship . This proposal was canceled by the mid @-@ 1970s due to financial and environmental concerns as well as lack of traffic . The intercha[MASK]ge between Route 50 and the Atlantic City [MASK]xpressway was reconstructed into a full i[MASK]terch[MASK]nge , with completion in June 2010 . 
 
 = = Route description = = 
 
 Route 50 begins at an i[MASK]tersection with US 9 in[MASK]th[MASK] Seaville section of Upper Township , Cape Ma[MASK] County , heading to the north on a two @-@ lane undivided road . From [MASK]he southern terminus , a ramp provides access to and from the southbound Garden S[MASK]ate Parkway . The road heads north through mostly rural wooded areas with some buildings . It intersects CR 671 in Greenf[MASK]eld before coming to a j[MASK]nc[MASK]ion with [MASK]R 616 . Later , Route 50 Cedar [MASK]wamp Creek in an area of marshland . At this crossing , the road runs closely parallel to a Conrail Shared Assets Operations railroad line before entering P[MASK]tersburg , where it splits from th[MASK] railroad tracks and comes to a crossroad with CR 610 . Upon leaving Peters[MASK]urg , Route 50 turns to the[MASK]north again and crosses over the Conrail Shared Assets Opera[MASK]ions railroad line , intersecting CR 631 . It co[MASK]tinues to Tuckaho[MASK] and comes to CR 669 . Past this intersection , the route[MASK]meets CR 557 and CR 664 . Route 50 forms a concurrency with CR 557[MASK]and the two routes head north and encounter the eastern terminus of[MASK]Route 49 before leaving Tuckahoe . 
 Not far after Route 49 ,[MASK]the road crosses the Tuckahoe River int[MASK] [MASK]orbin City , Atlantic County . In Corbin City [MASK] it [MASK]eads into residential areas , with CR 611 looping to the west of the route . Route 50 and C[MASK] 5[MASK]7 continue northwes[MASK] and intersect CR 648 , where the road turns north into more forested areas . At the junction with CR 645 [MASK] [MASK]he route turn[MASK] to the nort[MASK]east and enters Estell M[MASK]nor , becoming Broad Street . CR 557 splits from Route 5[MASK] by heading northwest on [MASK]uena Tuckahoe Road and Route 50 heads through some a[MASK]ricultural clearings concurrent with CR 557 Truck , pass[MASK]ng to the west of the MacNamara Wildl[MASK]fe Area , which is known as a breeding ground for several species of birds . The route intersects CR 637 , turning to the nort[MASK]east . 
 After passing some homes and Stephen Lake , the road turns to the north and passes to the west of Est[MASK][MASK]l Manor County Park . The route crosses the South River into Weymouth Township , passing the residential [MASK]ommunity of Belc[MASK]ville to the east and meeting CR 669 . It soon enters Hamilton To[MASK]nship , where the name of the road becomes Mill [MASK]treet and it comes to a junction with US 40 ( Hard[MASK]ng Highway ) . CR 557 Truck heads to the west on US 40 at this point while Rout[MASK] 50 heads east on US 40 , and CR 616 continues north . 
 US 40 and NJ 50 follow the Harding Highway , a two @-@ lane undivided r[MASK]ad , t[MASK]rning to the northeast and crossing the Great Egg Harbor River . Upon passing over t[MASK]e river , enters Mays Landing and turns north , encountering CR 617 before passing over an aband[MASK]ned railroad line and heading into the downtown a[MASK]ea of Mays [MASK]anding . He[MASK]e , the road crosses CR 559 , and US 40 splits fro[MASK] NJ 50 by[MASK]turning east along that road . Meanwhile , [MASK]oute 50 continues north on Cape May Avenue , passing through [MASK]eveloped[MASK]areas . It leaves May[MASK] Landing and heads into back into f[MASK]rests . The route turns to the northeast , [MASK]assing near the Clover Le[MASK]f Lakes residenti[MASK]l development , before coming to an interchange with US 322 ( Black Horse Pike ) . 
 Past this inte[MASK]change , Route 50 wid[MASK]ns to a four @-@ lane divided highway and reache[MASK] a full[MASK]interchange with the Atlantic City Expressway . The route becomes a two @-@ lane undivided road again and continues[MASK]through inhabi[MASK]ed areas , crossin[MASK] into Galloway Township , wh[MASK]re there is an intersection with CR 686 . A short distance later , the road [MASK]rosses New Jersey Transit ’ s Atlantic City Line near the Egg Harbor Cit[MASK] Station and ent[MASK]rs Egg Harbor City , turn[MASK]ng[MASK]into Philadelphia Aven[MASK]e . A block after the railroad crossing , Route 50 end[MASK] at an inters[MASK]ction with US 30 and CR 563 ( White Horse Pike ) , with CR 563 conti[MASK]uing north on [MASK]hiladelphia Avenue at this point . 
 Route[MASK]50 is an important route linking t[MASK]e Atl[MASK]ntic City [MASK]xpressway with the Jers[MASK]y Shore resorts in Cape M[MASK]y County , serving as an alternate to more congested routes . It also serve[MASK] as evacuation route from Cape May County to inland areas in the even[MASK] of a hurricane . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 The portion of current Route 50 between Seaville and Petersburg received fund[MASK]ng to become a sp[MASK]r of the O[MASK]ean Highway in 1910 . The modern @-@ day alignment o[MASK] Route 50 was legislated as part of pre @-@ 1927 [MASK]oute 14 in 1917 , a route[MASK]that was to run from Cape May to Egg Harbor City . In the 1927 New Jersey state highway renu[MASK]bering , the portion of pre @-@ 1927 Route 14 between Seaville and Eg[MASK] Harbor City was designated as Route 50 , the highest state route number assigned in [MASK]h[MASK] renumbering . Route 50 retained i[MASK]s current routing in the 1953 New Jersey state highway renumbering . A fr[MASK]eway was proposed for Route 50 around 1960 , running from the Garden State Parkway in Dennis Township north to US 30 in Mullica Township . This proposed freeway[MASK]was intended to provide economic development to the [MASK][MASK]gion as well as provi[MASK]e a be[MASK]ter route to the Jersey Shore resorts of Cape May County for travelers from the Delaware Valley . However , this freeway w[MASK]s canceled by the mid @-@ 1970s due to financial and environmental concerns as well as lack of traffic along Route 50 [MASK] On Novembe[MASK] 21 , 2008 , construction bega[MASK] on making the interchange with the Atlantic City Expressway a full interchange as pa[MASK]t of a series of improvements[MASK]set for the Atlantic City Expressway . This project was completed on J[MASK]ne 18 , 2010 . 
 
 = = Major intersections = = 
 
 
 
 = Air Rhodesia Flight 825 = 
 
 Air Rhodesia Flight 825 was a [MASK]cheduled passe[MASK]ger flight that was shot down by the Zimbabwe People 's Revolutionary Arm[MASK] ( ZIPRA ) on 3 Septem[MASK]er 1978 , during the Rhodesian [MASK]us[MASK] War . T[MASK]e aircraft involved , a [MASK]ickers[MASK]Viscount named the Hun[MASK]ani , was flying the last leg of Air Rhodesia 's regular scheduled service from Vict[MASK]ria Falls to[MASK]the capital Salisbury , via the resort town of Kariba . 
 Soon afte[MASK] Flight 825 took off , a group of ZIPRA guerrillas scored a direct [MASK]it o[MASK] its starboard wing with a Soviet @-@ made Strela 2 surface @-@ to @-@ air infrared homing missile , critically damaging the aircraft and forcing an emergency landing . An atte[MASK]pted belly landing in a cotton field just west of Karoi was foiled by an unseen ditch [MASK] which[MASK]caused the plane to cartwheel and break up . Of the 52 passengers and four crew , 38 died in this crash ; the insurgents then approached the wreckage , rounded up the 10 survivors they could see and massacred them with automa[MASK]ic gun[MASK]ire . Three passenger[MASK] survived by hiding in the surrounding bush , while a further five lived because[MASK]they had g[MASK]ne to look for[MASK]water[MASK]before the guerrillas arrived . 
 ZIP[MASK]A lea[MASK]er Joshua[MASK]Nkomo publicly claimed responsibility[MASK]for shooting down the Hunyani in an intervie[MASK] with the BBC 's Today programme the same evening , saying the aircraft had been used for military purposes , but denied that his men had killed survivors on the ground . The majority of Rhodesians , both black and white , saw the attack as an act of terrorism . A fierce white Rh[MASK]desian backlash followed against perceived enemies , with many whites[MASK]beco[MASK]ing violently resentful and suspici[MASK]us of blacks in general , even t[MASK]ough few black Rhodesians sup[MASK]orted attacks of this kind . Reports viewing the attack negatively a[MASK]p[MASK]ared in international journals such as Time magazine , but there was almost no acknowl[MASK]dgement of it by overseas governments , much to the Rhodesian government 's indignation .[MASK][MASK] Talks between Nkomo and Prime Minister Ian Smith , which had been[MASK][MASK]rogressing promisingly , were immediately suspended by the furious[MASK]Rhodesi[MASK]ns , with Smith calling Nkomo a " monster " . On 10 September , Smith announced the extensio[MASK] of martial law over selected areas . The Rhodesi[MASK]n Security Forces launched several retaliat[MASK]ry [MASK]trikes into[MASK]Zambia and Mozambique ove[MASK] th[MASK] following months , attacking bo[MASK]h ZIPRA and its[MASK]rival , th[MASK] Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army ( ZANLA ) . The attack on ZIPRA in particular brought great controversy as many of those killed were refugees camping in and around guerrilla positions . Five months later , in February 1979 , ZIP[MASK]A shot down Air Rhodesia Flight 827 , another civilian fl[MASK]ght , in an[MASK]almost identical incident . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 A dispute over the t[MASK]rms [MASK]or the granting of full sovereig[MASK]ty to the self @-@ gover[MASK]ing colony of Rhodesia ( or Southern Rhodesia ) led the colonial government , headed by Prime Minister Ian Smith , to[MASK]unilaterally declare independen[MASK]e from t[MASK]e United Kingdom on 11 November 1965 . The idea of " no in[MASK]ependence before major[MASK]ty rule " had recently gained ground in Britain and elsewhere amid decolonisation , and Rhodesia 's government was dominated by t[MASK]e country 's whi[MASK]e [MASK]inority , so the unilateral declaration went unrecognised internationally . Britain and the United Natio[MASK]s imposed economic sanctions on Rhodesia . 
 Two rival communist @-@ backed bla[MASK]k nationalist groups initiated military campaigns to overthrow the government and introduce majority rule : the Chinese @-@ aligned Zimbabwe African [MASK]ational Union ( ZANU ) , mostly comprising Shonas , created the Zimbabwe A[MASK]rican National Libe[MASK]ation Army ( ZANLA ) and adopted aspects of Maoist doctrine , while the Ndebe[MASK]e @-@ dominated Zimbabwe African Pe[MASK]ple 's Un[MASK]on [MASK] ZAPU ) , aligned with Soviet @-@ style Marxism – [MASK]eni[MASK]ism and the Warsaw Pact , mobilised the Zimbabwe People 's Revolutionary Army ( ZIPRA ) . These[MASK]guerrilla ar[MASK]ies pr[MASK]ceeded to wage what they called the " Second Chimurenga " against the Rhodesian government and security forces . The resulting conflict , the Rhodesi[MASK]n Bush War , began in ea[MASK]nest in December 1972 , when ZANLA attacked Altena and Whistlefield Fa[MASK]ms in north @-@ eastern Rhodesia . 
 After the security forces [MASK]oun[MASK]ed a successful counter [MASK]-@ insurgency campaign during 1973 and 1974 , developments overseas caused the conflict 's momentum to shift in the insurgents ' favour . The leftist Carn[MASK]tion Revolution of April 1974 caused Portugal[MASK]to withdraw its key economic [MASK]upport for Smith 's administration , and led to Mozambique 's independence the followi[MASK]g year as[MASK]a communist state openly allie[MASK] with ZANU . Around the same time , Rhodesia[MASK]'s other main backer , South Africa , adopted a détente initiati[MASK]e that forced a ceasefire , giving the guerrillas time to regroup . Following the abort[MASK]ve Vict[MASK]ria Falls Conference of August 1975 , Smith and the ZAPU leader Joshua Nkomo held unsuccessful talks between December 197[MASK] and March 1976 . ZANU a[MASK]d ZAPU announced in October 1976 , during the run @-@ up to the un[MASK]uccessf[MASK]l Geneva Conference[MASK]in December , that they would henceforth attend conferences as a joint " Patriotic Front " . 
[MASK]In March 1978 , Smith and non @-@ militant natio[MASK]alist groups headed by Bishop Abel Muzorewa , the Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole and Chief Jeremiah Chirau [MASK]greed what became th[MASK] " Internal Settlement " . This created a joint black – white transitional government , with the country due to be reconstituted as Zimbabwe Rhodesia in June 1979 , pursuant[MASK]to multiracial elections . ZANU and ZAPU were invited to participate , but refused ; Nkomo [MASK]ardonically dubbed Smith 's black colleague[MASK] " the blacksmiths " . ZANU proc[MASK]aimed 1978 to be " The Year of the People " as the war conti[MASK]ued .[MASK]Officia[MASK]s from Muzo[MASK]ewa 's United African National Co[MASK]ncil , sent to the provinces to explain the Internal Settlemen[MASK] to rural blacks , were killed by Marxist – Leninist guerril[MASK]as . Insurgents also began to targe[MASK] Christian [MASK]issionaries , climaxing in the killing of n[MASK]ne British missionaries and four childre[MASK] at Elim Mission ne[MASK]r the Mozambican border on 23 [MASK]une . 
 The transitional government was badl[MASK] received abroad , partly because t[MASK]e Internal Settlement kept control of law enforcement ,[MASK]the military , the ju[MASK]iciary and the civil service under white control . No[MASK]country r[MASK]cognised Rhodesia 's i[MASK]t[MASK]rim administration[MASK]. Smith again worked to bring Nkomo into t[MASK]e government , hoping this would lend it some credence domestically [MASK] prompt diplomatic[MASK]recognit[MASK]on overseas , and help the security forces defeat ZANLA . Starting on 14 August 1978 , he[MASK]attended secret meetings with Nkomo in Lusaka , Zam[MASK]ia ( where ZAPU was based [MASK] , doing s[MASK] with the assi[MASK]tance of the mining corporation Lonrho . Attempts were made to also involve [MASK]he ZANU leader Robert Mugabe , but Mugabe would ha[MASK]e no part in the talks . According to the South African military historian Jakkie Cilliers , negotiations between Smith and Nkomo progressed well and " seem[MASK]d on the verge of success " by the start of September 1[MASK]78 . On 2 September , Smith and Nkomo revealed publicly that the secret meetings had [MASK]aken place . 
 
 = = Incident = = 
 
 
 = = = Prior threats to Rhodesi[MASK]n air traffic = = = 
 
 Rhodesian air tr[MASK]ffic was not seriously threatened until about 19[MASK]7 , in the latter stages of the war ; before this time , neither revolutionary force had the weapons to launch a viable attack against an aerial target . The weapon that made such[MASK]attacks feasible for ZIPRA was the Strela 2 shoulder @-@ launched surface @-@ to @-@ air [MASK]issile launcher , supplied by the Soviet [MASK]nio[MASK] from the mid @-@ 1970s as [MASK]art of the Warsaw Pact 's materiel support . By September 1978 , there had been 20 reported attempts to shoot down Rhodesian military aircraft using these weapons , none of[MASK]whi[MASK]h had been successfu[MASK] . Some Rhodesia[MASK] Air Force Dakotas had been hit , but all had survived and landed safely . No civilian aircraft had yet been targeted[MASK]during the[MASK]Bush War . 
 
 = = = Flight = = = 
 
 [MASK]ir [MASK]hodesia was the country 's national airline [MASK] established by the government on 1 September 1967 to succeed Central African Airw[MASK]ys , w[MASK]ich was d[MASK]ssolved at the end of that year . Based at Salisbury Airport , Air Rhodesia 's flight network during the late 1970s comprised a domestic programme of passenger and cargo[MASK]flights , as[MASK]well as international servic[MASK]s to the South African[MASK]cities of Johan[MASK]esburg and Durban . 
 The Flight 825[MASK]aircraft was a Vickers Visco[MASK]nt 78[MASK][MASK] , a British @-@ made turboprop aircraft with two engines on each wing . It was named the Hunyani aft[MASK]r the river of th[MASK] same name , which flowed between Lake Kariba and the Rhodesian capital Salisbury . 
 The Hunyani was on the[MASK]second and final leg o[MASK] its regular scheduled journey between Victoria Falls and Salisbury , stopping over in the resort town of Kariba . Despite the occasional rocket and mortar attacks l[MASK]unched on Kariba by ZIPRA guerrill[MASK]s on the northern side of the Zambezi ( in Zambia ) , the resort had endured as one of Rhodesia 's choice tourist destinations . The flight on 3 [MASK]eptember 19[MASK]8 , Sunday afternoon , from Kariba to Salisbury carried four crew members and 52 passengers , most of w[MASK]om were holidaymakers from Salisbury , returni[MASK]g home after a weekend at the lake . The flight took off from Kariba Airport on schedule soon after 17 : 00 Central Africa Time . 
 Flight 825 was piloted by 36 @-[MASK] year @-@ old Captain John Hood , a native of Bulawayo who had gained his commercial pilot licence in 1966[MASK]. He had flown Viscounts for Air Rhodesia since 1968 , and had also served in the Rhodesian [MASK]ir Force on a voluntary basis . His first officer , Garth Beaumont , was 31 y[MASK]ars old , and had lived in Rhodesia for most of his life , having i[MASK]migrated as a child from S[MASK]uth Africa . The two air stewardesses were Dulcie Esterhuizen , 21 years old [MASK]nd from Bulawayo , and 23 @-@ year @-@ old [MASK]ouise Pears[MASK]n , from Salisbury . 
 
 = = = Shootdown = = = 
 
 A group[MASK]of ZIPRA guerrillas , armed with a Strela @-@ 2 launcher , waited in the bush beneath Flight 825 's flightpath , and fired on the Hunyani about five minutes after it took off , while the aircraft was still in the climb phase of[MASK]its flight . The hea[MASK] @-@ seeking[MASK]missile hit the plane 's starboard wing and exploded , causing the inner engine to also explode . A fuel tank and hydraulic lines ruptured , crea[MASK]ing a fire that the[MASK]pa[MASK]sengers and crew could not put out . The second starboard engine failed almost immediately , leaving Hood with only his t[MASK]o port eng[MASK]nes . Heaving wildly , the[MASK]Hunyani began to descend rapid[MASK]y . 
 At 17 : [MASK]0 Captain Hood sent a distress call to [MASK][MASK]r traffic control ,[MASK]in[MASK]orming them [MASK]hat he had lost t[MASK]e two sta[MASK]board engine[MASK] and was going to crash . " We 're going in , " he radioed . Telling his passengers to brace for an [MASK]mergency landing , he aimed for an open field of cotton in the Whamira Hills , in the bush to the west of[MASK]Kar[MASK]i , intending to belly land the craft . The landing was relatively stable unti[MASK][MASK]the Hunyani hit a previous[MASK]y unseen ditch , cartwh[MASK]eled and exploded . The remaining fuel tanks ruptured and caught fire , setting the wrecked cabin[MASK]ablaze . 
 
 = = = Ma[MASK]sacre on the ground = = = 
 
 Of the 56 peop[MASK]e on board , 38 , including Hood and Beaumont , died in the crash . Eigh[MASK]een survived , albeit wit[MASK] in[MASK]uries , and cli[MASK]bed out of the w[MASK]eckage . After briefly settling the others , one of the passengers , Dr Cecil MacLaren , led four others — young newlyweds Robert and Shannon [MASK]argreaves , Mrs Sharon Coles , and her fo[MASK]r @-@ year @-@ old daughter Tracey — off in the direction of a nearby village in search of water . The other [MASK]3 remained close to the wreckage . Meanwhile , nine guerrillas made their way towards the crash site , and reached it at about 17 : 45 . Three of the 13 survivors remaining at the crash site hid on seeing figu[MASK]es approaching :[MASK]Rhodesian Ar[MASK]y reservist Ant[MASK]ony Hill , 39 , took cover in the surrounding bush , while businessman Hans Hansen and his wife Dian[MASK] did the same . This left 10 passengers in full view [MASK]ear the wreckage , inc[MASK]uding four women and two girls ( aged 11 and 4 ) . 
 T[MASK]e guerrillas , who were[MASK]armed with AK @-@ 47 rifles , presented themselves to the 10 passengers as friendly , saying they would summon help and bring water . The[MASK] spo[MASK]e in [MASK]nglish , both t[MASK] the[MASK]survivors and among themselves . They told the passengers to congregate around a p[MASK]int a few metres from the wreckage ; when the survivors sai[MASK] that some of them were too badly injure[MASK] to walk , the insurgents told the able @-@ bodied men to carry the others .[MASK]The passengers were assembled into an area of about 10 square metres ( 110 sq ft ) . Standing roughly 15 metres ([MASK]49 ft ) away , the cadres now raised[MASK]their weapons . " You have [MASK]aken our land , " one of them said . [MASK] Please don 't shoot us ! " one of the passengers [MASK]ried , just before they we[MASK]e killed by a sustained burst of automatic gunfire . 
 Having c[MASK]llected water from the nearby village , MacLaren and his companions were almost back at the crash site when they he[MASK]rd the shots . Thinking it was personal ammunition in the luggage exploding in th[MASK] heat , they continued on their way , and cal[MASK]ed out to the other passengers , who they t[MASK]ought were still alive . This alerted the ins[MASK]rgents to the presence of more survivors ; one of the guerrillas told MacLaren 's group to " come here " . The insurg[MASK]nts then opened fire on their g[MASK]neral location [MASK] prompting MacLaren and the others to flee . Hill and the Hansens also ran ; they revealed their positions to t[MASK]e fighters in their[MASK]haste , but success[MASK][MASK]lly hid themselve[MASK] behind a ri[MASK]ge . After Hill and the others ha[MASK] hidden there for about two hours , they saw the attackers return to the crash site at about 19 : 45 . The guerrillas looted the wrecked cabin and some of the suitcases stre[MASK]n around the site , filled their arms [MASK]ith various passengers ' belongings , then left again . 
[MASK]The survivors were found over the following days by the Rhodesian Army and police ; Hill and Mr and Mrs Hans[MASK]n were taken to Karib[MASK] Hospit[MASK]l , while MacLaren and his group were airlifted to Andr[MASK]w Fle[MASK]ing Hospital in[MASK]Salisbury[MASK]. 
 
 = = = Nkomo claims responsibility , but denies killing[MASK]survivors = = = [MASK] 
 Nkomo claimed responsibility for the attack in [MASK]n interview with the BBC 's Today radio[MASK]programm[MASK] the next day , laughing as he did so , to the horror of mos[MASK] Rhodesian observers , both black and white . He said that he had received intelligence that the Hunyani was being used for military purposes . Nk[MASK]mo said he re[MASK]retted the de[MASK]ths as it was not his party 's policy to kill civilians , and denied th[MASK]t his men had killed any s[MASK]rvivors on the ground ; by contrast , he s[MASK][MASK]d that his men had helped them , and had left them alive . He also accused Air Rhodesia of surreptitiously hauling troops and war materiel for t[MASK]e government , an alleg[MASK]tion that Captain Pat Travers , Air Rhodesia 's general manager , called a " downright , deliber[MASK]te lie " . 
 According to[MASK]Eliakim Sibanda , a professor and human rights speaker who wrote a history of ZAPU , Nkomo was implying that responsibility for t[MASK]e massacre actually lay with secur[MASK]ty force pseudo @-@ guerrillas , more specifically the mi[MASK]ed race Selous Scouts unit , which had often been accused of brutalising rural civ[MASK]lians with the goal of sh[MASK]fting public opinion . Sibanda asserts that the massacre " can[MASK]ot be put beyond " the Scouts , and also supports Nkomo 's claim that the Hunyani had been used militarily , s[MASK]ggesting that ZIPRA might have believed there to be Rhodesian sol[MASK]ier[MASK] on board . " Rhodesian television , before attacks on ZANLA in Mozambique , had shown Viscounts ferrying paratroopers for the job , " he write[MASK] , " ... [ [MASK]nd ] ZIPRA [MASK]ntelligence knew there were paratroopers stationed [ at Victoria Falls ] " . 
 
 = = Reactions = = 
 
 
 [MASK] = = W[MASK]ite Rhodesians turn against blacks = = = 
 
 A r[MASK]port published in the American magazine Time a fortnight later descr[MASK]bed the incident as " a genuine horror story , calculated to make the most alarming of Rhodesian doomsday prophecies seem true . " I[MASK]deed , the white community in Rhodesia heard th[MASK] n[MASK]ws[MASK]with fury , and many turned their m[MASK]nds to exacting retribution for wh[MASK]t they and many others saw as an act of terrorism . The prominent Indian @-@ Rhodesian Gulab family was[MASK]p[MASK]rticularly affected by the inciden[MASK] , having lost eight members in the attack . Though Rhodesian authorities did not immediately acknowledge the cause of the crash , doing so only after four days ' investigation , the truth was common kn[MASK]wledge in Salisbury within hours . Smith wrote in his memoirs that the " degree of anger ... [ was ] difficult to contr[MASK]l " . White South Af[MASK]icans were [MASK]imila[MASK]ly enraged , part[MASK]cularly after reports appeared in the South African press that the killers had raped the female passengers before massacring [MASK]hem . A Fri[MASK]nds of Rhodesia Society in South Africa offered a reward of R100,000 to anybody who would either kill Nkomo or bring him to Salisbury to stand trial . 
 Geof[MASK]rey Nyarota , who was then one of the few black reporters at the Rhodesia Herald newspaper , later wrote in his memoirs that many whites became resentful and wary towards blacks in[MASK]general , bel[MASK]eving them all to be " t[MASK]rrorist sympathisers " . Describing the Herald newsroom t[MASK]e night of the incident , he relates a " vile collective temper " among the white sub @-@ editors : " They cursed until their voices beca[MASK]e hoarse , th[MASK]eatening dire consequences for all terrs and munts or ka[MASK]firs ... I sens[MASK]d that some of the more der[MASK]gatory[MASK]remarks made in unnecessarily loud voices that evening were meant s[MASK]ecifically for my ears . " 
 Seve[MASK]al racially motiv[MASK]ted incidents occurred over th[MASK] following days . According to the Time article , a group of whites entered an unsegregated Salisbury[MASK]bar " fingering the trig[MASK]ers of rifl[MASK]s " and forced blacks drinking there to leave . Time also reported a rumour that two white youths , on learning of the massacre[MASK], shot the first black man they [MASK]aw . Smith says that several would @-@ be vigilante gro[MASK]ps sought his permiss[MASK]on to ventur[MASK] into the bush around the crash site to " make the local people pay for[MASK]their crime of harbouring and assisting the te[MASK]rorists " . He instructed them not to , according to his memoirs , telling them that many rural blacks only assisted the guerrillas under ex[MASK]reme duress , and that it woul[MASK] not do to attack them . Many Rhodesians also resented the apparent lac[MASK] of sympathy [MASK]manating from overseas governments , especially considering the character o[MASK] the attack and its civilian target[MASK]. 
 
 =[MASK]= = M[MASK]morial service , 8 September 1978 = = = 
 
 At a memorial service held on 8 September 1978 for Flight 825 's passengers and crew at Salisbury 's Anglican Cathedral , about 2 @,@ 000 people crowded inside , with another 50[MASK] standing outside o[MASK] the steps and pavement , many listening to [MASK]he service inside on portable radio sets[MASK]. Prominent among those present in the cathedral were uniform[MASK]d Air Rhodesia and South African Airways personnel , as well as Rhodesian Special Air Service soldiers and sen[MASK]or officers from other military units . Smith and sever[MASK]l government ministers also attended , including P K van der Byl , the co [MASK]-@ Minister of [MASK]oreign Affairs . 
 Dean John de Costa gave a sermon damning what he described as a " de[MASK]fening silen[MASK]e " from overseas . " Nobody w[MASK]o holds [MASK]acred the dignity of human life can be anything but sickened at the events attending the Vis[MASK]ount , " he said . " But are we deafened with the voice of protest[MASK][MASK]rom nations who call themse[MASK]ves civilised ? We are not ! Like men in the story of[MASK]the Good Samaritan , they pass by on the other side ... The ghastliness of this ill @-@ fated flight [MASK]rom Kariba will be burnt upon our memories for years to come . For others , far from our borders , it is an i[MASK]tellect[MASK]al matter , not one which affects th[MASK]m deeply . Here is the tragedy ![MASK]" 
 
 = = = Smith[MASK]– Nkomo talks [MASK]alted = = = 
 
 The talks between Smith and the ZAPU leader that had been progressing so promisingly were immediately[MASK]halted by Salisbur[MASK][MASK]. Smit[MASK] himself called Nkomo a [MASK] monst[MASK][MASK] " . Cilliers comments that the ending o[MASK] the Smith – Nkomo talks at this time was " poten[MASK]ially the most serious result of [MASK]he Viscount massacre "[MASK], as the talks had been progressing well be[MASK]ore the inciden[MASK] . He surmises that an agreement between the two " at this critical stage " might have h[MASK]lped the transitional Rhodesian gov[MASK]rnment to secure international recognition[MASK]. 
 On 10 September , the Prime Minister announced to the nation that certain areas of the country would be place[MASK] under a variation of martial law , wh[MASK]ch [MASK]e said would be applied in particular regio[MASK]s as and when needed . He declared Rhodesia 's intent to " liquidate the internal workings o[MASK] those organisations associated with terrorism " , and warned neighbo[MASK]ring countries to prepare for " any defensive strikes we mig[MASK]t undertake " against guerrilla bases in their respective territories . He claimed that the war had escalated bec[MASK]use Britain and the United States were [MASK]upporting[MASK]the Patriotic Front . Wi[MASK]liam Irvine , the co @-@ Minister of Transport , warned the guerrillas that Rhodesia " w [ ould ] not let these innocents go[MASK]unavenged " . 
 
 = = R[MASK]odesi[MASK] str[MASK]kes back = = 
 
 
 = = =[MASK]Operation S[MASK]oopy ; Rhodesia hits New Chimoio [MASK] = = 
 
 Because ZAPU and ZIPRA were based in Zambia , many Rhodesians clamoured for a massive retaliator[MASK] strike against terrorist targets in that country , but the first external target hit by th[MASK] security forces followi[MASK]g the Viscount shootdown was the prominent cluster of ZANLA bases around Chimoio in Mozambique[MASK]. The Rhodesian military had struc[MASK] these bases extensively in Nove[MASK]ber 1977 dur[MASK]ng Operation Dingo , destroying much of the ZANLA presence there , but [MASK][MASK]e insurgents had sin[MASK]e built a complex called " New Chimoio " , slightly to the east ; the new camps were distributed acros[MASK] a far larger area than the originals . In[MASK]a combined airborne @-@ ground assault called Operation Snoopy , the Rhodesian Air Fo[MASK]ce ,[MASK]Rhodesian Light Infantry and Special Air Service wiped out much of New Chimoio on 20 September 1978 . Moz[MASK]mbique sent armo[MASK]r to ZANLA 's aid in the form of nine Soviet @-@ made T @-@ 54 tanks and four Russian BTR @-@ [MASK]52 armoured person[MASK]el carriers , but the former were r[MASK]u[MASK]ed and one of the latter destroyed by the Rhodesian security forces . According to Rhodesian fig[MASK]r[MASK]s , there were " several hundred " guerrillas killed , while the security [MASK]or[MASK]es lost only two soldiers , one o[MASK] whom was acc[MASK]den[MASK]ally killed by a friendly air strike . 
 
 = = = Operation Gatling ; the " Gr[MASK]en Leader " raid = = = 
 
 Rhodesia then attacked ZIPRA 's bases in Zambia , [MASK]n what Group Captain Peter Petter @-@ Bowyer later described as " payback time " for Flight 825 . Operation Gatling , launched on 19 Octo[MASK]er 1978 [MASK] wa[MASK] anothe[MASK] joint @-@ force operation betw[MASK]en the Air Force and the Army , which contributed Special Air Service and R[MASK]odesi[MASK]n Light I[MASK]fantry paratroopers . Gatling 's primary target , just 16 kilometres ( 10 [MASK]iles ) north[MASK]@-@ east of central Lusaka , was the formerly [MASK]hite @-@ owned Westlands[MASK]Farm , which had been transformed into ZIPRA 's main headquarters and t[MASK]aining base under the name " Freedom Camp " . ZIPRA presumed tha[MASK] Rho[MASK]esia would never dare to attack a site so close to Lusaka . About 4 @,@ 000 guerrillas underwent training at Freedom Camp , with senior ZIPRA staff also on site . The Rhodesian op[MASK]ration 's other targets were Chikumbi , 19 kilometres ( 12 miles ) north of Lusaka , and Mkushi Camp ; all three were to be attacked more or less simultaneously in [MASK] coordinated sweep[MASK]across Zambia . Assaulting targets deep inside Zambia was a first for t[MASK]e Rhodesian forces ; previously only guerril[MASK]as near the border had been att[MASK]cked . 
 Led by Squadron [MASK]eader Chris Dixon , who identified himself to Lusaka Airport tower as " Green[MASK]Leader " , a Rhodesian Air Force group flew into Zambia at very low altitudes ( thereby avoiding Zambian radar ) and took co[MASK]trol of the country 's airspace for about a quarter of an hour during the initial assault[MASK]on West[MASK]ands Farm , informing Lusaka [MASK]ower that the attack was against " Rhodesian dissidents , and not against Zambia " , and that Rhodesian Hawker Hunters were circling the Zambian airfields under orders to shoot down any[MASK]fighter that attempted to tak[MASK] off . The Zambians obeyed all of Green Leader 's in[MASK]tructions , made no attempt to re[MASK]ist and te[MASK]porarily halted civil air traffic . Using Rufunsa airstrip in eastern Zambia[MASK]as a forw[MASK]rd base , the Rhod[MASK]sian military suffered only minor casualties during the thr[MASK]e @-@ day o[MASK]eration , and afterwards c[MASK]aimed to have [MASK]illed over 1 @,@ 500 ZIPRA personnel , as w[MASK]ll as some Cuban instructors . 
 Historians Paul Moorcraft and Peter McLaughlin write that this exaggerated considerably the actual number of guerrillas killed , as most of Nkomo 's army , then numbe[MASK]ing about 10 @,@ 000 fighters , had not been touched . On the other hand , unarmed refugees [MASK]ften camped in or around insurgent positions , and hundreds of these had [MASK]een killed in the Rhodesian raid . M[MASK]orcraft and McLaughlin comment th[MASK]t for the Rhodesian airmen , it would have [MASK]een " impossible t[MASK] distinguish i[MASK]nocent refugees from young ZIPRA recruits . " Sibanda describes Freedom Camp as " a refugee camp for boys " , and says[MASK]" 351 boys and [MASK]irls " were killed . He claims that the Red Cross and the U[MASK] Refugee Agency " confirmed ZAPU 's claim that Smith 's forces struck at defen[MASK]eless , civilian trainees " . [MASK] 
 = = Aftermath = = 
 
 The Rhodesian att[MASK]ck[MASK] on ZANLA and ZIPRA bases did much to restore white morale follow[MASK]ng the Viscou[MASK]t incident , though they had not actually made much impact on the respective guerrilla campaigns . [MASK]komo and the Zambian Preside[MASK]t Kenneth Ka[MASK]nda all the sa[MASK]e requested[MASK]further military aid and better weapons fr[MASK]m the Soviets and the British respectively . Martial law was qu[MASK]ckly extended across Rh[MASK]desia 's r[MASK]ral areas , and[MASK][MASK]overed three @-@ quarters of the country by the end of 1978 . Air Rhodesia , meanwhile , began developing anti @-@ Strela shielding[MASK]for its Viscounts . Before this work was completed , ZI[MASK]RA shot down a second [MASK]iscount , Air Rhodesia Flight 827 , on [MASK]2 February 1979 . This time there were no s[MASK]rvivors . 
 Following the second shootdown , Air Rhodesia created a system whereby the underside of t[MASK]e Viscounts would be coated with low @-@ radiation paint , with the ex[MASK]aust [MASK]ipes conc[MASK]rrently sh[MASK]ouded . According to tests conducted by the Air Force , a Viscount so treated could not be detected[MASK]by the Strela 's target[MASK]ng system once it wa[MASK] over 2 @,@ 000 f[MASK]et ( 610 m ) .[MASK]There were no further Viscount shootdowns in Rhodesia . 
 In the elections held the following year[MASK]under the Internal Settlement terms , boycotted by ZANU and ZAPU , Muzorewa[MASK]won a majority , and became the first Prime Minister of the reconstituted [MASK] majority @-@ r[MASK]led state of Zimbabwe Rhodesia on 1 June 1979 . This new order failed to win international accept[MASK]nce , however , and in December 1979 the Lancaster House Agreement was agreed in London by Zimbabwe [MASK]hodesia , the UK government and the[MASK]Pat[MASK]iotic Front , returning the country to its former co[MASK]onial status . The[MASK]UK government suspended the consti[MASK]ution and took direct control for an[MASK]interim period . Fresh elections were won by Mugabe , who too[MASK] p[MASK]wer in April 1980 , concurrently with the country 's recognised independence as Zimbabwe . 
 
 = = Legacy and memorial = = 
 
 In m[MASK]dern Zimbabwe , it is not the Viscount shootdowns but rather the[MASK]retributory Rhodesian strikes against n[MASK]tionali[MASK]t guerrilla camps that endure predominantly in the cultural memory . State media in Zimbabwe , promi[MASK]en[MASK]ly the Herald newspaper , often c[MASK]aim that Rhodesian forces i[MASK]discriminately and deliberately slaughtered thousands of helpless refugees during [MASK]uch operations .[MASK]ZIPRA 's down[MASK]ng of civilian planes is meanwhile portrayed as a legitimate ac[MASK] of war on the grounds that the guerrillas might have believed them[MASK]to have military personnel or equipment on board . The [MASK]assacre of surviving Flight 825 passengers at the crash site is often omitted or attributed t[MASK] forces other than ZIPRA ; in his 1984 memoirs Nkomo repeated his claim that ZIPRA fighters had helped the survivors , and [MASK]rote [MASK][MASK]mply that [MASK] I truly have no idea how the ten died " . 
 A monument to those killed in the Rhodesian attack on C[MASK]ikumbi was built in Zambia[MASK]in 1998 , and de[MASK]icated join[MASK]ly by the Zambian and Zimbabwean governments . A memorial to the victims of the two Rhodesian Viscount incidents , dubbed the Viscount Memorial , was erec[MASK]ed on the grounds of the [MASK]oortrekker Monument in[MASK]Pretoria , South Africa in 2012 , and inaugurated on 1 September that year . The names of the dead[MASK]passengers and crew are engraved on two granite slabs that stan[MASK] upright , side by side , the pai[MASK] topped by an embl[MASK]m symbolising an aircraft . A pole beside the monument flies the Rhode[MASK]ian flag .[MASK]
 A Br[MASK]tish p[MASK]rliamenta[MASK]y motion [MASK]ut forward by Labour MP Kate Hoey in February 2013 to retrospectively condemn the Viscoun[MASK] attacks and memorialise [MASK]he victims on the anniversary of the second shootdown prom[MASK]ted outcry in the Zimbabwean press , with the Herald branding it a racist " Rhodie motion " intended to antagonise the Mugabe administration and its supporters . Dumiso Dabengwa , a former ZIPRA commander , described[MASK]the move as a provocation motivated by race that went against the spirit of the amnesty enacted at [MASK][MASK]ncaster House . Christopher Mutsvangwa , a diplomat and political analyst , too[MASK] a similar line , calling Hoey 's proposed commemoration " a provocation ... [ tha[MASK] ] means they only regard the death of white people alone during the strugg[MASK]e . There is no mention of what happened to our sons a[MASK]d daughters in and outside the country . " ZAPU 's official response to Hoey 's motion included the assertion tha[MASK] in all conflicts " civilians [MASK]et c[MASK]ught up in cross @-@[MASK]fires due to faulty intelligence reports and other communication erro[MASK]s " , and juxtaposed the civilians killed in the Viscount shootdowns with those killed at Chikumbi . 
 
 = = = Newspaper and journal articles = =[MASK]= 
 
 [MASK] 
 = Tikal = 
 
 Tikal ( / tiˈkäl / ) ( Tik ’ al in modern Mayan orthography ) is the ruins of a[MASK] ancient city found in a rainforest in Guatemala . Ambrosio Tut ,[MASK]a gum @-[MASK] [MASK]apper , reported the ruins to La G[MASK]ceta , a Guatemalan newspaper [MASK] which named the site Tikal . After the Berlin Academy of Sciences ' magazine republished the report in 1853 , archeologists and treasure hunters began visiting the forest . Today tourism to the[MASK]site may help protect the rainforest . It is one of the largest archaeological sites and urban centers of the pre @-@ Columbian Maya civilization . It is located in the archaeological region of the Petén Basin [MASK]n what is now northern Gu[MASK]temala . Situated in the department of El Petén , the site is part of Guatemala 's Tika[MASK] National Park and in [MASK]979 it was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site . 
 Tikal was the capital of a conquest state t[MASK]at became one of the most pow[MASK]rful kingdoms of the ancient Ma[MASK]a .
