Though monumental arc[MASK]itecture at the site dates back as far as the 4th centur[MASK] BC , Tikal reached its apogee during the Classic Period , c . 200 to 900 AD [MASK] During this time , the city dominated m[MASK]ch of the Maya region politically , economically , and militarily , whi[MASK]e interacting wi[MASK]h areas throughout Mesoamer[MASK]ca such as t[MASK]e great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the distant Valley[MASK]of Mexic[MASK] . There is evidence that Tikal was conquered by Teotihuacan in the 4th ce[MASK]tury AD . Following the end of the Late Classic Period , no new major monuments were built at Tikal and there is evidence that elite palaces were burned . These events were coupled with a gradual population decline , culminating with the site ’ s abandonment by the end of the 10th century . 
 Tikal is the best understood of any of the large lowland Maya cities , with a long dynastic ruler list , the discovery of the tombs of many of the ru[MASK]ers on th[MASK]s list and the investigation of[MASK]their monuments , temples and palaces . 
 
 = = Etymology = = 
 
 The name Tikal may [MASK]e derived from ti ak 'al in the Yucatec Maya language ; it is said to be a relatively modern name meaning " at t[MASK]e waterhole " . Th[MASK] name was apparently applied to one of the site 's ancient reservoirs by hunters and travelers in the region . It has alternatively been interpreted as meaning " the place of the voices " in [MASK]he Itza Maya language[MASK]. Tika[MASK] , however , is[MASK]not the ancient name for[MASK]the site but rather[MASK]the name adopted shortly after its discovery in the 1840s . H[MASK]eroglyphic inscription[MASK] at the ruin[MASK] refer to th[MASK] ancient city as Yax Mut[MASK]l or Yax Mutul , meaning " First Mutal " [MASK] Tikal may have come to have been called this because Dos Pilas also ca[MASK]e to use the same emblem [MASK]lyph ; the rulers of the city presumably wanted to distinguish themse[MASK]ves as the first city to bear the name . The kingdom as a whole was s[MASK][MASK]ply called Mutul , which is the reading of the " hair bundle " emblem glyph seen in the accompanying pho[MASK]o . Its precise meaning remains obscure . 
 
 = = Location = = 
 
 The c[MASK]osest large modern settlements are Flores and Santa Elena , approximately 64 kilometres ( 40 [MASK]i ) by road t[MASK] the southwest . Tikal is approximately 303 kilometres ( 188 mi ) north of Guatemala[MASK]City . It is 19 kilometres ( 12 mi ) south of the contemporary [MASK]aya city of Uaxa[MASK]tun and 30 kilometres ( 19 mi ) northwest of Yaxha . The city was locat[MASK]d 100 kilometres ( 62 mi ) southeast of its great Class[MASK]c Period rival , Calakmul , and 85 kilometres ( 53 [MASK]i ) northwest of Calakmul 's ally Caracol , now in [MASK]elize . 
 The city has been completely mapped and covered an area greater[MASK]than 16 squ[MASK]re kilometres ( 6 @.@ [MASK] sq mi ) that included about 3 [MASK],@ 000 structures . The topography of the site consists [MASK]f a series [MASK]f parallel limestone ridges rising above swampy lowlands . The major architecture of the sit[MASK] is clustered upon areas of higher ground and linked by raised causeways spanning the swam[MASK]s . The area around Tika[MASK] has been dec[MASK]ared as the Tikal National Park and the p[MASK]eserved area covers 570 square kilometres ( 220 sq mi ) . 
 The ruins lie among the tropical rain[MASK]orests of northern Guatemala that formed the cradle of lowland Maya civilization . The city itself was located a[MASK]ong a[MASK]undant fertile upland soils , and may have dominated a natural east[MASK]– west trade route across the Yucatan Peninsula . Conspicuous trees a[MASK] the Tikal park include giga[MASK][MASK]ic kapok ( Ceiba pentandra ) the[MASK]sacred tree of the Maya ; tropical cedar ( Cedrela odorata ) , and Honduras mahogany ( Swietenia macrophylla ) . Regarding the fauna , agouti , white @-@ nosed coatis , gray foxes , Geoff[MASK]oy 's spider monke[MASK]s , howler monkeys ,[MASK]harpy eagles , falc[MASK]ns , ocellate[MASK] turkeys , guans , toucans , green parrots and leafcutter a[MASK]ts can be seen there regularly . Jaguars , jaguarundis , and cougars are also said to roam in the park . For centuries this city was compl[MASK]te[MASK]y covered under jung[MASK]e . The average annual rainfall at Tikal i[MASK] 1 @,@ 945 millimetres ( 76 @.@ 6 in ) . 
 One of the largest of the Cla[MASK]sic Maya cities , Tikal had no[MASK]water other than what was collected from rainwater and stored in te[MASK] reservoirs . Arch[MASK]eologists working in Tikal during the 20th century refurbis[MASK]ed[MASK]one of these an[MASK]ient r[MASK]servoirs to store water for their own use . 
 The Tikal National Park covers an are[MASK] of 575 @.@ 83 square kilometres ( 222 @.@ 33 sq mi ) . It was cre[MASK]ted on 26 May 1955 unde[MASK] the auspices of the Instituto de Antropología e H[MASK]storia and was the first protected area in Guatemala . 
 
 = = Population = = 
 
 Population[MASK]estimates for Tikal vary from 10 @,@ 000 to as high as 90 [MASK],@ 000 inhabitants , with the most likely figure being at the upper end of this range . 
 The population of Tikal began a continuous curve[MASK]of growth starting in the Preclassic Period ( approximately 2000 BC – AD[MASK]200 )[MASK], with a peak in the Late Classic with the population growing rapidly from AD 700 th[MASK]ough to 830 , followed by a sharp de[MASK]line . For the 120 square kilometres ( 46 sq mi ) area falling within the earthwork defenses of the hinterland , the peak population is estimated at 517 per sq[MASK]are kilometer ( 1340 per square mile ) . In an area within a 12 kilometres ( 7 @.@ 5 mi ) radius of the site core , p[MASK]ak popula[MASK]ion[MASK]is estimated at 120 @,@ 00[MASK] ; populati[MASK]n density is [MASK]stimated at 265 per square kilometer ( 689 per square mile ) . In a region w[MASK]thin a[MASK]25 kilometres ( [MASK]6 mi ) radius of the site core and including some satellite[MASK]sites , peak population is estimated at 425 @,@ 000 with a density of[MASK]216 per square kilometer ( 515 per square mile ) . These population figures [MASK]re even more impressive because of the extensive swamplands that were unsuitable for habitation[MASK]or agriculture . However , some archaeologists , such as Dav[MASK]d Webster , believe these fi[MASK]ures to be far too high . 
 
 = = Rulers = = 
 
 The dynastic line of Tikal , founded as early as the 1st century AD , spanne[MASK] 800 years and included at [MASK]east 33 rulers . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 
 = = = Preclassic = = = 
 
 There are [MASK]races of early agriculture at the site datin[MASK] as far back as 1000 BC , in the Middle Preclassic . A cache of Mamon cerami[MASK]s dating from about 700 @-@ 400 BC were found in a sealed chultun , a subterranean bottle @-@ shaped chamber . 
 Major construct[MASK]on at Tikal was already taking place in the Late Preclassic period , first appearing around 400 – 300 BC , including t[MASK]e [MASK]uilding of major pyramids and p[MASK]atforms , although the city was still dwarfed by sites f[MASK]rther north such as El Mirador and Nakbe . At this time [MASK] Tika[MASK] participated in the widespread Chikan[MASK]l cu[MASK]ture that domi[MASK]ated the Central and Northern[MASK]Maya areas at this time – a region that included the entire Yucatan Peninsula including northern and eastern Guatemala and all of Belize . 
 Two temples dating to Late Chikanel times had [MASK]asonry @-@ walled superstructu[MASK]es that may have been corbel @-@ vaulted , altho[MASK]gh this has not been[MASK]proven . One of these had elaborate paintings on the outer wal[MASK][MASK] showing human figures against a scrollwork background , pain[MASK]ed in yellow , black , pink and red . 
 In the 1st century AD rich burials first appeare[MASK] and Tikal underwent a political and cultural florescence as its giant northern nei[MASK]hbors declined[MASK]. At the [MASK]nd [MASK]f the Late Preclassic , the Izapan style art and architecture from the Pacific Coast began to influence Tikal , as demonstrated by a broken sculpture from the acropolis an[MASK] early murals at the city . 
 
 = = = E[MASK][MASK]ly Classic = = = 
 
 Dynastic rulership among the lowland May[MASK] is most deeply rooted at Tik[MASK]l . According to later h[MASK]erogly[MASK]hic records , the dynasty was founded by Yax @-@ Moch @-@ Xoc , perhaps in the 3rd century AD . At the beginning of the Early Classic , power in the Maya region was concentrat[MASK]d at Tikal and Calakmul , in the core of the Maya heartland [MASK] 
 Tik[MASK]l may have benefited [MASK]rom the co[MASK]la[MASK]se of the large Preclassic states such as El Mirador . In the Early Classi[MASK] Tikal rapidly dev[MASK]loped into the most dynamic city in the Maya region , sti[MASK][MASK]lating the dev[MASK]lopment of other nearby Maya cities . 
 The site , however , was often at war and[MASK]inscriptions tell of alliances and conflict with other Maya states , including Uaxactun , Caracol , Naranjo and Calakmul . The site was defeated at the[MASK]end of the Early Classic by Caracol , which rose to take Tikal 's place as the paramount center in the southern Maya lowlands . The earlier part of the Ea[MASK]ly Classic saw hostilities between Tikal and its nei[MASK]hbor Uaxactun , with Uaxactun recording the capture of prisoners[MASK]from Tikal . 
 There appears to have been a b[MASK]eak[MASK]own in the male succession by AD 317 , when Lady Unen Bahlam conducted a katun @-@ ending ceremony , apparently as queen of the ci[MASK]y . 
 
 = = = = Tika[MASK] and T[MASK]otihuacan = = = = 
 
 The fourteenth [MASK]ing of Tikal was Chak Tok Ich 'aak ( Great Jaguar Paw ) . Chak Tok Ich 'aak built a palace that was preserved and developed by later rulers until it became the core of the Central Acropolis . Little is known[MASK]about Chak Tok Ich 'aak except that he was killed o[MASK] 14 January 378 AD . On the s[MASK]me day , Siyah K ’ ak ’ ( Fir[MASK] Is Born ) arrived from the west , having passe[MASK] through El [MASK]e[MASK]u , a site to the west of Tikal[MASK], on 8 January . On Stela 31 he is named as " Lord of the West " . Siyah K [MASK] ak ’ was probably a foreign general serving a figure represented [MASK]y a non @-@ Maya hieroglyph of a spearthrower combined with an owl , a gly[MASK]h that is well known from the great metropolis of Teotihuacan in the distant Valley of Mexic[MASK] . Spearthrower Owl may even have been the ruler of Teotihuacan . These recorded events strongly suggest that Siyah K ’ ak ’ led a Teotihuacan invasion t[MASK]at defeated the native Tikal king , who was captured and immediately executed . Siyah K 'ak ' appears to have been aided by a powerful political faction at Tikal itself ; roughly at the time of the conquest , a group of Teotihuacan[MASK]natives wer[MASK] apparently residing near the Lost Worl[MASK] complex [MASK] He also exerted control over other cities in[MASK]the area , incl[MASK]di[MASK]g Uaxactun , where he became king , but did not take t[MASK]e throne of Tikal for himself . Within a year , the son of Spearthrower Owl by[MASK]the name of Yax Nuun Ayiin I ( First Crocod[MASK]le ) had been installed as the tent[MASK] king of Tikal while he was still a boy , being enthroned on 13 September 379 . He reigned for 47 years as king of Tikal , and remai[MASK]ed a vassal of Siyah K 'a[MASK] ' for as long as the latter lived . It seems[MASK]likely that Yax Nuun Ayiin I took a wife from the preexist[MASK]ng , defeated [MASK] Tikal dynasty and thus legitimized[MASK]the right to rule of his son , Siyaj Chan K 'awiil II . 
 Río [MASK]zul , a small site 100 kilometres ( 62 mi ) northeast of Tikal , was conqu[MASK]red by the latter during the reign of Yax Nuun Ay[MASK]in I. The site became an outpost of Tikal , shielding [MASK]t from hostile cities further nort[MASK] , and also became a trade link to the Caribbean . 
 Although the new rulers of Tikal were foreig[MASK] , t[MASK]eir descendants were r[MASK]pidly Mayanized . Tikal became the key ally and tr[MASK]ding partner of Teotihuacan in the Maya lowlands . After being conquered by Teot[MASK]huacan , Tikal rapidly dominated the northern[MASK]and eastern Peten . Uaxactun , together wit[MASK] smaller towns[MASK]in the region , were absorbed into Tikal 's kingdom . Other sites , [MASK]uch as Bejucal and Motul de S[MASK]n José near Lake Petén Itzá became vassals of their more powerful neighbor to the [MASK]orth . By the [MASK]iddle of th[MASK] 5th century Tikal had a core territory of at [MASK]east 2[MASK] kilometres ( 16 mi ) in every direction . 
 Around the 5th century an impressive system of [MASK]ortifications consisting of ditches and earthworks was built along the northern periphery of Tikal 's hint[MASK]rland , joining up with the natural defenses provided by large areas of swampland lying to the east and west of the city . Additional fortifications were probably also built to[MASK]the south . These defenses protected Tikal 's core population and agricultural[MASK]resources , encirclin[MASK] an area of appr[MASK]ximately[MASK]120 square kilometres ( 46 sq mi ) . Recent research suggest[MASK] that the eart[MASK]works served as a water collection system rather than a defe[MASK]sive purpose . 
 
 = = = = Tikal and Copán = = =[MASK]= 
 
 In the 5th century t[MASK]e power of the city reached as far sout[MASK] as Copán , whose founder K 'inich Yax K 'uk ' Mo ' was clearly connected with Tikal . Copán itself was not in an ethnically Maya region[MASK]and the founding of the Copán dynasty probably involved the direct intervention of Tikal . K '[MASK]nich Yax K 'uk ' Mo ' arrived in Co[MASK]án in December 426 and b[MASK]ne analysis of his remains shows that he [MASK]assed his childhood and youth at Tikal . An individual known as Aj[MASK]w K 'uk ' Mo [MASK][MASK]( lord K 'uk '[MASK]Mo[MASK]' ) is referred to in an early text[MASK]at Tikal and may well be the same person . His tomb had Teotihuacan characteristics[MASK]and he was depicted in later portr[MASK]its dressed in the warrior garb of Teotihuacan . Hierogly[MASK]hic texts refer to him as " Lord of the West " , much like Siyah K ’ ak ’ [MASK] At the same time , in la[MASK]e [MASK]26 [MASK] Copán founded the nearby[MASK]site of Quiriguá ,[MASK]p[MASK]ssibly sponsored by Tikal itself . The founding o[MASK] these two centers may have been part of an effort to impose T[MASK]kal 's a[MASK]thority upon the southeastern portion of the Maya region . The interaction between these sites and Tikal was intense over the next t[MASK]ree centuries . 
 A long @-@ running rivalry between Tikal and Cala[MASK]mul b[MASK]gan in the 6th[MASK]century , with each of the two cities forming its o[MASK]n network of mutually hostile alliances arrayed against each other in what has b[MASK]en likened to a long @-@ running war b[MASK]tween two Maya superpowers .[MASK]The kings of these two capitals adopted the title kaloomte ' , a term that has not been precisely [MASK]ranslated but that [MASK]mplies some[MASK]hing akin [MASK]o " high king " . 
 The early 6th [MASK]entury saw another queen ruling the city , known only as the " Lady of Tikal [MASK] , who was very likely a d[MASK]ughter of Chak Tok Ich 'aak II . She seems never to[MASK]have ruled in her own right , rather being partnered wi[MASK]h male co @-@ rulers . The first of these was Kaloomte ' B 'alam , who see[MASK]s to have had a long caree[MASK] as a general at Tikal before becoming co @-@ ru[MASK]er and 19th in the dynastic sequ[MASK]nce . The Lady of Tikal [MASK]erself seems n[MASK]t have been counted in the dynastic numbering . It appears she was later paired with lord [MASK] Bird Cla[MASK] " , who is presumed to [MASK]e the otherwise unknown 20th ruler [MASK] . 
 
 = = = Late Classic = = = 
 
 
 = = = = Tikal hiatus = = = [MASK] 
 
 In the mid 6th century , Caracol see[MASK]s to have allied with Calakmul and defeated Tikal , cl[MASK]sing the Early Classic . The " Ti[MASK]al hiatus " refers to a period between the late 6th to late 7th century wh[MASK]re t[MASK]ere was a lapse in the writing of inscriptions and large @-@ scale construction at Tikal . In the latter half of the 6th [MASK]entu[MASK]y[MASK]AD , a serious crisis befell the city , with no new stelae being erected and with widespread deliberate mu[MASK]ilati[MASK]n of public sculpture . This hiatus in activity at Tikal was long unexplained until later epigraphic decipherments identified that the period was prompted by Tikal 's [MASK]omprehensive defeat at the hands of Calakmul and the Caracol polity in AD 562 , a defeat that seems to have resulted in the capture [MASK]nd sacrif[MASK]ce of the king of Tikal . The badly eroded Altar 21 at Caracol described how Tikal suffered this disastrous defeat in a major war in April 562 . It seems that Caracol was an ally of Calakmul in the wider conflict between that city and Tikal , with the defeat of Tikal having a lasting impact upon the city . Tikal was not sacked but its [MASK]ower and influence were broken . After its[MASK]great[MASK]victory , Caracol grew rapidly and some [MASK]f Tikal 's population may have been forcibly [MASK]elocated there . During the hiatus period , at least one ruler of T[MASK]kal took refuge with Janaab ' Pakal of Palenque , another of Calakmul 's victims . Calakmul itself thr[MASK]ved during Tikal 's long h[MASK]atus period . 
 The beginning of the Tikal hiatus has served as a marker by which a[MASK]chaeolo[MASK]ists commonly subdivide the Classic period of Mesoamerican chronology into the Early and Late Classic . 
 
 = = = = Tikal and Dos Pilas = = = = 
 
 In 629 Tikal founded Dos Pilas , some 110 kilometres ([MASK]68 mi ) to the southwest , as a military outp[MASK]st in order to control tra[MASK]e along the cour[MASK]e of the Pasión River . B 'alaj Chan K 'awiil was installed on the throne of the new outpost at [MASK]he [MASK]ge of four , in 635 , and for many years served as a loyal vass[MASK][MASK] fighting for his brother [MASK] [MASK]he king of Tikal .[MASK]Roughly[MASK]twenty years later Dos Pilas was attacked by Calakmul and was soundly defeated . B 'alaj Chan K 'awiil was capt[MASK]red by the king of Calakmul but , instead of being sacrifi[MASK]ed , he was re @-@ inst[MASK]ted on his throne as a vassal of his former enemy , and attack[MASK]d Tikal in[MASK]657 , forcin[MASK] Nuun Ujol Chaak , the then king of Tikal , to temporarily abandon the city . The fir[MASK]t two rulers of Dos Pilas continued to use the Mutal emblem glyph [MASK]f Tikal , and t[MASK]ey probably felt that they had a legitimate c[MASK]aim to the throne of Tikal itself . For some r[MASK]ason , B[MASK]'alaj Chan K 'awiil was not installed as the new ruler of Tikal ; [MASK]nstead he stayed at Dos Pilas . Tikal co[MASK]nterattacked against Dos Pilas in 672 , driving B 'alaj Chan K 'awiil into an exile that lasted five years . Calakmul trie[MASK] to [MASK]ncircle Tikal within an area dominated by its allies , such as El Peru , Dos Pilas and Cara[MASK]ol . 
 In 682 , Jasaw[MASK]Chan K 'awiil I erected the first dated monument at Tikal in 120[MASK]years and claimed the[MASK]title of kaloomte ' , so ending the hiatus . He initiated a programme of new [MASK]onstruction and turned t[MASK]e tables on Calakmul when , in 695 , he capt[MASK]red the enemy noble and threw the enemy state i[MASK]to a[MASK]long decline from which it never fully [MASK]ecovered . After this , Calakmul never aga[MASK]n erected a monument celebrating a military vict[MASK]ry . 
 
 [MASK] = = = Tikal after Teo[MASK]ihuacán = = = =[MASK]
 
 By the 7th century , there was no activ[MASK] Teoti[MASK]uacan presence at any Maya site and the center of Teotihuacan had[MASK]been razed by 700 . Even af[MASK]er this[MASK], formal [MASK]ar attire illustrated on monuments was Teotihuacan style . Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I and his heir Yik 'in Chan K 'awiil continued hostilities against Ca[MASK]akmul and its allies and imposed firm regional [MASK]ontrol ove[MASK] the[MASK]area around Tikal , e[MASK]tending as far as the territory around Lake Pe[MASK]én I[MASK]zá . These two ru[MASK]ers were responsible for much of the impressive architecture visible today . 
 In 738 , Quiriguá , a vassal of Copán [MASK] Tikal 's key ally in the south , switched allegiance to Cala[MASK]mul , defeated Copán and gained its own ind[MASK]pendence . It appears that this was a conscious effort on the part of[MASK]Calakmul to bring[MASK]about the collapse of Tikal 's southern allies . This upset the balance of power in the southern Maya area and l[MASK]ad to a steady decline in the [MASK]ortu[MASK]es of Copán . 
 In th[MASK] 8th century , the rulers of Tikal collected monuments from across the city and erected them in front of[MASK]the North Acropolis . [MASK]y the late 8th century and early 9th century , activity at Tikal slowed . Impressive architect[MASK]re was still built but [MASK]ew hieroglyphic inscriptions refer to later rulers . 
[MASK]
 = = =[MASK]Terminal Classic = = = 
 
 By the 9th century , the crisis of the Classic Maya collapse was sweeping across the region , with populations plummeting and city after city falling into silence . Increasingly endemic warfare in the Maya region caused Tikal[MASK]'s supporting population to heavily concentrate close [MASK]o the city itself , accelerating t[MASK]e[MASK]use of intensive agriculture and corresponding environmental decline . Construction continued at the beginning[MASK]of the century , wi[MASK]h the erection of Temple 3 , [MASK]he last of th[MASK] city 's major pyramids and t[MASK]e erection of monuments to mark the 19th K 'atun in 810 . The beginning of the 10th [MASK]ak 'tun in 830 passed unce[MASK]ebrated , and marks the beginning of a 60 @-@ year hiatus , probabl[MASK] resulting from the collapse of central control in th[MASK] city . During this hiatus , satellite sites traditio[MASK]ally under Tikal 's control began to er[MASK]c[MASK] their own monume[MASK]ts featuring local ru[MASK]er[MASK] and using the Mutal emblem glyph , with Tikal apparently lacking the authority or the[MASK]power to crush these bids for[MASK]independence . In 849 , Jewel K 'awiil is mentioned [MASK]n a stela at Seibal as v[MASK]siting that city as the Divine Lord [MASK]f Tikal but he is not re[MASK][MASK]rded el[MASK]ewhere and T[MASK]kal 's once great power was little more th[MASK]n a memory . The sites of Ixlu and Jimbal had by now inherit[MASK]d the once exclusi[MASK]e Mutal emblem glyph . 
 As Tikal and its hinterlan[MASK] reached[MASK]peak populati[MASK]n , the area suf[MASK]er[MASK]d deforestation , erosion[MASK]and nutrient [MASK][MASK]ss followed [MASK]y a rapid decline in population lev[MASK]ls . Tikal and its im[MASK]ediate surroundings seem to have lost[MASK]the major[MASK]ty of its population during the period from 830 to 950 and central authority seems to have collapsed rapidly . There is not much evidence from Tikal that the city was directly affected [MASK]y the endemic warfare that afflicted parts of the Maya region during the Terminal Classic , although an influx of refugees from the Petexbatún region may have exacerbated problems resulting from the already stretched environmental resources . 
 In the latter half of the 9th cent[MASK]ry there was an attempt[MASK]to revive royal power at the much dimini[MASK]hed city of Tikal , as evidenced by a stela er[MASK]cted in the Great Plaza by Jasaw Chan K 'awiil II in 86[MASK] . This was the last monument erected at Tikal be[MASK]ore the ci[MASK]y finally fell into silence . The former satellites [MASK]f Tikal , such as Jimbal and Uaxactun , did not last [MASK]uch longer , erecting their final monuments in 889 [MASK] By the end of the 9th century the vast majority of Tikal 's population had deserted the city , its royal pa[MASK]aces were occupied by squ[MASK]tters and simple thatched dwellings were being erected in the city 's ceremonial plazas . The squatters bloc[MASK]e[MASK] some doorways in the rooms they reoccupie[MASK] in the m[MASK]numental structures of the site and left rubbish that included a mixture of domestic refuse and non @-@ utilit[MASK]rian items such as musical instr[MASK]ments . These inhabitan[MASK]s reused the earlier monuments for their own ritual activities far removed from those of the[MASK]royal dynasty that had erected them . Some monuments were vandalized and some were moved to new locations . Before its final abandonment all respect for the o[MASK]d rulers had disappeared , with the to[MASK]bs of the North Acropolis being expl[MASK]red[MASK]for jade a[MASK]d the easier to find tombs being looted . After 950 , Tikal was all but deserted , although a remn[MASK]nt population may have survived in [MASK]erisha[MASK]le huts interspersed among the rui[MASK]s . Even these fi[MASK]al inhabitants abandoned the city in the 10th or 11th centuries and the rainforest claimed the ruins for the next thousand years . Some of Tikal 's population may have migrated to the Peten Lakes region , which remained heavily populated in spit[MASK] of a plunge in population levels in the first half of the 9th century . 
 [MASK]he most likely cause [MASK]f collapse at Tikal is [MASK]verpopulation and agra[MASK]ian failure[MASK]. The fall of Tikal was a blow to the heart of C[MASK]assic Maya civilization , the city having been at the forefront of courtly life , art and arch[MASK]tecture for over a thousand years , with an ancient ruling[MASK]dynasty . However , new research regarding paleoenvironmental proxies from the Tikal reservoir system suggests that a meteorological drought may have led[MASK]to the abandonment of T[MASK]kal . 
 
 = = = Moder[MASK] history = = =[MASK]
 
 In 1525 , the Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés passed within a few[MASK]kilometres of the ruins of Tikal but did not mentio[MASK] them in his letters . After Spanish friar[MASK]Andrés de Avendaño became lost in the Petén forests [MASK]n early 1696 he [MASK]escribed a ruin that may well have been Tikal . 
 As is often the case with huge ancient ruins , knowledge of the site was never completely lost in the region . It se[MASK]ms that loca[MASK] people [MASK]ever forgo[MASK] about Tikal and they guided Guatem[MASK]lan expeditions to the rui[MASK]s in the 1850s . Some second- or third @-@ hand accounts of Tikal appeared in print starting in the 17th century , continuing through the writings of John Lloyd Stephens in the early 19th c[MASK]ntury ( Step[MASK]ens and his illustrator Frederick Catherwood heard[MASK]rumors of a lost city , with white build[MASK]ng tops towering above the jungle[MASK], during their 1839 @-@ 40 travels in the region ) . Becaus[MASK] of the site 's remotene[MASK]s from modern towns , however , no explorers visited Tikal until Modesto Méndez and Ambrosio Tu[MASK] , respectively the commissioner and the governor of Petén , visited it in 1848 . Artist Eusebio Lara accompanied them and th[MASK]ir account was published in Germany in 1853 . Several other expeditions came to further investigate , m[MASK]p , and photograph Tikal in the 19th century ( including Alfred P. Maudslay in 1881 @-@ 82 ) and the early 20th century . Pioneering archaeologi[MASK]ts [MASK]tarted to clear , map and record the ruins in the 1880s . 
 In 1951 , a small airstrip was built at the ruins , which previous[MASK]y could only be reached by several days ' travel through the jungle on foot or mule . In 1956 the Tikal project began to [MASK]ap the city on a scale not previously seen in the Maya area . From 1956 through 1970 , major archaeological excavations were carried out by the University of Pennsylvania Tikal Project . They mapped much of the si[MASK]e and e[MASK]cavated [MASK]nd restored many of the structure[MASK] . Excavati[MASK]ns directed by Edwin M. Shook and later by William [MASK]oe of the un[MASK]versity investigated the North Acropolis and the Central Plaza from 19[MASK]7 to 196[MASK][MASK]. The Tikal Project recorded over 200 monuments at the site . In 1979 , the Guatemalan government began a further archeological[MASK]project at Tikal , which continued through to[MASK]1984 . 
 Filmmaker George Lucas used[MASK]Tikal as a filming location for the first Star Wars film , Episode IV : A New Hope [MASK] released in 1977 . Temple I at Tikal was featured on the reverse of the 50 centavo banknote . 
 Tikal is now a major tourist attraction sur[MASK]ounded by its own national park . A site museum has been built at Tikal ; it was completed in 1964 . 
 
 = = Site description = = 
 
 Tikal has been partially restored by the University of Pennsylvania and t[MASK]e government of Guatemala . It was one of the largest of the Classic p[MASK]riod Maya cities and was one of the largest cities in the Americas . The architecture of the ancient city[MASK]is b[MASK]ilt from limestone and [MASK]ncludes the remains of temples that tower over 70 metres ( 230 ft ) high , large royal palaces , in addition to a number of sma[MASK]ler pyramids , palaces [MASK] residences , administrative buildings , platforms and inscribed stone monuments . There is even a building which seemed to have been a jail , originally with wooden bars acro[MASK]s the windows and doors . There are also seven courts for playing the Mesoamerican ballgame , including a set of 3 in the Seven Temples Plaza , a unique feature in Mesoamerica [MASK] 
 The limestone used for construc[MASK]ion was local and quarried on @-@ site . The depressions formed by the extraction of stone for building were plastered to waterproof them and were used as reservoirs , together with some waterproofed natural depressions . The main plazas were surfaced with stucco and laid at a gradient that channelled rainfall into a system of canals [MASK][MASK]at fed the reservoirs . 
 The residential are[MASK] of Tikal covers an estimated 60 square kilometres ( 23 sq mi ) ,[MASK]much of which[MASK]ha[MASK][MASK]not yet been cleared , mapped , or excavated . A huge set of earthworks discovered by Dennis E. Puleston and Donald Callender in the 1960s rings Tikal with a 6 @-@ metre ( 20 [MASK]t ) wide trench behind a rampart . The 16 square kilometres ( 6 @.@ 2 sq mi ) area around the site core has been intensively mapped ; it may have enclosed an area of some 125 square kilometres ([MASK]48 [MASK]q[MASK]mi ) ( see below ) . Population estimates place the demographic size of the site between 10 @,@ 0[MASK]0 and 90 @,@ 000 , and possibly 425 @,@ 000 in the surrounding area . Recently , a project exploring the defensive earthworks has shown that the scale of the earthwor[MASK]s is highly variable and that in many places it is inconsequen[MASK]ial as a defensive feature . In addition , some parts of the earthwork were integrated into a canal system . The earthwork of Ti[MASK]al varies significantly in coverage from what was originally proposed and it is much more complex and multifaceted than originally thought . 
 
 = = = Causeways = = = 
 [MASK] By the Late Classic , a ne[MASK]work of sacbeob ( cau[MASK]eways ) linked various parts of the city , running for several ki[MASK]ometres through its urban [MASK]ore . The[MASK]e linked the Great Plaza with Temple 4 ( located about 750 metres ( 2 @,@ 460 ft ) to the west ) and the Temple of the Inscrip[MASK]ions ( about 1 kilometre[MASK]( 0 @.@ 62 m[MASK] ) to the southeast ) . These bro[MASK]d causeways were built of pac[MASK]ed and plastered limestone and have been named after early explorers and[MASK]archaeologists ; th[MASK] Maler , Maudslay , Tozzer and Méndez causewa[MASK]s . They assiste[MASK] the passage everyday traffic during the rain[MASK]season and also served as dams . [MASK] The Maler Causeway runs north from behind Temple I to Group H. A large bas @-@ relief is carved onto limestone bedrock upon the course of the causeway just south of Group H. It d[MASK]picts two bound captives and dates to the Late Classic . 
 The Mauds[MASK]ey Causewa[MASK] runs 0 @.@ 8 kilometres ( 0 @.@ 50 mi ) northeast from [MASK]emple IV t[MASK] Group H. 
 The Mendez Cau[MASK]eway runs southeast[MASK]from the East Plaza to Temple [MASK]I , a distance [MASK]f[MASK]about 1 @.@ 3 kilom[MASK]tres ( [MASK] @.@ 81 mi ) . 
 The Tozzer C[MASK]useway runs west from the Great[MASK]Plaza to Temple IV . 
 
 = = = Architectura[MASK] grou[MASK]s = = = 
 
 The Great P[MASK]aza lies at the core of the site ; it[MASK]is flanked on the east and west sides by two gre[MASK]t temple @-@ pyramids . On the north side it is bordered by the North Acropolis and o[MASK] [MASK]he sou[MASK]h by the Central Acropolis . 
 The Cen[MASK]ral Acropolis is a palace complex just south of the Great Plaza . 
 The North Acropoli[MASK] , together with the Great Plaza i[MASK]mediately to the south , is one [MASK]f the most studied architectural groups in the Maya area ; the[MASK]Tikal Project exca[MASK]ated a massive trench acr[MASK]ss the complex , thoroughly investigating its construction history . It is a complex group with construction beginning in the Preclassic P[MASK]riod , around 350 BC . It developed into a fune[MASK]ary complex f[MASK]r the ruling dynasty of the Classic [MASK]eriod , with each additional royal burial adding new temples on top of the older structures . After AD 400 a row of tall pyramids was added to the earlier Nort[MASK]ern Platform , which measured 100 by 80 metres ( 330 by 260 ft ) , gra[MASK]ually hiding it from view . Eight temple pyramids were [MASK]uilt in the 6th cent[MASK]ry AD , each of them had an elaborate roofcomb a[MASK]d a[MASK]stairway flanked by masks of the gods . By the 9th century AD , 43 stelae and 30 altars had been erected in [MASK]he North Acropolis[MASK]; 18 of these monume[MASK]ts were carved with hieroglyphic texts and royal portraits . The North Acropolis continued to receive burials in[MASK]o the Postclassic Period . 
 The South Acropolis[MASK]is found next to Temple [MASK]. It was built upon a large basal platform that covers an area of m[MASK]re than 20 @,@ 000 square metres ( 220 @,@ 000 sq ft [MASK] . 
 The Plaza of the Seven Temples is to the west of the Sout[MASK] Acropolis . It is bordered on the[MASK]east side by a row o[MASK] nearly identical templ[MASK]s , by[MASK]palaces [MASK]n t[MASK]e south and wes[MASK] sides and by an unusual triple ballcourt on the north side . 
 The Mundo Perdido is to the we[MASK]t of the Plaza of the Seven Temples . It is the largest ceremonial complex dating from the Preclassic period at Tikal . The compl[MASK]x wa[MASK] organized as a large E @[MASK]@ Group consisting of a pyramid aligned with a platform to the east that suppor[MASK]ed three temples . The Mundo Perdido[MASK]complex was rebuilt many tim[MASK]s over the course of its histor[MASK] . By AD 250 – 300 its architectural style was influenced by the great me[MASK]ro[MASK]o[MASK]is of[MASK]Teotihuacan in the Valley of Mexico [MASK] including the use of the talud @-@ tablero form . During the Early Classic period ( c . 250 – 600 ) the Mundo Perdido became one of the twin foci of the[MASK]city , the other being the North Acropolis . From AD 250 to 378 it may have served as the royal necropolis . The Mundo Perdido complex was given its name by the archaeologists of the University of Pennsylvania ; it is centered upon the Lost World Pyramid and a small platform to the west of it . 
 Group G lies just south of the Mendez Causeway . The complex dates [MASK]o the Late[MASK]Classic and consists of pa[MASK]ace @[MASK]@ type structures and is[MASK]one of the largest gr[MASK]ups of its type at Tikal . It has two stories but most of the rooms are on the lower floor , a to[MASK]al of 29 vaulted chambe[MASK]s . The remains of two further[MASK]chambers belong t[MASK] the upper storey . One of the entrances to the group wa[MASK] f[MASK]amed by a gigantic mask . 
 Group H is centered on a large plaza to the north of the Great Plaza . It is bordered by[MASK]temples dating to the Late Classic . 
 There are nine Twin @-@ Pyramid Complexes at Tikal , one of which was c[MASK]mpletely dism[MASK]ntled in ancient times and some othe[MASK]s were partly destroyed . They vary in size but consist of two pyramids facing each other on an east – west axis . These pyr[MASK]mids are flat @-@ toppe[MASK] [MASK]nd have st[MASK]irways on all four sides . A [MASK]ow of plain stelae is placed immediately to the west of the eastern pyramid and to the north of the pyramid[MASK] , and lying roughly equidistant from them , the[MASK]e is[MASK]usually a sculpted stela and altar pair . On the south side of these complexes there is a lo[MASK]g vaulted building containing a single room with nine doorways . The entire complex [MASK]as built a[MASK] once and these complexes were built at 20 [MASK]-@ year ( or k 'a[MASK]un ) intervals during the [MASK]ate Classic . The f[MASK]rst twin pyrami[MASK] complex was built in the[MASK]early 6th century in the East Plaza . It was once thought that these complexes were unique to Tikal but[MASK]rare examples have now been found at other sites , such as Ya[MASK]ha and Ixlu[MASK], an[MASK] they may reflect the ex[MASK]ent of Tikal [MASK]s political domin[MASK]nce in the Late Classic . 
 Group Q is a twin @-@ pyramid c[MASK]mplex , and i[MASK] one of the largest[MASK]at Tikal . It was[MASK]built by Yax Nuun Ayiin II in 771 in order to mark the [MASK]nd of th[MASK] 17th K 'atun . Most of it has[MASK]been restored and its monuments have been re @-@ erected . 
 Group R [MASK]s another twin @-@ pyramid complex ,[MASK]dated to 790 . It is close to the Maler Causeway . 
 
 = = = Structures = = = 
 
 There are thousands of ancient structures at Tikal and only a fra[MASK]tion of these have been excavated , after dec[MASK]des of archaeological work [MASK] The most prominent survivin[MASK] buildings include six very large pyramids , labelled Temples I - VI , each of which support a temple structure on their summit[MASK] . Some of these pyr[MASK]mids are over 60 metre[MASK] ( 200 feet ) high . They were numbered sequentially during the early survey [MASK]f the site[MASK]. It is estimated that each of these major t[MASK]mples [MASK]ould have been b[MASK]ilt in as little as two years . 
 Temple I ( also known as the Tem[MASK]le of Ah Cacao or T[MASK]mp[MASK]e of the Great Jaguar ) is a funerary pyramid dedicated to Jasaw Chan K 'awil , who was entombed in the structure in AD 734 , the pyramid was comp[MASK]eted around 740 – 750 . The temple rises 47 metres ( 154 ft [MASK] high . The massive roofcomb that topped t[MASK]e temple[MASK]was originally decorated with a giant sculpture of the enthroned king , although little of this[MASK]decoration[MASK]survives . The tomb of the king was discovered by Aubrey Trik of the University of Pe[MASK]nsylvania in 1962 . Among items recovered from the Late Class[MASK]c tomb were a large collection of inscribed human an[MASK] [MASK]nima[MASK] bone tubes and strips wi[MASK]h sophisticated scenes depi[MASK]ting deities and p[MASK]ople [MASK][MASK]finely ca[MASK]ved and rubbed with v[MASK]rmilion , as well as jade and shell ornaments and ceramic[MASK]vesse[MASK]s f[MASK]lled with offerings of food and drink . The shrin[MASK] at the summit of the pyramid has three chambers , each behind the next , with the doorways spanned by woo[MASK]en lintels fashioned[MASK]from multiple beams . The outermost lintel is plain but t[MASK]e two inner li[MASK]tels were carved , some[MASK]of the beams were removed in the 19[MASK]h century and their location is unknown , while others were [MASK]aken to museums in Europe . 
 Temple II ([MASK]also known as the Templ[MASK] of the M[MASK]sk ) it was built ar[MASK]und AD 700 and stands[MASK]38 metres ( 125 ft ) high . Like other major [MASK]emples at Tikal , the summit shrine had three consecutive chambers with the doorways spanned by wooden lintels , only [MASK]he middle of which w[MASK]s carv[MASK]d . The temple was dedicated to the wife of Jasaw Chan K 'awil , although no tomb was found[MASK]. The queen 's portrait was ca[MASK]ved into the lintel spanning the doorway of the summit shrine . One of the beams from this lintel[MASK]is now in the American Museum of Natural History in[MASK]New York . 
 Temple III ( also[MASK]known as the Temple of the Jaguar Priest ) was the last of the great pyramids to be built[MASK]a[MASK] Tikal . It stood 55 metres ( [MASK]80 ft ) tall and contained an elaborately sculpted but damaged roof lintel , possibly showing Dark Sun engaged in a ritual dance around AD 810[MASK]. The[MASK]temple shrine possesses two chambers [MASK] 
 Temple IV is the talle[MASK]t temple @-@ pyramid at Tikal , m[MASK]asuring 70 met[MASK]es ( 230 ft ) from the plaza floor level to the top of its roof comb . Temple IV marks t[MASK]e reign of Yik ’ in Chan Kawil ( Ruler B , the son of[MASK]Ruler A or Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I ) and t[MASK]o carved wooden lintels ov[MASK]r the doo[MASK]way that leads into the temple on the pyramid ’ s summit record a long count date ( 9 @.@ 15 @.@ 10 @.@ 0 @.@ 0 ) that corresponds to CE 741 ( Sharer 1994 :[MASK]169 )[MASK]. Temple IV is the largest pyramid built anywhere in the Maya re[MASK]ion[MASK]in the 8th[MASK]centur[MASK] , and as it currently s[MASK]ands is the tallest pre @-@ Columbian structure in the Americas although the Pyramid of the Sun at Teotihuacan may [MASK]riginally have been taller[MASK], as may have been one of [MASK]he structures at El Mirador . 
 Temple V stands south of the Central Acropo[MASK]is and is the mortuary pyrami[MASK] of an as yet unidentified ruler . The temple[MASK]stands 57 metres ( 187 ft ) high , making it the second tallest structure [MASK]t Tikal - only Temple IV is taller .[MASK]T[MASK]e temple has been dat[MASK]d to about AD 700 , in the Late Classic period , via radiocarbon analysis and the dating of ceramics associated with the structure places its construction during[MASK]the reign of Nun Bak Chak in the second half of the 7th century . 
 Temple VI is also known as the Temple of the Inscriptions and was dedicated in AD 766 . It is notable for its 12 @-@ metre ( 39 ft ) high roof @-@ comb . Panels of hieroglyphs cover the b[MASK]ck and sides of the roof @-@ comb . The temple faces onto a plaz[MASK] to the west and its front is un[MASK]estored . [MASK] Temple 33 was a funerary pyramid erected over the tomb of Si[MASK]aj Chan K 'awiil I ( [MASK]nown as Burial 48 ) in the North Acropolis . It started life in the Early Classic as a wide basal pla[MASK]form decorated with large stucco masks that flanked the stairway . Later in the Early Classic a new superstructure was added , with its own masks and decorated panels . D[MASK]ring the Hiatus a[MASK]third stage was built over the earlier constructions , the[MASK]stairway was demolished and another royal burial , of an unidentified ruler , was set into the struc[MASK]ure ( Burial 23 ) . While the new pyramid was being built another high ranking[MASK]tomb ( Burial 24 ) was inserted int[MASK] the rubble core of the building . The[MASK]pyramid was then completed , standing 33 metres ( 10[MASK] ft ) [MASK]all . The [MASK]inal[MASK]version of Temple 33 was completely dismantled by archaeologists in 1965 in order to arrive at the earlier stages of construction . 
 Str[MASK]cture 34 is a pyramid in the North Acropolis that was built by Siyaj Chan K 'awiil II over the tomb of his father , Yax Nuun Ayiin I. The pyramid wa[MASK] topped by a three cha[MASK]bered shrine , t[MASK]e rooms situated one behind the oth[MASK]r . [MASK] Structure 5D @-@ 43 is an unusual radial temple in the East Plaza , built over a pre @-@ existing twin pyramid [MASK]omplex[MASK]. It i[MASK] built into the end of the East Plaza Ballcourt and possessed four entry doorways and three stairways , the fourth ( south ) side was too close to the Central Acropolis for a stairway on that side . The building has a talud @-@ ta[MASK]lero platform profile , modified from the original style found at Teotihuacan . In fact , it has been suggested that the style of the [MASK][MASK]ilding has closer affinities with El Tajin and Xochicalco than with Te[MASK]tihuacan itself . The ve[MASK]tical tablero panels[MASK]are set between sloping talud panels and are decorated with paired disc symbols . Large flower symbols are set into the sloping talud panels , related to the Venus and star symbols used at Teot[MASK]huacan . The roof of the structure was [MASK]ecorated with friezes although only[MASK]fragments now rem[MASK]in , showing a[MASK]monstrou[MASK] face , perhaps that[MASK]of a jaguar , with another head emerging from the mouth . The second head possesses a bifurcated tongue but is probably not that of a snake . The temple , and its associat[MASK]d ballcourt , probably date to [MASK]he reign of Nuun Ujol Chaak or that of his son Jasa[MASK] Chan K 'awiil I , in the later part of the 7th century[MASK]. 
 Structure 5C @-@ 49 possesses a clear Teotihuacan @-@ linked arch[MASK]tectural st[MASK]le ; it has balustrades , an architectural featur[MASK] that is very rare in the Maya region , and a talud @-@ tablero façade ; it date[MASK] to the 4t[MASK] century AD . It is locate[MASK] near to the Lost World pyramid . 
 Structure 5C @-@ 53 [MASK]s a small[MASK]Teotihuacan @-@ style platform that dat[MASK]s to about AD 600 . It had stairways on all fou[MASK] sides and did not possess a superstructure . 
 The Lost World Pyramid ( Structure 5C @-@ 54 ) is the largest structure in the Mundo Perdido complex . It lies in the southw[MASK]st portion of Tikal ’ s central core , south of Temple III and west of[MASK]Temple V. It was decorated with stucco masks of the sun god and dates to the Late Preclassic ; this pyramid is part of an enclosed complex of structures that remained intact and un [MASK]-@ [MASK]mpacted by later building activity at Tikal . By the end of the Late Preclassic this pyramid was one of the largest structures in the Maya region . It attained its final form during the reign of Chak Tok Ich 'aak[MASK]in the 4th century AD , in the Early Classic , standing more th[MASK]n 30 metres ( 98 ft )[MASK]high with stairw[MASK]ys on all four sides and a flat top that possibly supported a superstructure built from peris[MASK]able materials . Although the plaza later suffered significant alterati[MASK]n , the organization of a group of temples on t[MASK]e east side of this complex ad[MASK]e[MASK]es to the l[MASK]yout that defines the so @-@ called E @-@ Groups , identified as solar observatories . 
 Stru[MASK]ture 5D @-@ 96 is the central temple on the east side [MASK]f the Plaza of the Seven[MASK]Temples [MASK] It has been restored and its rear outer wall is decorated [MASK]ith sk[MASK]ll @-@ and @-@ crossbones motifs . 
 Gro[MASK]p[MASK]6C @-@ 16 is an eli[MASK]e residential complex that has been[MASK]thoroughly e[MASK]cavated . It lies a few hundred[MASK]metres [MASK]outh of the Lost World Complex and the excavations have revealed elab[MASK]rate stucco masks , ballplayer murals , relief sculptures and building[MASK] wi[MASK]h Teo[MASK]ihuacan[MASK]characteristics . 
 The Great Plaza Ballcourt is [MASK] small ballcourt that lies between Te[MASK]ple I and the Central Acropolis . 
 The [MASK]at Palace is also known as the Palace of Windows and lies to the west of Temple III . It has two stor[MASK]ys , with a double range[MASK]of chambers on the lower store[MASK] [MASK]nd a si[MASK]gle range in the uppe[MASK] storey , which has been rest[MASK]red . The palace has ancien[MASK] graffiti and possesses low windows . 
 Complex N lies to the west of the Ba[MASK] Palace and Temple III . The complex da[MASK]es t[MASK] AD 711 . 
 
 = = = Altars = = = 
 
 Altar 5 is carved with two nobles , one of whom is probably Jasaw[MASK]Chan K 'awi[MASK]l I. They are performing a ritual using the bones of an important woman . Altar 5 was found in[MASK]Complex N , which lies to the west of Temple III . 
 Altar [MASK] is sculpted with a bound captive . It was found within Complex P in Group H and is now in the Museo Nacional de Arqueología y Etnología in Guatemala City . 
 Altar 9 is as[MASK]ociated with Stela 21 and bears the sculpture of a bound captive . It is located in fro[MASK]t of Temple VI . 
 Altar 10 is car[MASK][MASK]d with a captive tied to a scaffold . [MASK]t is in the northern enclosure of Group Q[MASK], [MASK] twin @-@ pyramid complex and has suffered from erosion . 
 Altar 35 is a [MASK]lain monument associated with Stela 43 . The stela @-@ altar [MASK]air is centrally located [MASK]t the base of the stairway of Temple IV . [MASK] 
 = = = Lintels = = = 
 
 At Tikal , beams of sapodilla wood were placed as lintels spanning the inner doorways of temples . These are the most elaborately carved wooden[MASK]lintels to[MASK]ha[MASK]e survived anywhere in the Maya regi[MASK]n[MASK]. 
 L[MASK]ntel 3 from Temple IV was taken to Basel in Switzerland in the 19th century . It was in almost perfect condition and depicts Yik 'i[MASK] Chan K 'awiil seated on a palanquin . 
 
 = = = Stelae = = = 
 
 Stelae are carved stone shafts , often sculpted with figures and hieroglyphs . A select[MASK]on of the[MASK]mo[MASK]t notable stelae at Tikal follows [MASK] 
 Stela 1 dates to the 5th century and depicts the king Siyaj Chan K 'awiil II in a standing position .[MASK]
 Stela 4 is dated to AD 396 , during the reign of Yax Nuun Ayiin[MASK]after the intrusion of Teotihuacan in the Maya area . The stela disp[MASK]ays a mix of Maya and Teot[MASK]huacan qualities , and deities from both cultures [MASK] It has a portrait of the king w[MASK]th the Underworld Jaguar God under one arm and the Mexic[MASK]n Tlaloc under the othe[MASK] . His helmet is a simplified version of the Teot[MASK]huacan War Serpent . Unusually for Maya sculpture , but typically for Teotihuacan , Yax Nuun Ayiin is depicted[MASK]with a frontal face , rather than in profile . 
 Stela 5 was dedicated in 744 by Yik 'in Chan K 'awiil . 
 Stela 6 is a badly [MASK]amaged monument dating to 514 and bears the name of [MASK]he " Lady of Tikal " who celebrated the end of the 4th K 'atun in that year [MASK] 
 Stela 10 is twinned with Stela 12 but is badly damaged . It described the accession of Kaloomte ' B 'alam in the early 6th century and earlier events in his career , including the capture of a pr[MASK]soner depicted on the monument . 
 Stela 1[MASK] was the last monument ever [MASK]rected at Tikal ; it was dedicated in 869 by Ja[MASK]aw [MASK]han K 'awi[MASK]l II . 
 Stela 1[MASK] is linked to the queen [MASK]nown as the " Lady of Tikal " and king Kaloomte ' B 'alam . [MASK]he queen is described as performing the year @-@ ending rituals but[MASK]the m[MASK]nument w[MASK]s dedicated in honor of the king . 
 Stela 16 was dedicated in 711 , during the reign of Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I. The sculpture , including a portrait of the [MASK]ing and a hieroglyphic text , are limited to the front face [MASK]f the monument . It was found in Complex N , west of Temple III . 
 Stela 18 was one of two stelae erec[MASK]ed by Yax Nu[MASK]n [MASK]yiin I to celebrate the [MASK] 'atun @-@ end[MASK]ng of AD 396 . It wa[MASK] re @-@ erected at the base of Temple 34 , his funerary shrine [MASK] 
 Stela 19 was dedicated in 790 by [MASK]ax Nuun Ayii[MASK] II . 
 Stela 20 was found in C[MASK]mplex P , in Group H , and was moved to th[MASK] Museo Nacional de[MASK]Arqueología y Etnología in Guatemala Ci[MASK]y . 
 Stela 21 was dedicated in 736 by Yik 'in Chan K 'awiil . Only the bottom of the stela is intact , the rest having b[MASK]en mutilated in ancient times . The survi[MASK]ing sculpture i[MASK] of fine quality , consisting of the feet of a figure and of accompanying hieroglyphic text . The stela is associated with Altar 9 and is locat[MASK]d in fron[MASK] of Temple[MASK]VI . 
 Stela 22 was dedicated i[MASK] 771 by Ya[MASK][MASK]Nuun Ayiin II in the northern enclosure of Grou[MASK] Q , a twin @-@ pyramid complex . The face of the figure on the stela has been mutilated [MASK] 
 Stela 23 was broken in antiquity and was re @-@ erected in a residential com[MASK]lex . The defaced portrait on the monument is that of the so @-@ called " Lady of Tikal " , a d[MASK]ughter of [MASK]hak Tok Ich 'aak[MASK]II who became queen at the age of six but never ruled in her own right , being paired with male co @-@ rulers . It dates to the ear[MASK]y 6th century . 
 Stela 24 was erected at the foot of Te[MASK]ple 3 in 810 , accompanied by Altar 7 . Both were broke[MASK] into f[MASK]agments in ancient times , althoug[MASK] the name of Dark Sun survives on three fragments . 
 Stela 26 was found in the summit shrine of Temple 34 , underneath a broken [MASK]as[MASK]n[MASK]y altar . The monument had originall[MASK] been erected at the base of the temple dur[MASK]ng the Early Classic period and was later broken , probably at the beginning of the Late Classic . Its remains were t[MASK]en interred within the temple shrine . 
 Stela 29 bears a Long Count ( 8 @.@ 12 @.@ 14 @.@ 8 @.@ 15 )[MASK]date equivalent to AD 292 , the earliest surviving Long Count date from th[MASK] Maya lowlands . The stela is also the earliest monument to bear the Tikal emblem glyph . It bears[MASK]a sculpture of the king f[MASK]cing [MASK]o the right , holding the head of an underworld jaguar god[MASK], one of the [MASK]atron deities of the city . The stela was deliberately smashed during the 6th century or som[MASK] time later , the up[MASK]er portion was dragged away and dumped in a[MASK]rubbish tip close to Temple III , to be uncovered by arch[MASK]eologist[MASK] in 1959 . 
 Stela 30 is the first surviv[MASK]ng monument to be erected after the[MASK]Hiatus . Its style and iconography is similar to that of Caracol , one of the more important of Tikal 's enemies . 
 Stela 31 is the accession monument of Siyaj Chan K 'awiil II[MASK], also bearing two portraits of his father , Yax Nuun Ayiin , as a youth dressed as a [MASK]eotih[MASK]acan warrior . He carr[MASK]es a spearthrower in one hand and bears a shield decorated with the f[MASK]ce of Tlaloc , the Teotihuacan war god . In ancient times the sculpture was br[MASK]ken and the upper portion was moved to the summit of Temple 33 and[MASK]ritually buried . Stela 31 has been de[MASK]cribed a[MASK] the greatest Early Classic sculpture to survive at Tikal [MASK] A long hieroglyphic text is carved onto the back of the monument ,[MASK]the longest to survive from the Early Classic , w[MASK]ich describes the arrival of Siyah K 'ak ' at El Peru and Tikal in January 378 . I[MASK] was also the firs[MASK] stela at Ti[MASK]al to be carved on all four faces . 
 Stela 32 [MASK]s[MASK]a fragmented monument wi[MASK]h a foreign Teotihuacan @-@ style sculpture[MASK]apparently depicting the lord of [MASK][MASK]at city with the attribut[MASK]s o[MASK] the central Mexican storm god Tlaloc , including his gog[MASK]le eyes and tasselled headdress . 
 St[MASK]la 39 is a broken monument that was erec[MASK]e[MASK] in the Lost World complex . The uppe[MASK] portion o[MASK] the stela is missing but the lower portion shows the lower body and legs of Chak Tok Ich 'aak , holding [MASK] flint axe in his left hand . He is tr[MASK]mpling the figure of a bound , richly dressed ca[MASK]tive . The monument is [MASK]ated to AD[MASK]376 . The text on the back of the monument describes[MASK]a bloodletting ritual to celebrate a Katun @-@ ending . The st[MASK]la also[MASK]names Ch[MASK]k Tok Ich 'aak I 's father as K '[MASK]nic[MASK] Muwaan Jol . 
 St[MASK]la 40 bears a portrait of Kan Chitam and dates to AD 468 . 
 Stela 43 is paired with Altar 35 . It is a plain monument at the base of[MASK]the stairway of Temple IV . 
 
 = = = Burials = = = 
 
 Burial 1 is a tom[MASK] in the Lost World[MASK]complex . A fine ceramic bowl was recovered from the tomb , with the handle formed from three @-@[MASK]dimensional head and ne[MASK]k of a bird emerging from the two @-@ dimensional body painted on the lid . 
 Burial 10 is the tomb of Yax Nuun Ayiin [MASK] It is located[MASK]beneath Structure 34 in the North Acropolis . The tomb contained [MASK] rich array of offerings , including ceramic vessels and food , and nine youths were sacrificed to accompany the dead king . A dog was also entombed wi[MASK]h the deceased king . P[MASK]ts in[MASK]the tomb were stuccoed and painted and many demonstrated a blend of M[MASK]ya and T[MASK]otihuacan styles . Among the[MASK]offerings was an incens[MASK] @-@ [MASK]urner i[MASK] the[MASK]shape[MASK]of an elderly underworld god , sitting on a stool made of human bones and holding a sev[MASK]red head in his hands . The tomb was sealed with a corbel vault , then the pyramid was built on top . 
 Burial 48 is generally accepted as the tomb of Siyaj Chan K 'awil . It is locat[MASK]d beneath Temple 33 in [MASK]he North Acropolis . The chamber of the tomb was cut fro[MASK] [MASK]he bedrock and contained the remains of the king himself together with those of two adolescents who had be[MASK]n sacrificed in order to accompany the de[MASK]eas[MASK]d ruler . [MASK]he walls of the tomb were covered with white stucco painted with hierogly[MASK]h[MASK] that included the Long Count date equivalent to 20 March 457 , probably the date of either the death or inter[MASK]ent of the king . The king 's skeleton was missing [MASK]ts s[MASK]ull , its femurs and one of its hands whil[MASK] the sk[MASK]letons of the sacrificial[MASK]victims were intact . 
 Burial 85 dates to the Late Preclassic and was enclosed by a[MASK]pla[MASK]form , with a primitive corbel vault . The tomb contained a single male skeleton , which lacked a skull and its thighbones . The dynastic f[MASK]under of Tikal , Y[MASK]x Ehb ' Xook , has be[MASK]n linked to this tomb , which lies[MASK]deep in the heart of the North A[MASK]ropolis . The deceased had probably died in battle with his body being mutilated by his enemies b[MASK]fore being recovere[MASK] and interred by his followers . The bones were wrapped carefully in textiles to form an upright bu[MASK]dle . T[MASK]e missing head was [MASK]e[MASK]laced by a sma[MASK]l greens[MASK]one mask with shell @-@ inlaid teeth and eyes and bea[MASK]ing a three @-@ pointed royal headband . This head wears an emblem of r[MASK]lers[MASK]ip [MASK]n its forehead [MASK]nd is a rare Preclassic lowland Maya portrait[MASK]of a king . Among the contents of the t[MASK]mb were a stingray spine , a spondylus shell and twenty @-@ six ceramic vessels . 
 Burial 116 is the tomb of Jasaw Chan K 'awiil I. It is [MASK] large [MASK]ault[MASK]d chamber deep within the py[MASK]amid , below the leve[MASK] of the Great Plaza . The tomb contained rich offerings of jadeite , ceramics , shell and works o[MASK] art . The body of the king was covered with large quantities of jade ornaments including an enormou[MASK] n[MASK]cklace with especially large beads , as depicted in sculpted p[MASK]rtraits of the ki[MASK]g . One of the outstanding pieces recovered from the tomb w[MASK]s an ornate jade [MASK]osaic vessel with the lid bearing a sculpt[MASK]d portrait of the king himself . 
 Burial 195 was flooded wi[MASK]h mud in antiquity . This flood had covered wooden o[MASK]jects that had completely rotted away by the time the tomb was excavated , leaving [MASK]ollows in the dried mud . Archae[MASK]logists filled these hollows with stucco [MASK]nd thus excavated four effigies of the god K 'awiil , the wooden originals long gone [MASK] 
 Burial 19[MASK] is a Late Classic ro[MASK]al tomb th[MASK]t contained a jade mosaic vessel topped [MASK]ith the head of the Maize God . 
 
 
 = Tropical Storm Josephine ( 2008 ) = 
 
 Tropical Storm Josephine was the tenth tropical storm of the 2008 Atlantic hurricane season[MASK]. Josephine developed out of a s[MASK]rong tropical wave which moved off the African coast on August 31 . The wave quickly became organized and was declared Tropical Depression Ten while located 170 mi ( 270 km ) to the south @-@ southeast of the Cape Verde Islands on September 2 . The depre[MASK]sion was quickly upgraded to Tropical Storm Josephine around noon the same day .[MASK]Over the next several days , Josephine moved in a genera[MASK] wes[MASK] @-@ northw[MASK]st direction and reached its peak intensity early on September 3 . Strong wind s[MASK]ea[MASK] , some due to the outflow[MASK]of Hurricane Ike , and dry air caused the storm to weaken . On S[MASK]ptember 6 , t[MASK]e combination of wind shear[MASK], dry air , and [MASK]o[MASK]ling waters ca[MASK]sed Josephine to weaken into a tropical depression . Josep[MASK]ine deteriorated into a remnant low shortly after as convection continued to dissipate around th[MASK] storm . The low ultimately dissipated while located 520 mi ( 83[MASK] [MASK]m ) east of Guadeloupe on September 10 . However , the re[MASK]nant moisture led to minor flooding on the i[MASK]land of St. Croix . 
 
 = = Meteorolog[MASK]cal history = = 
 
 Tropical Storm Josephine formed as a tropical wave that emerged off the west coast of Africa near the end of August 2008 . It tracked south of Cape Verde and slowly developed , and on September 2 the disturbance became[MASK]Tropical Depression Ten while located south @-@ southeast of the Cape[MASK]Verde islands . As the depression became more organized[MASK], an eye @-@ like fe[MASK]ture developed in the upper levels [MASK]f the system[MASK]. The depres[MASK]ion [MASK]as upgraded[MASK]to Trop[MASK]cal Storm Jo[MASK]ephine six hours after forming . Josephine was located in an area which was supportive for rapid intensification but was n[MASK]t forecast to intensify quickly . [MASK] Josephine continued to intensify throughout the [MASK]fternoon as the storm became more [MASK]ymmetrical . However , due to the location of the storm , there was a lack of accurate wind spee[MASK] readings , and the National Hurricane Center was uncertain of its actual intensity . Despite the lack of wind shear around the storm , the center became s[MASK]ightly exposed and ceased further intensification . The storm w[MASK]s also heading into an area where shear was forecasted [MASK]o significantly i[MASK]crease due to an upper @-@ level troug[MASK] diving southward . Despite convection being partially [MASK]emoved from the ce[MASK]ter of Josephine , the storm intensified slightly in the early morning hours on September 3 as thunderstorm acti[MASK]ity to the so[MASK]th of the center became more org[MASK]nized . The intensification was forecast to be sh[MASK]rt in[MASK]duration as the trough to the north was deepening ,[MASK]causing the wind shear to the west to become [MASK]tronger . 
 Josephine [MASK]eached its peak intensity of[MASK]65 mph[MASK]( 100 km / h ) around 8 a.m. ( EDT ) as it continued to[MASK]become more organized . However , there were indi[MASK]ations that it had[MASK]already [MASK]egun to weaken . Outflow towards the north was becoming restrict[MASK]d and arc clouds began emanating from the storm , a sign [MASK]hat dry air was entering the syst[MASK]m . During the afternoon hours , the structure of Josephine began to rapidly deteriorate as strong wind[MASK]shear and dry air took their toll . By the late n[MASK]ght , the center [MASK]as almost completely exposed and only a band of co[MASK]vection persisted near the center . 
 Despite continuing[MASK]effects from the strong wind shear , a large , deep burst of[MASK]convection [MASK]ormed in the northern semicircle of Josephine . The center was fou[MASK]d to have shifted towards the new convection leading to an increase in intensity . The forecast showed a slight decrease in win[MASK] shear as Josephine contin[MASK]ed westward and no change in intensity over the 5 [MASK]-@ day forecast was [MASK]red[MASK]cted . However , the convection decreased once more and the low became completely exposed by the late morning[MASK]hours and Josephine weakened again . By the afternoon , the center of Jos[MASK]phine was only a swirl of[MASK]clouds , devoi[MASK] of convection . During the overnight hours on September 4 into the morning of September 5 , conve[MASK]tion associated with J[MASK]sephine began to redevelop somewhat , mostly to the north of[MASK]the circulation , due to the strong southerly wi[MASK]d shear . By mid @-@ morning , Josephine re @-@ intensifie[MASK] slightly due to the redevelopment of some conv[MASK]ction . However [MASK] t[MASK][MASK] redevelopment was short lived and[MASK]win[MASK] shear again[MASK]t[MASK]ok its to[MASK]l on [MASK]os[MASK]phine by late morning[MASK]. The convection around the system became dislocat[MASK]d from the center[MASK]and Josephine weakened slightly . 
 The weakening trend continued th[MASK]ough the afternoon as th[MASK] storm was being affected by strong southerly shear . Josephine became almost fully devoid of any conv[MASK]c[MASK]ion by mid @-@ afternoon and the storm weakened to 40 mph ( 65 km / h[MASK]) , barely holding on to tropical storm status [MASK] Josephine regained a small amount of convection in the late night hours [MASK] but not enough to still be classified a tropical storm . Due to the lack of convection , Josephine was downgraded to a Tropical Depression at 11p.m. ( EDT ) with winds of 35 mph ( 55 km / h ) . Since there [MASK]as no convec[MASK]ion around the system , it [MASK]ould have normally been classified a remnant low but , due to the possibility of the storm regenerating over the next several days , it was co[MASK]sidered a tropical depression . The next morning , J[MASK]sephine was downgraded to a remnant[MASK]low as strong wind s[MASK]ear and dry air caused the demise of the storm . No redevelopment was expected with Josephine as it began to move over colder waters a[MASK]d rem[MASK]in under strong wind shear until it dissipated . 
 However , the remnant low associated with Josephine began to show signs of redevelopment during the afternoon on September [MASK] . Convection around the system increased significantly and the low was no longer exposed . On[MASK]September 8 , wind shear took over the system again . Convection around the remnant low was torn away and the low was exposed once more . The National Hurricane Center did not state t[MASK]e chance of regeneration on[MASK]e the low became exposed . Finally , on September 9 , wind shear and dry [MASK]ir led to [MASK]he remnants of Josephine deteriorating into an open wave . However , on September 10 , the remnants of Josephine redeveloped and global models picked up on the reformed system . [MASK]nce mor[MASK] ,[MASK]the chance of regen[MASK]ration was possi[MASK]le as the remnants[MASK]of Josephine headed towards the Bahamas . However , on September 14 , dry air and wind shear caused the remnants t[MASK] dissipate entirely . 
 
 = = Impact = = 
 
 As Josephine passed to the south of the Cape Verde islands on September 2 , outer rain bands produced minor rainfall , totalin[MASK] around 0 @.@ 5[MASK] inches ( 14 mm ) . There were no reports of damage or flooding from the rain and overall effects were minor . 
 Several[MASK]days after the low dissipated , the remnant moistur[MASK] from Jos[MASK]phine brought showers and thunderstorms to St. Croix where up to 1 in ( 25 @.@ 4 mm [MASK] of rai[MASK] fell . The heavy rains led to m[MASK]nor street flooding a[MASK]d some urban flooding . No known damage was caused by the flood . 
 
 
 = Mount Elbert = 
 
 Mount Elbert is the highest summit of the Rocky Moun[MASK]ains o[MASK] North America and the hi[MASK]hest point in the U.S.[MASK]state of Colorado a[MASK]d [MASK]he [MASK]ntire Mississipp[MASK] River drainage b[MASK]sin . The ult[MASK]a @-@ [MASK]rominent 14 @,@ 440 @-@ fo[MASK]t ( 4401 @.@ 2 m ) fourteener is [MASK]he highest peak in the Sawatch Range a[MASK]d the se[MASK]ond @-@ highest summit in the contiguous United States after Mount Whitney . Mount Elbert is l[MASK]cated in S[MASK]n Isabel National Forest , 12 @.@ 1 miles ( 19 @.@ 4 km ) southwest ( bearing 22[MASK] ° ) of the City of Le[MASK]dville in Lake County , Colorado . 
 The mountain was named in honor[MASK]of Colorado statesman Samuel Hitt Elbert , who was active in the formative period of the state and Governor of the Territory of Colorado from 1873 to 1874 . Henry W. Stuckle of the Hayden Survey was the first to record an ascent of the peak , in 1874 . The ea[MASK]iest and most popular climbing routes are categorized as Class 1 to 2 or A + in mountaineeri[MASK]g parlance . [MASK]ount Elbert is therefore often referred to as the " gentle giant " that tops al[MASK] others in the Rocky Mountains . 
 
 [MASK] = Geography = = 
 
 M[MASK]unt Elbert is visible to the southwest of Leadville , often snow [MASK]-@ capped even in the summer . Many other fourteeners surround Elbert in all directions , an[MASK] it is very close to central Colorado 's Collegiate Peaks . The neighboring Mount M[MASK][MASK]sive , to the north , is the second @-@ highest peak in the Rocky Mountains and the third @-@ highest in the contiguous United States , and La Plata [MASK]eak , t[MASK] the south , is the fifth @-@ highest in the Rockies . The community of Twin Lakes lies at the base of Mount El[MASK]ert , Denver is about 130 miles[MASK]( 20[MASK] km ) to the east , Vail is 50 miles ( 80 km ) to the no[MASK]th , and Aspen is 40 miles ( 64 km ) to the west . Lead[MASK]ille , about 16 miles ( 26 km ) to the northeast , is the nearest large town . Elber[MASK] 's parent peak i[MASK] Mount Whitney in California . Including Alaska and Hawaii , Mou[MASK]t Elbert is the fourteenth @-@ highest mountain in the [MASK]nited States . 
 Weather conditions often change[MASK]rapidly , and afternoon thunderstorms are com[MASK]on in the summertime ; hailstorms and snow are possible year @-@ round . An electrical storm on the mountain 's summit was considered remarkable enough to be reported in the July 1894 issue of Scienc[MASK] . 
 
 = = Geology = = 
 
 Mount Elb[MASK]rt is part of the Sawatch Range [MASK] an uplift of the Laramide Orogeny which separated from the Mosquito Range to the east around 28 milli[MASK]n years ago . The tops of this range were heavily glaciated , leaving[MASK]behind character[MASK]stic summit features and oth[MASK]r such clues . For example , the base of Elbe[MASK]t on the eastern side exhibits large igneous and metamorphic rocks deposited whe[MASK] t[MASK]e glaciers receded , which lie on a lateral moraine . Further up the eastern side there[MASK]is a large cirque with a small tarn . There are also l[MASK]kes to both the north and south , Turq[MASK]oise and Twin Lakes respectively ; the Twin Lakes are a result of the natural dam of end moraines , and Turquoise La[MASK]e was created by the manmade Sugar Loaf Dam . 
 Mount Elbert is composed la[MASK]gely of quartzite . However , the summit ridge consists of metamorphic ba[MASK]ement rock , which is Pre @-@ Camb[MASK]ian in origin and abo[MASK]t 1 @.@ 7 billion years old . There are various ign[MASK]ous intrusions including pegmatite , as well as " bands " of gneiss and schist . Unlike [MASK]ountains of similar altitude elsewhere , Elbert lacks both a [MASK]ermanent snowpack and a prominent north @-@ facing cirque , which can be attributed to its position amongst other mountains of similar height , causing i[MASK][MASK]to receive relatively small quantities of precipitat[MASK]on [MASK] 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 Mount Elbert was nam[MASK]d by min[MASK]rs in honor [MASK]f Samue[MASK] Hitt Elbert , the governo[MASK] of the then @-@ Territory of Colorado , because he brokered a treaty in September 1873 with the Ute tribe tha[MASK] opened up more than[MASK]3 @,@ 000 @,@ 000 acres ( 12 @,@ 000 km2 ) of reservation land to mining and railroad activity . The first recorded ascent of the peak was[MASK]by H.W.[MASK]Stuckle in 1874 , who was surveying the mountain as part of the Hayden Survey . 
 Originally measured as 1[MASK] @,@ 433 feet ( 4 @,@ 399 m ) in height , Mount Elbert 's ele[MASK]ation was later adjusted to 14 @,@ 440 feet ( 4 @,@ 4[MASK]0 m ) following a re @-@ evaluation of m[MASK]pped elevations , whic[MASK] sparked protests . The actual change was made in 1988 as a result of the North American[MASK]Vertical Datum of 1988 ; it seems the original measurement resulted from the Sea Level Datum of[MASK]1929 . A matter of some contention arose after the [MASK]reat Depression over the heights of Elbert [MASK]nd its neighbor , Mount Massive , which differ i[MASK] elevation by only 12 feet ( 3 @.@ 7 m ) . This led to an ongoing dispute that came to a head with the Mount Massive supporte[MASK]s building large piles[MASK]of stones [MASK]n the summit to boost its height , only to ha[MASK]e the Mount [MASK]lbert proponents demolish [MASK]hem . The effort was ultimately un[MASK]uccess[MASK]ul and Mount Elbert has remained the highest peak in Colorado . The f[MASK]rst motorized ascent of Elbert occurre[MASK] in 1949 , when a Jeep was driven t[MASK] the summit , apparently to judge suitability for skiing development . 
 
 = = Flora and fauna = = 
 
 The summit of Mount Elber[MASK] is an alpine environment , featuring plants such as Phaceli[MASK] sericea ( sky @-@ pilot ) , Hymenoxys grandiflora ( old @-@ man @-@ of [MASK]-@ the @-@ mountain ) , and Geum rossii[MASK]( alpine avens ) . Also noted are Car[MASK]x atrata var. pullata [MASK] Salix des[MASK]rtorum , Platanthera hyperborea , Thalictrum fendleri , Aquilegia canadensis , Chenopodium album , Gentiana detonsa var. hallii , and Bigelovia pa[MASK]ryi . Below tre[MASK]line the mountain is heavily forested , w[MASK]th the lower slopes covered with a mixture of lodgepole pine , spruce ,[MASK]aspen and fir . 
 Some of the fauna reported on the climb to the[MASK]summit include black[MASK]bears , marmots , mule deer , pikas , and pocket goph[MASK]rs[MASK]; there are also many species of avifauna . Elk , grouse , turkey and bi[MASK]horn sheep are present in[MASK]the area during the summer . 
 
 = = Climbing = = 
 
 There are thr[MASK]e main routes which ascend the mountain , all of wh[MASK]ch gain over 4 @,@ 100 feet ( 1 @,@ 200 m ) of elevation . The s[MASK]andard route ascends the peak from the east , starting from the Colorado Trail j[MASK]st no[MASK]th of Twin Lakes . Th[MASK] 4 @.@ 6 miles ( 7 @.@ 4 km ) long North ( Main ) Elbert Trail[MASK]begins close to [MASK]he Elbert Creek Campgro[MASK]nd , and gains about 4 @,@ 500 feet ( 1 @,@ 400 m ) . The trail is open to equestrians , mountain bikers and hunters during season . An easier , but longer route , the South Elbert Trail , is 5 @.@ 5 miles ( 8 @.@ 9 km ) long , climbing 4 @,@ 600 [MASK]eet ( 1 @,@[MASK]400 m ) at a less @-@ punishing gradient than the North Elbert Trail[MASK], approaching from the south an[MASK] then clim[MASK]ing the ea[MASK][MASK]ern ridge . 
 The most difficult of the main ro[MASK]tes[MASK]is the Black[MASK]Cloud Trail , a Class 2 climb that takes ten to fourteen hours depending on pace , gains 5 @,@ 300 feet ( 1 @,@ 600 m ) in elevation , and also involve[MASK] an ascent of the su[MASK] @-@ pe[MASK]k , South[MASK]E[MASK]bert , at 14 @,@ 134 feet ( 4[MASK]@,@ 308 m ) . Even healthy and experienced climbers report grea[MASK] difficulty on[MASK]this route , and des[MASK]i[MASK]e the fact that there is a trail , the route is extremely steep , [MASK]n[MASK]tab[MASK]e , and rocky in places . The elevation[MASK]gain i[MASK] not evenly distributed over the 5 @[MASK][MASK] 5 @-@ mile a[MASK]cent . Ther[MASK] are also route[MASK] approaching from the [MASK]estern face , and sout[MASK]western ridge , from Sout[MASK] H[MASK]lfmoon Creek Tr[MASK]ilhead and Echo Canyo[MASK] Trailhead respectively . 
 Although strenuous and[MASK]requiring physical fitness , none of the conventional routes require specialist mountaineering skills[MASK]or technical rock[MASK]climbing . The main dange[MASK]s of the mountain are those common to all high mountains , particularly altitude sickness . This can affect anyone , even those who are acclimatized . In seri[MASK]us cases , it can lead to high @-@ altitude pulmonary edema and cerebral edema ,[MASK]w[MASK]ich can lead to difficulties with breathing , paralysis [MASK] and death . Climbers are advised[MASK]to begin their ascent at or before 6 a.m. and to summit and descend before early afternoon to minim[MASK]ze exposu[MASK]e to possible aftern[MASK]on thunderstorms while at high altitudes . Although the[MASK]most conventional form of ascent is by hiking , Anna Elizabeth Dickinson , the orator , ascended the mountain on a mule borrowed from the U.S. government . 
 
 
 = Scientology [MASK]n Ger[MASK]any = 
 
 The Church of Scientology has been present in Germany since 1970 . Germ[MASK]n authorit[MASK]es esti[MASK]ate that there are 4 @,@ 000 active Scie[MASK]tologists in Germany today[MASK]; the Church of Scientology gives a membership figure of around 12 [MASK],@ 000 . The Church of Scientology [MASK]as encountered particular antagonism fro[MASK] the German press and government and occupies a precarious legal , social and cultural position in Germany . 
 German courts have so far not resolved whether Scientology should be accorded [MASK][MASK]e legal status of a religious or worldview community , and different courts ha[MASK]e reached contradictory conclusions . The German domestic intelligence service has monitored the organization 's activities . The German gov[MASK]rnment does not recognize Scientology as a religio[MASK] . It views it as an abusive b[MASK]siness[MASK]masquerading as a religion and believes that i[MASK] pursues political goals that conflict with[MASK]the values enshrined in the German constitu[MASK]ion . This stance has been criticized , most n[MASK]tably by the U.S. government , which recognizes Scientology as a religion and has raised [MASK]oncerns abo[MASK]t the violation of individual rights posed by sect [MASK]ilters . 
 Scientologists in Germany f[MASK]ce specific political and economic res[MASK]rictions . They are barred [MASK][MASK]om[MASK]members[MASK]ip in some major political parties , and business[MASK]s and other employers use so @-[MASK] called " sect fi[MASK]ters " to expose a prospective business partner 's or employee 's association with the organization . German f[MASK][MASK]eral and state in[MASK]erior ministers started [MASK] process aimed at banning Scientology in late 2007 , but abandoned the[MASK]initiative a year later , finding insufficient[MASK]legal grounds . Despite this , pol[MASK]s suggest that most Germans favor banning Scientology[MASK]altogether . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 Scientology , founded in the early 1950s in the United States by [MASK]. Ron Hubbard and today cla[MASK]ming to be represented in 150 countrie[MASK] , has been a very controvers[MASK]al new religious movement . Its stated[MASK]utopian aim is to " clear [MASK]he p[MASK]anet " , to bring about an enlightened age in which every[MASK]individual has overcome their psychologic[MASK]l limitations . Scientology teaches that[MASK]the source of people 's unhappiness[MASK]lies in " engrams " , psychological burdens acquired in the course of painful experiences , wh[MASK]ch can be clear[MASK]d through a type of counselling called " auditing " made [MASK]vailable by the Church of Scientology[MASK]. 
 The fact that Scientologists have to pay large fees for auditing and other Scientology services has brought controversy to Scientology throughout much of its history , with governments classing it as a profit @-@ making enterprise rather than as a religion . Critics maintain that Scientology[MASK]is " a business @-@ drive[MASK] , psychologically manipulative , total[MASK]tarian ideol[MASK]gy with world @-@ dominating aspirations " , and that it tricks its members into parting with significant sums of [MASK]oney for Scientology courses . Scient[MASK]logy has fought innumerable lawsuits to defend itself against such charges and to pursue legal recognition as a r[MASK]ligion .
