These efforts have been partly su[MASK]cessful [MASK] S[MASK]ientology has gained recognition as a tax @-@ exempt religious group in a number of countries , most no[MASK]ably in Australia in 1983 and the United States in 1993 , and [MASK]n 2007 won an important case [MASK]t the European Court of Human Rights , which censured Russia for failing to register Scientology as a r[MASK]ligion . 
 The Germ[MASK]n government has said that it doe[MASK] not consider Scientology a r[MASK]ligio[MASK] , but a " commercial enterprise with a history of taking advantage of vulnerable individuals and an extreme dislike of any criticism " whose " totalitarian structure and methods may pose a risk[MASK]to Germany 's democratic so[MASK]iety " . Acco[MASK]dingly , the German government has taken a very strong stance against the [MASK]rganization . Germany is[MASK]not alone in opposing Sc[MASK]entology ; in France , the Church of Scientology was convicted of organized fraud in October 2009 [MASK] after a court[MASK]found that members ha[MASK] been manipulated into paying large [MASK]ums for Scientology products , and the Church only narrowly escaped being banned altogether . Scientology is similarly controversial in Belgium , Greece and the UK . 
 On the subject of Scientology 's status as a religion , the German government has pointed to a 1995 decis[MASK]on by the Federal Labor Court of Germany . That [MASK]ourt , noting Hubbard 's[MASK]instruction that Scientologists should[MASK]"[MASK]make money , make more money – [MASK]ake other people produce [MASK]o as to make more money " , came to the conclusion that " Scientology purports to be a ' church ' merely as a cover to pursue its economic interests " . In the same decision , the court also found that Scientology uses " inhuman and totalitarian practices " . Given the lessons of Germany '[MASK] 20th @-@ century [MASK]istory , in which the country ca[MASK]e to be dominated by a fascist movement that started from similarly small be[MASK]innings , Germany is very wary of any ideologica[MASK] [MASK]ovement that mi[MASK]ht appear to be seeking a p[MASK]sition of absolute power . Referenc[MASK]s in S[MASK]ientology[MASK]writings to the elimination of " parasites " and " antisocial " people who stand in[MASK]the way of progress towards Scientol[MASK]gy [MASK]s utopian world " without insanity[MASK], without[MASK]criminals and without war " evoke uncomfortable parallels with Nazism , and have led to Scientology being c[MASK]assified as an " extremist political movement " . 
 To fur[MASK]her justify its stance , the German government[MASK]has also pointed to the long his[MASK]ory of U.S. court cases involving Scientology , includ[MASK]ng the [MASK]onviction of 11 top Scientologis[MASK]s in 1979 and 1980 for a conspirac[MASK] involving the infiltration of U.S. government agencies , wiretapping and the theft of government documents[MASK], a[MASK]1994 U.S. Supreme Court finding that Scientology practices t[MASK]ok place in a " coercive environment " , and Scientology[MASK]'s track record of pursuing its critics through malicious court cases and private investigators . In e[MASK]amining the potential threat posed by Scientology the German gove[MASK]nment has note[MASK] that Scientology orga[MASK]izations a[MASK]e " structured so as to make the individual psychologica[MASK]ly and financially dependent on a Scientology system " , [MASK]nd that members often abandon contact w[MASK]th friends and f[MASK]mily . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 
 = = = Scientology presence in Germany = = = 
 
 Sci[MASK]ntology first became active in Germany in 1970 . By 2007 , there were ten major cen[MASK]res ( " Scientology Churches " ) , as well as fourteen minor centres ( " Scientology Missions " ) in Germa[MASK]y . The German Sciento[MASK]ogy Ch[MASK]rc[MASK]es are located in the big cities – Munich , Hamburg , Berlin , Düsseldorf , [MASK]rankfurt am Main , Hanover and Stuttgart . Of the Scientology Missions , nine are in Baden @-@ Württemberg , and[MASK]thr[MASK]e in Bavaria . Following German re @-@ unification , Sci[MASK]ntology proved unable to gain significant numbers of followers in the territories of the former German Democratic Republic ; most adherents are found in Baden @-@ Württemberg , Bavaria and [MASK]orth @-@ Rhine Westphalia . [MASK] Scien[MASK]ology is represented by a large number of independ[MASK]nt associations or Vereine in Germany ; their umbrella organisation is the Scientology Kirche Deutschland e.V. Germany 's domestic intelligence service , the Bunde[MASK]amt für Verfassungsschutz ( BfV , or Federal [MASK]ffice[MASK]for the Protection of the Constitution ) , est[MASK]mates that there are 4 @,@ 000 Scientologists in Germany , down from earlier estimates of 5 @,@ 000 to 6 @,@ 000 .[MASK]The Church of Scientology reported around 30 @,@ 000 members from the mid @-@ 1990s onwards ; this number remained stable for many[MASK]years[MASK]. However more recently Scientology has said it has only 12 @,@ 000 members . Discrepancies in Sc[MASK]entology member[MASK]hip [MASK][MASK]mbers arise because the Church of Scientology app[MASK]ies more inclusive criteria in establishing its figures , e[MASK]sentially inc[MASK]uding anyone who has purchas[MASK]d a book or participated in courses , regardless of their subsequent involvement . The number of cont[MASK]actually bound Scient[MASK]logy staff mem[MASK][MASK]rs working in German Scientology organizations is unlikely to exceed a few hundred . 
 Scientology formulated a " Clear Germany " strategy i[MASK] 1994 – similar to equivalent strat[MASK]gies pursued by Sci[MASK]ntology in other countries and regions of the wo[MASK]ld – with the long @-@ term aim of tr[MASK]nsforming German society in line with the Scientological ideal : a non @-@ pluralist society [MASK]n w[MASK]ich Scientology enjoys overriding influence . The programm[MASK] sought to address Scientology 's image problems in Germany ,[MASK]to[MASK]identify weak points in Germany that could be exploited f[MASK]r political gain , su[MASK]h as Germany 's National Socialist history , and to increase both membership figures and political influence in German society , with a speci[MASK]l emphasis on manoeuvring Scient[MASK]lo[MASK]ists into key positions in industry and government . As most religions seek [MASK]o widen th[MASK]ir infl[MASK]ence in society , such a programme could of course also be defended as a[MASK]missionary effort , much like those many religions engage in . Howeve[MASK] , according to the BfV , the strategy has not had[MASK]any significan[MASK] success . By 1998 , [MASK]0 government officials had been suspected of being Scientologi[MASK]ts and in 48 cases the suspicions were[MASK]confirm[MASK]d , but apart [MASK]rom some isolat[MASK]d cases , most of the[MASK]officials concerned had not used their positions to advertis[MASK] Scientology . According t[MASK] Fifka & Sydora ( 2009 ) , it is unknown to what degree the " Clear Germany [MASK] programme is still being pursued . 
 
 = = = Public opposition = = = 
[MASK]
 Germa[MASK] public discourse does not regard Scientology as a religion ,[MASK]but generally characterizes it as a Sekte[MASK]( cult or sect [MASK] , or as an ex[MASK]loitative pro[MASK]it @-@ making vent[MASK]re preying on vulnerable minds . Public concer[MASK]s about the potential dange[MASK][MASK][MASK]posed by cults date back to the early 1970s , when widespread debate [MASK]ook place about " youth[MASK]religions " such as the Unification Church , ISKCO[MASK] , Children of God , and[MASK]the Divine Light Mission . The most prominent criti[MASK]s of these new religious movements were the " sect commissioners " ( Sektenbeauftragte ) of Germany[MASK]'s Protestant Churches , who also actively promoted th[MASK] establishment of private " in[MASK]tiatives of parents and [MASK]oncerned persons " . Aktion [MASK]ildungsinformation ( " Educational Information Cam[MASK]aign " ) became an important organization dedicated to opposing Scientology ; taking an activist stance , it warne[MASK] people not to get involved with Scientology , filed successful lawsuits against the Church of Scientology over its prosely[MASK]izing in public places , and published an influential book , The Sect[MASK]of Scientology an[MASK] its Front Organizations . In 1981 , the organization 's founder , Ingo Heine[MASK]ann , became the director of Aktion für gei[MASK]tige und psychische Freiheit[MASK]( " Campaign for Intellectual and Psychic Freedom " ) , Germany 's most prominen[MASK] anti @-@ cult organization . Warnings from sect experts about the influence of new religious movements gained media attention which put political pressure on the governmen[MASK] to deal with the situation ; as th[MASK] movements we[MASK]e not do[MASK]ng [MASK]nything illegal , the gover[MASK]ment resorted to issuing a range of leaflets and public state[MASK]ents giv[MASK]ng g[MASK]neral warnings about religious sects , the e[MASK]rliest of these publicati[MASK]ns [MASK]ppearing in 1[MASK]79 . 
 Fueled by events such as t[MASK]e Waco Siege in 1993 , the murders and suicides [MASK]ssociated with the Order of the Sol[MASK]r Temple , and the 1995 Au[MASK] Shinrikyo incidents in Japan , German fears and concerns about new religious movements [MASK]ained in intensity in the 1990s , w[MASK]th Scientology attracting particular attention . Percept[MASK]ons that Scientology had a totalitarian character were reinforced when Robert Vaughn Young[MASK], an Ameri[MASK]an ex @-@ Sci[MASK]ntologist[MASK]and former PR official in the Church of Scientology , visited German officials in late 1995 and wrote an article in Der Spi[MASK]gel , a widely @-@ read weekly magazine , describing Scientology as a totalitarian system operating a gulag [MASK] the Rehabilitation Project Fo[MASK]ce – for members of Scientology 's Sea Org found guilty [MASK]f trans[MASK]ressions . From the mid @-@ 1990s onward [MASK] press articles , reports and[MASK]essays on Scientology appeared on an a[MASK]most dai[MASK]y b[MASK]sis , accompanie[MASK] by books and television p[MASK]ogrammes that reached a mass au[MASK]ienc[MASK] . 
 As noted by the religious scholar Hu[MASK]ert Seiwert , Scientology came to be seen as a " serious political danger that not only threatened to turn ind[MASK]viduals into will @-@ less zombies , but was also conspir[MASK]ng to overthrow the democ[MASK]atic constitution of the state " . [MASK]his view of Scientology as a public enemy , Seiwert adds , " became a matter of political [MASK]orrectness " : senior political figures became involved in launching campaigns[MASK]against Scientology , and being suspected o[MASK] any association with it resu[MASK]ted in social ostracism . Stephen A. Kent , writing in 1998 , noted t[MASK]at officials at all levels of German government shared the insistence that Scientology should be suppressed . Scientology was viewed as " a totalitarian , business @-@ driven organiz[MASK]tion [ ... ] guilty of significant human rights abuses . " Officials exami[MASK]ing primary and se[MASK]ondary sources , legal documents , and the testimony of former members , concluded that the organization was " an[MASK]ithetica[MASK] to a democratic state " . Federal ministries an[MASK] st[MASK]te governments were asked to use all legal mea[MASK]s at their disposal to check the activities of Scientology . 
 G[MASK]vernment public[MASK]tions on the dangers of sects i[MASK]cr[MASK]ased between 1996 and 1998 , and a significant number of them dealt with the C[MASK]urch of Scientology . The Ger[MASK]an courts had approved such publications in 1989 ,[MASK]se[MASK]ing them as part of the government 's responsibility to keep the public informed , and fin[MASK]ing that they did not interfere with religious freedom . In 1996 , the German parliament launched an Enq[MASK]ete ( Enquiry ) Commission to investigate sects and similar g[MASK]oups , in large part because of public concerns about Scientology . Its final rep[MASK]rt , published in June 1998 , conclu[MASK]ed that Scientology , alone among new religious movements , required monitoring b[MASK] Germany 's domestic intelligen[MASK]e services . 
 An area of widespread concern in the German media has been the alleged " infiltration " of businesses by Scientologists , in[MASK]line[MASK]with Scientology 's decl[MASK]red aim to penet[MASK]ate society , politics and business in preparation[MASK]for world domination . Attempts to infiltrate businesses have reportedly been most successful among small and medium [MASK]-[MASK] size companies , such a[MASK] estate agents , management consultants and management @-@ training companies . Management @-@ consultancy firms led by Scientologists often conceal their associ[MASK]tion [MASK]ith Scientology ; once they have recruited members of their clients[MASK]' upper management , thes[MASK] man[MASK]gers may send employees to Scientology trainers , as part of company education and training programmes , without informing t[MASK]em as to the origin of the training methods used . An expensive commercial version of Scientology 's Oxford Capacity Analysis , usually offered free as part of Scientology pr[MASK]selytizing in public places , tem[MASK][MASK]rarily entered some major German companies [MASK] who were unaware of its provenance ) via[MASK]such a management @-@ consultancy firm . 
 In the mid @-@ 200[MASK]s , German sect experts expressed concerns [MASK]hat Scientologists were becoming act[MASK]ve in the German after @-@ school tutoring market . These concerns arose bec[MASK]use customers of around 20 after[MASK]@-@ school tutoring centres operated by Scientologists in Frankfurt , Hamburg , Stuttgart and els[MASK]wher[MASK] might be unaware that their children wer[MASK] being ta[MASK]ght by Scientologist[MASK] , using Scientology [MASK]ethods . Brochures advertising the tutoring s[MASK]rvices would at most mention the name of L. Ron Hubbard , the founder of Scientology , but not Sci[MASK]ntology itse[MASK]f . 
 In early 2008 , Thomas Gandow , Sect Commissioner of the German Lutheran Church in Berlin and Brandenburg , and the historian Guido Knopp [MASK]oth [MASK]ikened the Scientologist Hollywood actor Tom Cruise to Goebbels , the Nazi propaga[MASK]da minister . Gandow and Knopp cited a le[MASK]ked[MASK]Scientology video in whi[MASK]h C[MASK]uise was seen asking the audience whether Scientologists should " clean up "[MASK]the world , the audience responding with enthusiastic cheers – cheers which Gandow a[MASK]d K[MASK]opp felt were reminiscent of the audience 's response to Goebbels ' famous question , " Do you want total wa[MASK] ? " Gandow 's and Knopp 's comments found few critics in German[MASK] . Most Germans consider Scientology a subversive organization . In 1997 , Time reporte[MASK] that 70 % of Germans favoured banning Scientology ; a poll conducted in September 2008 by Der Spiegel found 67 % support [MASK]or a ban . 
 German scholars such as Brig[MASK]tte Schön and Gerald Willms have commented that rhet[MASK]ric dominates public discourse ar[MASK]und Scientology in Germany : in their view , efforts to " frame " in[MASK]ormation in such a way as to shape opinion have long been more important than the underlying realities . In Schön 's words , this includes both the " efforts of German politicians to enhance the[MASK]r popularity with strong @-@ worded statements " and " Scientology 's efforts to present itself as the victim of unjust persec[MASK]tion " ; commen[MASK]ing on foreign reporting on Scientology in Germany , she adds that " the American press may prefer sensationalist news to boring investigation and [MASK]ay frame the issue according to American stereotypes " . Both Willms and Schön assert that the situation is compounded by the gen[MASK]ral paucity of scientifi[MASK] studies of Scientology . Schön as well as Irving Hexham , Professor of Religious[MASK]Studies at the University of Calgary in Canada , have remarked in particular on the lack of academic studies by German scholars . Hexham attributes this situation to t[MASK]e strong influence of the Christian churches in Germany , which has made German academics wary of approaching the subject , because they fear repercussions for their research funding and for their prospects of future emplo[MASK]ment if they involve themselves in the debate . 
 In[MASK]2010 a German public broadcaster , ARD , showed the film Until Nothing Remains , a[MASK]dra[MASK]atized accoun[MASK] of the effect Scientology had on one German family . Said to be based on a true[MASK]story , the film a[MASK]tracted widespread media attention and a viewership of 8 @.@ 69 million . 
 
 = = Legal status = = 
 
 While there have been calls for Scientology[MASK]to be banned , the Church of Scientology remains legal [MASK]n Germany and is allowed to operate there . Its precise legal st[MASK]tus however is unre[MASK]olved . Two points are contested : first , whether or not the teachings of Scientology qualify as a "[MASK]religion or worldview " ( Religion or Weltanschauung ; these are equal before German law ) , and se[MASK]ondly , whether [MASK]r not these teachings are only used as a pretext[MASK]for purely commercial activ[MASK]ty ; if the latter were the cas[MASK] , th[MASK]s would most likely imply that Scientology would not qualify for protection as a " religious o[MASK] worldview com[MASK]unity " ( Religions- oder Weltanschauungsgemeinschaft ) under Article 4 of the German constitution , w[MASK]ich guarantees th[MASK] freedom of belief , rel[MASK]gion and w[MASK]rldview . Status [MASK]s a " religious or worldview[MASK]community " also affects a broad range of other issues in [MASK]ermany , such as taxation and[MASK]freedom of association . 
 The Federal Court of Justice of Germany has not yet made an explicit decision on the matter , but implicitly assumed in 1980 that Scientology represented a religious or world[MASK]iew community . The[MASK]Upper Administrative Court in Hamburg explici[MASK]ly asserted in 19[MASK]4 that[MASK]Scientology sho[MASK]ld be viewed as a world[MASK]iew community . In 1995 , the Federal Labor Court of Germany decided that the Church of Scientology merely pursued commercial[MASK]aims and did not represent a religious or worldview c[MASK]mmunity entitled to protection under Ar[MASK]icle 4 of the German Consti[MASK]ution , although another decision b[MASK] the same court left the question open again in 2003 . I[MASK] another 2003 decision , the Administrative Court of Baden @-@ Württemberg in Ma[MASK]nheim said there were no indicat[MASK]ons that the teachings of Scientology merely served as a pretext for commercial activity . In 2005 , the Federal Administrative Court of Germany explicitly granted a Scientologist protection under Article 4 @.@ 1 of the Germ[MASK]n Constitution , which declare[MASK] the freedom of religion and worldview i[MASK]violate [MASK] 
 Many courts have declined to [MASK]ssess the reli[MASK]i[MASK]us status of Scientology , finding that the que[MASK]tion was irrelevant to deciding the cas[MASK] at hand . The Federal A[MASK]ministrative Cou[MASK]t for example ruled in 1997 that the question whether or not Scientology was a religion [MASK]as irrele[MASK]ant , and that[MASK]its legal status should[MASK]be judged by its business activities . The German government does not consider the Church [MASK]f Scientology to be a religious or worldview community and asserts that Scientology is a profit @-@ making enterprise , rather than a religion . Rece[MASK]t years have seen [MASK] number of court deci[MASK]ions in Sc[MASK]entology 's favour , despite the very widespread negative attitude to S[MASK]ientology among politicians and the general public . 
 
 = = G[MASK]vernment [MASK]ur[MASK]eillance = = 
 
[MASK]Given the history of Nazism 's rise to power in Germany in the 1930s , the present German state has committed itself to taking active steps to prevent the rise of any ideology that threatens the values enshrined in the German constitution . The BfV domestic intelligence service ( Bund[MASK]samt für Verfassungsschutz , or Federal Office f[MASK]r the Pro[MASK]ection of the Constitution ) regards the aims o[MASK] Scientology as running counter to Germany 's free and democratic order , and has been monitoring Scientology since 1997 , as have the Offices for the Protection [MASK]f the Cons[MASK]i[MASK]ution in a number of German Länder . Minister for[MASK]Famil[MASK] Policy Claudia Nolte instituted the surveillance , say[MASK]ng that the church had totali[MASK]arian tendencies and that she wou[MASK]d oppose Scientology with all the means at her disposal[MASK]. 
 The German Church of Scientology has repeatedly challenged the legality of this surveillance in court . In December 2001 , the Administrative Court in Berlin ruled against the Berlin Office for the Protection of the Constitution and ordered it to stop the recruitment and deployment of staff and mem[MASK]ers of the Church of Scientolo[MASK]y Berlin as pa[MASK]d inform[MASK]nts . The court ruled that the use of infor[MASK]ants was disproportiona[MASK]e . In 2003 , the same cou[MASK]t ruled that it was illegal for the Berlin Office for the Protection of the Constitution t[MASK] in[MASK]lude the activities of Scientology in its report , given that the report did not [MASK]ocument any activities that were opposed to the constitution[MASK]. 
 At the fede[MASK]al level , Scientology lost a complaint against continue[MASK] surveillance by the[MASK]BfV in November 2004 . The federal c[MASK]urt based its opinion on [MASK]ts judgment that the aim[MASK] of Scientology , as outlined by L. Ron Hubbard in his writings , were in[MASK]ompatible with the German constitution . Lawyers acting for the Federal Office fo[MASK] the Protection of the Constitution pointed out that Hubbard had[MASK]written that civil rights , for example ,[MASK]should be restricted to Scientologis[MASK]s , and they asserted that the Scientology organization was taking systemati[MASK] steps to infil[MASK]ra[MASK]e society and government institutions in order to prevent [MASK]nti @-@ Scientology legislation . Opposing counsel acting for the Church o[MASK] Sc[MASK]entology had contended that Scientology was non @-@ political , its aims were the liberation of the human being [MASK] and that Hubbard 's [MASK]nstructions were valid only within the Church of Scientolog[MASK] and were subject to interpretation , and at [MASK]ny rate there was no effort to implement these instru[MASK]tions in Germany . The court disagreed and ruled that many sources , some of them not accessib[MASK]e to the[MASK]general public , indicated that the aims of the Church of Scientology did include the abrogation of the principle of equality and other essent[MASK]al human righ[MASK]s . 
 In Saarland ,[MASK]surveillance was stopped by a court as inapprop[MASK]iate in 2005 , because there is n[MASK] local branch of Scientology and few members . As of 6 May 2008 , the Church of Scientology in Germany dropped the legal battle to prevent surveillance of its activities by the BfV after the North Rhine @-@ Westphalia Higher Admini[MASK]t[MASK]ative Court in Münster refused to hear an a[MASK]peal on the ma[MASK]ter . Being suspected of maintaining [MASK] ambitions against [MASK]he free , democratic basic ord[MASK]r " , the Scientology organization added a d[MASK]claration on human rights and democracy to its bylaws . 
 There is at least one example of surveillance of[MASK]Scientology [MASK]y the German intelligence services outside of Germany . In 1[MASK]98 , the Swiss governm[MASK]nt detained an agent of the German government , charging[MASK]him with " [MASK]arrying out illeg[MASK]l [MASK]usiness for a foreign state , working[MASK]for a pol[MASK]tical infor[MASK]ation servi[MASK]e and fal[MASK]ifying identity documents " . The German[MASK]government posted bail for the agent . He was eventually given a 30 @-@ day suspended jail sentence for spying on Scientology , and the German government apologized to Switzerla[MASK]d for the incident . 
 
 =[MASK]= " Sect filters " = = 
 
 A " sect filter " , also known as a " protective declaration[MASK]" ( Schutzerklärung ) , is a document that requires prospective business partners or employees to acknowledge any association wit[MASK] a sect or new religious movement before entering a business or employment contract . Such sect filt[MASK]rs , prima[MASK]ily used to screen out Scientologists , have been drafted by German government agencies for use by businesses . " Sect commissioner 's " offices exist[MASK]in[MASK]Germany as part of regional [MASK]r local government . 
 A work instruction introd[MASK]ced in 1996 requires government staff in the Arbeitsämter – local employ[MASK]ent agencies and s[MASK]cial security [MASK]ffices operated by the Federal Ministry [MASK]f Labour and Social Affairs – to mark companies owned [MASK]y Scientologists with th[MASK] letter " S " . Where compani[MASK]s are suspected of having Scientologist staff , prosp[MASK]ctive employees are alerted to this fact by government staff . Government offi[MASK]ials have publicised the names of individual Scientologists and conducted media campaigns against th[MASK]ir businesses ; some businesspeople have placed advertisements in the press saying they a[MASK]e not Scientologists in order to avoid the associated stigma . 
 Du[MASK] to conce[MASK]ns about possible govern[MASK]ent i[MASK]filtrati[MASK]n by Scientolo[MASK]ists , applicants for civil service positions in Bava[MASK]i[MASK] are required to declare whether or not the[MASK] are Scientologists , and a similar policy has been instituted in Hesse . [MASK]ompanies tendering for government contracts were likewise required to state they are not Scie[MASK]tologists ; in 2001 , this [MASK]equirement was changed , and firms are no[MASK] asked to sign a form stating that " the technology[MASK]of L. Ron Hubbard will not be[MASK]used in executing the contract " . When it [MASK]ecame known that Microso[MASK]t 's Windows 2000 operating [MASK]ystem[MASK]included a disk defragmenter developed by Executive Software International ( a compa[MASK]y headed by a Scientologist ) , this[MASK]caused concern among German governm[MASK]nt [MASK]fficials and clergy[MASK]over data security and the potential for espionage . To assuage the[MASK]e concerns , Microsoft German[MASK] agreed to provide a means to[MASK]disable the utility . Following letters of complaint about discrimination from Scientology lawyers , some American[MASK]companies such as General Electric , IBM and Ford Motor Company instructed their German subsidiaries to cease the use of protective declarations . [MASK] The city @-@ state of Hamburg set up a full @-@ time office dedicat[MASK]d to opposing Scientolo[MASK]y , the[MASK]Scientology Task Force for the Hamburg Interior Authority , under the leadership of[MASK]Ursula Caberta . In 2005 , in a c[MASK]se brought by a Scientologist , the Federal Administrative Cour[MASK] of Germany ordered the city of Ha[MASK]burg to cease recommending the use of protective declarations to its busi[MASK]ess community , finding that the practice infringed religious freedom . In June 2008 , the Ham[MASK]urg Administrative Court fined the city of Hamburg 5 @,@ 000 Euros ([MASK]$ 7 @,@ 000 ) for not complying with cour[MASK] instructions [MASK]anning the use of " sect filters . " Internet links to sampl[MASK] filters to be used by [MASK]usinesses had conti[MASK]ued to remain[MASK]available . Eileen Barker , a p[MASK]ofessor of sociology at the London School of Economics , has noted that " Ger[MASK]any has gon[MASK] further than any other Western European country in restricting the[MASK]civil rights of Scientologists . " The[MASK]Hamburg task force was closed down in August 2010 as a result of budget cuts ; Caberta mov[MASK]d to a position within the Hambu[MASK]g interior authority , where sh[MASK] continues her work on Scientology . 
 Scientologists have been banned from joining major political p[MASK]rties [MASK]n Germany such as the Christian Democratic Union , the Christian Soci[MASK]l Union of Bavaria , the Social Democratic Party of Germany and the Free Democratic Party . Existing Scientologist members of these parties [MASK]ave been " purged " , according to Time Magazine . Scientologists have been prevente[MASK] fr[MASK]m running em[MASK]loyment and au pair agencies in G[MASK]rmany ; Scie[MASK]tologists who were running such agencies had their permi[MASK]s revoked . In 1995 , a sports scientist and fo[MASK]mer member of [MASK]he German [MASK]ational fencing team was dismissed from[MASK][MASK]is job at the German Oly[MASK]pic fenci[MASK]g centre after he stated in an interview that he h[MASK]d enjoyed reading[MASK]books by L. Ron Hubb[MASK]rd and had participated in a course run by a Scientologist mana[MASK]ement and communication consultancy firm . Thoma[MASK] Gottschalk , a German TV prese[MASK]ter , was falsely acc[MASK]sed in 1993 of having ta[MASK]en part in Scientology courses ; Gottschalk responded by [MASK]nnouncing that he had not , and that he would[MASK]he[MASK]cefo[MASK]th cease all contact with a friend who had links to Scientology . In 2007 [MASK] Günther Oet[MASK]inger , the Minister [MASK]-@ President of the German state of Baden @-@ Württemberg , expressed concern that Scientologist John Travolta was to appear on Gottschalk 's programme , and a[MASK]ked the ZDF TV station to consider revoking the invitation ; the ZDF said that uninv[MASK]ting Travolta would cause greater damage , and that Scientology was not going to be discussed in the programme . 
 In 2010 , the Bavarian Administrative Court r[MASK]led that a woman working in a children 's daycare cent[MASK]e , whose employ[MASK]ent had been terminated[MASK]when her ex[MASK]@-@ husband identified her as a Scientologist , should be reinstated . The woman had demonstrated[MASK]to the court 's[MASK]satisfac[MASK][MASK]on that her Scientological beliefs were [MASK]rrelevant to her work . According to the agreement that concluded the case , she prom[MASK]sed n[MASK]t to use Scientology methods in her[MASK]work , and to inform the child[MASK]en 's parents of her membership in Scientology .[MASK]
 
 = = Initiative to ban Sciento[MASK]ogy = = 
 
 In March 2007 , it was reported that G[MASK]rman authorities were increasing their[MASK]efforts to monitor Scientology in response to the opening of a new Scientology headquarters in Berlin[MASK]. On December 7 , [MASK]007 , German federal and state interior ministers [MASK]xpress[MASK]d[MASK]the opin[MASK]on that the Scientology organization w[MASK]s continuing to pursue[MASK]anti @-@ constituti[MASK]nal goals , restricting " essential basic and human rights like the dignity of man or the right to equal treatment " , and asked Germany 's domestic intelligence agencies to collect and evaluate the information req[MASK]ired for a po[MASK]sible judicial inquiry aimed at banning the organization . 
 The move was criticized by German politicians from all sides of the political spectrum , with legal experts and intelligence agencies expressing concern that[MASK]an attempt to ban the [MASK]rganization would li[MASK]ely fail in the courts . Sabine Weber , president of the Church of Scientology in Berlin , called the accusations " unrealistic " and " absurd " and said th[MASK]t the German interior ministers ' evaluation was based on " a few senten[MASK]es out of 500 @,@ 000 pages of Scientological li[MASK]erature " . She added ,[MASK]" I can also find hu[MASK]dreds of quotes in the[MASK]Bible that are totalitarian b[MASK]t that doesn 't mean I will demand t[MASK]e ban of Christianity . " 
 In November 2008 , the gover[MASK]ment [MASK]bandoned its attempts to ba[MASK] Scientology , a[MASK]ter finding insuffici[MASK]nt evidence of illegal or unconstitutional activity . The report [MASK]y the BfV cited k[MASK]o[MASK]ledge gaps and noted several point[MASK] that would make the[MASK]success of any legal undertaking to ban Scientology doubtful . First , the BfV report s[MASK]ated there was no evidence that Scientology c[MASK]uld [MASK]e viewed as a foreign [MASK]rganization ; there were German churches and missions , a German bo[MASK]rd , German bylaws , and no evidence that the organization was " totally remote @-@ controlled " from the United S[MASK]ates . A foreign organization would have been much easier to ban than a German one . The second argument on whic[MASK] those proposing the ban had counted was Sci[MASK]n[MASK]ology 's aggressive opposition to the [MASK]onstitu[MASK]ion . Here , the report found [MASK]hat Scientology '[MASK] behaviou[MASK] gave no grounds to assume that Scientology aggressively sou[MASK]ht [MASK]o attack and overthrow Germany 's free and democratic basic order[MASK]. " Neither its bylaws n[MASK]r any other utterances " supported[MASK]the " conclusion th[MASK]t the organization had[MASK]criminal aims "[MASK]. The[MASK]BfV also considered whether there were gr[MASK]unds to act[MASK]against the Church of Scientology on the basis that they were practising medicine without a licence , b[MASK]t expressed doubts that a court would accept this reaso[MASK]ing . 
 Commenting on the decision to drop the ban attempt , Ehrhart Körting , Berlin[MASK]'s interior minister , said , " This organization pursues goals – through its writings , its conce[MASK]t and its disrespect for minorities – that we cannot tolerate and that we consider in violation of the constitution . But they put very little of this into practice . The appraisal of th[MASK] Government at the moment is that [ Scientology ] is a lousy organization , but it is[MASK]not[MASK]an organ[MASK]za[MASK]ion that[MASK]we have to take a h[MASK]mmer to . [MASK] [MASK]he Church of Sciento[MASK]ogy expressed satisfaction with the decision , describing it as [MASK]he " only one possible " . M[MASK]nitoring of Scientology 's activities by the German intelligence services continues .[MASK]
 In February 2009 , the Berlin Administrative Court ruled that a poster plac[MASK]d by local city authorities on an [MASK]dvertising column next to a bus stop in front[MASK]o[MASK] the Berlin Scientology headquarters , warning passers @-@ by of the potential dangers Scientology activities posed to de[MASK]ocracy and i[MASK]dividual freedom , [MASK]hould be removed[MASK]. The decision was upheld in July 2009 by the Uppe[MASK] Administrative Court[MASK]of Berlin @-@[MASK]Brandenburg which ruled that the poster violated Scientologists ' basic religious rights . 
 
 = = Criticism of Germany 's stance = = 
 
 The U[MASK]ited States media , while generally reporting negatively on Scientology in domestic news , has taken an at least partially su[MASK]portive stanc[MASK] towards Sci[MASK]ntology in relation to Germany . Richard Co[MASK]en for exa[MASK]ple , wr[MASK]ting in the Washington Post , said[MASK]in 1996 : " Scientology might be one weird religion , but the German [MASK]eaction to it is weirder still – not to mention[MASK]disturbing . " Alan Cowe[MASK]l , writing in the New York Times , wrote [MASK]n 1997 that the German response to [MASK]cientology – motivated by officia[MASK]s ' fear that [MASK]cientology " was a totalitarian[MASK]movement growing , like the Nazi part[MASK] , from inconsequential beginn[MASK]ngs " – was itsel[MASK] redolent of " the Nazi era[MASK]'s au[MASK]horit[MASK]rianism " . 
 The U.S. Department of[MASK]State [MASK]as repeatedly claimed that Germany 's a[MASK]tions constitute g[MASK]vernment and societal discrimination against minority religious groups and ex[MASK]ressed it[MASK] concerns over the violation[MASK]of Sciento[MASK]o[MASK]ists ' i[MASK][MASK]ividual rights posed by sect filters . The U.S. Department of State began to include the issue of Scientology[MASK]in Germany in it[MASK] annual human rights reports after [MASK]h[MASK] 1993 agreement between the Church of Scientology and the U.S. Internal Revenue Service , through which Scientol[MASK]gy gained the status of a tax @-@ exempt religion in[MASK]the United States . That decision also marked the beginning of more intense lobbying efforts [MASK]y the Church of Scientology in Washington , using paid lobbyists . The[MASK]State Department 's 1996 human rights report on Ger[MASK]any , released in January 1997 , warned that artists and businesses with Scientology connections " may face boycotts and discrimination , sometime[MASK] with government approval . " Past targets of such actions had included Scientologist actors Tom Cruise and John Travolta , as well as jazz pianist Chic[MASK] Corea . 
 Also in [MASK]anuary 1997 , [MASK]n open let[MASK]er[MASK]to then[MASK]@-@ Chancellor Helmut Kohl appeare[MASK] , published as a newspap[MASK]r advertisement in th[MASK] International Her[MASK]ld Tribune , dra[MASK]ing parallels betwe[MASK]n the " organized oppression [MASK] of Scientologists in Germany and Nazi policies espoused by Germany [MASK]n the 1930s . The letter was[MASK]conceived and paid for by Hollywood lawyer Bertram Fields , whose clie[MASK]ts have incl[MASK]ded Tom Cruise and John Travolta , a[MASK]d was[MASK]si[MASK]ned by 34 prominent figures in the U.S. entertainment industry , including the top executives of MGM , Warner Bros. , Paramount , Universal and Sony Picture[MASK] Entertainment as well as acto[MASK]s Dustin Hoffman and Goldie Hawn , director Oliver Ston[MASK] , writers Mario[MASK]Puzo and Gore Vidal and talk [MASK]-@ show host Larry King . It echoe[MASK][MASK]simil[MASK]r p[MASK]rallels drawn by the Church of Scientology itself , which until then had received scant notice , and wa[MASK] followed by lobbying efforts of Scientology cel[MASK]brities in Washington . 
 U.S. Department of State spokesman Nicholas Burns rejected the Nazi comparisons in the open letter as " outr[MASK]geous " and [MASK]istanced [MASK]he U.S. gov[MASK]rnment from Nazi co[MASK]parisons made by the Church of Scientology , sayi[MASK]g , " We have criticized the Germans on this , but we aren 't going to support the Scientologists ' terror tactics against the German government . " Chancellor Kohl , commentin[MASK] on the letter , said that those who signed it " don 't know a thing about Germany and don 't want to know . " G[MASK]rm[MASK]n officials arg[MASK]ed that " the whole fuss was cranked up by the Scientologists to achieve what we won 't give them : tax @-@ exempt status as a religion . This is intimidation , pure and sim[MASK]le . " Officials explained that precisely because of Germany 's Nazi past , Germany took[MASK]a determined stance against all " radic[MASK]l cults and sects , in[MASK]luding right @-@ wi[MASK]g Nazi g[MASK]oups " , and not just against Scientology . Kohl 's Christian Democratic Union party denounced the letter as " absurd " and cited[MASK]German court rulings stating[MASK]that Scientology had primarily econ[MASK]mic goals and could legitimately be referred to using phrases such as a " contemptuous cartel of oppression " . 
 In February 1997 , a[MASK]United States immigration court judg[MASK] granted asylum to a[MASK]German Scientologist who claimed she would be subject to religious persecution in [MASK]er homeland . In April 1997 , John Travolta met perso[MASK]ally with U.S. President Bill Clinton at a conference i[MASK] Phil[MASK]delphia .[MASK]Travolta later said Clinton assured him that he would " really love to help " with the " issue over in Germany with Scientology " . According to Travolta , Clinton recalled that " he had a roommate years ago [MASK]ho was a Scientologist and had really liked [MASK]im , and respected his views on it " , stating [MASK]hat Scientologists " were given an unfair hand in [ Germany ] and that he wanted to fix it " . In Sep[MASK]ember 1997 , John Travol[MASK]a , Chick Corea and f[MASK]llow[MASK]Scientologist Isaac Hayes were heard[MASK]by [MASK]he Commission on Security and Cooperation in [MASK]urope ( CSCE , also known as the H[MASK]lsinki Commission ) , voicing their complaints about the treatment of Sc[MASK]entologists in [MASK]erman[MASK] , and had a briefing with Unit[MASK]d States National Security Advisor Sandy Berger , whom Clinton had assigned to be [MASK] the administration 's Scientology point person " . The German ambas[MASK]ador responded with a letter to the CSCE stating that the German government had come to t[MASK]e conclusion that Scien[MASK]ology 's " pseudo @-@ s[MASK]ientific courses can[MASK]seriously jeopardize individuals ' mental and physical health and that it exploits its members " , adding that " membership can lead to psychological and physical dependency , to financial ruin , and even to suicide . In addition , there are indicat[MASK]ons that Scientology poses a threat to G[MASK]rma[MASK]y 's basic polit[MASK]cal principles . " 
 A United Nations report [MASK]n April 1998 raised concerns about the violation of individual rights posed by se[MASK]t filters . However , it rejected the compa[MASK]ison of the treatment of Scientologists with that of Jews during t[MASK]e Nazi era . 
 In 2000 , the German Stern ma[MASK]azine published the results of its investigation of the asylum[MASK]case . It asserted that several rej[MASK]ction letters which the woman had submitted as part of her asylum application – ostensibly from potential employers who [MASK]ere[MASK]rejecting her because she was a Scientologist – had in fact been written by fellow Scientologists at her request and that o[MASK] Scientology '[MASK] Offic[MASK] of Special Affairs , and that she was in personal financial trouble and about to go on trial for tax evasion at the time she applied for asylum . On a 2000 visit[MASK]to Clearwater , Florida , Ursula Caberta of the Scientology Task Force for the Hamburg Interior[MASK]Authority likewise alleged that the asylum case had been part of an " orchestrated [MASK]ffort " by[MASK]Scientology und[MASK]rtaken " for political [MASK]ain " , and " a spectacular abuse of the U.S[MASK] system " . German expatriate Scientologists resident in Clearwater , in turn , accused Caberta of stoking a " hate campaign " in Germany that had " ruined the lives and for[MASK]unes of scores of Scientologists " and mainta[MASK]ned that S[MASK]ientologists had not " exaggerated their plight for political gai[MASK] in the United States . "[MASK]Mark Rathbun , a ( former [MASK] top Church of Scientolog[MASK] official ,[MASK]said that although S[MASK]ientology had not orchestrated the case , " there would have been nothing improper if it h[MASK]d . " 
 In 2003 , Joachim Güntner , writing in the Swiss Neue Zürcher Zeitung , noted that Gerhard B[MASK]sier , [MASK] German Christian theologian , director[MASK]of the Hannah Arendt Insti[MASK]ute for Research into Totalitarianism in Dresden and recipient [MASK]f an honorary doctorate from Lund University , Sweden , for his champi[MASK]ning o[MASK] religious freedom , had be[MASK]n pressured [MASK]o forego publication of[MASK]his scientific study of Scientology after having found himself the subject of widespread criticism in the [MASK]e[MASK]man media for advocating a more tolerant attitude t[MASK]wards Scientology . Güntner concluded that " alarmism " had " triumphed " over [MASK]cience and noted a[MASK] apparent lack of conf[MASK]dence in Germany 's [MASK]bility to engage in open public discourse on the matter . 
 The U.S. Department of State 's 2012 report o[MASK] religious freedom in Germany , published in 2013 , stated that " The status of the Church of Scientology remains in limbo . The Constitutional Court and various courts at [MASK]he state level have not [MASK]xplicitly ruled [MASK]hat Scientology is a religion . Government agencies [MASK]t the fed[MASK]ral and state level have rules and procedures that discriminate against[MASK]Scientology as [MASK] [MASK]roup and [MASK]gainst its members . Four of the major political parties ( the Christian Democratic Union , Christian Social Union , Social Democratic Party , and Free Democra[MASK]ic Party ) ban Scientologists from party membership . [ ... ] Scientologists reported instances of gover[MASK][MASK]ental discrimination . Although courts at the stat[MASK] and federal[MASK]le[MASK]el cond[MASK]mned the improper use of so @-@ called ' sect filters ' to blacklis[MASK] and boycott Scientologists , they remained i[MASK] use in the public sector . ' Sect filters ' typically asked potential new employees to confirm in writing that they had no contact with Scientology , did n[MASK]t p[MASK]rticipate in its training cou[MASK]ses , an[MASK] rejected[MASK][MASK]ts doctrines . [ ... ] Catholic and Protestant churches cont[MASK]nued to oppose Scientology publically [ sic ] , although press reporting and public reactions to Scientology decreased . Several private organizations issued warnings about after @-@ school study programs run by Scientologists . "

 [MASK] Japanese [MASK]attl[MASK]ship Asahi = 
 
 Asahi ( 朝日 , Asahi ) was a pre @-@ dreadnought battlesh[MASK]p built for the Imperial Japanese Navy ( IJN ) in the late 1890s . As Japan lacked the industrial capacity to build such warships itself , t[MASK]e ship was designed [MASK]nd built[MASK]in the United Kingdom . Shortly after her arrival in Japan , she became flagship of the Standing Fleet ,[MASK]the IJN 's primary combat fleet . She participated in every major naval batt[MASK]e of th[MASK] Russo @-@ Japanese War of 1904 – 05 and was l[MASK]ghtly damaged during the Battle of the Yellow Sea and the Battle of Tsushima . Asahi sa[MASK] no combat during World [MASK]ar I , although the ship participa[MASK]ed in the Si[MASK]erian Intervention in 1918 [MASK] 
[MASK]Reclassified as a coastal defence ship in 1921 , Asahi was disarmed two years l[MASK]ter to meet the terms of the Washington Naval Treaty , after which she served as a tra[MASK]ning and s[MASK]bma[MASK][MASK]ne depot ship . She was modified into a submarine sal[MASK]age and rescue ship before being placed in reserve in 1928 . Asahi was recommissioned in late 1937 ,[MASK]after the start of the Second Sino @-@ Japane[MASK]e War [MASK] and [MASK]sed to transp[MASK]rt Japanese troops . In 1938 , she was conv[MASK]rted into a [MASK]epair ship and based first at Japanese @-@ occupied Sh[MASK]nghai , China[MASK], and then Cam Ranh Bay [MASK][MASK]Frenc[MASK] Indochina , from late [MASK]938 to 1941 . The ship was transferred to occupied Singapore in early 1942 to repair a damaged light cruiser and ordered to return home[MASK]in May . She was sunk en route by the American submarine USS Salmon , although most of her cre[MASK] survived . 
 
 = [MASK] Background = = 
 
 Comb[MASK][MASK] experience in the First Sino @-@ Japan[MASK]se War of 1894 – 95 convinced the Imperial Japanese Navy of weaknesses in the Jeune École naval philosop[MASK]y , which emphasi[MASK][MASK]d torpedo boats and commerce raiding to offset expensive heavily armoured ships . Therefore , Japan promulgated a ten @-@ year nava[MASK] buil[MASK] @-@ up in early 1896 , to modernize and expand its fleet in preparation fo[MASK] further confrontation[MASK] , with [MASK]he construction of six battleships and six armoured cruisers at its core . These ships were paid for from the £ 30 @,@ 000[MASK]@,[MASK] 000 indemnity [MASK]aid by China after losing the First Sino @-@ Japa[MASK]ese War . As with the earlier Fuji and Shikishima classes , Japan lacked the technology and capability to construct[MASK]its own [MASK]attleships , and turned again to the Unite[MASK] Kingdom for the fo[MASK]r remaining battl[MASK]ships of the programme .[MASK][MASK]sahi , the fifth Japanese battlesh[MASK]p to be built in Britain , was ordered from the Clydebank Engineering[MASK]& Ship[MASK]uilding Company shipyard in Clydebank , Scotland in the 1897 annual naval programme . 
 
 = = Design and description = = 
 
 Asahi 's design was a modified version of the Formidable @-@ class battleships of the Royal N[MASK]vy , with two additional 6 @-@ inch ( 152 mm ) guns . The ship h[MASK]d an overa[MASK]l length of 425 feet 3 inches ( 12[MASK] @.@ 6 m ) , a beam of 75 f[MASK]et ( 22 @.@ 9 m ) , and a normal drau[MASK]ht of 27 feet 3 inches ( 8 @.@ [MASK] m ) . She di[MASK]placed 15 @,@ 200 long tons ( 15 @,@ 400 t ) at normal load . Asahi had a complete double bottom with 55 wa[MASK]ertight compartme[MASK]ts . Her hull was also subdivided into 223 wat[MASK]rtight compartments . She was f[MASK]tted as a flagship [MASK]nd her crew numbered about 773 officers and enlisted men , including the admiral 's staff . 
 The ship was powered by two vertic[MASK]l[MASK]triple @-@ expansion steam engines built by Humphrys , Tennant , each driving one pr[MASK]peller , using steam generated[MASK]by 25 Belleville boilers at a working pr[MASK]ssure of 17 @.@ 03 bar ( 1 @,@ 703 kPa [MASK] 247 psi ) . T[MASK]e engines were[MASK]rated at 15 @,@ 000 indicated horsepower ( 11 @,@ 000 kW ) , using forced draught , and designed to reach a[MASK]top speed of 18 knots ( 33 km / h ; 21 mph [MASK] although Asahi reached 18 @.@ 3 [MASK]nots ( 33 @.@ 9 km / h [MASK] [MASK]1 @.@ 1 mph ) from 16 @,@ 335[MASK][MASK]ndicated horsepower ( 12 @,@ 181 kW ) during her sea trials on 23 March 1900 . S[MASK]e carried a maximum of 2 @,@ 000 long tons ( 2 @,@ 032 t ) of coal w[MASK]ich allowed her to steam for 9 @,@ 000 nautical miles ( 17 @,@ 000 km ; 10 @,@ 000 mi ) at a speed of 10 knots ( 19 km / h ; 12 m[MASK]h ) . The ship was fitted with three steam @-@ drive[MASK] 4 @.@ 8 @-@ kilowatt ( 6 @.@ [MASK] hp ) dynamos . 
 Asahi 's main battery consisted of the same four Els[MASK]ick Ordnance Company 40 @-@ calibre twelve @-@ inch guns used in a[MASK]l of Japan 's[MASK]pr[MASK]ceding battleships . They were mounted in twin @-@ gun turrets fore and aft of the superstructure . The[MASK]hydraulically powered mountings allowed the guns to be loaded at all angles of trave[MASK]se , at a fixed elevation of + 13 @.@ 5 ° . Each mount could trave[MASK]se a tot[MASK]l of 240 degrees . They fired 850 @-[MASK] pound ( 386 kg ) projecti[MASK]es at a muzzle velocity of 2 @,@ 400 ft [MASK] s ( 730 m /[MASK]s ) . 
 The ship 's secondary armament consisted of fourteen 45 @-@ calibre 6 @-[MASK] inch ( 152 mm ) quick @-@ firing ( QF ) guns mounted in casemates . Eight of these guns[MASK]were positioned on the main deck and the other six guns were placed above th[MASK]m in the superstructure . They fired [MASK]00 @-@ pound ( 45 kg ) shells a[MASK] a muzzle velocity of 2 @,@ 300 ft / s ( 700 m / s ) . Protection against torpedo @-@ boat attacks was provided[MASK]by twenty QF 12 @-@ pounder 12 cwt guns . The 12 @-@ pounders fired 3 @-@ inch ( 76 mm ) , 12 @.@ 5 @-@ pound ( 5 @.@ 7 kg ) projectiles at a muzzle velocity of 2 @,@ 359 ft / s ( 719 m / s ) . Lighter guns consisted[MASK]of eight 47 @[MASK]@ millimetre ( 1 @.@ 9 in ) three @-@ pounder Hotchkiss guns and four 47 @-@ millimetre 2 @.@ 5[MASK]@-@ pounder Hotchkiss guns . The former were mounted in the superstructure and the latter in t[MASK]e fighting tops . The three @-@ pounder gun fired 3 @.@ 19 @[MASK]@ pound [MASK] 1 @.@ 45 kg ) projectiles at a m[MASK]zzle velocity of 1 @,@ 927 ft / [MASK] ( 587 m / s ) , while the[MASK]2 @.@[MASK]5 @-@ pounder f[MASK]red 2 @.@ 5 @[MASK]@ pound ( 1 @.@ 1 kg ) shells at a muzzle [MASK]elocity of 1 @,@ 420 ft / s ( 430 m / s[MASK]) . The ship was also equipped with four submerged 18 @-[MASK] inch torpedo tubes , two on each broadside . 
 The waterline main belt of Asahi consisted of Harvey armour 8 feet [MASK] 2 @.@ 44 m ) hig[MASK] , of which 3 feet [MASK] inc[MASK]es ( 1 @.@ 11 m ) was above th[MASK] waterline at normal load , and had a maximum thickness of 9 inches ( 229 mm ) for the middle 224 feet ( 68 @.@ 28 m ) of the ship . It was only 4 inch[MASK]s ( 102 mm ) thick at the ends of the ship and was surmounted by a six @-@ inch strake o[MASK] armour that ran between the barbettes . The barbettes were 14 inches ( 356 mm ) thick [MASK] but only 10 inches ( [MASK]54 mm ) behind the upper armour strake . The barb[MASK]tte hoods were protected by 10 inches of armour [MASK]n their face while their sides were[MASK]6 inches thick and the roof was 1 @.@ 5 inches ( 38 mm ) t[MASK]ick . Diagonal bulkhe[MASK]ds connecting the barbette[MASK] to the side armour were 12 [MASK] 14 inches thic[MASK] , but only 6 inches thick at the lower deck [MASK]evel . The frontal armour of the casemates protecting the secondary armament was also 6 inches thick with the rear protected by 2 @-@ inch ( 51 mm [MASK] armour plates . T[MASK]e flat portion of the deck armour was 2 @.@ 5 inches ( 64 mm ) thick and 4 inches ( 102 mm ) thick where it [MASK]loped down[MASK]to the sides of the ship . The conning tower was prote[MASK]ted by 14 inches[MASK]of armour . 
 Asahi[MASK],[MASK]like all t[MASK]e other Japanese battleships of the time , was fitted with four[MASK]Barr and[MASK]Stroud FA3 co[MASK]ncidence rangefinders tha[MASK] had an effective range of 8 @,@ 000 yards ([MASK]7 @,@ 300 m ) . The ships [MASK]ere also fitted with 24 @-@ power magnification telescopic gunsight[MASK] .[MASK]
 
 = = Construction and career = = 
 
 Asahi[MASK], meaning " rising sun " , a poetic name for J[MASK]p[MASK]n from a stanza of waka poetry , was laid down on 1 August 1898 in Clydebank , Scotland , by the Clydebank Engineering & Sh[MASK]pbuilding Co. and completed by John Brown & [MASK]ompany , which purchased the f[MASK]rm before Asahi was completed . She was launched on 13 March 1899 and completed on 31 July 1900 . Her completion was delayed by a[MASK]out [MASK]hree months w[MASK]en her bottom p[MASK]ating requ[MASK]r[MASK]d repairs after running aground off Southsea following sea trials . The ship departed England , after repairs in Portsmouth , on the day of her completion , and arrived at Yokosu[MASK]a , Japan , on 23 October 1900 . Asahi[MASK]became flagship of the Standing Fleet [MASK]n 22 May [MASK]901 and was assig[MASK]ed to the 1s[MASK] Battleship Divis[MASK]on of the 1st Fleet when the Combined Fleet was re @-@ formed on 28 December 1903 . 
 At the [MASK]tart of the Russo @-@ Japanese War , Asahi , commanded by Captain Hikohachi Yamada , wa[MASK] assigned to t[MASK]e 1st Division of the 1st Fleet . Sh[MASK] participated in the Battle of Port Arthur on 9 February 1904 , when Vice Admiral Tō[MASK]ō Heihachirō led the 1st Fleet in an attack on the Russian ships o[MASK] the Pacific Squadron anchored just outside Port Arthur . Tōgō had expected the surprise night attack by his destroyers to be much more successful[MASK]than it was , anticipating that the Russians would be badly disorganized and weakened ,[MASK]but they had recover[MASK]d from their surprise and were ready for his attack . The Japanese ships were sp[MASK]tted by the protected cruiser Boyarin , which was patrolling offshore and alerted the Russian defences . Tōgō chose to attack the Russian coastal defences with his [MASK]ain armament and engage the ships with his secondary guns . Split[MASK]ing his fire proved to be a poor decision as the Japanes[MASK] e[MASK]ght @-@ inch ( 203 mm ) and six[MASK]@-@ i[MASK]ch guns inflict[MASK]d little damage on the Russian sh[MASK]ps , which concentrated all their fire on the Japanese ships with some effect . Although many ships on both sides were hit , Russian casualties numbered only 17 , while the Japanese suffered 60 killed and wounded before Tōgō disengaged . Asahi wa[MASK] not hit during the engagement . 
 The ship participated in the action of 13 April , when Tōgō successf[MASK]lly lured out a portion of the Pacific Squadron , including Vice Admiral Stepan Makarov 's flagship , the battleship Petropavlovsk . When Makarov sp[MASK]tted the f[MASK]ve battleships of the 1st Division , he turned back [MASK]or Port Arthur and Petropavlovsk struck a minefi[MASK]ld laid by the Japanese the previous ni[MASK]ht .[MASK]The Russian battleship sank in less than two minutes after one of her magazines exploded , and Makarov was one of th[MASK] 677 killed . Emboldened by his success , Tōgō resumed long @-@ ra[MASK]ge bombardment mis[MASK]ions[MASK], [MASK]rompting the Russians to lay more minefields , which sank two Japanese b[MASK]ttleships the following month .[MASK]
 During the Battle of the Yellow Sea on 10 August , Asahi , now commanded by Captain Tsunaakira Nomoto , was second in line of the column of Japa[MASK]ese battleships , behind [MASK]ikasa , and [MASK]as one of the p[MASK]imary targets of the Russi[MASK]n ships . She was onl[MASK] hit by a single 12 @-@ inch shell [MASK]hat [MASK]o[MASK]nded two crewmen . Both guns in h[MASK]r[MASK]aft 12 @-@ inch gu[MASK] turr[MASK]t , however , were disabled by shell[MASK] [MASK]hat deto[MASK]ated prematurely in their barrels[MASK]. In turn she concentrated most of her fire upon the battleships Poltava and Tsesarevich although both ships w[MASK]re only lightly[MASK][MASK]amaged by the Japanese shells , which generally failed to penetrate any armour and detona[MASK]e[MASK] on impact[MASK]. The ship made the critical hits of the battle , however , when two[MASK]of her 12 @-@ inch shells struck the bridge of Tsesarevich , killing the Russian squadron comm[MASK]nder , Vice Admiral Wilgelm Vitgeft , two of his staff officers and the shi[MASK] [MASK]s quartermaster . Th[MASK] ship 's wheel was jammed to port by w[MASK]eckage and then slowed to a halt which [MASK]hrew the rest of the Russian ships into tota[MASK] confusion . Th[MASK] second @-@ in @-@ command , Rear Admiral Prince Pavel[MASK]Ukhtomsky , eventually gained control of the remainde[MASK] of the squadron and headed back to Port Arthur . Slightly more than two months later , on 26 October , Asahi struck a mine off Port Arthur while on blockade duty . Severely damaged , she was under repair at Sasebo Naval Arsenal [MASK]rom November 1904 to April 1905 . Russian naval forces in th[MASK] Far East had been destroyed o[MASK] neutra[MASK]ized by th[MASK]s time and the Russians were forced to transfer ships fro[MASK] the Baltic Fleet that did not arrive until May . 
 
 = = = Battle of Tsushima = = = 
 [MASK] At the Battle of Tsushima on 27 May 1905 , Asahi again followed the battleship Mikasa into combat , this time against the Second and Third Pacific Squadrons . Mikasa opened fire at the battleship Knyaz Suvorov , [MASK]he Russian flagship , at 14 : 10 , and was joined b[MASK] Asahi and the armoured cruiser Azuma shortly afterwards . Within an hour the Japanese ships had started a serious fire aboard the Russian ship [MASK] badly[MASK]wounded the fleet commander , Vice Admiral [MASK]inovy Rozhestven[MASK]ky , knocked [MASK]ut her rear 12 @-@ inch gun turret , and jammed Knyaz Suvorov 's steering so [MASK]hat s[MASK]e[MASK]fell out of f[MASK]rmation . Th[MASK] Russian ships were concentrating their fi[MASK]e on Mikasa during the early[MASK]part of the battle and Asahi was no[MASK] damaged during this time . Tōgō was able to cross the T of the Russ[MASK]an squadrons . Knyaz Suvorov 's steering was later repaired , but she blundered [MASK]etween the Japanese and Russian fleets several times l[MASK]ter [MASK]n the battle and was heavily damaged . Asahi seems to h[MASK]ve mostly engaged [MASK]he battleships Borodino and Oryol in the late stages of the battle , although Fuji fired the shots that cause[MASK] the[MASK]Borodino 's magazines to explode and sink her . Asahi fired more twelve @-@ inch shells , 142 , than any other ship during the ba[MASK]tle . In total , the ship was hit six times during the battle , but none of them damaged her significantly . While Asahi [MASK]s casualties are not precisely known , the Japanese only lost 110 men killed and 590 wounded to all ca[MASK]ses during the battle . The ba[MASK]tle was a[MASK]total Japanese victory with five Russian battleships captured and incorporated[MASK]into the IJN . 
 Captain W. C. Pakenham , the Royal Navy 's official militar[MASK] observer under the Anglo @-@ Japanese Alliance , took n[MASK]tes of the battle 's progress from a deck chair on Asahi 's exposed quarterdeck . His report confirmed the superiority of Japan[MASK]se training and tactics and p[MASK]bl[MASK]cized [MASK]he[MASK]victory [MASK]n the West . 
 
 = = = Later career [MASK] = = 
 
[MASK]In 1908 , Asahi was part of the Japanese fleet that escorted the American Grea[MASK] White[MASK]Fleet through Japanese waters during its round @-@ the @-@ globe voyage[MASK]. The ship was assigned[MASK]to the 1st Fleet in 1908 and 1910 – 11 . Asahi became a gunnery [MASK]raining ship in 1914 , an[MASK] was re @-@ armed in 1917 with Japanese gun[MASK] replacing her or[MASK]ginal British @-@ made guns . The same yea[MASK] , she was assigned to the 5th Division of the 3r[MASK] Fleet . In 1918 , Asahi became flagship of her division and participated in the Japanese intervention in the Russian Civil War . She escorted tr[MASK]op convoys to the [MASK]ussian Far East and was guard ship at Kamchatka from January to August 1918 . As[MASK]hi was reclassified as a first @-@ class coastal defence ship on 1 Se[MASK]tember 1921 , and began disarmament in 1922 at Yokosuka in compliance with the terms of the Washington Naval Treaty . She was reclassified as a training and submarine depot s[MASK]ip on 1 April 192[MASK] and her disarmament was completed in July of that same year . Her displacement dropped to [MASK]1 @,@ 441 long t[MASK]ns ( 11 @,@ 62[MASK] t ) with the [MASK]oss of her armour and guns[MASK], and her s[MASK]eed was limited to 12 knots ( 22 km / h ; 14 mph ) . 
 The navy decided to convert Asahi i[MASK]to a submarine salvage ship a[MASK]d she began the first stage of her conversion w[MASK]th the installation of specialized salvage equipment from February to August 1925 . From 1926 to October 1927 , the ship 's 25 Bellev[MASK]l[MASK]e boilers were replaced with four Kanpon Typ[MASK] RO boilers at Kure Naval Arsenal . One of her two funnels was also rem[MASK]ved , and two large lift[MASK]ng frames were installe[MASK] as par[MASK] of the second stage of her conversion . The ship [MASK]onducted experiments in submarine re[MASK]cue using the old German[MASK]submarine 0 @-@ 1 ( ex @-@ U @-@ 125 ) . In May 1928 , Asahi was fitted with a 62 @-@ foot @-@ 4 @-@ inch ( 19 m ) compressed @-@ air aircraft catapult [MASK]n her forecastle and successfully launched an E2N1 Ty[MASK]e 15 seaplane . After repeated accidents , the cata[MASK]ult was replaced by one powered by gunpowder . On the completion of tes[MASK]ing in 1928 , Asahi was placed in reserve . 
 Reclassified as a repair ship on 16 August 1937 , Asa[MASK]i was taken out of reserve in November , after the Marco Polo Bridge Incident that started the Second Sino @-@ Japa[MASK]ese War[MASK], and was used as a tr[MASK]nsport to land troops in an amphibious l[MASK]nding at Hangzhou Bay . Afterwards s[MASK]e began conversion at Kure , Japan , into a repair ship ; this was completed on[MASK]18 December 1938 [MASK] Asah[MASK] was fit[MASK]ed with a dummy w[MASK]oden[MASK]main battery fore and aft to resemble an old[MASK]battleship after her arrival in Shanghai on 29 December . In May 1939 she was modified to act as a t[MASK]rpedo depot ship and carried out patrols be[MASK]ween 29 May and 7 November 1[MASK]40 . She was [MASK]ransferred to Camranh Bay , French Indochina , on 15 November 1940 and later transpo[MASK]ted the 11th Base Unit from Kure to Camranh Bay 19 Nov[MASK]mber – 7 December 1941 . 
 From 13 March 1942 , Asahi was stationed at Singapore , and [MASK]n April her crew performed repairs on the light cruiser Naka , which had been torpedoed by t[MASK]e submarine USS Seawolf off Christma[MASK] Island . Departing Singapore for Ku[MASK]e on 22 May , esc[MASK]rted by the subchaser CH @-@ 9 , Asahi was sighted by the submarine USS Salmon on the night of 25 / 26 May 1942 , 100 miles ( 160 km ) southeast of Cape Padaran , Indo[MASK][MASK]ina . Of Salmon 's four torpedoes , [MASK]wo hit the ship in her port central boiler room and aft spaces . At 01 : 03 , moments after being hit , Asahi [MASK]ank at 10 ° 00 ′ N 110 ° 00 ′ E. Sixteen men were killed in the attack ; the ship 's captain and 582 crewmen were rescued[MASK]by CH @-@ 9 . 
 
[MASK]
 = Training Day ( The Office ) = 
 
 " Training D[MASK]y " is the twentieth episode of[MASK]the seventh season of the American comedy television series Th[MASK] Office and the shows 146th episode overall . It origin[MASK]lly[MASK]aired on NBC on April 14 , [MASK]011 . The episode was writt[MASK]n by Daniel Chun and directed by Paul Lieberstein . This episode marks the first ap[MASK]earance of Deangelo Vickers ( Will Ferrell ) in the series . 
 The serie[MASK] depicts the everyday lives of office employees in the Scranton , Pennsylvania branch of t[MASK]e ficti[MASK]nal Dunder Mifflin Paper Company . In the episode , Michael Scott 's ( St[MASK]v[MASK] Carell ) replacement appears in the office , to start receiving training from Michael . The new manager , Deangelo Vicker[MASK] ( Will Ferrell ) , has everyone[MASK]hoping to make good first impressions : Andy Bernard ( Ed H[MASK]lms ) finds himself awkward[MASK]y typecast while Jim Halpert ( Jo[MASK]n Krasinski ) and Pam Halpert ( Jenna Fischer ) worry [MASK]hat [MASK]hey 've come [MASK]n t[MASK]o [MASK]trong . Only Dwigh[MASK] Schrute ( Rainn Wilson ) is apath[MASK]tic [MASK]bout the new leader . 
 " Training Day " received mixed reviews from television critics , with many commenting on Ferrell 's appearance . The episode was also viewed by 4 @.@[MASK]16 million viewers and received a 4 @.@ 0 / 11 percent rating [MASK]mong adults between the ages of 18 and 49 , ranking first in its timeslot . The episode ultimately ranked as the highest @-@ rated NBC series of the night . 
 
 = = Synopsis = [MASK] 
 
 Michael is waiting in a hotel bar for his replacement Deangelo Vickers ( Will Ferrell ) to show up . While waiting , he meets a man at t[MASK]e bar and the[MASK]two instantly hi[MASK] it off . When Michael calls Vickers to see where he is , it is revealed that the man Michael has been talking to is actually Deangelo , though it takes [MASK]he two some time to actuall[MASK] realize this . 
 Deangelo comes to the branch the next day , and most o[MASK] the staff is eager to make a good first impression . Kevin wears his toupee , Jim and Pam believe they have started off well by mentioning their baby , and Deangelo designates Andy as the office " funny guy " when he reveal[MASK] that he carries name tags around to avoid situations like the one Deangelo and Michael were in . Meanwhil[MASK] , Dwight[MASK]is not pleased that he was not [MASK]elected to replace Michael , believing that Michael put in a good[MASK]recommendation for him . Michael becomes disturbe[MASK] , however [MASK] when Deangelo wan[MASK]s to make some changes , such as how Erin answe[MASK]s the phone . 
 While Deangelo gets annoyed with Jim and Pam , he loves the antics of Andy , who has resorted to[MASK]physical comedy when his jokes fall fl[MASK]t , getting to the point where he pour[MASK] hot coffee on his pants and ( at Deangelo 's urging ) eats soap ; Andy tells the camera with dazed [MASK]adness that " this is my life now " . Deangelo 's popularity with the employees causes Michael to get jealous t[MASK] th[MASK] po[MASK]nt where he passes out peanut butter sandwiches , despite Deangelo '[MASK] peanut allergy . Deangelo then a[MASK]sembles t[MASK]e staff in the " multipurpose room " , including Dwight , who learned from Gabe that Michael did not put in a [MASK]ecommendation a[MASK]d thus snubs Michael . Jim quietly tells Michael that he chose to resign his job and needs to come to terms with both that choice and the fact that life is goin[MASK] to go on at th[MASK] office . Deangelo then step[MASK] out of his meeting and asks Michael for advice for how to run the meeting , saying that [MASK]e 's a good manager and Dunder M[MASK]fflin won 't be the same without him . The two make up with a reverse hug , Deangel[MASK] telling him that he should s[MASK]art enjoying his retirement . Michael returns to his office while Deangelo conducts his meeting in the confere[MASK][MASK]e room . 
 In ano[MASK]her effort to impress [MASK]eangelo , Jim and Pam bring in Cece , to[MASK]which Deangelo reacts positively .[MASK]While they celebrate getting back on his good[MASK]side , Deangelo reveals to the c[MASK]mera that he is in fact indifferent to Cece and was just being polite . 
 
 = = Production = = 
 
 The epi[MASK]ode was written by co @-@ executive producer Daniel Chun , his fourth writing cre[MASK]it of the series . It was directed by[MASK]then @-@ showrunner Paul Lieberstein , his sixth[MASK]direc[MASK]ing credit of the series[MASK]. The episode marked the first appearance of Wil[MASK] Ferrell 's four @-@ episode arc on the series and is also o[MASK]e of series star[MASK], Carell 's last episodes as [MASK] regular on the series . Ferrell signed on to appear in Steve Ca[MASK]ell 's final t[MASK]ree episodes , and the first episode without Carell , " The Inner Cir[MASK]le " , to make [MASK]arell 's [MASK]ransit[MASK]on easier . Carell had decided to leave the series , because " I just think it 's time ... I want [MASK]o fulfill my contract . When I first signed on I had a contract for seven seasons , and this coming year is[MASK]my seventh . I[MASK]just thought it was time for my character to g[MASK] " . Ferrell initially called the producers and offered to appear in Carell 's last season , because h[MASK] 's[MASK]" a fan and wanted to commemorate Carell ’ s swan song " . He had previously starred alongside Carell , in the 2004 film , Anchorman : The Legend of Ron Burgundy . 
 The Season Seven DVD contains [MASK] number of d[MASK]lete[MASK] scenes from this episode . The cut scenes include a sequence in which Michael and D[MASK]angelo discuss cancer jokes and the 2010 film [MASK]egamind — an animated film that[MASK]featured the voice of Ferrell — while drinking vodka , shots of Michael and Deangelo [MASK]iscussing their enjoyment for coffee , and Dwight attempting to [MASK]ppease his new boss . 
 
 = = Reception = = 
 
 
 = = = Ratings = = [MASK] 
 
 In its original American broadcast , " Traini[MASK]g Day [MASK] was viewed by an estimated 7 @.@ 871 millio[MASK] viewers and received a 4[MASK]@.@ 0[MASK]rating / [MASK]1 % share among adults between the ages of 18 [MASK]nd 49 . This means that it was seen by 4 @.@ 0 % of all 18- to 49 @-@ year @-@ olds , and 11 % of a[MASK]l 18- to 49 @-@ year @-@ olds watching televisi[MASK]n at t[MASK]e time of the broadcast . This marked a rise in[MASK]the ratings from the[MASK][MASK]revious episode , " Garage Sale " , [MASK]hi[MASK]h can be attributed to Ferre[MASK][MASK] 's guest appearance . The episod[MASK] ranked first in its time[MASK]lot , beatin[MASK] the Fox crime drama[MASK]Bones , which scored a 3 @.@ 5 / 10 percent relating in the 18 @-[MASK] 49 demographic ; a rerun of the ABC medical drama Grey 's[MASK]Anatomy and a rerun of the CB[MASK] crime dra[MASK]a CSI : Crime Scene Investigation . 
 
 = = = Reviews = = =

IGN writer Cindy White wrote that Deangelo w[MASK]s not given a proper introduction a[MASK]d that he wasn 't dist[MASK]nguished from Michael 's character . Sh[MASK] [MASK]lso went on to criticize Jim ,[MASK]Pam and Dwight 's reaction to Deangelo[MASK]as th[MASK] new manager , particular that of Jim[MASK]and Pam , writing that " it 's becoming painfully ob[MASK]ious that the longtime writers don 't kn[MASK]w what to do with them anymore " . However , she concluded that[MASK]the episode continued the seventh season 's improvement over the sixth , and that it showed potential for future episodes of the season . She ultimately gave the episode a 7 @.@ 5 out of 10 rating , de[MASK]oting[MASK]a " good " episode . The A.V. Club reviewer Myles McNutt [MASK]raised Mic[MASK]ael 's reactions to[MASK]the office easily ignoring him for Deangelo , ca[MASK]ling[MASK]the final shot of him walking into[MASK]his office alone " quite effective " , and that Dwight 's reaction to not being suggested to be Michael 's replacement made it more " meaningful "[MASK]. Despite this , he continu[MASK]d by saying that the series was not " sophisticate[MASK] [MASK] enough to use this pl[MASK]tline effectively and criticized the writing for the cast , which made th[MASK]m look " s[MASK]upid " for " cheap humor " and a " enormously shallow laughter " [MASK] He ultimately gave the episode a[MASK]" C + " . Alan Sepinwall , a columnist for HitFix , complimented the chemi[MASK]try between Ferrell and C[MASK]rell , but criticized the storyline which eventually came down to Michael " being petulant a[MASK]out not being the center of attention every minute of every day " , negativel[MASK] comparing it to " Viewing Party " . D[MASK]spite this , he not[MASK]d that Ferrell 's presenc[MASK] did involve several[MASK]f[MASK]nny moments . 
 Bonnie Stiernberg , f[MASK]r Paste , was more positive , [MASK]riting [MASK]hat she preferred the use of comedy , following[MASK]the emotiona[MASK] episode , " G[MASK]rage Sale " . She ultim[MASK]tely gave it an 8 @.@ 7 out of 10 . Will Ferrell 's perfor[MASK]ance was especially noted by critics .
