 = J. C. W[MASK] Beckham = 
 
 John Crepps Wickliffe Beckham ( August 5 , 1869 – January[MASK]9 , 1940 ) was[MASK]th[MASK] 35th Governor of Kentuc[MASK]y and a United States Senator f[MASK]om Kentucky . He was the state[MASK]'s first popularly el[MASK]cted senator fol[MASK]owing passage of the Seventeenth Amendment . 
 Descended [MASK]rom a prominent politi[MASK]al family , Beckham was chos[MASK]n as Democrat William Goebel 's running mate in the gubernatorial election of 1899 despite the fact that he was not yet of legal age to serve as governor if called to do so . Goebel lost the [MASK]lection to Republican William S. Taylor , but the Kent[MASK]cky General Assembly disputed the election results . During the political wrangling that followed , an unknown as[MASK]assin shot Goebel . A day later the General Assembly invalid[MASK]ted enough votes to give the election to Goebel , who was sworn into offi[MASK]e on his[MASK]deathbed . Taylor claimed the election had been stolen by the Democratic majority in the General Assembly and a legal fight ensu[MASK]d between him and Beckham over the governorship . Beckham ultimately prevail[MASK]d and Taylor fled the state . 
 Following his term as go[MASK]ernor , Beckham made a bid to become a U.S. Senator . His stance in favor of prohibition cost him the votes o[MASK] four legislators in his own party and the seat went to Republi[MASK]an William O. Bradley . Six years later Beckham secured the seat by popular election , but he lost his re @-@ election bid largely because of his pro @-@ temperance views and his opposition to wo[MASK]en 's su[MASK]frage . Though he continued to play an active role in state politics for another two decades , he never returne[MASK] to elected office , failing i[MASK] his gubernatorial bid in 192[MASK] and his senatorial campaign in 1936 . He died in Louisv[MASK]lle on January 9 , 19[MASK]0 . 
 
 = = Early life[MASK]= = 
 
 J. C. W. Beckham was born at Wickland , ne[MASK]r Bardstown in Nelson County , Kent[MASK]cky , son of William Netherton and Julia Tevis ( Wickliffe ) Beckham . His maternal grandfather , Charles A. Wickliffe , was governor of Kentucky from 1839 to 1840 and se[MASK]ved as postmaster g[MASK]neral in the administration [MASK]f John Tyler . His uncle , Robert C. Wickliffe[MASK], served as governor of Louisiana . 
 Beckham obtained his early edu[MASK]ation at Roseland Academy in Bardstown . In 1881 he served as a page in the Kentucky House of Represen[MASK]atives at the age of 12 . Later , he enrolled at Central University ([MASK]now [MASK]astern Kentu[MASK]ky University ) in[MASK]Ri[MASK]hmond , Kentucky but was forced to quit school at the age of 17 to support[MASK]his widowed mother . Two years later , [MASK]e became principal of Bardstown public schools , serving from 1888 to 1893 . Concurrently , he studied law at the U[MASK]iv[MASK]rsity of Kentucky , where he earn[MASK]d his law [MASK]egree in 1889 . He was admitted to the bar , and commenced practice in Bardstown in 1893 . He[MASK]also served as president of the Young Democrats ' Club of Nelson County . 
 
 = = Political career = =[MASK]
 
 Beckham 's political career began in 1894 when he was elected without opposition to[MASK]t[MASK]e Kentucky House of Representatives . He served [MASK]our consecutive terms and was S[MASK]eaker of the House in 18[MASK]8 , his final year in the House . He also served as a delegate to every Democratic National Convention from 1900 to 1920 . 
 
 = = = Governor of Kentucky = = = 
 
 Democrat William Goebel chose Beckham as his running mate in the Kentucky gubernatorial election of 1899 . Goebel was hesitant about the selection becau[MASK]e he wanted someone who could deliver the vote[MASK]of his home county in the general election , and Beckham 's native Nelson County was already committed[MASK]to a rival candidate . But friends of Goebel assured him[MASK]that Beckham would be[MASK]loyal to Goebel 's reform agenda , whereas [MASK][MASK]e two other men Goebel was considering as running mates would " stack the Senate committees against him . " Beckham[MASK]was not yet 30 , the minimum age to serve as go[MASK]ernor , at the time of his selection . 
 Goebel lost a close election to Republican William S. Taylor . When the Genera[MASK] Assembly 's session opened on January 2 , 1900 [MASK] the [MASK]lection results were immediately challenged . With Democrats in control of[MASK]both houses of the A[MASK]sembly , the results see[MASK]ed sure t[MASK] be reversed . The Assembly was still deliberating on January 30 , 1900 , when Goebel was[MASK]shot by an unknown assailant as he entered the state capitol building . The following[MASK]day , as Goebel was being treated for his wounds at a local hotel , [MASK]he General Assembly invalidate[MASK] enough votes to g[MASK]ve h[MASK]m the electio[MASK] . He was sworn [MASK]nto office from his bed the same day . Three days [MASK]ater Goebel died , never having risen from the bed . 
 Legislative chaos ensued as Taylor refused to acknowledge the As[MASK]embly 's decision and vacate the governors[MASK]ip . The Repub[MASK]icans in the legisl[MASK]ture[MASK]obeyed Taylor 's[MASK]orders , while the Democrats ignored Taylor and followed the orders of their lead[MASK]rship . Finally , on February[MASK]21 , 1900 , Taylor and Beckham agreed to let the court[MASK] settle the m[MASK]tter . The case first went before the Louisville Circuit Court , which found in favor of Beckham . Republicans appealed to the Kentucky Court of Appeals , at that time the court of last resort in[MASK]the sta[MASK]e . On April 6 , 1900 , the Court of Appeals upheld the ruling of the lower court . Taylor appealed to the Supreme[MASK]Court of the United States , which declined to hear the[MASK]case on May 21 , [MASK]900 .[MASK]Taylor 's only supporter on the court was Kentuckian John Marshall Harlan . 
 Following the Supreme Court ruling , Taylor fled to Indianapolis , Indiana , fearing he would be implicated in Goebel 's assassi[MASK]atio[MASK] . Beckham became acting governor , but be[MASK]ause of the unusual [MASK]ircumstances surrounding the election , a special election w[MASK]s held November 6 , 1900 , to determine who would complete Goe[MASK]e[MASK] 's unexpired term . Beckham ( now of age ) won the election over Republica[MASK] John W. Yerkes by fewer than 4 @,@ 000 votes . Shortly following the special election , Beckham married Jean Raphael Fuqua of Owensboro . The couple had two sons . 
 As governor Beckham sought to unite his [MASK]arty and the state . As part of[MASK]this effor[MASK] he supported changes to the blatantly partisan [MASK]oebel Election[MASK]Law , authored by his late running mate while the latter [MASK]as a[MASK]member of the General Assembly . He s[MASK]ressed[MASK]non @-@ controversial issues such as improvements to roads and the stat[MASK] 's educationa[MASK] system . He recommended passage of a law to set uniform school textbook pr[MASK]ces , [MASK] reform both he and Goebel had advocated during the gubernatorial campaign . However , his passive leadership ensured that the General Assembly did little[MASK]to address his agenda . T[MASK]e only major pieces of legislation passed during Beckham 's term were a tax increase that [MASK]dded a half million dollars to the st[MASK]te 's revenue and a child labor law that for[MASK]ade c[MASK]ildren under 14 to work without their parents ' consent . 
 
 = = = Second term = = = 
 
 Although the Kentucky Constitution prohibited governors from serving consecutive terms , Beckham announced[MASK]he would seek a full [MASK]erm as governor[MASK]in 1903 . His candidacy was challenged in court , but the court ruled Beckham had not served a full first term and was eligib[MASK]e to run . Due to his record of reconciliation and supporting non @-@ controversial reforms , h[MASK] had no significant opposition in winning his party 's nominati[MASK]n . His record also deprived his Republican opponent , Morris B. Bel[MASK]nap , of any significant campaign issue in the general election . Beckham defeated Belknap and three minor candidates . 
 In his message to the[MASK]legislature in 1904 [MASK] Beckham again raise[MASK] the issue of a uniform s[MASK]hool textbook law , which had not passed during his first term . The law was one o[MASK] few significant reforms that passed during the 1904 sess[MASK]on . During the session funds were approved for building a new capitol building and a memorial to the late[MASK]Governor Goebel . 
 In March 1904 , Beckham sign[MASK]d the D[MASK]y [MASK]a[MASK] mandating racial segregation of all schools in Kentucky . Berea College , a p[MASK]iv[MASK]te college in ea[MASK]tern Kentucky that had been integrated since the 1850s , immediately filed suit to challenge the law . The sub[MASK]tance of the law was[MASK]upheld in the circuit c[MASK]urt and the Kentucky Court of Appeals . Berea appealed to the Supreme Court , and in 1908 the c[MASK]urt handed down an 8 – [MASK] decision aga[MASK]nst the colle[MASK]e . Only John Marshall[MASK]Harlan dissented . 
 Near the clo[MASK]e of the 1904 ses[MASK]ion , legislators app[MASK]oved the creation of Beckham Co[MASK]nty from parts of Carter , Elliott , and Lewis counties . Olive Hill [MASK]as made the county seat . Soon the county 's existe[MASK]ce was challen[MASK]ed in court on grounds that it fel[MASK] short of the 400 square miles ( 1 @,@ 000 km2 ) required by the state c[MASK]nstitution and that it reduced the counties it was carved from to less than 4[MASK]0 square [MASK]iles ( 1 @,@ 000 km2 ) .[MASK]Carter Cou[MASK]ty joined the lawsuit , claiming the border of Beckham County passed[MASK]too close[MASK]to Grayson , the seat of Carter County , and V[MASK]nceburg , the seat of Lewis County . The state constitution forbade county borders to pass within 10 miles ( 16 km ) of a county seat . On April 29 , 1904 , the Ke[MASK]tucky Cou[MASK]t of Appeals found in favor of the plaintiffs and dissolved Beckham Co[MASK]nty . 
 During the 1906 legislative ses[MASK]ion , Beckham urged investigation and pr[MASK][MASK]ecution of corrupt insurance companies , following th[MASK] lead of New York attorney[MASK]C[MASK]a[MASK]les Evans Hughes . In particular , he recommend[MASK]d reducing the practice of deferred dividends , which allowed the insurance companies to keep large sto[MASK]es of cash on @-@ hand for illegal pu[MASK]poses . He further advocated th[MASK]t i[MASK]surance[MASK]companies d[MASK]ing business in the state be required to invest a certain percentage of the[MASK]r earnings in Kentucky ,[MASK]bolstering the its economy an[MASK] providing policyholders some protection against f[MASK]aud . 
 Beckham [MASK]efused to send troops into the western part of the state to [MASK]uell the ongoing Black Patch Tobac[MASK]o Wars . He cited constitutional reasons for his refu[MASK]al , but more probably his reasons were political – the Democra[MASK]s were dominant in this region and h[MASK] didn 't want to challenge his o[MASK]n [MASK]arty . By collecting some old Civil War debts from the federal government , Beckham virtually eliminated the state 's debt [MASK] Encouraged by the state 's improved finances , the General Assembly voted to expand[MASK][MASK]wo of the state 's normal schools , Wester[MASK] [MASK]tate Teachers College in Bowling Green ( later Western Ke[MASK]tucky Uni[MASK]ersity ) and Eastern State Teacher[MASK] College in Richmond ( later part of Eastern Kentucky University ) . 
 With a s[MASK]ccessful legislative session behind him , B[MASK]ckham made a bold political move in June 1906 : he orchestrated an effort to set the Democratic gubernatorial and senatorial primaries in November – a ful[MASK] year b[MASK]fore the gubernatorial election and two years before the senatorial elect[MASK]on . Beckham wanted the Senate seat , and moving the primary up[MASK]two year[MASK] would allow him to secure his party 's nomination while he was still governor . It also allowed him to use his influence as governor to swa[MASK] the party 's cho[MASK]ce of his potential suc[MASK]essor as governor . State Auditor Samuel Wilb[MASK]r Hager was Beckham 's c[MASK]oice for governor and easily won the ea[MASK]ly prima[MASK]y over challenger N.B. Hays . Former governor James B. McCreary challenged Beckham for th[MASK] senatorial nomination , but Beckham won by more than 11 [MASK],@ 000 votes . 
 
 = = = U.S. Sen[MASK]tor = = = 
 
 Beckham 's term as governor ended December 10 , 1907 . In January 1908 he faced the legislature as the Democratic nominee for a seat in the U.S. Senate by virtue of the primar[MASK] held two years earlier [MASK] The Republicans [MASK]ominated fo[MASK]mer governor William O. Bra[MASK]ley . On the first ballot Beckham secured 66 of the needed 69 votes ; Bradley received 64 votes . Seven Democrats had not voted for Beckham . Over the next six weeks , 25 more votes were taken with ne[MASK]ther man secu[MASK]in[MASK] a majority , even though William Jennings Bryan , the Dem[MASK]cratic nominee for president , campaigned for Be[MASK]kham . S[MASK]me Democrats pressured Beckham to withdraw[MASK]and allow a more palatable Demo[MASK]rat to run , but he refu[MASK]ed . On the 29th ballot , taken near the e[MASK]d of February 1908 , Bradley finally secure[MASK] a major[MASK]ty after four Democrats crossed party lines to vote for him . 
 Beckham 's ardent support of prohibition likely cost him the election . His[MASK]position put him at odds with Henry[MASK]Watterson , editor of the powerful Louisville Cou[MASK]ier @-@ Journal . As governor Beckham had crossed t[MASK]e liquor interests and the political machiner[MASK] in Lo[MASK][MASK]sville . When the Kentucky Court of Appeals invalidated the results of Louisville 's municipal elections due to interference by the city 's " whiskey ring [MASK] in May 1907 , Beckham app[MASK]inted Robert Worth Bingham , a young lawyer and fellow prohibitionist , as interim mayor until elections could be held in November . Bingham e[MASK]iminated graft[MASK]ng in the police department ,[MASK]closed gambling houses and enforced blue laws closing saloons on Sunday . Following this , the whiskey ring announced Beckham had [MASK]orfeited the support of Louisville 's legislators . In the senatorial election in 1908 , three of the four Democrats who voted against Beckham were from Louisville .[MASK]Following his defeat , [MASK]eckham returned to his law[MASK]practice . 
 Six years later Beckh[MASK]m again attempted to win [MASK]he Senate seat . Due to the passage of the Seventeenth Amendment , the senator would not be elected by the legislature , but by popular vote [MASK] In the Democratic primary [MASK]eckham defeated Augustus O. Stanley , a 12 @-@ year veteran congressm[MASK]n . The Republican nominee was form[MASK]r [MASK][MASK]vernor Augustus E. Willson . Bolstered by his support of President Woodrow Wilson , Beckham won the el[MASK]ction by 32 @,@ 0[MASK]0 votes . 
 Beckham served as chairman of the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Labor from 1915 to 1917 and on the Senate Committee on Military Affa[MASK]rs . In the latter position he was influential in securing two large military trainin[MASK] posts for[MASK]Kentucky , Camp Zachary Taylor and Fort Knox . Though Camp Zachary Taylor was abandoned after World War I , Fort[MASK]Knox bec[MASK]me the home of the United States Bullion Depository . When the United States entered World War I , Beckham continued to back President Wilson and supported the League of [MASK]ations . 
 True to his prohibitionist stance , B[MASK]ckham supported passage of the Eighteenth Amendment forbidding the import and sale of alcohol in the United Sta[MASK]es . The amendment was ratified and became effective in January [MASK]920 . Believing women s[MASK]ould be protected from i[MASK]volvement in politics , Beckh[MASK]m opposed the Nineteenth Amendment , which granted women 's suffrage . The amendment fai[MASK]ed on February 10 , 1919 , but passed on June 4 , 1919 . Beckham[MASK]voted against it both times . 
 The Democrats renominat[MASK]d Beckham without opposition in 1920 . His opponent in the general election was Republ[MASK]can Richard P. Ernst . Prohibitio[MASK] had destroyed the distilling industry and the salo[MASK]n business in the sta[MASK]e , and in ar[MASK]as where these industries were prominent Beckham received more than 5 @,@ 000 fewer votes than Democratic presidenti[MASK]l nominee James M. Cox . [MASK]e was also hurt by the women 's vote and[MASK]by his support of President Wilson , who had lost popularity since Beckham 's election in 1914 . Ernst won the election by fewer than 5 @,@ 000 vote[MASK] , winning the race with 50 @.@ 3[MASK]percent of the vote to Be[MASK]kham 's 49 @.@ 7 percent . During his single term in the Senate Beckham served alongsid[MASK] three ot[MASK]er U.S. Senators from Kentucky : Ollie M. James , George[MASK]B. Martin and Augustus O. Stanley . 
 
 = = [MASK]ater life and death = = 
 
 Follo[MASK]ing his te[MASK]m in the Sen[MASK]te , Beckham resumed his legal practice in Louisville . He so[MASK]ght another term as go[MASK]ernor in 1927 . This time he ha[MASK] the support of th[MASK] Louisville Courier @[MASK]@ Journal , which had been purc[MASK]ased by his ally , Robert W. Bingham . He was opposed by a powerful political machine known as the Jockey Club , whose main interest was securing legislation to allow parimutuel betting at the state [MASK]s horse [MASK]acetracks . 
 The[MASK]Jockey Club ran a candidate in both parties ' prima[MASK]y elections . In the Democratic primary Beckham defeated the [MASK]lub 's relatively obscure candidate , Robert T. Crowe . Flem D. Sampson , the Club 's nomin[MASK]e in the Republican primary , won his party 's nomination . [MASK]n the general election Beckham could not secure[MASK]the[MASK]support of Democratic governor William J. Fields , who had been elected with the help of the Jockey Club . Despite the Democrats w[MASK]nning every other contest on the ballot , including the r[MASK]ce for l[MASK]eutenant governor , Beckham lo[MASK]t to Sampson by[MASK]more than 32 @,@ 0[MASK]0 votes . It was esti[MASK]ated that the Club spent over $ 500 @,@ 00[MASK] to defeat him . 
[MASK]Beckham was expected to be the Democrats ' nominee for governor in 1935 , but the death of his son in la[MASK]e 1934 left him distraught and his wife opposed to another campaign . The Democrats turned to A. B. " Happy " Chandler of [MASK]enderson , who won the election . Beckham supporte[MASK] Chandler 's b[MASK]d , and in return Chandler appointed him to the K[MASK]ntucky Public Servi[MASK]e Commission i[MASK] 1936 . Beckham also served on t[MASK]e D[MASK]partment of Business Regulations Commission and chaired the State Government Reorganiz[MASK]tion [MASK]ommission . [MASK] Beckham attempted [MASK]o retu[MASK]n to the Senate in[MASK]1936 . The head of the Jockey Club , James B. Brown , had lost his fortune and influence when his banking empire crashed in 1930 . In 1933 Beckham 's ally , Robert Bingham , had been appointed ambassador to the Court of St. James 's , increasing his prominen[MASK]e and influence . Beckham als[MASK] en[MASK]oyed the support of the United Mine Workers and Louisville mayor Neville Miller . The race[MASK]was compli[MASK]ated , though , by the entry of John Y. Brown , a Democ[MASK]at who was a U.S. Representative and former Speaker o[MASK] the Kentucky House of Representatives . He had agreed to support Chandler 's bid for th[MASK] g[MASK]vernorship in exchange for Chandler 's support in his run for the Senate . How[MASK]ver , Chandler threw his support to Beckham , and while Brown[MASK]was not able to win the seat without the support [MASK]f Bingham and Chandler , he did garner 85 @,@ 000 votes , most of them at Beckham 's expense . Democratic incumbent M. M. Logan retained the seat by 2 @,@ 385 votes . 
 Beckham died in Louisville on Janua[MASK]y 9 , 1940 , and was buried in Frankfor[MASK] Cemetery in Frankfort , Kentucky . Beckham County , Oklahom[MASK] , was named in [MASK]is honor at the sugges[MASK]ion of a Kentuckian [MASK]h[MASK] was serving as a delegate to Oklahoma 's constitutional convention in 1907 . Wickland , his [MASK]irthplace , wa[MASK] added to the National Register of Historic Places on F[MASK]bruary 16 , 1973 . 
 
 
 = 1888 – 89 New Zealand Native football team = 
 
 The 1888 – 89 New Zealand Native football team was a New Zealand rugby union team that toured Britain , Ireland , Australia and New Zealand in 1888 and 1889 . It mostly comprised play[MASK]rs of Māori ancestry , and al[MASK]o included some[MASK]Pākehā ( white New Zealanders ) . A wholly private endeavour , the tour was not under the auspices of any [MASK]fficial rugby authority ; it was or[MASK]anised by New Zealand international pla[MASK]er Joseph Warbrick , promoted[MASK]by civil servant Thomas Eyton , and managed by James Scott , a publican . The Natives were the first New Zealand team to perf[MASK]rm a haka , and also the first to wear all black . They played 107 rugby matches during the tour , as well as [MASK] small number of Victorian Rules football and association [MASK]ootbal[MASK] mat[MASK]hes in Australia . Having made a significant impact on the dev[MASK]lopment of New Zealand rugby , the Natives were inducted into the International Rugby[MASK]Board Hall of Fame in 2008 . 
 After a preliminary tour of New Zealand in 1888 , the side travelled to England via [MASK]elbourne an[MASK] Suez . The Māori players initially provo[MASK]ed curiosity due to their race , but the British press subsequently expressed some surprise that the side was not as[MASK]" Māori " as they had expected[MASK]. Playing their first match , on 3 [MASK]ctober against Surr[MASK]y , the team was subjected to a taxing match schedule , and frequently played[MASK]three matches per week . Their early m[MASK]tches includ[MASK]d a 9 – 0 loss to Middlesex , but their form improved in November , when t[MASK]ey won 10 of their 13 matches .[MASK]The team played its first international match on 1 December [MASK] against Ireland , and won 13 – 4 . This was followed by a win over one of the s[MASK]rongest English county teams , Yorkshire , and a 5 [MASK] 0 defeat against the Wales national team . By January 188[MASK] the Natives had played 36 matches in less than three months , winning 2[MASK] of them ; they had spent most of their time in the north of England , where the playing strength[MASK]was strongest a[MASK]d the crowds largest and most profi[MASK]able . 
 In a return match on 19 Ja[MASK]uary , Yorkshire fielded a stronger side than in the first match and inflicted one of the Natives ' heaviest losses , a[MASK]16 – 4 defeat . The tea[MASK] then went undefeated until 16[MASK]Fe[MASK]ruary , when they faced England . Of[MASK]icials [MASK]f the strictly amateur Rugby Football Union ( RFU ) had be[MASK]ome incre[MASK]singly concerned at the behaviour of the N[MASK]w Zealanders , rega[MASK]ding them as unsportsmanlike , and tensions reached a nadi[MASK] in the afterma[MASK]h of the England international , during which the RFU secretary [MASK]eorge Rowland Hill ,[MASK]refereeing the game , award[MASK]d a number of controversial tries to En[MASK]land , prompting [MASK]hree of the Natives to temporarily leave the fi[MASK]ld in pro[MASK]est ; England eventually won 7 – 0 .[MASK]The Natives apologised afterwards for[MASK]their behaviour , but the dam[MASK]ge was not[MASK]repa[MASK]red . The New Zealanders left England wit[MASK]out an of[MASK]icial send @-@ off , and travelled to Australia where they toured Victoria , New South Wales and Queensland . [MASK]hey then returned to New [MASK]ealand , where they displayed a level of combination not seen in their home country before . They went 31 games undefeated before losing their final match , on 24 August 1889 , 7 – 2 to Auckland . 
 The Natives ' final record in rugby matches was 78 wins , 6 draws and 23 losses . They introduced a number of tactical inno[MASK]ations to New Zealand[MASK]rugby on their return home , and their tour contributed to the formation of the New Zealand Rugby Football Union in 1[MASK]92 . Seventeen of the team 's 26 players went on to play provincially in New Zealand , and two , Thomas Elliso[MASK] and D[MASK]vid Gage , subsequently captained the New Zealand national rugby team . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 The idea for asse[MASK]bling [MASK] team of Māori footballers to tour Britain was conceived by Joseph Warbric[MASK] , a rugby player who had toured with t[MASK]e first New Zealand national team in 1884 . He initially proposed a team of Māori or part @-@ Māori to play the touring British side in 1888 ; this developed into a ventu[MASK]e to have a Māori te[MASK]m tour Britain if a preliminary tour[MASK]of New Zealand were successful . Hearing of Warbrick 's [MASK]lans , civil servant Thomas Eyton contacted hi[MASK] to offer help manag[MASK]ng the tour , which W[MASK]r[MASK]rick accepted . When James Scott , a publican , subsequen[MASK]ly joined the partnership , the thre[MASK] men decided that War[MASK]rick would be the team 's captain , Scott its manager and Eyton its promot[MASK]r . 
 Warbrick started assembling a team for the tour in ear[MASK]y 1888 . He had difficulti[MASK]s assembling a squad due to player availabi[MASK]ity , and failed to secure the talented Jack Taiaroa due to his university commitm[MASK]nts . Some Māori players who initially agreed to play later pulled out wh[MASK]n the eligibility criteria were relaxed to allow squad members wh[MASK] were only part @-@ Māori . Twenty Māori or part @-@ Māori players joined the squad ; five Pākehā ( white New Zealand [MASK] players were added after [MASK]he team lost to Auckland . Due to the inclusion of these Pākehā players the team was renamed from the " New Zealand Maori " to the " [MASK]ew Zealand Native Football Representatives " . The final squad comprised 26 players ( including Warbrick ) ; of these at least five were full @-@ blooded Māori , while fourteen had a Māori mother and a Pākehā father . The parentage of some of the players is unknown . 
 The team toured New Zealand [MASK]e[MASK]or[MASK] departing overseas , playing [MASK]gain[MASK]t[MASK]Ha[MASK]ke 's Bay [MASK] Auckl[MASK]nd , Nelson , Wellington , Canterbury , South Canterbury , a[MASK]d Otago . The first[MASK]game was contested against Hawke 's Bay in Napier on 23 June 188[MASK] . They played nine g[MASK]mes in their pr[MASK]liminary tour of New Zea[MASK]and , and won seven of them . T[MASK]eir last New Zealand match before departure , against Otago played in Dunedin on 31 July 1888 , [MASK]as won by one try to nil . 
 The team sailed for Australia from Dunedin , leaving on 1 August 1888 . In Melbourne , Scott recruited Jack Lawlor to train the pl[MASK]yers in Vic[MASK]orian [MASK]ules footb[MASK]ll in Britain as preparation for possible [MASK]ictorian [MASK]ules matches on their r[MASK]tur[MASK] to Australia . The team[MASK]played two rugby matches against the Melbourne Rugby U[MASK]ion team , winning the first and drawing the second , before continuing to Britai[MASK] via Suez . They arrived in London on 27 September 1888 . 
 
 = =[MASK]Arrival in England and early matches = = 
 
 The team were met in Britain by local rugby administrators , includin[MASK] an official of[MASK]England 's Rugby Football Union ( RFU ) . The first match of the tour was against Surrey[MASK], where the team became the[MASK]first New Zealand side to perform a haka , and also the first to wear an all black uniform . That the team was predominantly Māori provoked curiosity from the[MASK]British press – at the time , most Britons had not seen non @-@ white people – but [MASK]here was some surprise that the team [MASK]e[MASK]e [MASK]ot as " Māori " as had been expected . " They are not unlike Europeans , " a Scottish reporter wrote in November 1888 ; " that is their resemblance is great when one remember[MASK] that they were a savage tribe no further back than a generation " . The Surrey match , which was refereed by the RFU secretary Georg[MASK] Rowland H[MASK]ll , was won 4 – 1 by the Natives after they scored two tries . 
 The Natives next defeated[MASK]both Northampto[MASK]shire and Kent , before defeats by Moseley and Burto[MASK] @-@ on @-@ Trent . Both defeats were unexpected , and in the Moseley match , injuries played a part – the tourists played most of the match at least two men down , as replacements were then not allowed . The team recov[MASK]red to[MASK]win their next game , against Midlands Counties in Birmingham . Their next fixtur[MASK] was against Middlesex in a match not open to the public , and hosted by the Earl of Sheffield at Sheffield Park , Uckfield . T[MASK]e Middlesex side contained a number of international players , including Arthur Gould . Middlesex won easily , with the Natives play characterised by poor tackling . The final score was 9 – 0 , with three tries[MASK]conc[MASK]ded by the New Zealanders . Prior to the match both si[MASK]es had enjoyed lunch with wine – an indulgence the Natives were not used to . A report[MASK][MASK]n the Auckland Star had this to say of the game : 
 The New Zealanders expected to meet a mere exhibition 15 of scratch players [MASK] whereas Mr Rowland Hill had carefully coll[MASK]cted the best possible team available .[MASK]Such " passing " as the Home men displayed the Maoris frankly admit they have never previously witnessed . Said McCausland whilst we were on the pl[MASK]tfor[MASK] waiting for the London train , " I think [MASK]hey would have just beaten us[MASK], even if we had been in good form . " 
 Following the match against Middlesex , the team tr[MASK]velled to the north , where the strongest En[MASK][MASK]ish rugby teams were base[MASK] . Yorkshire and Lancashire dominated the county championship until many of the[MASK]r respective member clubs split from[MASK]the RFU in 1895 over the issue of " broken t[MASK]me " payments . The New Zealanders lost to Hull 1 – 0 , defeated Dewsbury , then lost to Wak[MASK]field . After their first draw of the tour ( against Northumberland Coun[MASK]y ) they defeated Stockton @-@ on @-@ Tees and Tynemouth . Joe Warbrick appeared in the match against Tynemouth , but[MASK]aggravated the foot injury that [MASK]ad kept him out of the side until that point . These victories were followed by a 13 – 4 defeat to Halifa[MASK] on[MASK]1[MASK] November . Th[MASK] team then won seven matches in a row , including one against Hawick RFC , their only Scottish opposition of the tour . The last two matches that month were a loss[MASK]to Swinton and a 9 – 0 victory over Liverpool and District . The team had played thirteen fixtu[MASK]es during N[MASK]vembe[MASK] and won ten of them . By this point , the[MASK]team was beset by injuries – of the fifteen players that played against Westmorl[MASK]nd C[MASK]unt[MASK] on 24 November , five had injuries . The squad comprised only 26 players , and the tourists were oft[MASK]n struggling to[MASK]field a side . Nevertheless , their heavy schedule continued ; on 30 November 1888 they left for Dublin , where a match had been organised against the Ireland national team . [MASK] 
 = = Ireland , further En[MASK]lish matches , and Wales = = 
 
 The Ireland fixture was played at Lansdowne Road , Dublin , on 1 December 1888 . Both teams had a number of leading playe[MASK]s out injured – the Irish were fo[MASK]ced to make four changes to their o[MASK]iginal se[MASK]ection . Ireland led 3 – 0 at [MASK]alf @-@ time after sc[MASK]ring a converted tr[MASK] , but the Natives improve[MASK] considerably in the second @[MASK]@ half , scoring four tries . Patrick Keogh scored the first two tries , and[MASK]his play was praised by the local press . The third try scored was by Thomas[MASK]Ellison after a counter @-@ attack by Geo[MASK]ge Williams . The try was not converted , but the strong finish from the New Zealanders gave the visitors a 13 – 4 victory . The Irish press were surprised by the loss and strongly criticised their team , but Ireland did go on to defeat Wales two tries to nil [MASK]n the 1889 Home Nations Championship . Followin[MASK] their defeat of Ireland[MASK], the Natives played Trinity College and then North of Ireland . The match against Trinity College[MASK]was drawn 4 – 4 , and despite Ke[MASK]gh not playing , the Native side played much [MASK]etter than thei[MASK] previous fixture . The team then travelled to Belfast , where they defeated North of Irelan[MASK] 2 – 0 on 5 December ; scoring two tries to nil . 
 A[MASK]ter returning to England , the Natives [MASK]aced Lancashire in Manchester , where they lost 1 – 0 . Two days later they drew with Batley Bulldogs , despite their opposition scoring five[MASK]tries . Their next[MASK]match was against Yorkshire , who were one of the strongest counties in the coun[MASK]ry , and went on [MASK]o win the inaugura[MASK] County Championship that season . Yorkshire f[MASK]elded a weakened team , a[MASK]d we[MASK]e [MASK]ubsequently defeated 10 – 6 by the Natives , who sc[MASK]red six tries . After a further two victories , the team travelled to Wales , where they lost 3 – 0 to Llanelli , before facing Wa[MASK]es on 22 D[MASK]cember . 
 At the start of the match the home crowd were fairly hostile towards the Welsh team due to fans of both Swansea and Llanelli feeling sli[MASK]hted by the lack of selecti[MASK]n of [MASK]heir players . Four teams dominated Welsh international selection at the time , and out of the 15 @-@ [MASK]an team only William Towers and William Bowen of Swan[MASK]ea and Dan Griffiths of Llane[MASK]li had bee[MASK] selected [MASK] The match was played in Swansea , and the lack of local players may have contributed to a poor crowd , with ga[MASK]e receipts [MASK]f only £ 120 recorded . The crowd '[MASK] [MASK]ostility impacted on the players , and debutant Norman Big[MASK]s[MASK]was " palpably nervous " at the start of the mat[MASK]h . Biggs , aged 18 years and 49 days , became the youngest[MASK]Welsh international p[MASK]ayer – a record he held until the debut[MASK]of Tom Prydie in 2010 . D[MASK]spite the heckles aimed primarily at Biggs , Charlie Arthur and George Thomas , the Welsh team produced an excellent effort , especially from the forwards . 
 Towers scored the first Welsh try , whi[MASK]h was converted by Jim Webb . The Natives replied with a sp[MASK]rited run by Ellison , but he fai[MASK]ed to break through the Welsh defence .[MASK]The tourists trailed even further after George Thomas scored a breaka[MASK]ay try frrm the half @-@ way line , w[MASK]ich went some way to silence the heckles f[MASK]om the crow[MASK] . Webb , playing in out of p[MASK]sition [MASK]t full @-@ back , missed the conversion [MASK]nd then failed at a l[MASK]ng distance goal from a mark . The Natives continued to push , with Elliot coming within five @-@ yards of the tr[MASK] [MASK]ine , and when Ell[MASK]son di[MASK] manage[MASK]to cross the line he was carried back into the 25 @-@ yard line before he could[MASK]tou[MASK]h down . In the second[MASK]half Wales continued to p[MASK]sh their advantage when Alexander Bland dribble[MASK] the ball into the Natives ' 25 ; this was collected by Sydney Nicholls , who managed to get the ball acros[MASK] the t[MASK]y line , allowing Jim Hannan to sc[MASK][MASK]e . War[MASK]rick for the Natives and Stadden for Wales both subsequently came close to scoring tries , but there were no further sco[MASK]es in the game . 
 The match was also of his[MASK]orical importance because of the Welsh tactics employe[MASK] . In the 1886 Home Nations Championsh[MASK]p Wales had trialled the four three @-@ quarter system , wherein the team would play with eight forwards rather than nine , and instead employ an extra centre three @-@ quarter . The sys[MASK]em was deemed a failure and was particularly unpopular with star Welsh player Arthur Gould , whose formidable ability as a back allowed his club team Newport to retain the additional forward . With Gould working in[MASK]the West Indies , Wales again tried the four three @-@ quarter system against the Natives , and its success saw the team permanent[MASK]y adopt the system . Within six years the other three Home Countries had adopted four three @-@ quarter style of play . 
 Before they [MASK]eft Wales , the Natives played Swansea and two other local clubs , [MASK]ewport , and Ca[MASK]diff . They defeated Swansea for th[MASK]ir firs[MASK] win in Wa[MASK]es , and fol[MASK]owed this up with a victory over Newport [MASK]n front of 8 @,@ 000 spectators . They finished their [MASK]elsh matches , [MASK]nd the year , with a 4 – 1 loss to Cardiff in front of a partisan crowd[MASK]. 
 
 = = Return to Engla[MASK]d = = 
 
 The side entered 1889 having played 36 matches for 22 wins and three[MASK]draws . The Natives ' play had improved th[MASK]oughout Novemb[MASK]r and December following poorer form in their Oc[MASK]ober matches ; positive press reports reflecte[MASK] this impro[MASK]ement . The[MASK]team would go on to play a further 17 matches before their 16 February international against England . January started w[MASK]th a 4 – 1 loss to Bradford , duri[MASK]g which 25 police officers w[MASK]re required to keep many of the 12 @,@ 000 spectators , many[MASK]of them non @-@ paying , in order . This was followed by victories over Leeds Parish Church , Kirkstall , Brighouse Ran[MASK]ers , and H[MASK]ddersfield . Following[MASK]further matc[MASK]es against Stockport , Cast[MASK]eford , and Warrington , where the team drew , lost , then won , the side faced Yorkshire for[MASK]a[MASK]second time . 
 Yorkshire had been criticised i[MASK] the press for fie[MASK]ding a[MASK]weakened line @-@ up against the Natives when the sides f[MASK]rst met in De[MASK]ember . After the un[MASK]xpected loss , [MASK]orkshire were determined to ma[MASK]e amends and a stro[MASK]g[MASK]side was selected for the county , including Fred Bonsor , Richard Lockwood[MASK]and Joh[MASK] Willie Sutcliffe , all o[MASK] whom would appear [MASK]o[MASK] England against the Natives l[MASK]ter that season . Described as " kno[MASK]ked about " and " stale " , the Natives struggled to compete against such strong opp[MASK]sition , and Yorkshire scored three converted tries before a try to Ellison left the scores at 9 – 1 at half @-@ time . The second @-@ half was little better fo[MASK] the Natives ; they conceded a further two tries as well as [MASK] dro[MASK] @-@ go[MASK]l . The second of these tries was scored b[MASK] Lockwood after he ran the ball from his own half . [MASK]llis[MASK]n s[MASK]ored a converted try late in the match , but this didn 't prevent the Natives suffering their largest defe[MASK]t of the tour : 16 – 4 to the Yorkshiremen . Ellison later described the match as " without a murmur , the biggest beating we received in ou[MASK] whole tour " . 
 After a victory over Spen Valley District , [MASK]he te[MASK]m travelled west to play Somersetshire , Devonshire , Taunton ,[MASK]and Gloucestershire , and won all five games . The vic[MASK]ory[MASK]over Somerset was the New Zeala[MASK][MASK]ers [MASK] largest of the tour ; they scored nine tries in a 17 – 4 victory . Half @-@ back Keo[MASK]h play[MASK]d outsta[MASK]dingly for the Natives , while the entire side demonstrated superior p[MASK]ssing and combination to their opposition . Devon[MASK]hire [MASK]nd Tauton suffered heavy defeats by the New Zealanders , [MASK]efore a strong Gloucestershire side was dismissed . After defeating Midland Counties , the Natives returned to London . 
 The team had two further matches before their international against England . The first was against one of the strongest c[MASK]ubs in England , Blackheath . Andrew Stoddart , who had toured New Zealand and Australia with th[MASK] 1888 British Isles side , played for the club in their 9 – 3 defeat to the Na[MASK]ives . The New Zealanders won having scored four tries , including two by Keogh . Their next[MASK]opposition was a United Services side mainly comprisin[MASK] Royal Navy players . The Natives were again victorious , this time 10 – 0 . The match against Oxford University was [MASK]ostponed due to heavy frost , and so the team had a seven @-@ day break from playing – their longest of the tour . 
 
 = = England international = = 
 
 The match against England was causing the Natives ' players and management problems bef[MASK]re it had even begun . The team manager , Scott , was in dispute with the RFU over where the m[MASK]tch sho[MASK]ld be pla[MASK]ed – the RFU wer[MASK] adamant that the match should take plac[MASK] at Blackheath 's ground , but Scott[MASK]wanted the game to proceed at The Oval , where a larger crowd , and therefore higher gate receipts , could be secured . The strictly ama[MASK]eur RFU establishment were alre[MASK]dy suspicious of the profit[MASK]@-@ making motives of the Natives , and were unwilling to yield on the selection of v[MASK]nue . The RF[MASK] was also in dispute[MASK]with the other Home Unions over the formation of the International [MASK]ugby Footba[MASK]l Boa[MASK]d ( IRFB ) . Following a [MASK]isputed try in an England – Scotland international match in 1888 , the Scottish authoriti[MASK]s had pushed for the establishment of an international body to overse[MASK] the game , but [MASK]he RFU insisted that they would[MASK]only join if they held a deciding vo[MASK]e , arguing that they deserved this as they were , the[MASK] asserted , the [MASK]enior body , and had the most member clubs . Ireland , Wales and S[MASK]otland consequently re[MASK]used to play aga[MASK]nst England until 1891 , when , following a[MASK]bitrat[MASK]on , the RFU relented and joined the[MASK]IRFB [MASK] The absence of international [MASK]atches was a factor in England agreeing to f[MASK]ce the Natives on 16 February 1889 . 
 The line @-@ ups selected for the 16 February match were both s[MASK]rong , and close to full strength . T[MASK][MASK]ugh 12 of the England side had not played internationally before , all were experienced at domestic level . The match was refereed by Rowland Hill , who had also officiated the Natives ' first match in Britain , against Surrey . The opening of th[MASK] first half was a scoreless affair , with much tacklin[MASK] and scrummagin[MASK] on the heavy ground . Later in the half England scored two tries thr[MASK]ug[MASK] Harry Bedford , but both were disput[MASK]d by the Natives , who claimed that one of their players had grounded the[MASK]ball in @-@ goal . England took the two @-@[MASK]try advantage into the second half . 
 Early in the second h[MASK]lf a third disputed tr[MASK] was sc[MASK]red by the English . The try [MASK]nd i[MASK]s af[MASK]ermath caused controversy and a rift between the Natives and the [MASK]FU . Ell[MASK]son [MASK]ttempted to tackle the English player Stod[MASK]a[MASK]t , and in the process ripped his shorts off . The Natives quickly formed a circle around Stoddart to a[MASK]low him to replace his clothing without being seen . While this was happening one of the Eng[MASK]ish players , Frank Evershed ,[MASK]picked[MASK]up the ball and scored a try . The New Zealand[MASK]rs protested , believing that play had stopped after claiming [MASK]toddart had called " dead ball " – but Hill awarded the try , prompting t[MASK]re[MASK] of the Native players , Dick Taiaroa , Williams , and Sherry Wynyard , to [MASK][MASK]ave[MASK]the field in p[MASK]otest . The aggrieved players were eventual[MASK]y pe[MASK]suaded to return , but not before Hill had restarted play . Ellison was very criti[MASK]al of Hill , particularly[MASK]because he was also Secretary of the RFU . Ellison wrote after the tour that " gross as[MASK]these errors were , they were insignificant when compared wi[MASK][MASK] another that Mr Hill commi[MASK]ted at the outset of the ga[MASK]e , viz , refereeing[MASK]at all in that game " . The disputed try was follow[MASK][MASK] by[MASK]a final try for the English , who ultimately[MASK]won [MASK] – 0 . 
 The RFU , at Hill 's instigation , promptly demanded an apolo[MASK]y from the Natives ' captain of the day , Edward McCausla[MASK]d , who had led the team as Joe Warbrick was injured . The English authorities[MASK]of the time believed that the decision of a referee w[MASK]s above question , and that p[MASK]otesting a decision as the New Zealanders had done was unsports[MASK]anlike . The RFU threatened to bar any of their affiliated playe[MASK]s – in other [MASK]o[MASK][MASK]s , the entire rugby playing population of England – from facing the Natives if they did not apologise[MASK]. McCausland sw[MASK]ftly sent an apology[MASK]b[MASK] telegram , bu[MASK] this was deemed inadequate ; he therefore sent anot[MASK]er , four days [MASK]fter the game : 
 The London establishment that governed the game wer[MASK] disturbed by the New Zealander[MASK] ' app[MASK]oach to the game ; reports of rough and over @-@ aggressive play by the Natives had steadily increase[MASK] in frequency since their arrival in Britain . In the nor[MASK]h of England[MASK], criticism [MASK]f the visitors ' sportsmanship was rarer ; the tourists we[MASK]e accepted as playing the [MASK]ame in the same spirit as their loc[MASK]l opponents , which in the north was a more working class sport than in the south . Some of the Natives , including Joe Warbrick , accused the RFU and the Engl[MASK]sh press of hypocrisy , claiming t[MASK]at they were quick to criticise the New Zealanders for rou[MASK]h play , yet tolerant of similar behaviour from their own player[MASK] . 
 
 = = Later matches and departure from England = = 
 
 The Natives remained in Lon[MASK]on following the England in[MASK]ernation[MASK]l . They defeated London Welsh on 18 February , before losing first to Cambridge , then Oxford University[MASK]. From there they travelled north and won two m[MASK]tches before los[MASK]ng to Leigh . After a win over Runcorn , there was a defeat to Oldham , played on a ground Eyton said was so f[MASK]ozen it was dangerous . After reversing their previous loss to Halifax with a 6 – 0 win , the Natives suffered a loss to Barrow and District on 7 March . The New Zealand[MASK]rs then had a run of seven straight wins before a 1 – 1 dr[MASK]w with Hull . Widnes were then [MASK]efe[MASK]t[MASK]d for the second time in two weeks in t[MASK]e tourists ' last match in [MASK]orthern England . 
 The team struggled to find an opponent for their final match in Britain . They event[MASK]ally played Southern Counties , and beat them 3 – 1 . This was their 74th match in the British Isles and their 49th victory . The authorities and press in London [MASK]ontinued to [MASK]iew the team [MASK]egativel[MASK] , and the Natives boarded ship without a formal farewell . This perceived affront from the RFU pr[MASK]vo[MASK]ed some criticism from the press[MASK]outside London , as[MASK]well as from the team manager Scott , w[MASK]o felt[MASK]that with the team 's official apology after[MASK]the England match , the controversy should have put to rest . 
 
 = = Australia = = 
 
[MASK]The majority of the Na[MASK]ives left P[MASK]ymouth on 29 March ( Eyton[MASK]and Pie Wynyard followed a week later ) . They arrived in Melbourne in May , where the team played mostly Victorian Rules football , hoping to make more money that way . Although the[MASK]side had employed Jack Lawlor to coa[MASK]h t[MASK]em in Victo[MASK]ian Rules during t[MASK]eir tour of the British Isles , the heavy schedule and high injury count had left little time and energy for suc[MASK] training . As a result , the Victorian Rules matches w[MASK]re a failure ; the players ' unfam[MASK]liarity with the rules , combined with the fact that most of the Natives were rugby forwards ( and therefore less suited to the [MASK]ore open Victorian Rules ) , ensured that they failed to perform well on the field an[MASK] struggled to attract large crowds . The side p[MASK]ayed nine Victorian Rules matches in t[MASK]tal , including one in Ne[MASK] South Wales , but won only three of[MASK]them , all against relatively weak oppo[MASK]ition . 
 The side 's success in their rugby matches contrasted to their failure in Victorian Rules – the New Zealanders played three rugby matches while in Victoria : against M[MASK]lbourne [MASK] a Navy selection , and Victoria . The matches were all won , with their game against Victoria a 19 – 0 victory . After[MASK]this they left for Sydney for further rugby matches , and defeated New South Wales 12 – 9 . After two furthe[MASK] victories , the side [MASK]gain faced New South Wales , and won the match 16 – 12 . Another two victories follo[MASK]ed , before the team played their on[MASK]y association football matches of the tour – both defeats . 
 The team [MASK]ravelled north to Queensland , where , as in New South Wales , rugby was t[MASK]e dominant code of football . Con[MASK]equently , th[MASK] team exclusively played rugby while in th[MASK] region .[MASK]The Natives faced Queensland at the Association Ground in[MASK]Bri[MASK]bane . The 8000 spectators witnessed the New Zea[MASK]anders overwhelm the Queenslanders to win 22 [MASK] 0 ; the Natives did not exert themselves in the win , and the sc[MASK]re did not reflect their dominance . Af[MASK]er a further[MASK]two matches , against Toowoomba and Ipswich ( both of whom were comfortably defeated ) , the team returned to Brisbane for a rematch [MASK]ith Queenslan[MASK] . In contrast to their first meeting , the fir[MASK]t @-@ half was a close affair , and the two sides were tied at the conclusion[MASK]of the half . Billy Warbrick suffered a ki[MASK]k to the head , and had to retire early in the secon[MASK] @-@ half . Following the los[MASK] of Warbrick , the play of the Natives improved and they recovered to win 11 – 7 . Not long after the gam[MASK] concluded rumours[MASK]circulated [MASK]hat som[MASK] of the players had been offered ₤ 50 by bookmakers to throw the game . Eyton later said : 
 It was on the occasion o[MASK][MASK]this match that four of our players were thought , i[MASK] racing parlance , to be playing " stiff " , and that they had been got by some boo[MASK]ies ;[MASK]at all event[MASK] , when ac[MASK]used of it at half @-@ t[MASK]me and cau[MASK]ioned , they played a different game in the second half . 
 [MASK]he response from the team 's management was to suspen[MASK] four players . The team travelled to Toowoomba , where they defeated the locals 19 – 0 . The Natives included a replacement player for only the second time , Charles Speakman , after the suspensions reduced the playing strength of the side . The team then travelled back to New Zealand , and arrived in Invercargill on 5 August . 
 
 = = Retur[MASK] to Ne[MASK] Zealand = = 
 
 Two days[MASK]after their return , the Natives faced Southl[MASK]nd , who they defeated 5 – 1 in front of a crowd of 2 @,@ 000 . The side suffered further injury , to Harry Lee , and recruited[MASK]Southlander W. Hirst for their match against Mataura District on 8 August . Despite playing the match two players down , the Natives comfortably defeated Mataura 16 – 3 . Following the side 's return to New Z[MASK]a[MASK]and , the Otago Rugby Football Union d[MASK]mand[MASK]d that the team 's management explain the accusations levelled at them in Queensland .[MASK]Eyton responded by insisting that the [MASK]layers had only been suspended while an investiga[MASK]ion was conducted , and that the management was confident no wrongdoing had occurred . The Northern Rugby Union ( since re[MASK]amed Queenslan[MASK] Ru[MASK]by Union ) summarised the [MASK]ncident and aftermath in the 188[MASK] Queensland Rugby Union Annual : 
 ... it was [MASK]pparent to a judge of the game that something was wron[MASK] with the Maori , [MASK]s they were not showing their usual dash and combination . Four [MASK]embers of [MASK]he team were suspended , a charge b[MASK]ing made against them of attempting the sell the ma[MASK]ch . The ma[MASK]ter was bough[MASK] before the Otago[MASK]Union , who p[MASK][MASK]sed the following resolution : That , havin[MASK] heard all available evidence regarding the charges a[MASK]ains[MASK] certain members of the Native Team , and having received an expl[MASK]cit denial of charge[MASK] f[MASK]om the accused membe[MASK]s and a satisfactory ex[MASK]lanation from the management , we are of op[MASK]nion that there are no facts before [MASK]s justifying the allegations ... 
 It is unlikely , given the attitude of the Otag[MASK] Rugby Union to the Natives before their departure [MASK] that they would have dismissed the allegations if incrimina[MASK]i[MASK]g evidence had existed . The side was back to full strength following t[MASK]e return of their suspended players when the side faced Otago in Dunedin [MASK] The Natives outscored their opponents five tries to two , and won 11 – 8 . The side 's star player and h[MASK]lf @-@ b[MASK]ck , Keogh , stayed in Dunedin when the team departed for Christchur[MASK]h . The side faced Hawke 's Bay , who were touring , in Christchurch , and handily defeated them 13 – 2 . The Natives ' play was praised by The Press : " ... the wearers of the black passed with remarkable accuracy and quickne[MASK]s between their[MASK]legs [MASK] over their shoulders , under their arms and with their feet " . The side then faced Canterb[MASK]ry [MASK]n 17 August , who they thrashed 15 – 0 . The report published [MASK]n The Press said of the Natives '[MASK]performance : 
 The play show[MASK]d on Saturday afternoon was a fine exhibition of what several months[MASK]of combination and practice [MASK]ill do ... it must be admitted they were far and away too good for our local men . In the loose , in the scrum , dribbling , [MASK]assing , collaring , or running they were very much indeed Canterbury 's superior . Such runs as were made b[MASK] Warbrick at full back , by[MASK]Madigan , Gage , and W. Wynyard , the passing of H. Wynyar[MASK] , F. Warbrick , and all the backs as well as several forwards , the rushe[MASK] of Alf Warbrick , Maynard , Taare , Taiaroa , and Rene , and[MASK]the dodging and fending powers of nearly every one , non[MASK]lu[MASK]sed their opponents ... 
 The side left Christchurch[MASK]and [MASK]ravelled north [MASK]here [MASK]hey played Wairarapa in Masterton . The match was won 10 – 8 , and the ne[MASK]t day they faced Wellington , who they also defeated . T[MASK]e [MASK]ixt[MASK]re against We[MASK]l[MASK]ngton was nearly abandoned because Scott [MASK]nd the Wellington Rugby U[MASK]ion could not agree on a venue ; the match went ahead only when the Well[MASK]ngton officials agreed to c[MASK]de the Natives all profit fro[MASK] the match . After this the Natives travelled to Auckland where [MASK]hey played their last match , against [MASK]he province on 24 August . The match was lost 7 – 2 after each team scored two tries each , but the Auckland[MASK]rs kicked a drop @-[MASK] goal and a conversion . The loss ended a r[MASK]markable run of match[MASK]s – the Natives had a 31 @-@ game unbeaten streak in rugb[MASK] matches that started with their victory over Widnes on 9 March ; the side won 30 , and drew one match betwe[MASK]n the defeats . 
 
 = = Impact and legacy = = 
 
 Th[MASK] tour had a significant impact on the development of rugby within New Zealand . It was the first tour of the British Isles by a team from the S[MASK]uthern He[MASK]isphere , and the longe[MASK]t in the history of the sport . By the time the Natives retu[MASK]ned to N[MASK]w Zealand , they had developed into a side superior to any in the country , and introduced a number o[MASK] tactical innovations . Seventeen of the 26 playe[MASK]s went on to play provincially in New Zealand , and two[MASK], Ellison and David Gage , subsequently captained New Zealand . 
 The tour also prompted the eventu[MASK]l formation of the New Zealand Rugby Football Union ( NZRFU , later renamed New Zealand Rugby Union ) in 1892 ; one reason for its form[MASK]tio[MASK] was to ensure greater co[MASK]trol over any future tou[MASK]ing New Zealand sides . The NZRF[MASK] sent an officially sanctioned New [MASK]ealand team , captained by Ellison , to tour Australia [MASK]n 1893 . The Natives are also the forefathers of the Māori All[MASK]Blacks , a representative team organised by the[MASK]NZRFU , that first played in 1910 . The[MASK]Native team , along with Joe Warbrick , was inducted into the IRB Hall of F[MASK]me in 2008 – the seventh inductee . 
 
 = = Squad = = 
 
 The squad consisted of 26 players . The[MASK]exact names of several o[MASK] the players is unknown . The number o[MASK] matches played is a minimum number only – the line @-@ ups for a num[MASK]er of matches in Britain and Australia[MASK]are either incomplete or unknown .
