 = Éva Gauthier = 
 
 Éva Gauthier ([MASK]September[MASK]20 , 1885 – December 20 , 1958 ) wa[MASK] a Canadian @-@ American [MASK]ezzo @-@ soprano and voice teacher . She performed and p[MASK]pularised songs by contemporary c[MASK]mposers throughout her career an[MASK] sang in the American premieres of several works by[MASK][MASK]rik Satie , Mau[MASK]ice[MASK]Ravel and I[MASK]or Stravinsky , including th[MASK] title role in the latter 's Perséph[MASK]ne . 
 The niece of Lady Laurier and Sir Wilfrid Laurier , who also were her patron[MASK] , she initially trained and performed in Europe . She then travelled to Java and for four years immersed herself in its native music , which she introduced[MASK]to North American audiences on her return . She retired [MASK]rom performing in 1937 , and opened a voice studio[MASK]in New York , where she became a founding member of the American Guild of Musical Ar[MASK]is[MASK]s and[MASK]served on its board of governors . Gauthier was praised for the many qualities her s[MASK]nging brought to[MASK]music . The [MASK]itation from the Campion Society of Sa[MASK] Fr[MASK]ncisco , which she received i[MASK] 1949 , said : " ... her rare open @[MASK]@ mindedness and u[MASK]o[MASK]thodox e[MASK]thusia[MASK]m having been initially responsible for the recogni[MASK]ion of many vital and important modern composers " 
 
 = = Singing career = = 
 
 Born in Ottawa , Ontario , Gauthier received mus[MASK]cal lessons as a child , in ha[MASK]mony , voice , and piano . The[MASK]custom of the time dictated [MASK]hat North America[MASK] musi[MASK]ians travel to [MASK]urope for training if they desired a reputable professional career , and in July 1902 [MASK] at the age of seventeen , Gauthier set out for Europ[MASK] , financed by her aunt and uncle , Lady Zoé Laurier and Sir[MASK]Wilfrid Laurier .[MASK]
 
 = = = Training in Europe = = = 
 
 Gauthier travelled to France , where she received [MASK]rivate voice lessons from Auguste @-@ Jean Dubulle of the Paris Conservato[MASK]y . Nodules on her vocal cords were pro[MASK]lematic , but they were removed surgically . She later began training under Jacques Bouhy , whom she would later credit for her vocal technique . In 1906 , Gauthier was retained by fellow Canadian singer Emma Albani to accompany her on a tour of England and her Canadian farewell tour . Albani provided a degre[MASK] o[MASK] mentorship to Gauthier during the 30 week tour of Canada . 
 Lord S[MASK]rathcona awarded Gauthier[MASK]a scholarship in 1906 that allowed her to return to Europe and co[MASK]tinue her vocal studies . She retur[MASK]ed there and continued bot[MASK] to study and give performanc[MASK]s . Her first operatic performance came in 1909 in Pavia , Italy as[MASK]Micaëla in Bizet 's Carmen . She landed a second operatic role as Mallika in Delibes ' Lakmé , which was being performed by the London Covent Garden opera compan[MASK] . The opera opened in June 1910 . Supposed[MASK]y , Luisa Tetrazzini , the prima donna soprano of the company[MASK], feared that Gauthier 's voice would outshine her own , and demand[MASK]d that Gauthier be removed from the opera . The company 's directo[MASK] acquiesced to Tetr[MASK]zzini 's demands , informing Gauthier on opening night that she wo[MASK]ld not be performing . Gauthier reacted badly , and quit opera entirely . 
 
 = = = Move to Java [MASK] = = 
 
 Disappointe[MASK] by her blocked entry into the operatic scene , Gauthier departed Europe and travelle[MASK] to Java . There , she met a Dutch importer and plantat[MASK]o[MASK] manager[MASK]named Frans Knoote . Gauthier and Knoote married on Ma[MASK] 22 , 1911 . Gauthier studied the m[MASK]sic of Java , and began to include this in her repertoire .[MASK]Her accompanying pianist was Paul Seelig , who had previously been the conductor for the Kraton of Surakarta , which afforded Gauthier a number of oppor[MASK]unities[MASK]. On permission of the Javanese court , she studied th[MASK] gamela[MASK] , probably being the first western wo[MASK]an [MASK]ith a classical music education to be afforded this opportunity . While living in Java , Gauthier travelled extensively , givin[MASK] performances in China , Japan , Singapore , Malaya , Austra[MASK]ia , and New Zealand . [MASK]he remained in Java for four years , but with the outbreak of Wor[MASK]d War I she d[MASK]cid[MASK]d to travel back to North America [MASK] arriving in New York City [MASK]n the fall of 1915 . 
 
 = = = Return to North America = = = 
 
 Arriving in New York , Gauthier struggled to find a niche in an already crowded music scene . She put on a performance in Vaudevil[MASK]e entitled Songmotion ,[MASK]which c[MASK]mbine[MASK] Javan music with dancers . New York was already h[MASK]me to many North American and European musical performers , so G[MASK]uthier focused on her Javan musical repertoire , which she combined with knowledge and skill in modernist western singing . Gauthier began giving annual recitals at Aeolian Hall , and in Novem[MASK]er 1917 her performance there caught the eye of many leading composers . She developed her own reputation quickly , known as[MASK]a " ... sensitive purveyor of interesting , untried songs " [MASK] She[MASK]gave renditions of three songs by Maur[MASK]ce Ravel . Her performance then also included American premieres of Stravinsky 's Three Japanese Lyrics an[MASK] Griffes ' Five Poems of Anc[MASK]ent China and Ja[MASK]an . The performance was a great success , and she began to receive [MASK]nvitations to perform[MASK]premieres of songs by contemporary [MASK]omposers . Stravinsky arranged to have Gauthier to premiere all of his voc[MASK]l piece[MASK] . 
 Ga[MASK]thier travelled to Paris in 1920 at the behest of th[MASK] Music League of America . Sent there to arrange a tour of North America by Maurice Ravel , she struck u[MASK] a friendship and professional correspondence not [MASK]nly with him , but also with Erik Satie and Les six . This led to more music being sent to her by vario[MASK]s composers that she would premiere in concert . She accepted and premiered almost all works sent to her , the only exception being a refusal to perform Pierrot Lu[MASK]aire by Arnold Schoenberg . Thro[MASK]gh this , Gauthier performed larg[MASK] amounts of contempor[MASK]ry Fr[MASK]nch music across the United States . She also in[MASK]luded American music in all of her concerts . Gauthier toured America frequently and returned to Europe in 1922 , and again in 1923 . She began to explore J[MASK]zz music in concert as well , ear[MASK]ing[MASK]her negati[MASK]e re[MASK]iews by many musical critics[MASK]. 
 Her 1923 annual perfo[MASK]mance at Aeolian Hall entitled " Reci[MASK]al of Ancient and Modern Music fo[MASK] Voice " became a historic occasion w[MASK]en she presented the works of George Ge[MASK]shwin , the first time his works were performe[MASK] by a classical singer in concert . T[MASK]e first ha[MASK]f of the programme pre[MASK]ented works considered serious music at the time . She performed both classical works by Vincenzo Bellini and Henry Purcell , mixing them with modernist and neoclassical works by Arnold Schoenberg , Darius Milhaud , Béla Bartók , and Paul Hindemith . The second half of her perf[MASK]rmance would upset the musical establishment , however . She opened with Alexander 's Ragtime Band by Irving Berlin , then [MASK]erformed works by Jerome Kern and Walter Donaldson , and finally finished with three works by George Gershwin : I 'll Build a Stairway to Paradise , Innocent Ingénue Baby , and Swan[MASK]e . Gershwin played the piano for [MASK]hese pieces . Importan[MASK] figures in the audience includ[MASK]d Ernestine Schumann @-@ Heink , Virgil Thomson , and Paul Whiteman . Although some musical critics panned her decision to include Jazz music , the performance was overall a huge success ,[MASK]and provoked serious dis[MASK]ussion among conserv[MASK]tive[MASK]audiences whether jazz mus[MASK]c could be considered[MASK]serious art . 
 Gauthier continued to present music that wa[MASK] thought poorly of by conservative audiences . On so[MASK]e occasions , such as her performances of Gershwin in New[MASK]York in 1923 and 1925[MASK], as well as in London in 1925 , this was quite successful . A critic in Vienna welcomed[MASK]her musical selection as a reprieve from the usual fare of classical performances - Schubert , Brahms , Wolf , Richard Strau[MASK]s - while praising h[MASK]r skill with more classical choices . Other performances suffered [MASK] she was booed while performing works by Heitor Villa @[MASK]@ Lobos at the Festival of the International Society of Contemporary Music in Venice . She became a celebrity , and continued giving performances across the United States , Europe , and her native Canada . On the [MASK]ixtieth anniversary of C[MASK]nadian Confederation in 1927 , she gave a performance in Ottawa which was the first transcontinental radio broadcast in Canada[MASK]. Although she toured Canada from time to time , and [MASK]ttended performances of Canadian music in New York , she held a n[MASK]gative opinion of Canada 's treatment of native musicia[MASK]s , saying " Canadians . . . would rather listen to foreigners than their own people .[MASK]" 
 
 = = = Retirement[MASK]from th[MASK] stage = = = 
 
 Illness fo[MASK][MASK]ed Gauthier to halt giving performa[MASK]ce[MASK] in the late 1920s , but she would return to the stage in 1931 , giv[MASK]ng a c[MASK]ncert in Havana , Cuba . As time passed she began to[MASK]engage more and more[MASK]in teac[MASK]ing , and less and less in stage pe[MASK]forming .[MASK]Her income from teach[MASK]ng was substantial[MASK]y better tha[MASK] from touring . She retired from [MASK]erforming [MASK]ntirely in 1937 [MASK] and opened a music studio in New York . There she became a founding member of the Ame[MASK]ican Guild of Musical Artists[MASK], serving on its board of governors . She died on December 20 , 1958 . 
 
 = = Views of critics and audiences = = 
 [MASK] Gauthier was a controversial musician in her time . Her choice of music for performance was often condemned , and[MASK]often praised . The appropriateness of jazz music for a classically trained singer , combined with the performances taking place in concert halls lead some cr[MASK][MASK][MASK]cs to cheer her for promoting otherwise overlooked m[MASK]sic , and others to condemn her for taking lowbrow music into a highbrow v[MASK]nue . 
 A M[MASK]y 1 , 1917 review by the New York Times praised her natural talent , with some reservati[MASK]ns abou[MASK] the unpolished[MASK]quality of her voice . Her ability to capture the spirit of the pieces was also praised : " ... her singing of songs by Frenchmen of today and the day before yesterday [MASK]ave pleasure because of her under[MASK]tandin[MASK] of them and the a[MASK]propriate expression which she found for them . " 
 A November 12 , 19[MASK]3 Time review of her performance of historic [MASK]talian so[MASK]gs , as well as modern English[MASK], French , Austrian , German and A[MASK]er[MASK]can numbers[MASK]focused on her choice to include selections of[MASK]contemporary jazz music . The critic [MASK]ema[MASK]ked " Her voice was much too good for jazz . " Here she was pra[MASK]sed as a serious , scholarly artist whose perform[MASK]nce was " [MASK].. neat and exp[MASK]essive . " The audience r[MASK]ceived the concert very enthusias[MASK]ically . 
 Her performance in Fargo in 1923 resulted in a headline in the Fargo[MASK]Forum [MASK]he next day that was headed Eva Gauthier[MASK]’ s Program Sets Whole Town Buzzing : Many People Ar[MASK] of Two M[MASK]nds Regarding Jazz Numbers – Some [MASK]eluctantly Admit T[MASK]at They Like Them – Others Keep Silent or Condemn Them . The review divides the audien[MASK]e and critics into various cam[MASK]s : those who [MASK]penly enjoyed and applauded the performa[MASK]ce ; those who o[MASK]enly di[MASK]liked and condemned it ; those u[MASK]sure how to react to a performance they liked but felt was inappropriate ; and those who liked the performance but would not show approv[MASK]l for fear of looking foolish or uncultured . 
 
 = = Archival materials = = 
 
 Éva Gauthier papers , 1899 @-@ 1960 Music Division , The New York Public Library . 
 
 
[MASK]= Battle of Sullivan 's Island = 
 
 The Battle of [MASK]ullivan 's Island or the Battle of Fort Sullivan was fought on June 28 , 1776 , during the A[MASK]erican Revolu[MASK]ionary War . It took place near Charleston , South [MASK]arolina , during the first[MASK]British attempt to captu[MASK]e the c[MASK]ty from A[MASK]erican[MASK]rebels . It is also sometimes referred to as the First Siege of Charleston , owing to a more successful British siege in 1780 . 
 The British [MASK]rganized an expedition in e[MASK]rly 1[MASK]76 for operations in the rebellious southern colonies of Nor[MASK]h America . Delayed by logis[MASK]ical concerns and bad weather , the expe[MASK]ition reac[MASK]ed the coast of North Carolina in May 1776[MASK]. Finding conditions unsuitable fo[MASK] their o[MASK]era[MASK]ions , General Henry Clinton and Adm[MASK]ral[MASK]S[MASK]r Peter Parker decided instead to act against Charleston . Arriving there in early June , troops were landed on Long[MASK]Island , near Sullivan 's Island where Colonel William Moultrie commanded a partially constr[MASK]cted fort , in preparation for a naval bombardment and land assaul[MASK] . General Charles Lee , commanding the southern Continental theater of t[MASK]e war , would provide s[MASK]pervision . 
 The land assault was [MASK]rustrated when the channel between the two islands was found to be too deep to wade , and the American defenses prevented an amphibious landing[MASK]. The naval bombardment had littl[MASK] effect due to the sandy soil and the spongy natur[MASK] of the fort 's palmetto log construction . Careful fire by the defenders wrought sign[MASK]ficant damage on the British fleet , which withdrew afte[MASK] an entire day 's bombardment . The British withdrew their expedition force to New York , and did not return to South Carolina until 1780 . 
 
 = = Background = =[MASK]
 
 When the American Revolutionar[MASK] War broke out in 1775 , the city of Charleston in the colony of South Carolina was a center of commerce in sou[MASK]hern North America . The city 's citizens joined other colonists in opposing the British parliament 's attempts to tax them , an[MASK] militia recruitment increased when word arrived of the April 1775 Battles of Le[MASK]ington and Concord . Throughout 1775 an[MASK] into 1776 [MASK] militia recruits arriv[MASK]d in the city from the colony 's backcountry [MASK] the city 's manufacturers and tradesmen[MASK]began producing war materie[MASK] , and defensive fortifi[MASK]ations began to take shape around [MASK]he city . 
 
 = = = British o[MASK]erations = = = 
 
 British army forces in North America wer[MASK] primarily tied up with the Siege of Boston[MASK]i[MASK] 1775 . Seeking bases of operat[MASK]ons where they had more control , the British planned an expedition to the southern colonies . Major General Henry Clinton , the[MASK] in Bo[MASK]ton , was to travel to Cape Fear , North Carolina ,[MASK]where he would join with largel[MASK] Scottish Loyalists raised in th[MASK] North Carolin[MASK] back[MASK]oun[MASK]ry , and a force of 2 [MASK],@ 000 men from Ireland under the comm[MASK]nd of Major General [MASK]harles Cornwallis . 
 The plan was beset by difficulties from[MASK]the start . The Irish expedition , orig[MASK]nall[MASK] supposed to [MASK]epart at the beginning of December 1775 , was delayed by logisti[MASK]al difficulties , and its 2 @,@ 500 troops did not depart u[MASK]til February 13 , 1776 , escorted by 11 warships under the command of Admiral Sir Peter Parker . Clinton left Boston on January 20 with two companies of light infantry , an[MASK] first stopped at New York City to confer with William Tryon , New York 's royal governor . Ma[MASK]or [MASK]eneral Charles Lee , sent by Major G[MASK]neral George Washington to see to the defense of[MASK]New York , coincidentally arrived there the sam[MASK] day as Clin[MASK]on . New Yo[MASK]k was at that time extremely tense ; Patriot forces were beginning to disarm and[MASK]evict L[MASK]yalists , and the British fleet anchore[MASK] there was having difficulty acquiring provisions[MASK]. Despite this , Clinton made no secret[MASK]that his final target was in the south . Lee observed that this was " certainly a droll [MASK]ay of proceeding ; to communicate his full plan to the enemy is too novel to be credited . " This was not even the first notice of the expedition to the colonists ; a letter intercepted in December had already provided intelligenc[MASK] that the British wer[MASK] planning[MASK]to go to the South . 
 Clinton arrived at Cape Fear on[MASK]March 12 , expecti[MASK]g to find the European convoy already there . He met w[MASK]th the [MASK]oyal governors of North and South Carolina , Josiah Martin and[MASK]William Campbe[MASK]l , and learned that the recruited Scottish Loyalists had been defeated at Moore 's Creek Br[MASK]dge two weeks earlier . Clinton also received pleas [MASK]or assistance from the royal governor of Georgia , James[MASK]Wright ,[MASK]who had been arrested , and th[MASK]n escaped to a navy ship . 
 Parker 's fl[MASK]et had an ext[MASK]emely difficult crossing . Battered by storms and [MASK]igh seas , the [MASK]irst ships of the fle[MASK]t did not arrive at Cape Fear until April 18 [MASK] and Cornwallis did not arrive until May 3 . After several weeks there , in which the British troops raided Pat[MASK]iot properties , Clinton , Cornwallis and[MASK]Parker concluded [MASK]hat Cape Fear was not a suitable base [MASK]or further operations . Parker had sent out some ship[MASK] on scouting exp[MASK]ditions up and down the [MASK]oast , and reports on the part[MASK]ally finished condition of the Charleston defenses were sufficiently promising [MASK]hat the de[MASK]ision was made to go there . 
 
 = = = American defenses = = = 
 
 John Rutledge , recently elected president of the General Assembly that remained as the backbone of South Carolina 's revolutionary government [MASK] organized a defense force under the command of 46 @-@ year @-@ old Colonel William Moultrie , a former [MASK]iliti[MASK]man and Indian fighter . These forces comprised three infantry regiments , two rifle regiments , and a small artillery regiment ; they were augmented by three independent art[MASK]llery companies , and th[MASK] total force numbered ab[MASK]ut 2 @[MASK][MASK][MASK]000 . These forces were further au[MASK]ment[MASK]d by the arrival of Continenta[MASK] regiments fr[MASK]m North Carolina and Virgin[MASK]a ( 1 @,@ 900 troops ) , as well as militia numbering 2 @,@ 700 from Charleston and the surrounding backcountry . 
 Moultrie saw Sullivan 's Island , a sandy spit of land at the entrance to Charleston Harbor extending north ab[MASK]ut 4 miles ( 6 @.@ 4 km ) long and a [MASK]ew hundred yard[MASK] wide , as a place well suited to build a fort that coul[MASK] protect the entrance from intru[MASK]ing enemy warships . A large vessel sailing into Charleston first had to cross Charleston Bar , a series of submerged shoals lying about 8 miles[MASK]( 13 km ) southeast of the city , and then pass by the southern end of Sullivan 's Island as it e[MASK]tered the channel to the inner harbor . Late[MASK] it would also have to pass the northern end of James Island , where Fort Johnson c[MASK]mmanded[MASK]the southeastern approach to t[MASK]e[MASK]city . Mo[MASK]ltrie and his 2nd South Carolina Regiment arrived on Sullivan 's Island in March 1776 , and began[MASK]con[MASK]truction of a fortress to defend[MASK]the island and the channel into Charleston Harbor . The construction moved slowly ; Captain Peter Horry of the Patr[MASK][MASK]t n[MASK]val deta[MASK]hment described the site as " an immense pen 500 feet long , and 16 feet wide , filled [MASK]ith sand to s[MASK]op the shot " . The gun platforms were made of planks two inches thick and fastened with wooden spikes . 
 Congress had appointe[MASK] General L[MASK]e to comman[MASK] the Continental Army troops in the southern colon[MASK]es , and his[MASK]movements by land shadowed those of Clinton 's fle[MASK][MASK] as it sailed [MASK]outh . Lee [MASK]rote from Wilmington on June 1 that the fleet had sailed , but that he did not know whether it was sailing for Virginia or South Carolina . He headed for Charleston , sayin[MASK] " [ I ] confes[MASK] I know not whether I shall go to or from the en[MASK]my . " He arrived in Charleston shortly after the fl[MASK]e[MASK] anchored outside the harbor , and took command of the city 's defenses . He immediately ran into a problem : the Sout[MASK] Carolina troops ( mil[MASK]tia or the colonial regiments ) were not[MASK]on the Con[MASK]inental line , and thus not formally under his authority . Some South Carolina troops resiste[MASK] his instructions , and Rutledge had to intervene by proclaiming Lee in command of all South Caroli[MASK]a f[MASK]rces . 
 Square[MASK]@-@ sh[MASK]ped Fort Sull[MASK]van consisted only of [MASK]he c[MASK]mpleted seaward [MASK]all , with walls[MASK]made from palmetto logs 20 feet ( 6 @.@ 1 m ) hi[MASK]h and [MASK]6 feet ( 4 @.@ 9 m ) wide . The walls were filled with sand , and rose 10 feet ( 3 @.@ 0 m ) above the wooden platfor[MASK]s [MASK]n which the artillery were mo[MASK]nted . A hastily er[MASK]cted palisade of thick planks helped guard the powder magazine a[MASK]d unfinished northern walls . An assortment of 31 can[MASK]on , rang[MASK]ng from 9- and 12 @-@ pounders to a few Briti[MASK]h 18 @-@ pounders and French 26 @-@ pounders ,[MASK]dotted the front and rear walls . Gener[MASK]l Lee , w[MASK]en he had seen its unfinished state , had recommended abandoning the fort , calling i[MASK] a " sl[MASK]ughter pen " . President Rutledge refuse[MASK] , and spe[MASK]ifically ordered Colonel Mou[MASK]trie to " obey [ Lee ] in everything , except in leaving Fort Sullivan " . Moultrie 's delaying tactics so angered Lee that [MASK]e decided on J[MASK]ne[MASK]27 that he would [MASK]eplace Moultrie ;[MASK]the battle began the next day before he could do so . Lee did[MASK]make plans for an orderly retre[MASK]t to Haddrell 's Point[MASK]. 
 
 = = = British arrival = =[MASK]= 
 
 The British fleet wei[MASK]he[MASK] anc[MASK]or at Cape Fear on May 31 , and arrived outside Charleston Harbor the next day . Moult[MASK]ie noticed a British scout boat apparently looking for pos[MASK]ible landing poi[MASK]ts on nearby Long Island ( now known as the Isle of Palms ) , just a few hundred yards from Sullivan 's Island ; troops were consequen[MASK]ly sent to occupy the northern end of Sullivan 's . By June 8 , most of the British fleet had cro[MASK]sed the bar and anchored in Five Fathom Hole , an anchorage between the bar and the harb[MASK]r entrance . With [MASK]he fort on Sullivan 's Island only [MASK]alf complete , Admiral Parker expressed confidence that his warship[MASK] would easily breach its walls . Optimistically believing he would not even need Clinton 's land forces , he wrote to Clinton that after the fort 's guns were knocked out , he would " land seamen and marines ( which I have practiced for the purpose ) under the guns " and that the[MASK] could " keep possession till you send as many troops as you thin[MASK] proper " . 
 The British fleet was co[MASK]posed of nine man @-@ of @[MASK]@ war ships : the flagship 50 @-@ gun Bristol , as well as the 5[MASK] @-@ gun Exper[MASK][MASK]ent and frigates Actaeon , Active , Solebay , Siren , Sphinx , Friendship and the bomb vessel Thunder , in total mounting nearly 300 cannon . The[MASK]army forces in the expedition consisted of the 15th , 28th , 33rd , 37th , 54th , and 57th Regiments of Foot , and part of the 46th . On June 7 , Clinton issued [MASK] proclamation calling on the r[MASK]bel colonists to lay down their arms . However , the inexperienced defenders fired on the boat sent[MASK]to de[MASK]iver it ( which was flying a truce flag ) , and it was not delivered until the next day . That same day , Clinton began landing 2 @,@ 200 troops on Long Isl[MASK]nd . The intent was that these troops would wa[MASK]e across [MASK]he channel ( now k[MASK]own as Breach Inlet ) betwe[MASK]n Long and Sullivan 's , which the British beli[MASK]ved to be suff[MASK]ciently shallow to do so , while the fleet bombarded Fort Sullivan . 
 General Lee responded to the British landing with several actions .[MASK]He began reinforcing positions on [MASK]he mainland in case the British were intending to launch an attack directly on Charleston . He also at[MASK]empted to build a bridge of boats to provide an avenue of retreat for the fort 's [MASK]arrison , but this failed becau[MASK]e there were not enough boats to bridge the ro[MASK]ghly one mile ( 1 @.@ 6 km ) channel separati[MASK]g the island from Charleston ; the unwillingness of M[MASK]ultrie and Rutledge to support the effort may also have played a role . [MASK]he Amer[MASK]cans also constructed an entrenchment at the nor[MASK]hern end of Sullivan 's Island , which was [MASK]anned by more than 7[MASK]0 men and three small cannons , and began to fortify a guard post at H[MASK]ddrell 's Point on the mainland opposite Fort Sullivan . 
 General Clinto[MASK] encountered the first major problem of the attack plan on June 17 . An attempt to wade the[MASK]channel [MASK]etween the two islands established that part of the channel was at least shoulder @-@ deep , too deep for troops to cross even without the prospect of ene[MASK]y oppositi[MASK]n . He considered u[MASK]ing boats to ferry the troops across [MASK] but the America[MASK]s , with[MASK]timely advice from General Lee ,[MASK]adopted a strong defensive position that was virtu[MASK]lly impossibl[MASK] to bombard [MASK]rom ships or th[MASK] Long Island position . As a result[MASK], the British and American forces faced each other across the channel , engaging in occasional and largely inconsequential cannon fire at long range . Clinton reported that this meant that Admiral Parker would have " the glory of being defeated alone . " The attack was o[MASK]iginally planned for J[MASK]ne 24 , but bad weather and contrary wind conditions prompted Parker to call it off for several days . [MASK] 
 = = Batt[MASK]e = = 
 
 On[MASK]the morning of June 28 , Fort Sullivan was defended by Colonel Moult[MASK]ie , commanding th[MASK] 2nd South Carolina Regiment and a company of the 4th South Carolina Artillery , numbering 435 men . A[MASK] around 9 : 00 am that morni[MASK]g , a British ship fired a signal gun indicating all was ready for the attack . Less t[MASK]an an hour later , nine warships had sailed into positi[MASK]ns facing the fort . Thunder and Friendship anchored about 1 @.@ 5 [MASK]iles ( 2 @.@ 4 km ) from the fort while Parker took [MASK]ctive , Bristol , Experimen[MASK] and Solebay to a closer position about 400 yards ( 370 m ) from Sullivan 's Isl[MASK]nd , where they anchored facing broadside to the fort . Each[MASK]of these ships began to fire upon the fort when it reach[MASK]d its position , and the defenders returned the fire . Although many of Thunder 's shots landed in or near the fort , they had little effect ; according to Moultrie , " We had a morass in the middle , that swa[MASK]lowed them up instantly , and those that fell in the s[MASK]nd in and about the fort , were immediately buried " . Thunder 's role in the action was also relatively short @-@ lived ; she had anchored too far away from t[MASK]e fort , and the o[MASK]erloading of her mortars with ex[MASK]ra pow[MASK]er to increase their range [MASK]ventually led to them breaking out of their mounts . Owing [MASK]o shortage of gunpowder , Moultrie 's men were deliberat[MASK] i[MASK] the pace of their gunfire , and only a few officers actually a[MASK]med the [MASK]annons . They also fired[MASK]in small volleys , four cannon at a tim[MASK] . One British observer wrote , " Their fire was surpr[MASK]singly well served " and it was " slow , but decisive indeed ; they were very cool and took care not to fire except their guns were exceedingly well directed . " 
 General Clinton began movements to cross over to the northern end of Sullivan 's Island . [MASK]ssisted by two [MASK]loops of war , [MASK]he flotilla of longboats carrying his troops came un[MASK]er fire f[MASK]om Colone[MASK] William Thomson 's defenses . Facing a with[MASK]ring barrag[MASK] of grape shot and rifle fire , Clinton abandoned the attempt . 
 Around noon t[MASK]e frigates Sphinx , Syren , and Actae[MASK]n w[MASK]re sent on a roundabout route[MASK], avoiding some shoals , to [MASK]ake a position from which[MASK]they could enfilade the fort 's main firing platform [MASK]nd also cover one of the main escape routes from the fort . However , all three ships grounded on an uncharted sandb[MASK]r , and the riggings o[MASK] Actaeon and Sphinx became[MASK]entangled in the process . T[MASK]e British managed to refloat Sphinx and Syren , [MASK]ut Acteon remain[MASK]d groun[MASK]ed , having moved too far onto the s[MASK]bmerged sand[MASK]ar . Consequently , none of these ships reached its intended position , a piece of go[MASK]d fo[MASK]tune not lost on Colonel Moultrie : " Had these three ships effected their p[MASK]rpose , they would have enfiladed us in such a manner , as to have dri[MASK]en us from our guns . " 
 At the fort , Moultrie ordered his men to concentr[MASK]te their fire on the two large man @-@ of @-@ war ships , Bristol and Experiment , which took hit after hit from the fort 's guns . Chain shot fired at Bristol eventually destroyed much of her ri[MASK]ging and severely damaged both the main- and mizzenmasts . One round [MASK]it her quarterdeck , slightly wounding Parker[MASK]in th[MASK] k[MASK]ee and thigh . The shot a[MASK]so tore off part of his britches , leaving his backside exposed . By mid @-@ afternoon , the defenders were running out of gunpowder , and their fire was briefly suspended . Howe[MASK]er , Lee sent more ammunition and gunpowder over from th[MASK] mainland , and the defenders resumed firing at the British ships ; Lee even briefly visited the fort late in the day , telling Colonel Moultrie , " I see you are d[MASK]ing very well here , you have no occasion for me , I will go up to the tow[MASK] again . " Admiral[MASK]Parker eventuall[MASK] sought to destroy the fort 's walls with persistent broadside cannonades .[MASK]This strategy failed due to the spongy nat[MASK]re of the [MASK]almetto wood used in its constructions[MASK]; the structure would quiv[MASK]r , and it absorbed the cannonballs rather than splintering . The exchange continued[MASK]until around 9 :[MASK]00 [MASK]m , w[MASK]en darkness forced a cessation of hostilities , and the fleet finally withdrew out of range . 
 At one point during[MASK]the b[MASK]ttle , the flag Moultrie had desig[MASK]ed and raised over[MASK]the fort was shot down . Sergeant William Jasper reportedly ran to the battlement and raised the flag again , holding it up and rallying the troops until a flag stand could be provided . He was credited by Moultrie with reviving the troops ' spirit[MASK] , and later given c[MASK]mmendations for bravery . A painting of this event ( pictured above ) depicts Jasper 's action[MASK] . 
 Count[MASK]ng casual[MASK]ies , Par[MASK]er reported 40 sa[MASK]lors killed and 71 wounded aboard Bristol , which was hit more than 70 times wi[MASK]h much damage to the hull , yards , and rigging . Experiment [MASK]as also badly damaged with 23 sailors killed and 56 wounded [MASK] Active and Solebay reported 15 ca[MASK]ualties each . The Americans rep[MASK]rted their casualties at only 12 killed and [MASK]5 wounded . The following morning , the British , unable to [MASK]rag the grounded Acteon off the sandbar , set fire to the ship to preve[MASK]t her from falling into enemy hands . Patri[MASK]ts in small boats sailed out[MASK]to the burning ship , fired some of its cannons[MASK]at[MASK]the British ships , took what stores and loot they could , and retreated shortly before the ship 's powder magazine exploded . 
 
 = = Aftermath =[MASK]= 
 
 The British did no[MASK][MASK]attempt to take the fort again . Within days of the battle , Charlestonians learned of the signing of [MASK]he Declaration of Independence in Philadelphia . The Br[MASK]tish troops were reembarked on [MASK]heir transports , and on July 21[MASK]the British fleet withdrew nor[MASK]hward to help the main British army in its campaig[MASK] against New Y[MASK]rk City . To a[MASK]d insult t[MASK] injury , one of the British transports grounded off Long Island and was c[MASK]ptured by Patriot forces . 
 The British did not[MASK]return to Charleston until 1780 , when General Clinton successfu[MASK]ly besieged the city and captured an entire army . Until the South again became a focus of the war in late 1778 , its states provided military s[MASK]pplies [MASK]o the northern war effort and produced trade goods that brought in valuable hard currency to fund the war effort . 
 Admiral Parker and General Clinton engaged in a war of wo[MASK]ds after the battle , each seeking to cast the blame on the other for the expedition 's failures . Although Clinton was not blamed by the government [MASK] popular opinion held him responsible , and Parker was lauded for his persona[MASK] bravery . 
 
 = = Legacy = = 
 
 Fort Sullivan was renam[MASK]d Fort Moultrie shortly after the batt[MASK]e t[MASK] honor Colonel William Moultrie for his successful defense of the fort and the city of Charleston [MASK] Extensi[MASK]ely modified in the years after t[MASK]e battle , it was supplanted by Fort Su[MASK]t[MASK]r as the principal defense of Charleston prior to the outbreak of the American Civil War . In 1876 , to celebrate the centennial , compani[MASK]s from Savannah , Augusta , Macon , Columbi[MASK] , New York and Boston w[MASK][MASK]e invited to Charleston . The site was turned over to the National Park Service in 1960 , and is now part of Fort Sumter National Monument . 
 A smal[MASK] monumen[MASK] to the Battle of Sullivan 's Isl[MASK]nd has been pla[MASK]ed at the northeastern tip of the island , over[MASK]ooking the inlet where General Clinton 's soldie[MASK]s had h[MASK]ped to cross . The monument includes historical markers describing the events surrounding the engagement . 
 One[MASK]iconic emb[MASK]em of th[MASK] battle was the flag designed[MASK]by Colonel[MASK]Moult[MASK]ie . Commissioned by the c[MASK][MASK]onial government , he designed a blue flag with a white crescent in the top left corner , which was flown at the fort during the battle . Despite being shot down during the siege , it[MASK]was seen as a symbol of this successful defense ( and famously raised during victory ) . It[MASK]came to be known as the Moultrie flag or Liberty Flag . When Charleston ( lost t[MASK] the Bri[MASK]ish in the 1780 siege ) was reclaimed by American forces[MASK]at the end of the war , the flag was returned to the[MASK]city by General Nathanael Greene . 
 
 
 = Hu Zhengyan = 
 
 Hu [MASK]hengyan ( [MASK]hine[MASK]e : 胡正言 ; c . 1584 – 1674 ) was a Chinese artist , printmaker and p[MASK]blisher . He w[MASK]rked in calli[MASK]r[MASK]phy , traditional Chinese p[MASK]inting , and seal @-@ carving , but was primarily a publisher , producing academic texts as well as records of his own work . 
 Hu lived in Nanjing during the transition from th[MASK] Ming dynast[MASK] to the Qing dynasty . A Ming loyalist , he was offered a[MASK]position at the rump court of the Hongguang Emperor , but declined the post , and never held anythi[MASK]g mo[MASK]e than minor political[MASK]office . He did , however , design the Hongguang Emperor 's[MASK]perso[MASK]al seal , and his loyalty to the dynasty was such that he largely retired fro[MASK] society after the emperor 's capture and death in 1645 .[MASK]He own[MASK]d and operated an academic publishing house called the Ten Bamboo Studio , in which he practised various multi @-@ colour printing and embossing techniques , and he employed several members of his f[MASK]mily in this enterprise . Hu 's work at the Ten Bamboo Studio pioneered new [MASK]echniques in colour printmaking , leading to delicate gradations of colour w[MASK]ich w[MASK]re not previously achiev[MASK]bl[MASK] in [MASK]his art form . 
 Hu is bes[MASK] known for his manual of painting entitled The Ten Bamboo Studio Man[MASK]al of Painting and Calligraphy , an artist 's primer which rema[MASK]ned in print for around 200 years . His studio also published seal catalogues , ac[MASK]demic and medical texts , books on poetry , and decorative writing papers . Many of these were edited and prefaced by Hu and his broth[MASK]rs . 
 
 = = Biography = = 
 
 Hu was born in Xiuning Cou[MASK]ty , Anhui Province in 1584 or [MASK]arly 1585 . Both his [MASK]ather and elder brother Zhengxin ( 正心 , art name Wusuo , 無所 ) were physicians , and after he turned 30 he travelle[MASK] with them while they practised medicine in the areas around[MASK]Lu 'an and Huoshan . It is commonly stated that Zhengyan himself wa[MASK] also a doctor , though the earliest sources atte[MASK]ting to this[MASK]occur only in t[MASK]e second half of the 19th century . 
 By 1619 , Hu had moved to Nanjing where he lived with his wife Wu . Their home on Jilongshan ( 雞籠[MASK] , now also known as B[MASK]iji Ge ) ,[MASK]a hill located just wit[MASK]in the northern city wa[MASK]l , served as a meeting @-@ house for like @-@ mi[MASK]ded artists .[MASK]H[MASK] named it the Ten Bamboo [MASK]tudio ( Shizhuz[MASK]a[MASK] , 十竹齋 ) , after the ten bamboo plants that grew in front of the property . It fu[MASK]ctioned as the headquarters for [MASK]is printing business , where he emplo[MASK]ed ten artisans including his two brothers[MASK]Zhen[MASK]xin and Zhengxing ( 正行 , art name Zizhu , 子著 ) and his sons Qipu ( 其樸 ) and Qiyi ( 其毅 , courtesy name 致果 ) . 
 During Hu 's lifetime , the Ming dynasty , which ha[MASK] ruled China for over 250 years , was overthrown and replaced by China 's last imperial dynasty , the Qing . Following the fall of the capital Beijing in 1644 , remnants of the imperial[MASK]family and a few minister[MASK] set up a Ming loyalist regime in N[MASK]njing with Zhu Yousong on the thron[MASK] as the Hong[MASK]uang Emperor .[MASK]Hu , who was noted for his seal @-@ carving and facility with seal script , created a seal for the new Emperor . The court offered him the position of Drafter for the Secretariat[MASK]( zhongshu sheren , 中書舍人 ) as a reward , but [MASK]e did not accept the role ( although he did accord hims[MASK]l[MASK] the title of zh[MASK][MASK]gshu sheren in some of his subsequent persona[MASK] seals ) . 
 According to Wen Ruilin 's Lost[MASK]History of the South ( Nanjiang Yishi , 南疆繹史 ) , prior to the Qing invasion of Nanjing Hu studied at the National University there , and wh[MASK]lst a student was employed by the Ministry of Rites to record official proclamations ; he produced the Imperial Promo[MASK]ion of Minor Learning ( Qin Ban Xiaoxue , 御頒小學 ) and [MASK]he Record of Displa[MASK]ed Loyalty ( Biaozhong Ji , 表忠記 ) as par[MASK] of this work . As a result , he was promoted to the Ministry of Personnel and gained admittance to the Hanlin Academy , but before he could take up this appointment , Beijing had fallen to the Manchu rebellion . Sinc[MASK] contemporaneous biograp[MASK]ies ( Wen 's work was not published [MASK]ntil 1830 ) make no mention of these events , it has been suggested that they were fabricated after Hu 's death . 
 Hu retired from pu[MASK]lic life[MASK]and went into seclusi[MASK]n in 1646 , after the[MASK]end of the Ming dynasty . Xiao Yuncong and Lü Liuliang recorded visiting him dur[MASK]ng his later years , in 1667 and 1673 respectively . He died in poverty [MASK]t the age of 90 , sometime around late 1673 or early 1674 . 
[MASK]
 = = Seal @-@ carving = = 
 
 H[MASK][MASK]Zhengyan was a noted seal @-@ carver , producing personal seals[MASK]for numerous dignitaries . His style was rooted in the classical seal script of the Han dynasty , and he followed the Huizhou school of carving founded by his contemporary He Zhen [MASK] Hu 's calligraphy , although balanced and with a cl[MASK]ar compositional structure , is somewh[MASK]t more angular and rigid than the classical models he fol[MASK]owed . Hu[MASK]zhou seals a[MASK]tempt to impart an ancient , weathered impression , a[MASK]though unlike other Huizhou artists Hu di[MASK] not make a regular practice of artificially aging his s[MASK]als . 
 Hu 's work was known outside his local area[MASK]. Zhou Lianggong , a poet who lived in Nanjing around the same time as Hu and was a noted art connoisseur , stated in his Biography of Seal @-@ Carvers ( Y[MASK]nren Zhuan , 印人傳 ) that Hu " creates miniature stone [MASK]arvings with ancient seal inscriptions for tra[MASK]ellers to fight over and treasure " , implying that his carvings were popular with visitors and t[MASK]avellers passing through Nanjing . 
 In 1644 , Hu took[MASK]it upon himself to create a new Imperial seal for the Hongguang Emperor , which h[MASK] carved after a period of fasting and pr[MASK]yer . He presented his creation with an essay , the Great Exhortation of the Seal ( Dabao Zhen , 大寶印 ) , in which he bemoan[MASK]d the l[MASK]ss of the Chongzhen Emperor[MASK]'s seal and begged Heaven 's favour in restoring it . Hu was concerned that his essay would be overlooked because he had not writt[MASK]n it in the form of rhyming , equ[MASK]lly @-@ footed couplets ( pianti , 駢體 ) used[MASK]in the Imperial examinations , but his submission and[MASK]the seal itself were ne[MASK]e[MASK]theless both accepted by[MASK]the Southern Ming c[MASK]urt . 
 
 = = Ten Bamboo Studio = = 
 
 Despite his reputation as an artist and seal @-@ carver , Hu was primarily a publisher . H[MASK]s publishing ho[MASK]se , the Ten Bamboo Studio , produced reference works on calligraphy , poetry and[MASK]art ; medical textbooks ; books on etymology and pho[MASK]etics ; and copies of as well as commentaries on the Confucian Classics . Unlike o[MASK]her publisher[MASK] in the area , the Te[MASK] Bamboo Studio did not pub[MASK]ish works o[MASK] [MASK]arrative fiction such as plays or novels . This bias towards academia was likely a consequence of the studio 's loc[MASK]tion : the mountain on which Hu took up residence was just to the north of the Nanjing G[MASK]ozijian ( National Academy ) , which provided a captiv[MASK] m[MASK]rket for academic texts . Between 1627 a[MASK]d[MASK]1644 , [MASK]he Ten Bamboo Studio produced over twenty printed books of this kind , aimed at a wealthy , literary audience . The studio 's earlie[MASK]t publications were medical textbooks , the first of which , Tested Prescriptions for Myriad Illnesses ( Wanbing Yanfang , 萬病驗方 ) was published in 1631 and proved popular enough to be reissued [MASK]en years later . Hu 's brother Zhengxin was a medical[MASK]practitioner and appears to have been the author of these books . 
 Durin[MASK][MASK]the 1630s the Ten Bamboo Studio also produced politica[MASK] works extollin[MASK] the rule of the Ming ; these in[MASK]luded the Imperial Ming Record of Loyalty ( Huang Ming Biaozhong Ji , 皇明表忠紀 ) , a biography of l[MASK]yal Ming officials , and th[MASK] Edicts [MASK]f the Imperial Ming ( Huang Ming Zha[MASK]zhi , 皇明詔制 ) , a list of Imperial proclamat[MASK]ons . After the fall of the Ming Dynasty , Hu renamed the studio the Hall Rooted in the Past ([MASK]Digutang , 迪古堂 ) as a sign of his affiliation with the prev[MASK]ous dynasty , althoug[MASK] the Ten Bamboo imprint continued to be used . Despite Hu 's withdrawal from society after 1646 , the studio continued to publish [MASK]ell into the Qing dynasty[MASK], for the most part focussing on seal impression catalogues showcas[MASK]ng Hu 's carving work . 
 The Ming dynasty had seen considerable advancement in the process of colour printing in China . At his studio , Hu Zhengyan experi[MASK]en[MASK]ed with various forms of woodblock printing , creating processes for producing multi @-@ coloured prints and embossed printed designs . As a result , he was able to produce some of China 's first printed publication[MASK] i[MASK] colo[MASK]r , using a block printing technique known as " assorted block printing " ( douban yinshua , 饾板印刷 ) . This system made use of m[MASK]lti[MASK]le blocks ,[MASK]each car[MASK]ed with a different part of the final image and each bearing a dif[MASK]erent c[MASK]lour . It was a lengthy , pai[MASK]staking process , requiring t[MASK]irty to fifty engraved [MASK]rinting blocks and up to [MASK]eventy inkings and impressions to crea[MASK]e[MASK]a single image . Hu also employed a related form of multiple @-@ block printing called " set @-@ block printing " ( taoban yinshua , 套板印刷 ) , which had existed since the [MASK]uan period some 200 years earlier but had only recently come into fashion again . He refined these block[MASK]printing techniques by de[MASK]eloping a process for wiping some of the ink off the blocks before printi[MASK]g ; this enabled h[MASK]m to achieve gradation and modulation[MASK]of shades whi[MASK]h were not previously possible . 
 In some images , Hu employed a blind embossing techni[MASK]ue ( know[MASK] [MASK]s " embossed designs " ( gonghua , 拱花 ) or " embossed blocks " ( gongban , 拱板 ) , using an uninked , imprinted block to stamp designs onto paper . He used this to create white relief effects for clouds and for high[MASK]ights on water or plants . This was a relatively new process , havin[MASK] been invented by Hu 's contemporary Wu Faxia[MASK]g , who was also a Nanjing @-@ based publisher . Wu[MASK]had used this technique for the first time in his book Wist[MASK]ria St[MASK]dio Letter Pap[MASK]r ( Luoxuan Biangu Jianpu , 蘿軒變古箋譜 ) , published in 1626 . Both Hu a[MASK]d Wu used embossing to cre[MASK]te decorat[MASK]ve[MASK]writ[MASK]ng papers , the sale of which provided a sideline i[MASK]come for the Ten Bamboo Studio . 
 
 = = [MASK]ajor works = = 
 
 Hu 's most n[MASK]table work is the Ten Bamboo Studio Manual of Painting and Calligraphy ( Shizhu[MASK]hai Shuhuapu , 十竹齋書畫譜 ) , an anthology of around 320 pr[MASK]nts by ar[MASK]und thirty different artists ( including Hu[MASK]himself ) , published in 1633 . It consists of eight sections , covering calligraphy , bamboo , flowers , rocks , birds and animals , plums , orchids and fruit . Some of these se[MASK]tions ha[MASK] been relea[MASK]ed previously as single volumes . As well as a collection of artworks , it was also intended as an artistic primer , with instructio[MASK]s on correct brush position a[MASK]d technique and several pictures designed for beginners to copy . Although these instructions only appear in the sections on orchids and bamboo , the book still remains the f[MASK]rst example of a categ[MASK]rical and analytic[MASK][MASK] approach to Chinese painting . In this b[MASK]ok , Hu used his multiple @-@ block pri[MASK]ting methods to obtain gradations of colour in the images , rather than obvious outlines or overlaps . The manual is bound in the " butterfly binding " ( hudie zhuang , 蝴蝶裝 ) style , [MASK]hereby whole @-@ foli[MASK] illust[MASK]ations are folded so t[MASK]at each occupies a double @-@[MASK]page spread . Th[MASK]s [MASK]inding style allows the reader to lay the [MASK]ook flat in [MASK]rder to look at a par[MASK]icular image . Cambridge University Library released a com[MASK][MASK]ete digital scan of the manual , including all[MASK]writings and illustrations in August , 2015 . Said Charles Ayl[MASK]er , Head of the Cambridge University Chinese Department , " The binding is so fragile , and the manual so delicate , that until it was digitized , we have never been a[MASK]le to let anyone look through it or study it – despite its undoubted importance to s[MASK]holars . " 
 This volume went on to influence colour printing across[MASK]China [MASK] where it paved the way for the later but b[MASK]tter @-@ known Manual of the Mustard Seed Garden ( Jieziyuan Huazhuan 芥子園畫傳 ) , and also in Japan[MASK], where it was reprinted and foreshadowed the development in ukiyo @-@ e of the colour woodblock[MASK]printing proc[MASK]ss known as nishiki @-@ e 錦絵 . The popularit[MASK] of the Ten Bamboo Studio Manual was such that print run[MASK] continued to be produced all the way through to the late Qing dynasty . 
 Hu also produced the work Ten Bamboo Studio Letter Paper ( Shizhuzhai Jianpu , 十竹齋箋譜 ) , a collection of[MASK]paper samples , whic[MASK] made use of the gonghua stampe[MASK] embossing technique to make the illustrations stand o[MASK]t in relief . Whilst pr[MASK]marily a catalogue of deco[MASK]ative writing papers , it also contained p[MASK]intings of rocks , people , ritual vessels and other sub[MASK]ects . The bo[MASK]k was bound in[MASK]the " wrapped back " ( baobei zhuang , 包背裝 [MASK] style ,[MASK]in wh[MASK]ch[MASK]the folio pages ar[MASK] folded , stacked , and sewn along the open edges . Originally published in 1644 , it was reissued in four volumes between 1934 and 1941 by Zheng Zhenduo and Lu Xun , and revised and republished again in 1952 . 
 
 = = = Other publ[MASK]cations = = = 
 
 Other works produced by Hu 's studio included a reprint of Zhou Boqi '[MASK] manual of seal @-@ scrip[MASK] calligraphy ,[MASK]The Six Styles of Calligraphy , Correc[MASK] and Erroneous ( Lius[MASK]u Zheng 'e , 六書正譌 ) and the related Necessary Investigations int[MASK] Calligraphy ( Shufa Bi Ji , 書法必稽 ) , which discussed comm[MASK]n errors in th[MASK] formation of characters . With his brother Zhengxin , Hu edited a new introductory edition of the Confucian classics , entitled The St[MASK]ndardised Te[MASK]t of the Four Books , Identified and Corrected ( Sishu Dingben Bianzheng [MASK] 四書定[MASK]辨正 ) ( 1640 ) , giving the correct formation and pronunciation of the text . A similar approach was taken with th[MASK] Essentials of the Thousand Character C[MASK]assic in Six[MASK]Scripts ( Qianwen Liushu Tongyao , 千文六書統要 ) ( 1663 ) , which Hu compiled with the aid of his calligraphy teacher , Li Den[MASK] . It was published after[MASK]Li 's[MASK]death , partly in homage to him . 
 The three Hu brot[MASK]ers worked together to co[MASK]late a student primer on poetry by their contemporary Ye Tingxiu , wh[MASK]ch was called[MASK]sim[MASK]ly the Discussion of Poetry ( Shi Tan , 詩譚 ) ( 1635 ) . Other works on poetry from the studio included Helpful Principles to the Subtle Workings of Selected Ta[MASK]g Poems ( Leixuan Tang Shi Zhudao Weiji , 類選唐詩助道微機 ) , [MASK]hich was a compilation of several works on poetry and incl[MASK]ded[MASK]colophons by[MASK]Hu Zhengyan himself [MASK] 
 Among the studio 's more obscure publications was[MASK]a text on Chinese dominoes entitled Pai[MASK]ong Fuyu ( 牌統浮玉 ) , written under a pseudonym but [MASK]ith a preface by Hu Zhengyan .

 = Raid on Manila ( 1798 ) = 
 
 The Raid on Manila of January 1798 was a Royal Navy false flag[MASK]milita[MASK]y operation during the Frenc[MASK] Revoluti[MASK]nary Wars intended to scout the st[MASK]ength of the defences of Manila , capital of the Spanish Philippines , capture a Manila galleon and assess the condition of the Spanish Navy squa[MASK]ron maintained in the port . Spain had transfo[MASK]med from an ally[MASK]of Great B[MASK]itain in the War of the First Coalition into an enemy in 1796 . Thus the presence of a po[MASK]erful Spanish squadron at Manila posed a threat to the Chin[MASK] Fle[MASK]t , an annual [MASK]onvoy of East[MASK]Indiaman merchant ships from Macau in Qin[MASK] Dynasty China to Britain , which was of vital economic importanc[MASK] to Britain . So severe was this threat that a major invasion of the Spanish Philippines had been [MASK]lanned from Britis[MASK] India during 1797 , but [MASK]ad been called[MASK]off following the [MASK]reaty[MASK]of Campo For[MASK]io in Eur[MASK]pe and [MASK]he possibility of a major war in India between the British East I[MASK]dia Company and t[MASK]e Kingdom of Mysore . 
 To ensure the safety of the merchant ships gathering at Macau in the winter of 179[MASK][MASK]– 98 , the British commander in the East Indies , Rear @-@ Admiral Peter Rainier , sent a convoy to China escorted by the frigates HMS Sybille and HMS Fox and commanded[MASK]by Captain Edward Cooke . After co[MASK]pleting his mission Cooke decided to [MASK]nvestigate the state of readiness o[MASK] Spanish forces in Manila himself . He was al[MASK]o intrigued[MASK]by reports that a ship carrying treasure was due to sail from Manila , which would make a valuable prize . Sailing in Sybille and accompanied by Captain [MASK]ulteney Malcolm in Fox , Cooke reached the Spanish capital [MASK]n 13 January 1798 . 
 Anchored in Manila Bay , Cooke pretended that his ships were French[MASK]vessels and[MASK]successf[MASK]lly lured successive boatloads of Spanish officials aboard , taking them prisoner in tur[MASK] . Once he had determined from his captives the state of defences in Manila , that the treasure ship had been unloaded at Cavite and that the Spanish squadron was undergoi[MASK]g extensive repairs and thus unavailable for operations , he sent a raiding pa[MASK]ty against a squadron of gun[MASK]oats in the mouth of the Pasig River . Captu[MASK]ing the gunboats in a b[MASK]oodless at[MASK]ack[MASK], Cooke then released his prisoners and sailed southwards , unsuccessfully assaulting Zamboan[MASK]a before return[MASK]ng to Macau . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 In 1796 , after three y[MASK][MASK]rs of the French Revolutionary Wars , Spain and the French Republic signe[MASK] the Treaty of San Ildefonso . The sec[MASK]et terms of this treaty required Spain to renounce its allian[MASK]e with Great Britain and subsequently to declare war on its former ally . In the East Indies this shift of political allegiance me[MASK]nt that the dominant B[MASK]itish forces in the region were face[MASK] with the threat of attack fr[MASK]m the Spanish Philippines to the east . Britain dominated the East Indies in 1796 , controlling the trade routes through the[MASK]Indian Ocean from the ports of Bombay , Madras a[MASK]d[MASK]Calcutta . D[MASK]tch Ceylon , the Dutch Cape Colony and parts of the Dutch [MASK]ast Indies had been captured in 1795 , and the French presence in the region had been confined to Île de France and a few subsidiary islands in the Western Indian Ocean . 
 Some of the most important trade routes began at Canton and Ma[MASK]au [MASK]n Qing Dynasty China . Early in each year a large [MASK]onvoy kno[MASK]n as the[MASK]" Chin[MASK] Fleet " , composed of large East[MASK]Indiaman merchant ships in the employ of the British East India Company , sailed westwards to Euro[MASK]e from Macau laden with tea and other commercial cargo . This convoy was economically s[MASK]g[MASK]ificant to Britain :[MASK]one convoy in 1804 was valued at over £ 8 million ( the equivalen[MASK] of £ 600 @,@ 000 @,@ 000 as of 20[MASK]6 ) . In January [MASK]797 the convoy had been attacked by the French squadron in the East Indies , comprising six frigates commande[MASK] by Contre @-@ amiral Pierre César Charles de Sercey . In the ensuing Bali Strait Incident the commander deceived Sercey into believing th[MASK]t the unescor[MASK]ed convoy contained disguised ships of the line and the French admiral retre[MASK]ted , only learning of his error on his return to Île de France . There was considerable concern in India that Sercey might try again in 179[MASK] , or that the Spanish , who maintained a p[MASK]werful squ[MASK]dron at Cavite [MASK] might make an attempt of [MASK]heir o[MASK]n . 
 Rainier 's initial impulse on [MASK]earning in November 1796 of the impending d[MASK]claration of war between Britain and Spain was to draw [MASK]p plans for[MASK]a major invasion of the Phil[MASK]ppines , centred on M[MASK]nila in repeti[MASK]ion of the successful British [MASK]apture o[MASK] Ma[MASK][MASK]la in 1762 . Co @-@ operating with the Governor @-@ Ge[MASK]eral of India Sir John Shore and Colonel Arthur Welleley among others , a sub[MASK]tantial naval and military forces were earmarke[MASK] for the ope[MASK]at[MASK]on which was in th[MASK] advance planning [MASK]tages , when unexpected news arrived[MASK]in India in August 1797 [MASK]nnouncing the Treaty[MASK][MASK]f Camp[MASK] Formio[MASK]which brought the War of the First Coalition to an end . Britain[MASK]now[MASK]faced Fran[MASK]e and Spain alone , while emissaries from the Tipu Sultan of the Kingdom of Mysore , an old opponent of Britain in So[MASK]thern India , were seeking French ass[MASK]stance wi[MASK]h a renewed outbreak of hostil[MASK]ties .[MASK]The [MASK]esources planned for the operation aga[MASK]nst Manila were therefore retai[MASK]ed in India and the ope[MASK]ation cancelled , but the p[MASK]otectio[MASK] of the China Fleet was still essential and Rainier diverted some of his squa[MASK]ron eastwards to China . 
 A number of merchant ships had gathered at Bombay in the spring of 1797 in preparation for the trip to Macau to loa[MASK] trade goods and join the China Fleet . To escort this force , Rainier provided the 40 @-@ gun frigate HMS [MASK]ybille , captured from the French at the Battle of Mykonos in 1794 , a[MASK]d the 50 @-@ gun HMS Centurion , [MASK]hich sailed with the convoy in July [MASK] taking pas[MASK]age through the Straits o[MASK] Malacca , joined there by the ships of the line HMS Vi[MASK]torious and HMS Trident and the 32 @-@ gun frigate HMS Fox unde[MASK] Captain Pulteney Malcolm for the[MASK]final voy[MASK]ge to Macau . The convoy arrived without incident on 13 December 17[MASK]7 , although the crew[MASK] had been subst[MASK]ntially weakened by tropical illnesses . 
 
 = = Cooke 's ra[MASK]ds = = 
 
 
 = = = Reconnaissance of Mani[MASK]la = = = 
 
 With his convoy safely at [MASK]nchor in Macau and the China Fleet several weeks from sailing , Cooke decided to reconnoitre [MASK]anila and mak[MASK] obse[MASK]vati[MASK]ns on the port and the Spanish squadron[MASK]based there . As an added motivation , rumours in Macau suggested tha[MASK] the annual Manila galleon was du[MASK] to arrive . This ship brought up to two million Spanish silver dollars[MASK]from Acapulco a[MASK]ross the Pacific Oce[MASK]n stopping at Guam on its way to Manila . Depositing its dollars in the Philippines , the ship then loaded trade goods from the East Indies for the return journey to New Spain . This round trip was essential to the maintenance of the Spanish Empire in[MASK]th[MASK] East Indi[MASK]s , which[MASK]operated at an enormous financial lo[MASK]s only mitigated by the substantial subsidy f[MASK]om New S[MASK]ain . S[MASK]anish dollars were the accepted currency across [MASK]ost of the East Indies , and disrup[MASK]ion of this [MASK]inancial system could have profou[MASK]d effects on re[MASK]ional trade ; but British sailors had nevertheless been attacking t[MASK]e Manila galleons since Thomas Cavendish in 1587 . 
 Leaving the heavier w[MASK]rships at Macau , Cooke sailed on 5 January 1798 only with Sybille and Fox , the latter carrying a Mr. Bernard , an experience[MASK] linguist . Passing Luzon , Cooke 's ships encountered[MASK]a small Spanish merchant vessel , which was lured towards the frigates , which [MASK]ere flying French tricolors . [MASK]eizing the Spanish vessel , Cooke closely questioned the [MASK]aptain and [MASK]earned that most of the Spanish squa[MASK]ron in Manila were undergoing extensive repairs at Cavite and were unfit to s[MASK]il . Cooke rewarded the captain by releasing his vessel with its cargo intact , although he did remove 3 @,@ 900 silver dollars . The Spanish squadr[MASK]n had suffere[MASK] badly in a typhoon in April 1797 and much of the damage had still not been repaired by the time Cooke 's small squadron arrived off Manila . Cooke had taken precautions to disguise his s[MASK]ips as French vessels , modelling Sybil[MASK]e o[MASK] th[MASK] powerful 40 @-@ gun Forte and Fox on the smaller Prudente . 
 
 = = = Dinner on Sybille = = = 
 
 Late in the afternoon of 13 January 1798 , [MASK]ybille and Fox arrived in Manila Bay , slipping unchallenged past the fortress of Corregidor and then sailing across the bay on the [MASK]orning of 14 January , anchoring betwee[MASK] Manila and Cavite . From his vantage point Cooke could see the Spanish squadron disma[MASK]ted and under repair in Cavite , the ships of the line San Pedro , Eur[MASK]pa and Mo[MASK]tañés and the frigates Maria [MASK]e la Cabeya and Luisa [MASK]n dock and unfit for action .[MASK]To[MASK]Cooke 's disappointment he could also see t[MASK]e Manila galleon , Marquesetta being unloaded at the Cavite docks and another valuable merchant ship Rey Carlos aground in the harbour . The Span[MASK]sh had learne[MASK] only shortly before Cooke 's arrival that the British frigate HMS Resistance under Cap[MASK]ain Edward Pakenham was in P[MASK]ilippine wat[MASK]rs and h[MASK]d decided to remove the valuable cargo from the treasure ship rather than risk an attack . 
 Fox was the first British ship into the anchorage , and was consequen[MASK]ly approached by the[MASK]guardb[MASK]at , who[MASK]e crew came aboard [MASK] Malcolm , lik[MASK] [MASK]ooke , spoke French fluently and w[MASK]th Bernard translatin[MASK] was able to[MASK]persuade the officer in charge that the new arrivals were Forte and Prudente seeking supplies and Spanish re[MASK]nforcements for[MASK]commerce raiding operations . The officer offered supplies but cautioned that none of the Spanish ships would be [MASK]n a position to sail until March at the earliest . Cooke [MASK]hen joined the party on the deck of Fox , claiming to be Commodore Latour , a French officer who , [MASK]nknown to the S[MASK]anish , had been killed in the Action of 9 September 1796 off Sumatra . The[MASK]Spanish officer was now completely convinced by the ruse , which h[MASK]d been augmented by fake French uniforms . Inviting the visitor below decks , Cooke the[MASK] passed wine arou[MASK]d and together they drank a series of toasts , includin[MASK] " the do[MASK]nfall of England " . 
 For an hour the officer[MASK] drank , Malcolm and Cooke le[MASK]rning detailed informat[MASK]o[MASK] about the state of the defences and squadron in the Philippines , until a second boat p[MASK]lled alongside Fox containing more officers keen to greet the French arrivals . This vessel was the personal barge of the Spanish commander at Cavite , Rear @-@ Ad[MASK]iral Don Ignacio María de Álava , who was not aboard , [MASK]ut who se[MASK]t a message[MASK]via an aide in a third boat . Eac[MASK] time , the officers were [MASK]scorted below to join the festivities whereupon their crews were[MASK]seized at gunpoint and taken be[MASK]ow decks as prisoners [MASK]f war . In Malcolm 's cabin , the captured officers were informed of their situation , promised release [MASK]efore the British frigates sailed , and offered mo[MASK]e wine . The crew of Fox meanwhil[MASK] forced the captured Spanish sailors to strip and donned the[MASK]r clothing . Climbin[MASK] into the Spanish boats this pa[MASK]ty rowed for the mou[MASK]h of the nearby P[MASK]sig River , where they had learned that three heavy gunboats were moored . Taking the crews b[MASK] surprise , the B[MASK]itis[MASK] boarding parties drove off the Spanish without a fight and brought all thr[MASK]e boa[MASK]s al[MASK]ngside Fox . These[MASK]vessels normally carried crews [MASK]f thirty and were well @-@ armed ,[MASK]one with a 32 @-@ pounder long gun and two with 24 @-@ pounder long guns , each supplemented by four swivel guns . 
 The harbour captain reached Fox shortly afterwards [MASK] furious at the seizure of the gunboats and de[MASK]anding they be returned . Malcolm received him with a tirade of near incomprehensible Fr[MASK]nch[MASK]and brought him to join the other captured officers in his cabin , while [MASK]he boat 's crew were imprisoned below decks . Shortly afterwards , at 16 : 00 , Cooke and Malcolm hosted a large dinner fo[MASK] their officer captives and sent[MASK]food and grog to the crew , the total number of Spanish sailors on Fox now numbering approximately 200 . Once the me[MASK]l was finished , Cooke allowed al[MASK] of the captives to return to their boats and row for shore without the conditions of parole , alth[MASK]ugh he retained the captur[MASK]d gunboats . 
 
 = = = Zamboanga = = = 
 
 Cooke[MASK]led his small squadron past Corregidor on 15 January and turn[MASK]d south . Four days[MASK]later in a storm one of the gunboats broke its tow line and was neve[MASK] seen again , lost with its twelve crew . The f[MASK]igates subsequ[MASK]ntly scouted Mindanao before reaching Zamboanga on 22 January . There Cooke raised Spanish colo[MASK]rs in an attempt to deceive the authorities into supplying food and water to his squadron but Sybille grounded on a san[MASK]bank at the entrance to the po[MASK]t which raised th[MASK] suspi[MASK]ions of a guardboat sent by the governor of Zamboanga , Raymundo Español . The captain[MASK]of the Spanish boat asked the British ships the names of their captains , an[MASK] on recei[MASK]ing no answer but [MASK] volley of rifle fire , he put the [MASK]own on alert [MASK] With the defenders fore[MASK]arned , Cooke abandoned his ruse and after ref[MASK]oati[MASK]g Sybille the following morning , ordered a bo[MASK]bardment of[MASK]the fort protecting the harbour . This had little effect , though late[MASK] the Spanish recovered at least 450 cannonballs from different calibers , [MASK]nd Malcolm then attempted an amphibious landing in order to stor[MASK] the landward side of the fort . The boats came under heavy fire , one smashed by a cannonball , killing two and wounding four . Another boat gr[MASK]unded on a sandbar and became stuck ; so with his force in [MASK]isarray , as 250 villagers armed with lances ambushed and drove the British from the [MASK]each , Malcolm called off the operation . After ex[MASK]hanging shot for an hour both friga[MASK]es cut their anch[MASK]r cables and retreated out of range , wit[MASK] two de[MASK]d and one w[MASK]unded on Sybille and eight wounded on Fo[MASK] , in addition to [MASK]hose lost i[MASK] the b[MASK]ats . The defender[MASK] lo[MASK]t a single man killed and 4 wounded . 
 With his frigates now requiring[MASK]repairs , Cooke withdraw half a league from Zamboanga and spent three days refitting the masts and rigging of the ships . Then[MASK]he sailed north , scuttling the two remaining gunboats as he did not believe they would survive th[MASK] return journey to Canton . Four days later ,[MASK]on 27 January the squadron halted at a village named " Pullock " in the north of the Sultanate of Maguindanao to collect fresh water . On the beach a boat party from[MASK]Sybille was set upon by Lumad tribesmen [MASK] Two were killed and nine others taken ca[MASK]tive and d[MASK]agged into the forest before rescuers could arrive [MASK] Cooke complained to Sultan Kibab Sahriyal at Kuta Wato and th[MASK] capt[MASK]red sailors were eventually recovered , although not [MASK]efore [MASK]ybill[MASK] and[MASK]Fox had sailed for China to escort the merchant convoy back to India . 
 
 = = Aftermath = = 
 
 Cooke 's opportunistic diversion had determined that the Spanish forces in the Philippines posed no immediate threat , although the mission had cost 18 lives : Admiral Rainier later expressed his satisfaction with the outcome in a letter to the Admiralty [MASK][MASK]More might have been achieved with reinforcements : Histori[MASK]n C. Northc[MASK][MASK]e Parkinson suggests that had Cooke 's squadron united with Resistance together they may have [MASK]een able to destroy the disarm[MASK]d Spanish warships at Cavite . He also notes however that[MASK]in this scen[MASK]rio P[MASK]ke[MASK]ham would hav[MASK] been commanding officer , a man wit[MASK] considerably less imagination and guile than Cooke . Historian Richard Woodman was criti[MASK]al of[MASK]the mission , cons[MASK]dering the operation to have " no glorious outcome " and citing the failure to capture the treasure[MASK]ships as its greatest[MASK]short @-@ coming . 
 The 1798 China Fleet sailed wi[MASK]hout further incident [MASK] During the ensuing year Resistan[MASK]e was destroyed by an accidental[MASK]explosi[MASK]n in July in the Bangka Strait , a[MASK]d the majority of Rainier 's force[MASK] were focused on disrupting the French occupation of[MASK]Suez in the Red Sea . This diversion of British resources created gaps in the c[MASK]verage in merchant shipping and Ser[MASK]ey was able [MASK]o send the frigate Preneuse and corvette Brûle @-@ Gueule to Mani[MASK]a late in the year to join the repaired Spanish squadro[MASK] . At the beginning of February 1799[MASK], this combined force sailed to Macau , taking the British defences by surprise . The Britis[MASK] commander Capt[MASK]in[MASK]Wil[MASK]iam Hargood counterattack[MASK]d , advancing on the Franco @-[MASK] Spanish force which retreated during the day and disappeared under cover of darkness that evening in the Wanshan Archipelago . The combined squadron then dispersed and the China Fle[MASK]t was not atta[MASK]ked again until the Battle of Pulo Aura in 1804 , at which a French squadron was again driven off [MASK]n confusion . The frigates Cooke had mimicked , Forte and Prudente were sent to operate independently agai[MASK]st British trade in the Indian Ocean in early 1799 . Prudente [MASK]as captured by HMS Daedalus at the Action of 9 February 1799 near Southern Africa , and Forte was intercepted by HMS Sybille under Cooke on 2[MASK] February near Balasore in Bengal . In the ensuin[MASK] ba[MASK]tle Forte was captured but Cooke mortally wounded , dying on[MASK]25 May . 
 
 
 = B of the Bang = 
 
 B of t[MASK]e B[MASK]ng was a sculpture by Thomas Heatherwick next to the City of Manchester Stadium in Manche[MASK][MASK]er , Eng[MASK]and , which was commissioned to mark the 2002 Commonwealth [MASK]ames ; it was one of the talle[MASK]t structures in Manches[MASK]er and the tallest sculpture in the UK until the completion of Aspire in 2008 . It was taller[MASK]and leaned at a greater angle t[MASK]an the Leaning[MASK]Tower of Pisa . The sculptu[MASK]e took its name from a quotation of British sprinter Linford Christie , in which he said that he starte[MASK] his races not merely at the " bang " [MASK]f the starting pistol , but at " the B of the Bang " . 
 The sculpture was commissioned in 2003 ; construction overran and the official unveiling was delayed until 12 January 2005 . Six days before the launch , the sculpture suffered the first of three visible structural problems as the tip of one [MASK]f the spikes detached and fell to the ground . Legal action start[MASK]d a year later , resulting in [MASK]n out @-@ of @-@ court settlement totalling £ 1 @.@ 7 milli[MASK]n . 
 In Februa[MASK]y 2009 , Manchester City Council announ[MASK]ed that the sculpture w[MASK]uld be dismantled and placed in storage . Despite the [MASK]romise of storage and potential reassembly , the core and legs of the sculpt[MASK]re were cut apart during removal . The core was sold for s[MASK]rap in July 2012 , while the 180 spikes remain in [MASK]torage . 
 
 = = Design and statistics = = 
 
 B of the Bang originally stood 56 metres ( 184 ft ) tall with 180 hollow tapered steel columns or spikes radiating from a central core . It was angled at[MASK]30 degrees and supporte[MASK] by five 25 m ( 82 ft ) l[MASK]ng , tapered steel legs which connected to the spikes 22 m[MASK]( 72 ft ) above the ground . The sculpture weighed 165 tonnes , with the concrete in the foundations weig[MASK]ing over 1 @,@ 000 tonnes , including a 400 m2 ( 4 @,@ 300 sq ft ) reinforced concrete slab . The foundati[MASK]ns are 20 m ( 66 ft ) [MASK]eep . 
 The sculpture was made from the same weat[MASK]ering steel ( also known as Cor @-@ Ten ) as the Angel of the North sculpture , which gradually develops a tightly adhering oxide layer as it is exposed to the elements . This layer inhibits f[MASK]rther corrosion by reducing its permeabili[MASK]y to water[MASK]. As part of the des[MASK]gn , the spikes swayed slightly in the wind [MASK]n order t[MASK] withstand gusts in exc[MASK]ss of 100 mph ( 160 km / h ) . At the time of construction a time caps[MASK]le was placed in one of the [MASK]pikes of the sculpture , containing children 's poems and paintings , due to be opened c[MASK]rca 2300 . The[MASK]location of the time capsule after disman[MASK]ling is curren[MASK]ly unknown . 
 B of the Bang[MASK]was located next to the City of Manchester Stadium at Sportcity , in Beswick , at the cor[MASK]er of Alan Turing Way and Ashton New Road ; . It took its name [MASK]rom a quotation of British sprinter Linford Christie in which he said that he started his races not merely at the ' bang ' of the [MASK]tartin[MASK] pistol , but at ' The B of the Bang ' . The artwork had been nicknamed KerPlunk by the locals after the popular child[MASK]en 's game from the 1970s . 
 Prior to[MASK]the construction of Aspire at the University of Nottingh[MASK]m , B of t[MASK]e Bang was Britain 's tallest sculpture at well over twice the height of the Angel of the N[MASK]rth , which stan[MASK]s[MASK]at 66 feet ( 20 m ) . It was designed to look like an exp[MASK]oding firework and was taller and leaned at a greater [MASK]ngle than [MASK]he Leaning Tower of Pisa . It[MASK]was commissioned by[MASK]New East Manchester Limited to commemorate the 2002 Commonwealth Games . The design was selected by a panel consisting of both local residents and art experts via a competition in 2002 and was designed by Thomas Heatherwick . 
 
 = = [MASK][MASK]nstruction and funding = = 
 
 The sculpture was constructed in Sheffield [MASK]y Thomas He[MASK]therwick Studio , Packman Lucas , Flint and Neill and Westbury Structures . It was approved at the start of 2003 , with the central core arriving in Manc[MASK]ester on 13 June 2004 . T[MASK]is was the largest load that could be transfe[MASK]red via road from the factory , and required a police escort . This central core was lifted into place in August 2004 , after which the 180[MASK]spikes could begin being attached . Early estimates had [MASK]iven an[MASK]optimistic completion date o[MASK] July 2003 , which contributed to the sculpture gaining the nickname G of the Bang . 
 The off[MASK]cial unveiling by Linford Christie took place[MASK][MASK]n 12 January 2005 . 
 In total the sculpture cost £ 1 @.@ 42 million t[MASK] design and construct — twice the original estimate , as the initial costing had neglected to include installation costs . Funding was sourced from a European Regional Development Fu[MASK]d contribution of £ 700[MASK]@,@ 000 , the North West Develop[MASK]ent Agency[MASK], contributing £ 500[MASK]@,@ 000 , and Manch[MASK]ster City Council providing £ 120 @,@ 000 . 
 
 = = Struc[MASK]ural problems and legal action = = 
 
 The tip of one of the 2 @.@ 1 m ( 6 @.@ 9 ft ) spikes detached and fell from the sculpture on 6 January 2005 , only six days before the off[MASK]ci[MASK]l unveiling . [MASK]fter inspection , the event went ahead as planned . 
 Four months later , in May 2005 , a s[MASK]cond spike had to be cut off by firefighters after it was discovered hanging loose . At that time the sculpture was closed off to the public , and the[MASK]junction and pathway near the sculpture were temporarily closed . As a result , some of the j[MASK]ints were re @-@ welded , with[MASK]equipment put in place to prevent excessive movement . This consisted of retrofitting tip weights to 70 % of the spikes ' weights . 
 Despite thes[MASK] modifications , B of the Ba[MASK]g remained fenced off , prompting a local newspaper campaign to ' Get It Sorted ' . In May[MASK]2006 a total of nine spikes were remove[MASK] from the sculpture and taken awa[MASK] for metallurgical[MASK]analysis , to discover the stresses being placed on the steel . 
 It was announced in October 200[MASK] that Manchester City Council [MASK]ere t[MASK]king legal action against the makers [MASK]f the sculpture , with the aim of completing the necessary repairs to the sculpture . In Novembe[MASK] 2008 this[MASK]culmina[MASK]ed in an out @-@ of @-@ court settlement being rea[MASK]hed between Manchester City Council , the project 's desi[MASK]ners Thomas Heat[MASK]erwick Studio Ltd , and the engineering and construction subcontractors Packman Lucas[MASK]L[MASK]d , Flint and Neill Partnership and Westbury Struct[MASK]res Ltd . The agreement was to pay the council £ 1.7m in damage[MASK] for br[MASK]ach of contract and negligence . [MASK] 
 = = Dismant[MASK]in[MASK] = = 
 
 Acting on a report [MASK]n January 2009 , the city council recommend[MASK][MASK] that B of the [MASK]ang should[MASK]be dismantled and placed in storage until funds could be raised for its safe reinstatement . [MASK]he report recognised[MASK]the sculpture 's aes[MASK]hetic value for Manchester an[MASK] Manchester City Council committed itself to working with the artist to reach a l[MASK]ng @-@ term solution . One [MASK]os[MASK]ibility involved the repla[MASK]ement of the steel spikes with altern[MASK]tives made from carbon fibre , although the report underlined th[MASK] necessity for e[MASK]tensive testing . 
 In January 2009 , Antony Gormley , creator of the Angel of the North [MASK] to which B of the Bang is often compared — spoke out in support of the sculp[MASK]ure , stating that , " It is a gr[MASK]at tribute to Manchester that this ground @-@ [MASK]reaking work was commissioned . To allow it to disappear would be a loss not just of an inspirational artwork but also of the council 's nerve . " 
 Despite Gormle[MASK] 's plea , removal of B of the Bang [MASK]e[MASK]an in April 2009 . More substantial hoarding was erected arou[MASK]d the site and demolition firm Connell [MASK]rothers Limited began removing the spikes with oxyacetylene cutting equipment . 
 Although the council[MASK]had promised to store the complex central[MASK]core and legs , these too were cut apart during removal , casting doubt on future prospects for the landmark sculpture 's return[MASK], and in ea[MASK]ly July 2012 the core was sold a[MASK] scrap for £ 17 @,@ 000 . 
 [MASK] 
 = Ba[MASK]tle of the Hongorai River = 
 
 The Battle [MASK]f the Hongorai River took place duri[MASK][MASK] the Second World War and involved Au[MASK]tralian[MASK], New Zealand and Japa[MASK]ese forces . Part of the wider Boug[MASK]inville Campaign of the Pacific[MASK]theatre , the battle [MASK]as fought[MASK]in the southern sector of Bougainville[MASK]Island . Coming after the Battle of [MASK]later 's Knoll[MASK]in which a strong Japanes[MASK] counterattack was defeated , the battle occurred in two distinct[MASK]periods between 17 April and 22 May 1945 , as elemen[MASK]s of the Australian 15th Brigade advanced south along the Buin Road . 
 The initial phase saw the Australians advance towards the Hongorai River . Fol[MASK]owing the end of the early fighting , the Austra[MASK]ian advance towards the main Japanese co[MASK]centration[MASK]at Buin continued as they stru[MASK]k out towards the Hari and Mivo Rivers . This continued until torrential rain and flooding brought the[MASK]advance to a halt s[MASK]ort of the[MASK]objective , washing away many bridges and roads upon which the Australians relied for supplies . As the Australian advance stalled , the Japanese began harassing the Australian line of communications , and as t[MASK]e rain stopped and the flooding subsided in late @-@ July and into August , the Australians began making preparations to resume the advance[MASK]towa[MASK]ds Buin again . Ultimately , though , the war came to an end before the final Australian advance began , bringing the[MASK]campaign to an [MASK]n[MASK] . 
 
 = = Backgro[MASK]nd = = 
 
 
 = = = Strategic situatio[MASK] = = =
