Among other things , one of the witness[MASK]s originally alleged that Nosek and Blythe shook hands or that one of them o[MASK]fered hand to a[MASK]other on stage ; however , at the court hear[MASK]ng , he testified that there was no prior contact between them . Blyt[MASK]e also argued that vi[MASK]eo evidence[MASK]shown in court refuted claims ab[MASK]ut[MASK]his aggressive behavior . 
 
 = = [MASK] Day 3 of the trial = = = 
 
 Milan Pořádek , the fan whom Blythe admitted to shoving off the stage , testified on the third day of the [MASK]rial . Pořádek said h[MASK] climbed the stage twice in order to stage dive ; he changed his min[MASK] during the third attempt to get on stage . Pořádek testified that Blythe knocked him down , kn[MASK]lt on him and held him down for a moment [MASK] but Blythe definitely did not choke him . He also admitted that taking [MASK]nto account the fact that he ( Pořádek ) was[MASK]drunk and the way he acted , Blythe 's reaction was adequate . He commented that he grasped the fact that he was not wanted on stage . 
 Another witness who had attended the concert at the[MASK]rear of the crowd testif[MASK]ed that Blythe 's behavior was standard to metal concerts , saying that metal bands always put on angry and tough acts and the concert at issue was no exception . She said that it was evident that Blythe did not want any fans on the stage . Neither the tw[MASK] nor any other witne[MASK]s who took the stand [MASK]hat day gave a testimony as to[MASK]the moment of Nosek 's fall at the[MASK]end of the concert . 
 Th[MASK] judge also read a sworn statement from Abaton 's former producer , who stated th[MASK]t she had [MASK]ot known about the incident[MASK]. She was aware that an ambulance was called that evening , but learned about[MASK]the[MASK]reasons for that only later , duri[MASK]g the police investigation . The court further heard that Lamb of God had sent a list of security deman[MASK]s to the concert venue , including that barriers should be placed 1 @.@ 5 metre[MASK] ( 4 @.@ 9 ft ) from the stage . Pr[MASK]moter Tomáš Fiala testified that although this was not the case , the band had not expresse[MASK] any concerns to him either before or after the concert . 
 Randy Blythe was [MASK]alled again to the stand that day . The jud[MASK]e first alerted hi[MASK] that he had the right to remain silent and can deny answering his questions . The judge went again through the Blythe 's te[MASK]timony and , with a view to the previous witness statements , asked [MASK]lythe whether he insi[MASK]ts that [MASK]t was Milan P[MASK]řádek whom Blythe threw off th[MASK] stag[MASK] . Blythe res[MASK]onded [MASK]y[MASK]saying : " To the be[MASK]t [MASK]f my knowledge , it was Milan Pořádek who w[MASK]s coming up [ on stage ] every time . " 
 Also tha[MASK] day , expert medical witness Michal Pogoši took the stand . According to The Prague Post , Pogoši testified that Nosek 's cause of death wa[MASK] pneumonia resulting from a blow to the brainstem . Pogoši added that the " mortality rate from thi[MASK] kind of inju[MASK]y is around 40 percent , and that doctors couldn 't have done more to save the patient . "[MASK]Nosek was initially taken to a [MASK]earby hospital less than a kilometer from the [MASK]enue , where the initial diagn[MASK]sis took place . Since this hospital did not have a spe[MASK]ialized neurology department , Nosek was transferred to another hospital after the diagnosis . There , Nosek underwent two operations , first to tend to [MASK]he injury and second to reduce pressure on brain by removing[MASK]some bone . 
 Finally , defense asked f[MASK]r adjournment as a key witness [MASK]ell ill . The court decided to continue with the hearings the next day , after which the hearin[MASK]s would be adjourned until March 4 , 2013 , in order to hear the defense 's witness . Blythe co[MASK]mitted to retur[MASK] when the trial resumed . 
 
 = = = Day 4 of the trial = = = 
 
 On Febru[MASK]ry 7 , 2013 , only one witness took the s[MASK]and before the hearing was adjourned . Lukáš Havlena contacted the defense af[MASK]er reading about the trial in news[MASK]apers because he " didn 't like the description of the situation " by the previous w[MASK]tnesses . He [MASK]aid he did not think Blythe was aggressive that night , and that fans should realize any aggressive behavior displayed onstage is just part of the show . He also sa[MASK]d[MASK]that each time somebody g[MASK]t on the stage , Blythe demonstrated that they were not allowed there . Havlena testified that he saw how a fan tried to reach the stage three times and that as he was preparing to stage dive [MASK] somebody aid[MASK]d his fall from[MASK]behind . He[MASK]had not seen anybody fall directly on the ground . Havlena had trouble recalling details from the[MASK]show , as he had visited multiple concerts on other dates in Abaton , and thus could not descri[MASK]e , among other things[MASK], the position of the [MASK]uardrail . 
 
 = = = Day 5 of the trial = = = 
 
 The trial resumed on March 4 , 2013 with testimonies from expert witn[MASK]sses in the fields of criminal psychology ( Tereza Soukupová , appointed by the court ) and psychiatry ( Alena Gayová , appointed by the defense ) . Blythe returned to attend the hearin[MASK]s in person , even though the presiding judge had[MASK]told him that at this point they may be undertaken in his absence . T[MASK]e two expert witnesses agreed that Blythe[MASK][MASK]s not aggressive ; nevertheless , he[MASK]may have issues with controlling his emotions under stress . The court further heard testimonies from two eyewitnesses . [MASK]ne[MASK]of them was a bodyguard who wa[MASK] present at the concert but did not see the fall . He testified [MASK]hat when by the exit , he saw two men tak[MASK]ng a third man out of the building to fresh air .[MASK]He said that he was told by them that the person [MASK]ell off the stage . The[MASK]ambulance ar[MASK]ived 5 – 10 minutes later . 
 Another eyewitness was a fan , [MASK]lena Rozsíval[MASK]vá , who testified that she saw[MASK]Blythe s[MASK]ove Nosek , saying " [ h [MASK] e climbed onto the stage , and when he tried to stand up , Blythe shoved him . " According to her , the shove was strong enough for Nosek to fall behind the front row of the fans into a place where no[MASK]fans were staying at the [MASK]oment . Sh[MASK] testified that Nosek fell backwards . Anot[MASK]er attendee of [MASK]he concer[MASK] who took the stand tha[MASK] day did not[MASK]recall seeing any fall by the end[MASK]of the concert . 
 
 = = = Day 6 of the trial = = = 
 
 A [MASK]efense @-@ appointed expert witness in the field of biomechanics testified on Mar[MASK]h 5 that Nosek co[MASK]ld not turn 180 degrees during the fall and that should he be falling for[MASK]ard , he could not have sustained an i[MASK]jury to the back of his head . He further[MASK]said that if Nosek fell over the first row of the fans , he must have been not only pushed , but must have jumped himself . The State Attorney im[MASK]ed[MASK]ately attacked this testimon[MASK] , cla[MASK]ming that the expert witnes[MASK] omitted the conditions at the place and [MASK]ime , as well as som[MASK] of the eyewitness testimonies , according to which Nosek[MASK]fell onto hi[MASK] back [MASK]rom the beginning a[MASK]d did not turn during the fall . The presiding judge agreed with the State Attorney on some of his points . 
 In his closing speech , the State Attorney asked t[MASK]e court to incarcerate Blythe for 5 [MASK]ears , claiming that " even children in the kindergarten a[MASK]e aware [MASK]ha[MASK] a fall from height may lead to an injury . " 
 A Nosek family representative said[MASK]t[MASK]at b[MASK]sed on the witness testimon[MASK]es , the family did not believe that Blythe was solely responsible . He c[MASK]ntinued that he would not be substantiating the requested amount , as no money c[MASK]uld replace the loss the family [MASK]as suffered . He further added that Daniel had died[MASK]on his father 's [MASK]irthday , and his mother has consequently become a psychiatry pat[MASK]ent unable to work . 
 In his closing word , Blythe said that he did not wish to avoid any responsibility and that if he felt guilty he woul[MASK] have pleaded so . He further commented that in case of acquittal [MASK] measures would be undertaken to avoid anythin[MASK] similar from hap[MASK]ening at Lamb of God concerts again . [MASK] 
 = = = First instance verdict = = = 
 
 On [MASK]arch 5 , 2013 , the court delivered a verdict , according to which Blythe was not criminally liable for Nosek 's death , even though he had the moral responsibility for it . Consequently , the court dismi[MASK]sed the d[MASK]mages claim and ordered t[MASK]e return of Blythe 's b[MASK]il . 
 T[MASK]e court held that it was proven that Blythe had thr[MASK]wn Nosek off the stage . Howev[MASK]r , Blythe , due to his nearsightedness , cou[MASK]d have mistaken[MASK]Nosek for the other fan[MASK]who had repeatedly gotten over the guardrail . According to the court , the largest part of the blame lies[MASK]with the promoters and security members . Judge Kubovec further reproached Blythe f[MASK]r not having met with the Nosek family . 
 The State Attorney announced that he would appeal the verdict [MASK] 
 
 = = = Appeals verdict = = = 
 
[MASK]The State Atto[MASK]ney 's appeal was heard[MASK]by a panel[MASK]of three judges of the Prague High Court , chaired by judge Jiří Lněnička . The hearing took place in Blythe 's absence . Blythe 's acquittal was upheld by the panel on June 5 , 2013 . 
 The verdict may have been a[MASK]pealed by the Supreme State Attorn[MASK]y ( SSA [MASK] to the Supreme Court . As the appeal hasn 't been lodged by SS[MASK] within two months of the delivery of written second instance verdict , it has become final . 
 In 2015 Blythe demanded ca CZK 15 millions for damages but the Municipa[MASK] Court for[MASK]Prague 2 dismissed the suit . 
 
 = = Reaction = = 
 
 In reaction to the arrest and detention ,[MASK]a fan created a petition at the official White House pet[MASK]tion site . By the ti[MASK]e Blythe was released on bail , it gathered over 27 @,@ 5[MASK]0 signatures . 
 [MASK]n July 7 , 2012 , there w[MASK]s a vigi[MASK] organized in Lamb of God 's h[MASK]metown of Richmond , Virgin[MASK]a , by[MASK]a f[MASK]iend [MASK]f Blythe 's . At t[MASK]e event , Gwar ( who are also from Richmond [MASK] frontman Dave Brockie said : “ I don ’[MASK]t think it was right for him to be arrested . I don ’ t think it was right for him to be locked up .... This stuff could have all [MASK]een work[MASK]d out diplomatically or legally before h[MASK] got there . ” In additio[MASK] to Brockie , other notable figures in hea[MASK]y [MASK]etal , such as Tom Araya and David Draiman , have also come out in support of Blythe . 
 In a post to his blog , Blythe[MASK]explained that he met the Nosek family [MASK]n[MASK]private after the tri[MASK]l , a[MASK]d promised the[MASK] to[MASK]be " a spokesperson[MASK]for safer shows " . He emphasized that the family never attacked him a[MASK]d " just[MASK]wanted to kn[MASK]w the truth of what had happened to their s[MASK]n " . 
 
 
 = U.S. Route 2 in Michigan = 
 
 US Hig[MASK][MASK]ay 2 ( US 2 ) is a component of the United States Numbered Highway System that connects Everett , Washing[MASK]on , to the Upper Peninsula ( UP ) o[MASK] the US state of Michigan , with a separ[MASK]te se[MASK]ment that runs from Rouses Point , [MASK]ew York , to Hoult[MASK]n , M[MASK]ine . In Michigan , the highway runs through the UP in two segments as a part of the state trunkline highway system , entering[MASK]the state at Ironwood and ending at St. Ignace [MASK] in betw[MASK]en , US 2 briefly traverses the state of Wisconsin . [MASK]s one of the major transportation arteries in the UP , US 2 is a major conduit for traffic through the state and neighboring no[MASK]thern Midwest states . Two sections of the roadway are included as part of the Great Lakes Circle Tours , and o[MASK]her segmen[MASK]s are listed as [MASK]tate @-@ designated Pure Michigan Byways . There are several memorial highway designations and historic bridges along US 2 t[MASK]at date to the 1910s and[MASK]1920s . The highway runs through rural sections of the UP , passing through two national and two state[MASK]f[MASK]rests [MASK]n the p[MASK]ocess . 
 The route of what became US 2 was used as part of two Indian trails before European settlers came to the UP , and as part of the Michigan segmen[MASK]s of the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway and the King 's International Highway auto trails in the early 20th century . The state later included these trails as part of M ‑ [MASK]2 when the first state highway trunklines were designated[MASK]in [MASK][MASK]19 . Most of M ‑ 12 wa[MASK] redesigna[MASK]ed as part of US 2[MASK]when the US Highway System was created on Novemb[MASK]r 11 , 1926 . Since the 1930s , several changes have[MASK]reshaped the highway 's routing through the UP . One such alteration eventually created [MASK] business loop that connected across the state line with Hurley , Wisconsin , and others pushed an originally inland routing of US 2 closer to the Lake Michigan shoreline . With the creation[MASK]of the Interstate Highway System , pa[MASK]t of US 2 [MASK]as rerouted to coincide with t[MASK]e new I[MASK]terstate[MASK]75 ( I ‑ 75 ) , though in the 1980s , th[MASK] U[MASK]S.[MASK]Highway [MASK]as truncate[MASK] and removed from [MASK]he I ‑ 75 freeway , resulting in today 's basic form . 
 
 = = Route d[MASK]scri[MASK]tion = = 
 
 Acco[MASK]ding [MASK]o a 2006 regional planning committe[MASK] report , US 2 is a key highway for Michigan , providing its main western gateway . The roadway plays " an important role in the transportation of goods across the northern ti[MASK]r of states in the Midwest " , and is listed o[MASK][MASK]the Nat[MASK]onal Highway System ([MASK]NHS ) for its entire leng[MASK]h . The NHS is a network of roadways important to the country 's economy , defense , and mobility . Together with M ‑ 28 , US 2 is part of a pair of primary trunklines that bridge the eastern and western sides of the UP . Th[MASK] 305 @.@ 151 mile[MASK] ( 491 @.@ 093 km ) o[MASK] roadway in Michigan is divided into a 109 @.@ 177 [MASK]-@ mile ( 175 @.@ 703 km ) western segment and a 195 @.@ 97[MASK][MASK]@-@ mile ( 315 @.@ 390 km ) eastern segment , interr[MASK]pted by a section that runs for 14 @.@ 460 miles ( 23 @.@ 271 km ) in the state of Wisconsin . 
 
 = = = Western segment = = = 
 
 US 2 enters Michigan from Wisconsin for the [MASK]irst time north of downtown Hurley , Wisconsin , and Ironwood , Michigan , over the state line that runs along the Montreal River . The highway [MASK]rosses the river into [MASK]ogebic County and passes a welcome ce[MASK]ter on the way into a c[MASK]mmercial distr[MASK]ct north of downtown . Running along Clov[MASK]rland Drive , US 2 meets its[MASK]only business route in Michigan at D[MASK]uglas Boule[MASK]ard . The business[MASK]route was pr[MASK]viously a full loop that ran west through downtown Ironwood and crossed the border into Hurley and back to the main highway . The Wisconsin Department of Transportation has removed [MASK]he signage on their [MASK]ide of the border , which reduced the loop to a[MASK]business spur that ends at the state line . US 2 continues eastward through UP woodlands to the city of Bessemer . While bypassing the community of Ramsay , the highway crosses a branch of the Black River . The roadway enters Wakefi[MASK]ld on the south[MASK]side of Sunday Lake , meeting M ‑ 28 at a stoplight in tow[MASK] . As the US Highway leaves Wakefield , it turns southeasterly through the Ottawa National Forest , cros[MASK]ing Jackson Creek and two branches of the Presq[MASK]e Isle River . US[MASK]2 and M ‑ 64 merge and run concurrently over the secon[MASK] branch of the Presque Isle in the community of Marenisco . This concurre[MASK]cy has the lowest traffic volume along the entir[MASK] length of the highway within the state ; in 2010 the Michigan Department of Transportation ( MDOT ) recorded a daily average usage along the stretch of 770 vehicles , compared [MASK]o the overall average [MASK]f 5 @,@ 188 vehicles for the highway . At the end of the concurrency , M ‑ 64 turns northerly to run along Lake Gogebic . 
 The highway continues parallel [MASK]o[MASK]t[MASK]e state line f[MASK]om th[MASK] Marensico area through the national forest toward Watersme[MASK]t . That unincorporated community is[MASK]the home of the Watersmeet High School Nimrods , the bas[MASK]etball team featured on a series of ESPN commercials and a documentary series on the Sundan[MASK]e Channel . The area is also w[MASK]ere the [MASK]aters meet ; the rolling hills drain to Lake Superior via the Ontona[MASK]on Riv[MASK]r , to Lake Michigan via the Brule and Menominee rivers , or to the Gulf of Mexico via the Wisconsin and Mississippi rivers . Al[MASK]o located in the area are the Sylvania Wilderness , and the Lac Vieux Desert In[MASK]ian Reservation , which includes the Lac Vieux Desert Casino and Resort . The highway tr[MASK]vels southeasterly from Watersmeet around the many lakes and streams in the area and crosses into rural Iron County . US 2 intersects Federal Forest Highway 16 ( FFH 16 ) near Golden Lake in Stambaugh Township in the middle of the national forest . The [MASK]runkline then runs along the Iron River as i[MASK] approaches the city of the sam[MASK] name and meets M ‑ 73 . In town[MASK], US 2 intersects M ‑ 189 before crossing the river and turning northeast out of[MASK]the city .[MASK]
 US 2 leav[MASK]s the Ottawa[MASK]National F[MASK]rest at Iron River , and the highway continues eastward through forest lands near [MASK]everal small lakes to Crystal Falls , the county seat of Iron County . On the west side of town , US 2 meets US 141 ; [MASK]he two[MASK]highways run concu[MASK]rently along Crystal Avenue . The combined highway turns south onto 5th[MASK]Street and meets M ‑ 69 's eastern terminus at the interse[MASK][MASK]ion between 5th Street an[MASK] Superior Avenue nex[MASK] to the county courthouse at the top of the hill . US 2 / US 141 runs south out of [MASK]rystal Falls to the west of , and parallel to , the Paint River . The roadway passes Railroad , Kennedy and St[MASK]ger lakes and leaves the state of Michigan at the[MASK]Brule River , crossing into Flo[MASK]ence County , Wisconsin for about 14 miles ( 23 km ) . 
 
 = = = Eastern segment = = = 
 
 US 2 / US 141 re @-@ enters Michigan [MASK]here it crosses the Menominee River and subsequently meets M ‑[MASK]95 in Breitung Township north of I[MASK]on Mountain and Kingsford . The highways merge in a triple concurrency and run south on Stephenson Avenue into [MASK]ron Mountain along the west side of Lake Antoine , parallel to a b[MASK]anch line of the Escanaba and Lake Superior Railroad ( ELS Railroad ) . The road crosses through a retail corridor[MASK]and over a[MASK]flooded pit of the Chapin Mine . In downtown Iron[MASK]Mountain at Ludin[MASK]to[MASK] [MASK]treet [MASK] M ‑ 95 turns west off Stephenson Avenue to run across town to Kingsford . US 2 / US 141 exits downtown and turns [MASK]ast along a second reta[MASK]l corridor near the Midtown Mall . The highway re @-@ enters Breitung Township where US 141 [MASK]eparates to the so[MASK]th to re @-@ enter Wisconsin . US 2 continues eastward parallel to a branch of the Canadian National Railway ( CN Railway ) . [MASK]oth road and rail travel through the community of Quinnesec , where they pass near the largest paper mill in the UP . The trunkline runs alon[MASK] the main street of Norway , where the highway meets the eastern terminus of US 8 .[MASK]Then US 2 co[MASK]tin[MASK]es east through rural Dickinson County to Vulcan , passing north [MASK]f Hanbury Lake through the Copper Count[MASK]y State Forest , before crossing the Sturgeon River in Loretto and passing into Menominee County . 
 In Menominee County , the environment takes on a more agricultural character along US 2 . The highway passes through th[MASK] edge[MASK]of the community of Hermansville before entering Powers[MASK]. US 2 comes to a three @-@ way intersection and turns northeast merging onto US 41 . The concurrent hi[MASK]hway runs [MASK]rom Powers [MASK]hrough the communities of Wilson and Spaulding on th[MASK] south side of the CN R[MASK]ilwa[MASK] . At Harris , the trunkl[MASK]ne enters t[MASK]e Han[MASK]ahville Indian Community . Harris is on the Menominee County side of the reservation , [MASK]ut as the highwa[MASK] continue[MASK] east , it crosses over to Bark River on the Delta County side . The county line in [MASK]etween not only[MASK]separates the two communities , but[MASK]also s[MASK]rves as the boundary between the Central and Eastern time zones . Ea[MASK]t of Bark River , the hi[MASK]hway crosses the community 's namesake[MASK]waterway[MASK]before intersecting the eastern terminus of M ‑ 69 . The roadway crosses the Ford River prior to turning due east into the outskirts of Escanaba . 
 US 2 / US 41 widens to four lanes[MASK]along Ludington Street ,[MASK]which forms the [MASK]ast – west axis of the Escanaba s[MASK]reet grid . Nea[MASK] downtown , the highway meets M ‑ 35 [MASK] which runs along the city 's north – south axis , Lincoln Avenue . The trunklines merge and run north , bypassing the traditional central business distric[MASK] for a different business corri[MASK]or . Lincoln [MASK]venue runs north carryin[MASK] four lanes of traffic past the Upper Peninsula State Fairgrounds , site[MASK]of one of th[MASK] two state fairs for the state of Michigan , the only[MASK]state to have twin fairs . US 2 / US 41 / M ‑ 35 continues north on Lincoln Avenue past the campus of Bay de Noc Community College . The four @-@ lane highway crosses the Escanaba River just upstream from its mouth near the large Mead Pap[MASK]r Mill [MASK]nd shifts to run immediately next to Little Bay de Noc . The section h[MASK]re ca[MASK]ried the highest traffic counts along all of US 2 in the state : an average of 23 @,@ 977 vehicles used this segment of roadway daily in 2011 . 
 The road turns inland again , [MASK]nd US 2 / U[MASK] 41 / M ‑ 35 passes to the west of downtown Gladstone . The highway through here is an expressway , four lanes divided by a central median[MASK]and no driveway access [MASK] Unlike a freeway , the expressway has standard intersections and not interchanges . The highway intersects the eastern terminus of County Road 426 ( CR 426 ) [MASK]nd crosses the ELS Rai[MASK]road south of the stoplight for 4th Avenue North , where M ‑ 35 separates from[MASK]the US Highways and turns to the n[MASK]rthwest . The expressway continu[MASK]s north parallel to the CN Railway , crossing the Days River . Through this area , the trunkline carries a speed limit of 6[MASK] mph ( [MASK]05 km / h ) for car traffic . This is the only road in the UP with a speed limit higher than 55[MASK]mph ( 89 km / h ) besides I @-@ 75 ,[MASK]which has a speed limit of 70 mph ( 11[MASK] km / h ) . The expressway [MASK][MASK]gment runs around the upper end of Little Bay de Noc before ending at Rapid River . In this [MASK]ocation , US 41 separates[MASK]to the nor[MASK][MASK] , and US 2 retu[MASK]ns to an easterly track as a two @-@ lane[MASK]road , crossing the Rapid and Whitefish rivers and turning southeast around the head of the bay . As US 2 crosses southern Delta County , it passes through the western unit of the Hiawatha National [MASK]orest . Near Garden C[MASK]rners , the highway runs along the shore of Big Bay de Noc . Af[MASK]er the intersection with the northern terminus of M ‑ 183 , US 2 turns inland cutting across the base of the Garden Peninsula and enters School[MASK]raft County . 
 As the highway approaches Thompson , US 2 [MASK][MASK]aves the western unit of the Hiawat[MASK]a National Forest and ente[MASK]s the Lake Superior State Forest . The road[MASK]ay runs along Lake Michigan to Manistique , crossing the Manist[MASK]que[MASK]River . The trunkline turns inland app[MASK]oaching Gulliver and then turns north @-@ northeast to[MASK]Blaney Park . The community there is a former logging town @-@ turned @[MASK]@ resort at t[MASK]e southern terminus of M ‑ 77 [MASK] the resor[MASK] was a[MASK]tive from the late 1920s but declined by the 198[MASK]s . From Blaney Park[MASK], US 2 turns due east and crosses into Mackinac County west of Gould City [MASK] W[MASK]ere it intersects a former routing , the main highway crosses the CN Railway one last time and runs to the south [MASK]f Engadine to follow the Lake Michigan shor[MASK]line through Naubinway . After passing the community of Epoufette , US 2 crosses the Cut Ri[MASK]er Bridge , 147 feet ( 45 m ) over the [MASK]ut[MASK]River . The highway crosses into the eastern unit of the Hiawath[MASK] National Forest near Brevort , running between Lake Michigan and Br[MASK]vort Lake in the pro[MASK]e[MASK]s . The road contin[MASK]es along the [MASK]ake Michigan shoreline , passing Mystery Sp[MASK]t near Gros Cap and turning inland immediately west of St. Ignace . The US 2 [MASK]esignati[MASK]n ends at the[MASK]highway 's partial cloverleaf interchange with I ‑ 75[MASK]. The roadway continues easterly into downtown St. Ignace as Business Loop I ‑ 75 ( BL I ‑ 75 ) . 
 
 = = Hist[MASK]ry = = 
 
 
 = = = I[MASK]dian trail through auto trails = = =[MASK]
 
 In 1701 , the first trans[MASK]ortation routes through what became the [MASK]tate of Mic[MASK]igan were the lakes , river[MASK] and Indian trails . Two of these trails followed parts of the future US 2 . The[MASK]Sault – Green Bay Trail roughly followed the Lake Michigan shoreline[MASK]routing of US 2 between Escanaba and St. Ignace . The Mackinac T[MASK]ail connected St. Ignace with Sault Ste . Marie . 
 In the age of the auto trail , the roads that[MASK]later formed US 2 through the UP were given a few different highway names . When the or[MASK]ginal roadways betwee[MASK] [MASK]ronwood and Iron River were completed in late 1915 , the Upper Peninsula Develo[MASK]ment Bureau ( UPDB ) named the area Cloverland and the highway the Cloverland [MASK]rail . Later the name w[MASK]s extended ove[MASK] th[MASK] high[MASK]ay to Escanaba , and [MASK]o all highways in the area in the early 1920s ; the name was phased out by the UPDB completely in 1927 . The roadways were also used for the Theodore Roosevelt International Highway , named for for[MASK]er US president Theodore Roosevelt after his death in 1919 .[MASK][MASK]vera[MASK]l , this highway [MASK]an from Portland , Oregon , t[MASK] Portland , Maine , by way of Mi[MASK]higan and the Canadian province of Ontar[MASK]o . Through the UP , the southern branch followed the immediate predecessors [MASK]o US 2 , including the section through Florence [MASK]ounty , Wisconsin . 
 The Great Lakes Automobile Route was [MASK]stablished in 1917 by the UPDB . A predecessor of the Great L[MASK]kes Circ[MASK]e Tours by[MASK]seventy years , the route followed " a circular journe[MASK] along the banks of lakes Michigan and Superior and Green Bay ... " This route followed the modern US 2 from Ironwood to the M ‑ 94 junction in Manistique , using the modern M ‑ 69 and M ‑ [MASK]5 to sta[MASK] in Michigan . Bran[MASK]hes of the route followed US 41 and [MASK] ‑ 35 between Powers and Escanaba . The route was originall[MASK] intended to entice motorists to drive around Lake Michigan .[MASK]The name fell out of use before its first anniversary because o[MASK] World War I. 
 One Canadian auto tr[MASK]il was routed through the UP as well . In 1920 , the[MASK]King 's International Highway linked [MASK]ancouver[MASK], British Columbia , to Halifax , Nova Scotia , bu[MASK] there was no highway to carry it around the north side of Lake Superior . Motorists h[MASK]d to shi[MASK] their cars by boat between Sault Ste . Marie ,[MASK]Ontario , and Thunder Bay or enter the United States to continue along the auto trai[MASK] . The routings vari[MASK]d on the maps of the time , bu[MASK] its basic route used US 2 through [MASK]he UP from Ironwood to Sault Ste . Marie until a highway north [MASK]f Lake Superior was opened[MASK]in 1960 ; by that time , the auto trail had taken on the Trans @-@ C[MASK]nada Highway name . 
 
 = = = State trunkline = = = 
 
 The first [MASK][MASK]ate trunkline highway designated along the path of the modern US 2 was M ‑ 12 , a designation that was in use by July 1 , 1919 , between Ironwood and Sault Ste . Marie . The first roadside park in the country was created by Herbert Larson nea[MASK] what is[MASK]now US 2 n[MASK]ar Iron Rive[MASK] in[MASK]1919 – 20 , although other sour[MASK]es state that the first was a picnic table alongside US 16 ( [MASK]rand River Avenue ) in 1929 south of Saranac . When the US High[MASK]ay System was c[MASK]eated on November 11 , 1926 ,[MASK]US 2 partially replaced [MASK] @-@ 1[MASK] . Between Crystal Falls and Iron Mounta[MASK]n , US 2 was routed thro[MASK]gh Florence , Wisconsin . The former routi[MASK]g of M ‑ 12 from Crystal Falls to Sagola became a new M ‑ 69 when the former M ‑ 69 became [MASK]S 102 [MASK] now U[MASK] 141 ) . M ‑ 12[MASK]from[MASK]Sagola south to Iron Mountain was made[MASK]a part of an extended M [MASK] 45 , which is now M ‑ 95 . By the next year , M ‑ 48 was added al[MASK][MASK]g US 2 from Rexton to Garnet as part of a larger extension . 
 The first changes to the routing of US 2 itself were ma[MASK]e in[MASK]1930 with a bypass of downtown Escanaba . A larger rerouting was completed in 1933 between Rogers Park an[MASK] Sault Ste . Marie . The new ro[MASK]ting followed Mackinac Trail[MASK]instead of turn[MASK]ng east to Cedarville and north to Sault Ste . Marie ; the former routing[MASK]was given the M[MASK]‑ 121 designat[MASK]on . Another realignment in the Iron Mountain area shifted US 2 / US 141 to a new bridge over the Menomine[MASK] River between[MASK]1932 and 1934 . Downtown Ironwood was bypassed in [MASK]934 , and the former route was initially designated M ‑ 54 . 
 The Michigan State Highway Departme[MASK]t ( MSHD ) changed the routin[MASK]s and designations o[MASK] the highways around Cooks , Thompson and Manisti[MASK][MASK]e in the mid @-@ 1930s . The agency rerouted [MASK]S 2 between Cooks and M ‑ 149 in Thompson , turning the old [MASK]oad back to county control . The section [MASK]etween M ‑ 149 and M ‑ 125 was redesignated as an extension of M ‑ 149 to Thompson , and M ‑ 125 was replaced by a further extension of M ‑ 149 . The las[MASK] change was to route US 2 along its current alignment in the area , completing the changes on August 2 , 1936 . 
 The MSH[MASK] started construction in 1936 on a new r[MASK]ad that rerouted US 2 into St. Ignace for the first time . Between Brevort and Moran , US 2 previously followed Wort[MASK] Road inland to the Tahquamenon Trail to meet the northern extension of US 31 into the Upper Peninsula . The new routing took US 2 along the lakeshore into St. Ignace .[MASK]US 31[MASK]was trunc[MASK]te[MASK] to the sta[MASK]e ferry docks in Macki[MASK]aw City an[MASK] US 2 was routed through St. Ignace along th[MASK] former US 31 to Rogers Park ; the[MASK]connection in [MASK]t. Ignace to the stat[MASK] ferry docks b[MASK]came M ‑ 122 . Furthe[MASK] changes in the early 1940s straighten[MASK]d the roadway ou[MASK] near Watersmeet and Cr[MASK]stal Falls . 
 Additional realignments were completed by the MSHD t[MASK] move US 2 to its modern lakeshore routing between Gould City and Epoufette in 1941 . The ne[MASK] highway [MASK]raveled due east from Gould City to Naubinway and then along the lake to Epoufette . The former[MASK]route through Engadine was turned back to local control as far east as Garnet . From there east , it was numbered just M ‑ 48 , removing US 2 from a concurrency . Another former section into Epoufette was added to extend M ‑ 117 . The new highway was detoured around the [MASK]ut River Bridge until it was completed in 1946 after construction delays over steel shortages dur[MASK]ng World War II . 
 The western end of US 2[MASK]took on two[MASK]changes in the 1940s . M ‑ 28 was extended along US 2 to the state line at Ironwood from its western terminus at Wakef[MASK]eld . A similar extension was made from M ‑ 28 's east[MASK]rn terminus to Sault Ste . Marie in 1948 . The M ‑ 54 designation was renumbered as Business US 2 by 1945 . The eastern M ‑ 28 extension was reversed in 1950 , and the western extension [MASK]o the state line was shifted to a new locat[MASK]on by 1952 . 
 
 = = = Interstate era = = = 
 
 With the coming of t[MASK]e Interstate Highway System in Michigan , the MSHD planned to convert the eastern section of US 2 to a freeway between St. [MASK]gna[MASK]e and Sault St. Marie . In planning maps from 1947 , this highway co[MASK]ridor was included i[MASK] the syst[MASK]m that later became the Interstates . It was also included in the Gene[MASK]al Locat[MASK]on of National System of Interstate Highw[MASK]ys Including All Additio[MASK]al Routes at Urban Areas Designa[MASK]ed in September 1955 , or Yellow[MASK]Book after the cover color , that was released in 1955 as the federal government readied plans for the freeway system . The propo[MASK]ed number in 1958 was Interstate 75 ( I ‑ 75 ) . 
 The first section of freeway was built in late 1957 or early 1958 between Evergre[MASK]n Shores and M ‑ 123 north of St. I[MASK]nace . The Mack[MASK]nac Bridge was opened to traffic on November 1 , 1957 ; a new section [MASK]f freeway and an interchange connected US 2 to the bridge . In 1961 , an[MASK]the[MASK] new freeway segment closed the gap between the[MASK]Mackinac Brid[MASK]e and Evergreen [MASK]hores section[MASK] . At the time , the I ‑ 75 designation supplanted US 27 on the bridge , and U[MASK] 2 was shifted to follow I ‑ 75 along the fre[MASK]ways in the St. Ignace area . The former routing of US 2 in downtown St. Ignace was redesignated BL I ‑ 75 . More sections of freeway were opened in 1962 [MASK]mmediately to the south of the newly constructed International Bridge in Sault Ste . Marie as well as between Dafter and Kinross . The last two sections opened in 1963 connected the northern end of the freeway at M ‑ 123 to Kinross , and t[MASK]e section between Dafter and Sault Ste . Marie . At this time , all o[MASK] US 2 's former routing became a county road known as Mackinac Trail ( [MASK] @[MASK]@ 63 ) . 
 The Department of State Highways expanded US 2 / US 41 into[MASK]an expressway be[MASK]ween Gladstone[MASK]and Rapid River in 1971 . The state built a new bridge over the Manistique Rive[MASK] in 1983 , bypassing downtown .[MASK]MDOT disposed of the former routing of US 2 into downtown in two ways . The western[MASK]half was initially an unnumbered sta[MASK]e hi[MASK]hway until it was later transferred to local control . An extension of M ‑ 94[MASK]replaced[MASK]the remainder[MASK], including the Siphon B[MASK]idge , through[MASK]downtown . In that same yea[MASK][MASK], the department truncated US 2 to end in St. Ignace by removing it from the I ‑ 75 freeway . The last changes were made to US 2 's routing through Iron River in 1998 , bypassin[MASK] the bridge that formerly carried the hi[MASK]hway over the river in town . I[MASK] 2011 , MDOT raised the speed limi[MASK] along the expressway section i[MASK] Delta County f[MASK]om 5[MASK] to 65 mph ( 89 to 105 km /[MASK]h ) , although[MASK]the speed lim[MASK]t for trucks rem[MASK]ins 55 mph ( 89 km / h ) . 
 
 = = Memorial designations and to[MASK]rist routes = = 
 
 On July 1 , 1924 , the State Administrative Board named M ‑ 12 , the predecessor to US 2 in Michigan , the Bohn Highw[MASK]y to honor Frank P. Bohn , a prominent local citizen who later served in Congress fro[MASK] 1927 to 1933 . In 1929 , the residents of Escanaba created a memorial to the veterans of World War[MASK]I called Memory Lane . The project consisted of elm and maple trees planted along US 2 / US 41 west of tow[MASK] . The American Legion sold the trees to local businesses and individuals who could honor specific soldiers . Later in 1949 , the Bessemer Women 's Club created a tribute in [MASK]he form of a permanent livi[MASK]g memorial to the area veterans . Also called Memory[MASK]Lane , the group planted 140 elms and 1 @,@ 840 evergreens , trees and shrubs as a landscaped parkway along 2 @.@ 3 miles ( 3 @.@ 7 km ) of US 2 e[MASK]st of Bessemer . 
 Most of US 2 , along w[MASK]th US 23 in the Lower Peni[MASK]sula , was designated the United Spanish War Veterans Memorial Highway in 1949 . To connect the [MASK]ap in the routing where US 2 cuts through Wisconsin , M ‑ 95 and M ‑ 69 were used in place of US 2 between[MASK]Iron Mountain and Crystal Falls . Signs marki[MASK]g the highway were not er[MASK]cted until 1968 when Governor George W. Romney had them in[MASK]talle[MASK] . 
 The Am[MASK]ets M[MASK]morial Drive designation was created for the section of US [MASK] / US 41 / M ‑ 35 between the northern Esca[MASK]aba city limits and County Road 426 ( CR 426 ) in Delta County . The Ame[MASK]ican Veterans ( AMVETS ) organization in Mich[MASK]gan petitioned the Michigan Legislature to grant this designation , which was assigned under Public Act 144 in 1959 [MASK][MASK]
 Two sections of US 2 are part of the overall Great[MASK]Lakes Circle Tour ( GLCT ) : th[MASK] segment from the Wisconsin state line near Ironwood to the M ‑ 28 junction in Wakefield[MASK]is par[MASK] of the Lake Superior Circle Tour ( LSCT ) , and the segment from the southern M ‑ 35 junction in Escanaba to[MASK]the eastern terminus in St. Ignace is part of the Lake Michigan Circle Tour[MASK]( LMCT ) . These two tours were created[MASK]in May 1986 through a joint effort between MDOT and it[MASK] counterparts in Wisconsin , Minnesota and Ontario . The section of US 2 between Iron River and Crystal F[MASK]lls has been named the [MASK]ron County Heritage Trail . This Pure Michigan Byway [MASK]as designated to honor the " rich history of two industries that built a state and nation : mining and [MASK]ogging . " On August[MASK]26 , 2007 , MDOT announced that the section of US 2 that r[MASK]ns concurrently with M ‑ 35 in Delta County was being included in the UP Hid[MASK]en [MASK]oast Recreational Heritage Trail . 
 
 = = Historic bridges =[MASK]= [MASK] 
 There[MASK]are six bridges along current or former section[MASK] of US 2 that MDOT has added [MASK]o its listing of Michigan 's Historic Bridges ; two of t[MASK]ese are also listed on the National Register of Historic Places ( NRHP ) . A third bridge added to the NRHP in late 2012 has not been[MASK]added to MDOT 's listin[MASK] however . Th[MASK] first of t[MASK]ese historic bridges is the crossi[MASK]g of [MASK]he Iron R[MASK]ver , which has since been[MASK]bypassed by a new bridge . The original struc[MASK]ure , dating to 1918 , is a 55 @-@ foot @-@ long ( 17 m ) spandrel arch span that was built by the MSHD as Trunk Li[MASK]e Bridge No. 191 . The structure was listed on[MASK]the NRHP on December 9 [MASK] 1999 , for its architectural and engineering [MASK]ignificance . 
 In [MASK]e[MASK]ember 2012 , the Nat[MASK]onal Park Service approved the listing of the[MASK]Upper Twin Falls Bridge that crosses the Menominee River north[MASK]est of Iron Mountain . The [MASK]tructure is a single [MASK]-@[MASK]span , pin @-@ connected , camelback [MASK] through @-@ truss bridge , and[MASK]it is the only known example of its type in Michigan . It was built bet[MASK]een 1909 and 1910 because the Twin Falls Power Dam would flood an existing river crossing . The span cost $ 5 @,@ 10[MASK] ( equivalent to $ 780 @,@ 000 in 2015 ) , paid equally by Dickinson and[MASK]Florence counties . Until the 1930s , the Upper Twin Fal[MASK]s Bridge carried U[MASK] 2 across the[MASK]Menominee River . In 1934 , a new bridge was built about a mile downstream , and the highway was rerouted over the new [MASK]pan .[MASK]The bridge closed to automobile traffic in[MASK]September 1971[MASK],[MASK]and the[MASK]nomination process for inclusion o[MASK] the National Register of Historic Places[MASK]began in 2012 . 
 In 2003 , MDOT re[MASK]laced the Sturgeon River [MASK]ridge i[MASK] Waucedah Towns[MASK]ip , Dickinson County . As of October 2011 , even though the old bridge was demo[MASK]ished and replaced , MDOT retained it on the[MASK]r historic bridge list . I[MASK] was built in 1929 . 
 Before 1983 , US 2 used a[MASK]different routing[MASK]through Manistique and crossed the Manistique River on what is [MASK]icknamed the " Siphon Bridge " . Built as a part of a raceway flume on the river , th[MASK] water [MASK]evel is[MASK]actually higher than the r[MASK]ad surface . This produces [MASK] siphon effect , giving the bridge its nickname . The Manistique Pulp an[MASK] Paper Company was organized in 1916 and needed a dam on the Manistique River to su[MASK]ply their mill [MASK] This dam w[MASK]uld requir[MASK] a large section of the city to be flooded , and shallow river banks meant difficulties in any bridge constr[MASK]ction . Ins[MASK]ead of expensive dikes , a concrete ta[MASK]k was built lengthwise in the riv[MASK]r bed ; the sides of this tank pro[MASK]ided man @-@ mad[MASK] banks highe[MASK] than the natural banks .[MASK]The Michi[MASK]an[MASK]Works Progress Administration described th[MASK] bridge as having " concrete bulkheads , formed by the side spans of the bridge , [ that ] allow the mill to maintain the water level several feet above the roadbed . " The Man[MASK]stique Tourism Cou[MASK]cil stated : " At one time , the bridge itself was partially supported b[MASK] [MASK]he water tha[MASK] was atmospherically forced under it , " and that the bridge ha[MASK] been featured in Ripley 's Believe It or Not ! . The eight @-@ span structure is 294 feet ( 90 m )[MASK]long . 
 The Cut [MASK]iver Bridge carries[MASK]US 2 across the Cut River in Hendricks Township , Mackinac County . This structure was built during World War II but completion was delayed due to war @-@ induced steel shortages . The span uses 888 short tons ( 793 long tons ; 806 t ) of structural steel to bridge the 641 feet ( 195 m ) over the river and its gorge at a height of 147 feet ( 45 m )[MASK]above the river . The Cut River Bridge is [MASK]n[MASK] of only two cantilevered deck truss bridges in the st[MASK]te . On either side of the bridge , there are p[MASK]cni[MASK] areas and trails down to the river . 
 Listed on the NRHP on December 17 , 1999 , the Mackinac Trail –[MASK]Carp River Bridge carries H @-@ 63 , the modern successor to US 2 , over the Carp River no[MASK]th of St. Ignace . The bridge is another spandrel arch struc[MASK]ure 60 feet ( 18 m ) in leng[MASK]h and built in 1920[MASK]. Inc[MASK]easi[MASK]g traffic along Mackinac Trail prompted the MSHD to " widen its deck by five feet [ 1 @.@ 5 m ] and install new guardrails in the 1929 – 1930 biennium " along with the addition of deco[MASK]ative retaining walls . 
 The last of the histori[MASK] bridges along a former segment of US 2 is the structure carrying Ashmun Street ([MASK]BS I ‑ 75 ) over the Power Canal in Sault Ste [MASK] Marie . B[MASK]ilt in 1934 [MASK] it is one of only three steel arch bridges in the state . The 42 @-@ foot @-@ wide ( 13 m ) and 257 @-@ foot @-@ lo[MASK]g ( 78 m ) s[MASK]ructure is described by MDOT as " massive " with an " innovative " construction method : the previous st[MASK]ucture was used[MASK]as a [MASK]alsework for the current bridge before removal . 
 
 = = Major intersectio[MASK]s = = 
 
 MDOT has erected milemarkers alon[MASK] the two Michiga[MASK] segments of the highway that use the total mileage starting at the state line in Ironwood ; the signs [MASK]n the east[MASK]r[MASK] segment reflect t[MASK]e mileage in Florence County , Wisconsin . 
 
 =[MASK]= Bus[MASK]ness route[MASK]= [MASK] 
 
 Business U.S. Highway 2 ( Bus . US 2 ) is a 1 @.@ 270 @-@ mile ( 2 @.@ 044 km ) business r[MASK]ute that runs from the Wisconsin stat[MASK] line at the Montreal River . The route extends t[MASK]ro[MASK]gh downtown[MASK]Iro[MASK]wood on Silver and Aurora streets before turning northward along Suffolk Street . Bus . US 2 stays on Suffolk Street [MASK]or a short while until it turns onto Frederick Street . On Frederick Street , Bus [MASK] US 2 bears north through a residential area along Douglas Street . The eas[MASK]ern terminus of the[MASK]route is at i[MASK]s junction with US 2 at the corner of Clo[MASK]erland Drive and Douglas Street[MASK]north of downtown . 
 The business route was create[MASK] in August 1942 when former M ‑ 54 in Ironwood was renumbe[MASK]ed as a[MASK]business loop of US 2 . It was originally a bi @-@ state busines[MASK] connection before the Wisconsin Department of Transportation deco[MASK]missioned Bus . US 2 i[MASK] Hurley westward along State Trunk Highway 77 and northward along US 51 in 2002 . 
 
 
 = Butterfly World Tour = 
 
 The Butterfly Wor[MASK]d Tour was[MASK]the third [MASK]oncert tour by American singer @-@ songwri[MASK]er Mariah Carey . The tour promoted Carey 's album at the time , Butterfly ( 1997 ) , a[MASK]d inclu[MASK]ed songs from seve[MASK]al of her previo[MASK]s albums . The tour visited Asia , Australia and the United States , with rehearsals taking place in December 1997 . Starting on January 11 , 1998 the tour spanned five shows in Asia , six in Australia , and one in Hawaii , US . Thr[MASK]ughout the[MASK]tour , Carey var[MASK]ed hairs[MASK]yles and outfits , as well as song selecti[MASK]ns . The Butterfly [MASK]orld Tour was very successful ; the [MASK]our dates at Japan 's largest[MASK]stadium , Tokyo Dome , sold out in under one hour , equaling [MASK]ver 200 @,@ 000 tickets , breaking [MASK]he previ[MASK]us record she hel[MASK] at the stadium for show sell @-@ outs . 
 The t[MASK]ur was recorded in VHS format , and was titled Around the World . The video featured live performances of Carey at different worldwide venues including New York , Japan , Hawaii and Brisbane . Other scenes are included in the video such as a conversation between [MASK]arey and Brenda K. Starr prior to her performance of " I Still Believe " . Prior to the performances in Australia , a scene of Carey swimming with dolphins is shown . Additionally , Olivia Newt[MASK]n @-@ John makes a cameo[MASK]appearance during their joint[MASK]performance of Newton @-@ John 's [MASK]ong ,[MASK]" Hopelessly Devoted t[MASK] You " . The video was commer[MASK]ially [MASK]uccessful , being[MASK]certified platin[MASK]m in the United States by the Recording Industry Association of Americ[MASK] ( RIAA ) and gold in Brazil by the Associação [MASK]rasileira dos Prod[MASK]tores de Discos ( ABPD ) . 
 
 = = Background = = 
 
 Since her debut in 1990 , Carey had not journeyed on a larg[MASK] or extensive tour . I[MASK] fact , she had not embarked on a tour until her third stu[MASK]io effort , Music Box ( 1993 ) , when she performed six arena shows in the United States during [MASK]he Music Box Tour . The opening night of the[MASK]tour r[MASK]ceived scathing reviews , mostly[MASK]aimed at Carey 's deemed " obvious " stage @-@ fright and failure to make[MASK]a connection with the crowd . Succeeding nights were more favorably reviewed , with[MASK]critics raving about Carey 's[MASK]vocals . Jon Pareles of The New York Times wrote regarding Carey 's live vocals , " Be[MASK]ond any doubt , Ms. Carey 's v[MASK]ice is no studio co[MASK]coction . Her range extends from a rich , husky alto to dog @-@ whistle high notes ; she can linger over sensual turns , growl with playful confidence , syncopate like a scat singer . " Howeve[MASK] , [MASK]fter the strong medi[MASK] attention , Carey did not visit the US on her succeeding Daydream World[MASK]Tou[MASK] in 1996 , vi[MASK]iting only Europe and Asia . The tour in contrast [MASK] received critical acclaim from critics and fans alike , as well as breaking ticket[MASK]sale records . Carey 's three shows a[MASK] Japan 's largest [MASK]tadium , Tokyo Dome , sold out in under three hours , equal[MASK]ng in over 150 @,@ 000 tickets , setting the recor[MASK] of fastest show sellouts in Jap[MASK]n 's history . On the Butterfl[MASK] Wo[MASK]ld Tour [MASK] Carey broke the record , selling 200 @,@ 000 tickets in under one hour . During 1997 , after the co[MASK]mercially and c[MASK]itically successful release of Butterfly , Carey had not planned [MASK]o [MASK]our once again , due to th[MASK] long travel times and strain on her voice . However , due to overwhe[MASK]ming demand by fans , Carey agreed to p[MASK]rform in Asia once again , only extending the tour to Taiwan an[MASK] Australia , as well as one last show in the United S[MASK]ates . Rehearsals for the show began shortly after Christmas 1997 , extending for a period of[MASK]two weeks . 
 
 = = Concert synopsis = = [MASK][MASK]
 The show began wi[MASK]h Carey standing on a small elevated [MASK]ent[MASK]rpiece on stage , surrounded by several long draped curtains . Carey featured three background vocalists throughout [MASK]he tour , Trey Lorenz , Melodie Daniels and Kelly P[MASK]ice . As the introduction began with " E[MASK]otions " , each of the curtains were slowly draped , revealing Carey atop [MASK]he platform , dressed in a bei[MASK]e mini @-@ dress and matching sheer blouse and stiletto heels .[MASK]As she be[MASK]an performing " Emotions " , the platform was lowered so Carey could [MASK]ccess the other sections of the sta[MASK]e throughout the song 's performance[MASK]. After [MASK]n intimate performance with dimmed lights for " The [MASK]oof ( Back [MASK]n Time ) " , Carey was [MASK]oined on @-@ stage by a Peruvian guitar player , who played the Latin @-@ inspired guitar melodies during her performance[MASK]of " My[MASK]All " . Afterwards , Carey sang " Close My[MASK]Eyes " , t[MASK]e only sitting performance of the show . During the song , several male backup dancer[MASK] performed slow and ample dance routines behind Carey on a higher level of the [MASK]tage . 
 For the second part of the [MASK]how , Carey had the sec[MASK]nd costume change of the even[MASK]ng , donning a long sequined bla[MASK]k go[MASK]n and semi @-@ teas[MASK]d hair . For the performance of " Dreamlover " , [MASK]arey w[MASK]s joined by three female back @-@ up dancers , who mimicked her light dance routines during the song . The next song on the set @-@ list was " Hero " , which featured Carey alone on @-@ stage , without any vocal back @-@ up . After the song 's performance , Carey[MASK]was joined on @-@ stage by Lorenz , who performed " I 'll[MASK]Be There " alongside her . Next came " Make It Happen " , a song which accompanied yet anot[MASK]er wa[MASK]drobe change for Carey . She donned a shor[MASK] mini @-@ skir[MASK] , alongside a sleeveless white blouse [MASK]nd loose golden curls .[MASK]O[MASK] @-@ stage , Carey was joined by a full church choir , all dresse[MASK] in lon[MASK] black garments . After the song 's recital , Carey performed " One Sweet Day " , alongside a previously recorded video of Boyz II Men during their live perf[MASK]rman[MASK]e of the song w[MASK]th Carey at Madison Square Garden in 1995 . 
 After completing the song , Carey changed to a pair of leg @-@ hugging blue jeans and a tank top . Her next performance was t[MASK]e " Fantasy[MASK]" remix , fea[MASK]uring Ol ' Dirty Bastard on a la[MASK][MASK]e pr[MASK]jection screen behind the sta[MASK]e , as Carey performed light chair dance @-[MASK] routines alongside several male dancer[MASK] . The performance featured the most i[MASK]tricate choreography Carey performed on the tour . After a low @-@ key performance of " Babydoll " ,[MASK]or " Whenever You Call " in other countries , Carey was once again[MASK]joined by several male dancers , as she sang " H[MASK]ney " , [MASK]hile re @-@ enacting the music video during a small skit [MASK] Carey once again changed to a [MASK]eige e[MASK]semble similar to her first outfit before performing her debut single , " Vision of Love " . The fina[MASK] song on the tour was " Butt[MASK]rfly " , which featured large stills of butterflies and flowers p[MASK]ojected onto the large screen behind Carey . She donned a long brown sequine[MASK] gown for the performance , being joined on stage once again by h[MASK]r trio of back @-@ up sing[MASK]rs . Durin[MASK] the shows in Japan , Carey performed her h[MASK]liday classic " All I Want for Christmas [MASK]s You " , al[MASK]ngside var[MASK]ous male and female dancers on stage who performed light dance routines alongside Carey . During the song , [MASK]arey donned a Santa suit and matching h[MASK]t ,[MASK]while being carried on a large stage prop by the dancers . 
 
 = = Critical reception = = 
 
 Virtually [MASK]he entire tour was an instant sell @-@ out ; the four shows at Ja[MASK]an 's largest stadium , Tokyo Dome , broke Care[MASK] '[MASK] p[MASK]evious ticket @-@ sales record , sell[MASK]ng out all 200 @,@ 000 tickets in under one hour . Additionally , the entire Australian leg sold out within hours , leading Carey to extend the tour one more da[MASK]e in the United States . The show at Hawaii 's 50 @,@[MASK]000 c[MASK][MASK]acit[MASK] Aloha Stadium sold ou[MASK] as well , making her one of [MASK]he[MASK]few acts in the stadium[MASK] history to [MASK]ell out the entire venue . Aside from its commercial success , [MASK]ans and critics raved about the show 's visuals , as well as Carey 's vocal delivery . 
 
 = = Broadcasts and[MASK]recordings = = 
 
 During the tour , several bits and performances were filmed and[MASK]later edited into a VHS and DV[MASK] entitled Around the World . The VHS f[MASK]atured performances from Tokyo Dome , Aloha Stadium a[MASK] well as few other skits and scenes that were later compiled into the video .[MASK]The film first begins with performances in Hawaii ,[MASK]where the[MASK]song 's recitals are cut into halves , excluding the second vers[MASK]s and bridge to shorten the bulk length of the [MASK]ideo . Afterwards[MASK], Carey 's per[MASK]ormance of " My All "[MASK]is shown in int[MASK]r @-@ cu[MASK] scenes from Japan [MASK]nd Taipei . After the conclus[MASK][MASK]n of the song , scenes of Carey co[MASK]versing with Brenda K. Starr are shown , which eventually lea[MASK] to a tribute to her at a small and intimate New York club , where Carey performs " I Still Believe " . Soon after , Carey 's performance in Japan with Lorenz for " I[MASK]'ll Be There " is shown , leadin[MASK] to scenes of Ca[MASK]ey swimming with dolphins in Australi[MASK]. the next title on the video is Carey 's live rendition of " Hopelessly Devoted To You " , where she is[MASK]joined by Olivia New[MASK]on @-[MASK] John on stage in M[MASK]lbourne . A scene of a fans gathering outside of a New York City stu[MASK]io is shown , follo[MASK]ing a performance of " Honey , " and " Hero " at [MASK]loha Stadium . The VHS was a commercial success , being certified platinum [MASK][MASK] the Recording Industry Association of America ( RIAA ) , denoting shipments of over 100 @,@ 000 units . The video was [MASK]lso certif[MASK]ed gold in Brazil by the Associação Brasileira dos Produtores d[MASK] Discos ( ABPD ) .
