 Source : 
 
 
[MASK]= Thelnetham Windmill = 
 
 Thelnetham Windmill , also known as Button 's Mill is a Grad[MASK] II * list[MASK]d tower mill [MASK]onstructed of brick . The windmill is [MASK]ocated[MASK]at Thelnetham , Suffolk , England . It[MASK]was built in the early nineteenth century to grind wheat into f[MASK]our . Thelnetham w[MASK]ndmill worked by wind po[MASK]er until 1924 , latterly on two sails , after which it became derelict . 
 In 1979 , a [MASK]rou[MASK] of enthusiasts purchase[MASK] Thelnetham windmill fo[MASK] restoration . Numerous volunteers help[MASK]d to [MASK]e[MASK]tore the mill to ful[MASK] working order over an eight @-@ year period . The mill is open to the public , and flour ground at the mill can be bought at the site . 
 The mill[MASK]is[MASK]a small four storey tower mill with Patent sails and winded by a fantail . It drives two pairs of millstones , with a third pair driven by an auxiliary engine . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 The windmill at Thelnetham was built by millwright George Bloo[MASK]field for William Button in 1819 . It replaced a post mill which had been move[MASK] to Sandy Lane , Diss , Norfolk the previous year . The mill was [MASK]et to work on Christmas Day 1819 . I[MASK] 1832 , the mill was modernised by the fitting of [MASK] cast @-@ iron windshaft , Patent sails and a fantail . The new windshaft was fitted on 16 July 1832 .[MASK]It was made by J Aickman , the Kings Lynn millwright , and weighs 1 ¾ tons ( 1 @,@ 780 kg ) . A new stock was fitted in September 1836 .[MASK]William Button died on 11 February 1837[MASK]. The mil[MASK] passed[MASK]jointly to his widow Rebec[MASK]a and [MASK]heir son Richard . Richard Button worked the mill until 1860 , at which date it was conveyed to his sons Richard and William , who sold it to Richard Pever[MASK]tt from Kenninghall , Norfolk in 1862 . 
 Th[MASK] mill was worked by Stephen Peverett[MASK], Richard 's son . He inherited the mill on the deat[MASK] of his father in 1875 and leased it to Henry Bryant in 187[MASK] . In 1884 , the mill was sold by auction , and Henry Bryant purchased the freehold . Bryant rebuilt the floors of the mill . From 1892 , a portable steam engine was used as auxilia[MASK]y power , driving an extra pair of mills[MASK]ones on the ground floor . This was replaced in 1914 by a Hornsby o[MASK]l engine . Bryant ran th[MASK] mill until 1920 when he[MASK]sold it to Alphonso Vincent , a retired millwright from Garboldisham , Norfolk . The Hornsb[MASK] engine w[MASK]s sold in the early 1920s . The mill was tailwinded c1920 , and as a result one pair of sails was removed . Vincent carried out som[MASK] repairs to the mill and ran it until he retired in 1924 . One of the remaining two sails was wrecked in 1926 when the mill was again tailwinded . 
 On the death of Alphonso Vincent in 1932 , his son George inherited the prope[MASK]ty . He lived at the site in an old lorry until his de[MASK]th in 1973 . The mill passed to his daughter , who sold it[MASK]in 1974 to Mr and Mrs Humphries , who [MASK]ntended to convert it into a house . They later[MASK]changed their minds and offered it for sale for restor[MASK]tion . In 197[MASK] ,[MASK]the cap of the mill was blown to pieces[MASK]in a g[MASK]le . Thelnetham windmill was purchased by five members of the Suffolk Mills Group in November 1979 , and plans for rest[MASK]ra[MASK]ion were mad[MASK] . The consortium consisted of Mark [MASK]arnard , Charles Dolman , Peter Dolman , David Pearce and Ch[MASK]is Seago . The d[MASK]relic[MASK] mill and an acre of land cost £ 6 @,@ 000 . 
 
 = = Restoration = = 
 
 The mill was restored over a period of six years . Much [MASK]f the work was carried[MASK]out by enthusiasts who used wor[MASK]ing hol[MASK]days to repair the mill . 
 
 = = = 1979 – 1980 = = = 
 
 The consortium[MASK]took possession of the mill in November 1979 . The first priority was to mak[MASK] the mill as weathertight as possible . Polythene sheets were spread on the dust floo[MASK] of the mill to prevent [MASK]urther water penetration of the structure . The mi[MASK]l was surveyed and recorded . In spring 1980 , the dust flo[MASK]r partially collapsed and was removed as a safety measure . Scaffolding was erected t[MASK] allow the fanstage to be dismantled , and the cap[MASK]centering wheel[MASK] were removed in prepara[MASK]ion for the rem[MASK]val of the cap frame . 
 A t[MASK]o @-@ week work @-@ in was held at the end of July and beginning o[MASK] August 1980 . Thirty @-@ three volunteers worked on the mill over the work @-@ in . Two new main floor beams for th[MASK] dust floor were made from baulks of pitc[MASK] pine which had previously been in a maltings at Bury St Edmunds . On 3 August 1980 , the windshaft and remaining sail fra[MASK]ments were remo[MASK]ed by a mobile crane , f[MASK]llowed by th[MASK] c[MASK]p [MASK]rame and th[MASK] cast @-[MASK] iron [MASK]urb sections . 
 New oak joists were laid on the dust floor and temporary boarding l[MASK]id to provide a working platform for repairs to the top of the mill towe[MASK] . The bin f[MASK]oor was removed , apart from[MASK]one oak main beam which was repairable . A r[MASK]placement main beam[MASK]was made fr[MASK]m pitch pine , and the oa[MASK] beam was repaired . New oak joists were fitted , along with some salvaged from the [MASK]riginal floor which were fit to be reused . One of these had previously been [MASK] whip from a Common sail . Some of the jo[MASK]sts were made fro[MASK] pitch pin[MASK] [MASK]rom the Eastbridge Windpump , which , follow[MASK]ng its collap[MASK]e on 19 February 1977 , ha[MASK] been re @-@ erected at the Museum of East Anglian Life , Stowmarket . The sack hoist was dismantled to enable its repair , brickwork wa[MASK] repaired , a[MASK]d [MASK]ew [MASK]intels were made for some [MASK]f the windows . A tarpaulin was secured over the mill tower to keep the weath[MASK]r out over winter . The floorboards on the bin floor were replaced and one of the two pairs of millstones was removed . 
 The work was financed by grants of £ 500 [MASK]rom the Council for the Preservation of Rural Essex , £ 250 from St Edmundsbury [MASK]orough Council , £ 200 from the Scarfe Trust , and £ 200 from the Suffolk Mills Group . Other donations and income amounted to £ 65 , with the balance o[MASK] expenditure being me[MASK] jointly by the five owners . 
 The " work @-@ in " was reported in both local and national media , including BBC Look East , Bury Free P[MASK]ess[MASK], Eastern Daily Press , Ea[MASK]t Anglian Daily Times , Daily Telegr[MASK]ph , and Radio Orwell . 
 
 = = = 1981 = = = 
 
 In the 1981 season two separate work @-@ ins were hel[MASK] , the first from 25 July to 2 August and the second from 22 August to 30[MASK]August . A total of 37 volunteers participated over the two weeks . 
 The millstones were removed from the stone floor , which wa[MASK] then repair[MASK]d . One of the main beams was found to have been attacked by Death Watch beetles , and over a third o[MASK] the elm beam [MASK]as rep[MASK]aced with oak . The six supports for the h[MASK]rst frame were repaired[MASK]one at a time , as they bore the whole of the weig[MASK]t of the machinery above . One post required replacement . It had rott[MASK]d and the floor had sunk[MASK]by 4 inches ( 100 mm ) causing the sec[MASK]nd main floor beam to fracture . When th[MASK]s work had been completed , the stone floor was removed , including the second main floor bea[MASK] , which was removed in one piece so that the most suitable route to install its r[MASK]placement could be assessed . 
 The new main beam[MASK]for the sto[MASK]e floor was installed and the ground floor was concreted . The stone[MASK]floor was re[MASK]onstructed , reusing the old stone bearers an[MASK] those joists that were fit for reuse . Other joists were made new from oak or pitch pine . New floorboards w[MASK]re laid in the dust floor , the 1 1 ⁄ 4 inches ( 32 mm ) thick elm boards being double @-@ [MASK]rooved with a metal[MASK]tongue between them . Those on the bin floor are of a similar configuration . Th[MASK] top four courses of brickwork of the mill tow[MASK]r were removed and work began on rebuilding them [MASK] aided by a trammel attac[MASK]ed to the upright sha[MASK]t[MASK]. 
 D[MASK]ring the second work @-@ in , the remainder of the ston[MASK] floor was boarded , agai[MASK] using double @-@ grooved board[MASK] with a metal tongue between them . The window on the dust floor was rebuilt and the reconstruction of the top four courses of brickwork continued . The top two courses were rebuilt with red engineering bricks . The dust floor window had a reinforced concrete lintel cast as the tower was weak at[MASK]thi[MASK] point and had distorted .[MASK]The windshaf[MASK] , the curb s[MASK]gments and fantail gear[MASK]ng were given two coats of red lead paint . A new finial for [MASK]he cap was mad[MASK] from a piece of oak 3 feet ([MASK]910 mm ) long by 16 inches ( 410 mm ) diam[MASK]ter . A start [MASK]as made on remo[MASK]ing the old pointing on the[MASK]brickwork and repointing with gau[MASK]ed mortar . 
 After [MASK]he work @-@ in had finished , the boardi[MASK]g of [MASK]he stone floor wa[MASK] completed and the mill thoroughly cleaned in preparation for an open[MASK][MASK]ay which was held in late autumn . The work done in 1981 cost £ 3 @,@ 250 . Donations r[MASK]ceive[MASK] were £ 2 @,@ 000 f[MASK]om Rank Xerox , £ 1 @,@ 704 from the Historic Building[MASK] Council and £ 130 from St Edmundsbury Borough Co[MASK]ncil . Other donations and income[MASK]received amounted to £ 70 . The proje[MASK]t received further coverage in local media , the Eastern Daily Press , and South Norfolk News . 
 
 = = = 1982 = = = 
 
 The 1982 work @-@ ins took place from 24 July t[MASK] 1 [MASK]ugust and 21 August to 29 August . The work pla[MASK]ned included the complet[MASK]on of the brickwor[MASK] at the top of the tower , inst[MASK]llation of the Elm curb , a start on the constr[MASK]ction of the new cap , installing machiner[MASK] and making and fitting[MASK]various[MASK]doors and windows . The cap fram[MASK] was constructed , incorporating two beams from the original cap frame that were[MASK]fit to be re[MASK]sed . The cap frame was completed in autumn 1982 . It had been constructed upside down and a[MASK]mobile crane was used to turn it over and place the[MASK]windshaft in[MASK]o p[MASK]sitio[MASK] . 
 
[MASK]= = = 1983 = = = 
 
 Work in the early part of 1[MASK]83[MASK]was[MASK]mainly confined t[MASK] smaller jobs such as casting various brasses and overhaul of the var[MASK]ous parts of the fantail driv[MASK]train and mechanism for control[MASK]ing the Patent sails . The mill was generally made as safe as possible inside in preparation for schedule[MASK] visits , including one from the Wind and Watermill Section of the Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings .[MASK][MASK]ther work included [MASK]he o[MASK]erhaul of the final drive to the 4 feet 7 [MASK]nches ( 1 @.[MASK] 40 m[MASK]) stones , including dismantling the stone nut and replacement of th[MASK]ee cogs in be[MASK]ch . [MASK] When the weather improved , work commenced outside . The cap circle was mostly constructed before the firs[MASK] work @-@ in commenced . The wor[MASK] @-@ ins took place over two separate weeks in July and August , with [MASK]5 people participating . D[MASK]ring the first work @-@ in , the fantail posts and braces were fitted . The oak cap ribs , which had been prefabricated[MASK]offsite were fitted and the finial was supp[MASK]rted by scaffolding ready for final fitting . Inte[MASK][MASK]diate noggings of[MASK]oak were fitted and the[MASK]finial was p[MASK]lled into position using a[MASK]windlass . The [MASK]ap frame was competed with the fitting of intermediate ribs and noggings . The[MASK]rear of the cap circle was also completed during this time . 
 Between [MASK]he two work @-@[MASK]ins , the rear dormer was completed and the fitting of noggings to the [MASK]ap frame completed . This enabled a start to be made on boarding the cap on the Monday of the[MASK]se[MASK]ond work @-@ in . The boards f[MASK]r the cap are ½ inch ( 13 mm ) thick and 9 inches ( 230 mm ) wide at the petticoat , tapering toward[MASK][MASK]the top . A new neck bearing was i[MASK]stalled under the windshaft , not without difficulty and much machining before it would fit . When the boarding of the cap was completed , the cover strips were fi[MASK]ted over the joints . The petticoat was drawn into position using a rope and windlass , and the galvanised steel reinforcing band screwed into position , produ[MASK]ing a sturdy structure . The striking rod was fitted through the windshaft and the axle for the fantail fitted in position on top [MASK]f the fantail posts . At the top of the mill t[MASK]wer , the curb was prepared [MASK]o accept the cap , and the[MASK]cast iron curb track plates bolted into position [MASK][MASK]Re[MASK]ointing of the brickwork of the tower continued , wit[MASK] nearly half of it completed at the end of the [MASK]econd wor[MASK] @-@ in[MASK]. 
[MASK][MASK]fter the wo[MASK]k @-@ ins had ended , work continued on[MASK]finishing the [MASK]ap which was scheduled for lift @-@ on in October . The weather hampered the work initially , but the application of a modern microporous paint , designed to withstand normal movement of the timber and yet remain waterproof , was completed in time for the lift @-@ on .[MASK]A m[MASK]ni work @-@ in was held the weekend before [MASK]he cap was lifted , with 17 people p[MASK]rticipating over the [MASK]eekend . Final work was done to the cap and a new window was fitted to the stone floor of the mill . The tarpaulin was removed and t[MASK]e trammel[MASK]dismantled . The 5[MASK]@-@ ton cap was lifted into place by a mobil[MASK] [MASK]rane [MASK]n 24 October 1983 , watched by a crowd of some 70 people . The fitting of the cap was [MASK]oasted with b[MASK]er from Ad[MASK]ams Brewery , Southwold . 
 Restoration work in 1983 cost £ 1 @,@ 408 [MASK] Grants were received from the Association of Independent Museums , Blo ' Norton Women 's Instit[MASK]te , Ipswich Historical Transport Society , the National Association for Gifted Children , Mr D. Porter and the Society for the Protec[MASK]ion of[MASK]Ancient Buildings .[MASK]Further income came from the sale of guide books and a drawing of the mill by Wilf Foreman . 
 
 = = = 1984 [MASK] = = 
 
 Four [MASK]ork @-@ ins were held during 1984 . The first two were by apprentices[MASK]from Eastern Electricity Board . Thelnetham Windmi[MASK]l was chosen at the project to benefit from the Young Person 's Development Project for that year . Pakenham Watermi[MASK]l [MASK]ad previously benefited from the project , and its owners , the Suffol[MASK] Preservation Trust , had suggeste[MASK] that Thelnetham Windmil[MASK] wo[MASK]ld be a good candidate for the scheme . Two separate parties spen[MASK] a week each at the mill . A mains electricity supply was provided .[MASK]An underground[MASK]cable was laid with assistance from Bri[MASK]ish Telecom who were trialling a thrust bore[MASK] which had been developed at their research facility at Martlesham Heath . The thrust borer laid 25 [MASK]ards ( 23 m ) of ducting through which the mains cable was pulled into position . The mill was then supplied with lights and sockets on each floor . 
 Other work undertaken b[MASK] the appr[MASK]ntices involved repairing some fros[MASK] damage to th[MASK] foundation brickwork , digging a drainage trench[MASK]around the mill and moving the aux[MASK]liary engine into position . A concrete path ar[MASK]und the tower was trapping moisture , leading to[MASK]rising damp . A Fren[MASK]h drain was constructed around th[MASK] mill to remedy these problem . A 21 horsepower ( 16 kW ) Ruston & Hornsby 4YHR diesel engin[MASK] had been[MASK]purchased in 1981 and was fitted onto a permanent concrete base with the aid of a mobile crane . After fit[MASK]ing it [MASK]as then painted . Some missing or broken parts[MASK]were made or repaired as necessary . 
 Off @-@ site , the new brake wheel and fantail were made . The original brake wheel was too rotte[MASK] to repair , and showed evidence that it had been [MASK]lter[MASK]d from t[MASK]e original o[MASK]e installed in 1819 . The original brake wheel w[MASK]s 6 feet ( 1 @.@ 83 m ) diameter to al[MASK]ow the Common [MASK][MASK]ils to run at their optimum speed [MASK] When the mill was modernised in[MASK]1832 it was necessary to alter the gear ratios within the mill , as Patent sails [MASK]un at a slower speed tha[MASK] Common sails . The great spur wheel was increased in diameter and[MASK]the stone nuts reduced in diameter . The bra[MASK]e wheel was also rebuilt , with a[MASK]cast iron segment ring fitted in place of the original cogs , resulting in a wheel 7 feet 2 inches ( 2 @.@[MASK]18 m ) in diameter . The opinion of professional millwrights was sought , and it was decided that a scaled @-@ up version of [MASK]he original brake wheel would be made , b[MASK]t retaining the cast iron teeth segments . The remains of the original brake wheel were retained as an exhibit in the mill . The original iron segments were all broken , so a pattern was made and[MASK]new [MASK]egments were cast i[MASK] heat @-@ treated malleable cast iron . When the [MASK]rak[MASK] wheel w[MASK]s completed i[MASK] was dismantled and transported to t[MASK]e mill ready for reassembly . 
 The fantai[MASK] was made . Some[MASK]of the smal[MASK] gears were replac[MASK]d . The stocks were made from [MASK]itch pine and the blades from Douglas fir . Work at the mill over the winter included repairs to the brickwork and w[MASK]ndows , with only one window s[MASK]ill needing attention when the first work @-@ in began . New beech cogs were fitted to the cro[MASK][MASK] wheel , wh[MASK]ch[MASK]was restored to its correct positio[MASK] on the upri[MASK]ht shaft . 
 The stocks and sails were made during the two work @-@ ins held in July and August , a total of 41 peo[MASK]le attending[MASK]over the two weeks . A second @-@ hand stock had been bought in the 1920s and preserved at the mill , but upon examinat[MASK]on i[MASK] was fo[MASK]nd to be unfit for use . Thus two new stocks were required instead of one . Modern steel stocks had already been discounted on cost and durability grounds , leaving two options . Tra[MASK]itional stocks made from a si[MASK]gle piece of timber , or laminated stocks . Good quality pitch pine was not obtainable in the[MASK]lengt[MASK]s required . Douglas fir was obtainable in such lengths but[MASK]w[MASK]s discounted o[MASK] st[MASK]ength and durability grounds . A Douglas fir stock on a nearby mill had rotted[MASK]after only seven years . Thus it was decided that laminated stocks would be made . 
 The 52 [MASK]eet ( 15 @.@ 85 m ) lo[MASK][MASK] stocks were made from Douglas fir . All timber had[MASK]been pressure treate[MASK] with prese[MASK]vative and well seasoned . It was es[MASK]imated that a laminated stock [MASK]ould be up to 20 % stronger than a similar stock of solid timber .[MASK]The timber used was 1 1 ⁄ 2 inches ( 38 mm ) thick and nine laminations were required at the centre , where the stock passes through [MASK]he poll end of t[MASK]e win[MASK]shaft . Careful at[MASK]ention[MASK]was paid to where individual joints occurred between different pieces of timber . Both stocks were made during the work @-@ in , with one of them being trimmed and finished ready for use . The stocks were the firs[MASK] laminated stocks made by amateurs . 
 The f[MASK]ur sails were made . The originals being s[MASK]ightly different pairs . Those on the inner stock having bays o[MASK] 3 feet ( 910 mm ) pitch and those on the outer stock having bays of 3 [MASK]eet[MASK]2 inches ( 970 mm ) pitch . It was decided that the new sails wo[MASK]ld be identical , at the larg[MASK]r pitch . Fou[MASK] 27 feet ( 8 @.@ 23 m ) long whips were cut from a baulk of pitch pine obtained from a demolished maltings at Bury St Edmunds . The wh[MASK]ps are 6 inches ( 150 mm ) square at their inner end . Sail bars and uplongs were made from modern pitch pine , selected for quality . The mo[MASK]tices for the sail bars were cut . That at the heel of the sail being at[MASK]27 ° [MASK]nd that at the tip being 15 ° , decreasing by 1 ½ ° at each sai[MASK] bar . Three of the four sails [MASK]ad been completed at the end of the work[MASK][MASK]n .[MASK]
 The fantail and associated gearing was fitted to the mill . At the end of the secon[MASK] work @-@ in , the cap could be turned by means of t[MASK]e hand c[MASK]ank . The fantail itself , with the blades painted red , white and blue was installed [MASK]hortly afterwards . The clasp arm brake wheel was assembled aroun[MASK] the windshaft . It was found that the w[MASK]llower was eccentric on the upright shaft by ½ inch ( 13 mm ) .[MASK]When this was corrected the brake wheel[MASK]was within 1 / 16 th of an inch ( less than 1 mm ) of true . The clamps for the stocks were sawn from [MASK] baulk of pit[MASK]h pine ready for completion later in the year . Other work included[MASK]a new frame for one of the ground floor doors , cleaning and painting ironwork an[MASK] further repointing on the brickwork . The four sails were fitted to the mill with the aid of a mobile crane at the end of the sec[MASK]nd work @-@ in . The stock , with one sail attached was carefully inserted thr[MASK]ugh t[MASK]e poll end of the windshaft and when wedged in position and the clamps had[MASK]been attached the second sail was fitted to the stock . The process was [MASK]epeated for[MASK]the secon[MASK] pair of sails . The mill turned by wind again on the las[MASK] day of the second work @-@ in . 
 Work later in the year included the finishing of [MASK]he fourth sail , balan[MASK]ing the [MASK]antail and sorti[MASK]g out teething troubles with the fantail gearing . The brake[MASK]and brake lever were made and installed and shutte[MASK] cranks for the sails were cast . 
 Restoration work in 1984 cos[MASK] £ 2 @,@ 918 . Grants received were £ 1 @,@ 209 from English Heritage , £ 5[MASK]0 fr[MASK]m St Edmundsbury Borough Council , Other d[MASK]nations a[MASK]ounted to £ 52 . Income from open days at the [MASK]ill ca[MASK]e to £ 151 . A[MASK]boost to[MASK]the funds was £ 2 @,@ 000 from Hervey Benham .[MASK]This money ha[MASK] been allocated to allow the moving of a derelict post mill buck to Thelnetham . In the end , the removal was not proce[MASK]ded with , and Mr Benham allowed the donation to remain with the Thelnetham Mill Preservation Trust . The project received further support in local media , including the East Anglian Daily Times , one of the work @-@ ins [MASK]eing featured on Anglia Television 's About Anglia pr[MASK]g[MASK][MASK]mme . 
 
 = = = 1985 - 87 = [MASK] = 
 
 Wor[MASK] planned for 1985 included the replacement of the dust floor window and completion of the stocks and sails .[MASK]The external walls of the mill were[MASK]tarred and internal walls plastered . Two[MASK]work @-@ ins were held , from 20 July to 28 July and[MASK]1[MASK] August to 26[MASK]August .[MASK]Further work over t[MASK]e next two years saw the restoration completed in 1987 . 
 
 = = Restoration team = = 
 
 The restoration of Thelnetham Windmi[MASK]l was made possible by the efforts of 135 individuals and 61 organisations . This was achieved by the donation of labour , plant , materials or gran[MASK]s of money , or by giving discou[MASK]ts for materials purchased or providing publicity for the project . 
 
 =[MASK]= Description = = 
[MASK]
 Terms explained in the Mill machinery article are in italics 
 As built in 1819 
 A four[MASK]@-@ storey tower mill with Common sails carried on a wooden windsh[MASK]ft , driving two p[MASK]irs of overdrift mi[MASK]lstones . Brake wheel 6 feet ( 1 @.@ 83 m ) diameter . Winding wa[MASK] by hand . 
 As restored 
 [MASK]he four @-@ st[MASK]rey tower is built of brick , and stands 31 [MASK]eet 5 inches ( 9 @.@ 58 m ) from ground level to the curb . The walls are 2 feet ([MASK]610 mm ) thick at ground level . The mill is d[MASK]scribed from the top down .[MASK]
 The pepperpot cap sits on top of the tower , giving the m[MASK]ll an overall height of 45 feet ( 13 @.@ 72 m ) to the f[MASK]nial . It houses the cast @-@ iron windshaft and 7 feet 2 inches ( 2 @.@ 18 m ) diameter w[MASK]oden brake wheel internally . Ext[MASK]rnally the four double Paten[MASK] sails span 64 feet ( 19 @.@ 51 m ) . They are 9 feet ( 2 @.@ 74 m )[MASK]wide and can develop 30 horsepower ( 22 kW ) . The eight bladed fantail keeps the mill turned into wind . 
[MASK]The top floor of the [MASK]ill is the dust floor . It could be used for stor[MASK]ge of grain and gives internal access to the [MASK]ap . The cast @-@ iron wallower[MASK], which is driven by the brake wheel is carr[MASK]ed at the top of the upright shaft , in the centre[MASK]of the mill . 
 The bin floor is where the grain is stored before b[MASK]ing ground into flour . The sack hoist mechanism is housed on this floor , d[MASK]iven from the wooden crown wheel on the floor below by belt . 
 The stone floor is where the two pairs of underdrift French Burr[MASK]millstones are located . Th[MASK] stones are 4 feet 4 inches ( 1 @.@ 32 m ) and 4 feet 7 inches ( 1 @.@ 40 m ) diameter . T[MASK]e wooden c[MASK]own wheel is located towards the ceiling . This drives the sack hoist on the bin floor . Other machinery on this floor are an oat crush[MASK]r and a flour dresser . 
 The ground floor of the mill is the meal floor . It is whe[MASK]e the freshl[MASK] ground flour is delivered for bagging up . T[MASK]e wooden great spur wheel , located at the bottom of the e[MASK]tended upright shaft and st[MASK]ne nuts are located on this floor . The g[MASK]eat spur wheel has been converted from co[MASK]pass arm construction to clasp arm constructio[MASK] . A third pair of 4 feet 6 inches ( 1 @.@ 37 m ) diameter French Burr millstones is locat[MASK]d on a hurst frame , driven by the auxiliary engine via a[MASK]fast and loose pulley .

 = = Pub[MASK]ic access =[MASK]= 
 
 Thelnetham Mill is open to the public on Easter Monday [MASK] the Sunday of the la[MASK]e May and August bank holida[MASK]s and the fir[MASK]t Sunday in July , Augus[MASK] and September . I[MASK] is also open at other times by pri[MASK]r arrangement . 
 
 
 = Sailor Mou[MASK]h = 
 
 " Sailor Mouth " is the first segment of the 18th episode of the second season , or the 38th overall episode of the American animated televisio[MASK][MASK]se[MASK]ies SpongeBob SquareP[MASK]nts . Th[MASK] episode was directed by Andrew Overtoom , and was written by Walt Dohrn , Paul Tibb[MASK]tt , and Merriwethe[MASK] Williams . Dohrn and Tibbitt also served [MASK]s storyboard directors , and Carson Kugler[MASK], William Re[MASK]ss , and Erik Wiese worked as storyboard artists . It originally aired on Nickelodeon in the United States on September[MASK]21 , 2001 . 
 T[MASK]e series follows the ad[MASK]entures and endeavors of the title character and his vario[MASK]s friends in the underwater city of Bikini Bottom . In this episo[MASK][MASK] , SpongeBob reads a " bad word " off[MASK]a dumpster behind the Krusty Krab , but does not know what it means . Pa[MASK]rick explains to him that it is a " sentence enhancer " which is used " when you want to talk fancy .[MASK]" The two start using it in [MASK]very sentence they speak . However , when Mr. Krabs hears them , he warns the two never to use the word ag[MASK]in or any [MASK]f the 13 bad words . Later on[MASK], SpongeBob accidentally swears again . Patrick then runs to tell Mr. Krabs [MASK]ith Sponge[MASK]ob trying to stop him . However , w[MASK][MASK]n Mr. [MASK]rabs acci[MASK]entally injures [MASK]is toe , he utters all the 13 bad words . The two cannot believe it and run to Mama Krabs t[MASK] tell on him . Mama Krabs , who i[MASK] app[MASK]lled by their use of the words , makes the three paint her house as punishment . 
 The episode received positive reviews , while v[MASK]rio[MASK]s members of the SpongeB[MASK]b SquarePants crew consider the epi[MASK]ode to be one of thei[MASK] favorites , mainly due to the satirical nature of the episode . Howev[MASK]r , the episode wa[MASK] not immune to negative r[MASK]ception , and was criticized by watchdog media group the Parents Television Council and fans , who interpreted the episode as an example of promoting and implicitly satirizing [MASK]se of profanity towards children . 
 
 = = Plot summary = = 
[MASK]
 W[MASK]en SpongeBob goes around[MASK]to the back of the Krusty Krab to take out the trash , he reads some words writt[MASK]n on a dumpster . SpongeBob [MASK]sks Patrick what is it and Patrick says that the word is a " sentence enhancer " which is used " when [MASK]ou want to talk fancy . " The next day , SpongeBob walks into the Krusty Krab and says the word to Patrick and [MASK]hen over the intercom . The Kr[MASK][MASK]ty Krab customers a[MASK]e [MASK]pp[MASK]lled by SpongeBob 's use of his " word " and leave . S[MASK]uidward then informs Mr. Krabs , who then decides to t[MASK]ll them that they were[MASK]using pr[MASK]fanity , and mentions that there are 13 swear wo[MASK]ds they should not use . SpongeBob and Patrick vow Mr. Krabs that they will never use swear words again . 
 Later , they play their favorite game , Eels and Escalators . Patrick always gets escalators but SpongeBob always gets [MASK]els . Eventually ,[MASK]he loses the game and accidentally utters the swear word[MASK]. Patrick then races to the Krusty Krab to tell Mr. Krabs with SpongeBob trying to stop him . SpongeBob bursts through the front door and tells Mr. Krabs that Patrick said the swear word , Patrick then joins along . Eventual[MASK]y , Mr. Krabs stops their gibberish explanations , and takes SpongeBob and Patrick outside and makes them paint the Krus[MASK]y Krab as punishment . 
 Mr. Krabs is about to give SpongeBob and Patrick the job , but he hits his foot on a rock , throws the paint away and says all 13 swear words whil[MASK] complaining about his foot being injured . When Sp[MASK]ngeBob and Patrick hear all the swear words , they run to Mama Krabs ' house to tell her that M[MASK]. Krabs swears . When they all reach her house , [MASK]hey repeat the same sw[MASK]ar words that Mr. Krabs used . This makes her faint , but short[MASK]y afte[MASK] Mr. Krabs scolds SpongeBob and Patrick for saying all those bad words in front of her she regains consciousness . M[MASK]ma Krabs [MASK]tates that all three [MASK]f them should be ashamed for saying a[MASK]l those words . She then gives all [MASK]hree of them the task of painting her house with a fresh coat of paint [MASK]s punishment for saying those words at her . 
 [MASK] = = Production = = 
 
 " Sailor Mouth " was directed by Andrew Overtoom , and was written by Walt Dohrn , Paul Tibbitt , and Merriwether Williams . Dohrn an[MASK] [MASK]ibbitt also served as storyboard directors , and[MASK]Carson Kugler[MASK], William Reiss and Erik Wiese worked as storyboard[MASK]artists . Series creator Stephen Hillenburg has described the episode plot as " a classic thing all kids go through . " Much of the storyline for the episode was ins[MASK]ired by the writers ' own experiences f[MASK]om childhood . The episo[MASK]e originally aired on Nickelodeon in the United States on September 21 , 2[MASK]01 . The episode marks the intro[MASK]uction of Mr. Krabs ' mother , Mama Krabs , who was voiced by former SpongeBob SquarePants creative prod[MASK]cer and current exe[MASK]utive producer[MASK]Paul Tibbitt . 
 The writing staff used their individual childhood ex[MASK]eriences as inspirations to come up with much of the story lines for this episode . The idea for " Sailor Mouth " was inspired[MASK]by creative dire[MASK]tor Derek[MASK]Drymon 's experience " [ when ] I got in trouble for saying the f @-@ word in front of my mother . " Drymon said , " The scene where Patrick is running to [MASK]r. Krabs to tattle , with SpongeBob chasing him [MASK] is pretty much how it happened in real life . " The end of the e[MASK]isode , where Mr.[MASK]Krabs uses more p[MASK]ofanity than SpongeBob and Patrick , [MASK]as also inspired " by the fact th[MASK]t my [ Drymon [MASK]s ] mother has a sailor mouth hers[MASK]lf . " 
 The scene where [MASK]po[MASK]geBob and Patrick playing a game [MASK]f Eels and Escalators , which is a parody of Snakes and Ladders , was difficult for the crew to animate , since many shots featured certain board pieces changing location . According to the series ' sea[MASK]on 2 DVD commentary , it was planned to have a scene that[MASK]had SpongeBob saying " Go ' dolphin noise ' yourself " followed[MASK]by Patrick saying " ' Dolphin noise ' you too ! " during the Eels and Escalato[MASK]s game . It was removed in the final episode check because it would have been inappropriate for the younger [MASK]udience . 
 " Sailor Mouth " was released on the DVD compilation called SpongeBob S[MASK]uarePants : Sea Stories on March 12 , 2002 . It was [MASK]lso included in the SpongeBob Sq[MASK]arePants : The Complete 2nd Season DVD released on October 19 , 2004 . On September 22 , 2009 , " Sailor Mouth " wa[MASK] release[MASK] on the SpongeBob Squ[MASK]rePants : The First 100 Episodes , alongside all the epi[MASK]odes of seasons[MASK]one through five . 
 
 = = Reception = = 
 
 Erik Wiese , a member of the SpongeBob S[MASK]uarePants crew , considers " Sailor Mouth " to be his favorite episode , mainly due to its random and satirical nature , saying " Sometimes SpongeBob[MASK]just catches me[MASK][MASK]ff @-@ guard . [MASK] Nancy Basile of About.com ranked[MASK]the episode at number two for her list of the Top 10 SpongeBob SquarePants[MASK]Episodes . She[MASK]said " ' Sailor Mouth ' just barely missed being in[MASK]the numbe[MASK] one slot . " Basile praised the episode 's plot and called it " genius [ ... ] because child[MASK]en can relate to the forbidden thrill of using curse words , and [MASK]dults can laugh at the parody of TV censorship . " In an in[MASK]erview with Paul Tibbitt , one of the episode 's writers , he told that " Sailor Mouth " is his second favorite SpongeBob episode . 
 [MASK] = = = Criticism and cont[MASK]oversy = = [MASK] 
 
 According to a report titled Wolves in Sheep 's Clothing [MASK] which d[MASK]cuments[MASK]the incre[MASK]se in potentially violent , profane , and sexual content in children 's programming , the Parents Television [MASK]ouncil , a wa[MASK]chdog media group , and fans believed the SpongeBob SquarePan[MASK]s episode " Sai[MASK]or Mouth " was an implicit attempt to promote and satir[MASK]ze use of profanity among[MASK]children . The e[MASK]isode originally aired during the 2001 – 02 television season , ironically the season in which the PTC nam[MASK]d SpongeBob SquarePants among the best programs on cable television , but the report cited a repeat broad[MASK]ast of the episode from 2005 to prove its point that it promoted use of p[MASK]ofanity [MASK]mong children . In a[MASK]later report , several members of the PTC listed " Sailor Mouth " as an example of how levels of profane , sexual , and violent activity has increased in children 's television program[MASK]ing . Nickelodeon , in response to the incident , said " It 's sad and a little desperate that they stooped to literally putting profane language in the [MASK]ouths[MASK]of our characters to make a point . Has the FCC looked at this ? " Richard Huff of the N[MASK]w York Daily News criticized the repor[MASK] for misinterpreting an episode of SpongeBob SquarePants , " Sailor Mouth " , over its intent to sati[MASK]ize profanity implicitly . 
 
 
 = Military history of Australia = 
 
 The military history of Australia spans the nation 's 220 @-@ year modern history , from the e[MASK]rly Australian frontier wars between Aboriginals and Europeans to the ongoing conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan in the early 21st century . Alt[MASK]ough t[MASK]i[MASK] history is short wh[MASK]n compared to that of many other nations , Austra[MASK]ia has been involved in numerous conflicts and war[MASK] , [MASK]n[MASK] war and military service have been significant influences on Australian society and national identity , including the Anzac spirit . The relationship between war and Australian society has also been sha[MASK]ed by[MASK]the enduring themes of Australian st[MASK]ategic culture a[MASK]d its unique security dilemma . 
 As British offshoots , the Aust[MASK]ali[MASK]n [MASK]ol[MASK]nies participated in Britain 's small wars of the 19th century , while later as a federated dominion , and t[MASK]en an independent n[MASK]tion , Australia fought in the First World War and Second World War , as well as in the wars in Korea , Malaya[MASK], Borneo and Vietnam d[MASK]ring the Cold[MASK]War . In the Post @-@[MASK]Vietnam era Australia[MASK] forces have been involved in numerous international peacekeeping missions , through the United Nations [MASK]nd other agen[MASK]ies , including in the Sinai , Pe[MASK]sian Gulf , Rwanda , Somalia , East Timor and the Solomon Islands , while more recently they have also fought as part [MASK]f multi @-@ lateral forces in Iraq and Afghanistan . In total , nearly 103 @,@ 000 Australians died during the [MASK][MASK]urse of these c[MASK]nflicts . 
 
 = = War and Australian society = = [MASK] 
 For most of the l[MASK]st century military service[MASK]has be[MASK]n one of the single greatest shared experiences of white Australian males , and alth[MASK]ugh this is now changi[MASK]g due to the pro[MASK]essionalisation of the m[MASK]litary and the absence of major wars during the second half of the 20th century , it continues to influence[MASK]Australian society to this day . War and military servi[MASK]e h[MASK]ve been defining influences in Au[MASK]tralian history , wh[MASK]l[MASK] a major part of the national identity has been built on an idealised conception of the Australian experience of war and[MASK]of soldiering , known as the Anzac spirit . [MASK]hese ideals include no[MASK]ions of endurance , courage , ingenuity , humour , larrikinism , egalitarianism and mateship ; traits which , ac[MASK]ording to popular thought , de[MASK]ined the behaviour of Austr[MASK]lian soldiers fighting at Gallipoli during the First World War .[MASK]The Gal[MASK]ipoli campaign was one o[MASK] the first internation[MASK]l events that saw [MASK]ustralians taking part as Australians and has been seen as[MASK]a key event i[MASK] forging a sense of national identity . 
 The relationship between war a[MASK]d Australian society has been shaped by two of the more [MASK]nduring themes of Australian strategic culture : bandwagoning with a power[MASK]ul ally and expeditionary w[MASK]rfare .[MASK]Indeed , Australian defence policy was closely [MASK]inked to Britain until [MASK]he Japanese crisis of 1942 , while since then an alliance with the United States has underwri[MASK]ten its security . Arguably , this pattern of bandwagoning — both for cultural reasons such as shared values and beliefs , as well as for more pragmatic security concer[MASK]s — has ensured that Australian strategic policy has often been defined by relations with its allies . Regardless , a tendency towards strategic complacency has also been evident , with [MASK]ustralians often reluctant to think about defence [MASK]ssues or to allocate resources until a crisis arises ; a trait which ha[MASK] historically resul[MASK]ed in unpreparedness for major military challenges . 
 R[MASK]flecting[MASK]both the realist and liberal paradigms of international relations and the conception of national interests , a nu[MASK]ber of other important themes in Australian strat[MASK]gic cultu[MASK]e are also obvious . Such t[MASK]e[MASK]es include : an acceptance of the state as the key actor in internationa[MASK] politics , [MASK]he centrality of notions o[MASK] Westphalian sovereignty , a belief in the enduring relevance and legiti[MASK]acy of armed force as a guarantor of security , and the proposition that the status quo in internat[MASK]onal [MASK]ffairs should only be changed peac[MASK]fully . Likewise , multilateralism , collectiv[MASK] security and defence se[MASK]f @-@ reliance have also been important th[MASK]mes . Change has been more evolutionary than revolutionary and these strategic behaviours have persisted throughout its history , being the product of Australian society '[MASK] democratic political tradition and Judaeo @-[MASK] Christian [MASK]nglo @-@ European heritage , as well its associated values , beli[MASK]fs and economic , political and religious ideology . These behaviours are also refl[MASK]ctive of its unique security dilemma as a largely European island on the edge of the Asia @-@ Pacific , and the geopolitical c[MASK]rcumstances of a middle power physica[MASK][MASK]y removed from the centres of world power . To be sure , during threats to th[MASK] core Australia has often found itself defending the periphery and perhaps a[MASK] a result , it has frequently beco[MASK]e i[MASK]volved in fore[MASK]gn wars . Throughout these conflicts [MASK]ustralian soldiers — known colloquially as Diggers — have often b[MASK][MASK]n noted , somewhat paradoxically [MASK] for both their fighting abilities and their huma[MASK]itarian qualities . 
 
 = = Colonial era = = 
 
 
 = = = Brit[MASK]sh Forces in Australia , 1788 – [MASK]870 =[MASK]= = 
 
[MASK]From 1788 until 1870 the defence of the[MASK]Australi[MASK]n colonies was [MASK]ostly[MASK]pro[MASK]ided by British Army regular force[MASK] . Originally Ma[MASK]ines protected the early settlements at Sydney Cove a[MASK]d Norfo[MASK]k Island , however they were relieved of these duties in 1790 by a British Army unit specifically recruited for colonial service , known as the [MASK]ew South Wales Corps . The New So[MASK]th Wales Corps subsequent[MASK]y was involved in putting down a rebellion of Irish convicts at Castle Hill in 1804 . Soon however shortcoming[MASK] in the c[MASK]rps convinced the War Office of the need for a more reliable garrison in New South Wales and Van Diemen 's Land . Chief of these shortcoming[MASK] wa[MASK] the Rum Rebellion , a coup mounted by its officers in 1808 . As a r[MASK]sult , i[MASK] January 1810 the 73rd ( Perths[MASK]ire ) Regiment of F[MASK]ot arrived in Australia . By 1870 , 25 British infan[MASK]ry regiments h[MASK]d served in Austral[MASK]a , as[MASK]had a small number of[MASK]artillery [MASK]nd[MASK]engineer u[MASK]its . 
 Although the primary role of[MASK]the British Army[MASK]was to protect the colo[MASK]ies against external attack , no actual threat ever material[MASK]sed . The British Army wa[MASK] instead used in policing , guarding convicts at penal institutions , co[MASK]ba[MASK]ing bushranging , putting d[MASK]wn convict rebellions — as [MASK]ccurred at Bathurst in 1830 — and to suppress Aboriginal[MASK]resistance to the extension of E[MASK]ropean settleme[MASK]t . Notably [MASK]ritish soldiers were involved in the[MASK]battle at the Eureka Sto[MASK]ka[MASK]e in 1854 on the Victorian[MASK]goldfields . Members of British regiments stationed in Australia also saw action in India , Afghanistan , New Zealand and the Sudan [MASK] 
 During th[MASK] early years of settlement the naval defence of [MASK]u[MASK]tralia was provided by detached Royal Navy units of the East Indies Station ,[MASK]based in Sydney . Howeve[MASK] , in 1859 Australia was established as a separate squadron under the command of a comm[MASK]dore , marking the first occasion that Royal Navy ships had been permanently stationed[MASK]in Australia . The[MASK]Royal Navy remained the primary naval force[MASK]in Australian waters until 1913 , when the Australia Station ceased and responsibility handed ov[MASK]r to the [MASK]oyal Australi[MASK]n Navy ; the Roya[MASK] Navy 's depots , doc[MASK]yards and structures were given to the Australian people . 
 
 = = = Frontier warfare , 1788 – 1934 = = = 
 
 The reaction[MASK] of the native Aboriginal inhabitants to the sudden arrival of British settlers in Australia were v[MASK]ried , but were inevitably hosti[MASK]e when the settler 's presence led to competition over resources , and to the occupation of the indigenous inhabitants ' lands . European diseases decimated Aboriginal popul[MASK]tions , and the occupation or destruction of lands and food resources sometimes led to starvat[MASK]on . By and large neither the British nor the Aborigines approached the conflict in an organised sense and conflict occurred between groups of settlers and individual tribes rather tha[MASK] systemati[MASK] warfare . At times , howe[MASK][MASK]r , the frontier wars[MASK]did see the involvement of British soldiers and later mounted pol[MASK]ce units . Not all Aboriginal groups resisted white encroachment on their lands , while many Aborigines served in mounted police [MASK]nits and were involved in attacks on other tribes . 
 Fight[MASK]ng between Aborigines and Europeans was localised a[MASK] the Aborigines did not form confederations capable of sus[MASK]ained resistance . As a result , there was not a single war , but rather a series of violent engagements and massacres across the continent . Organised or disorganised however , a pattern of frontier warfare emerged with Aboriginal resistance beginning in the 18th century and continuing into the early 20th century[MASK]. This warfare contradicts t[MASK]e popular and at times academic " myth " of peaceful settlement in Australia . Faced wi[MASK]h Aboriginal resistance settlers often reacted with viole[MASK]ce , resulting in a number of indiscriminate massacres . Among[MASK][MASK]he [MASK]ost famous is the Battle of Pinjarra [MASK]n Western Australia in 1834 [MASK] Such incidents were not o[MASK]f[MASK]cially sanctioned however[MASK], and after t[MASK]e Myall Creek ma[MASK]sacre in New South[MASK]Wales in 1838 seven Europeans were han[MASK]ed for their[MASK]part in the[MASK]killings . However , in Tasmania the so @-@ called Black War was [MASK]ought between 1828 and 1832 , and aimed at driving most of the [MASK]sland 's native inhabi[MASK]an[MASK]s onto a number of isolated peni[MASK]sulas . Although it began in failure for the British , it ultimately resulted in considerable casualties[MASK]amongst the native population . 
 It may be inaccurate though to depict the conflict a[MASK] one sided and mainly perpetrated by Europeans on Aborigines . Although many more Aborigines died than British , this may have had more to do with the technological and logistic advantages enjoyed by the Europeans . Aboriginal tactics varied , but were mainly based on pre @-[MASK] existing hunting and fighting pract[MASK]ces — using spears , clubs and other primitive weapons . Unlike the indigenous peoples of New Zeal[MASK]nd and [MASK]orth America , on the main Aborigines failed to adapt to meet the challenge of the Europeans . Although there were some instances of in[MASK]ividuals and gr[MASK]ups acquiring and usin[MASK] firearms , this wa[MASK] not wides[MASK]read . The Aborigines were never a serious military threat to European settlers , regardless of how much the settlers may have feared them . On occasio[MASK]s large [MASK]roups [MASK]f Aborigines attacked the[MASK]settlers in open terrain and [MASK] conventional battle ensued , during which the[MASK]Aborigines would a[MASK]tempt to use superior [MASK]umbers to their advantage . This could sometimes be effective , with reports of [MASK]hem advancing in crescent formation in an attempt to outflank[MASK]and surround their opponents , waitin[MASK] out the first volley of shots and then hurling their sp[MASK]ars while the settlers reloaded . However , such open warf[MASK]re usually proved more costly fo[MASK][MASK]the Aborigines t[MASK]an the Europeans . 
 Central to the success of the Eu[MASK]opeans was [MASK][MASK]e use of firear[MASK]s .[MASK]How[MASK]ver , the advantages afforde[MASK] by firearms have often b[MASK]en overstated . Prior to[MASK]the late 19th century , firearms were often cumbersome muzzle @-@ loading , smooth @-@ bor[MASK] , single shot muskets with flint @-@ lock mechan[MASK]sms . Such weapons produced a low rate of fire , while suffering from a high rate of failure and were only accurate within 50 me[MASK]res ( 160 ft[MASK]) . These [MASK]eficiencies may have initially given the Aborigines an advantage , allowing them to move in close and engage with [MASK]pears or clubs . Yet [MASK]y 1850 significant advances in firearms gave the Europeans a distinct advantage , with the six @-@ shot Colt re[MASK]olver , t[MASK]e Snider single shot breech @-@ loading rifle and later the Mart[MASK]ni @-@ Henry rifle , as well as rapid @-@ fire rifles such as the Winchester rifle , becoming [MASK]vailable . These weapons , when used on open g[MASK]oun[MASK] and combined with the superior mobility provided by horses to surround and engage groups of Aborigines , often proved successful . The Europeans also had to adapt their tactics to [MASK]ight their fast @-@ moving , often hi[MASK]den enemies . Tactics employed included night @-@ time surprise a[MASK]tacks , and positio[MASK][MASK]ng f[MASK]rces to drive the natives off cliffs or force them to [MASK]etreat into rivers while attacking from both banks . 
 The conflict lasted for over 150 years and followed the patter[MASK] of British settlement in Australia . Beginning in New South Wales with the arrival of the first Euro[MASK]eans in Ma[MASK] 1788 , it continued in Sydney[MASK]and its surrounds until the 1820s . As the frontier moved west so did the conflict , pushing into outback New [MASK]outh Wal[MASK]s in th[MASK] 1840s . In Tasmania , fighting can be [MASK]raced from 1804 to the 1830s , while in Victoria and the southern parts of South Australia , the majority of the violence occurred[MASK]duri[MASK]g the 1830s and 1840s . The south @-@ west of Western Australia experienced warfare from 1829 [MASK]o 1850 .[MASK]The war in Queensland began in[MASK]the area around Brisbane in [MASK]he 1840s and continued until 1860 , moving to central Que[MASK]nsland in the 1850s and 1860s , and then to northern Queensland from the 1860[MASK] to 1900 . In Western Aus[MASK]ralia , the violence moved north with European settlement , reaching the Kimberley region by 1880 , with violent clashes continuing until the 1920s . In the Northern Territory conflict l[MASK]sted even later still , especially in central Australia , c[MASK]nt[MASK]nuing[MASK]from t[MASK]e [MASK]880s to the 1930s [MASK] One estimate of casualties plac[MASK]s Eur[MASK]pean deaths at 2 @,@ 500 , while at least 20 @,@ 000 Aborigines are believed to have perished . Far more devastating though was the effect of disease which significantly reduced th[MASK] Aboriginal population by the beginning o[MASK] the 20th[MASK]century ; a fact which may also have limited their ability to resist[MASK]. 
 
 = = [MASK] New Zealand Wars , 1861 – 64 = = = 
 
 
 = = = = Ta[MASK]anaki War = = = = 
[MASK]
 In 1861 , the Victoria[MASK] ship HMCSS Victoria was dispatched to help the New Zealand colonial government in its war against M[MASK]ori in Taranaki . Vic[MASK]o[MASK]ia was subsequently used[MASK]for patrol duties and lo[MASK]ist[MASK]c support , although a numb[MASK]r of p[MASK]rsonnel were involved in actions against Māori fortification[MASK] . One sailor died from an ac[MASK]idental gunshot wound during the deployme[MASK]t . 
 
 = = = = Invasion of the Waikato = = = = 
 
 In late 1863 , the New Zealand government requested troops to assist in the invasion of the Waikato province [MASK]gainst the Māo[MASK]i . Promised settlement on confiscated land , more than 2 @,@ 500 Aust[MASK]alians ( over half of whom were from Victoria ) were recruited to form[MASK]four Waikato[MASK]Regiments . Other Australian[MASK] became scouts in the Company of Forest Rangers . Despite experiencing arduous conditions the Aust[MASK]alians were not heavily involve[MASK] in battle , and were primarily used for patrolling and garrison duties . Australians were involved in actions at Matarikori[MASK]o , Pukekohe East , Titi Hill , Ōrākau [MASK]nd Te Ranga . Fewer than 20 were believed to[MASK]have been killed in action . Th[MASK] conflict was over by 1864 , and the[MASK]Waikato Regiments disbanded in 1867 . Howeve[MASK] , many[MASK]of the soldiers who [MASK]ad chosen to claim farmland at the ce[MASK]satio[MASK] of hostilities had drifted to the towns and cities by the end of[MASK]the de[MASK]ade , while man[MASK] others had returne[MASK] to Australia . 
 
 = = = Colonial military forces , 1870 – 1901 = = = 
 
 From 1870 until 1901 , each of the six colonial governments was responsible for their [MASK]wn defence . The colonies had gained responsible government between [MASK]855 and 1890 , and while the Colonial Office i[MASK] London retained control of some affairs , the Governor of the ea[MASK]h colony was[MASK]require[MASK] to raise their own colonial militia . To do this , they were g[MASK]anted the authority from the Britis[MASK] crown to raise military and naval forces . Initially these were militia[MASK] in support of British regulars , [MASK][MASK]t when military support for the coloni[MASK]s ended in 1870 , the colonies assumed their [MASK]wn defence responsibiliti[MASK]s . Th[MASK] colonial milita[MASK]y forces inclu[MASK]ed unpaid volunteer militia , paid citizen s[MASK]ldiers , and a small permanent component . They were mainly infantry , cavalry and mounted infantry , a[MASK][MASK] were[MASK]neither housed in barrack[MASK] nor subj[MASK]ct to[MASK]full military discipline . Even[MASK]after si[MASK]nificant reform[MASK] in the 1870s —[MASK]including the expansion of the permanent forces to include engineer and arti[MASK]lery units — they remained too small and unbalanced to be con[MASK]idered armies i[MASK] the modern sense . By 18[MASK]5 , the forces numbered 21 @,@ 00[MASK] m[MASK]n . Although [MASK][MASK]ey cou[MASK]d not be compelled to serve overseas many volu[MASK]teers subsequently did see action in a number conflicts of the British Empire during the 19th century , with the colonies raising continge[MASK]ts to serve in Sudan , South Africa and China . 
 Despite a reputation o[MASK] colonial inferiority , many of th[MASK] locally raised units [MASK]ere highly organised ,[MASK]discip[MASK]ined , professional , and well trained . During this period , defences in Austra[MASK]ia mainly revolved around[MASK]static defenc[MASK] by combined infantry and artillery , based on garrisoned coastal [MASK]orts . However , by the 1890s , improved railway communications b[MASK]tween [MASK]he mainland eastern colonies led Major General James Edwards — who had recently completed a survey [MASK]f colonial military forces — t[MASK] the belief that [MASK]he colonies c[MASK]uld be defended by the rapid mobilisation of brigades of infantry .[MASK]As a consequence he called for a restructure of defences , and defensive agreements to be made between the colonies . Edwards argued for the colonial forces to be federated and for professional units — obliged to serve anywhere in the South Pacific — to replace the volunteer forces . [MASK]hese views found support in the influential New South Wales Commandant , Major General Edward Hutton , however suspicions held by the smaller colonies towards New South Wales and Victoria stifle[MASK] the proposal . These[MASK]reforms remaining unresolved however , and defence [MASK]ssues were generally given little attention in the debate on the political federation of the colonies . 
 With the exception of Western Australia , the colon[MASK]es also operated their own navies . [MASK]n 1856 , Vic[MASK]oria received its own[MASK]naval vessel , HMCSS Victoria , and its deployment to New Zea[MASK]and in 1860 during the First [MASK]aranaki War marked the first occasion that an Aust[MASK]al[MASK]an warship had been deployed ov[MASK]rseas . The colonial navies were expanded greatly in the mid @-@ 1880s and consisted of a numb[MASK]r of gunboats and torpedo @-@ boats for the defence of ha[MASK]bours and rivers[MASK], as well as naval brigades to man vessels and fo[MASK]ts . Victoria[MASK]b[MASK]came the most powerful of all the [MASK]olonial navies , with the ironclad HMVS Cerberus in service from 1870 , as well as the steam @-@ sail warship [MASK]MS Nelson on loan from the Royal Navy , three small gunboats and[MASK]five torpedo @-@ boats . New South Wales formed a Naval Brigade in 1863 and by the sta[MASK]t of the 20th century had two small torpedo @-@ boats[MASK]and a corvette . The Queensland Maritime Defence For[MASK]e was established i[MASK] 1885 , while South Australia operated a single ship , [MASK]MCS Protector . Tasmania had[MASK]also a small Torpedo Corps , while Western Australia 's only naval defences included the Fremantle Naval Ar[MASK]illery . Naval personnel from New South Wales and Victoria took part in the suppression of the Boxer Rebellion in China in 1900 , while HMCS Protector was sent by South Austral[MASK]a but saw no action .[MASK]The separate [MASK]olonies maintained control over their military and naval forces until Federation in 1901 , when th[MASK]y were amalgamated and placed under the control of the new Commonwealth of Australia . 
 
[MASK]= = = Sudan , 1885 = = = 
 
 During the early years of the 1880s , an Egyptian regime in the [MASK]udan , backed by [MASK][MASK]e British , came under threat from rebellion under the leadership of native Muha[MASK]mad Ahmad ( or Ahmed ) , known as Mahd[MASK] to his fol[MASK]owers . In 1883 , as part of the Mahdist War , the Egyptians sent an army to deal wit[MASK] the revolt , but they were defeated and faced a diffi[MASK][MASK]lt campaign o[MASK] extracting their[MASK]forces . The[MASK]British instru[MASK]t[MASK]d the Egy[MASK]tians to abandon the Sudan , a[MASK]d sent General Charles Gordon to co @-@ ordinate the evacuation , but he w[MASK]s killed in January[MASK]1885 . When news of his death arrived in New South Wales in February 1885 , the go[MASK]ernment offered to send fo[MASK]ce[MASK] and meet the contingent 's expenses . The New South Wales Contingent co[MASK]sisted of an infantry bat[MASK]alion[MASK]of 522 men[MASK]and 24 officers , and an artillery battery of [MASK]12 men a[MASK]d sai[MASK]ed[MASK]from Sydney on 3 Marc[MASK] 1885 . 
 The contingent arrived in Suakin on 29 March a[MASK]d were attached [MASK]o a brigade that consisted of Scots , Grenadier and Coldstream Guar[MASK]s . They subsequ[MASK]n[MASK]ly marched for Tamai in a l[MASK]rge " square " formation made up of 10 @,@ 000 men . Reaching the village , they burned huts and returned to Suakin : three[MASK]Australians we[MASK]e wounded in mi[MASK]or fighting . Most of the contingent was then sent to work [MASK]n a railway line that was being laid across the desert towards Berber , on the Nile . The Australians were then assigned to guard duties , but soon a camel corps was raised and 50 men volunteered . They rode on a reconnaissance to Takdul on 6 M[MASK]y and were heavily involved in[MASK]a skirmish during which more than 100 Arabs were kill[MASK]d or captured . On 15 May , they made one last sortie to bury the dead from the fighting of the previo[MASK]s March . Meanwhile , the artillery were posted at Handoub and drilled for a month , but t[MASK]ey soon rejoined the camp at Suakin . 
 Eventually the B[MASK]itish gover[MASK]ment decided that[MASK]the campai[MASK]n in Sudan was not[MASK]worth the effort required and left a garrison in Suakin . The New South Wales Contingent sailed for home on 17 May ,[MASK]arriving in Sydney on 19 June 1885 . Approximat[MASK]ly 770 Australians served in Sudan ; nine subseque[MASK]tly died of disease during the return journey while three had been wounded during the campaign . 
 
 = = = Second Boer War , 1899 – 1902 = = = 
 
 British e[MASK]croachment into areas of South Africa already settled by the Afrikaner B[MASK]ers and the com[MASK]etition for resources and land that developed between them as a result , led to t[MASK]e Second Boer War in 1899 . P[MASK]e @-@ empting the deployment of British f[MASK]rce[MASK] [MASK] the Afrikaner Republics of the Orange Free State and the Transvaal Republic under President Paul Kruger[MASK]declared war on 11 October 1899 , striking deep[MASK]into the British te[MASK]ritories of Natal and the Cape Colony . After the outbreak of war , plans for the dispatch of a combined Australian force were subsequently set aside by the British War Office and each of the six colonial gover[MASK]ments sent separate contingents to serve w[MASK]th British formations , with two squadrons each of 125 men fr[MASK]m New South Wales a[MASK]d Victo[MASK]ia , and one each from the other colonies . The first troops a[MASK]rived [MASK]hree weeks later , with the New South Wales Lan[MASK]ers — who had been training in England before the war , hurriedly diverted to South A[MASK]rica . On 22 November , the Lancers came under fire for the fi[MASK]st time near Belmont , and they subsequently forced their attackers to wi[MASK]hdraw afte[MASK] inflicting significant casualties on them . 
 Following a series of minor victories , the British suffered a major setback during Black Week between 10 – 17 December 18[MASK][MASK] , although no Australian[MASK]units wer[MASK] involved [MASK] The first contingents of infantry from Victoria , South Australia , Western Australia , and Tasmania arrived in Cape Town on 26 November and were designated the Australian Regiment under the command of Colonel John Charles Hoad . With a need for increased mobility , they were soon converted into mounted infantry . Further units from Queensland and New South Wales arrived in December and were soon committed to the front . The first casualties occurred soon after at Sunnyside on 1 January 1900 , after 250 Quee[MASK]sland Mounted Infantry and a column of Canadian[MASK] , British and artillery attacked a Boer laager at Belmont . Troopers David McLeod and Victor Jones were killed when their patrol clashed with the Boer forward sentries . Regardless ,[MASK]the Boers were surprised and during two hours of heavy fighting , mor[MASK] than 50 were killed and anoth[MASK]r 40 taken prisoner . Five hundred Queenslanders and the New[MASK]South Wales Lancers subsequently took part in the S[MASK]ege of Kimberley in February 1900 . 
 Despite serious set @-[MASK] backs at Colenso , Stormberg[MASK], Magersfontein , and Spion Kop in January — and with Ladysmith s[MASK]ill under siege — the British mounted [MASK] five division cou[MASK]ter @-@ invasion of[MASK]the Orange Free State in February . The attacking force included a division of cavalry commanded by Lieutenant General John French with the New South Wales Lancers , Queensland Mounted Infantry an[MASK] New South Wales Army Medical Corps atta[MASK]hed . First ,[MASK]Kimberley was relieved foll[MASK]wing the [MASK]attles of Modder River and Magersfontein , and the retreating Boers defeated at Paardeberg , with the New South Wales Mounted Rifle[MASK] loc[MASK]ting the Boer general , Piet Cronjé . The British entered Bloemfontein on 13 March 1900 , [MASK]hile Ladysmith was relieved [MASK][MASK]Disease began to take its toll and scores of men died . Still the advance c[MASK]ntinued , with the drive to Pr[MASK]toria in May including more than 3 @,@ 000 Australian[MASK] . Johannesburg fell on 30 May , and the[MASK]Boers withdrew from Pretoria on[MASK]3 June . T[MASK]e New South W[MASK]les Mou[MASK]ted Rifles and Western Australians saw a[MASK]tion again at Di[MASK]mond Hill on 12 June . Mafeking was relieved[MASK]on 17 May . 
 Following th[MASK] defeat of the Afrikaner republics still the Boers held out , forming small commando units and conducting a campaign of guerrilla warfare to disrupt British troop movements and lines of supply . This new phase of resistance led to further recruiting in the Australian colonies and the raising of the Bushmen 's Contingents , with these soldier[MASK] usually being volunteers with horse @-@ riding and shooti[MASK]g skills , but[MASK]little military experience . After Federation in 1901 , eight Australian Commonwealt[MASK] Horse battalions of the newly created Australian Army w[MASK]re also sent to South Afri[MASK]a , a[MASK]t[MASK]ough they saw litt[MASK]e fighting [MASK]efore the war ended [MASK] Some Australians later jo[MASK]ned local South African irregular units , instead of returning home after discharge . These soldiers were part of the British Army , and were subject to B[MASK]it[MASK]sh military discipli[MASK]e . Su[MASK]h units included the Bushveldt Carbineers which gained notoriety a[MASK] the un[MASK]t in which Harry " Breaker " Morant and Peter Handcock served in before their court martial and execution f[MASK]r war crimes . 
 With the guerrillas requiring supplies , Koos[MASK]de la Rey lead a force of 3 @,@ 000 Boers against Brakfontei[MASK] , on the Elands River in Weste[MASK]n Transvaal . The post held a large quantity of stores and was defended by 300 Australians and 200 Rhodesia[MASK]s .[MASK]The attack began on 4 August 1900 with[MASK]heavy shelling causing 32 casualties . During the night the d[MASK]fenders dug in , en[MASK]uring shelling and rifle fire .[MASK]A relief force was stopped by the Boers , while a second column turned back believing tha[MASK] the post had alread[MASK] been re[MASK]ieved . The siege lasted 11 days , during which more than 1 @,@ 800 shells were fired into [MASK]he post . After calls to surrender were ignored by [MASK]he[MASK]defenders , [MASK]nd not prepared to risk a frontal attack , the Boers [MASK]ventually retired . The Siege of Elands[MASK]River w[MASK]s one of the major achievements of the Australi[MASK]ns during the war , with the[MASK]post finally relieved on 16 August . 
 In response[MASK]the British adopted counter @-@ insurgency tacti[MASK]s ,[MASK]including a scorch[MASK]d earth policy involving the bur[MASK]ing of houses and crops , the establishment of co[MASK]centration camps for Boer women and children ,[MASK]and a system of blockhouses and field obstacles to limit Boer mobility and t[MASK] protect railway[MASK]communications . Such measures required considerable expenditure , a[MASK]d caused much bitterness towards the British , however they soon yielded results . By m[MASK]d @-@ 1901 , the bulk of the fighting was over , and British mounted units would ride at night to attack Boer farmhouses or encampments , overwhelming them with superior numbers . Indicative [MASK]f warfare in last months of 1901 , the New South Wales Mounted Rifles travelled 1 @,@ 814 miles ( [MASK] @,@ 919 km ) and were involved in 1[MASK] skirmishes , killing 2[MASK] Boers , woundi[MASK]g 15 , and capturing[MASK]196 for the loss of five dea[MASK] and 19 wounded . Other notable Australi[MASK]n actions included Slingersfontein , Pink Hill , Rhenosterkop and Haartebeestefontein . 
 Australians were not [MASK]lways successful however , suffering a number of heavy losses late in the war . On 12 June 1901 , the 5th [MASK]ictorian Mounted Rifles lost 19 killed and 42 wounded at Wilmansrust , near Middleburg after poor sec[MASK]rity allowed a force of 150 Boers to surprise[MASK]them . On 30 October 1901 , Victorians of the Scottish Horse Regiment also suffered heavy casualties at Gun Hill , al[MASK]hough 60 Boers were also[MASK]k[MASK]lled in the engagement [MASK] Meanwhile , at Onverwacht on 4 January 1902 , the 5th Quee[MASK]sland Imperial Bushmen lost 13 killed and 17 wounded . Ultimately the Boers were defeated , and the war ended on 31 May 1902 . In al[MASK] 16 @,@ 175 A[MASK]stralians served in S[MASK]ut[MASK] Africa , and perhaps[MASK]another 10 @,@ 000 enlisted as individuals in Imperial units ; casualties included 25[MASK] killed in action , 267 died of diseas[MASK] and 43 missing in action ,[MASK]while a further[MASK]735 were wounded . Six Australians were awarded the Victoria Cross . 
[MASK]
 = = = Boxer Rebellion , 1900 – 01 = = = 
 
 The Boxe[MASK] Rebell[MASK]on in China began in 1900 , and a number of western nations — including many European powers , the United [MASK]tates , and Japan — soon sent forces as part of the China Field Force to protect their[MASK]interests . In Ju[MASK]e , the British government sought permission from the Australian colonies to dispatch ships from the Australian Squadron to China . T[MASK]e colon[MASK]es also offered to assist further , but as most of their troops were still engaged in[MASK]South Africa , they had to rely on naval forces f[MASK]r manpower . The force dispatched was a modest one[MASK], wit[MASK][MASK]Britain accepting 200 men fr[MASK]m Victoria , 260 from New South [MASK]ales and the South Aus[MASK]ralian ship HMCS Protector , under the command of Cap[MASK]ain [MASK]illiam Cresw[MASK]ll .[MASK]Most of these forces[MASK]were made up of naval brigade reservists , who had been trained in both ship handling and soldiering to fu[MASK]fil their coastal defence role . Amongst the naval contingent from New South Wales were 200 naval officers and[MASK]sailors and 50 permanent sold[MASK]ers headquartered at Victoria Barracks , Sydney who originally enlisted for the Second Boer War . The soldiers were keen [MASK]o [MASK]o to Chi[MASK]a but refused to be enlisted as sailo[MASK]s [MASK] wh[MASK]le the New South [MASK]ales Nava[MASK] Brigade objected to havin[MASK] soldiers in their [MASK]anks . The Army and Navy compromised and titled the contingent the NSW Marine Light Infan[MASK]ry . 
 The contingents from New South Wales and Victoria sailed for China on [MASK] August 1900 . Arriving in Tientsin , the Austral[MASK]ans provided 300 men to [MASK]n 8 @,@ 000 @-@ strong multinational force tasked with capturing the Chinese forts at Pei Tang , which dominated a key railway . They arrived too l[MASK]te to take part in the battle , but were involved in the attack on the fortress at Pao @-@ ting Fu , where the Chinese government was believed to have foun[MASK] asylum after[MASK]Peking was captured by western forces . The Victorians joined a force o[MASK] 7 @,@ 500 men on a ten @-@ day march to the fort , [MASK]nce again only to find that [MASK]t had already surre[MASK]dered . The Victorians then garrisoned Tientsin and the New South Wales contingent undertook g[MASK]rrison duties in Peking . HMCS Protector was[MASK]mostly used for survey , tra[MASK]sport , and courier duties in the Gulf of Chihli , before de[MASK]arting in November .[MASK]The naval brigades remained during the winter , unhappily performing policing and guard duties , as well as working as railwaymen and fir[MASK] @-@ fighters . They left China in March 1901 , having played only a minor role in a few offensives and punitive expedit[MASK]ons and in the restoration of civil order . Six Australians died from sickness and injury , but none were killed as a result of enemy action . 
[MASK]
 = = Australian military forces at Federation , 1901 = = 
 
 The Commonwealth of Australia came into existence on 1 [MASK]anuary 1901 as a resu[MASK]t of the federation of[MASK]the Australian colonies . Under the Constitution of Australia , defence responsibility was [MASK]ow vested in the n[MASK]w federal government . The co @-@ ordination of Australia @-@ wide defensive efforts in the face of Imperial German interest in the Pa[MASK]ific Ocean was one of driving forc[MASK]s behind federalism , and the Department of Defence immediately came into being as a resu[MASK]t , while [MASK]he Commo[MASK]wealth Military Forces ( early forerunne[MASK] of the Australian Army ) and Commonwealth Naval Force were also soon established . 
 The Australian Commonwealth Military Forces came into being on 1 March 1901 and all t[MASK]e colonial forces — including those still in South Afric[MASK] — became part of the new force . 28 @,@ 923 colonial soldiers , including 1 @,@ 457 professional soldiers , 18[MASK]@,@ 603 paid militia and[MASK]8 @,@ 863 unpaid volunteers , were subsequently[MASK]transferred . The individual units continued to be administered under the various colonial A[MASK]ts until the Defence Act 1903 brought all the units under one piece of legislation .[MASK]This Act also prevented the raising of standing infantry units and specified that mi[MASK]itia forces could not be[MASK]used in industrial disputes or serve outside Australia . However , the majority of soldiers remained in militia units , known as the Citizen Military Forces ( CMF ) . Major General Sir Edward Hutton — a former commander of the New South Wales Military Forces — subse[MASK][MASK]ently became the first commander of the Commonwealth Military Forces on 26 December and set to [MASK]ork devising an integrated structure for the new army . In 1911 , following a report by Lord Kitchener the Royal Military College , Duntroon was established , as was a s[MASK][MASK]tem of universal National Service . 
 Prior to federation each self @-@ gov[MASK]rning co[MASK]ony had[MASK]opera[MASK]ed its own naval force . These navies were small[MASK]and lacke[MASK] blue water capabilities , forcing the separate colonies to subsidise the cost of a British naval squadron in their [MASK]aters for decades . The[MASK]colonies maintained control over their respectiv[MASK] navies until 1 March 1901 , when the Commonwealth Naval Force was created . [MASK]his new force also lacked blue wate[MASK] capable ships , and ul[MASK]imately did not lead to a change in Australian naval policy . In 1907 Prime Minister Alfred Deakin and Creswell , while attending[MASK]the Imperial Con[MASK]erence in London , sought the British Government 's agreement to end the subsidy system and deve[MASK]op an Aust[MASK]alian navy . The Admiralty rejected and resented the challenge , but suggested diplo[MASK]atically that a small fleet of destroyers and su[MASK]marines would be sufficient . Deakin was unimpressed , and in 1908 invited the American Great White Fleet to [MASK]isit Australia . This visit fired public enthusiasm[MASK]for a[MASK]mo[MASK]ern na[MASK]y and in part led to the order of two 700 @-@ ton River @-@ class destr[MASK]yers . The [MASK]urge in German [MASK]aval [MASK]onstruction prompted the Admiralty to change their position however and the Royal Australian Navy was subsequently formed in 1911[MASK], absorbing the Commonwealth Naval Force . On 4 October 191[MASK] , [MASK]he new fleet steamed t[MASK]rough Sydney Heads , consisting of the battlecruiser HMAS Australia , three light cruisers , and three destroyers , while several o[MASK]her ships were still under construction . [MASK]nd as a cons[MASK]quence the navy entered the First World War as a formidable [MASK]orce . 
 The Australian Flyin[MASK] Corps ( AFC ) wa[MASK] established as par[MASK] of the Commonwealth Military Forces in 1912 , prior to the formation of the Australian Mili[MASK][MASK]ry Forces in 1916 and was [MASK]ater s[MASK]parated in 1921 to form th[MASK] Royal Australian Air Force , making it the second oldest air force in the world . Regardless , the service branches were not [MASK]ink[MASK]d by [MASK] single chain of command however , and eac[MASK] reported to their own minister and had separate administrative arrangements and government departments . 
 
 = = First World War , 1914 – 18 = = 
 
 
 = = = Outbreak of hostilities = = = 
 
 When Britain declared war on Germany at the star[MASK] of the First World War , the Australian govern[MASK]ent rapidly followed s[MASK]it , with Prime Minister Joseph Cook declaring on 5 August 1914 that "[MASK]...[MASK]when the Empire is at war , so also is Australia "[MASK]and[MASK]reflecting the sentiment of many [MASK]ustralians that any declaration of [MASK]ar by Britain[MASK]automatically included Australia [MASK] This was itself in part due to the large number of British @-@ born citiz[MASK]ns a[MASK]d first generation Anglo @-@ Australians that made up the Australian population at the time . Indeed , by [MASK]he end of the war almost 20 % of those who served in the Austral[MASK]an forces had been born in Britain . 
 As the existing militia forces were unable to serve overseas und[MASK]r the provisions of the D[MASK]fence Act 1903 , an all @-@[MASK]volunteer expeditionary force known as the Australian Imperial Force ( AIF ) was formed and recruitment began on 10 August 1914 . The government pledged 20 @,@ 000 men , organised as one infa[MASK]try division and one light horse brigade plus supporting units . [MASK]nlistment and organisation was primarily regi[MASK]nall[MASK] based and was [MASK]ndertaken under mobilisation plans drawn up in 1912 . The first commander was Major General William Br[MASK]dges , who also assumed command of the 1s[MASK] Division . Throughout the course of the conflict Australian efforts [MASK]ere predominantly focused upon the ground[MASK]war , although small air and naval forces[MASK]were also committed . 
 
 = = = Occupation of Germ[MASK]n New Guinea = = = 
 
 Following the outbreak of war Australian forces moved quickly to reduce t[MASK]e threat to s[MASK]i[MASK]ping posed by the proximity of Germany 's Pacific colonies . The Australia[MASK] Naval and Military Expeditionary Force ( AN & MEF ) , a [MASK]000 @[MASK]@ man volunteer force — separate from the AIF — and consisting of an infantry [MASK]attalion plus 500 naval rese[MASK]vists and ex [MASK]-@ sailors , was rapidly formed under the command of [MASK]illia[MASK] Holmes . The objectives of the force were the wireless sta[MASK]ions[MASK]on Nauru , and [MASK]hose at Yap in the Ca[MASK]oline Islands , and at[MASK]Rabaul in German Ne[MASK] Guinea . The force reached Rabaul on 11 September 1914 and occupied it th[MASK] [MASK]ext day[MASK], encountering only b[MASK]ief resistance from the German and native defenders during fighting at Bita Paka and Toma . German New Guinea surrendered on 17 September 1914 . Australian losses were light , including six killed during the fighting , but were compounded by the mysterious loss offshore o[MASK] the submarine AE1 with all 35 men aboard . 
 
 = = = Gallipoli = = = 
 
 The AIF departed by ship in a single convoy from Albany on 1 Novembe[MASK] 1914 . D[MASK]ring the journey one of the convoy 's naval esco[MASK]ts — HMAS Sydn[MASK]y — [MASK]ngag[MASK]d and destroyed the Ge[MASK]man cruiser SMS Emden at the Bat[MASK]le of Cocos on 8 November , in the fir[MASK]t ship @-@ to @-@ ship action involving the Royal Australian Navy . Although originally bound for England to undergo further training and then for[MASK]employment on the Western Front , the Australians were inst[MASK]ad sent to British @-@ controlled Egy[MASK]t to pre @-@ empt any Turkish attack against the strategically important Suez Canal , and with a view to opening another front against the Central Powers . 
 Aiming to knock Turkey out of the war the British then decided to stage an amphibious lodgement at Gallipoli [MASK]n[MASK] following a period of training and reorganisation the Australians were included amon[MASK]st the British , Indian and French forc[MASK]s comm[MASK]tted to the campaign . The combined Australian and New Zealand A[MASK]my Corps ( ANZAC ) — commanded by British ge[MASK]er[MASK]l William Birdwood — subsequently landed at Anzac Co[MASK]e on the Gallipoli peninsula on 25 April 1915 . Although promising to transform the war if successful , the Gallipoli Campaign was ill [MASK]-@ conceived and ultimately lasted eight months of bloody stalemate[MASK], without achieving its objectives . Australian casualties totalled 26 @,@ 111 , including 8 @,@ 141 killed . 
 For Austral[MASK]ans and New Zealanders the Gallipoli campaign came to symbolise an important milestone in the emergenc[MASK] of both nations as independent actors on the worl[MASK] stage and the development of a sense of na[MASK]ional identity .
