Today , the date of the initia[MASK] landings , 25 April , is known as Anzac[MASK]Day in Australia a[MASK]d N[MASK]w Zealand and [MASK]very year thousands of [MASK]eople gather at memorials in both nations , as well as Turkey , to honour the bravery and sacrifice of the original Anzacs[MASK], and of all those who have subsequently lost their lives in war . 
 
 = = = Egypt and P[MASK]lestine = [MASK][MASK]=[MASK]
 
 After the withdrawal from Gallipoli the Aus[MASK]ralians returned to Egypt and the AIF underwent a major expa[MASK]sio[MASK] . In 1916 the in[MASK]antry began to move to France while the cavalry units remaine[MASK] in the Middle Ea[MASK]t to fight the Turks . Australian troops of the Anzac Mounted D[MASK]vision and the Australian Mounted Division saw action in all the major battles of the Sinai and Palesti[MASK]e Campai[MASK]n , playing a pivotal role in fighting the Turkish troops that were threatening British control of Egypt . The Australian 's first saw combat du[MASK]i[MASK]g the Senus[MASK]i uprising in the [MASK]ibyan Desert and the Nile Valley , during which the combined British forces[MASK]s[MASK]ccessfully pu[MASK] down the primitive pro @-@ Turkish Islamic sec[MASK] with heavy c[MASK]s[MASK]alties . The Anzac Mounted Division subsequently[MASK]saw considerable action in the Battle of Romani against the Turkish betwee[MASK] 3 – 5 August 1916 , with the Turks eventually pus[MASK]ed back . Following this victory the [MASK]ritish forces went on t[MASK]e offensive in the Sinai , although the pace of the advance was governed by the speed [MASK]y which the railway and water pipelin[MASK] could be constructed from the Suez Canal . Rafa was captu[MASK]ed on 9 January 1917 , while the last of the small Turkish garrisons in the Sinai were eliminat[MASK]d in February . 
 The advance entered Pale[MASK]tine and an initial , unsuccessful attempt was made to capture Gaza on 26 March 1917 , while a s[MASK]cond an[MASK] e[MASK]ually unsuccessful attempt was launched on 19 April . A[MASK]third assault occu[MASK]red between 31 October[MASK]and 7 November and this [MASK]ime bot[MASK] the Anzac Mounted Division and the Australian Moun[MASK]ed Divi[MASK]ion took part . The battle was a complete success for the British , over @-@ running the Gaza @-@ Beersheba line and capturing 12 @,@ 000 Turkish so[MASK]diers . The critical momen[MASK] was the capture of Beersheba on the first day , after the Australian 4th Light Horse Brigade charged more than 4 miles ( 6 @.@ 4 km ) . The[MASK]Turkish trenches were overrun[MASK], with the Austral[MASK]ans[MASK]capturing the wells [MASK]t Beers[MASK]eeba and securing t[MASK]e valuable water th[MASK]y contained along with over 700 prisoners f[MASK]r the loss of 31 kille[MASK] and 36 wounded . Later , Australian troops assisted in pushing the Turkish forces o[MASK]t of Palest[MASK]ne and took part in actions at Mu[MASK]har [MASK]idge , Jerusalem and the Me[MASK]iddo . The Turkish government surrende[MASK]ed on 30 October 1918 . Uni[MASK]s of the Light Horse were subsequently used to help put down a [MASK]ationalist revolt in Egypt in 1919 and did so with efficiency and brutality , although they su[MASK]fered a number of fatalities in the process . 
 Meanwhile , the AFC had undergone remarkable development , and its independen[MASK]e as a separate national force was unique among the Dominions . Deploying just a s[MASK]ngle aircraft to German New Gu[MASK]nea[MASK]in 1914 , the first operational flight did not occur until 27 May 1915 however , when the Mesopotamian Hal[MASK] Flight was called upon to assist in protecting British oil [MASK]nterests in Iraq . The AF[MASK] was soon expanded and four squadrons later saw actio[MASK] in Egypt , Palestine and on the Western Front , where they performed well . 
 
 =[MASK]= = Western F[MASK]ont = = = 
 
 Five infantry divisions of the AIF saw action[MASK]in France and Bel[MASK]ium , leaving Egypt in March[MASK]1916 . I Anzac Corps subsequently took up positions in a qu[MASK]et sector south of Armentières on 7 April 1916 and for the next two and a half years the AIF participated in most of the major battles o[MASK] the Western Front , earning a formidable reputation . Although spared from the disastrous first day of the Battle of the Somme , within weeks four Australian divisions had been committed . The 5th Division , positioned on the left flank , was the first in action duri[MASK]g the Battle of Fromelles[MASK]on 19 July 1916 , [MASK]uffering 5 @,@ 533 casua[MASK]ties in a single day . The 1st Division entered the li[MASK]e [MASK]n 23 July , assaulting Pozieres , and by the time that they were relieved by the[MASK]2nd Division on 27 July , they had[MASK]suffe[MASK]ed 5 @,@ 286 casualties . Mouquet Farm was attacked in August [MASK] with casualties totalling 6 @,@ 300 men . By the time the AIF was withdrawn from the Somme to re @-@ organise , they had suffered 23 @,[MASK] 000 casualtie[MASK] in ju[MASK]t 45 days . 
[MASK]In March 1917 , the 2nd and 5th Divisions pursued the Germans back to the Hindenburg [MASK]ine[MASK], capturing the town of Bapaume . On 11 April , the 4th Division assaulted the [MASK]indenburg Line in the disastrous First Battle of Bullecourt , losing over 3 @,@ 000 casual[MASK]ies and 1 @,@ 170 captured . On 15 April , the 1st and 2nd Div[MASK]sions were counter @-[MASK] attacked near Lagnicourt and were forced to abandon the town , before recapturing it[MASK]again . The 2nd Divisio[MASK] then took part in the Second Battle of Bullecourt , beginning on 3 May[MASK], and succeeded in taking se[MASK]tions of[MASK]the Hindenburg[MASK]Line and holding them until relieved by the 1st Division . Finally , on 7 May the 5th Division relie[MASK]ed the 1st , [MASK]emaining in the line un[MASK]il the battle ended in mid @-@ May . Combined these efforts cost 7 @,@ 482 Australian casualties . 
 On 7 June 1917 , the II [MASK]nzac Corps — along with two B[MASK]itish corps — launched an operation[MASK]in Flanders to eliminate a salient south of Ypres . The attack commenced with the detonation of a mil[MASK]ion pounds ( 454 @,@ 545 k[MASK] ) of explosives that had b[MASK]en placed underneath the Messines ridge , destroying t[MASK]e German trenches . The advance was virtually unopposed , and despite strong German counterattacks the next day , it succeeded . Australian casual[MASK]ies during[MASK]the Ba[MASK]tle of Messines included nearly 6 @,@ 800 men . I Anzac Corps then took par[MASK] in the Third Battle of Ypres in Belgium as part of the campaign to capture the Gheluv[MASK]lt Plateau , bet[MASK]een Sept[MASK]mber and November 1917 . Individual actions took pla[MASK]e at Menin Road [MASK] Polygon Wood , Broodseinde , Poelcap[MASK]elle and Passchendaele and over the course of eight weeks fighting th[MASK] Australians suffered 38 @,@ 000 casualties . 
 On 21 [MASK]arch 1918 the German Army launched its Spring[MASK]Offensive in a last @-@ ditched ef[MASK]ort to win the war , unlea[MASK]hing sixty @-@ three divisions over a 70 miles ( 110 km[MASK][MASK] front . A[MASK] the [MASK]llies fell back the 3rd a[MASK]d 4th Divisions were rushed south to Amiens on the Somme . The offen[MASK]ive lasted for the next five months and all five AIF divisions in [MASK]rance were engaged in th[MASK] attempt to stem the tide . By late May th[MASK] Germans had pushed to within 50 miles ( 80 km ) of Paris . During this time the Australians fought at Dernacourt , Morlancourt , Villers @-@ Bretonneux , Hangard Wood , Hazebrouck , and Hamel . At Hamel the commander of the Australian Corps , Lieutenant General John[MASK]Monash , successfully used combined arms — including aircraft , artillery and armour — in [MASK]n attack for th[MASK] first time . 
 The German offensive ground to[MASK]a halt in mid @-@ July and a [MASK]rief lull follow[MASK]d , during which the Australians undertook a ser[MASK]es of r[MASK]ids , known as Peaceful Penetrations . The Allies soon launched thei[MASK] own offensive — [MASK]he Hundred Days Offensive — ultimatel[MASK] ending the war . Beginning on 8 August 1918 the offensive included four Austr[MASK]lian divisions str[MASK]king at Amiens . Using the combined arms techniques developed earlier at Hamel , significant gai[MASK]s were made on what became known as the " Black Day " of the German Army . The offensi[MASK]e continued for four months , and during Second Battle of th[MASK] Somme the Australian Corps fought actions at Lihons , Etine[MASK]em , Proyart , Chuignes , and Mont St Quentin , before their [MASK]inal engagement of the war on 5 October 1918 at Montbrehain . The AIF was subsequently out of the line when the armistice was declared on 11[MASK]November 1918 . 
 In[MASK]all 416 @,@ 806 Australi[MASK]ns [MASK]nlisted in the AIF during the [MASK]ar and 333 @,@ 000 served overseas . 61 @,@ 508 were kille[MASK] and another 155 @,@ 000 were wounded ( a total casualty rate of 65 % ) . The financial cost to the Australian government was calculated at £ 376 @,@ 9[MASK]3 @,@ 052 . Two referendums on [MASK]onscription for overseas[MASK]service had been defeated during the war , preserving the volunteer status of the Australian force , but stretching the reserves of m[MASK]npower available , particularly to[MASK]ards the end of[MASK]the fighting . Consequently , Australia remained one of only two armies on eith[MASK]r[MASK]side not to resort to conscription during the war . [MASK] The war had a profound effect on Australian society in other ways also . Indeed , for many Australians the nation 's involvement is seen as[MASK]a symbol of its emergence as an international actor , whi[MASK]e many of the notions of Australian character and nationhood that exist today have their origins in the war . 64 Australians were awarded the[MASK]Victoria Cros[MASK] during the First World War . [MASK] 
 =[MASK]= Inter @-@ war years = = 
 
 
 = = = Russ[MASK]an Civil War , 1918 [MASK] 19 = = = 
 
 The Russian Civil War began after the Russian provisional government collapsed and the Bolshevik party assumed power in October 1917 [MASK] Following th[MASK] end of the First World War , the western powers — incl[MASK]ding Britain — intervened , giving half @-@ hearte[MASK] support to the pro @-@ [MASK]sarist , anti @-@ Bo[MASK]shevik White Russian forces . Although the Aust[MASK]alian gover[MASK]m[MASK]nt refu[MASK]ed to commit forces , many Australians serving with the British Army became involved in the[MASK]fighting . A small number served as advisors to White Russian units with the Nort[MASK] Russian Expeditionary Forc[MASK] ( NREF ) . Awaiting repatriation in Eng[MASK]and , about 150 Australians subsequently enlisted in the British North Russia Relief Force ( NRRF ) , where t[MASK]ey were in[MASK]olved in a number of sharp battles and several were killed . 
 The Royal Australian Navy destroyer HMAS Swan was also briefly engaged , carrying out [MASK]n intelligence gathering mission in the Black Sea i[MASK] late 1918 . Other Aust[MASK]alians served as advisers with the British Militar[MASK] Mission to the White Russian Ge[MASK]eral , Anton D[MASK]nikin in [MASK]outh Russia , while several more advised Admiral Aleksandr Kolchak in Siberia . Later , they als[MASK] served in Mesopotami[MASK] as part of Dunsterforce and the Malleson Mission , although these [MASK]issions were aimed at prevent[MASK]n[MASK] Turkish access to the Middle East and India , and did little fighting . 
 Although the motivatio[MASK]s of those Australian 's that volunteered to fight in Russia can only be guessed at , it seems unlike[MASK]y to ha[MASK]e been political . Regardless , they confirmed a rep[MASK]tation for audacity and coura[MASK]e , winning the only two Victoria Crosses of the land campaign , despite their[MASK]small numbe[MASK]s . Yet Australian involvement was ba[MASK]ely noticed at home at the time and made little difference to the outcome[MASK]of the war . Total casualties included 10 killed and 40 wounded , with most deaths being from disease during op[MASK]rations in Mesopotamia . 
 
[MASK]= = = Ma[MASK]aita [MASK] 1927 = = = 
 
 In [MASK]ctober [MASK]927 , HMAS Adelaide was called to the British Solomon Island[MASK] Protectorate as part of a punitive expedition in response to the killing of a district officer and sixteen others by Kwaio natives at Sinalagu on the island of Malaita on 3 October , k[MASK]own as the Malaita massacre . Arriving at Tulagi on 14 October , the ship proc[MASK]eded to Malaita [MASK]o protect the landing of three platoons of troops , then remained in the area to provide personnel support for t[MASK]e soldiers as they search[MASK]d for the kil[MASK]ers . The ship 's personnel took no part in operations ashore , providing onl[MASK] logistic and communications supp[MASK]rt[MASK]. Adelai[MASK]e[MASK]returned to Australia on 23 November . 
 
 = = = Spanish Civil [MASK]ar , 1936 – 39 [MASK] = = 
 
 A small number of Austra[MASK]ian volunteers fought on both sides of the Spanish Civil War [MASK] although they predominantly supported the Spanish Republic through the International Brigades . The Australians were su[MASK]sequently allocated to the battalions of other nationalities , such as the Brit[MASK]sh Battalion and the Lincoln Battali[MASK]n , rather than forming their own units . Most were[MASK]radicals motivated by ideological reasons , while a number were [MASK][MASK]anish @-@ born migrants who returned to fight in their country of ori[MASK]in . At least 66 Australians volunteered , with only one — Nugent Bull , a conservative catholic who[MASK]was la[MASK]er killed serving in the RAF during [MASK]he Second World War — known to have fought for General[MASK]Francis[MASK]o Franco 's N[MASK]tionalist forces . 
[MASK]While a celebrated caus[MASK] for the Australian left — parti[MASK]ularly the Communist Party[MASK]of Australia and the trade union movement — the war failed to s[MASK]ark particular public interest and the government maintained its neutrality . Australian opposition to the Republican cause was marshalled by B.A. Santamaria on an anti @-@ communist basis , rather than a pro @-@ [MASK]a[MASK]ionalist basis . Equally , although individual right wing Australia[MASK]s may hav[MASK] served with the Nationalist rebels , they received no public support . Service in a foreign armed force was illegal at the t[MASK]me , however as the government received no reports of Australians travelling to Spain to enlist , no action was taken . Consequently , returned veterans were neither recogn[MASK]sed by the[MASK]gover[MASK]ment or the [MASK]eturned and Servic[MASK]s League of Australia ( RSL ) . Although the number of Australian volunteers was relatively small compared to those from other countries , at least 14 were killed . 
 
 = =[MASK]Second World War , 1939 – 45 = [MASK] 
 
 
 = = = Europe and [MASK]he Middle E[MASK]st = = = 
 
 Australia entered the Second World W[MASK]r on 3 September 1939 . At the time of the dec[MASK]aration of war against Germany the Australian military was small a[MASK]d un[MASK]eady for war . Recruiting for a Second Austr[MASK]lian Imperial Force ( 2nd AIF ) b[MASK]gan in mid @-@ September . While there was no rush of volunteers like the Fi[MASK]st World War , a high proportion of Australian men of military age had enlisted b[MASK] mid @[MASK]@ 1940 . Four infantry divisions were formed during 19[MASK]9 and 1940 , three of which w[MASK]re dispatched to the Middle East . The RAAF 's res[MASK]urces were initially mainly devoted [MASK]o training airmen for service with the Commonwealth air forces through the Empire Air Training Scheme ( EATS ) , through which almost 28 @,@ 000 Australians were trained during the [MASK]ar . 
 The Au[MASK]t[MASK]alian military 's first major engagements of the war were ag[MASK]inst It[MASK]lian forces in the Mediterranean and North Africa . During 1940 the light cruiser HMAS Sydney and five elderly destroyers ( [MASK]ubbed the "[MASK]Scrap Iron Flotilla " by Nazi Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels — a title proudly accepted by the ships ) took part in a series of operations as part of the British Mediterranean[MASK]Fleet , and sank several Italian warships . The Army fi[MASK]st saw action in January 1941 , when the 6[MASK]h Division formed p[MASK]rt of the Commonwealth fo[MASK][MASK]es during Operation Compass .[MASK]The division assaulte[MASK] and captured Bardia on 5 January and Tobruk on 2[MASK] January , with tens of thousands of Italian troops surrendering at both towns . The 6th Division took[MASK]part in the pursuit of the Italian Army[MASK]and captured Ben[MASK]hazi on 4 F[MASK]bruary . In late February it was withdrawn for service [MASK]n Gree[MASK]e , and was[MASK]replaced by the[MASK]9th Division [MASK] 
 The Aus[MASK]ralia[MASK] f[MASK]rces in the Mediterranean endured a number of campaigns during 1941 . During April , the 6th Divisi[MASK]n , other elements of I Corps and several Australian warships formed part of the Allied force which unsuccessfully at[MASK]empted [MASK]o defend Greece from German invasion during the Battle of Greece . At the end of this campaign , the 6th Division was evacuated to Egypt and Crete . The force at Crete subsequently fought [MASK]n the Battle of Crete during Ma[MASK] , which also ended in defeat for the Allies . Over 5 @,@ 000 Australians were capture[MASK] in these campaigns , and the 6th Division required a long period of rebuilding before it was again re[MASK]dy for combat . The Germans and Italians also went on the offensive in North Africa at the end of March and drove the Commonwealth force there back to near[MASK]the border with Egypt . T[MASK]e 9th Division and a brigade[MASK]of the 7th Division were besieged at Tobruk ; successfully defending the key por[MASK] town until they[MASK]were replaced by British units in October . During June , the main body of the 7th Division , a brigade of the 6th Division and the I Corps headquarters took part in the Syria[MASK]@-@ L[MASK]banon Campaign again[MASK]t the Vichy French . Resistance was stronger than expected ; Austra[MASK]ians were involved in most of the fighting and sustained most of the[MASK]casualties before the French capitulated in[MASK]early July . 
 The majority of Australia[MASK] units in the Mediterranean returned to Australia in early 1942 , after the outbreak of the Pacific W[MASK]r . The 9th Division was the largest unit to remain in the Middle East , and played a key role in the First Battle of El[MASK]Alamein during June and[MASK]the Second Battl[MASK] of El Alamein in October . The division returned to Australia in early 1943 , but several RAAF squadrons and RAN warships took part[MASK]in [MASK]he subsequent Tunisia Campaign and the Italian Ca[MASK]paign from 1943 until the end of the war . 
 The RAAF 's role in the strategic air offensive in Europe formed [MASK]ustralia 's main contribution to the defeat of Germany . Approximately 13 @,@ 000 Australian air[MASK]en served in dozens of [MASK]r[MASK]tish and five Australian squadrons in RAF Bomber Command between 1940 and the end of the w[MASK]r . Australians took part in all of Bomber Command 's ma[MASK]or offensives and suffered heavy losses [MASK]uring raids on [MASK]erman cities and targets in France . Au[MASK]tralian aircrew in Bomber[MASK]Command had one of the high[MASK]st casualty rates of[MASK]any part of the Australian military during the Second World War and sustained almost 20 percent of all Australia[MASK] deaths in combat ; 3 @,@ 486 were kil[MASK]ed and hundreds [MASK]ore were taken prisoner . Australian airmen in light bomber and fighter squadrons also participated in the liberation of Western Europe during 1944 and 1945 and t[MASK]o RAAF maritime patrol squ[MASK]drons served in the Battle of the Atlantic . 
 
 = = = Asia and the Pacif[MASK]c = = = 
 
 From the 1920s Australia 's defence thinking was dominated [MASK]y British Imperial defence policy , which wa[MASK] embodied by the " Singapore stra[MASK]egy " . This strategy involved the construction and defence of a major n[MASK]val base at[MASK]Singapore from which a large British fleet would respond to Japanese a[MASK]gression in the region . To this end , a high [MASK]roportion of Australian forces in Asia were concentrated[MASK]in Malaya during 1940 and 1941 as the[MASK]threat from Japan incr[MASK]ased . However , as a result of the emphasis on co @-@ operation with Britain , [MASK]elatively few Australian military units had been retained i[MASK] Australia and the [MASK]sia @-@ Pacific region . Measures were taken to improve Australia 's defences as war with Japan loomed in 1941 , but these [MASK]roved inadequate . In Decem[MASK]er 1941 , the Australian Army in the Pacific comprised the 8th Division , most of w[MASK]ich was stationed in Malaya , and eig[MASK]t partially trained and equipped divisions in Australia . [MASK]he RAAF was equipped with 373 aircraft , most of which were obsolete trainers , and the RAN had three cruis[MASK]rs and two destroyers in Australian waters . 
 The Australian military suffered a series of defeats during the early mo[MASK]ths of the Pacific War . The 8th Division and RAA[MASK] squadrons in Malaya formed a part of the Briti[MASK]h Commonwealth forces which were unable to stop a smaller Japanese invasion f[MASK]rce w[MASK]ich[MASK]landed on 7 December . The British Commonwealth force withdrew to Singap[MASK]re at the end of January , but was force[MASK] to surrender on 15 Febr[MASK]ary after the Jap[MASK]nese captured much of the island . Sm[MASK]l[MASK]er Australian forces were also overwhelmed and defeated during early 1942 at Rabaul ,[MASK]a[MASK]d in Ambon , Timor , and Java . The Australian town of Darwin was heavi[MASK]y bombed by t[MASK]e Japanese on 19 February , to prevent it from being used as an Allied base . Ove[MASK] 22 @,@ 000 Australians were taken prisoner in e[MASK]rly 1942 and endured harsh conditions [MASK]n Japanese captivity . The prisone[MASK]s were subjected to malnutrition , denied medical treatment and frequently[MASK]beaten and killed by their guards . As a result , 8 @,@ 29[MASK] Australian prisoners died in captivity . 
 The rapid Allied defeat in the Pacific caused many Australians to fear that the Japanese would invade the Australian mainland . While elements of the Imperial Japanese Navy p[MASK]oposed this in early 1942 , it was judged to be impossible by the Japan[MASK]se Imperial General Headquarters , which instead adopted a strategy of isolating Australia from the United States by capturing New Guinea ,[MASK]the Solomon Islands , Fiji , Samoa , and New Caledonia .[MASK]This fact was not known by the Allies at the time , and the Australian military was greatly expanded to meet the threat[MASK]of invasion . Large number[MASK] of United States Army and Army Air Forces units arrived in Australia in early[MASK]1942 , and the Australian military was placed under the overall command of Gener[MASK]l Douglas MacArthur in March . 
 Australians played a ce[MASK]tral role i[MASK] the New Guinea campaign during 1942 and 1943 . After an a[MASK]tempt to land troops at Port Moresby was d[MASK]feated in the Battle of the Coral Sea , the Japanese attempted[MASK]to capture the strategically important town by advancing overl[MASK]nd across the Owen Stanle[MASK] Ranges and M[MASK][MASK]ne Bay . Australian Army units defeated these offensives[MASK]in the Kokoda Track campaign and Battle of Milne Bay [MASK]ith the [MASK]upport of the RAAF and USAAF . Australian a[MASK]d US Army units subsequently assaulted and captured the Japanese bases on the north coast of Papua in the hard @-@ fought Battle of Buna @-@ Gona . The Australian Army also defeated a Japanese attempt to capture the town of Wau in January 1943 and went onto the offensive in the Salamaua @-@ Lae campaign in April . In late 1943 , the 7th and 9th Divisions played an important role in Operation Cartwheel , when they landed to the east and west of Lae a[MASK]d secured the Huon Peninsula during t[MASK]e Huon Peninsula campaign and Finisterre Range campaign . 
 The Australian main[MASK]and came under attack during 1942 and 1943 . Japanese submarines operated off Australia from May to August 1942 and January to June 1943 . T[MASK]e[MASK][MASK] attacks so[MASK]ght to cut the Allied sup[MASK]ly lines between Australia and the US and Australia and New [MASK]uinea , but were unsucce[MASK]sful . Japanese aircraft also conducted air raid[MASK] ag[MASK][MASK]nst Allied bases in northern Aust[MASK][MASK]lia whi[MASK]h were being used to mount the North Western Area Campai[MASK]n against Japanese positions in the Netherlands East Indies ( NEI ) . 
 Australia 's role in the Pacific W[MASK]r decline[MASK] from 1944 . The increasing size of the US forces in the Pacific rendered the Australia[MASK] military superfluous and labour [MASK]hortages forced the Governm[MASK]nt [MASK]o reduce the size of the armed forces to boost war production . N[MASK]vertheless , the Govern[MASK]ent wanted the Australian military to remain active , and agreed to MacArthur 's proposals that [MASK]t be used in relativ[MASK]ly unimportant campaigns . In late 1944 , Australian troops[MASK]and RAAF squadrons replaced US garrisons in eastern New Guinea , New Britain , and Bougainville , and launched offensives aimed at destroying or cont[MASK]ining the remaining J[MASK]pan[MASK]se forces ther[MASK] . In May 1945 , I[MASK]Corps , the Australian First Tactical Air Force and USAAF and USN units began the Borneo Campaign , wh[MASK]ch continued until the end of the war . These cam[MASK]aigns contributed li[MASK]tle to Japan 's defeat and remain controversial . 
 Following Japan 's surr[MASK]nder on 15 August 1945 Australia assumed re[MASK]ponsibility for occupying much of Borneo and the eastern Netherlands East Indies until British and Dutch colonial rule was restored[MASK]. Australian authorities also conducted a number of[MASK]war crimes trials of Japanese personnel . 993 @,@ 000 Australians enlisted during the war , while 557 @,@ 000 served overseas . Casualties included 39 @,@ 767 killed and another 66 @,@ 553 [MASK]ere [MASK]ounded . 20 Victoria Crosses were awarded to Australians . 
 
 = = Post @-@ war period = = 
 
 
 = = = D[MASK]mobilisation and peace @-@ time defence arrangements = = = 
 
 The demobilisation of the Australian military following the end of the Second World W[MASK]r wa[MASK] c[MASK]mpleted in[MASK]1947 . Plans for post @-@ [MASK]ar defence a[MASK]rangements were predicated on maintainin[MASK] a relatively strong peacetime force . It was envisioned that the Royal Australian Navy maintaini[MASK]g a fleet that would incl[MASK]de two light fleet carriers , two crui[MASK]ers , six d[MASK]stroyers , 16 others s[MASK]ips in commiss[MASK]on and another 52[MASK]in reserved . The Royal Australian Air Force would have a stre[MASK]gth of 16 squadrons , including four manned by the Citizen Air Force . Meanwhile , in a significant departure from previous Australian defence policy whi[MASK]h had previously relied on citizen forc[MASK]s , the Au[MASK]tralia[MASK] Army would in[MASK]lude a[MASK]permanent field force of 19 @,@ 000 regulars organised into a brigade of thre[MASK] infantry battalions with armoured support[MASK], serv[MASK]ng alongside a part @-@ time force of 50 @,@ 000 men in the Citizen Military Forces . The Australian Regular Army was subsequently formed on 30 September 194[MASK] , while the CM[MASK][MASK]was re @-@ ra[MASK]sed on 1 J[MASK]ly 1948 . 
 
 = = = Oc[MASK]upation of Japan , 1946 – 52 = = = 
 
 In the immediate post @-@ war period Australi[MASK] contri[MASK]uted significant forces to the Allied occupation[MASK]of Japan as part of the British Commonwealth Oc[MASK]upation Force[MASK][MASK] BCOF ) , which included forces from Australia , Britain , India and New Zealand . At its height in 1946 the Australian component [MASK]onsisted of an infantry brigade , four warships and three fighter squadrons , totalling 13 @,@ 500 personnel . The Australian Army component initially[MASK]consisted of the 34th Brigade which arrived in Japan in February 1946 and was based in Hiroshima Prefecture [MASK] The three i[MASK][MASK]antry battalions raised fo[MASK] occupation duties were designated the 1st , 2nd and 3rd battalions of the Royal Australian Regiment in 1949 , and the 34th Brigade became the 1st Brigade when it retu[MASK]ned to Au[MASK]tralia in December 1948 , forming the basis of the post @-@ war Regular Army . From that time the Australian Army[MASK]contributio[MASK] to the occupation of Japan was reduced to a single under @-@ strength battalion . Australia[MASK] forces r[MASK]mained until September 1951 when the BCOF ceased op[MASK]rations , although by the time[MASK]the major[MASK]ty of units had been committed to the fighting on the Korean peninsular following the outbreak of t[MASK]e Kor[MASK]an War [MASK]n 1950 . The RAAF component consisted of Nos. 76 , 77 [MASK]n[MASK] 82 Squadrons a[MASK] part of No. 81 Wing RAAF flying P @-[MASK] 51 Mustangs , initially based at Bofu from March 1946 , before transferring to [MASK]wakuni in 1948 . However , by 1[MASK]50 [MASK]nly No. 77 Squadron remained in Japan . A total of ten R[MASK]N warships served in Japan during this period , including HMA Ships Australia , Hobart , Shr[MASK]pshire , Arunta , Bataan , Culgoa , Murchison , Shoalhaven ,[MASK]Quadrant and Quiberon , while HMAS Ships Manoora , Westralia and Kanim[MASK]la also provided suppo[MASK]t . 
 
 = = Cold War = = 
 
 
 = = = Early planning and commitm[MASK]nts = =[MASK]= 
 
 During the early years of the Cold War , Australian defence planning assumed that in the event of the outbreak o[MASK] a global war between the Western world and Eastern bloc countries[MASK]it would n[MASK]ed to contribute forces und[MASK]r collective security arr[MASK]ngements [MASK]s part of the United Nations , o[MASK] a coalition led by either the United States or Britain . The Middle East was consider[MASK]d the most likely area of operations [MASK]or Australian forces , where they would most likely operate with British forces . Early commitments included the involvement of RAAF aircrew d[MASK]ring the Berlin Airlift in 1948 [MASK] 49 and the deployment of No. 78 Wing RAAF to Malta i[MASK] the Mediterranean from 1952 to 1954 . Meanwhi[MASK]e , defence prep[MASK]r[MASK]dness initiatives included the introduction[MASK]of a National Service Scheme in 1951 to provide manpower for the citizen forces of the [MASK]rmy , RAAF[MASK]and RAN . 
 
 = = = Korean War , 1950 – 53 = = = 
 
 On 25 Ju[MASK]e 1950 , the North Korean Army ( KPA ) crossed the border into South Korea and[MASK]advanced for the capital Seoul , which fell in less than a we[MASK]k . North Korean forces continued toward the port of Pusan and two days later the United States offered its assistance to South Korea . In response the Unit[MASK]d [MASK]ations Security Council requested members to assist in repelling the North Korean attack . Australia initially contr[MASK]bute[MASK] P @-@ 51 Mustang fighter @-@ bomber aircraft fro[MASK] No. 77 Squadron RAAF and infantry from the[MASK]3rd Battalion[MASK], Royal Australian Regiment ( 3 RAR ) , both of which were stationed in Japan as part of the BCOF . In addition , it provided the majority of supply and support personnel to the British Commonwealth Forces Korea . The RAN frigate HMAS Shoalhaven , and the destroyer HMA[MASK] Bataan , were also committed . Later , an aircraft carrier strike group aboard HMAS Sydney was added[MASK]to the force . 
 By the[MASK]time 3 RAR arrived in Pusan on 28 September , the North [MASK]oreans were in retreat following the Inchon landings . As a par[MASK] of the invasion force under the UN Supreme Commander , General Douglas MacArthur , the bat[MASK]alion moved nor[MASK]h a[MASK]d was involved in [MASK]ts first major action at Battle of Yongju near Pyongyang on 22 [MASK]ctober , before advancing toward[MASK] the Yal[MASK] River . Further successful actions followed at Kujin on 25 – 26 October 1950 and at Chongju o[MASK] 29 October 1950 . North Korean casualties were heavy , while Australian losses included their com[MASK]anding officer , Lieutenant Colone[MASK] Charles[MASK]Green , who was wounded in the s[MASK]omach by a[MASK]tillery fire after t[MASK]e battle and succumbed to his wounds and died two days later on 1 November . Meanwhile , during the last weeks of October the Chinese had moved 18 divisions[MASK]of the Pe[MASK]ple 's Volunteer Army across the Yal[MASK] [MASK]iver to reinforce the remnants of the KPA . Undetected by US and South Korean[MASK]intelligence , the 13th Army Group crossed the border on 16 October and pen[MASK]trated up to 100 kilometres ( [MASK]2 mi ) into North Korea , an[MASK] were reinforced in early November by 12 divisions f[MASK]om the 9th Army Group ; in total 30 divisions composed of 380 @,@ 000 men . 3 RAR fought its first action against the Chinese a[MASK] Pakchon on 5 Novem[MASK]er . The fighting cost the battalion hea[MASK]ily and despite halting a Chinese divi[MASK]io[MASK] the new battalion commander was dis[MASK]issed in the wake . Following the Chinese intervention , the UN forces were defeated in successive battles and 3 RAR was forced to withdraw to t[MASK]e 38th parallel . 
[MASK]A series of battles[MASK]followed at Uijeongbu on 1 – 4 January 1951 , as the British and Australians occupied defensive positions in an attempt to sec[MASK]re the northern approaches to[MASK]the South Korean capital . Further fighting occurred at Chuam @-@ ni on 14 – 17 February 1951 following another Chinese advance , and later at Maehwa @-@ San between 7 – 12 March 1951 as the UN[MASK]resumed the offensive . Australian troops [MASK]ubsequently participated in two more major battles in 1951 , with the first taki[MASK]g place during fighting which later became known as the Battle of K[MASK]pyong . On 22 April , Chinese force[MASK] attacked the Kapyong valley and forced the South Korean defenders to withdraw . Australian and[MASK]Canadian troops were ordered to halt this Chinese advance . After a night of fighting the Australians recaptured their positions , at the [MASK]ost[MASK]of 32 men killed and 59 wounded . In July 1951 , the Australian battalion beca[MASK]e part of the combined Canadian , British , Australian , New Zealand , and Indian 1st [MASK]ommonwealth Division . The second maj[MASK]r battle took place du[MASK]ing Operation Co[MASK]mando and occurred after the Chinese attac[MASK]ed a [MASK]alient in a bend of th[MASK] Imjin River . The 1st Commonw[MASK]alth Division counter @-@ att[MASK]cked on 3 October , capturing a num[MASK]er of objectives including Hill 355 [MASK]nd Hill 317 during the Battle of Maryang San ;[MASK]after five days the Chines[MASK] retreated . [MASK][MASK]stralian casua[MASK]ties included 20 dead and 104 wounded . 
 The [MASK]elligerents then became locked in static trench warfare akin to the First World War , in which men lived in tunnels , redoubts , and sandbagged forts behind barbed wire defences . From 1951[MASK]until the end of the war , 3 RAR held tre[MASK]ches on the eastern side of the division 's positions in the hills northeast of the Imji[MASK] Rive[MASK] . Across from them[MASK][MASK]ere heavily fortified Chin[MASK]se positions . In March 1952 , Australia increased its ground commitment to two battalions , sending 1 RAR . This battalion remained in Korea fo[MASK] 12[MASK]months , before being repl[MASK]ced by 2 RAR [MASK]n April 1953[MASK]. The Australians fough[MASK] their last battle during 24 – 26 July 195[MASK] , [MASK]ith 2 RAR holding off a concerted Chinese attack along the [MASK]amichon [MASK]iver and inflicting significant casualties for the loss of five k[MASK]ll[MASK]d and 24 wounded . Hostilities were suspended on 27 July 1[MASK]53 . 17 @,@ 808 Austr[MASK]lians served during the war , with 341 killed , 1 @,@ 216 wounded and 30 captured . 
 
 = = = Malayan Emergency , 1950 – 60 = = = 
 
 The Malayan Emergency was declared on 18 June 1948 , after three[MASK]est[MASK]te ma[MASK]agers were murdered by members of the Malayan Communist Party ( MCP ) . Australian involve[MASK]ent began in Ju[MASK]e 1950 , when in response to a British request , six Lincolns from No. 1[MASK]Squadron and a[MASK]flight of[MASK]Dakotas from No. 38 Squ[MASK]dron [MASK]rrived in Singapore to form part of the Britis[MASK] Commonwealth Far East Air Fo[MASK]ce ( FEAF ) . The Dakotas were subsequently used on cargo runs , troop movement , as well as paratroop and l[MASK]aflet dro[MASK]s , while the Lincoln bombers carried out b[MASK]mbing raids against the Communist Terrorist ( CT ) jungle bases . The RAAF were particularly successful , and in one such mission known as Operation Termite , five Lincoln bombers destroyed 181 communist camps , killed 13 communists and forced one into surren[MASK]er , in a joint operation with the RAF and ground troops . The Lincolns were withdrawn in 1958 , and were re[MASK]laced by Canberra bombers from No.[MASK]2 Squa[MASK]ron and CAC Sabres from No. 78 Wing . Based at RAAF Base Butterworth they also carrie[MASK] out a n[MASK]mber ground attack missions a[MASK]ainst the guerrillas . 
 Australian ground forces were deployed to Malaya i[MASK] October 1955 as part of the Far East Strategic Reserve . In January 1[MASK]56 , the first Australian ground forces were deployed on Malaysian peninsula , consisting of the 2nd B[MASK]ttalion , Royal Australian[MASK]Regiment ( 2 RAR ) . 2 RAR mainly participated in " mopping up " operations over the next 20 months , conducting extensive patrolling in and near the [MASK]T jungle bases , as part of 28th British Commonwealth Bri[MASK]ade . Contact with the ene[MASK]y was infrequent and results small , achieving relatively few kills . 2 RAR left Malaysia October 1957 to be replaced by 3 RAR . 3 RAR underwent six weeks of jungle training and began dr[MASK]ving MCP insurgents back into[MASK]the jungle of Perak and Kedah . The new battalion[MASK]extensi[MASK]ely patrolled and was involved in food denial operations a[MASK]d ambushes . Again contact was limit[MASK]d , a[MASK]though 3 RAR had more success than its predecessor . By late 1959 , operations against the MCP were in th[MASK]ir final phase , and most communists had been pushed back and across the Thailand border . 3 RAR left Malaysia October 1959 and wa[MASK] repl[MASK]ced by 1 RAR . Though patrolling the border 1 RAR did not [MASK]ake contact with the insurgents , an[MASK][MASK]in October 1960 it was replaced b[MASK] 2 RAR , which stayed in Malaysia[MASK]until August 1963 . The Malayan Emergency officially ended on 31 Ju[MASK]y 1960 . 
 Australia also provided artillery and engineer [MASK]upport , along with an air @-@[MASK]field construction squadron . The Royal Australian Navy also served in Malayan waters , firing on suspected communist[MASK]positio[MASK]s between 1956 and 1957 . The Emergenc[MASK] was the longest continued commitment i[MASK] Australian military history ; 7 @,@ 000 Australians served and 51 died in Ma[MASK]aya — although only 15 were [MASK]n operations — and an[MASK]t[MASK]er 27 w[MASK]re wounded . 
 
 = = = Military and Naval growth during the 1960s = = = 
 
 At the start of[MASK]the 1960s , Prime Minister Robe[MASK]t Menzies greatly expanded the Australian military so that it cou[MASK]d carry out the Government 's policy of " Forward Defence " in South East Asia . In 1964 , Menzies announced a large increase[MASK]in defence spendi[MASK]g . The strength of the Australian Army would be i[MASK]creas[MASK]d by [MASK]0 % [MASK]ver three years[MASK]fro[MASK] 22 @,@ 000 t[MASK] 33 @,@ 000 ; providing a full three @-@ brig[MASK]de division with [MASK]ine battalions . The RAAF and[MASK]RAN would al[MASK]o both be increase[MASK] by 25 % . In 1964 , conscription or National Service was re @-@ introduced [MASK]nder the Nationa[MASK] Service Act , for selected 20 @-@ year @-@ olds based on date of birth , for a period of two years ' continuous full @-@ time service ( the previous scheme having been suspended in 1959 ) . 
 In 1961 , [MASK]hre[MASK] Charles F. Adams @-@ class destroyers were purchased from the United Sta[MASK]es to replace the ageing Q @-@ class destroyers . Traditionally , the RAN had purchased designs based on those of the Royal Navy and the purchase of American destroyers was significant[MASK]. HMAS Perth and[MASK]HMAS Hobart joined the fleet in 1965 , followed by HMAS Brisbane in 1967 . Other [MASK]r[MASK]jects included the construction of six River @-@ class frigates , the conversion of the aircraft carrier [MASK]MAS Melbourne to an anti @-@ submarine role , the acquisition of ten Wess[MASK]x helicopters , and the purchase of six Oberon @-@ [MASK]lass submarines . 
 The RAAF took delivery of their firs[MASK] Mirage fighters in 1967 , eq[MASK]ipping No. 3 , No. 75 and No. 77 Squadrons with them . The service also rec[MASK]ived American F @-@ 111 strike aircraft ,[MASK]C @-@ 130 Hercule[MASK] [MASK]ransports , P @-@ 3 Orion maritime reconnaissance ai[MASK]craft a[MASK]d Italian Macchi trainers . 
 
 = = = Indonesia @-@ Malaysia Confrontation , 1962 – 66 = = [MASK] 
 
 The Indonesia @-@ Malaysia confrontation was fought from 1962 to 1966 betw[MASK]en th[MASK] British Commonwealth and Indone[MASK]ia over the creation of the Federation[MASK]of Malaysia , with the Common[MASK]ealth attempting to s[MASK]fegu[MASK]rd the security of the new state . The war remained limited , and was fought primarily on the island of Borneo , although a number of Indonesian seaborne and a[MASK]rborne incursions onto the Malay Penins[MASK]la did occur . As part[MASK]of Australia 's continuing milita[MASK]y commitment to the[MASK]securit[MASK] of Malaysia , army , naval and airforce units were based there as [MASK]art of the Far E[MASK]st Strategic Reserve . Regardless the [MASK]ustralian government was wary of[MASK]i[MASK]volvement in a [MASK]ar[MASK]with Indonesia and initially limited its involvement to t[MASK]e defence of the Malayan peninsula only . On two occasions Austral[MASK]an troops from 3 RAR wer[MASK] used to help mop up infiltrators [MASK][MASK]om seaborne and airborne incursions at Labis and Pontian , in September and October 1964 . 
 Following these raids the go[MASK]ernment conceded to Britis[MASK] and Malaysian requests to deploy an infantry[MASK]battalion to Borneo . During the early phases , British and Mal[MASK]ysian troops[MASK]had attempted only to control the Malaysian / Indonesian border , and to protect popula[MASK]ion centres . However , by t[MASK]e time the Austra[MASK]ian battalion deployed the British had decided on more aggressive action , crossing the border into Kalimantan to obtain information and conduct ambushes to force the Indo[MASK]esians to remain on the defensive , under the codename Operation Claret . The fighting took place in mountainous , jungle @-@ clad terrain , and a debilit[MASK]ting climate[MASK], with operations characterised by the extensive use of company bases sited along the border , cros[MASK] @-@ border operations , the use of helicopters for troop movement a[MASK]d re[MASK]upply , and the role of human and signals intelligenc[MASK] to determine [MASK]ne[MASK]y movements and intentions . 
 3 RAR deployed to Borneo in March 1965 , a[MASK]d served in Sarawak until the end of July , operating on both sides of the border . The battalion had four major contacts with Indonesian forces and sever[MASK]l smaller ones — including at Sungei Koemba , Kindau and Babang during which they inflicted heavy casualties on the Indonesians — as well as suffering casualties in two mine incidents . 4 RAR served a less @-@ eventful tour [MASK]etween April and August 1966 , and also opera[MASK]ed over the border , successfully clashing with the Indonesian[MASK] on a number of occasions . A squadron of t[MASK]e Special Air Service Regiment ( SASR ) was[MASK]a[MASK]so deployed in 19[MASK]5 and again in 1966 , taking part in cross @-@ border operations and inflicting significant casualti[MASK]s on the Indonesians , even though they were often tasked with [MASK]overt reconnaissance . Ot[MASK]er units included artillery and engineers , while a number of [MASK]AN shi[MASK]s were involved in shelli[MASK]g I[MASK]donesian positio[MASK]s in Borneo and in repellin[MASK] infiltrators in th[MASK] Singapore Strait . The RAAF played a relatively minor role , although it would have been used far m[MASK]re extensively had the war escalated . 
 Ope[MASK]ations in Borneo were extremely se[MASK]sitive and they received little press coverage in [MASK]ustralia , while official acknowledgement of inv[MASK]lvement in cross @-@ border missions only occurred in 1996 . Following a military coup in Indonesia in early 1966 which brought General Suhart[MASK] t[MASK] powe[MASK] , a peace treaty was signed in August 1966 which ended the conflict . 3 @,@[MASK]500 Australians served during Confrontation ; casualties included 16 [MASK]ead , with seven killed in action and eight wounded . 
 
 = = = Vietnam War [MASK] 1962 – 73 = = = 
 
 Australia 's involvement in the Vietnam War was driven largely by the rise of communism in Southeast Asia after the Secon[MASK] Worl[MASK] War , and the fear of its spread which developed in Australia d[MASK]ring the 1950s and early 1960s . As a [MASK]onsequence , Australia [MASK]upported South Vietnam throughout the ear[MASK]y 1960s . In 1961 and 1962 , [MASK]he leader of the South Vietnamese government ,[MASK]Ngo Di[MASK]h Diem , asked for assistance from the US and its allies in response to a[MASK]growing insurgency supported by communist [MASK]orth Vietnam . Australia offered 30 military advisors from [MASK]he Australian Army T[MASK]ain[MASK]ng Team Vietnam , which became known simply as " The Team " . They arrived in July and August 1962 , beginning Australia 's involvement in the war . Later in August 1964 , the RAAF sent a flight of Caribou transport aircraft to the port city of Vung Tau . 
 However , with the security situation in South Vietnam continuing to deteriorate , the US increas[MASK]d its involvement to 200 @,@ 000 combat troops by early 1965 [MASK] Australia also committed ground forces , dis[MASK]atching the 1 RAR to serve with the US 173rd Airborne[MASK]Brigade in Bien Hoa province in June 1965 and it subsequently fought a number of significant actions , including Gang Toi , Operation Crimp and Suo[MASK] Bong Trang . In M[MASK]rch 1966[MASK], the Austral[MASK]an government announced the deployment of a [MASK]rigade @-@ s[MASK]zed unit — the 1st Australian Task Force ( 1 ATF ) — to replace 1 RAR . Included were a large number of conscripts , under the increasingly controversial National Service Scheme . Consisting of two infantry battalions a[MASK][MASK]well as armour ,[MASK]aviation , artillery and other support arms , th[MASK] task force was assigned primary responsibility for its own area and was bas[MASK]d at Nui Dat , in Phuoc Tuy Province . Included were the Iroquois helicopters of No. 9 Squadron RAAF . At the Battle of Long Tan on 18 August 1966 , D Company , 6[MASK]RAR with considerable artillery support held off and defeated a Viet Cong force that was a[MASK] least six times bigger than itself . 18 Aus[MASK]ralians were killed and 24 wounded , while 245 communist dead were later recovered from the battlefie[MASK]d . The battle allowed the Aus[MASK]ralians to gain dominance over Phuoc Tuy Province and 1 ATF was not fundamentally challenged again . Regardless , during February 1967 the Australians suffered their heaviest casualties[MASK]in the war t[MASK] that point , losing 16 men killed and 55 wounded in a single week , th[MASK] bulk during[MASK]Operation Bribie . 
 Yet with the Phuoc Tuy province coming progressively und[MASK]r control throughout 1967 , the Australians increasingly spent a significant period of time condu[MASK]ting[MASK]operations further afield . 1 ATF was subsequently deployed astride infiltration routes leading to Saigon to interdict communist movement against the capital as part of Operation Coburg during the 1968 [MASK]et Offensive and later during the Battle of Coral – Balmoral in May and June 1968 . At Fire Support Bases Coral and Ba[MASK]mora[MASK] the A[MASK]st[MASK]alians had clashed with regular North Vietnamese Army and V[MASK]et Cong main force units [MASK]perating in battalion an[MASK] regimental stre[MASK]gth for the first time in near conven[MASK]ional warfare , ultimately fighting their largest , most hazardous and most sustained batt[MASK]e of the war . During 26 days[MASK]of fighting Australian casualties included 25 killed and 99 wounded , while communist casualties incl[MASK]ded 267 killed confirmed by body c[MASK]unt , 60 possibly killed , 7 wounded and 11 captured . Other significant Australian actions included Binh Ba in June 1969 , Hat Dich in late @-@ December 19[MASK]8 and early 1969 and Long Khanh in June 1971 . At the height of the Australian commitment , 1 ATF numbered 8 @,@ 500 troops , including three i[MASK]fa[MASK]try battalions ,[MASK]armour , artillery , engineer[MASK] , logist[MASK]cs and aviation units in support[MASK].[MASK]A third RAAF unit , No. 2 Squadron RAAF , flying Canberra bo[MASK]bers , was sent in 1967 , and four RAN destroyers joined US patrols [MASK]n the wat[MASK]rs off North Vietnam . 
 The Australian withdrawal effec[MASK]ively commenced in November 1970 . As a conseque[MASK]ce of the overall allied strategy of Vietnamiz[MASK]tion and with the Australian government keen to[MASK]reduce its own commitment to the war , 8 RAR was not replaced at the[MASK]end o[MASK] its tour of duty . 1 ATF was again reduced to just two infantr[MASK] battalions[MASK], albeit with significant armour , artillery and aviation support rema[MASK]ning . Australian combat forces[MASK]were fu[MASK]ther reduced during 1971 as part of a phased withdrawal , and 1 ATF ceased opera[MASK]ions in October . Mea[MASK]while , the advisors remained to train South Vietnamese troops until withdrawn on 18 [MASK]ecember 1972 by the newly elected L[MASK]bor government of Gough Whitlam . The last Australian forces were finally withdrawn in 1973 . The Vietnam War was Australia '[MASK] longest and[MASK]most controversial war and although initially enjoying broad support , as the nation 's military involvement increased a[MASK]vocal anti @-@ war movement developed . More than 50 @,@ 000 Australians served in Vietnam ; 519 wer[MASK] killed and 2 @,@ 398 were wounded . Four were awarded[MASK]the Victoria Cross . 
 
 = = Post @-@ Vietnam era = [MASK] 
 
 
 = = = Creation of the Australian Defence Force , 1976 = = = 
 
 Although the importance of ' joint ' warfare had been highlighted during Second World War when Australian naval , ground and air units frequently served as part of single commands , the absence of a central authority continued to result in poor co @-@ ordination[MASK]between the services in the p[MASK]st @-@ war era , with each organising and operating on [MASK]he basis of a different military doctrine . The need for an integrated command [MASK]tructure received more emphasis during the Aust[MASK]alian military 's ex[MASK]eriences in the Vietnam War . In 1973 , the Secretary of the Department of Defence , Arthur Tange , subm[MASK]tted a report to the Governm[MASK]nt that recommended the unification of the separate departmen[MASK]s supporting each service into a single departme[MASK]t and the crea[MASK]ion of the post of Chi[MASK]f of the Defence Force Staff . 
 The Whitlam La[MASK]or Government subsequently amalgamated the five defence ministries ( Defence , Navy , Army , Air Force , and Supply ) into a s[MASK]ngle Department of Defence i[MASK] 1973 , while conscription under the National Service scheme was abo[MASK]ished . On 1 January 197[MASK][MASK], the three branches of the Australian military wer[MASK] brought tog[MASK]ther as a unified , all @-@ vol[MASK]nteer , professional force known as the Australian Defence Force ( ADF ) . T[MASK]day , the ADF is headquartered at Russell Offices in Canberra and is divided into Air , Land , Maritime and S[MASK]ecial Opera[MASK]ions [MASK]o[MASK]mands . In addition ,[MASK]Northern Command[MASK]is based [MASK]n Darwin , and is responsible for operations in Northern Australia . 
 
 = = = Defence of Australia , 1980s and 1[MASK]90s = = = 
[MASK]
 Until the 1970s , Australi[MASK] 's military strategy centred on the concept of Forward Defence , in which the role of Australian military and naval forces were to co @-@ operate with Allied force[MASK] to cou[MASK]ter threats in Australia 's region . Following the adoption of the Guam Doctrine by the Un[MASK]ted States in 1969 , and the British withdrawal ' east of Suez ' in the early 1970s , Australia developed a defence polic[MASK] emphasising self @-@ reliance and the defence of the Austral[MASK]an continent . Known as the Defence of Australia Policy , it focused Australian defence planning on protecting the nation 's northern maritime approaches ( the ' air @-@ sea gap ' ) against possible attack . 
 In line with this goal , the ADF was restructured to increase its ability to strike at enemy forces from [MASK]u[MASK]tralian bases[MASK]and to counter raids on continental Australia . This was achieved by increasing the capabilities of the RAN and RAAF ,[MASK]and relocating regular Army units to Northe[MASK]n Australia . During this time the ADF had no military units on operational deployment outside Australia . However , in 1987 the ADF made its first operational deployment as part of Operation Morris Dance , in which several warships and a rifle company deployed to the waters [MASK]ff Fiji in response to the 1987 Fiji[MASK]n coups d 'état . While broadly successful , this deployment highlighted the need for[MASK]the ADF to improve its capability to [MASK]apid[MASK]y respond to unforese[MASK]n[MASK]events .[MASK]
 During this period Australia conti[MASK]ued to retain forces in Malaysia as part of the Five Power Defence Arran[MASK]ements ( FPDA ) agreed in 1971 to defend it in the event of external attack , with this commitment initi[MASK]lly inclu[MASK]ing significant air , ground and naval forces . However , these forces were gradually reduced with the infantry battalion withdrawn from Singapor[MASK] in 1973 , and the two Mirage fighter squadrons in 1988 . Sin[MASK]e then a detachment of Orion maritime patrol a[MASK]rcraft , sup[MASK]ort per[MASK]onnel , and an infantry company known as Rifle Company Butterworth have been ma[MASK]ntained , as well[MASK]as occasional deploymen[MASK]s of F / A @-@ 18 Hornet fighter aircraft . Australian submarines w[MASK]re reportedly also involved[MASK]in a number of[MASK]cl[MASK]ndestine surveillan[MASK]e missions throughout Asian waters in t[MASK]e [MASK]ast decades of the Cold War [MASK] Airforce a[MASK]d Navy units were also involved in tracking Soviet ship and submarine movements in the region . Since then the Orions have continued to participate[MASK]in maritime[MASK]security operations as part of Operation Gateway , conducting patrols over the Indian Ocean [MASK] Strait of Malacca and Sout[MASK] China Sea . They have reportedly also been involved[MASK]in freedom of navigation fl[MASK]ghts . 
 
 = = = Gulf War , 1991 = = = 
 
 Australia was a member of the internationa[MASK] coalition wh[MASK]ch [MASK]ontribut[MASK]d military forces to the 1991 Gulf War , deploying a na[MASK]al task group of two wa[MASK]ship[MASK] , a support shi[MASK] and [MASK] cl[MASK]arance diving team ; in total about 750 personnel[MASK]. The Australian contribut[MASK]on was the first time Australian personnel were[MASK]deployed to an active war zone since the establ[MASK]shment of the ADF and the deployment tested its capabilities and command structure . However , the Australian force did[MASK]not see combat , and instead playing a significant role in enforcing the sanctions put in place against[MASK]I[MASK]aq following the invasion of Kuwait . Some ADF personnel servin[MASK] on exch[MASK]n[MASK]e with Briti[MASK]h and American units did see combat , and a few were later decorated for their actions . Following the wa[MASK] , the Navy regularly deployed a fri[MASK]at[MASK] to the Persian Gulf or Red Sea to enforce the trade [MASK]anctions which continued to be applied to Iraq . A number of Australian airmen and ground crew posted to or on exchange [MASK]ith US and British air forces subsequently participat[MASK]d in enforcing no @-@ fly zones imposed over Iraq between 1991 and 2003 .[MASK]
 
 = = = Global security , late @-@ 1990s = = = [MASK] 
 Since the [MASK]ate 1980s , the Australian government had increasingly called upon the ADF to contribute forces to peacekeeping missions around the w[MASK]rld . While most of these d[MASK]ployments involved only small numbers of specialists , several led to the deployment of hundreds of personnel . Large peacekeeping deployments were made to Namibia in early 1989 , Cambodia between 1992 and 1993 , Somalia in 1993 , Rwanda between 1994 and 1995 an[MASK] Boug[MASK]inv[MASK]lle in 1994 and from 1997 onwards . The 1996 election of the Howard L[MASK]beral government resulted in significant reforms to the ADF 's force structure and role , with the ne[MASK] government 's defence strategy plac[MASK]d less singular emphasis on defending Australia from direct attack and greater emphas[MASK]s on w[MASK]rking in co @-@ operation with regional states and Australia 's allies to manage potential security threats in recognition of Australia 's global security interests . In line with this new focus , the ADF 's force structure changed[MASK]in an attempt to increase the proportion of combat units to support units and to improve the ADF 's combat effectiveness . 
 
 = = New Millennium = = 
 
 
 = = = East Timor , 1999 – 2013 = =[MASK]= 
 
 The former @-@ Portugue[MASK]e colony of East[MASK]Timor was invaded b[MASK] Indonesia in 1975 , however , f[MASK]llowing years of violent struggle the new Indonesian government of President B.J. Habibie subsequently agreed to allow the East Timorese to vote on autonomy in 1999 . The [MASK]nited Nations Mission in E[MASK]st Timor ( UNAMET [MASK] was established to organise and c[MASK]nduct th[MASK] vote , which was held at the end of [MASK]ugust 1999 and resulted with 7[MASK] @.@ 5 % of voters deciding in favour of independence . However , following the announcement of the results pro[MASK]@-@ Indonesian militias supported by elements [MASK]f the Indonesian milit[MASK]ry , launched a campaign of violence , looting and arson and many East Timorese were killed , w[MASK]ile perhaps more than 500 @,@ 000 were displaced [MASK] Una[MASK]le to control the violence [MASK] Indonesia subsequently agreed to the deployment of a multinatio[MASK]al peacekeeping force . Australia , which had contributed police to UNAMET , organised and le[MASK] an international military coalition , known as the International Force for East Timor ( INTERFET ) , a non @-@ UN force operating i[MASK] accordance[MASK]with UN resolutions . The total size of the Australian force committed numbered 5 @,@ 500 personnel , and included a significant ground force , supported by air and naval forces[MASK], in the largest single deploym[MASK]nt of[MASK]Australian f[MASK]rces since 1945 . 
 Under the overall c[MASK]mmand of Australian Major General [MASK]eter Cosgrove , INTERFET began arriving on 12 September[MASK]1999 and was tasked with rest[MASK]ring peace and security , protecting [MASK]nd suppor[MASK]ing UNAMET , and facilitating humanitarian assistance operations . With[MASK]the with[MASK]rawal of the Indonesian armed forces , police and government officials from East Timor , UNAMET re @-@ establish[MASK]d its headquarters in Dili on 28 Sep[MASK]ember . On 19 October 1999 , Indonesia formally recognised the result of the refer[MASK]ndum and shortly there[MASK]fter a UN pe[MASK]cekeeping force , the United Nations [MASK]ransitional Ad[MASK]inistration in East Timor ( UNTAET ) was established , becoming fully respon[MASK]ible for the administration of East Timor during its transition to independence . The han[MASK] @-@ ov[MASK]r of command of military operations from INTERFET to UNTAET w[MASK]s completed on 28 February 2000 . Australia continued to support the UN peacekeeping operation with between 1 @,@ 500 and 2 @,@ 000 personnel , as well as landi[MASK]g craft and Blackhawk helicopters and remained the [MASK]argest contributor of personnel to the peacekeeping missi[MASK]n . During the[MASK]e operations Australian forces regularly clashed with pro @-@ Ind[MASK]nesian militia and on a number of occasions Indonesian forces as well , [MASK]specially along the border with West Timor . Significant actions occurred in Suai , Mota 'ain and at Aidabasalala in October 1999[MASK]. However , with the security situation stabilised the b[MASK]lk of the Australian and UN forces were withdrawn by 2005 . Two Australians died from non @-@ battle related c[MASK]uses , while a nu[MASK]ber were wounded in action . 
 The unexpected deployment to East Timor in 1999 led to significant changes in Austr[MASK]lian defence policy and to an enhancement of the ADF '[MASK] ability to conduct operati[MASK]ns outside Australia . This successful deployment was the first time a l[MASK]rge Australian military force had operated outside of[MASK]Australia since the Vietnam War and revealed shortcomings in the ADF 's ability to mount and sustain such operations . In response , the 2000 Defence White Paper placed a greater emphasis on preparing the [MASK]DF for overseas deplo[MASK]ments . The Australian go[MASK]ernment committed to improve the ADF 's capabilities by[MASK]improving the readiness and equipment of ADF units , ex[MASK]anding the ADF to 57 @,@ 000 full @-@ time personnel and increasing real Defence expendit[MASK]re by 3 % per year . 
 In May 2006 , 2 @,@ 000 ADF personnel[MASK]were again deployed to East Timor as part of Opera[MASK][MASK]on Astute , following unrest between e[MASK]e[MASK]ents of the Timor Leste Def[MASK]nce Force . Austr[MASK]lian forces were involved in a number skirmishes during this tim[MASK] , including a heavy clash with rebels [MASK]ommanded by Alfredo Re[MASK]nado at Same on 4 March 2007 . However , by early @-@ 2010 the s[MASK]curity sit[MASK][MASK]tion had been stabilised and just 400 Australian personnel remained to train the local security forces as part of a small international force . Following a drawdown , the International Stabilisation Force commenced withdrawing from Timor @-@ [MASK]este in November 2012 , a process which was[MASK]completed in April 2013 . 
 
 = = = Afghanistan , 2001 – present = = = 
 
 Shortly after the Islamist inspired terrorist attacks in New York and Washington on 11 September 2001 , Australian forces were c[MASK]mmitted to the American @-@[MASK]led international coalition against terrorism . The ADF 's most visible contribution —[MASK]codenamed Operation Slipper — has been a special forces task group operating i[MASK] Afghanistan from 2001 to 200[MASK] [MASK]nd again from mid @-[MASK] 2005 to fight against the Taliban . Over time the Australian commitment has grown ,[MASK]with the addition of further ground forces in the fo[MASK]m of a Reconstruction Task Force from 2006 to [MASK]rovide security , reconstruction and to mentor and train the Afghan N[MASK]tional Army . Australia has also contributed a frigate[MASK]and two AP @-@ 3C [MASK]rion sur[MASK]eilla[MASK][MASK]e aircraft and three C @-@ 1[MASK]0 Hercules transport aircraft to international operations in the Persian Gulf and Indian Ocean since 2001 , supporting both the operations in[MASK]Af[MASK]hanistan a[MASK]d th[MASK]se in Iraq under Oper[MASK]tion Catalyst . A detachment of four F / A @-@ 18 Hornet fighter @-@ bombers was based at Diego Garcia from la[MASK]e @[MASK]@ 2001 to mid @-@ 2002 , while two Boein[MASK] 707 air @-@ to @-@ air refuelling aircraft were also based in Manas[MASK]A[MASK]r Bas[MASK] in Kyrgyzstan t[MASK] provide support to coali[MASK]ion aircraft operating in Afghan[MASK]airspace but were later withdrawn . A Special Operations Task Group was deployed to support the Reconstruction Taskforce in April 2007 . In addition to radar crews , logistics and intelligence officers , and security personnel , this brought the number of Australian personnel in Afgha[MASK]istan to 950 by mid @-@ 2007 , with further small increases to 1 @,@ 000 in mid @-@ 20[MASK]8 , 1 @,@ 100 in early 2009 and 1 @,@ 550 in mid @-@ 2009 . 
 A modest[MASK]force remained in Afghanistan over this time and was involved in counter @-@ insurgency operations in Uru[MASK]gan Province in conjunction United States and other coalition for[MASK]es , including the Dutch prior to their withdrawal . The[MASK]force consisted[MASK]of motorised infantry , special for[MASK]es , engineers , cavalry , artillery and aviation elements . By 2010 it included a combined arm[MASK] battalion @-@ sized battle group known as the Mentorin[MASK] Task Force , and the Special Operations Task Group [MASK] both based at Forward Operation Base Ripley outside of Tarin Kowt , as well as the Rotary Wing Group[MASK]flying CH @-@ 47D Chinooks [MASK] the Force Logistics Asset and an RAAF air surveillance radar unit based in Kandahar . In addition , a further 800 Australian logistic[MASK]personnel w[MASK]re also based in the Middle East in support , but are located outside of Afghanistan . Meanwhile , detachments of maritime patrol and transport aircraft continued to support operations in Iraq and [MASK]fghanistan , based out of Al Minhad Air Base in the United Arab Emirates . Also included is the deployment of one of the RAN 's frigates t[MASK] the Arabian [MASK]ea and Gulf of Aden on co[MASK]nter piracy and maritime interdiction duties . 
 [MASK]ustr[MASK]lian forces were at times involved in heavy fighting , and significant actions included Operation Anaconda in 2[MASK]02 and Operation Perth in[MASK]2006 , as well as actions [MASK]n Chora in 2007 , Kakarak in 2009 , the Shah Wali Kot and Derapet in 2010 , and Doan in 2011 ; although others have yet to be publicly acknowledged due to operational security requirements . Casualties include 41 killed and 256 wounded , while another Australian also died serving with the British Army . Four Australians have been awarded the Victoria Cross for Australia , the first such decorations in forty years . Following a drawdown in forces , the last combat troops were withdrawn on 15 Decem[MASK]er 2013 ; however , approximately 400 personnel remain in Afghanistan as trainers and[MASK]advisers[MASK], and are stati[MASK]ned in Kandahar and Kabul [MASK] Over 2[MASK] @,@ 0[MASK]0 Australian pe[MASK]sonnel have served in Afghanistan . 
 
 = = = Iraq , 2003 – 11 = = = 
 
 Australian forces later joined British and American fo[MASK]ces during the 2003 invasion of Iraq . The init[MASK]al contribution was also a modest one , consis[MASK]ing of just 2 @,@ 058 personnel — co[MASK]enamed Operation Falconer . Major force elements included special forces , rotary and fixed wing aviation and nav[MASK]l units . Army units in[MASK]luded elements from the SASR and 4th[MASK]Battalion , Royal Australian Regiment ( Commando[MASK]) , a CH @-@ 47 Chinook detachment and a [MASK]umber of othe[MASK] specialist [MASK]nits . RAN units included the amphibious sh[MASK]p HMAS Kanimbla and the frigates HMAS Darwin and HMAS Anzac , while the RAAF deployed 14 F / A @-@ 18 Hornets from No. 75 Squadron , a number o[MASK] AP @-@ 3C Orions and C @-@ 130 Hercules . [MASK]he Australian Special Forces Task Force was one[MASK]of the first coalition units forces to cross the border into [MASK]raq , while for a few days , the closest ground troops to Baghdad were from the SASR . During the inva[MASK]ion the RAAF also flew its first combat missions since the Vietnam War , with No. 75 Squadron flying a to[MASK]al of 350 sorties and dropping 122 laser @-@ gu[MASK]ded bombs . 
 The Iraqi military quickly proved no match for coalitio[MASK] military power , and with their defeat the bulk of Australian forces were withdrawn . While[MASK]Australia did not initially take part in the post[MASK]@-@ war occupation of Iraq , an Australian Army light armoured battlegroup — designated th[MASK] Al Muthanna Task Group[MASK]and including 40 ASLAV light armoured vehicles and infantry — was later deployed to Southern Iraq in[MASK]April 2[MASK][MASK]5 as part of Oper[MASK]tion Catalyst . The role of this force was to protect the Japanese engineer contingen[MASK] in the region and [MASK]upport the training of New Iraqi Army units . The AMTG later became the Overwatch Battle Group ( West ) ( OBG ( W ) ) , following the hand back of Al Muthanna pr[MASK]vince to Iraqi control[MASK]. Force levels [MASK]ea[MASK]ed[MASK]at 1 @,@ 400 personnel in May 2007 including the OBG ( W ) in Southern [MASK]raq , the Security Detachment in Bagh[MASK]ad and the Australian Army Training Team — Iraq [MASK] A RAN frigat[MASK] was based in the North Persian Gulf , while RAA[MASK] assets included C[MASK]@-@ 130H Hercules and AP @-@ 3C elements . Following the election of a new Labor government under Prime Minister Kevin Rudd the bulk of these forces were withdrawn by mid @-@ 2009 , while RAAF and[MASK]RAN operations were redirected to other parts [MASK]f the Middle East Area of[MASK]Operati[MASK]ns as part of Operation Slipper . 
 Low @-@ level operations continued , however , with a small Australian force of 80 soldiers remai[MASK]ing in Iraq to protect the Australian Em[MASK]assy in Baghdad as part of SEC[MASK]ET under Operation Kruger . SECDET was finally withd[MASK]awn in A[MASK]gust 2011 , and was replaced by a p[MASK]ivate militar[MASK] company which took over responsibility for providing security for Australia 's diplomatic presence [MASK]n Iraq [MASK] Although mo[MASK]e than 17 @,@ 000 personnel ser[MASK]ed during operations[MASK]in Iraq[MASK], Australian casualties were relatively light , with two s[MASK]ldiers accidentally killed , while[MASK]a thi[MASK]d Austral[MASK]an died serving with the British Royal Air Force . A further [MASK]7 personnel were[MASK]wounded . Two officers remained in Iraq attached to the United Nations Assistance Mission for Iraq as part of Operation Rive[MASK]bank . This operation concluded in November 2013 . 
 
 = = = Military intervent[MASK]on aga[MASK]nst ISIL , 2014 – present = = = 
 
 In June 2014 [MASK] small number of[MASK]SASR personnel were deployed[MASK]to Iraq to protect[MASK]the Australian embassy when the security of Baghdad was thre[MASK][MASK]ened by the 2014 Northern Iraq offensive[MASK]. Later , in August and September a number[MASK]of RAAF C @-@ 17 and C @-@ 130J[MASK]transport aircraft based in the Middle East were used to c[MASK]nduct aird[MASK]o[MASK]s of humanitarian aid to trapped civilians and to airlift arms and munitions to forces in Kurdish @-@ controlled northern Iraq . In late September 2014 an Air Task Group ( ATG ) and Special Operations Task Group ( SOTG[MASK]) were deployed to Al Minhad Air Base in the United Arab Emirates as part of the coal[MASK]tion to combat Islamic State forces in Iraq . Equipped with F / A @-@ 18F Super [MASK]ornet strike aircraft , a KC @-@ 30A Multi Role Tanker Transport ,[MASK]and an E[MASK]@[MASK]@ 7A Wedgetail Airborne Early Warning &[MASK]Control aircraft ,[MASK]t[MASK]e ATG began operations on 1 October . The SOTG is tasked with operations to advi[MASK]e and assist Iraqi Securi[MASK]y For[MASK]es , and was deployed to Iraq after a legal fram[MASK]work cover[MASK]ng their presence in the country was[MASK][MASK]greed between the Australian and Iraqi Governments . It[MASK]began moving into Iraq in[MASK]early Novem[MASK]er . In April 2015 a 300 @-@ strong unit known as [MASK]ask Group Taji was deployed to I[MASK]aq to train th[MASK] r[MASK]gular [MASK]raqi Security Force[MASK] . Airstrikes were extended to Syria in Septemb[MASK]r 2015 . 
 
 = = Peacekeeping = = 
 
 Australia 's involvement in [MASK]nternational peac[MASK]keeping operatio[MASK]s has be[MASK]n diverse , and included participation[MASK]in both United[MASK]Nations sponsored mission[MASK] , as well as those as part of [MASK]d @-@ [MASK]oc coalitions . Au[MASK]tralians have been in[MASK]olved in more conflicts as peacekeepers than as belligerents ; however " in comparative international terms , Australia has only been a moderately energetic peace[MASK]eeper . " Although Australia has had peacekeepers in the field continu[MASK]usly for 60 years [MASK] being among the first group of UN [MASK]ilitary obser[MASK]ers in Indonesia in 1947 — its commitments have generally been limited , consisting most[MASK]y of small numbers of high @-@ leve[MASK] and technical support troops such as signallers , engineers , medics , observers , and police . One signific[MASK]nt commitment has been Australia 's ongoing involvement with the long r[MASK]nning Multinational Force and Observers in the S[MASK]nai .[MASK]The operational tempo started increasing in the mid @-@ 1990s , when Australia became involved in a series of high @-@ profil[MASK] operations , deploying significan[MASK]ly larger combat units in suppo[MASK]t of a number of mis[MASK]ions in[MASK]luding Cambodia , Rwanda , Somalia , East Timor , and the Solomon Islands . Australia has been involved in close to 100 separate missions , involving more than 30 @,@ 000 personnel ; 14 Australians have died during t[MASK]ese operations . 
 
 = = Military statistics = = 
 
 
 
 = Ward Churchill = 
 
 Ward LeRoy Chur[MASK]hill ( born 1947 ) is a[MASK] American author and political activist . He was a pro[MASK]essor of ethnic studies at the University of Colorado Boulder from 1990 until 2007 . The primary focus of his work is on the historical treatment of political dissenters and Native Americans by the U[MASK]ited States governmen[MASK] . His work features controv[MASK]rsial and provoc[MASK]tive views , written in a direct , often confrontational styl[MASK] . 
 In January 2005[MASK], Churchill 's work attracted controversy because of the[MASK]circulation of a 2001 essay , " On the[MASK]Justice of Roosting Chickens " , in [MASK]hich he argued the September 11 attacks were a natural and unavoidable consequen[MASK]e of unlawfu[MASK] US foreign policy over the latter half of the 20th century ; the essay is well known for Churchill 's use of the ph[MASK]ase " little Eichmanns " to describe the " technocratic corps " working in the World Trade Center . 
 In March 2005 the University of Colorado bega[MASK] investigating allegations that Churchill had engaged in rese[MASK]rch misconduct ; it report[MASK]d in June 2006 [MASK]hat he had done so . Churchill was fired on July 24 , 2007 , leading to a claim by some scholars that he was fired because of the " Little Eichmanns " comment . Churchill filed a lawsuit against the University of Colorado for un[MASK]awful termination of employment . In April 2009 a[MASK]Denver jury f[MASK]und that C[MASK]urchill was wrongly fired , awarding him $ 1 in[MASK]damages . In July 2009 , a[MASK]District Cou[MASK]t judge vacated the monetary award and declined Churchill 's request to order his reinstatement , decidin[MASK] the u[MASK]iversity has " quasi @-@ judicial immunity " . In February 2010 , Churchill appealed the judge 's [MASK]ecision . In November 2010 , the C[MASK]lorad[MASK] Court of Appeals upheld the lower @-@ court 's ruling . In September 10 , 2012 , the Colorado [MASK]upreme Court uphel[MASK] the lower courts[MASK]' decisi[MASK]ns in favor of the University of Colora[MASK]o . On [MASK]pril 1[MASK], 2013 , the United States Supreme Court declined to hear the case . 
 In a February 2014 interview , Churchill commented that after living more than forty years in the n[MASK]rthern plains / Colorado region , he had relocated to Atlanta , Georgia in 2013 . Churchill also stated that he had a[MASK]half @-@ dozen uncompleted books which he intended to finish[MASK]and publish in the next three years . 
 
 = = Ea[MASK]ly life and education = = 
 
 Churchill was born in U[MASK]bana , Illinois , to Jack LeRo[MASK] Churchill and Maralyn Lucretia Allen . His parents divorced before he was two , and he grew up in Elmwood , where he attended local schools . 
 In 1966 , he was drafted into the United States[MASK]Army . On his [MASK]980 resume [MASK] he said he served as a public [MASK]-@ information specialist who " wrote and edited the battalion newsletter and wrote news releases . " 
 In a 1987 profile on Churchill , the Denver Post reported th[MASK]t he w[MASK]s drafted , went to paratrooper school ,[MASK]then[MASK]volunteer[MASK]d for Viet[MASK]am , where he served a 10 @-@ month tour as Long Range Reconnaissance Patrol ( [MASK]RRP ) , one of a six @-@ man team sent out to track down the enemy . The Post article[MASK]also reported that Chur[MASK]hill was politically radicalized[MASK]as a result of his experienc[MASK]s in Vietnam . Churchill told the Post that he had spent some time at the Chicago off[MASK]ce of the Students for a Democratic Society ( SDS ) in the late 1960s , and briefly taught members of the Weather Undergr[MASK]und how to build bombs and fire weapons . 
 In 2005 , the Denver Post reported that Churchill 's military records show he was t[MASK]ained as a film projection[MASK]st and light truck driver , but they do not reflect par[MASK]trooper school or LRRP training . The 75th Ranger Regiment Association found no record of Churchill having been a member of the unit , or a LRRP team . 
 Churchill received his B.A. in technological communications in 1974[MASK]and M.A. in communications theory in 1975 , bo[MASK]h from[MASK]Sangamon State University , now[MASK]th[MASK] University of Illinois a[MASK] Springfield . 
 
 = = Career = = 
 
 In 1978 , Churchill began working at the University of Colorado Bould[MASK]r as an affirmati[MASK]e action officer in the university admini[MASK]tration . He also lectured on American Indian issu[MASK]s in the ethnic studies program . In 1990 , the University of Colorado hired him as an associate profes[MASK]or , although he did not possess the academic doctorate usually required for[MASK]the position . The following year he was granted tenure in the Communications department , without the usual six @-@ year probationary period , after having been declined by the Sociology and Political Science departments . 
 He has lon[MASK] been interested in issues associated with the Dawes Act , which broke up the communal reservation lands and assigned plots to indi[MASK]idual households [MASK] Connected with that was the federal government 's f[MASK]rst use of " blood quantum " to define individual membership in trib[MASK]s , for what became known as the Dawes Rolls . Since re @-@ establishing self @-@ governments , fed[MASK]rally recognized tribes have established their own criteria for enrollment as members , o[MASK]ten related t[MASK] descent[MASK]from recognized historical lists , but less[MASK]often re[MASK]uiring proofs of blood quantum . So[MASK]e of his published works address these iss[MASK]es , which he has interprete[MASK] as part of the feder[MASK]l government 's poli[MASK]y of genocide against N[MASK]tive Americans .[MASK]
 In 1995 Churchill discussed his views with David Barsamian in an [MASK]nterview :[MASK]
 [MASK]ou could say that five hundred years ago was the basis of blood quantum in[MASK]Ibero @-@ America . But in Anglo @-@ America , while there was some preoc[MASK]upation with it , it was not formalized until the passage of the General Allotment A[MASK]t , m[MASK]d @-@ 1880s . At that [MASK]oint they began to define In[MASK]ian as being someone who was demonstrably and doc[MASK]mentably of at lea[MASK]t one @-@ quarter by quantum bloo[MASK] [MASK]ndigenous in a given group .
