You couldn 't be an eighth Cheyenne and an eighth Arapaho and be an Indian . You had to be a quarter Cheyenne or a quarter Arapaho or hopefully a quarter and a quarter . The reason for this was quite[MASK]clear [MASK] They were identify[MASK]ng Indians for purposes of allotting them i[MASK]dividual p[MASK]rcels of land in the existing reservation base at that p[MASK]int . If they ran out of Indians identifiabl[MASK] as such , then the rest of[MASK]the la[MASK]d would be declared surplus . So it was clearly in the interests[MASK]of the government to cre[MASK]te a definition of Indianness that would minimiz[MASK] the number of Indians that were available . It wa[MASK] an economic motivation for the application of this genetic criter[MASK]a to Indianness in the first plac[MASK] . It 's become increas[MASK]ngly so ever since . " ( David Barsamian ( December 1995 ) . " Interview with Ward Churchill : Historical and Current Perspectives " . Z Magazine . ) 
 In 1996 , Churchill moved to the new Eth[MASK]ic Studies Department of the University of Colorado . In 1997 , he was promoted to full professor . He was selected as chairman of the department in June 2002 . 
 In January 2005 , during the controversy over his 9 / 11 remarks , Churchill resigned as c[MASK]airman of the ethnic studies depar[MASK][MASK]ent at the University of Colorado — his term as chair was schedu[MASK]e[MASK] t[MASK] expire in June of that year . On May 16 , 200[MASK] , the Investigative Committee of the Standin[MASK] Committee on Research Misconduct at the Uni[MASK]ersity of Colorado concluded that Churchill h[MASK]d committed mul[MASK]iple c[MASK]unts of academic misconduct , specifically plagiarism , fabrication , and falsi[MASK]ication . On July 24 , 2007 , Churchill was fired for academic misconduct in an eight to one vote by the University of Colorado 's Board of Regents . 
 
 = = Genealogy and Tribal affiliation = = 
 
 In 2003 , Churchill stated , " I am myself of Muscogee and Creek[MASK]descent on my father 's side , Cherokee on my mother 's , and am an enrolled member o[MASK] the United Keetoowah Band of[MASK]Cherokee Indians . " In 1992 , Churchill wrote elsewhere that he is one @-@ eighth Creek and one @-@ sixteenth Cherokee . I[MASK] 1993 , Chu[MASK]chill told the Colorado[MASK]Daily that " he was one @-@ sixteenth Creek and Cherokee . " Churchill told the Denver Post in February 2005 that he is three @-@ sixteenths Ch[MASK]rokee . 
 In a statem[MASK]nt dated May 9 , 20[MASK]5 , and posted on its we[MASK]site , the United Keetoowah Band initially[MASK]said , 
 " The United Keetoowah Band would like to make it clear that Mr. Churchill IS NOT a me[MASK]ber of the Keetoowah Band and was only given an honorar[MASK] ' associate membership ' in the early 1990s [MASK]ecause he could not prove any Cherokee ance[MASK]try . " The tribe s[MASK]id that all of Churchi[MASK]l 's [MASK] past , present[MASK]and[MASK]future claims or assertions of Keetoowah ' enrollm[MASK]nt , ' written or spoken , including but not limited to ; biographies , cur[MASK]iculum vitae , lectures , applica[MASK]ions for employme[MASK]t [MASK] or any other reference not listed herein , are deemed fraudulent by the United Keeto[MASK]wah Band . " 
 Two days later[MASK], t[MASK]e United Keetoowah Band replaced its statement and acknowledged Churchill 's " alleged ancestry [MASK] of being Cherokee : 
 " Because Mr. Churchill had genealogical information regarding his alleged ancestry , and his wi[MASK]lingness to assist the UKB in pro[MASK]oting the tribe an[MASK] its causes , he was awarded an ' Associate Membership [MASK] as an honor , " the tribe 's website now said . " Ho[MASK]ever , Mr. Churchill may possess eligibility status for Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma , since he claims 1 / 16 Cherokee . " 
 The tribe 's spokesperson , Lisa Stopp , stated the tribe enrolls only me[MASK]bers with certified one @-@ quarter American Indian blood . The website statement furthe[MASK] clar[MASK]fie[MASK] that Chu[MASK]chill " was no[MASK] eligible for tr[MASK]bal membership due to the fact that he does not possess a ' Certificate of Degree of Indian Blood ( CDIB ) " , and the associa[MASK]e membership did not entitle an individual to voting rights or enrollment in the tribe . 
[MASK]Churchill has never asked for CDIB certification , and finds the idea of [MASK]eing " vetted " by[MASK]the US government offensive . 
 In June 1994 , the United Keetoowah Ban[MASK] had voted to stop[MASK]award[MASK]ng associate memberships . Such honorary associa[MASK]e membership recognizes an individual 's assistance to the tribe , but it [MASK]as nothing to do[MASK]wit[MASK] Indian ancestry , an[MASK] it does not e[MASK]t[MASK]tle an individual to vote in the tribe as [MASK] member . The [MASK]eetoowah Band states that Churchill stil[MASK] holds the associate membership and it has not been rescinded . In a separate interview , Ernestine Berry , formerly on t[MASK]e tribe 's enrollment committee and four years [MASK]n its council , said that Churchill had never [MASK]ulfilled a promise to [MASK]elp the tribe . 
 In June 2005 , the Rocky Mountain News published an article about Churchill 's genealogy and family history . It " turn[MASK]d up no evidence of a singl[MASK] Indian a[MASK]cestor " among 142 direct ances[MASK]ors [ of Churchill 's ] identified from records . The News reported that both Churchill 's birth parents were listed as w[MASK]ite on the 1930 census [MASK] as were all but two of h[MASK]s great @-@ great @-@ [MASK]randparents listed on previous census and other official documents . The News found that some of Churchill 's accounts of where his ance[MASK]tors had lived did[MASK]not agree with documented records . Numerous member[MASK] of Churc[MASK]ill 's extended family have longstanding family leg[MASK]nds of Indian ancestry among ance[MASK]tors ; but , none [MASK]as confirmed among the 142 direct forebears of Churchill who w[MASK]re identif[MASK]ed[MASK]. 
 Docu[MASK]ents in Churchill 's university personnel [MASK]ile show [MASK]hat he was granted tenure in a " special opportunity position . " In 1994 , then CU @-@ Boulder Chancellor James Corbridge refused to take action on allegations [MASK]hat Churchill was fraudulently claim[MASK]ng to be an Indian , sayin[MASK] " it has alw[MASK]ys been university poli[MASK]y that a person 's race or ethnicity is self @-@ proving . " 
 Some of Churchi[MASK]l 's[MASK]Native Ameri[MASK]an critics , such as Vernon Bellecourt ( White Earth Oji[MASK]we ) and Suzan Shown Harjo ( Southern Cheyenne [MASK]-@ Muscogee C[MASK]eek ) , argue that his assertion of Native American ancestr[MASK] without[MASK]the ability to prove it might co[MASK]stitute misrepresentation and gro[MASK]nds for termination . The University has said that it does not hire on the basis of ethnicity . The Univ[MASK]rsity of Colorado 's Research Misconduct Committee conducted a preliminary investigation into whether Churchill misrepresented his ethnicity to " add credibility and publi[MASK] acceptance to his scholarship . " The committee concluded that the allegation was not " appropriate for further investigation under the definition of research misconduct . " 
 In a 2005 int[MASK]rview in The Rocky Mounta[MASK]n News , Churchill said , " I have never been confirmed as having one @-@ quarter blood , and never said I was . An[MASK] even if [ the critics [MASK] are absolutely right , w[MASK]at does that have to do with this issue ? I have never claimed to be goddamned Si[MASK]ting Bull . " The longtime indigenous activist Russell Means said in February of that year[MASK], " So I want [MASK] from this day forward , every media perso[MASK] nationally , internationally and locally to know that we have ascertained that Wa[MASK]d Churchill is a full @-@ blooded Indian l[MASK]ader . " 
 
 = = = Bloo[MASK] quantum = = = 
 
 Churchill has [MASK]esponded to requests[MASK]for verification of his claimed Indian heritage in various ways , including attacking the blood quantum upon which some Native Americ[MASK]n tribes establish their membership requirements . Churchill argues that the United States instituted bloo[MASK] quantum laws based upon rules of descendancy in order to further goals of personal enrichment and political expediency . 
 For decades in his writings , Churchill has argued that blood quantum laws ha[MASK]e an inherent genocidal purpose . He says , 
 " Set the blood quantum at one @-@ quarter , hold to it as a rigid definition of Indians , let intermarriage proceed as it [ has ] and eventually Indian[MASK] will be defined out of e[MASK]istence " . 
 Church[MASK]ll 's assertions have been raised as one of the several resear[MASK]h @-@ misconduct allegations that were brought against him in [MASK]005 ( see below ) . He has been accused of using his interp[MASK]etation of the Dawes Act to attack tribal governments that would not recognize him as a member . 
 
 = = Writing = = 
 
 C[MASK]urchil[MASK] has written on American [MASK]ndian history and culture , and speaks about genocide inflicted on t[MASK]e indigenous people of[MASK]t[MASK]e Americas by European settlers and what he describes as the repression of native people[MASK] that continues to t[MASK]is day . 
 As [MASK]f 2007 , according to a report submitted o[MASK] his behalf , Churchill has w[MASK]itten 10 books on his own and co @-@ auth[MASK]red 4 . Some have been reprinted with updates . He has [MASK]ritte[MASK] 51 book[MASK]chapters , 3 law reviews , [MASK]nd 50 scholarly essays ; 27 of these were ref[MASK]reed . He has edited 4 volumes and co [MASK]-@ edited 3 more . 
 Accor[MASK]ing to the Univers[MASK]ty of [MASK]olorado in[MASK]estigation , " His academic pub[MASK]ications are nearly all works of synthesis and reinterpretation , drawing upon studies by other scholars[MASK], not monographs describing new research ba[MASK]ed on prima[MASK]y sources . " The investigation also no[MASK]ed that " he has decided to publish lar[MASK]ely in alternative presses or journals , not in the university presses or mainst[MASK]eam peer @-@ reviewed journals often favored by more conventional academics [MASK] " In additio[MASK] to his academic writing , Chu[MASK]chill has written for several general readership [MASK]agazines o[MASK] political[MASK]opi[MASK]io[MASK] . 
 In 1986 , Churchill wrote an essay[MASK]titled Pacifism as Pathology : Notes on an American Pseudopraxis critic[MASK]zing pacifist politics within the U.S. left as being hypocritical , de facto racist and ineffectual . In 1998 , Arbeiter Ring Publishi[MASK]g published the essay in a book entitled P[MASK]cifis[MASK] as Pathology : Reflections on the Role of Armed Struggle in North America and [MASK]isting Ward Churchill as the author . The book included a preface by Ed Mead ,[MASK]a new int[MASK]oduction t[MASK] the essay by Churchill and a commentary by Mike Ryan . The book sparked much debate in leftist circles [MASK]nd inspired more aggressive tactics within the anti @-@ globalization movement in the following few years . 
 Agents of Repression ( [MASK]988 ) , co @-@ authored by Jim Vand[MASK]r Wall , describes what the authors claim was a secret war against the Black Panther Party and American Indian Movement carried out during th[MASK] late [MASK]960[MASK] and '[MASK]70s by the FBI unde[MASK] the COINTELPRO program . The COINTELPRO Papers ( 1990 ; reissued 2002 ) , also co @-@ autho[MASK]ed [MASK]ith Jim Vander Wall , exa[MASK]ines a series of original FBI memos that detail the Bureau 's activities against various leftist groups , from the U.S. C[MASK][MASK]munist Party in the 1950s to activists c[MASK]ncerned with Central American issue[MASK] in the 1980s . 
 In Fant[MASK]sies of the Master Rac[MASK] ( 1992 ) , Churchill ex[MASK]mines the portrayal of American Indians and the use of American Indian symbols in pop[MASK]lar American culture . He focuses on such p[MASK]enomena as Tony [MASK]illerman[MASK]'s mystery[MASK]novels , the[MASK]film Dances with Wolves , and the New Age movement[MASK], finding examples of cultural imperialism and exp[MASK]oitation . Churchill calls auth[MASK]r Carlos Castaneda 's claims of revealing the teachings of a Yaqui Indian [MASK]ha[MASK]a[MASK] , the " greatest hoax since Piltdown Man . " 
 Struggle for the Land ( 1993 ; reis[MASK]ued 2002 ) is a collect[MASK]on of essays in wh[MASK]ch Churchill chronicles what he describes as [MASK]he U.S. government 's systematic exploitation of Native lands and the killing or displacement of American Indians . He det[MASK]ils Native American efforts[MASK]in the 19th and 20th centuries to prevent defoliation and industrial practices such as surface[MASK]mining . 
 Churchill 's Indians Are Us ? ( 1994 ) , a sequel to Fantasies of the Master Race , further explores American Indian issues in popular culture and politics . He examines the movie Black Robe , the Pine Ridge Indian Reserv[MASK]tion killings[MASK], the prosecution of Leon[MASK]rd Peltier , sports mascots , the Indian Arts and Crafts Act of 1990 , and blood quantum law[MASK] , c[MASK]lling t[MASK]em tools of genocide . Churchill is particularly outspoken [MASK]bout New Age exploitations [MASK]f shamanism and American Indian sacred traditions , and th[MASK] " do @-@ it @-@ yourself Indianism " of [MASK]ertain contemporary authors . John P. LaVelle of the University of New Mexico School of Law publish[MASK]d a rev[MASK][MASK]w[MASK]of Indians Are Us ? in The American Indian[MASK]Quarterly . Professor LaVelle , an enrolled member of the Santee Sioux N[MASK]tion , states that Indians [MASK]re Us ? twists histo[MASK]ical facts and is hostile toward Indian tribes . It was in this book tha[MASK] Churchill first made the clai[MASK] that the United States distributed " smallpox @-@ infested blankets " to Indian tribes , a claim [MASK]hich he repeated several times over the next decade . The claim has been criticized as a falsification . Churchill h[MASK]s , however , received support from some scholars . 
 From a Native Son : Se[MASK]ected Essays on Indigenism , 1985 – 1995 ( 1996 ) is a collection of 23 prev[MASK]ously published essays on Native American history , culture , and p[MASK]litical activism . In [MASK]is introduction to this volume , Howard Zinn lauds " the emergence of a new generation of Native @-@ American scholars " and describes Churchill 's writing [MASK]s " powerful , eloquent , [MASK][MASK]sparing of ca[MASK]t and deception " . 
 Church[MASK]ll 's A Little Matter of Genocide ( 1997 ) is a survey of [MASK]thnic cleansing in the Americas from 1492 to the present . He compares[MASK]the treatment o[MASK] North American Indians to historical instances of genocide by the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia , Turks against Armenians , and Europeans against the Gypsies , as well as Nazis against the Poles and [MASK]ews . 
 In Perversions of Justice ( 2002 ) , Churchill argues that the U.S. ' s legal s[MASK]stem was adapt[MASK]d to gain control over [MASK]ative American people . Tracing the evolution of federal Indian law , Churchill argues that the principles set forth were not only app[MASK]ied to non @-@ Indians in the U.S. , but later adapted for application abroad . He concludes that [MASK]his demonstrates the developm[MASK]nt of t[MASK]e U.S. ' s " imperial logic , " which depends on a " corrupt form of legalism " to establish colonia[MASK] control and empire . 
 Churchill 's controversial essay on 9 / 11 was expanded into a book @-@ length manuscript , published as On the[MASK]Justice of Roosting Chickens : Reflections on the Consequences of U.S. I[MASK]perial Arrogance and Criminality ( 2003 ) by AK Press . The book features two other chapters , one listing US m[MASK]litary interventions[MASK], another list[MASK]ng what Churchill believes to be US violations of inter[MASK]ational law . The original es[MASK]ay takes the " roosting chickens " of the title from a 1963 Malcolm X speech , in which Malcolm X linked the assassination of U.S. president John F. Kennedy to the violence which Kennedy perpetuated as " merely a case of chickens coming home to roost . " Churchill 's essays in this book address the worldwide forms of resistance that he posits were and con[MASK]inue to be provok[MASK]d by U.S. imperialism of [MASK]he 20th and 21st centuries . 
 In Kill the Ind[MASK]an , Save the [MASK]an : The Genocidal I[MASK][MASK]act of A[MASK]erican Indian [MASK]esidential Schools ( 2004 ) , Churchill traces the history of removing American Indian childr[MASK]n fro[MASK] their homes to residential schools ( in Canada ) or Indian boarding schools ( in the USA ) as part of gov[MASK]rnment policies ( 1880s – 1980s ) which he r[MASK]gards as g[MASK]nocidal . 
 
 = = Activism on Native Amer[MASK]can issues = = 
 
 Churchill has been active since at least[MASK]1984 as the co @-@ director of the Denver @-@ based American Indian Movement of Colorado , now an autonomou[MASK] chapter of the American Indian Movement . In 1993 , he and other local AIM leaders , including Russell Means , Glenn T. Morris , Robert Robideau , an[MASK] David Hill , broke with the national AIM leadership , including Denni[MASK] Banks and the brothers Vernon a[MASK]d Clyde Bellecourt , claiming that all AIM chapters are [MASK]utonomous . The AI[MASK] Grand Governing Council is based in Minneapolis and retains the name of the national group[MASK]. It says that the schism arose when [MASK]eans , Churchill , Glenn T. Morris and othe[MASK]s openly[MASK]supported the Miskito Indian group Misurasata , who were allied with the anti @-@ revolutionary , CIA @-@ backed Contras . 
 Journalists such as Harlan McKosato attributed the split to Means and other AIM members dividing over opposition to the [MASK]ellecourt brothers because of their alleged involvement in the executi[MASK]n of Anna Mae Aq[MASK]ash in December 1975 , who was then the highest @-@ ran[MASK]ing woman in A[MASK]M but had[MASK]been suspected of being an informa[MASK]t . It was a year in which other FBI informants had been discovered in AIM . On November 3 , 1999 , Means held a press conference in Denve[MASK] , Colorado in which [MASK]e accused the Bellecourt brothers of complicity in Aquash 's d[MASK]ath , and named th[MASK]ee lower @-@ [MASK]evel AIM members involved in her death : Arlo Looking Cloud[MASK], John Graham , and Theda Nelson Clark . This was the first time that an AIM leade[MASK] active at the time of the Aquash murder had publicly accused AIM of having been involve[MASK] . 
 Looking Cloud and Graham w[MASK]re convicted of murder in 2004 and 2010 , by federal and South Dako[MASK]a state juries , respectively . By then Clark was being cared for in a nursing home and was not indicted . Means a[MASK]tributed the split in AIM to divi[MASK]ions[MASK]in the aftermath of Aquash 's murder . The journali[MASK]t Harlan McKosato said in 1999 , " ... her [ Aquash 's ] death has divided the American Indian Mo[MASK]emen[MASK] ... " 
 The schism continued , with the nati[MASK]nal AIM leadership claiming that the local AIM leaders , such as Churchill , are tools of the U.S. governme[MASK]t used against other American Indians . Th[MASK] leaders of the national AIM organization , now called AIM Grand Governing Council , claim that Churchill has worked in the past as an undergrou[MASK]d counter @-@ intelligence source for the U.S. government , for example the FBI , and loc[MASK]l , non @-@ Indian , police forces , to subvert the national AI[MASK] organization . Specifically , they refer to a 1993 Boulder , Colorado interview with Jodi Rave , a former colum[MASK]ist for the Denver Post , in which Churchill stated that he " was teaching the Rapid City Police Department about the American Indian Movement . " In[MASK]addition , Vernon Bellecourt accused Chur[MASK]hill of having ' fraudulently represented himself as an Indian ' to bolster his credentials . Bellecourt said he complained to the University of Colorado about this as early as 1986 . 
 Churchill has been a leader of Colorado AIM 's an[MASK]ual protests in Den[MASK][MASK]r against the Columbus Day holiday and i[MASK]s associated parade . Colorado[MASK]AIM 's lea[MASK]ership has come into conflict with some leaders in t[MASK]e Denver Italian Americ[MASK]n community , the main supporters of the parade . As early as 2004 [MASK] Churchill had claimed that such pa[MASK]ades are unconstituti[MASK]nal , ar[MASK]uing that the Ninth Amendment[MASK]to the Constitution provides Nati[MASK]e Americans with a right not to be subjected [MASK]o such displays , overriding the First Amendment rights of non @-@ [MASK]ative Americans . 
 
 [MASK] = 9 / 11 essay controversy = = 
 
 Churchill wrote an essay in September 2001 entitled On the Justice of Roosting Chickens . I[MASK] it , he argued that the September 11 attacks were provoked by U.S. foreign poli[MASK]y . He[MASK]compared the role of fina[MASK]cial workers[MASK]at the Wor[MASK]d Trade Center i[MASK] " ongoing genocidal American imperialism " to the role played by Adolf Eic[MASK]mann in organizing the Holocau[MASK]t . In 2005 , this essay was widely publicized w[MASK]en Hamilton College invited Churchill to speak . This led to both condemnations of Churchill and counter @-@ accusations of McCarthyism by Churchill and supporters . Following the controversy , t[MASK]e University of Colorado interim Chancellor Phil DiStefano said , " While Professo[MASK] Churchill has the constitutiona[MASK] right to express his political views , his essay[MASK][MASK]n 9 / 11 has outraged and appalled us and the general public . " 
 A documentary called Shouting Fire : [MASK]tories from the Edge of Fre[MASK] Speech , broadcast on HBO , prominently features Churchill 's case in addressing the iss[MASK]es of free speech and First Amendment rights . 
 
 = = Research miscondu[MASK]t investigation = = 
 [MASK] The controversy attracted increased acad[MASK]mic atte[MASK]tion to Churchill 's research , which had already been criticized by the legal scholar Jo[MASK]n LaVelle and h[MASK]storian Guenter Lewy . Additional critics w[MASK]re the soc[MASK]ologist Thomas Brown , who had [MASK]een preparing an article on Churchill 's work , and[MASK]the historians R.G. Robertson and Ru[MASK]sell Thornton , who claimed that Churchill had misrepres[MASK]nted their work . In 2005 , University of Colo[MASK]ado Boulder adm[MASK]nistrators[MASK]ordered an investigation into seven allegations of research misconduc[MASK] , including three al[MASK]egations of plagiarism , and four allegations of fabrication or falsification regarding the history of [MASK]he Dawes Act , the Indian Art[MASK] and Crafts Act of 1990 , and statements that smallpox was intentionally spread to Native Americans by John Smith in[MASK]1614 and by the United States Army at Fort Clark in 1837 ( not to be confused w[MASK]th the well @-@ documented use of smallpox @-@ infected blankets at F[MASK]rt Pitt in 1764 ) . 
 On May 16 , 2006 the University released their findings ; the Invest[MASK]gative Committee agreed unanimously that Churchill h[MASK]d engaged in " serious research misconduct " , including falsification , fabrication , and two of the three allega[MASK]ions of plagiarism . The committee was divided on the appropriat[MASK] level of sanctions . The Stan[MASK]ing Committee on Research Misconduct accepted the fin[MASK]ings of the Investigat[MASK]ve Committee but a[MASK]so disagreed on what sanctions should be imposed . Churchill 's ap[MASK]eal against his proposed dismissal was considered by a panel of[MASK]the University 's Privilege and Tenure[MASK]Committee , which found that two of the seven [MASK]indings of misconduct di[MASK] not constitute dismissible offences . Three members recommended that the pen[MASK]lty should be demotion and one year 's suspension without pay , while two favored dismissal . 
 On July 24[MASK], 2007 [MASK] the U[MASK][MASK]versity regents voted seven to two to uphold all seven[MASK]of the findings of research m[MASK]sconduct , overruling the recommendation of [MASK]rivilege and Tenure[MASK]panel that two be dismisse[MASK] [MASK][MASK][MASK]y a vote[MASK]of eight to one , th[MASK] regents determined to fire Church[MASK]ll . [MASK] The nex[MASK] day , Churchill file[MASK] a law[MASK]uit in state court claiming that the firing was retribution for his expressing politically unpopular views . The jury in Churchill 's suit for reinstatement weigh[MASK]d the university 's claims of academic misconduct per jury i[MASK]structions it received [MASK]n the case . As Stanley Fish said , " [MASK]t was the jury ’ s task to determine whether Chu[MASK]chill ’ s dismissal wo[MASK]ld have[MASK]occurred independently of the adverse politi[MASK]al response to his co[MASK]stitutionally protected statements . " The[MASK]jury found that the a[MASK]leged misconduct would not have led to Churchill 's firing and reje[MASK]ted the university 's academic misconduct claim as[MASK]the grounds for dismissal . On April 1 , 2009 , a Colo[MASK]ado jury found that Churchill had been wrongly fired , and awarded $ [MASK] in damages . As one of the juror[MASK] said later i[MASK] a press interview , " it wasn 't a slap in his face [MASK]r anything like that when we didn 't give him any money . It '[MASK] just that [ Churchill 's attorney ] David La[MASK]e kept saying this wasn 't about the money , and in the end , we took his wor[MASK] for that . " Chu[MASK]chill 's counsel asked Chief Judge Larry J. Naves of the Denver District Court to order reinstatement in light of the verdict . 
 On July[MASK]7 , 2009 , Judge Naves found that the defendants ( university ) were entitled to quasi @-@ judici[MASK]l immunit[MASK] as a matter of law , vacated the jury[MASK]verdict and determined that the University did not owe Ch[MASK]rchill [MASK]ny financial comp[MASK]nsati[MASK]n . Naves denied Churchill 's request for reinstatement at CU . 
 Churchill appealed both decisions [MASK] On November 24 , 2010 [MASK] a three @-@ judge panel [MASK]f the Colorado Court of Appeals affirme[MASK] the trial court 's decis[MASK]on . In February 2011 , Churchill [MASK]iled a petition for writ of certiorari with the Colorado Supreme Court . In late May 2011 , the Colorado Supreme Court agreed to hear [MASK]is case . Court [MASK]ecords indicate that oral arguments began June 7 , 2012 . On September 10 , 2012 , the court ruled that the University had " quasi @-@ judicial immunity " , [MASK]pholding the trial court 's ruling . On April 1 , 2013 , the U.S. Supreme Court declined to hear an ap[MASK]eal from Churchill . 
 
 = = Honors = = 
 
 1992 [MASK] Alfred University awarded him an honorar[MASK] Doctorate of Humane Letters .

 = = Artwork [MASK] = 
 
 Churchill 's subjects are often [MASK]merican Indian figures and other the[MASK]es associated with Native American Culture . He uses historical photographs as source materia[MASK] for works .[MASK]In the early 1[MASK][MASK]0s at Santa Fe Indian Market , Churchill protested the passage[MASK]of the 1990 Indian Arts and Crafts Act . It [MASK]equi[MASK]es that , to identify and exhibit works as being by a Native A[MASK]erican , artists and craftsmen must be enrolled in a Native American tribe or designated[MASK]by a tribe as an artisan . Under federal[MASK]law , Churchill cannot identify his art as by a Native American . 
 Some of Churchill 's pieces may infringe copyrights . For[MASK]example , his 1981 se[MASK]igraph Winter Attack was , a[MASK]co[MASK]ding to Churchill and others , based on a 1972 drawin[MASK] [MASK]y the[MASK]artist Thomas E. Mails Churchill printed 150 copies of Win[MASK]er Attack and sold at least one of them . Othe[MASK] copies are available online for purchase . Churchill says that , when he p[MASK]oduced Winter Attack , he pub[MASK]i[MASK]ly ac[MASK]nowled[MASK]ed that [MASK]t was based on Mails ' work . The[MASK]online journal Artnet mentions Churchill 's artwork and the controversy surrounding its originality . 
 
 
 = Exit Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart = 
 
 " Exit Through the Kwik [MASK]-@ E @-@ Mart " is the fifteenth episode of the twenty @-@ [MASK]hird season of the American animated television sitcom The Simpsons . It originally aired on the Fox network in the United States on March 4 , 2012 . In the episode , Bart is punished by H[MASK]mer after causi[MASK]g trouble . He gets revenge on his father by spray @-@ painting images of him with the word " dope " all over Springfield . Street artist Shepard Fairey encoun[MASK]ers [MASK]art one night and[MASK]offers him a gallery show of B[MASK]rt 's artworks . [MASK]owever , Chief Wiggum suddenly appears during the show and arres[MASK]s [MASK]art for covering the town i[MASK] graffiti . It turns out that Fairey is an undercover officer working for Wiggum . 
 The episode references the 2010 street art documentary Exit Through the Gift [MASK]hop by g[MASK]affiti artist Banksy , and feature[MASK] guest appearan[MASK]es from street artists Ron English , Kenny Scharf , and Robbie Conal as themselves . Fairey , who is a long @-@[MASK]time fan of The Simpsons , also guest starred i[MASK] the e[MASK]isode as himself . Around 5 @.@ 09 million Americans tuned i[MASK] to watch " Exit Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart " during its original broa[MASK][MASK]ast . Since then , the episode has received praise from television critics for its opening sequence , wh[MASK]ch parodie[MASK] the open[MASK]ng sequence of the m[MASK]dieval fantasy [MASK]elevision series Game[MASK]of Thrones . 
 
 = = Plot = = 
 [MASK] As a birthday gift for Marge , [MASK]omer [MASK]uys a blender desi[MASK]ned by television chef[MASK]Paula Paul . He go[MASK]s to a health food store called S[MASK]apper Jack 's , where Paula is giving away autographs , to have Paula sign it . Homer is impressed by the store and says he will not be shopping at the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart any more . Apu , who is there to spy , overhears Homer and the two engage in a fight until the sec[MASK]rity guards grab hold of Apu and take him away . At the signing , Homer tell[MASK] Paula that Marge is a big fan of hers . Paula decides that she will call Marge live during her upcoming [MASK]how to wish her a h[MASK]ppy birthday . Meanwhile , Bart gets his mother a rabbit for her birthday . The rabbit chews through the phone lines in the Simpsons ' home , causing Marge to miss Paula '[MASK] call . Paula becomes furious at Marge for not answering the phone as she emb[MASK]rrassed herself on her[MASK]show . Homer punishes Bart by locking him up in the rabbit 's cage .[MASK]
 To get revenge on Homer , Bart goes around Springfield spray @-@ painting graffiti of Homer 's f[MASK]ce and the word " dope " . When his work appears on the television news[MASK], it encourages Bart to create even more graffit[MASK] in the town . Street artists Shepard Fairey[MASK], Ron English , Kenny Scharf , and Robbie Conal enco[MASK]nter Bart one night when he is making some graffiti . The four tell [MASK]a[MASK]t that they are impressed by his work and w[MASK]uld like to showcase his art in a galler[MASK] show ,[MASK]at first Bart is unsure , but Bart remembers ho[MASK] Homer treated him , and th[MASK]n agrees . Meanwhile , the Kwik @-@ E @[MASK]@ Mart suffers because of the competition from Swapper Jack 's . Apu ends up atte[MASK]ptin[MASK] to rob [MASK]wapp[MASK]r Jack 's in a desperate measure , but the cashier ( Snake Jailbird ) convinces him to hand over[MASK]the gun . Later , Apu [MASK]s about to shut down the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart when his wife Manjula tells him that Swa[MASK]per[MASK]Jac[MASK] 's is closing because it was discover[MASK]d they were s[MASK]lling monkey meat imported from Brazil as chick[MASK]n . 
 Homer initially refuses to attend Bart 's show because he discovers the artwork is an insult to him , but changes his mind after Bart[MASK]apologizes a[MASK]d writes " I 'm sorry " o[MASK] the hood of Homer 's car . At [MASK]he show , Chief Wiggu[MASK] and the Spring[MASK]ie[MASK]d Police Department suddenly appear to arrest Bart for making graf[MASK]iti throughout the town . It is revealed that the gallery show is a sham and that Fairey is an undercover [MASK]fficer who helped the pol[MASK]ce [MASK]d[MASK]ntify Bart as the graffiti artist that had be[MASK]n spray @-@[MASK]paintin[MASK] Springfield . Since Bart is just a boy , he is not sent to jail[MASK]. Instead , he is punished by once again being locked up in the rabbit cage . When Bart tells Wiggum that he[MASK]has to go to[MASK]the bathroom , Wiggum covers the cage with the blank[MASK]t and finds Bart gone when he removes the blanket from the cage[MASK]. 
 
 = = Production = = 
 
 " Exit Thro[MASK]gh the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Ma[MASK]t " was written by Marc Wilmore and directed by Steven Dean Moore as part of the twenty [MASK]-@ third season[MASK]of The Simpsons ( 2011 – 12 ) . It spoofs the debated status of street art [MASK]s a true form of art . The title is a r[MASK]ference to Exit Through the Gift Shop , a 2010 street art documentary by graffiti a[MASK]tist Banksy who produced the opening sequence of an earlier Simpsons ep[MASK]sode titled " MoneyBART " ( 201[MASK] [MASK] . The Richard Ha[MASK]ley song " Tonight T[MASK]e Streets Are Ours " , which is the theme song of Exit Through the Gift Shop , is included in the epis[MASK]de during a montage of Bart painting g[MASK]affiti in Springfield . Hayden Childs of The A.[MASK]. Club noted in his review of " Exit Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart " that the " reveal that the art show[MASK]was a police sting gives the show a moment to joke about the anti @-[MASK] a[MASK]t market theme from Exit Through The Gift Shop . W[MASK]ggum asks who would be st[MASK]pid enough to pay for work that an amateur puts up f[MASK]r free [MASK]n public , and the an[MASK]wer is ,[MASK]as in Banksy ’ s movie , the very wealthy , here represented by Mr. Burns . " 
 American street artist [MASK]airey guest starred in " Exit Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart " as himself . Th[MASK] graffiti art featuring Homer 's face and the word " dope " that[MASK]Bart creates in the episode is a reference to Fairey 's Barack Obama " Hope " poster and his OBEY Giant imag[MASK] . Fairey has s[MASK]id that The Simpsons has bee[MASK] one of his favorite television shows since the early 1990s because of its " blend of humor and social commentary " , and he felt " deeply [MASK]onored " to be included in an episode . Fairey wrote on his website that [MASK] Part of being on The Simpsons , is you ’ re being honored as a refer[MASK]nce point in cul[MASK]ure . " He described the plot of the episode as " great " , [MASK]dding that the staff members of the show " were kind enoug[MASK] to indu[MASK]ge a co[MASK]ple of my [MASK]ialogue suggestions designed to make the social commentary more pointed [MASK] even though I had to make fun of m[MASK]self to do so ) . " This was F[MASK]irey 's first acting [MASK]erformance . Street artists English , Scharf , and Conal als[MASK] guest [MASK]tarred in the episode a[MASK] thems[MASK]lves . 
 The traditional [MASK]impsons opening sequence was replaced in this episode with a redesigned vers[MASK]on that spoofed the opening sequence of the HBO medieval fantasy series Game of Thrones . The Game of Thrones opening shows the various [MASK]ocations featured in the series on a th[MASK]ee [MASK]-@ dimensional map of the fictional continent Westeros . In the Simpsons opening , these l[MASK]cation[MASK] were substituted with places in Springfield , and The[MASK]Wall was replaced with the[MASK]Simpson family 's couch . The theme song featured in the Game of Thrones opening sequence was arranged by The Simpsons composer Alf Clausen and[MASK]used in the Simpsons opening as well . Nicholas McKaig , known for uploading a cappella co[MASK]er[MASK] of famous songs on YouTube , performed the Simpsons theme song over the closing credits of " Exit Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart " . He was recruited after a staff member of the show saw his cover of the Simpsons theme on YouTube . 
 
 = [MASK] Release = = 
 
 " Exi[MASK] Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart " was originally broadcast on the Fox network in the United States on March 4 , 2012 . It was watched by approximately 5 @.@ 09 million people during this broadcast , and in the demographic for adults ag[MASK]d 18 – 49 , the episode received a [MASK] @.@ 5 Nielsen rating and a seven percent share . This was a[MASK]sl[MASK]ght decrease [MASK]rom the previous episode , " At Long Last Leave " , which acquired a 2 @.@ 6 rating . The episode became the second highest @-@ ra[MASK]ed [MASK]roadcast in Fox 's Animation Domination lineup for th[MASK] night [MASK]n terms of both total viewers and in the 18 – 49 demographic , finishing higher than new epis[MASK]des of American Dad ! , Napoleon Dynamite , and The Cleveland Show , but lower than[MASK]a new Family Guy episode ( which receiv[MASK]d a 2 @.@ 8 rating and was seen by 5 @.@ 33 million people ) . For the week of Fe[MASK]ruary 27 [MASK] March 4 , 2012 , " Exit Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart " placed 25th in the ratings among all prime @-@ time broadcasts in the 18 – 49 demographic , and seventh among all Fox prime @-@ t[MASK]me broadcasts . 
 Wr[MASK]ting for The A.V. Club , television reviewer Hayden Childs commented that " Exit Through the Kwik @-@ E @-@ Mart " was " some[MASK]hat amusing and far more coher[MASK]nt than many recent episodes , but the satire is relatively mild . The episode cu[MASK]dles a bi[MASK] while looking for [MASK] sweet ending , but[MASK]it is otherwise solid enough . " Critics have pra[MASK]sed the opening s[MASK]quence that parodies Gam[MASK] of Thrones . Tim Surette of TV.com called it " one min[MASK]te of genius " , and MTV 's Brandon Freeberg wrote : " Congratulations are in order for Matt Groening and his staff for really knocking this one out of the park . " Jenna Busch of Zap2it and K[MASK]lly West of Cinema Blend , both fans of Ga[MASK]e of Thron[MASK]s , named the opening the best in the history of t[MASK][MASK] show [MASK] IGN 's Eric G[MASK]ldman commented : " Ah , The Simpsons . Always there for us [MASK][MASK]th clever / loving parody of something we all love . Such was the case last night ,[MASK]when the animated series opened with an epic opening credit se[MASK]uence that gave us the Spr[MASK]ngfield @-@ inspired version of[MASK]the terrific Game of Thrones credits . " 
 
 
 = [MASK]he Boat Race 2008 = 
 
 The 154th Boat Race took place on 29 March 2008 . Held annually , the event[MASK]is a side @-@ by @-@ side rowing ra[MASK]e between crews from the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge along the River Thames . Oxf[MASK]rd won the r[MASK]c[MASK] . Oxford '[MASK] crew[MASK]featured the oldest competitor in Boat Race history . The race took place in very difficult weather conditions [MASK] strong winds and heavy rain – resulting in the slowest winni[MASK]g time in over sixty years . Oxfor[MASK] won by six lengths , the largest margin of victory since the 2004[MASK]race . 
 Oxford 's Isis [MASK]eat Cambridge 's Gol[MASK]ie in the reserve race ,[MASK]while Oxford won the Women 's Bo[MASK]t [MASK]ace . 
 
 =[MASK]= Background = = 
 
 Th[MASK] Boat Race is a side @-@ by @-@ side rowin[MASK] competition between the University of Oxford ( sometimes [MASK]eferred [MASK]o as the "[MASK]D[MASK]rk Blues " ) and the University of Cambridge ( sometimes[MASK]referred to [MASK]s the " Light Blues " ) . First held in 1829 , the race takes place on the 4 @.@ 2 @-@ mile ( 6 @.@ 8 km ) Championship Course on the River Thames in southwest London [MASK] The rivalry is a major point of honour between th[MASK] two universit[MASK]es and followed throughou[MASK] the United Kingdom and broadcast worldwide . Cambridge went[MASK]into the race as reigning champions , having beaten Oxford by over a length [MASK]n the previous year 's r[MASK]ce and the [MASK]verall lead , with 79 victories to Oxford 's [MASK]3 . The race was spons[MASK]red by Xchanging for the fourth time . 
 The first Women 's Boat Race took place in 1927 , but did not become an annual fixtur[MASK] until the 196[MASK][MASK] . Until 2014 , the[MASK]contest was[MASK]conducted as part of the He[MASK]ley Boat Races , but as of the 201[MASK][MASK]r[MASK]ce , it is held on the River Thame[MASK] , on the same day as the men 's main and reserv[MASK] races . The reserve race , contested between Oxford 's Isis boat and Cambridge 's Goldie boat has been held since 1965 . It usually takes place on the Tideway , prior to the main Boat Race . 
 
 = = Crews = = 
 
 Oxford 's crew weighed an average[MASK]of 12 pounds ( 5 @.@ 4 kg ) more per rower than their opponents , and featured the oldest com[MASK]etitor in Boat Race history in 36 @-@ year @-@ old American Mik[MASK] Wherley . Cambridge crew consisted of six Britons , two Australians and an American , while Oxford 's comprised four Americans , three Britons , an Australian and a German . Both c[MASK]xes , Nick Brodie an[MASK] Rebecca Dowbiggin , were f[MASK]rmer Bl[MASK]es , while Cambridge also saw 30 @-@ year @-@ old Tom Edwards return , [MASK]aving rowed in 2006 .[MASK]Cambridge 's boat club president Dan O 'Shaughnessy was the seventh Light Blue president not to row in his own Blue Boat . 
 
 = = Race = = 
 
 Oxford were pre @-@ race favourites , but Cambridge won the toss and[MASK]elected to start from the Surrey station . Ox[MASK]ord took an early lead ,[MASK]but the boats closed on each[MASK]other , and Umpire John Gar[MASK]ett was forced to issue a number of warnings to both coxes in an attemp[MASK] to prevent a colli[MASK]ion . By Craven Cottage , Oxf[MASK]rd were nearly a length ahead and Cambridge responded ; by the time the crews passed under Hammersmith Bri[MASK]ge they were level . Along Chiswick Ey[MASK]t Oxford moved ahea[MASK] once ag[MASK]in , and were clear of Cambridge after 30 strokes . Oxford extended their lead to pass the finishing post in 20[MASK]m[MASK]nutes 53 seconds ,[MASK]six lengths and 2[MASK] seconds ahead of their opponents . Driving rain , strong winds and choppy water resulted in the [MASK]lowest winning time for over si[MASK]ty years , but the largest margin of victory since the 2004 race . 
 Oxford[MASK]'s Isis beat Cambridge 's Goldie by three @-@ and @-@ a @-@ quarter len[MASK]ths in the reserve race . Oxford won the 44[MASK]h running of the Women 's Bo[MASK]t Race by half a length . 
 
 = = Reaction = = 
 
 Oxford 's Oliver Moore s[MASK]id[MASK]" we got the rage going in the[MASK]crew , a[MASK]d w[MASK] started to kill it , we hit an awes[MASK]me rh[MASK]thm " . Cambridge coach Duncan Holland congratulated his opponents : " We[MASK]l d[MASK]ne to Oxford , they were much faster on the day " . Following tradition , the [MASK]ictorious Oxford crew tossed their c[MASK]x Brodie into the Thames . 
 
 
 = Fort Scott National Historic Site = 
 
 Fort Scott National Historic Site is a historical area under the control of the United States National Park Service in Bourbon County , Kansas [MASK] United States . Named after General Winfield Scott , who achieved renown during the Mexican @-@ Ameri[MASK]an War , during the middle of the 19th century the fort served as a military base for US Army action in what was the edge of settlement in 1850 . For the n[MASK]xt quarter century , it was used as a[MASK]su[MASK]ply base and to [MASK]rovide securi[MASK]y in turbulent areas during the opening of the West to settlement , a per[MASK]od which included Bleeding Kansas and the American Civil War . 
 The current national historic site protects 20 his[MASK][MASK]ric structures , a parade ground , and five acres ( 20 @,@ 000 m ² ) of restored tallgrass[MASK]prairie , inside the city of Fort Scott . It is open to visitors most days of the year . 
 
 = = History = = 
 
 In 1842 , Fort Scott was named after Winfield Scott , w[MASK]s established on t[MASK]e Am[MASK]rican frontier[MASK]on the military road in eastern Kansas between Fo[MASK]t Leavenworth [MASK]nd Fort Gibson . It was establis[MASK]ed to provide protection to the[MASK]rapidly increasing number of[MASK]settlers , who were migrating from the Eastern United States . Fort Scott became one of a chain[MASK]of forts intended to protect t[MASK]e new settlers from the Plains [MASK]ndians , as we[MASK]l as to protect the Indians from the settlers ' encroachment . 
 The United States government inte[MASK]tion to reserve permanent Indian lands west of the Miss[MASK]uri River gave way to the competition of settlers continuing to encroach on the Indian[MASK]settlements . Fort Scott[MASK][MASK]s most active days were between 1842 and 1853 , although it wa[MASK] also used during the Civil War . 
 
 = = = Army days = = = 
 
 The Cherokee of Indian Territory ( now Oklahoma ) were upset to have Fort Wayne in t[MASK]eir proximity . After some delay , the US Army decided to a[MASK]andon Fort Wayne and move its soldiers to a new f[MASK]rt to be built between F[MASK]rt Leaven[MASK]orth and the site . The Army both wanted to pl[MASK]cat[MASK] the Cherokee ( who were supervised by the Department of Defense ) and provide more defense for white[MASK]settlers and other Indians against the Osage , who had been conducting frequent raids in the area . On April 1 , 1842 , some soldiers of Fort Wa[MASK]ne left their fort and on Ap[MASK]il 22 arrived where Fort Scott would be built , in the Osage C[MASK]estas section of modern @-@ day Kansas[MASK]. After haggling with the Cherokees to acquire[MASK]t[MASK]e land , the r[MASK]st of Fort Wayne 's garrison left the[MASK]fort on May 26 and arrived at the Fort Scott site on May 30 . 
 Unlike most fort[MASK] for military use , the fort did not have[MASK]defensive walls or structures when first built ; the wi[MASK]e @-@ open ar[MASK]a and the avai[MASK]able artillery made an enclosed fort unnecessary . The s[MASK]ldiers concentrated on building structures for lodging the men , animals , and equipment . Thes[MASK] buildings were on the edges of a 350 @-@ foot ( 110 m ) parade ground . 
 The post quar[MASK]ermaster , Captain Thomas Swords , was in cha[MASK]ge of building Fort Scott 's structures , and had to deal with the problems of construction on the Kansas prairie , which had few trees . He had only two bricklayers and three carpente[MASK]s to re[MASK]y on , a[MASK] there were few civilians and most of [MASK]he soldiers had other duties to perform . Wood was available , but the mill was built 1 @.@ 5 miles ( 2 @.@ 4 km ) away [MASK] [MASK]aking transport time consuming . Swords found his efforts [MASK]lagued by lack of wood , skilled labor and working equipment . Freak accidents d[MASK]stroyed much of the wood intende[MASK] for the fort 's construction . As a result , only one duplex of the five planned officers quarters ( four duplexes and post commandant 's [MASK]ouse ) was built [MASK]y 1[MASK]44 , and the intended enlisted barracks were not co[MASK]pleted [MASK] In his 1844 inspection of the fort , Colonel [MASK]eorge Croghan reporte[MASK] that , in comparison to other frontier forts , he considered Fort Scott " above averag[MASK] " . 
 Due to the rising tensions that esca[MASK]ated in the Mexican @-@ American War , the US Army redeployed troops to the Southwest . With Fort Scott still [MASK]ncompleted , official[MASK] decided on April 25 , 1850 , that no more construction would be done there [MASK] after eight years and $ 35 @,@ 000 . By the time it [MASK]as finished , it was obsolete ; three years later , it was abandoned by the military in favor [MASK]f the more wes[MASK]ern Fort Riley . 
 For the average soldier , life at the fort was " monotonous " . Until the permanent structures were [MASK]uilt , soldiers h[MASK]d to live in tents , which lacked comfort . Aside from a few whiskey peddlers and prostitutes , few civilians lived[MASK]at the fort . Officers[MASK]had brought their personal slaves [MASK]ith them , including Captain Swords . Five miles [MASK]ast in Missouri w[MASK]s a grog sh[MASK]p that supplied soldiers , and qui[MASK]e a few [MASK]ourts @-@ martial followed soldiers ' going AWOL at the shop . The dese[MASK]tion rate from the fort ranged from 12 %[MASK]-16 [MASK] , [MASK]ue to boredom , irregular[MASK]pay , and hatred for military life . As no combat took place near the fort , it seemed more of a frontier village than a military base . Hunting was a popular pastime ; acco[MASK]ding to Captain Sword[MASK] , " wolf chasing and duck hunting " was the only way one officer could tolera[MASK]e the place . 
 
 = = = Bleeding Kansas = = = 
 
 Tw[MASK] years after the army abando[MASK]ed the fort , the buildings were sold by auction to civilians , with two being converted to hotels . In 1854 the Kansas @-@ Nebraska Act repea[MASK]ed the Missouri Compromise of 1820 , which had kept [MASK][MASK]avery out of Kansas . Missourians in [MASK]avor of slavery soon moved to Kansas to try to sway the vote of whether or [MASK]ot Kansas would permit slavery . Settlers from New England arrived equally determined to keep it out . Each of the two competing factions of the Bleeding Kansas conflict claimed one of the hotels at Fort [MASK]cott : Free @-@ Soil at the Fort Scott [MASK]otel and Pro @-@ Slavery at [MASK]he Western Hotel . Mos[MASK] of the residents in Fort Scott supported slavery , but those outside the town tended t[MASK] the free @-@ soil side . During this time ,[MASK]there were[MASK]local incidents of murder and attem[MASK]ted arson ,[MASK]typical element[MASK] of the [MASK]uerrilla conflicts that[MASK]were prevalent in the fighting . 
 
 = = = Army[MASK]re[MASK]urns = = =[MASK]
 
 During the American Civil War , the fort was rene[MASK]e[MASK] as a US military post . In August 1861 , the Union Army took command of Fort Scott , and readied it for the war times . The United States Army also took over severa[MASK] blocks within the t[MASK]wn fo[MASK] commis[MASK]ary and quartermas[MASK]er functions . The Union [MASK]rmy rented the properties from the current c[MASK]vilian owners . Troops from Indiana , Iowa , Colorado , Ohio , a[MASK]d Wisconsin would come to the f[MASK]rt , and either stayed by the fort , or traveled farther , to subjugate Missouri [MASK] Arkan[MASK]as , or the Indian Territory . Fort Scott was one of the few installations that re[MASK]ruite[MASK] and trained blac[MASK] soldiers for the United Sta[MASK]es Colored Troops of the Union Army . 
[MASK]A major supply depot was situated at the fort . Confe[MASK]erate general Sterlin[MASK] Price hoped to [MASK]apture the town , but the closest the Confederate force came to t[MASK]e garrison was 10 miles ( 16 km ) away at Battle of Dry W[MASK]od Creek . The site was strategically important as it was within a Southern @-@ sympathizing area and close t[MASK] the Confederate state of Arka[MASK]sas and the " unstable " Indian Territory ( present @-@ day state of Oklahoma ) , where[MASK]many of the members o[MASK] the Five Civilized Tribes were[MASK]allied with the Conf[MASK]derates . The fort served as a " general hospital " ( large military hospital ) and prison until after the war . Following the end of the war , in Oc[MASK]ober 1865 the US Army left the facilities [MASK]nd sold off by auction what they controlled . 
 On J[MASK]nuary 14 , 1870 , the Army returned with the formation of the Post of Southeast Kansa[MASK] . The Post was based at Fort Scott , but the [MASK]oldiers camped along the rail tracks , and sel[MASK]om used the original fort . They were sent to protect the railroad[MASK] and workers from settlers . Some of the latter feared that[MASK]the railroad , which had been awarded land for development by the US Government in rights @-@ of @-@ way , would evic[MASK] t[MASK]em from their squatter homes . The settlers considered the [MASK]roops lacke[MASK]s to the railroads , and lumped both as enemies . 
 Settlers also h[MASK]d some continuing conflicts with Indians and insurge[MASK]ts using the recent Confederate cause as excuse for robbery . By th[MASK] spring of 1873 , the[MASK]US Army withdrew the troops from Fort Scott for good . From 1873 to 1965 , the bu[MASK]ldings of the fort were l[MASK]ft unattended , and slowly deteriora[MASK]ed .[MASK]Many military buildings were razed and replaced with structures built for civilian use . 
 
 = = Modern times = = 
 
 With the Act of August 31 , 1965 , the National Park Service g[MASK]ve the city government of Fo[MASK]t [MASK]cott , Kansas the necessary funds and technical knowledge to restore the fort . 
 On October 19 , 1978 , Fort Scott became a National Historic Site under the supervision of the National Park Service , encompassing 17 acres ( 69[MASK]@,@ 000 m2 ) . Today the fort is open throug[MASK]out the year , sa[MASK]e for Thanksgiving , Christmas , and New Year[MASK] Day . Visitation has declined in recent years . In 2005 visitation [MASK]as 25 @,@ 528 ; in 2007 it was 22 @,@ 314 . 
 Surviving structures inc[MASK]ude four officers ' barracks , one dragoon 's barracks , two infantry bar[MASK]acks , a hospital ,[MASK]guardho[MASK]se , dragoon stables , ordnance[MASK]and post headquarters , quartermaster[MASK]stables , bake shop , fla[MASK]pole , and magazine . Another feature[MASK]of the park is 5 acres ( 2 @.@ 0 ha[MASK]) of ta[MASK]lgrass prair[MASK]e restored as part of an[MASK]ecology @-@ restoration pr[MASK]ject . 
 
 
 = Slammiversary [MASK] 2008 ) = 
 
 Slammiversary ( 2008 ) was a professional wrestling pay @-@ per @-@ view ( PPV [MASK] event produced by the Total Nonstop Action Wr[MASK]stling ( TNA ) promotion that took place on June 8 , 2008 a[MASK] t[MASK]e DeSoto Civic Center in Southaven , Mississippi . It wa[MASK] the fourth event under the Slammiversary name and the sixth event [MASK]n the 2008 [MASK]NA PPV schedule . Seven professional wrestling matches and one dark match were featured on the eve[MASK]t 's card , th[MASK]ee of which were for championships . The event commemorated TNA 's six year anniversary . 
 The main event was a King[MASK]of the Mountain match for the TNA World Heavyweight Championship , in which then @-@ champion Samoa Joe def[MASK]nded against Booker T , Christian Cage , [MASK]hino , and Robert Ro[MASK]de . Joe won the match to retain the title . The card also fea[MASK]ured a bout pitting A.J. Styles against Kurt Angle , whic[MASK] Styles wo[MASK] . The[MASK]TNA World Tag Team Championship was defended by The Latin A[MASK]erica[MASK] Xchang[MASK] ( Hernandez and Homicide ; LAX ) against Team [MASK]D ( Brother Devon a[MASK]d Brother Ray ) at the event . LAX was the victors in the contest to retain the championship . A Six Woman Tag Team [MASK]atch was won by the team of Gail [MASK]im , ODB , and Roxxi over The Beautifu[MASK] People ( Angelina Love and Velvet Sky ) and Moose on the unde[MASK]card . 
 Slammiversary is remembered for Joe being the first to retain a championship in a K[MASK]ng of the Mountain match . The reported fi[MASK]ure of purchasers for the event was 20 @,@ 000 , as reported by The Wrestling Observer New[MASK]letter . Slammiversary had an attendance of 2 @,[MASK] 000 people . Jon Waldman of the professional wrestling section of the Canadian Online Explorer [MASK]ated the show [MASK] 7 out of 10 , which was lower than the 8 out of 10 given to the 2007 ed[MASK]tion by Jason Clevett . After the event , an accident occurred which resulte[MASK] in the death of one man and the injury of anothe[MASK] .

 The m[MASK]in event was a King of the Mountain match for the TNA World Heavyweight[MASK]Championship with Kevin Nash as [MASK]pecial Guest Ringside Enforcer b[MASK]tween then @-@ champion Samoa Joe an[MASK] the challengers Booker T , Christian Cage , Rhino , and Robert R[MASK]ode . In a [MASK]ing of the Mountain ma[MASK]ch , the objective is to climb[MASK]a ladder and hang the championship belt on a hook above the ring . In o[MASK]der to do so , a wrestler mu[MASK]t first qualify by e[MASK]ther pinning or making anot[MASK]er wrestler submit in the match . A wrestler who is pinned or made to submit is this placed in a [MASK]enalty b[MASK]x for two minutes .[MASK]The match is fought under no disqualification rules . Booker[MASK]T wa[MASK] the first to qualify by pinni[MASK]g Rhino after[MASK]slamming him back[MASK]@-@ first int[MASK] [MASK]he mat with his signature B[MASK]ok End maneuver . [MASK]hino was this placed [MASK]n the penalty box[MASK]. Roode was the next to quali[MASK]y after bashing a ladd[MASK]r Cage held with a chair into him and following with a pin . Imm[MASK]diately afterwards , Rhino pinned Roode with a r[MASK]ll @-@ up pin to qualify . Later , Joe held Booker T in his signature Coquina[MASK]Clutch submission hold when Cage ascended a padde[MASK] turnbuckle and jumped off onto Booker T and Joe . He follo[MASK]ed by [MASK]inning Booker T to qualify and send Booker T to the penalty box . When Booker T w[MASK]s released from the box , he att[MASK]cked Nash with the title belt and then attempted to hang it . Nash stoppe[MASK] him [MASK]nd [MASK]he[MASK] dropped Booker T back @-@ first against the mat with his signatu[MASK]e Jackknife Powerbomb maneuver . Joe was the last to [MASK]ualify by pin[MASK]ing Roode after slam[MASK]ing him back and[MASK]neck @-@ first into[MASK]the[MASK]mat with his signature Muscle Buster maneuver . Joe then hung the title belt at 19 minutes and 49 seconds to win the competition . 
 
 [MASK] = Reception = =[MASK]
 
 A total of 2 @,@ 000 people attended Slamm[MASK]versary[MASK], while the The Wrestli[MASK]g Observer N[MASK]wsletter r[MASK]ported that 20 @,@ 000 peopl[MASK] bought the [MASK]vent . Canadian Online Explorer writer Jon Waldman rated the entire event a 7 out of 10 , which was lower than the 8 out of 10 gi[MASK]e[MASK] to the 2007 edition by Jason Clevett . The 7 out of 10 was the same rating given to the 2009 edition by Chris and Bryan Sokol . The previous PPV event Sacrific[MASK] and TNA 's next PPV e[MASK]ent Victory Road both received a 7 out of 10 by Chris Sokol an[MASK] Bob Kapur , respectively . Compared to rival World Wrestling E[MASK]tertainment 's ( WWE ) On[MASK] Night Stand PPV event on June 1 , both performed equally , as One Night Stand received the same rating from Matt Mackinder . [MASK] Wa[MASK][MASK]man felt that " TNA put on a stro[MASK]g PPV " that was in " l[MASK]rge part to little gimmickery . " Regarding the main even[MASK] ,[MASK]Waldman ga[MASK]e it a 6 out[MASK]of 10 , while th[MASK] World T[MASK]g Team Championship match recei[MASK]ed a 4 out of 10 . He gav[MASK] the Six Woman Tag Team match a 4 @.@ 5 out of[MASK]10 and the A.J. Styles versus Kurt Angle bout a 9 out of 10 . Th[MASK] X [MASK]ivision Championship contest was given a 7 out of 10 . 
 Wade Keller of the Pro Wrestling Torch Newsletter review[MASK]d the show . He felt the main event had " lots of action and [MASK]rama , " but that having to hang the belt on a hook does n[MASK]t make for a " particularly dramatic end to a match as it seems[MASK]l[MASK]ke someone hanging a pla[MASK]t in the corner " than " beating s[MASK]meone to win a fight . " Keller said the World Tag Team Championship contest was a " solid tag match " with some [MASK] e[MASK]aborate sequences " that were " well executed . " Keller stated that th[MASK] X Division Championship match was a " very good opener . " Regarding the Styles and Angle bout , Keller commented that [MASK]t was a "[MASK]good[MASK]match , but [MASK][MASK]ort of a classic must @-@ see match in part because there were to[MASK] many chinlocks mid @-@ match from Angle that took the crowd out of it . " 
 Jame[MASK] Caldwell , also of the Pro Wrestling [MASK]orch Newsletter , posted a review of the show in which he felt the main event was a " slow , plodding match " with an " anticlimacti[MASK] finish . " Caldwell stat[MASK]d that the Styles versus Angle contest was a [MASK] fine spotlight singles ma[MASK]ch , " but was a " bit underwhelmi[MASK]g when the expectations were reasonably high for two of TNA 's best wrestlers in a featured singles match . " He[MASK]went on to say that he felt it was " missing something " and that it " s[MASK]emed like the match just never moved out of[MASK]second gear . Caldwell felt the X Divisio[MASK] Championship bout was a " very go[MASK]d opening match , " which " could have been a fe[MASK]tured match to sell a few additional PPV buys , but TNA didn 't give the X Division any foc[MASK]s until the fi[MASK]al show before the PPV . " Caldwell stated the World Tag Tea[MASK] Championship was " just a slow , plodding tag match [MASK] " Regarding the marriage segment during the s[MASK]ow , Caldwell[MASK]said " it was just a bad , ba[MASK] , bad segment that died slowly and painfully in front of the live audience . " Overall , Caldwell felt that " TNA showcased the[MASK]X Division in the opening match , " b[MASK]t needed more " athleticism on the show to bal[MASK]nce the slow , plodding forme[MASK] WWE heavyweight wrestlers in the main [MASK]vent slots . " 
 
 = = Accident = = 
 
 After Slammi[MASK]ersary ended , crews began to disassemble the set used for the event . During this time , a man named Kevin " Angus " Sinex was removing a light ar[MASK]ay [MASK]hen the scaffolding he was positioned on collapsed , causing him to slam against the concrete floor below . He was rushed to the Baptist DeSoto Hospital in Southave[MASK] [MASK] Mississippi where he was pronounced dec[MASK]ased . Another worker named Paul Ma[MASK]tin was als[MASK] taken to t[MASK]e hospita[MASK] due to his thumb being cut off i[MASK] the incident . TNA released a statement regarding the inciden[MASK] the next day through their website . The June 12 episode of[MASK]Impact ! was ded[MASK]cated to Sinex , with a banner at the beginning of the show stating " In memory Kevin Sinex ( 1963 – 2008 ) " . A moment of silenc[MASK] was [MASK]eld prior to the Impact ! tapings after Slammiversary in honor of Sinex . 
 
 = = Aftermath = = 
 
 Severa[MASK] wrestlers were concerned with Kurt Angle 's health going into his Slammive[MASK]sary match with A.J. Styles . Despite the concerns , Angle appeared to be out of it after the contest but was expected to be alright . 
 Sa[MASK]oa J[MASK]e and Booker T started a rivalry[MASK]over the TNA World[MASK]Heavyweight Championship fol[MASK]owin[MASK] Slammive[MASK]sary . On the June 12 episod[MASK] of Im[MASK]act ! , Booker T claimed that Joe did not beat him at the event due to interference from Kevin Nash . This led to Nash stating that Joe could not beat Booker T in a one @-@ on @-@ one match later in the broadcast . After this segment , Joe announced t[MASK]at Booker T and he would face[MASK]at Victory Road on July [MASK]3 [MASK]or the title . On the [MASK]uly 10 episode of Impact ! , Sting proclaimed that he did not know which of the two would win at Victory Road , but that he would be there to watch . At the event , Joe beat Booker T till he was bloody , causing several referees and security per[MASK]o[MASK][MASK]el to try to stop him to no avail . He was stopped wh[MASK]n S[MASK]ing interfered i[MASK] the contest by bashing Joe with a baseball bat . Booker T then covered J[MASK]e for an unofficial pinfall victory [MASK]hat was counted by Booker T 's legitimate wife Sharmell[MASK]. The match result was ruled a no @-@ contest , with Joe retaining the title . 
 A.J. Styles was [MASK]oined by Christian Cage and Rhino in his feud with Kur[MASK] Angle , who was joined by Team 3D . Styles and Angle faced in a Lumberjack match on the June 12 episode [MASK]f Impact ! , which Angle won . Team 3D then injured bot[MASK] Cage and Rhino in the narrative , with Rhino being knocked out on the June 19 e[MASK]isod[MASK] of Impact[MASK]! , while on the June 26 episode of Impact ! Cage w[MASK]s slammed through a glass table by Brother Ray [MASK] Rhino returned from injury on the July 3 episode of Impact ! , chall[MASK]nging Team 3D and Angle [MASK]o a Six Man Tag Team match at Victory Road , while teasing at add[MASK]ng Full Metal Mayhem rules to the bout . An online poll was held to determine the stipulation f[MASK]r the match , resulting in Full Metal Mayh[MASK]m being chose[MASK] . The team of Angle an[MASK] Team 3D were the victors at the event . 
 After Slammiversary , Kaz went on to captain Team TN[MASK] in the 2008 TNA W[MASK]rld X Cup Tournament . He competed in a Four Way Ultimate X matc[MASK] at Victory Road as the final round of th[MASK] t[MASK]urnament . He was unsuccessful in winning the match[MASK]and gaining the appropriate points to win the tournament , thus causing Team TNA ( Kaz [MASK][MASK]Al[MASK]x Shelley , Chris Sabin , and Curry Man ) to finish in second place , with Team Mexico ( Averno [MASK] Rey Bucanero , Último Guerrero , an[MASK] Volador Jr . ) being the victors in point [MASK]ankings . 
 LAX feuded with James Storm and Robert Roode over the TN[MASK] World Tag Team Championship after Slammiversary . Roode and Storm[MASK]form[MASK]d[MASK]a team known as Beer[MASK]Money Incorporated and challenged LAX for the title on the J[MASK]ne 12 episode of Impact ! . The match was originally won by Roode and Storm before being[MASK]restarted due to interference . LAX won the restart to retain the championship . After the bout , [MASK]oode and Storm assaulted LAX and Héctor Guer[MASK]ero .[MASK]Management Director Jim Cornette scheduled a title defense at Victory Road between LAX and Roode and Storm under " Fan 's Revenge " Lumberjack rules on the June 19 episode of Impact ! . LAX were successful in defending the title at Victory Road .
