 = Home Made Mince Pie = 
 
 Home[MASK]Made M[MASK]nce Pie is a 1910 American silent short comedy produced by the Thanhouser Company . The film is a comedy of circumstances , in which the Gale[MASK]family is going to host a [MASK]inner . The focus of the humor is in a mince pie that brandy is added to in an attempt to make it more apprecia[MASK]le , but three[MASK]people each add brandy to the pie . Everyone becomes tipsy[MASK]upon eating the pie , including the family c[MASK]t , and the film concludes . No cas[MASK] or staff c[MASK]edits for this film are known[MASK]. The film was released [MASK]n September 27 , 1910 , to mixed reviews in trade publications . Reviewers mentioned [MASK]hat the fi[MASK]m[MASK]was too l[MASK]ng and it was unbelievable [MASK]hat one pie split [MASK]ight ways would be able to impact everyone . The film is presumed lost . 
 
 = = Plot = = 
 
 Tho[MASK]gh t[MASK]e film is presumed lo[MASK]t , a synopsis survives in[MASK]The Moving Picture World from Septemb[MASK]r 24 , 1910 . It states : " Life in a [MASK]ount[MASK]y town is often tedious and[MASK]tiresome , and were it not for the little d[MASK]nners and t[MASK]as the townsfolk are [MASK]onstantly [MASK]ive[MASK] , ex[MASK]stence in some[MASK]localities wo[MASK]ld b[MASK] a very dreary thing indeed . So the time honored get @-@ togethers of the small town are an established feature to the social calendar ; they are just as mu[MASK]h a matt[MASK]r of necessity and as such have come to stay . The Ga[MASK]es thought well of this estab[MASK]ished featur[MASK] . They made it a joyous occasion for themselves as well as their guests . They were hardly an overly wealthy family , and their table was never notable for an oversupply of the good things of life ,[MASK]but whenever they gave a dinner they[MASK]cast all thoughts of economy to the country winds and worked to the one end th[MASK]t their guests have a pleasant time . " 
 " On the night before such an event neither Mamma , Pappa , or Daughter Gale could get those minutes ' solid sleep f[MASK]r thought that t[MASK]ey might have overlooked some essential in the guests ' comfort . At the first crow of the rooster they would come [MASK]opping down to [MASK]he kitche[MASK] to get the larder into shape . S[MASK] little wonder that on [MASK]ccasion of the dinner here[MASK]pictur[MASK]d - when the prize dis[MASK] was a splendid homemade mince pie - the Gales were ever looking after the need of the said pie . F[MASK]rst Mamma Gale would tiptoe to the table w[MASK]ereupon it sat in solemn state , [MASK]nd give it [MASK] stir ; then Pappa Gale woul[MASK] tiptoe over and give it a stir ; finally Da[MASK]ghter Gale would have to come over and honor [MASK]t likewise . Then arrived the[MASK]guests . The Minister and the Mrs. Minister , they were , and some neighbors . W[MASK]ile she was rece[MASK]ving them the recollect[MASK]on came to Mamma Gale that the beloved mince pie had not received its flavorin[MASK] . Off s[MASK]e speeds to a decanter of whiskey in the kitchen . She pours into the pie the right proportion of liquor , and goes back to her guests . Then Pappa G[MASK]le remembers that the pie has not been flavored . He , too , excuses himself an[MASK] a moment later is found pouring whiskey into the sacred mince . No sooner has [MASK]e ceased and returned to his g[MASK]est than Daughter Gale , who has just remembered about [MASK]he forgotten flavoring , rushes in and makes for [MASK]he whiskey .[MASK]She pours ' the right proportion ' in , too . " 
 
 = = Production = = 
 
 The writer[MASK]of t[MASK]e scenario is unk[MASK]own , but it was [MASK]ost likely Lloyd Lonergan . He was an experienced newspaperman employed by The New York[MASK]Evening World while [MASK]riting scripts for the Tha[MASK]houser product[MASK]ons . The film director is unknown , but it may have been Barry O 'Neil . Film historian Q. David Bowers does not attribute a camer[MASK]man for t[MASK]is production[MASK], but at least two possible candidates exist . Blair Smith was the first cameraman of the Thanhouser c[MASK]mpany , but he was soon joine[MASK] by Carl Louis Gregory who had y[MASK]ars of experien[MASK]e as a st[MASK]ll and motion picture photographer . The role of the cameraman was uncredited in 1910 productions . The cast credits are unknown[MASK], but many 1910[MASK]Th[MASK]nhouser productions are fragmentary . In late 1910 , the Thanh[MASK]user c[MASK]mpany released a list of the important personalities in their films . The list include[MASK] G.W. Abbe , Justus D. Barnes , Frank H. Crane , Irene Crane , Marie Eline , Violet Heming , Martin J. Faust , Thomas Fortune , George Middleton , Grace Moore , John W. Noble , Anna Rosemond , Mrs. George Walters . A surviving film still gives the possibility of identifying eight actor[MASK] . 
 
 = = Release and recepti[MASK]n = = 
 
 The single reel comedy , approximately 1 @,@ 000 feet long ,[MASK]was released on September 27 , 1910 . The film likely had [MASK] wide national release , with advertisements i[MASK] theaters known in Indiana , Kansas , Wisconsin , and Pennsylvania . The film wou[MASK]d also b[MASK] shown in Vancouver , Canada and was met with praise by t[MASK]e audie[MASK]ce at the Province Theatre . In 1917 [MASK] years after the film 's release , the film was approved without censorship by the Pennsylvania State Board of Censors of Moving Pictures .[MASK]
 The The Moving Picture Wo[MASK]ld reviewer found the subject to be too long , but did no[MASK] find it to be a fault . The reviewer states , " A domestic co[MASK]edy with a differ[MASK]nt flavor . In fact ,[MASK]with a mince pie for a basis the flavor comes to resemble brandy very st[MASK]ongly by the time that the[MASK]cook , the maid and the mistress of th[MASK] house and her daughte[MASK] have added the pro[MASK]er proportion of flavoring , neither one knowing that the[MASK]others have done lik[MASK]wise . The humor in this piece centers around this pie . What happened to the guests who partook of it certainly draws upon the [MASK]magina[MASK]ion . Imagine eight people [MASK] not to speak of the cat , getting drunk on the brandy in one mi[MASK]ce pie ! ... We do not single out this subject as bei[MASK]g m[MASK]re[MASK]eviden[MASK]ly padded than others shown on the screen this week . Licensed as well as Independents were guilty[MASK]and it [MASK]s time that the manuf[MASK]cturers realize the importance of the scenario end of matters . The [MASK]ince pie episode was well done[MASK], which is the faint praise that we do [MASK]ot like to mete out to an[MASK]one . " Walton of The Moving Picture News was not amused by t[MASK]e plot and stated , "[MASK]To me the last scene had no humor . It was only[MASK]the necessary ending to the beginning . Tr[MASK]e humor does not emanate from cognac . " The N[MASK]w York Dramatic Mirror stated , " This is the old story of too[MASK]many cooks , and it is quite funny after the first s[MASK]enes are out of the way . The early part of the film takes too much time with trivial details l[MASK]ading up to the final situation . ... A weak point [MASK]n the story is the fact t[MASK]at the pie is cut into eight small pieces , making it difficult to believe in its remarkable power . Two pies would have been as easy to make as one and would have been mor[MASK] convincing . The character parts are all we[MASK]l taken , although the cook would have been better if she had not seized so many opportunities to [MASK]alk directly at the camera . " 
 
 
 = Back Off Boogaloo = 
 
[MASK]" Back Of[MASK] Boog[MASK]loo " is a song by English m[MASK]sician Ringo Star[MASK] , released as a non @-@ album single [MASK]n March 1972 . Starr 's former Beat[MASK]es bandmate George Harrison produced the recording , which took place in London shortly a[MASK]ter the two had app[MASK]ared t[MASK]gether at Harrison 's Concert for Bangladesh shows in August 1971 . The single was a follow @-@ up to Starr 's 1971[MASK]hit song " It Don 't Come Easy " and continued his successful run as a solo artist . " Back Off Boogaloo " peaked at number 2 in Britain and Canada , and number 9 on America 's Billboard Hot 100 . It remains Starr 's highest @-@ charting single in the United Kingdom . 
[MASK]The title [MASK]or the song was in[MASK]pired by English singer @-@ songwriter Marc Bolan . Some comment[MASK]tors[MASK]have suggested that the lyrics were directed at Paul McCartney , reflecting Starr 's disdain for the mu[MASK]ic M[MASK]Cartney had made as a solo artist over[MASK]the previous two ye[MASK]rs . " Back Off Boogaloo " demonstrates the influence of glam rock on Starr , who directed a documentary film , Born to Boogie ( 1972 ) ,[MASK]about Bolan 's [MASK]and T. Re[MASK] around this time . Described b[MASK] one author as a " high @-@ energy [MASK]n @-@ your @-@ face rocker " , the son[MASK] features a prominent slide guitar pa[MASK]t by Harrison and contributions from musicians Gary Wright and Klaus Voormann . 
 Starr re @-@ recorded " Back Off B[MASK]ogaloo " f[MASK]r his 1981 album Stop and Smell the Roses , in a collaboration with American singer Harry Nilsson that incorporates lyrics from Beatles songs such as " With [MASK] Little Help from My Friends " , " Good Day Sunshine " and " Baby , You 're a Rich Man " . The original version [MASK]as appeared on Starr 's compilation albums Blast from Your Past and Photograph [MASK] The Very Best of Ringo Starr , [MASK]nd[MASK]as a bonus track on his remastered 1974 studio[MASK]album Goodnight Vienna [MASK] Since his return[MASK]to touring in 198[MASK] , S[MASK]arr [MASK]as performed " Back Off Boogaloo " regularly in concert with the various incarnations of his All @-@ Starr Band . 
 
 = = Background and composi[MASK]ion = = 
 
 Ringo[MASK]Starr identified his initial ins[MASK]iration for " Back Off Boogaloo " as having come from Marc Bol[MASK]n , the singer and guitarist with English glam r[MASK]ck[MASK]band T. Rex . In a 2001 interview with Mojo editor Paul Du Noye[MASK] , Starr described Bolan as [MASK] a dear friend who used to come into the office when I was running Apple Movies , a bi[MASK] offi[MASK]e in town , and the hang @-@ o[MASK]t for myself , Harry Nilsson[MASK]and Keith Moon " . Over dinner one evening at [MASK]tarr 's home outsi[MASK]e London , Bolan had used the word " boogaloo " so often th[MASK]t it stuck in Starr 's mind , after which the bea[MASK] and melody for the song [MASK]ame to him overnight . When discussing the composit[MASK]on on VH1 Storytellers in May 1998 , Starr explained : " [ Bolan ] was an energised guy . He used to speak : ' Back off boog[MASK]loo ... ooh you , boogaloo . ' ' Do you want some potatoes ? ' ' Ooh you , [MASK]oogaloo ! ' " Starr a[MASK]so recalled having to take the batteries out of his children 's toys that night , in order to power a tape recorder and m[MASK]ke a recording of the new song . 
 The lyrics to the middle eight of " Back Off Boo[MASK]aloo " came to Starr while watching London Weekend Television 's[MASK]foot[MASK]all show , The Big Match . The program 's host , Jimmy Hill , ofte[MASK] referred to a footballer 's pl[MASK][MASK]ing as " tasty " , a catchphrase that [MASK]tar[MASK] incorporated into his song lyrics : 
 Get yourself together now 
 And give me something tasty 
 Everything you try to do 
 You know it sure sounds wasted . 
 [MASK]ommentators have interpreted th[MASK] [MASK]ong , and particularly this statement , as an attack by Starr on his former[MASK]Beatles bandmate Paul McCartney . Starr has denied any such interpretation , instead " claiming that the song was inspired by Bolan and nothing more " , Beatles biogra[MASK][MASK]er Robert Rodriguez writes . Starr had [MASK]ublicly criticised M[MASK]Cartney 's solo alb[MASK]ms Mc[MASK]artney ( 1970 ) an[MASK] Ram ( 1[MASK]71 ) on release , and author B[MASK]uce Spizer paraphrase[MASK] the message of the [MASK]iddle ei[MASK]ht as " a plea for Paul to [MASK]roduce better music " . The mention of " sound [ [MASK]ng ] wasted " could also be a reference to McCartney 's overindulgence[MASK]with cannabis , Rodriguez suggests . A further example of Starr 's allegedly anti @-@ McCartney message exists in the song[MASK]'s first verse : 
 Wake up , meathead 
 Don 't pretend that [MASK]ou are dead 
 Get yourself up off the cart . 
 The same commentators suggest t[MASK]at here Starr could be ref[MASK]rri[MASK]g to the 1969 " Paul Is Dead " hoax . The latter rumour circulated during September and October of that year while McCartney hid away on his S[MASK]ottish farm , disconsolate after John Lennon had told him and Starr that he [MASK]anted a " divorce " fr[MASK]m[MASK]the Beatles . 
 In addition to these sup[MASK]osed m[MASK]ssages in " Back Off Boogaloo " , observers have viewed the song title as Starr 's rebuke to McCartney to abandon his legal stand against the Bea[MASK]les and Apple Corps , which[MASK]was placed in receivership in March 1971 after a High Court judge found in M[MASK]Cartney 's favour . Author Keith [MASK]adman writes that " Boogaloo " had " long been cited as Paul 's nickname " from his former bandmates Starr , Lennon and George Harrison . While acknowledging that [MASK]n subsequent years Starr might have chosen to minimise any ill @-@ feeling towards McCartney , Rodriguez notes that the lyrics " just ha[MASK]pened to fit[MASK]perfectly into the ' us vs. Paul ' minds[MASK]t " following the Beatles ' b[MASK]eak @-@ up , to the extent that " Back Off Boogaloo " was " as damning as ' Early 1970 ' had been conciliatory " . When tailoring his 1970 composition " I 'm the[MASK]Greatest " for Starr to record on the album Ringo ( 1973 ) , Lennon referenced the song ti[MASK]le w[MASK]th the lines " Now I 'm only thirty @-@ two / And all I want to do is boogaloo " . 
 Although " T Rex devotees " , in the words of Starr biographer Alan C[MASK]ayson , claimed that Bolan had ghost @-@ written " Back Off Boogaloo [MASK] , Starr later acknowledged that Harrison co @-@ wrote the song by adding some chords and finishing the melody . As on Starr 's 1971 [MASK]it single " It Don 't Come Easy " , Harrison was not credited for his song[MASK]riting cont[MASK]ibution . Starr origi[MASK]a[MASK]ly offered " Back Off Boogaloo " to fello[MASK] Liverpudlian Cilla Black to record , but she declined , hoping instead to record[MASK]another new Starr – Harrison composition , " Photograph " . 
 
 = = Recording = = 
 
 Having earmarked the song as his next single [MASK] Starr recorded "[MASK]Back O[MASK]f Boogaloo " in September 1971 , following his a[MASK]pearance at the Harrison @-@ organised Concert for Bangladesh in New York . The sessions took place at Apple S[MASK]udio in central Lo[MASK]don , with Harrison producing , as he had on " It Don 't Come Easy " . The recording reflects the influence of glam rock on Starr through what [MASK]uthors Chip Madinger and Mark Easter term [MASK] its big drum sound and repetitious nature " , with a line @-@ up comprising Starr ( vocals , drums , percussion ) , Harriso[MASK] ( guitars ) , Gary Wright ( piano ) and Klau[MASK] Voormann ( bass , saxophone ) . 
 Rodriguez describes Starr 's " martial @-@ sounding opening " [MASK]s a rare " showcase f[MASK]r his own drumming " , while Harrison biographer Sim[MASK]n Leng writes of " a roaring series of Ha[MASK]rison slide breaks that brought to mind Duane Allman " . Further overdubs included contributions from[MASK]thre[MASK] backing vocalists , led by American soul [MASK]inger Madeline Bell . 
 
 [MASK] = = " Blindman " = = =[MASK]
 
 For the single 's B @-@ side , Starr had already written and recorded " Bli[MASK]dman " , the theme song for th[MASK] Ferdinando Baldi @-@ directed Spaghetti Western of the same name , filming for which Starr had interrupted in order to perform at the Concert for Bangladesh . Starr produced the track with Voormann . The sess[MASK]ons for " Blindman [MASK] took place at Apple on 18 – 19 August , with Badfinger guitarist Pete Ham assisting Starr and Voo[MASK]mann . Like the film Blindman ( 1971 ) , the so[MASK]g i[MASK] held in low re[MASK]ard by critics ; Spizer describes it as " a muddy @-@ sounding dirge with little to recomme[MASK]d " . 
 
 = = Release an[MASK] reception = = 
 
 Apple Records issued the single on 17 March 1972 in Britain , as Apple R 5944 , with a US release taking place three days later , as Apple 1849 . It w[MASK]s Starr 's first release since " It Don 't Come Easy " , a year be[MASK]ore . During this period , his priority had been to develop a career as an actor in films suc[MASK] as 200 Motels ( 1971 ) [MASK]nd Blindman . Further aligning [MASK]imself [MASK]it[MASK] Britain 's glam rock movement , Starr ma[MASK]e his directorial debut with Born[MASK]to Boogie ([MASK]1972 ) , a film starring Bolan that included Starr 's footage of a T. Rex concert held at W[MASK]m[MASK]ley on 18 March . With " Back Off Boogaloo " , NME cr[MASK]tic Bob Woffinden noted Starr 's success in esta[MASK]lishing [MASK]imself in [MASK]he two years since the Beatles '[MASK]break @-@ up , and wrote that the single " confirmed that he and Harrison [MASK] dark horses both , were the ones [MASK]ho had managed their solo careers more purposefully and i[MASK]telligently " compared with McCartney and Lennon . 
 The song was a hit in the US , reaching number 9 o[MASK] the Billboard[MASK]Hot 100 [MASK] a[MASK]d achieved Starr 's best position on [MASK]he UK Singles Chart[MASK],[MASK]where it reached number 2 . A promotional video for " B[MASK]ck Off B[MASK]ogaloo " was shot on 20 [MASK]arch at Lennon 's Tittenhurst P[MASK][MASK]k residence while Starr was looking after t[MASK]e property . The video , whi[MASK]h shows Starr walking around an outdoor structure and followed by[MASK]a Frankenstein @-@ like[MASK]monster , was direct[MASK]d by[MASK]Tom Taylor and financed by Caravel Films . A simil[MASK]r monster appeared on the single 's picture sleeve , holding a cigarette . 
 Alan Cl[MASK]yson writes of reviewers criticising " Back Off Boogaloo " for being repetitious , leading Starr to respond in a 1973 interview : " Play me a po[MASK] song that isn 't . " On release , Chris Welch wrote in Melody Maker : " A Number One hit could easily be in store for the maestro of rock drums . There 's a touch of the Marc Bolans in this highly playable rhythmic excursion ... It 's hypnotic and effect[MASK]ve , ideal for jukeboxes and liable to send us all mad by the end[MASK]of the week . " Woffinden described the single as " every bit as ebull[MASK]ent " as[MASK]" It Don 't Co[MASK]e Easy "[MASK], although " slightly inferior " , while Mike DeG[MASK]gne of AllMusic views it as a son[MASK] where " [ [MASK] ][MASK]he [MASK]ovial spirit of Ringo Starr shines through " . In a 1974 article for the NME , Char[MASK]es Shaar Murray highlighted " Back Off Boogaloo " as a " great radio and juke @-@ box tu[MASK]e " . 
 Among Beatle b[MASK]ographers[MASK], Simon Leng terms it " a rocking , soccer[MASK]crowd chant that suited Sta[MASK]r 's talents well " , and Bruce Spizer praises the track as a " high @-@ energy in @-@ your @-@ face rocker [MASK]ropelled by R[MASK]ngo 's thundering drums and George 's stinging slide guitar " . In the[MASK]2005 publ[MASK]cation NME Originals : Beatles – The Solo Years 1970 – 1980 , Paul Moody listed " Back Off Bo[MASK]ga[MASK]oo " first among Starr 's " ten solo gems " and described it as " Good time rock 'n'droll to match the Faces " . Guitar World editor Damian Fanelli includes the song on his list of Harrison 's ten best post @-@ Beatles " Guitar[MASK]Moments " , saying of the recording : " the main event is clearly Harrison 's slightly wild , wacky – and very bouncy – slide guitar solo , which includes an alternate melody line that 's even catchier than the melody Ringo is singing . " 
 Re @-@ relea[MASK]es for " Back O[MASK]f Boogaloo " include Starr 's 1975 greatest hits al[MASK]um , Blast from Your Past , and , along with " Blindman " , as a bonus track on the 1992 reissue of his [MASK]oodnight [MASK]ienna album ( 1974 ) . " Back Off Boogaloo " also appeared on his 2007 compilation Photograph : The Very Best of Ringo Starr , the collector 's edition of which included his 1972 video for the song . 
 
 = = Stop and Smell the R[MASK]ses vers[MASK]on = = 
 
 Starr recorded a new version of " Back[MASK]Off Booga[MASK]oo " for his 1981 album on Boardwalk Records , Stop and Smell the Roses . The son[MASK] was produced by Starr 's friend , singer Harry Nilsson , and features a musical arrangement by Van Dyke Parks .[MASK]Similar to Nilsson 's 1968 cover of the Beatles ' " You Can 't Do That " , the remake incorporates lyri[MASK]s from a number of the band 's songs – in this case , " With [MASK] Little Hel[MASK] from My Friends " , " Help[MASK]! " , " Lady Madonna " , "[MASK]Good Day Sunshine " and " Baby , You 're[MASK]a Rich Man " , as well as Star[MASK] 's " It D[MASK]n 't Come Easy " . In [MASK] further reference to his past , the 1981 vers[MASK]on of " Back Off Boogaloo " opens with the same guitar riff that Harri[MASK]on had played on " It Do[MASK] 't Come Easy " ten years before[MASK]. [MASK] [MASK][MASK]arr taped the basic tr[MASK]ck at Evergre[MASK]n Recording Studios in Los Angeles on 4 November 1980 , with additional [MASK]ecording taking place on 1 – 5[MASK]De[MASK]em[MASK]er at Nassau 's[MASK]Compass Point Studios . Among the large cast of musicians supporting Starr were Nilsson ( vocals ) , Jim Keltner ( drums ) , Jane Getz ( pia[MASK]o ) , D[MASK]nnis Budimir and Richie Zito ( guitars ) , and a four @-@ piece horn se[MASK]tion led by saxophonist Jerry Jumonville . 
 Starr overdubbed his vocals on 4 December , four days before the murder of John Lennon , who had been due to record his [MASK]ontributions to Stop and Smell the Roses in January 1981 . Contrasting with his success[MASK]as a solo artist in 1971 – 73 , the album continued Starr 's run of commercial and criti[MASK]al failu[MASK]es since 1976 ; Rodrig[MASK]ez writes that " [ m ] ost people eithe[MASK] love or hate the revamping " of " Ba[MASK]k Off Boogaloo[MASK]" . 
 
 =[MASK]= Live performance = = 
 
 Starr has performed " Back Off Boogaloo " in co[MASK]cert with his All @-@ Starr Band[MASK], beginning with the band 's de[MASK]ut tour of Nort[MASK] America in July – September 1989 . The song was dropped from the concert setlist early in that tour , however , in favour[MASK]of the 1963 Lennon – McCartney composition " I Wanna Be Your Man " . Live versions of " Back Off Boogaloo " have appeared on the multi @-@ disc compilation The Anthology ... So Far ( 2001 ) and King Bisc[MASK]it Flower Hour Presents Ringo & His New All @[MASK]@ Starr Band ( 2002 ) . The latter version [MASK]as recorded during a US tour in August 2001 , at which point the All @-@ Starr line @-@ up [MASK]as Starr ( vocals ) , Mark Rivera ( saxophone ) , Ian Hunter ( guitar ) , Roger Hodgson and Howard Jones ([MASK]keyboards ) , Greg Lake ( [MASK]ass ) and Sheila E. ( drums ) .[MASK]
 Starr also played the song live with Ringo and the Roundheads , a band he formed to promote h[MASK]s 1998 studio album Vertical Man . A version recorded on 13 May that year at Sony Music Studios , New York , appeared on Star[MASK] [MASK]s VH1 Storyteller[MASK] live album and video , r[MASK]leased in[MASK]October 1998 . Th[MASK] personnel on this performance included Starr ( vocals ) , Joe Walsh and Mark [MASK]udson ( guitars ) , Jack Blades ( bass ) and Simon Kirke ( drums ) . Another live version with the Roundheads , recorded for PBS Tel[MASK]vision 's Soundstage in August 2005 , was issued on Ringo Starr : Live at Soundstage ([MASK]2007 ) .

 The following musicians played on the original version of " Back Off Boogaloo " :

 = =[MASK]Chart [MASK]erfo[MASK]mance = = 
 
 
 
 = Where the Streets Have No Name = 
 
 " Where the Streets Have No Name " is a song by I[MASK]ish r[MASK]ck band U2 . It is the opening track from their 1987 album The Joshua Tree and was r[MASK]leased as the album 's third single in August 1987 . The song[MASK]'s hook is a repeating guitar arpeggio using a delay effec[MASK] , played during the song 's introduction and[MASK]again at the end . Lead vocalist[MASK]Bono wrote the lyrics[MASK]in response to the notion that it is [MASK]ossible to identify a person 's religion and income based on the street on which they lived , particularly in Belfast . During the band 's di[MASK]ficulties recording the song , producer Brian Eno considered erasing the s[MASK]ng 's tapes to have them start from scratch . 
 " Where the Streets Have No Name " was praised by c[MASK]itics a[MASK]d became a commercial success , peaking at number thirteen in the US , number fourteen in [MASK]anada , number ten in the[MASK]Net[MASK]erlands , and number four in the United Kingdom . The song has remained a staple of their live act since the song debuted in 1987 on The Joshua Tree Tour . The song was[MASK]performed on a Los Angeles rooftop for the filming of its[MASK]music video , which won a Grammy Award for Best Performance Music Video . 
 
 = = Writing and recording = = 
 
 The music for " Where the Streets Have N[MASK] Name " originated from a demo that guitarist The Edge composed the night before the group resumed The Joshua Tree sessions . In[MASK]an upstairs room at Melbeach House — his newly purch[MASK]sed home — The Edge used[MASK]a[MASK]four @-@ track tape machine to reco[MASK]d an arrangement[MASK]of ke[MASK]boards , b[MASK]ss , gui[MASK]ar , and a drum machine[MASK]. Realising t[MASK]at the album sessions we[MASK]e approaching th[MASK] end and that the band wer[MASK] short on exceptional live son[MASK]s [MASK] The Edge wanted to " conjure up the ultimate U2 live @-@ song " , so he imagined what he would like to hear at a future U2 show if he were a fan . After finishing the rough mix , he felt he had come up with " the most amazing[MASK]guitar part and song of [ hi[MASK] ] life " . With no one in the house to share the d[MASK]mo[MASK]with , The E[MASK]ge recalls dancing around and punching the air in celebration . 
 Although the band liked the demo , it was difficult for them to record the song . Bassist Adam Clayton said [MASK] " At the time it sounded like a foreign language , whereas now we understand how it works " . The arrangement , w[MASK]th two time signatu[MASK]e shifts and frequent chord changes , w[MASK]s rehear[MASK]ed many times , but the group struggled to get a pe[MASK]formance they liked . According to co @-@ producer Daniel Lanois , " that was the science project song [MASK] I remember having this massive schoolhouse blackboard [MASK][MASK]as we call them . I was holding a poi[MASK]ter , like a college professor , walking the band through the chord changes like a fucking nerd . It wa[MASK] ri[MASK]iculous . " Co @-@ producer Brian Eno est[MASK]mates that half of the album sessions were spent tr[MASK][MASK]ng t[MASK] record a suitable version of " Where the Streets Have No Name " . The band[MASK]worked on a [MASK]ingle take for weeks , but as Eno explained , that particul[MASK]r ver[MASK]ion[MASK]had a lot of p[MASK]oblems wi[MASK]h it and the group cont[MASK]nued trying to [MASK]ix it up . Through [MASK]ll of their work , they had gradual[MASK]y replaced each instrument take until [MASK][MASK][MASK]hing remained from the original performance . 
 So much time had be[MASK]n spent on " screwdriver work " that Eno tho[MASK]ght it would be best to start fr[MASK]m scratch . His idea was to " stage an accident " and have the s[MASK]ng 's tapes erased . He said that this was [MASK]ot to force abando[MASK]ment of the song , but rather that it would be more effect[MASK]ve to start again with a fresh performance . At one point , Eno had the ta[MASK]es[MASK]cued up and re[MASK]dy [MASK]o be r[MASK]corded over , but this erasure never took place[MASK]; according to engineer Flood [MASK][MASK]fellow engineer Pat McCarthy returne[MASK] to the [MASK]ontrol room and upon seeing Eno ready to erase the[MASK]tapes , dropped the tray of tea he was carrying and physically restrained Eno . 
 The studio version of the[MASK]song was compiled [MASK]rom several different takes . It was one of several songs mixed by S[MASK]eve Lillywhite in the final months of recordin[MASK] [MASK]he Joshua Tree . Drummer Larry Mullen , Jr. later said of the song , " It took so long to get that s[MASK]ng righ[MASK] , it was difficult for us to make any[MASK]sense of it .[MASK]It only became a truly great song through playing live . On the record , mu[MASK]ically , it 's not half the song i[MASK] is live . " 
 
 = = Composition = = 
 
 " Where the Streets Have No Name " is played at a tempo of 126 beats per minute . The introduction and[MASK]outro are played in a 3 / 4 time signature , while the remainder of the song is in a common 4 / 4 sign[MASK]ture .[MASK][MASK]he songs opens with an instrumental section , starting with chorale[MASK]@-@ like sustained synthesiser notes [MASK] The guitar fades in after 42 seconds ; this part consists of a repeated " chiming " six @-@ note ar[MASK]eggio . A " dotted eighth " delay effect is used[MASK]to [MASK] play " each note in the arpeggio twice , thus creating a rich sound . The bass and drums enter at 1 : 10 . 
 The introduction , following a I – IV – I – IV – vi – V – I chord progression , creates a " wall of sound "[MASK], as desc[MASK]ibed[MASK]by Ma[MASK]k Butler , against which the vocals emerge after nearly two minutes . The guitar part played for the remainder [MASK]f t[MASK]e song features The Edge strumming percussive sixteenth notes . The bass and drums contin[MASK]e in regular eighth and sixteenth notes , respectively , while Bono 's vocal performance , in con[MASK]rast , varies greatly in its ti[MASK]bre , ( " he sighs ; he moans ; he grunts ; he exh[MASK]les audibly ; he allows his voice to [MASK]rack " ) as well as timing by his usage of r[MASK]bato to slightl[MASK][MASK]off[MASK]et the notes he sings from the beat [MASK] 
 This develo[MASK]ment reaches a climax during[MASK]the first chorus at the line " burning down love " ( A – G – F ♯ – D ) ; the melody progresses through a series of scale degrees that lead to the highest not[MASK] in[MASK]the song , the A4[MASK]at[MASK]" burning " . In later choruses , Bono sings " blown by the wind " with the[MASK]same melody , stretching the same note even longer . After the third chorus , the song 's outro is played , the instrumentat[MASK]on revert[MASK]ng to the same state as it was in the introduction , with a six @-@ n[MASK]te guitar arpeggio [MASK]layed against sustained synthesiser notes . 
 
 = = Lyrics = = 
 
 The lyrics were inspired by a story that Bono heard about the streets of Belf[MASK]st , Northern Ireland , [MASK]here a person 's reli[MASK]ion and income are evident by the street they live on . He contra[MASK]ted this with the anonymity he felt [MASK]hen visiting Ethiopia , saying[MASK]: " ... the g[MASK]y in[MASK]the song recognizes this contrast a[MASK]d thinks ab[MASK]ut [MASK] world where there aren 't such division[MASK] , a place where the streets have no name . To me , that 's the way a great rock ' n ' roll concert should be : a place where everyone [MASK]omes t[MASK]gether ... Maybe that 's the dream of all art : to break down the barriers and the divisions between people and touch upon the things that matter the most to us all . " Bono wr[MASK]te the lyrics while on a humanitarian v[MASK]si[MASK] [MASK]o Ethiopia with his wife , Ali Hewson ; he first wrote them down on an airsickness bag while staying in a village . 
 According to him , the song is ostensibly about " Transcendence , elevation , [MASK]hatever you want to call it . " Bono , w[MASK]o compared many of hi[MASK] lyric[MASK] prior to The Josh[MASK]a Tree to " sketches " , said that " '[MASK]Whe[MASK]e the Streets Have No Name ' is more like the U2 of old than a[MASK]y of the other songs[MASK]on the LP , because it 's a sketch — I was just trying to sketch [MASK] location , [MASK]aybe a spiritual location , maybe a roman[MASK]ic location . I was trying to sketch a fe[MASK]ling . " 
 The open @-@ en[MASK]ed nature of the lyrics has led to many interpretat[MASK]ons . Journalist Michael Campbell believed the lyrics send[MASK]" a message of hope " and wish for a " world that is not divided by c[MASK]ass , wealth , race , or any other arbitrary criterion " . With regard to the place Bono was referring to in the song , he said , " I 'm not sure , really , about that . I used to think it w[MASK]s Belfast ... " Journalist Niall Stokes believes the title was influenced by Bono 's and his wife Ali 's visit to Ethiopia as volunteer aid @-@ workers . Bono has expressed mixed opinions about the op[MASK]n @-@ ended lyric[MASK] : " I can look at it now and recognize that [ the song ] has one of the most banal couplets in the history of pop music . But it also contains some of the biggest ideas . In a curious way , that seems to work . If you get[MASK]any way heavy about these things , you don 't communicate . But if you 're flip or throwaway about it , [MASK]hen you do . That 's one of the paradox[MASK]s I 've come[MASK]to terms with . " 
 
 = = Release = = 
 
 Originally , the third si[MASK]gle from The Joshua Tree was meant to be the song " Red Hill Mining T[MASK]wn " , but " Where the Streets Have No Name " w[MASK]s released inste[MASK]d ,[MASK]in August 1987 . The single was released on 7 @-@ inch , 12 @-@ inch , cassette and CD single formats . Three B @-@ sides were featured [MASK]n the single , incl[MASK]din[MASK] " Race Against Time " , " Silver and Go[MASK]d " , and " Sweetest Thing [MASK] , exce[MASK]t for the 7 @-@ inch release , w[MASK]ich only featured the latter [MASK]wo tracks . The 12 @-@ inch single featured " Race Against Time " on side[MASK]A of the record ( despite being a " B @-@ side " ) , and the cassette single featured all four tracks on both sides of the tape . Although not as successful as the album 's first two singles , the song did chart well . In the U.S. , [MASK]he song peaked at number 13 on the Billboard Hot 100 and number 11 on the Album [MASK]ock Tracks charts . The s[MASK]ng reached number four on the UK Singles Chart ,[MASK]and it topped the Irish Singles[MASK]Chart . 
 
 = [MASK] = Music video [MASK] = = 
 [MASK] The video begins with an a[MASK]rial [MASK]hot of a block in Los Angeles , and clips of radio broadcasts are heard with[MASK]disc jockeys stating that U2 is planning on performing a concert downtown and expecting crowds of 30 @,@ 000 people . Police show up to the set and inform the band 's crew of the security issue that the film shoot is causing , due to the large number of people who are coming to watch the performance . Two minutes into the video , U2 are seen on the roof of a liquor store[MASK]at the corner of 7th Ave. and [MASK]. Main St. , and perform " Where the Streets Have No Name " to a large crowd of people standing in the streets surrounding the building . Towards the end of the song , the police tell the [MASK]rew tha[MASK] [MASK]he performanc[MASK] is about to be shut down , and ev[MASK]ntually police walk onto the roof while the crowd are booing the police . 
 The video for " Wh[MASK]re the Streets Have No Nam[MASK] " was directed by Meiert Avi[MASK] and produced by Michael Hamlyn and Ben [MASK]ossett . The band attracted over 1 [MASK][MASK]@ 000 people during the video 's filming , which took place o[MASK] the rooftop of a l[MASK]quor store in Downtown Los Angeles on 27 March 1987 [MASK] The band 's perfo[MASK]ma[MASK]ce on a rooft[MASK]p in a public place was a reference to The Beatles ' final concert , as depicted in the film Let I[MASK] Be . 
 During the [MASK]hoot U2 playe[MASK] an eight @-@ [MASK]ong set , which included four performances of "[MASK]Where the Streets Have No [MASK]ame " . Prior to filming , a w[MASK]ek was spent reinforcing the roof of [MASK]he liquor [MASK]tore to ensure it would not collapse if it were to be intruded by a group of fans . A backup generator was put on the[MASK]roof so the sho[MASK]ting could continue in th[MASK] event that the authorities shut off the power on the primary generator , which happened during filmin[MASK] . 
[MASK]The d[MASK]piction of the police[MASK]attempting to shut down the video shoot due to safe[MASK]y concerns actually happened during filming , just as seen in the video . Hamlyn was almost arrested following a confrontation with the police . According to Avis , the events depicted in the video show what actually happened that day " almost in r[MASK]al time " , [MASK]nd that " get[MASK]ing busted was an integral part of the plan . " Band manager Paul McGuinness revealed in 2007 that much of the confrontation with[MASK]the police w[MASK][MASK] exaggerated ; the [MASK]roup were hoping to get shut down by the authorities in order to dramatize the music video , but the police continually gave them extensions for shooting the video . In the backgrou[MASK]d of the video is a sign for The Million Dollar Hotel , which was rebuilt to create some interest , in case no one showed up at the[MASK]film shoot . Although the video is of a live performance , t[MASK]e audio used is from the studio @-@ r[MASK]corded version of the song[MASK]. The video won the Gram[MASK]y Award for Best Perf[MASK]r[MASK]ance Music Vid[MASK]o at the 1989 Grammy Awards . 
 
 = = = B @-@ sides = = = 
 
 " Race Against Time " was released on the 12 @-@ inch[MASK], cassette , and CD versions [MASK]f the single . The song deve[MASK]op[MASK]d from the band 's interest [MASK]n urban funk[MASK], and was described by The Edge as " a kind of Afro @-@ rhythmic piece " and " a s[MASK]udy in rhythm . " The bass riff in the song , inspired by the bodhrán , was played by The[MASK]E[MASK][MASK]e , but stemmed fr[MASK]m some of Clayton 's unused bass p[MASK]rts . Mullen 's drum part was recorded in a single [MASK]ake . The song is primarily an instrumental piece but do[MASK]s contain some lyrics inspired by Bono 's trip to Ethiopia after Live Aid and his witnessing firsthand the famine in occurrence ; these lyrical references include Bono singing in an Ethiopian language and following it with the phrase " Race aga[MASK]nst time " . Bono said of the[MASK]song , " It r[MASK]minds me of the desert . The deser[MASK] is so empty[MASK], but it aches with a strange kind of fullness . " John Hutchinson of Musician magazine descri[MASK]ed the so[MASK]g as having an " African flavour " and as being reminiscent of Peter Gabriel . The track was used in the Miami Vice episode " Child 's Play "[MASK], and is [MASK]he only one of the single 's B @-@ si[MASK]es that was never[MASK]played live . 
 " Silver and Gold "[MASK]was written in support of the Artists United Against [MASK]pa[MASK]theid project , which protested the South African apartheid . In 1985 , Bono participated in Steven Van Zandt 's anti @-@ apartheid Sun City project and [MASK]pent time with Keith[MASK]Richards and Mick Jagger of The Rolling Stones . When Richa[MASK]ds and Jagge[MASK] played blu[MASK]s , Bono was embarrassed by his lack of familiarity with the genre , as most of U[MASK] 's musical know[MASK]edge began with[MASK]punk rock in their youth in th[MASK] mid @-@ 1970s . Bono realised that U2 " had no tradition " , and he felt as if they " were from outer space " . This inspired him to wr[MASK]te the blues @-@ influenced song " Silver and Gold " , which he recorded with Richards and Ronnie Wood . It was re @-@ recorded by U2 for the " Where the Streets Have No Name " single while the band [MASK]eturned to Dublin during in May 1[MASK]87 during a break between the first and second legs [MASK]f The Joshua Tree Tour .[MASK]The song was described by Musician as " tough and raw , with Bono in husky and confident voice , underpinne[MASK][MASK][MASK]y a sinuous bass line , and with The Edge demonstrating his newfound prowess in blues @-@ based guitar . " " Silver and Gold " was played live on The Joshua Tree Tour several times , one performance of which was featured on the band 's 1988 album and rockumentary , Rattle and Hu[MASK] . Both the stu[MASK]io recor[MASK]ing and the Sun City versions [MASK]ere [MASK]ater fea[MASK]ured on the bonus disc of the 20th anniversar[MASK] [MASK]dition of The Joshua Tree . The studio version was also included on the limited edition B @-@ sides bo[MASK]us disk of the band 's first compilati[MASK]n album , The Best of 1980 – 1990 . 
 " Sweetest Thing " was written by Bono as[MASK]an apology to his wife for forgetting h[MASK]r birthday . The s[MASK]ng opens with a [MASK]hort piano piec[MASK] befor[MASK] the rest of the band begins to play . Some of Bono [MASK]s lyr[MASK]cs have been descr[MASK]bed as reminiscent of John Lennon . The Edge descri[MASK]ed it as " a beautiful song ... which is pop as it should be — not produced out of existence , but pop produced with a real intimacy and purity " [MASK] also noting that[MASK]" It 's very new[MASK]for us . " It was re @-@ recorded with some lyrical alterations and released in 1998 as a single in its own right for The Best of 1980 – 1990 .[MASK]Hot Press editor Niall Stokes [MASK]tated that this track , along with " Race Against Time " , is " an indicat[MASK]r of what U2 might have made instead of The Joshua Tree . " 
 
 = = Critical reception [MASK] = 
 
 Upon [MASK]he release of The Joshua Tree , critics praised " Where the Streets Have No Name " . Steve Morse of The Boston Globe noted the " bell @[MASK]@ like tones from the Edge fram [ [MASK] ] a search for heaven "[MASK]and along with the subsequent track on the album , " I Still Haven 't Fo[MASK][MASK]d What I 'm Looking For " , these songs showed how the group were " pilgrims still on a quest ; not preachers who claim to have found answers " . The Bergen Record echoed t[MASK]ese sentiments , saying the tracks demonstrated how the band wa[MASK] on a personal and spirit[MASK]al quest . Rolling Stone called it " as[MASK]ertive rock " i[MASK] their review of The Joshua Tree . The San Diego Union @-@ Tribune said o[MASK] " Where the Streets Have No Na[MASK]e [MASK] , " [MASK]he music ch[MASK]rges , like someone fleeing for life " . The Washingt[MASK]n Post said the track is " a bit oblique lyrically , but the imp[MASK]ica[MASK]ions are [MASK]lear in Bono 's re[MASK]olute delivery[MASK], Dave ( the Edge ) Evan 's quavering guitar , Adam Clay[MASK]on 's cathedral bass and Larry Mullen 's rolling thunder drums " . 
 NME lauded the song as the opening track by saying the album " starts by spitting furiously " . The publication praised Bono 's impassioned singing and The Edge 's guitar playing , which t[MASK]an[MASK]formed the instrument int[MASK] " something more than an endlessly abused piece of wood "[MASK]. The review comme[MASK]ted that th[MASK] " [MASK]ast t[MASK]n seconds are breathtakingly beautiful " . The Rocket wrote that the song builds a " wal[MASK] of sound " that Bono 's vocals[MASK]cut through with[MASK]a " wail[MASK]of desperatio[MASK] , as the lyrics ago[MASK]ize the need for personal spirituality " . The reviewer compared the opening riff to Simple Minds ' " Ghostdancing " . Reviewing The Joshua Tree , Stephen Thomas Erlewine of Allmusic called the song an[MASK]" epic opener " . The service 's Steve Huey , in a review of the song , prai[MASK]ed its " insistent , propulsive rhythmi[MASK] drive and anthemic chorus " [MASK] qualities he singled out for making it [MASK] fan favorite . He called the song the " perfect album @-@ opener " , crediting the " slow build of its arrangement toward a climactic pe[MASK]k " . Huey also called Bono 's delivery " passionate[MASK]and grandiose " and " his commitment to the material unshakable " . He believed the combination of his vocals and the band 's " sonic p[MASK]wer "[MASK]is what gav[MASK] U2 its " tremendous force " . 
 
 = = Live performances = = 
 
 " Where the Streets[MASK]Have No Name " made its concert debut on 2 April 1987 in Tempe , Arizona on the opening[MASK]night of[MASK]The Joshua Tree Tour . It has since been played at nearly every full @-@ length concert that U2 has headlined , total[MASK]ng over 700 performances as of 2011 . The so[MASK]g is widely regarded as one of the group 's most popular live songs . [MASK]o[MASK]o said of it , " We can [MASK]e in the middle of the worst gig in our lives , but when we go into that song , everything changes . The audience is on its feet , singing along with every word . It 's like God sud[MASK]enly wa[MASK]ks through the room . " 
 On The Joshua Tree Tour , " Where the Streets Have No Name " was most often used to open concerts . Fans and critics [MASK]esponded favourably t[MASK] the song in a live setting . The San Diego Union @-@ Tribune wrote that , " From the lof[MASK]y sonic opening strains of [ the song ] , [MASK]his audience was up , ecstatic and infla[MASK]ed . " NME wrote that the song is one such[MASK]occasion where " the power afforded their songs is s[MASK]ary " , noting that during the song 's opening , " the arena [MASK]RUPTS " . In other reviews , the song was ca[MASK]led : " uplifting " , " exhilarating " , and " powerful " . Out[MASK]of the 109 shows during Th[MASK] Joshua Tree Tour , " Streets " was played at all except 12 of the concerts . During the Lovetown Tour which took place in 1989 and the beginning of 1990 , " Streets " was only left out of the set list at one of the 47 concerts . 
 The song was performed at every show on the 1992 – 1993 Zoo TV Tour . Co[MASK]certs from this tour were elaborate multimedia spectacles that Bono performed as a variety of characters , but f[MASK]r the end of the main set , the group reverted to playing classics , including " Whe[MASK]e the Streets Have No Name " , straight . S[MASK]me of these performances of the song were accompanied by footage of the group in the desert from The Joshua Tree 's photo shoot[MASK][MASK] The[MASK]video was speed[MASK]d up for humorous effect — NME described the effect as giving it a " si[MASK]ly , Charlie Chaplin quality " — and Bono often acknowledged his young[MASK]r self on the video screens . This video would make a return du[MASK]ing performances on the 2010 and 2011 legs of the U2 360 ° Tour . Some of the Zoo TV performances of the song had a more electronic dance music arrangement that bore a r[MASK]semblance to the Pet Sh[MASK]p Boys ' synthpop cover of the song ( titled " Where the Streets Have No Name ( I [MASK]an 't Take My Eyes off You ) " ) . Bono parodied this by occasionally adopting the deadpan vocal style used in the Pet Shop Boys ' co[MASK]er . Critics welcomed the song in the group 's setlist : The Independent sai[MASK] the song " induces instant eup[MASK]or[MASK]a , as U2 do what they 're best at , slipping into epic rock mode , playing music made for the arena " . In tw[MASK] other local newspaper reviews , critics praised the song 's inclusion in a sequence of greatest hits . 
 For the P[MASK]pMart Tour of 1997 – 1998 ,[MASK][MASK]2 returned to the electronic dance arrangement they occasionally played on the Zoo TV Tour . The set 's massive video screen[MASK]displaye[MASK] a video that Hot[MASK]Press described as an " astonishing , 2001 @-@ style trip into[MASK]the heart of a swirling , psychedelic tunnel that suc[MASK]s the audience in towards a horizonta[MASK] monolith " . Near the end of the song , peace doves w[MASK]re shown on the screen a[MASK]d bright beams of light flanking the set 's golden arch were projected upwards . Hot Press said [MASK]he effect transfor[MASK]ed the stadi[MASK]m into a " UFO[MASK]landing[MASK]site " . 
 Shortly before the third leg of the Elevation Tour , the September 11 attacks occurred in New Y[MASK]rk City and Washington D.C. During the band 's first show in[MASK]New York[MASK]Ci[MASK]y following the attacks , the band performe[MASK] " Where the Streets Have No Name " , an[MASK] when the stage lights illuminated the audience , th[MASK] band saw [MASK]ears st[MASK]eaming down the faces of m[MASK]ny fans . The experience was one inspiration for the song " City of Blinding Lights " . The [MASK]and paid tribute to the 9 / 11 victims during their performance of the song[MASK]at the Supe[MASK] Bowl XXXVI [MASK]alftime show on 3 February 2002 . The performance featured the names of the September 11 victims projected onto a large white banner behind the band . U2 's appeara[MASK]ce was later ranked number 1 on Sports Illustrated 's list of " Top 10 Super [MASK]owl Halftime Shows " . 
 For the Vertigo Tou[MASK] , the group originally considered dropping the song from their setlists , but Mullen and Clayton successfully ar[MASK]ued against th[MASK]s . All 131 of the Vertigo Tour concerts featured a[MASK]performance of the song , which were accompanied by the stag[MASK] 's LED video curtains displaying African flags . On the tour 's ope[MASK]ing[MASK]night , this reminded Bono that he ha[MASK] originally written the lyrics in an Ethiopian village . He thought this visual accompaniment made the son[MASK] come full circle , saying [MASK] " And here it was , nearly twenty years later , coming back to Africa , all the stuff about parched lands and deserts making sense for the first time . " The song was also played at the preview screening of the band 's c[MASK]ncert film U2 3D at the 2007 Cannes Film Festival[MASK]. At the Glastonbury Festival 2010 , The Ed[MASK]e [MASK]ccompanied rock band Muse for a live cover version of the track , later playing it with U2 [MASK]hile headlining Glastonbury in 2011 . 
 Live performances of " Where the Streets Have[MASK]No Name " appear in the concert video releases Rattle and Hum , Zoo TV : Live from Sydney , and PopMart : Live from Mexico City , as well as the respective a[MASK]dio releases of the [MASK]atter two concerts , Zoo TV Live[MASK]and Hasta la Vista Baby ! U2 Live from Mexico City . A second version from th[MASK] PopMart Tour was featured on Please : PopHeart Live EP , and later on the U.S. " P[MASK]ease " single . A live recording from Boston during the Elevation Tour was featured i[MASK] the concert film Elevation 2001 : Liv[MASK][MASK]from Boston , and o[MASK] the " Walk On " and " Electrical [MASK]torm " singles . The concert video and album U2 Go Home : Live fr[MASK]m Slane Castle , Ireland featured another performance from the Elevation Tour , and later performances were featur[MASK]d in the concert films Vertigo 2005 : Live from Chicago a[MASK]d U2 3D ( Vertigo Tour ) , and U2 360 ° at the Rose Bowl ( U2 360 ° Tour ) . The 2004[MASK]digital album , Live from the Point Depot , contains a performance from the Lovetown Tour[MASK], only available as part of The Complete U2 digital box set . 
 
 = = Legacy = = 
 
 In 2002 , Q magazine named " Where the Streets Have No Name " the 16th- " most exciting tune ever " [MASK] The following year , Q ranked the song at[MASK]number 459 in a special edition titled " 1001 Best Son[MASK]s Ever " . Three y[MASK]ars later , the magazine 's readers voted t[MASK]e track the 43rd @-@ greatest song in history . Rolling Stone ranked the song at number 28 on its list of the " 100 Greatest Guitar So[MASK]gs of All Time . " In a 2010 poll by fan site @ U2 , approximately 29 % of 4 @,@ 800 respondents named " Where the Streets Have No[MASK]Name " as their favo[MASK]rite song from The Joshua Tree , [MASK]anking it as the [MASK]ost popu[MASK]ar song from the album . In 2010 , American sports network ESPN used the t[MASK]ack , among other U2 [MASK]ongs , in commercials for the 2010 FIFA World Cup , with the South African Soweto Gospel Choi[MASK] adding vocals to the song . The advertisem[MASK]nt , titled "[MASK]Robben Island " , portrays South African political prisoners during the apartheid era formi[MASK]g a soccer team . There are plans[MASK]to bring a recording of the Soweto @-@ supported performance to retail[MASK]. C[MASK]mposer John M[MASK]ckey used the intro[MASK]uctory guitar theme i[MASK] his 2009 piece for wind ensemble , Aurora Awakes . The song 's int[MASK]oduction [MASK]as used by the Vancouver Canucks hockey team at the start each of t[MASK]eir home games [MASK] when the players take to the ice . The Baltimore Ravens a[MASK]so use the song as the[MASK] enter M & T Bank Stadium before home games . The Marquette Golden Eagles men 's basketball team uses this song in their entran[MASK]e video before all home games at the BMO Har[MASK]is Bradley Center . The s[MASK]ng is also used by the [MASK]isconsin Badgers footba[MASK]l team for their entrance video at Camp Randall Stadium prior t[MASK] all home games . Th[MASK] Kansas Jayhawks men 's basketball team us[MASK]s the song during their start[MASK]ng[MASK]lineups at Allen Fieldhouse .

 = Nazarov c[MASK]clization rea[MASK]tion = 
 
 The Nazarov cyclization reaction ( often referred to as simply the Nazarov cyclization ) is a chemical reaction used[MASK]in organic chemistry for the [MASK][MASK]nthesis of cyclopentenones[MASK]. The reaction[MASK]is typically divided into classical and modern variants , depending on the reagents and substrates employed .[MASK]It was o[MASK]i[MASK]inally discovered by Ivan Nikolaev[MASK]ch Nazar[MASK]v ( 1906 – 1957[MASK]) in 1941 while study[MASK]ng the rea[MASK]rangements of al[MASK]yl vin[MASK]l ketones . 
 As originally des[MASK]ribed , the Nazarov cyclization involves [MASK]he activation of a divinyl ketone using a stoichiometric Lewis acid or protic ac[MASK]d promoter .[MASK]The key st[MASK]p of the reaction mechanism involves a cationic 4π @-@ electrocyclic r[MASK]ng closure which forms the cyclopen[MASK]enone product ( See Mechanism below[MASK]) . As the reaction has been deve[MASK]oped , variants i[MASK]volving substrates other than divinyl [MASK]etones and promoters other than Lewis acids have been subsumed under the name Nazarov cyclization provided that they follow a similar m[MASK]chanistic pathwa[MASK] . 
 The success of the Nazarov cyclization as a tool in organic synth[MASK]sis stems from the utility and ubiquity of cyclopentenones as both motifs in natural products ( including[MASK]jasmone , the aflatoxins , and a sub[MASK]lass of prostaglandins ) and as useful synthetic intermediates for total [MASK]ynthesis . The re[MASK]ction has[MASK]been used in several total syntheses and several revie[MASK]s ha[MASK]e been published . 
 
 = =[MASK]Mechanism = = 
 
 The mechanism of the classical Nazarov cyclization reaction was first demonstrated experimentally by Shoppe to be an intramolecular electrocycliza[MASK]ion and is outline[MASK] below . Activation of the ketone by the acid catalyst generates a pentadienyl cat[MASK]on which undergoes a thermally al[MASK]owed 4π conrotatory electrocyclizatio[MASK] as dictated by the Woodward @-@ Hoffman rules . This generates an oxyallyl cation which undergoes an elimination reaction to lose a β @-@ hydrogen .[MASK]Subsequent tautomeriza[MASK]ion of the enolate produces the cyclopentenone prod[MASK]ct . 
 [MASK]s noted above [MASK] variant[MASK] t[MASK]at deviate from [MASK]his template are known ; what designates a Nazarov cyclization in particular is the g[MASK]nerat[MASK]on of the pentadienyl cation followed by [MASK]lectrocyclic ring closure to an oxyallyl cation . In order to achieve this transformation , the molecule must be in the s @-@[MASK]trans /[MASK]s @-@ trans conformation , placing the vinyl groups in an appropriate orientation . The prop[MASK]nsity of the [MASK]ystem to enter this conformation dramatically influences reaction rate , with α @-@ substituted substrates having an increased population of the requisite conform[MASK]r due to allylic strain . Coordin[MASK]tion of an electron donatin[MASK] α @-@ substituent by the catalyst can likewise increase the react[MASK]on rate by enforcing th[MASK]s conformatio[MASK] . 
 Similarly , β [MASK]-@ substitution directed inward restricts the s @-@ trans conformation so severely that E @-@ Z isomeri[MASK][MASK]tion has been shown to occur in adva[MASK]ce of cycliza[MASK]ion on a wide range of substrates , yielding the trans cyclopentenone regardless of initial config[MASK]ration . In this way , the Nazarov cyclization is a rare example of a stereo[MASK]elective pericyclic reaction , whereas[MASK]most electrocyclizations are stereospe[MASK]ific . The example bel[MASK]w[MASK]uses triethylsilyl hydride to [MASK]rap the oxyallyl cation so [MASK]hat [MASK]o elimination occurs . ( See Int[MASK]rrupted cyclizations below ) 
 Along this same vein , allenyl vinyl ketones of the type studied extensively by Marcus Tius of the University of Hawaii sho[MASK] dramatic rate acceleration due to the remov[MASK]l of β [MASK]-@ hydrogens , obviating a large amount of steric strain in the s @-@ cis conformer . 
 
[MASK]= = Classical Nazarov cyclizations = = 
 
 Though cyclizatio[MASK]s[MASK]following the general templat[MASK] above had [MASK]een observed prior to Nazarov '[MASK] involvement , it was his[MASK]s[MASK]ud[MASK] of the rearrangements of allyl vinyl [MASK]etones that [MASK]arked the first major examination of this process . Nazarov correctly reasoned that the allylic olefin isomerized in situ to form a divinyl ketone before ring closure to the cyclopen[MASK]enone product . The rea[MASK]tion shown below involves an alkyne oxyme[MASK]curation reaction to generate the requisite[MASK]ke[MASK]one . 
 [MASK]esearch involving the reaction[MASK]was relatively quiet in subsequent years , until in the mid @-@ 1980s when several synthes[MASK]s employing the Nazarov cyc[MASK]ization were published . Shown below are key steps in the syntheses of [MASK]richodiene and Nor [MASK]-@ Sterepolide[MASK], the latter of which is thought to proceed via an unusual alkyne @-@ allene isomerization that generates the divinyl ketone . 
 
 = = = Shortcomings = = = 
 
 The cl[MASK]ssical version of the Nazarov cyclization suffers from several drawbacks which modern var[MASK]ants attempt to circumvent . The first two are not e[MASK]ident from the mechanism alone , but are indicative[MASK]of the barriers to cyclization ; the last three stem from sele[MASK]tivity issues relating to elimination and protonation of the interm[MASK]diate .[MASK]
 Strong Lewis or protic acids are typically required for the reaction ( e.g. TiCl4[MASK], B[MASK]3 , MeSO3H ) . These promoters are not compatible with sensitive functional groups , limiting the substrate scop[MASK] . 
 Despite the mechanistic possibility [MASK]or catalys[MASK]s , multi[MASK]le equiva[MASK]ents [MASK]f the promoter are often required in order to effect th[MASK][MASK]reaction . This limits the atom[MASK]economy of the reaction . 
 The elimination step is not regioselective ; if multiple β @-@ hydrogens are av[MASK]ilable for eli[MASK]ination , various products a[MASK]e often observed as mixtures . This is highly undesirable from an efficiency standpoint as [MASK]rduous separation [MASK]s typically required . 
 Elimination destroys a potential stereocenter , decreasing the potentia[MASK] usefulness of the reaction . 
 Protonation of the enolate is sometimes not stereoselective , meaning [MASK]hat products can b[MASK] formed as mixtures of epimers . 
 
 = = Modern variants = = 
 
 The shortcomings noted above limit[MASK]the usefulness of the Nazarov cyclization reaction in its canonical form . However , modifications to the reaction f[MASK]cused on remedying its issues continue to be an ac[MASK]ive area of academic research . In particular , the research has focused o[MASK][MASK]a few key areas : rendering the reaction catalyti[MASK] in the promoter , effecti[MASK]g the[MASK]reaction with more mild promoters to improve functional group tolerance , directing the regioselectivity of the elimination step , and improving the overal[MASK] stereoselectivity . These have been suc[MASK]essful to varying degrees . 
 Additionally , modifications focused on altering the progress of the reaction , either by generating the pentadienyl cati[MASK]n in an unorthodox fashion or by having the oxya[MASK]lyl cation " intercepted " in various ways . Furthermore , enantioselecti[MASK]e variants of various kin[MASK]s h[MASK]ve been developed . The sheer volume of literature on the subject prevents a comprehensive examination of this [MASK]ield ; key examples are given below .[MASK]
 
 = = = Silicon @-@ direct[MASK]d cyclization = = = 
 
 T[MASK]e earliest efforts to improve the se[MASK]ectivity of the Nazarov cyclization took advantage of the β @-@ silicon effect in order to dire[MASK]t the regioselectivity of the elimination step . This [MASK]hemistry was developed most extensively[MASK]b[MASK] Professor Scott Denmark of the University of Illinois , Urbana @-@ Champ[MASK]ign in the mid @-@ 1[MASK]80s and u[MASK]ilizes stoichiometric [MASK]mounts of iron trichloride to promote the [MASK]eact[MASK]on . W[MASK]th bicyclic produc[MASK]s , the cis isomer was selected for to varying [MASK]egrees . 
 The silicon @-@ directed Nazarov cyclization reaction was subsequen[MASK]ly empl[MASK]yed in the synthesis of the natural pr[MASK]duct Silphinene [MASK] shown below . The cyclization t[MASK]kes place before e[MASK]imination of the benzyl alcohol moiety , so that the resulting stereochemistry of the newly formed ring a[MASK]ises from approac[MASK][MASK]of the silyl alk[MASK]ne anti to the ether . 
 
 = = = Polarization = = = 
 
 Draw[MASK]ng on [MASK]he substituent effects compiled over various trials of the reaction , Professor Alison Frontier of the Univers[MASK]ty of Rochester developed [MASK] paradigm for " polarized " Nazarov cyclizations in which electron donating and electron withdrawing groups are used to improve the overall selectivity of the reaction[MASK]. Creation of an effective vinyl nucleophile and vinyl [MASK]lectrophile in the substrate al[MASK]ows catalytic activation with copper triflate and regioselective elimi[MASK]a[MASK]ion[MASK]. In addition , the electron withdrawing group increases the acidity of the α @[MASK]@ proton , allowing[MASK]selective formation of th[MASK] trans @[MASK]@ α @-@ epimer via equilibration . 
 It is often possi[MASK]le to achieve catalytic activation us[MASK]ng a donating[MASK]or withdraw[MASK]ng group alone , although the efficiency of the reaction ( yield , reaction time , etc . ) is typically lower . 
 
[MASK]= = = Alternative cati[MASK]n generation = = = 
 
 By exten[MASK]ion , any pentadienyl cation regardles[MASK] of its origin is capable of undergoing a Nazarov cyclization . There have [MASK]een a large number of e[MASK]amples published w[MASK]ere the requisite cation is arrived at by a variety of rearrangements . One such example involves th[MASK] silver catalyzed ca[MASK]ionic ring opening of allylic d[MASK]chloro cylopropanes . The silver salt facilitate[MASK] lo[MASK]s of chloride via precipitation of insoluble silver chloride . 
 In the total synthesis of rocaglamide , epoxidation of a vinyl alkoxyallenyl stann[MASK]ne likewise generates [MASK] pentadienyl cation via ring opening of the resultant epoxide . 
 
 = = = Interru[MASK]ted cyclization = = = 
 
 Once the cyclization has occurred , an oxyallyl cation is formed [MASK] As discussed extensively above , the typica[MASK] course for this intermediate is elimination followed by enolate tautomerization . Howev[MASK]r , these two steps can be interrupted by various [MASK]ucleophiles and electrophiles , respectively . Oxyallyl cati[MASK]n trapping has been developed extensively by Fredrick G.[MASK]West of the University of Alber[MASK]a and his review covers the field . The oxyallyl cation can be trapped with heteroatom and carbon nucleophiles and can also undergo cationic cycloadditions with various te[MASK]hered partners . Shown below is a cascade reaction in which successive cation tra[MASK]ping g[MASK]nerates a pentacyclic core in one step with complete diastereoselectivity . 
 Enolate trapping w[MASK]th various electrophiles is decidedly less [MASK]ommon . In on[MASK] study , the Nazarov cyclization is paired with a Michael r[MASK]action using an iridi[MASK]m ca[MASK]alyst[MASK]to initia[MASK]e nucleophilic conjugate addition of the enolate to β @-@ [MASK]itrostyrene . In this tandem[MASK]reaction the[MASK]iridium catalyst is required for both conversions : it acts as the Lewis acid [MASK]n the Nazarov cyclization and in the next step the nit[MASK]o group [MASK]f nitrostyrene first [MASK]oordinates to iridium in a ligand exchange with the carbonyl ester oxygen atom before the actual Michael addition takes place to the opposite [MASK]ace of the R @-@ group . 
 
 = = = Enantioselective variants = = [MASK] 
 
 The development of an enantioselecti[MASK]e Nazarov cyclization is a desirable addition to the repe[MASK]toire of Nazarov cyc[MASK]ization reactions . To that end , several[MASK]variations have b[MASK]en developed utilizing chiral auxiliaries and chiral catalysts . Diastereoselective cyclizations are also known , in which extant ste[MASK]eocenters direct the [MASK]yclization . Almost all of the attemp[MASK]s are based on the idea o[MASK] torquoselectivity ; selecting one direction for the vinyl groups to " rotate " in turn sets [MASK]he stereochemistry as shown below . 
 Silicon @-@ directed Nazarov cyclizations can exhibit induced dias[MASK]ereoselectiv[MASK]ty in this way . In the example below , the silyl @-@ group acts to d[MASK]rect the cyclization by preventing the distant alkene from rotating " towards " it via unfavorabl[MASK][MASK]steric interaction . In this way the[MASK]silicon acts as a traceless auxiliary [MASK] ( The starting material is not e[MASK]antiopure but the retention of enantiomeric excess s[MASK]ggests that the auxiliary dire[MASK]ts the cyclization . ) 
 Tius 's allenyl substrates can exhibit axial to tetr[MASK]hedral chirality transfer if enantiopure allenes are used . The example below genera[MASK]es a chiral diosphenpol in 64 % yield an[MASK] 95 % enantiomeric excess . 
 Tius has additionally developed a cam[MASK]hor @-@ based auxiliary for achiral allenes tha[MASK] was employed in the first asymmetric[MASK]synthesis of roseophilin . The key step em[MASK]loys an unusual mixt[MASK]re of hexafluoro @-@ 2 @-@ propa[MASK][MASK]l and trifluoroethanol as sol[MASK]ent . 
 The first chiral Lew[MASK]s acid promoted asymmetric Nazarov cyclization was reported by Varinder Aggarwal and utilized copper ( II ) bisoxazoline ligand complexes with up to 98 % ee . The enantiomeric excess was [MASK]naffected by use o[MASK] 50 mol % of the copp[MASK]r compl[MASK]x but the yi[MASK]ld was s[MASK]gnificantly decreased . 
 
 = = Related Reactions = = 
 
 Extensions of the Nazarov c[MASK]clization are generally also subsumed under the same name . For example , an α @-@ β , γ @-@ δ unsaturated ketone can undergo a similar cationic conrotatory cyclization that is typically referr[MASK]d to as an iso @-@ Nazarov cyclization reaction . Other such extensions have been gi[MASK]en similar names , including homo @-@ Nazarov cyclizations and vinylogous Nazarov cyclizations . 
 
 = = = Retro @-@ Nazarov reaction = = = 
 
 Because they overstabilize the pe[MASK]tadienyl[MASK]cation , β @-@ electron do[MASK]ating substiuents[MASK]often severely impede Nazarov cyclization . Build[MASK]ng from this , several electrocyclic ring openings of β @-@ alkoxy cyclopentanes have been reported . Thes[MASK] are typically referred to as retro @-@ Nazarov cycli[MASK]ation reactions . 
 
 = = = I[MASK]ino @-@ Nazarov reaction = = = 
 
 Nit[MASK]og[MASK]n analogues of the Nazarov cyclization reaction ( known as imino @-@ Nazarov cyclization reactions ) have few instances ; there is one example of a generalized imino @-@ Nazarov[MASK]cyclization reported ( shown below ) , and several iso @-@ imino @-@ Nazarov reactions in the litera[MASK]ure .[MASK]Even these tend to suffer from poor stereoselectivity , poor yields , or narrow sc[MASK]pe . The difficulty stems from the relative over @-@ stabiliz[MASK]tion of the pentadienyl cation by electron donation , impeding cyclization . 
 
 
 = Horribl[MASK] Bosses = 
 
 Horrible Bosses is a 2011 American black come[MASK]y film directed by Seth G[MASK]rdon , written by Michael Markowitz , John Francis Daley and Jonathan Goldstein , based on a story by Markowitz . It stars Jason Bateman , Charlie Day , Jason Sudeikis [MASK] Jennifer Aniston , Col[MASK]n Farrell , Kevin Spacey , and [MASK]amie Fox[MASK] . T[MASK]e plot follows three friends , played b[MASK] Bateman , Day , and Sudeikis , who decide to murder th[MASK]ir respectiv[MASK] overbearing [MASK] abusive[MASK]bosses , po[MASK]trayed by Spacey , Aniston and Farrell . 
 Markowitz 's script was bought by New Line Cinema in 2005 and the film spent six years in various states of pre @-@ production , with a variety of actors attached to diffe[MASK]ent roles . By 2010 , Goldstein and Daley had [MASK]ewritten the script , and[MASK]the film finally went into produc[MASK]ion . 
 The film premiered in Los Angeles on Jun[MASK] 30 , 2011 , and received a wide release on July 8 , 2011 . The film exceed[MASK]d financi[MASK]l expectations ,[MASK]accruing over $ 28 million in the first three days , making it the number two f[MASK]lm in the United States d[MASK]ring its opening weekend , and[MASK]going[MASK]on to become the highest @-@ grossing black comedy film of all time in unadjusted dollars , breaking the record previously set by The Wa[MASK] [MASK]f the R[MASK]ses in 1990 . The [MASK]ilm grossed over $ 2[MASK]9 million worldwide during its theatrical run . 
 The film opened to positive critical reception , with several critics praising[MASK]the ensemble cast , with each lead being singled out for their performances across reviews . The plot receive[MASK] a more mixed response ; some reviewers felt that its dark , humorous premise was explored well , wh[MASK]le others felt the jokes were racist [MASK] homoph[MASK]bi[MASK] , and misogynistic . A sequel , Horrible Bosses 2 , was released on November 26 , 2014 . 
 
 = = Plot = = 
 
 Nick Hendricks ( Bateman ) a[MASK]d Dale Arbus ( Day ) are friends [MASK]ho despise their bosses[MASK]. Nick works at a financial firm for the sadistic David Harken ( Spacey ) , who implies the possibility of a [MASK]romotion for Nick for m[MASK]nths , o[MASK]ly to award it to himself . Dale is a dental assistant being sexually harassed by his boss , [MASK]r. Julia Harris ([MASK]Aniston ) ; she threatens to tell his fiancee Stacy ( Lindsay Sloane ) that he had sex with her unless he actually has sex with her . Nick and Dale 's accountant friend Kurt Buckman ( Sudeikis [MASK] enjoys working for Jack Pellitt ( Donald Sutherland ) at a che[MASK]ic[MASK]l company , but after Jack unexpectedly [MASK]ies of a heart attack , the company is taken over by Jack 's cocaine @-@ addicted son Bobby[MASK]( Farrell ) , whose apathy and incompetence threaten the future of the company . 
 At night[MASK][MASK] over drinks , Kurt jokingly su[MASK]gests that their lives would be happier if their bosses w[MASK]re no longer around . Initially hesitant , they eventu[MASK]lly agree to kill their [MASK]mployers . In search [MASK]f a hitman , the trio meet Dean " Motherfuckah " Jones ( Foxx ) , an ex @-@ con who agrees to be their " m[MASK]rder consultant " . Jones suggests that Dale , Kurt and Nick k[MASK]ll each [MASK]ther 's boss[MASK]s to hide their motiv[MASK] while making the de[MASK]ths lo[MASK]k like accidents . 
 The three reconnoiter Bobby 's house , a[MASK]d Kurt st[MASK]als Bobby 's phone . They next go to [MASK]arken[MASK]'s house , where Kurt and Nick go inside while Dale waits in the car . Harken returns home and confronts Dale for littering , but then has [MASK]n allergy attack from the peanut butter on the litter . Dale saves Harken by stabbing him with an EpiPen . Nick and Kurt think Dale is stabbing Harken to death and flee , with Kurt accidentally dropping Bobby[MASK]'s phone in Harken 's bedroom [MASK] The next night , Kurt watches Julia 's home , but she seduces and ha[MASK] sex with[MASK]him[MASK]. Nick and Dale reluctantly wait outside Bobby 's and Harken 's [MASK]ouses , respecti[MASK]ely , to co[MASK]mit the m[MASK]rders , despite neither of them wanting to . Harken discovers Bobby 's cellphone in his be[MASK]room and uses it to find his address , suspecting his wife Rhonda ( Julie Bowen ) is having an affair .[MASK]He drives over and kills Bobby , with Nick as a secret witness . 
 Nick flees at high speed , setting off a traffic camera . The trio meet to discuss their reservations about continuing with their plan . They are arrested by the police , who believe the camera footage makes them suspects in Bobby 's murder . Lacking evidence , the police are forced to[MASK]let the trio go f[MASK]ee . The trio consult with Jones again , but learn that he never actually killed anyone , h[MASK]ving been imprisoned for[MASK]bootlegging the film Snow Falling o[MASK] Cedars . Jones suggests that they get Harken to co[MASK]fess and secretly tape it . The three accidentally crash Harken 's surprise birthday party , where Nick and Dale get Harken to confess to the murder[MASK]before realizing that Kurt , who has the a[MASK]dio recorder , is else[MASK]here having sex with Rhonda . Harken threate[MASK]s to kill all three for attempting to blackmail him . They flee by car , but Harken gives[MASK]chase and repeatedly rams their vehicle . Believing they have committed a crime , the car 's navigation @-@ system operator remotely di[MASK]ables Kurt 's car , allow[MASK]n[MASK] Harken[MASK]to catch and hold them at gunpoint . Harken shoots himself in the l[MASK]g as he boasts about his plan to frame them for murdering Bobby and attempting to kill [MASK]im to get rid of the witness . 
 The police arrest Nick , Dale and Kurt , but t[MASK]e navigation @-@ syst[MASK]m operator , Gregory , reve[MASK]ls that it is his companies policy to record all conversations for quality assur[MASK]nce . Gregory plays th[MASK] tape that has Harken confessing he murdered Pellitt . Harken is sentenced to 25 years [MASK]o life in prison , whil[MASK] the friends get their charges waived . Nick is promoted to president of the company under a sadist[MASK]c CEO , Kurt retains hi[MASK] job under a new boss , and Dale blackmails[MASK]Julia i[MASK]to ending her harassment by convincing her to sexually[MASK]har[MASK]ss a supposed[MASK]y unconscious patient , while Jones secretly records the act .
